title: AI-Driven Enzyme Engineering for PFAS Degradation Using Protein LLM, Expression Classifier, and Cell-Free Expression
abstract: PFAS, or "forever chemicals," are toxic compounds linked to cancers, infertility, and vaccine resistance at concentrations below 1 ppt. The IEA iGEM team is employing AI to design enzymes that break down PFAS through a four-step process: 1. Using protein large language models (pLLMs) and a new enzyme classifier to generate novel PFAS-degrading enzymes. 2. Computationally validating the predicted catalytic activity of these enzymes against PFAS. 3. Assessing the expressibility of the enzymes in a cell-free system to ensure feasibility for lab testing, and as input for a expression classifier that we design. 4. Expressing enzymes successfully, and then sent to a specialized lab to confirm PFAS degradation activity. By combining AI-driven protein design with experimental validation, our approach seeks to provide an efficient and cost-effective solution to combat the environmental and health risks posed by PFAS.
nominations: Best Integrated Human Practices, High School
advisors: Alec Lourenco, Galia Bar-Sever, Jason, Vikki Adams
students: Camille, Jael Santos, Lucas Garcia, MayaK, Ray Chung, Troy Reyes, Willow

title: SONG-H: a modular therapeutic platform for tissue healing using cell-based regenerative medicine and gene therapy.
abstract: Burn injuries are devastating wounds associated with serious complications including infection, disfiguring scarring, and contractures which require intensive medical intervention to alleviate their physical and psychological impact. This year, we are tackling this challenge by developing SONG-H (Stem cell-based Occlusive Nutritive Gel of Healing). Our approach is based on promoting the SCs' regenerative capacities and enhancing the healing process of non-regenerative tissues besides using hyaluronic acid (HA) hydrogel as a scaffold for topical delivery. We integrated two modular devices to control our therapeutic approach. Firstly, we've designed a novel programmable receptor that is specific and sensitive to the Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) within the burn microenvironment, which triggers conditioned expression of Yes-Associated Protein (YAP-1) that regulates the differentiation and proliferation rate of SCs. Secondly, we utilized SCs' exosomal signaling ability to deliver YAP-1 transcripts within our Translation Initiation Device (TID) modular protein-based switch.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, Undergrad+Safety and Security Award, Undergrad

title: Heartecho: A cancer screening kit for post-myocardial infarction patients
abstract: Patients with cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) such as myocardial infarction (MI) have an increased risk of developing cancer. The emerging research field of reverse cardio-oncology demonstrates that multiple cardiovascular diseases including MI could promote cancer progression. To identify MI patients at risk of developing cancer, we designed a screening kit Heartecho that employs a Loop-Initiated RNA Activator (LIRA)-based system to detect microRNAs that are both highly expressed in MI patients and capable of promoting cancer. We employed bioinformatics methods to identify two microRNAs, miR-142-3p and miR-210-3p, as optimal biomarkers, and designed LIRAs that target these two microRNAs. Finally, we chose chromogenic method to show results visibly. The detection liquid will change color from yellow to purple to indicate the presence of these two microRNAs in the samples. As a new detection system, Heartecho provides a rapid and simple way to help MI patients aware of risk of cancer.
nominations: Best Diagnostics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Model, Undergrad+Best Education, Undergrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad

title: SERENE: Bringing serenity into your lives!
abstract: In today's fast-paced society, stress and busy lifestyles often lead to persistent negative emotions, which can result in serious consequences such as depression, impacting millions worldwide. To address this issue, we are developing a comprehensive approach that enhances emotional awareness through our stress management app, Pokefish, while also designing genetically modified probiotics to synthesize 5-HTP (5-Hydroxytryptophan), thereby boosting serotonin production in the body. Our innovative strategy involves expressing the necessary enzymes and coenzymes and utilizing scaffolding techniques to optimize 5-HTP production. To increase accessibility, we will deliver these probiotics in an edible film attached to beverage seals, making it easy for individuals to incorporate them into their daily routines. By providing an effective and holistic solution, we aim to improve mood and enhance overall quality of life.
PIs: Chun Ying Yu, Ching HUNG, Ching-Chieh Weng

title: ResiSense - A rapid point-of-care test kit for detecting bacterial antibiotic resistance genes
abstract: Bacterial antibiotic resistance, exacerbated by antibiotic misuse and overuse, has become a global health crisis responsible for millions of deaths, particularly in underdeveloped areas. However, current diagnostic strategies require highly-trained personnel and expensive on-site equipment, which are often infeasible in low-resource settings. To help alleviate these challenges, we propose ResiSense, a cell-free point-of-care strategy tailored to rapidly detect bacterial antibiotic resistance genes. In the presence of a targeted resistance gene, a selected G-quadruplex DNAzyme will be produced from a strategically designed DNA template by rolling circle amplification (RCA). The DNAzyme oxidises colourless tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) into blue TMB?, resulting in colourimetric detection. As a proof of concept, we generated a non-infectious Escherichia coli strain containing a short snippet of blaKPC2, an antibiotic resistance gene derived from Klebsiella pneumoniae, and we successfully detected the gene via the RCA-generated DNAzyme. ResiSense represents a rapid and economical technology that could accurately detect antibiotic resistance.
nominations: Best Education, Undergrad
PIs: Jacky Chi Ki Ngo, Jonathan Choi
instructors: Bryan Lee, Chun Fung WU, Joankett Wong, Kelly Lam

title: ?Digiworm?Smart Dental Braces for Cardiovascular Monitoring
abstract: Cardiovascular disease, causing 18 million deaths annually worldwide and 23000 deaths in Taiwan in 2022, poses a significant public health challenge.To address this, our project focuses on an innovative solution including a detection kit, smart braces, and an app. First, a biosensor detects cardiac biomarker levels which are protein and microRNA. A color change in the kit correlates with its concentration, changing the shade of yellow. Patients photograph the result with the Digiworm app, which analyzes the color and the risk. If a high risk is detected, the smart braces activate via infrared light. These braces contain engineered E. coli that produce Lumbrokinase when stimulated by an LED light. Our approach aims to enhance early diagnosis and treatment, potentially saving lives, improving quality of life for patients, and reducing overall healthcare inequality.
instructors: SHIANG-SHIN GAU, Tzu-Yun Wang, Yu-Ling Wu

title: micellaway - Bioremediation of PAHs
abstract: In our project "micellaway," we aim to address riverine oil pollutions which, while less publicized than marine oil spills, occure more frequently. Freshwater oil spills often lead to the formation of oil in water emulsions, which make conventional cleanup methods less effective. A particular concern are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), toxic and carcinogenic components of oil that pose significant threats to ecosystems. Therefor, we want to bioremediate PAHs using synthetic biology. Our chosen bioremediation chassis is Pseudomonas vancouverensis DSM8368, which naturally degrades three PAHs, naphthalene, fluorene and phenanthrene. We genetically introduced nine enzyme coding sequences into this chassis. Creating a metabolic pathway, which channels pyrene degradation into the native phenanthrene degradation pathway. To ensure biosafety, the modified bacteria will be immobilized inside a device, which can be installed at target sides in rivers. Polluted water and native bacteria will pass it, giving our chassis the opportunity to break down PAHs.
nominations: Best Bioremediation Project, Overgrad+Best New Basic Part, Overgrad
advisors: Christian Hake
students: Alexander Fabrin, Beyza Demirel, Caroline Schmidt, Florian Weiß, Julian Kuhn, Luan Luca Chambron Pinho, Richard Meuten, Samer Bacha, Sven Nachtigal, Ximena Arana

title: Plastid-mediated RNA interference achieves efficient control of agricultural pests
abstract: As the main pest of tobacco, Calyptogramma has a serious impact on the yield and quality of tobacco.HUBU-China exploited RNAi's mechanism of action to induce complementary mRNA degradation leading to gene silencing in the important lepidopteran pest Spodoptera litura.Tobacco plastid is designed as a delivery system capable of expressing both the VLP protein shell and the chitin synthase gene.Firstly,expressing a large number of artificial microRNA (dsRNA) of the chitin synthase gene necessary for the growth of Spodoptera litura, which can enter the cytoplasm after Spodoptera liturae eats tobacco.Additionally, Argonaute proteins (AGOs) assemble these siRNAs to form RNA-induced silencing complexes (RISCs) that mediates the degradation of endogenous mRNA complementary to its guide strand, so that the chitin synthase gene cannot be expressed.As a result, lepidopteran peststo can be control efficiently.We hope that this delivery system can make a difference in disrupting insect development.
PIs: Zhifan Yang, Sheng Yang, Shengchun Li, Haimou Zhang, Kim, Longhai Dai, Yangyong, Yumei Hu
advisors: Ali Raza Ishaq, Asfand
students: Baichuan Jiang, Binyu Guo, Cankai Yu, Jiahui Huang, Jialin Jiang, Jiawen Shi, Ke Li, Ken Chen, Maosen Bai, Siyu Zhou, Wanting Yang, Xiang Li, Xianyi Ke, Xingsha Wu, Xinyi Li, Xinyi Sun, Yang Liu, Yanxi Zhou, Yina Li, Yingshui Xie, Yuhuan Chun, Yuxin Liu, Yuxin Xiao, Zihao Wan, Zining Huang

title: ScanCer: A FRET-Based Biosensor Targeting ATP Concentration for High-Throughput Breast Cancer Drug Discovery
abstract: Breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths in women, with 2.3 million cases and 670,000 deaths in 2022 (WHO). Our project aims to find drugs that are highly targeted to the cancer cells, helping to improve patient survival. For this reason, the team wanted to improve the screening methodology to efficiently screen high-throughput drug libraries. Our team decided to use mBaoJin and Aquamarine as fluorescent pairs to design a FRET-based biosensor for observing intracellular ATP concentration to reflect apoptosis and physiological conditions. We successfully developed the tool ScanCer and performed a high-throughput screening of 1,220 compounds from the Novel Bioactive Compound Library. The team screened the lead compounds and used protein docking to discover downstream targets, which are expected to be new drugs for breast cancer. In addition, the team performed a virtual screening and validated the screened compounds through analysis and modeling.
advisors: Han Gao
students: Chengyin Yang, chenyu Zhao, Donglai Lin, Jia Li, Jiayang Liu, Jingwen Lyu, lin shiyin, Rachel Zhang, Tianxing Li, Xiyuan Shen, Yifei Chen, Yuehan An, Yumo Sun, Zhongjun Bai

title: LipOdyssey: A Quest For Precision Treatment
abstract: Breast cancer is the most diagnosed cancer among women worldwide, with a mortality rate in Greece reaching 25%. Despite being a leading cause of cancer-related deaths in women, current therapies often struggle with drug resistance, limiting long-term outcomes and contributing to disease progression. Inspired by recent vaccine advancements, we aim to develop a targeted therapy for the aggressive HER2+ subtype. Up to 70% of HER2-positive breast cancer patients develop resistance to trastuzumab, reducing its effectiveness. Our approach uses RNA-based gene silencing delivered via lipid nanoparticles, enhanced with trastuzumab to improve targeting and efficacy. Once inside the cells, the nanoparticles release shRNA to silence the TERT gene, lowering telomerase activity. This dual approach disrupts cancer cell immortality and increases sensitivity to trastuzumab, thereby overcoming resistance. Our project's combination of targeted therapy and gene silencing offers a precise, promising strategy with the potential to revolutionize cancer treatment and bring hope to patients.
nominations: Best Wiki, Undergrad
advisors: Katerina Patrinou, Sotiris Marinos
students: Achilleas Tyrovolas, Aristelina Celaj, Christos Karvelas, George Nikolopoulos, Ioannis Vogiatzoglou, Konstantinos Dimas, Maria Konstantina Maniati, Nefeli Bouta, Valentina Giampanzi

title: Vespa velutina Eradication through gene Silencing and Precise Ai based recognition
abstract: The Asian hornet (Vespa velutina), an invasive species introduced in France in 2004, poses a significant threat to pollinators, especially honeybees, impacting biodiversity and food security across Europe. This leads to significant economic losses, underscoring the need for urgent solutions. Our project offers a novel approach: a box equipped with an image recognition software containing a bait inoculated with engineered Lactococcus lactis. The software can distinguish insects and ensures that only the Asian hornet is granted access to the bait. When the bait is consumed by the larvae, the bacteria deliver shRNA to disrupt key developmental genes via RNA interference. By targeting specific genes, this method minimises harm to other species. And by targeting larvae, this method aims to reduce hornet populations more efficiently than current methods. Our design is efficient, cost-effective, and offers a promising solution to the growing threat of Asian hornets in Europe.
nominations: Best Conservation Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
instructors: Astri Kusumawardhani, Emanuele Boni, Gábor Holló, Jung Hun Park
advisors: Asia Zanella
students: Aisha Shah, Alicia Requena, Aline Raub, Anna Puzyrko, Clément Vanmerris, Gabriele Fasano, Ida L. Neinhardt

title: Intestide
abstract: Small peptides possess notable attributes. However, existing methods for delivering short peptides into the intestine remain constrained. Our proposed design encompasses three modules--Secretion, Adhesion, and Biosafety--and involves two strains of engineered bacteria: peptide producers and controllers. The Secretion module is present in the peptide producer strain. This module features a transmembrane protein, integrated into the outer membrane of E. coli. Synthesis of small peptides occurs in conjunction with this transmembrane protein, enabling their delivery into the surrounding environment. Both the peptide producer and controller strains incorporate the Adhesion module, which employs two adhesins capable of binding to each other. This arrangement results in the formation of a strain-layered matrix that securely adheres to the intestinal lining. The biosafety module comprises two distinct components within two strains. Based on a reciprocal activation principle, this module regulates the population dynamics of two strains to ensure optimal small peptide production.
advisors: Guoming Gao, Jiaze Liu, Jingcheng Wang, Zixuan Ding
student leaders: Anya Zhu, Li Yutong, Yecheng Zhao, Yuting Chen
students: Chenyue Zhang, Huang Nanqiao, Jiangyue Niu, Kailing Cai, Lv Siqing, Sam I Lei, Wei He, Xie Xiaoyu, Xu Pan, Yiheng Liao, YING HOOI WEE, Yizhou Wang, Zhang Zhenyu, ZIHAN MA, Ziyan Peng

title: Enhancing Animal Feed with Surface-Displayed Xylanase on Pichia pastoris
abstract: Our project aims to improve animal feed digestibility and nutritional efficiency by using Pichia pastoris to surface-display thermostable xylanase from Streptomyces thermovulgaris, addressing SDGs 2 (Zero Hunger) and 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production). Utilizing the GTH1 promoter, we expressed xylanase with two anchor proteins, GCW61 and Pir1. Comparative analysis using DNS assays and 3D modeling techniques (I-TASSER, YASARA with FoldX, and PyMOL) identified GCW61 as the more effective anchor. Xylanase-GCW61 showed significant activity and stability, while Xylanase-Pir1 exhibited measurable but lower activity. We conducted investigations on optimal enzyme activity conditions, resistance to gastric proteases, and feed processing stability. Our findings highlight the potential for this method to enhance livestock feed efficiency safely and cost-effectively.
advisors: Hung-Jen Liu, I CHUN YEH, Pei-Hsin Ho
students: Amber, Amy Chen, Angelina, Emily, Evelyn Ong, Junyuan Shih, Nita, Paul, Phoebe, Renee, Sefina Liao, Yan-Cheng Chen, YOU-XUAN LAI, Yung Ching Yang

title: Biosynthesis of Liamocin Oils in Saccharomyces cerevisiae through a multigene pathway derived from Aureobasidium pullulans
abstract: Liamocins are novel extracellular polyol lipids produced autogenously by Aureobasidium pullulans, exhibiting promising Streptococcus-specific inhibiting activity. Secondarily, liamocins possess surface-active and possibly anti-cancer properties. Liamocins can also cyclize into massoia lactone, a key compound produced by the threatened Cryptocaria massoy tree. Past research on liamocins has centered on elucidating the metabolic interactions influencing their synthesis, as well as their structure and applications. As such, methods of liamocin production have not yet reached an industrial or commercial scale. Our project aims to reduce the costs and enhance the rate of liamocin production to a commercial scale, via engineering the fast-doubling and well-documented S. cerevisiae to express the endogenous four-gene liamocin synthesis pathway in A. pullulans EXF-150.
PIs: Chan Ka Loi, Anson Chung, Chung Hin Wong
advisors: Conrad Young, Helene Heling Huang, Michelle Lam, Wong Man Yi
students: Ameya Pandey, Charlyn Lo, Jaime Poon, Krishna Bagale, Wai Cheng, Yuen Ting Tso, Yuk Ho Tsang

title: CyanoVolt: Creating Carbon-Negative Energy Through Cyanobacteria Based Biophotovoltaics
abstract: Due to the photosynthetic capability of cyanobacteria, they are an attractive model for synthesizing new biocompounds and have gained interest in producing bioenergy. Therefore, the development of genetically engineered cyanobacteria has increased in relevance over the last two decades. Our project aims to use genetically engineered cyanobacteria to create a biophotovoltaic fuel cell that can sequester CO2 from the environment and create a source of carbon-negative electricity, all while also producing a valuable byproduct, ethanol. Our biophotovoltaic fuel cell consists of two electrodes screen printed on paper substrate, with a layer of printed cyanobacteria on the anode. This "cell" is then covered by a hydrogel to act as a proton exchange membrane and collect ethanol. In order to efficiently assemble our biophotovoltaic fuel cells, we designed an automated screen printer to mass produce our cells.
advisors: Allison Lopatkin, Elizabeth Martin, Eric Heinze, Kate Kelchner
students: Alexis Fielding, Caleb Lee, Claire English, Elina Roshchupkina, Grace Widjaja, Jack Reinstein, Jeff Zhu, Michelia Hoang, Seeya Khattar, Shuhan Zhang, Weronika Kierzenka

title: NitroBLAST
abstract: NitroBLAST aims to address the nitrogen crisis by using the unique properties of the "nitroplast," a recently discovered nitrogen-fixing organelle derived from the cyanobacterial endosymbiont UCYN-A. Investigating its relationship with its host, the marine alga Braadurosphaera bigelowii, we identified two UCYN-A transit peptides (uTP1 and uTP2) essential for protein import into the nitroplast. Using bioinformatics, we predicted proteins involved in this transport system. We designed new parts for expressing uTP in S. cerevisiae and C. reinhardtii to investigate its function. Additionally, we isolated UCYN-A and refined a protocol for the fusion of E. coli with S. cerevisiae, hoping that it can be used in the future for the transplantation of nitroplasts into eukaryotic cells. This research lays the groundwork for nitrogen-fixing crops, potentially reducing reliance on synthetic fertilizers and mitigating both environmental and agricultural challenges
advisors: Britte Bouchaut, Ellen Bakker-Winkler, Friedrich Kleiner, Marijn van den Brink, Pietro
students: Abel Tordai, Ángel, Bálint Magyar, Eva Stempher, Natalia, Shraddha Raghuram

title: CAP'siRNA - A bioinspired solution against Virus Yellows disease to preserve sugar beets
abstract: Food security faces threats from emerging agricultural diseases, particularly Virus Yellows, which significantly impacts sugar beet crops, reducing yields by up to 40% and causing localized losses of up to 90% due to the Beet Yellows Virus (BYV). We developed CAP'siRNA, a solution based on RNA interference, a natural defense mechanism present in plants. We engineered Escherichia coli to produce long hairpin RNA (lhRNA) precursors that specifically target the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and P21, an RNA interference suppressor gene. These lhRNAs are processed by the plant's machinery, ultimately degrading the viral genome of BYV. These lhRNAs include an Origin of Assembly Sequence, which allows Tobacco Mosaic Virus coat proteins - produced by engineered E. coli - to form a capsid around the lhRNAs, protecting them from the environment. CAP'siRNA is non-GMO, biodegradable, and targets only the virus. Furthermore, this platform can adapt to combat other viral diseases in crops.
nominations: Best Agriculture Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad
advisors: Ben lamine Karim, Savandara BESSE
students: Alicia.G, Bérénice Varin, Camellia Lambert, Clémence Guyoux, Danyil, Hélène Gravelines, Jade Noailly, Laurine Wachspress, Maïtena Fayolle, Margaux MALOSSE, Marion Guillot, Matteo BETTIATI, Mélodie-Rose, NicolasBinand, Sadaf Barakzoy

title: Merging Old and New: Treating non-small cell lung cancer by Cordyceps and AI-designed peptides
abstract: We aim to produce two types of engineered proteins to target Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) and check for any combination effects of those peptides with cisplatin, a common chemotherapy drug. Four peptides from Cordyceps militaris, a well?known dietary therapy in anticancer treatment, were selected to test their effectiveness to lung cancer. Also, we modified those peptides by adding linker and cell-penetrating peptide. Furthermore, we used RFdiffusion and ProteinMPNN-AI to generate peptide sequences by targeting PDE?, which regulates KRAS signaling, a common gene mutation in cancerous cells. Then, those peptides were expressed by BL21. Finally, A549, a lung cancer cell line, was used to test the effectiveness of those peptides and check for whether two groups of peptides have any combination effects with cisplatin. If there are combination effects, lower concentration of cisplatin can be used, so that it can reduce the side effects of it.
nominations: Best Model, High School+Best Education, High School

title: CAPTURE - Combating Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections with anti-microbial peptide carriers
abstract: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of antibiotic-resistant hospital-acquired infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia and sepsis. This pathogen exacerbates the condition of already compromised patients and poses a significant challenge in healthcare settings. Our project, CAPTURE, tackles this challenge by proposing a novel approach using specialized transport vesicles, such as lipid-based nanocarriers and outer membrane vesicles, to deliver plasmids encoding potent antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) directly into bacterial cells. By delivering our plasmid, we aim to create a targeted therapeutic system for eradicating P. aeruginosa infections. Focusing on lung infections, we plan to administer the carriers using an aerosol delivery system. This innovative strategy combines synthetic biology and drug delivery techniques to enhance AMP efficacy. Our research has the potential to develop a novel therapeutic approach that could reduce the mortality rates associated with P. aeruginosa in hospitals.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, Overgrad+Best Measurement, Overgrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad

students: Alexej Wolosski, Emil Kozma, Isabelle Tipp, Ivana Rozi?, Jan Zielinski, Laura Pasman, Leonie Mungenast, Liv Neumann, Lucille Gutzmer, Marina Hammerl, Mathilda Bertges, Nafis Madappalli, Nicole Kucera, Niels Geipel

title: YOB3: an alternative for vitamin B3 production
abstract: The YOB3 system, developed by the Rio_UFRJ_BR team, aims to enhance plant productivity and stress tolerance by producing nicotinamide riboside (NR), a precursor of NAD+. Using Saccharomyces cerevisiae as the chassis, the system was engineered to increase NR production through genetic modifications, which will drive the NAD salvage pathway towards NR synthesis and includes the deletion of transporters to boost secretion of NR. Testing in sugarcane juice-based media, which is largely produced in Brazil, and low phosphate levels, further optimized NR output. A degron system mimicking low phosphate and a kill switch for cell control were designed for future use. As a proof-of-concept tests in Arabidopsis thaliana showed NR-induced stress resistance. The project also included an educational outreach program, explored commercial opportunities, and was also shaped by feedback from plant growers and scientists, promising reduced agricultural chemical use and higher land productivity.
advisors: André Goulart, Caio Vitor Rangel Goulart, Giovanni, Paula Yamamoto Alves de Lima
students: Ana Paula Goulart, Clarissa De Souza Chacon, Helena Brazuna, Joice Silva, Juliano de Moraes Rodrigues, Lucas Santiago, Mariana Hecksher Oliveira, Vitória Rodrigues

title: Scaling Ursolic Acid Biosynthesis for Breast Cancer Treatment via Gene Knockout and CSTR
abstract: Ursolic Acid (UA) is a natural product that has been discovered to have numerous medically beneficial properties. Preliminary studies have shown therapeutic potential for breast cancer [Seo et al., 2018]. The current method of obtaining UA requires extraction from apples and loquats, which is environmentally unsustainable [Yu et al., 2018], time-consuming, and not standardized across scientists. Although UA has high promise within oncology studies, it's also found to have low oral bioavailability, limiting its efficacy as a pharmaceutical. Team Cornell genetically engineered the mevalonate (MVA) pathway by knocking out a transport protein and introducing new enzymes within the MVA pathway. Furthermore, a high specificity carrier system was developed to assist with bioavailability. Oncurex improves the efficiency and standardization of UA biosynthesis. This project also provides an industrially scalable platform that can be utilized by pharmaceutical companies to increase UA supply for breast cancer treatment.
nominations: Best Presentation, Undergrad
advisors: Adithya Prabakaran, Aindri Patra, cameron meyer, David Xiang, Derek Huang, Javohir Abdurazzakov, Jaymee Palma, Maggie Elpers, Noelle Pappous, Pedro Da Silveira, Rowan Gould, Sarah Henretta, Shara Shanmugasundaram, Shohum Finkelstein, Siddhanth Bhatt, Srishti Khetan, Vernetta Huang, Yannis Ntekas

title: NeoMineX: Engineered bacterial strains and biofibers for cation extraction from wastewater
abstract: Our reliance on technological solutions to increase and maintain a standard of living beyond the Earth's capacity, is driving the depletion of Earth's finite mineral resources. Mining ores is depleting and destroying our ecosystems, while large amounts of these metal ions end up in our waters at concentrations that can affect our ecology, but are usually too dilute to make recycling economically viable. NeoMineX aims to tackle both metal scarcity and water pollution by bioaccumulating metal ions from waste water, providing a viable route for metal recycling and recovery. In our project, we characterised 28 previously reported metal-binding peptides for their in vivo Cu (copper) and Ni (nickel) accumulation (and detoxification). We also demonstrate that these peptides could be turned into functional protein fibers for specialist applications or for environments where GMOs are not well suited.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, Overgrad
advisors: Joris Kenis
student leaders: Gabriella Christina Petra Grimmelprez, Jena Amand
students: Aurora Licaj, Daniele Ciabatti, Dúnia Bobet Cañadell, Enrique Esteban, Gerard, Harini Gopalakrishnan, Imane Fath Allah, Jeremy, Juan Cossio, Julia Rank Teixeira, Maria Krunic, Mary Anna Nishiotis, wout keymis

title: PHAGEVO
abstract: Directed evolution mimics and accelerates the natural evolution process by generating random mutations and selecting desired variants. This project introduces PHAGEVO, a novel tool that combines Phage-Assisted Non-Continuous Evolution (PANCE) and the Evolution.T7 system, providing a powerful method for in vivo protein evolution. While PANCE enables efficient selection of functional variants, it lacks targeted gene specificity. We decided to combine it with Evolution.T7, a system developed by Evry-Paris-Saclay team 2021 which enables targeted and modular double-stranded in vivo mutagenesis using RNA polymerase-guided cytosine and adenine deaminases' that introduce mutations in specific gene sequences. As a proof of concept, the project focuses on evolving the XylS transcription factor to detect plastic degradation products Phthalic Acid (PA) and Terephthalic Acid (TPA). Our project, PHAGEVO, also leverages the power of artificial intelligence to engineer XylS for PA and TPA sensitivity owing to FLINT, a model developed by our team based on PocketGen.
nominations: Best Foundational Advance Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Chloe SEYMAN, Tom Zaplana
students: Clara Sube, Daria Kurganskaya, Doriane Blaise, Fethi BOUGHMADI, Florent Cha, Hugo Pitaval, Kenan Oggad, Mathéo Tripnaux-Moreau, Matisse Ferrer, Nathan JOMBY MOUKOKO, Sophia Molteni, Talissa Kassably, Victor ROBERT LAMBRECHT

title: CAR_Ma - A next-generation in-vivo immunotherapy
abstract: Cancer is a complex disease that has plagued mankind for sometime. Humanity has developed almost as many weapons on cancer as we have on each other. Chemcial, radiological and even biological weapons have developed to little avail, due to their inability to takle the inherent complexities of cancer from the ground-up. Solid tumors act on multiple fronts simultaneously: One part rapidly growing parasitic organism, another part immune evasion, and finally one part self-sustaining microenvironment. To tackle cancer effectively, we need to be able to tackle the tumor in its multiple modalities, with a solution that is inherently multi-modal. CAR_Ma is this solution. Built upon our own multi-modal RNA - Combining sustained, controllable and transient expression, gene editing and modulation, and our nanoparticle delivery solution. We are able to engineer macrophages capable of targeting tumor cells, negating immune evasion, then penetrating and destroying the tumor from the inside out.
PIs: Weiping Wang, Rio Ryohichi Sugimura, Kevin K.M. Tsia, David J.H Shih, Anderson Shum

title: Project Obviation - A novel dual-action therapeutic for cardiovascular disease
abstract: Our iGEM project is centered on producing a fusion protein, TP1-P5, by combining ginsentide TP1 with lupin peptide P5 we aim to develop a more effective and affordable cardiovascular supplement. This fusion protein addresses significant gaps in the current market, where many existing products lack comprehensive benefits or are prohibitively expensive. Our strategy involves the cost-effective biosynthesis of TP1-P5 in E. coli, and then extracting them to make as different forms of supplements, ensuring accessibility for a broader audience. We believe that this innovative supplement can play a vital role in promoting cardiovascular health, ultimately contributing to better health outcomes for individuals at risk of heart disease.
PIs: Wai Yin Lau, Cheuk Long Ip, Constantine Wing Heng Lau, KWAN SIN KEI, Steven Chau, Tsui Shing Yan, Tsz Yeung Li, Yeung Wai Lok Wesley, YUEN, Man Leuk

title: EsperSense - A Breath of Hope
abstract: Trimethylaminuria (TMAU), commonly known as "fishy odor disease," is a metabolic disorder where the body cannot oxidize trimethylamine (TMA) into odorless trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO). This results in the buildup of TMA, causing a strong odor released through sweat, breath, and urine. The 2024 iGEM@FSU team is continuing efforts initiated by the 2023 team to address this rare condition. Building on the previous team's therapeutic development, the current team is creating a biomarker monitoring device, specifically a breathalyzer that utilizes a BIOFET sensor. This device aims to provide patients with a reliable method to monitor their TMA levels and adjust treatments more effectively. The project also seeks to integrate last year's therapeutic approach with this diagnostic tool for a comprehensive management solution. Beyond technical advancements, the team is committed to raising public and professional awareness about TMAU, encouraging better support for affected individuals.
students: Aidan Marengo, Arjan Adhikari, Ava Polly, Dorian Chin, Jordan Schwartz, Lucas Bonassi, Megan Perusse, Michael Pilapil, Zachary Asarnow

title: PROtech: Precise RNA Oncotherapy technology
abstract: Protein-targeted therapies present challenges in cancer treatment, particularly when cellular redundancy enables cancer resistance. Furthermore, many mutations are synonymous, producing no detectable protein changes, leaving patients with untargetable silent mutations. To address this, our project focuses on an mRNA-targeting therapy using a Toehold Switch mechanism. This system selectively activates in the presence of cancer-specific mRNA, enabling precise delivery of cytotoxic proteins. The project developed a model to optimize toehold switch designs and validated its approach using yeast and human cell lines, focusing on pancreatic cancer. Additionally, educational and entrepreneurial initiatives were launched to further expand synthetic biology's impact.
students: Daniel Benarroch, Itai Fabian, Jonathan Yoni Klein, Marana Abboud, Nati, Neve, Oren, Peleg, Rotem Gal, Tal Shemesh

title: Dengue Beeters - A novel synergy of recombinant biolarvicidal toxins, naturally-derived geosmin, and gravid-trap
abstract: The rise of dengue fever in recent years has become a significant issue in tropical and sub-tropical areas, inflicting serious socioeconomic and healthcare burdens. In our project, we successfully engineered 12 recombinant biolarvicidal toxins and partially reproduced a chromosome-free system. We conducted WHO standard larvicidal assay with Aedes albopictus larvae and proved the potency of Cyt2Ba, Xpp81Aa1 and BmK IT1. In addition, we consistently proved that 2.5 mg/ml of beetroot peel powder can significantly attract gravid female Ae. albopictus mosquitoes in oviposition assays. We integrated the synthetic biology-based product with beetroot peel powder and developed Taiwan's first 3D-printed household-use sticky ovitrap. We also developed an OpenCv mosquito egg analyzer to automatically analyze mosquito eggs, helping field entomologists and scientists in dengue surveillance work. Dengue Beeters is an exciting project that breaks mosquito life cycle through synthetic biology and contributes to the end of dengue fever disease by 2030.
awards: Grand Prize Winner+Finalist+Top 10+Best New Basic Part+Best Project Promotion Video+Best Wiki

title: Development of a genetic engineered EcN for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease
abstract: EcN can be used as a probiotic for the treatment of intestinal-related diseases due to its good intestinal short-term colonization ability and non-pathogenicity. In recent years, targeted drugs represented by monoclonal antibodies have greatly improved the clinical treatment effect of inflammatory bowel disease, but there are unmet needs such as high prices, unresponsiveness of some patients, infection caused by long-term medication, and poor patient compliance. Using synthetic biology techniques, we expressed the novel nano antibodies in EcN. After oral administration of the engineered EcN, these nano-antibodies will be continuously secreted in the inflammatory intestinal tract, and the inflammatory signaling pathway was blocked to achieve efficient, safe, convenient, and low-cost treatment.

title: Visual biosensors for mercury and cadmium heavy metal ions
abstract: The increasing prevalence of heavy metal contamination poses significant risks to ecosystems and human health. Existing detection methods for heavy metals often suffer from limitations such as lengthy processing times, high costs, and inadequate sensitivity, making them less effective for real-time monitoring. This project aims to develop a whole-cell biosensor leveraging the natural pigments to visually indicate the heavy metals in water. By integrating metal-responsive transcriptional regulators MerR and CadR with the pigment biosynthesis gene clusters, we engineered E. coli as the biosensor capable of detecting Hg (II) and Cd (II). The biosensor exhibits high sensitivity and selectivity, with clear colorimetric changes correlated to metal ion concentrations. This innovative biosensor offers a promising tool for environmental monitoring, enabling rapid and accessible detection of heavy metal pollutants, and could be further adapted for use in various ecological and industrial applications, enhancing environmental safety and public health initiatives.
advisors: Cheng Zhibo, LI JUNYUE, Wang Chupeng, Wen Haohan, WU SHI-YU, Zhou Yile
students: ALINA ZHANG, BOWEN YANG, CAI WENHAO, CAI ZEYANG, CHEN NUO, DA JIAYI, FENG TIANYU, GUO XILAI, HUANG ZIHAO, JIAO JINNAN, LI JIAXI, LI MUZE, LIUAN WANG, LIU JINGMING, LIU ZIHAO, MING JINGXUAN, PAN ZIRUI, TSENG OWEN MINXUAN, XIE LEFAN, xinyin zhang, XU ZHIHUAN, YANG YAXIN, YAN XINYI, ZHIYU JIA, ZIYI LYU

title: Development of Pompe disease drug screening kit
abstract: Nowadays, Some individuals suffer from Pompe disease, a rare condition caused by a lack or low activity of acid alpha-glucosidase (GAA) in lysosomes, leading to glycogen accumulation and impaired lysosomal function. Currently, enzyme replacement therapy is the sole treatment, yet it's costly and may cause rejection. Our project utilizes gene engineering to produce stable, high-efficiency GAA proteins and develop a screening kit for small-molecule drugs. Then we screened some small molecule drugs that may increase GAA enzyme activity through bioinformation technology, and further used our drug screening kit to verify the effect of the drug. We hope that we can not only contribute to the screening of drugs to alleviate Pompeii disease, but also hope that we can pay attention to Pompeii disease and give more support to patients with Pompeii disease.
advisors: Jinhua He
student leaders: WANCHEN HSIEH, XU XINLIN, ZUO ZIQING
students: CHANG JIAXIN, CHENJUNJIE ZHU, CHEN WANQING, GAO YUNTIAN, GUO JIAMING, JANNY JIN YU XU, MAO YIXIN, OU JIAHUAN, WEN CHING CATHERINE, XIE TIANHUI, XINYAN JIN, YOUXUAN SONG, YU SHITAO, ZHAO TIANYING, ZISHUO CHEN

title: Hyaluronidase high-yield yeast cell factory
abstract: Patients undergoing surgery often face the issue of local edema or hematoma, which can prolong recovery or cause further complications. Hyaluronidase (HAase) is an enzyme that helps eliminate edema and hematoma and has additional medical uses. Currently, the only commercial source of HAase is from cow testicles, leading to limited supply and the risk of zoonotic disease transmission. Our project employs synthetic biology and genetic engineering to insert an optimized HAase gene from leeches into Pichia pastoris, a yeast known for its robust capacity to secrete recombinant proteins. The optimized gene enhances HAase production and the modified yeast efficiently produces HAase that can be extracted for medical applications, including cancer treatment, drug delivery, postoperative edema and hematoma reduction. Our high-yielding, cost-effective yeast strain promises to increase the availability and purity of HAase, facilitating its broader use in medical treatments.
nominations: Best New Improved Part, High School

title: Directional mining of terpene skin care products in deep-sea metagenome
abstract: The various extreme environments of the deep sea (?1000 m) form a high degree of biodiversity, with abundant genetic resources and biosynthetic potential. In this project, based on deep-sea microbial metagenomic data mining, high-value terpene natural products with skin care activity will be mined. Metagenomic analysis will be performed on samples from deep-sea ecosystems, and deep-sea microbial genome sets and biosynthetic gene clusters will be constructed. Directional mining of biosynthetic gene clusters of terpene natural products in 1-2 deep-sea microorganisms, and analysis of product structure. Finally, the biological activities of terpene natural products such as antibacterial, anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective effects were evaluated to provide a research basis for their application in the field of skin care products.
advisors: Deng Ziheng, Ju Kaiyang, Peng Linhao, ZHAO XU

title: Design of Escherichia coli resistant to T7 phage infection based on CRISPR-Cas9
abstract: Escherichia coli is one of the most important chassis cells in industrial production and has become one of the important tools in bioengineering and industrial production. However, the industrial application of E.coli is often threatened by phage infection. Among them, T7 phage is one of the common industrial harmful phages, which has strong infectivity to E.coli. It may lead to pollution in the production process, which in turn affects production efficiency and product quality, and even causes production interruption and economic losses. Our project aims to use CRISPR-Cas9 technology to design E.coli strains resistant to T7 phage infection. By accurately cutting the key genes of the T7 phage genome, the resistance of E.coli to T7 phage infection is enhanced, which is expected to improve the stability and reliability of E.coli in industrial production.
advisors: CHEN YIYU, Ding Wu, Zixuan Wang

title: EvC-T system
abstract: The EvC-T system is an innovative therapeutic approach for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) developed by HBMU-Taihe in 2024. This system consists of two core components: GPC3-CAR and EXOtic. The EvC-T system aims to develop a virus-free CAR-T cell immunotherapy platform. It incorporates an AFP promoter and IL-12 secretion module based on GPC3-CAR, which further enhances the targeting and tissue specificity of CAR-T cells, significantly improving the safety of CAR-T therapy. For GPC3-negative HCC cells, the EvC-T system employs a hypoxia-inducible exosome delivery mechanism. Using the L7Ae-C/D box sequence, exosomes deliver GPC3 mRNA to hypoxic regions in liver cancer tissues, converting GPC3-negative cells into GPC3-positive cells, thus making them targets for GPC3-CAR-T cell attacks. This combined killing mechanism greatly improves treatment efficiency.
PIs: Zhongji Meng, Yigan Zhang, Juan Chen

title: Development of a bacteria detecting biosensor in fridge
abstract: Have you ever wondered if our fridge is really as clean as we think? Do you know when you should clean your fridge? In our project, we constructed a biosensor using cell free system hydrogel containing RNA toehold switch, which was the main component of a detector used for detecting pathogenic bacteria in refrigerator. If the bacteria fall to the hydrogel in fridge, it will switch on the RNA toehold to express lacZ gene and produce ?-galactosidase, catalyzing the blue product which is detected by the detector. This information is scanned by RGB color sensor and converted to the electric signal which is transferred to a pilot lamp, making the red LED light up on the screen of refrigerator door, reminding people to clean or disinfect the refrigerator in time. It is very convenient and beneficial for people to use it in refrigerator at home.
student leaders: Wang Zishuo, Xinyu Feng, Ziyang Wei
students: Guanying Li, Huining Shen, Leqi Liu, Linyan Liu, Lirui Huo, QU JIAYU, rui li, Ruilin Liu, WANG XIAOXI, Wenyi Qian, Xitong Jin, Yi Tian, Yumeng Zhao

title: TamponX: creating a tampon prototype that prevents Toxic Shock Syndrome
abstract: Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) is a rare, sometimes fatal implication of certain types of bacterial infections. The use of tampons and other devices such as menstruation cups is one of the identified risk factors of TSS. Currently, preventative measures on menstruation related TSS are limited to avoiding usage of tampons and other invasive menstruation products. Therefore, Tampon X aim to design a tampon product that prevents menstruation related TSS by introducing TSS-suppressing probiotics to help maintain and improve the health of vaginal microbiome. We aim to over-express a FMN reductase in Lactobacillus johnsonii to improve its H2O2 production, and utilize a CRISPR/Cas9 system assisted by Red/ET recombinase mediated homologous recombination in Lactococcus lactis to improve its nisin production through engineering the self-regulating Nisin Controlled Gene Expression (NICE) system, in order to suppress pathogens and maintain a healthy microbiome in the vagina.
advisors: Qizhou Jiang, Yuxin Wang
students: Jiayan Xie, Jingwen Jia, Jordan, Malak Musabeh, Ruoxuan Wang, Samia Idaghdour, Shaban Muhammad, Wiam Benadder, Xinjin Du, Xinyu Hu, Xiupu Zhao, Yitong Wang, Yuanfei, Yuhan Lin

title: reSkin - Protein-based hydrogel dressings for burn wound treatment
abstract: As iGEM team Hamburg 2024, we present our project reSkin: a hydrogel dressing for burn wounds. The WHO confirms that 11 million people suffer burn wounds every year globally. Our reSkin hydrogel is based on photo-crosslinking the natural components resilin and hyaluronic acid using riboflavin phosphate as photo-initiator. Resilin is a protein found in insects. It is well known for its exceptional mechanical properties and resilience. Hyaluronic acid is a negatively charged polymer with an extremely high water capacity. This allows for the hydration of the burn wound and the absorption of the wound fluid. To support wound healing, prevent inflammation, and promote the regeneration of skin tissue, we have added astaxanthin, bromelain, and vitamin E to our hydrogel. Furthermore, the protease bromelain helps to differentiate between degrees 2a and 2b of the burn injury and is therefore used to assess whether a skin transplant is necessary.
advisors: Andrea Elisabeth Kothe, Lennert Weber, Lisa Siemers, Malcolm Summer Rose-Heine
students: Annabell Winkler, Boy Hansen, Can, Emily Magdalena Bärmann, Felisa Kowalewski, Hannah Goldgräbe, Inara Maniglio, Laura Döß, Luna Brandes, Marcela, Oliver Richter, Sophia Bach

title: Bloom Busters: Engineering Chlamydomonas reinhardtii to fight toxic algal blooms
abstract: The Problem: Excess nutrient loading in Utah Lake is causing increased eutrophication, which leads to increased cyanobacterial blooms that produce toxins hazardous to human, animal, and aquatic life. The excess nutrients are composed mostly of nitrogen and phosphorous compounds that enter the lake primarily from wastewater treatment plants, runoff fertilizer, and naturally occurring within inorganic environmental resources. Our Solution: Reduce the nutrient load of wastewater entering the lake by engineering a harmless organism to sequester phosphorus and convert nitrogenous compounds to atmospheric nitrogen, which is biologically inert. We chose the microalgae Chlamydomonas reinhardtii as the chassis for the genetically engineered machine. A second, long-term goal would be to turn the sequestered nutrients into a marketable product.
students: Abigail Brimhall, Audrey Domyan, Callie Ross, Elise Bennett, Erick Alvarez, Gerardo Acosta, Hagen Harmer, Jacob Bowman, Jacob "Jam" McFadden, Jake Hafen, Jonathan Kinross, Matthew Harris, Natalia Frezzia, Nico Crawford, Pedro Rodriguez

title: SynAxis - An Engineered System for Targeted Degradation of Misfolded ?-Synuclein in Parkinson's Disease
abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) presents significant healthcare challenges, affecting millions globally and currently lacking disease-modifying therapies. Our project focuses on the engineered degradation of misfolded ?-synuclein seeds, a key pathological feature in PD. Braak's staging of PD highlights a progressive spread of pathological ?-synuclein seeds, starting in the enteric nervous system within the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and advancing to the central nervous system. We developed a modular protein switch designed to selectively degrade pathological ?-synuclein in enteroendocrine cells (EECs) of the gastrointestinal tract. This switch is activated by an output domain (CypD), ensuring degradation by the input domain (KLK6) occurs only in the presence of misfolded ?-synuclein, thereby minimizing off-target effects. An oral spore-based probiotic delivery system encapsulates the switch, facilitating its targeted release to EECs. Our approach aims to change PD treatment by addressing the underlying pathology rather than merely managing symptoms and providing a strategy suitable for other synucleinopathies.
advisors: Youzi Bi

title: A Biosensor for Detecting Milk Spoilage Using AHL Sensing
abstract: Milk spoils rapidly, particularly in warm climates, posing challenges for determining its freshness. Our project addresses this issue using synthetic biology to develop a dual-plasmid biosensor that detects the presence of harmful bacteria in milk by measuring acyl-homoserine lactone (AHL) concentrations. The first plasmid expresses LuxR under the control of the strong promoter J23119, enabling high LuxR protein levels. AHL molecules bind to LuxR, forming a complex that activates the second plasmid, which contains a Lux promoter driving the expression of the fluorescent protein VenusNB. The resulting fluorescence is proportional to the bacterial contamination, providing a reliable method to assess milk spoilage.
advisors: Jay
student leaders: Arno Li, David, Jason Lu, Qiantong Gao, TAN,Yuxin

title: A soothing nasal suction complex, no taboos to ride a roller coaster!
abstract: Riding a roller coaster is a thrilling entertainment activity, however, adverse reactions unavoidably occur, such as dizziness, vomiting, head tremors. In addition, activities related with vestibular functions including riding, boating and bungee jumping would also bring the similar side effects. Based on our recent invivo studies, vitamin B6 and B12 took effects in nourishing vestibular functional areas mainly through increasing the permeability of vascular endothelial cells and regulating special signal pathways. Therefore, in the present project, we planned to research and develop a soothing nasal suction complex to minimize vestibular function damages. Through constructing neurons damage model, the effects of VB6/VB12 and their combinations in alleviating neuron injuries were primarily evaluated, and their best ratio were selected, the molecular mechanism was further validated.. Then, VB6/VB12 nanoparticles were prepared with ursolic acid, to promise the slow-release effects. With feedback gathering, we hope to create an effective and novel remedy.

title: The Application of RNA Secondary Structure to Diagnose Gastric Cancer in the Early Stage
abstract: Gastric cancer is one of the leading causes of cancer-related death worldwide. Ras?GTPase?activating protein SH3 domain binding protein1 (G3BP1) is the first RasGAP SH3 domain binding protein. G3BP1 has been reported to be upregulated in gastric cancer tissues and strongly associated with the survival rate of the patients suffering from gastric cancer. G3BP1 protein could directly regulate the mRNA decay through interacting with the highly structure in the 3'-untranslated region (3'UTR). Our project plans to create a sensor containing highly structured 3'UTR to monitor the change of G3BP1, which may provide a novel method to diagnosis gastric cancer at the earlier stages in the future.
advisors: Gezhi Ma, Mingxi Huang, Xiaoxiao Tan, Yi Li
student leaders: Haoning Huang, Wanyue Zeng, Yang Wei, Yuhao Chen
students: Chuhan Wang, LIU LU, QIANYA ZHOU, Shenzixuan Zhou, Shuwen Yang, Yixin Ning, Yuxi Chen

title: Development of weight loss probiotics
abstract: Our project was inspired by a team member's father who used semaglutide injections for weight loss. With the growing global obesity issue, we aimed to address it by developing a plasmid based on Escherichia coli Nissle 1917, incorporating fat-reducing, muscle-building, and suicide systems, and validating their feasibility. The fat-reducing system includes GLP-1 secretion and DPP-4 protein inhibitor secretion systems; the muscle-building system includes Bimagrumab secretion; and the suicide system includes an arabinose-induced system and a low-temperature induction system to minimize gene leakage risks. Our goal is to produce this probiotic as a powder to help obese patients achieve both fat loss and muscle gain, while reducing the discomfort and inconvenience of traditional weight loss methods.
student leaders: Chen Jiayi, Jia Shanqiao, Ruichun Liang, Wu Sirui

title: Smart Probiotic for Early IBD Detection and Treatment
abstract: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) causes intestinal damage and inflammation, leading to symptoms like abdominal pain and recurring episodes. Current diagnostic and treatment methods are insufficient. Colonoscopies, the main diagnostic tool, are invasive and costly, while medications can suppress symptoms but have side effects. Our project aims to create a smart engineered probiotic for early IBD prediction and treatment. This probiotic detects elevated thiosulfate levels in the gut, triggering a sensory system that turns the patient's stool blue to indicate IBD. For treatment, the bacteria release Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) to heal the intestinal lining. A safety kill-switch system ensures no environmental release or persistence in the human body. This integrated diagnostic and therapeutic approach offers a more convenient, affordable, and precise solution for early IBD detection and treatment, potentially reducing its incidence.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, High School
students: 00, Adeline, Amino, Bruce, Bryan, charles, Daniel, Grace, Hermione, ju, Julie, Mingzhe Du, Olivia., oliviali, Th0mas, YEeeA, Yilan, Yuxuan Liu, Zenith

title: HEATMAP: Harmonizing Enzymatic Activity and Temperature in Metabolic Pathways
abstract: The optimization of metabolic pathway within the Saccharopolyspora spinosa plays an irreplaceable role in increasing purity and unit yield of spinosad. Enzymes, as essential components of life, have long been a research focal point. One of their fundamental characteristics, optimal temperature, serves as a key link between biological activity and temperature. In this project, we set up a deep learning model to predict the optimal temperatures of enzymes within the body of Saccharopolyspora spinosa and compared them to the actual fermentation temperatures to identify enzymes with large differences. These enzymes became our key targets for optimization. Moreover, to simplify the optimization, based on the GEM model, we added enzyme and temperature constraints to construct the etcGEM model so that key enzymes with yield limitations can be identified. Targeted evolution of these key enzymes brings their optimal temperatures closer to the actual fermentation temperatures, thus improves productivity.
students: Aifei Jiang, Chaokai Xu, Dian Zhang, Julian Hua, MING GAO, mingjian yuan, Minying Wang, Qihao Huang, Siyu Chen, Suning Wang, Yibo Peng, YIDAN ZHANG, Yuan Yuan, Yuhang Cheng, Zhiwei Yu, Zhuohao Tang

title: MicroDETECT
abstract: This project develops a diagnostic platform targeting microRNAs, combining polymerase self-amplification and a two-step CRISPR reaction to diagnose various cancers. The system first utilizes machine learning to screen target cancer-related microRNAs, then amplifies the target signal using a signal self-enhancement system constructed by a two-step polymerase reaction, and combines the CRISPR system for secondary signal amplification. Finally, the results are captured by single-molecule fluorescence super resolution microscopy for automated numerical analysis to derive the diagnostic outcome, establishing a quantitative analysis platform for fluorescence values and target concentrations. Key features of this diagnostic system include: no requirement for PCR, suitability for various operational environments, high accuracy, and adjustable sensitivity.
nominations: Best Software Tool, Undergrad

title: PrymDetect: Engineering the SHERLOCK Platform for Golden Algae Detection
abstract: Prymnesium parvum, commonly known as "golden algae," is the species responsible for the 2022 ecological disaster in the Oder River. Despite the serious threat posed by this organism, current detection methods are time-consuming, tedious, and often ineffective. In our iGEM project, we engineered SHERLOCK (Specific High-sensitivity Enzymatic Reporter Unlocking), a synthetic biology tool, to specifically and effectively detect the Oder strain of Prymnesium parvum. We developed a lateral flow test - PrymFlow - for in-field detection, as well as a 3D-printed device - PrymChip. Additionally, we created SynLOCK - the crRNA Synthesis System for SHERLOCK - which simplifies and standardizes the production of custom crRNAs, making it easier to develop detection tools similar to ours. Overall, our project aims not only to improve the monitoring of water bodies prone to Prymnesium parvum blooms, but also to mitigate their ecological and economic impacts.

title: Tarakate - From Rainforest Deforestation to Sustainable Rubber: Using Plant SynBio to Facilitate Dandelion Engineering
abstract: Natural rubber production from Hevea brasiliensis poses significant environmental and economic challenges, including deforestation, labor exploitation, and vulnerability to diseases like South American leaf blight. With a global demand of 15 million tons annually and over 50,000 rubber products, finding sustainable alternatives is critical. Taraxacum kok-saghyz, a rubber-producing dandelion, emerges as a promising solution. Consultations with experts revealed that the primary limitation in dandelion cultivation is not rubber yield but agriculturally significant traits like plant morphology. To address this, we developed a comprehensive collection of characterized genetic parts specific to dandelions, including constitutive regulatory elements. We tested our constructs using four transformation methods - two transient (leaf infiltration and protoplast transformation) and two stable ("extremely simplified cut-dip-budding" and sterile transformation). By creating efficient protocols and tools, we aim to make dandelion a viable chassis for synthetic biology, enabling future iGEM teams to contribute to sustainable rubber production and other applications.
awards: Grand Prize Winner+Finalist+Top 10+Best Agriculture Project+Best Part Collection+Best Plant Synthetic Biology+Best Wiki

title: RePLAse - compost accelerator, that helps improve PLA plastics degradation under standard commercial composting conditions.
abstract: The problem of petroleum-based plastic pollution persists for over 50 years. Biotechnology has enabled more sustainable plastic options to gain popularity. PLA plastics are marketed as biodegradable, but they require high temperatures, sustained moisture, and 20 times more organic matter to decompose. Compost facilities in Manitoba are unable to accept PLA because its degradation requirements are not compatible with current infrastructure. We designed a bio-based compost accelerator that facilitates PLA degradation without disrupting natural composting processes, and improves compost quality. Our final design consists of gram-negative compost-native bacteria, Pseudomonas putida, with a surface-display mechanism involving an anchor protein, PLA-specific adhesion protein and PLA depolymerases optimized for composting conditions. We tested three PLA-degrading enzymes against both short and long chain PLA and determined that our device has the potential to degrade target both the amorphous and crystalline regions of PLA when used in concert.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Overgrad
advisors: Camille Prefontaine, Jessica Marinelli, Kartik Sachar, Kaushik

title: Micronaut: A Biosensor for Non-Hodgkin's B-cell Lymphoma
abstract: Non-Hodgkin's B-cell lymphoma is a deadly disease that currently lacks early screening tests. Often, patients are diagnosed at advanced stages due to ambiguous symptoms, making it much more difficult to treat. Studies have shown that many diseases, including non-Hodgkin's B-cell lymphoma, have microRNA signatures - associated increases or decreases in the concentrations of certain microRNAs. Existing microRNA detectors such as toehold switch-based systems require complex secondary structure modeling. We engineered Micronaut, a novel microRNA biosensor that takes advantage of the RNA-Induced Silencing Complex (RISC) and a dual regulation system. Our GFP reporter gene is suppressed by transcriptional and translational repressors (LacI and L7Ae, respectively). In the presence of our target microRNA, the two repressors will be silenced by RISC, leading to a fluorescence signal. With a simple switch in a 20-nucleotide sequence, our system can be expanded to measure any microRNA and thus, any disease with a microRNA signature.
PIs: J. Peter Gergen, Gabor Balazsi, Kathryn Gunn
advisors: Abhishek Cherath, Andrew Sillato, Bushra Islam, Christopher Helenek, Joshua Rest, Melanie Cragan, Michelle Yang
student leaders: Dan Jian, Hua Huang, Manas Singh, Manuel Marques Vilar, Maryam Elfeky, Yuxuan Lin
students: Ethan Kim, Fritz Ebner, Genesis Ceron, Max Gazes, Mingrui Cui (Jack), Nadia Mathew, Qiongran Dong, Varun Gambhir, Wendy Zeng

title: Design of a Lateral Flow Assay and Exploration of Biopesticide Strategies for Clubroot in Canola
abstract: Plasmodiophora brassicae, the pathogen responsible for clubroot disease, significantly threatens Alberta's canola crops, leading to major yield losses. Current detection methods, such as PCR, can be expensive and time-consuming, limiting early intervention. Our project, C.R.O.P.S. (Clubroot Oversight and Prevention System), focuses on the initial design of a lateral flow assay (LFA) for rapid, on-site detection of the pathogen. Building on prior research, we engineered a nanobody and fragment antigen-binding (FAB) antibody to target the PbEL04 protein, unique to P. brassicae, and successfully expressed and purified these components for use in a proof-of-concept immunoassay. Additionally, we explored biopesticide strategies involving Bacillus subtilis and Pseudomonas fluorescens to reduce spore loads. Our main achievement lies in the early design stages of a competitive format LFA, which offers farmers a potential quick and accessible method for pathogen detection, complemented by future biopesticide solutions to manage clubroot disease.
advisors: Andrea Rivera, Aum Patel, Elisha Wong, Gregory Ian Robinson, Jason Luddu, Jenna Letain, Morgane Govone, Reece Martin
students: Aaron De Silva, Abigail Giacchetta, Ashkan Mosabeb-Omran, Ayden McCue, Charles Abdelmessih, Enrique Zaki Olvis, Erin Christel Oliveros, Esther Usen, Gracious Agwa, Mehzad Muqadas, Molly Aellen, Morgan jeffries, Nolan Fomradas, Odin schaefer, SarahAnn, Tarlan Goharian, Temi Agunlejika

title: Bo-Find: A rapid detection device for field-side diagnosis of bovine respiratory disease
abstract: Alberta, Canada is home to more than 4.5 million heads of cattle and is the largest cattle producing province. Bovine respiratory disease (BRD) has a significant economic impact on cattle production, as approximately 15% of cattle in North America are treated each year. BRD is caused by several different bacterial and viral pathogens. The four most common bacterial pathogens are Mannheimia haemolytica, Pasteurella multocida, Histophilus somni, and Mycoplasma bovis. Misdiagnosis of infected cattle can lead to an increase in antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs) and loss of antibiotic efficacy. Currently, only traditional bacterial culture and PCR analysis of the pathogens can provide accurate diagnosis; however, results can take up to a week. In order to quickly and successfully diagnose BRD pathogens in the field, we propose the use of a recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA)-based tool that can reliably give test results in under an hour without laborious sample preparation or analysis.
advisors: Jenna Letain, Sophia Bird
students: Arman Bidarian, Bobby Zhao, Carlos Saunders, Dana Omar, Elyse Burgess, Gabe Anoos, Ian Benkoczi, Jayabhishek Chaudhary, Jerry Wang, Jovin Bach, Keitaro Tatsuno, Khushi Patel, Marie Metz, Maya Walton, Mercy Awosoga, Nicole Burgess, Nora Laird, nour salmi, Ry Baker, Selina Sun, Zitong Wu

title: Sugar Control and Fiber Boost: Developing a Functional Food Produc
abstract: Our "Sugar Control and Fiber Boost" project aims to develop a novel functional food product designed to address the modern challenge of excessive sugar intake and its associated health risks, such as diabetes and obesity. This initiative responds to the growing need for dietary solutions that promote healthy blood sugar levels while enhancing gut health through increased prebiotic and dietary fiber content. Our research focuses on formulating a food product that reduces sugar content and enriches the diet with beneficial nutrients. Through rigorous experimentation and formulation adjustments, we aim to achieve an optimal balance of taste, nutritional benefits, and consumer acceptance. Ultimately, our goal is to contribute to public health by offering a convenient and effective dietary option that supports metabolic health and overall well-being in individuals prone to sugar-related health issues.
student leaders: JINJIA YAN, YIFAN DAI, YOUYI ZHENG
students: CHEN JIANG, KEYUE PAN, MINGYANG FU, SIYUAN YANG, SIYU LU, XUCHEN HAN, YANG XIAO, YINGTING WANG, ZHENYAO LUO

title: WAVEPLAST
abstract: PET plastic is one of the most commonly recycled plastics, often remade into various products. Over the past few decades, the uncontrolled disposal of PET plastic waste led to significant environmental damage. In response, industries and scientists are now focused on developing more cost-effective biological methods to break down PET plastic. Our research team concentrated on enhancing the activity of the PETase enzyme using site-directed mutagenesis, creating variant IsPETase enzymes. These IsPETase enzyme variants accelerate the breakdown of PET plastic into the monomers terephthalic acid (TPA)" and mono-(2-hydroxyethyl) terephthalate (MHET). Our goal is for these IsPETase enzyme variants to be adopted at the industrial level to be more viable for them to reduce plastic pollution and enable more efficient recycling of these monomers. The MHET will then be further degraded into TPA and ethylene glycol (EG) by an MHETase, a focus of our team's future work on MHETase biobricks design.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School
advisors: Sebastian Griesing
students: Chen Charley, Chen Jyun Siang, CHEN,YU-CHI, Chih-Chun Huang, Ethan Huang, Justin Lan, Kuan Yu Chen, Mandy Liao, Po-Han Chiang, Ruei-Yun Hsu, Tzu-Ning Hsu, Yan-Jyun Huang, Yu-Lin Chen, YU-YU LIN

title: SHIELD: A New Generation of Antimicrobials to Combat Resistance
abstract: The World Health Organization has declared antimicrobial resistance (AMR) as the biggest global public health threat of the 21st century. AMR occurs when microorganisms evolve to resist antibiotics, rendering traditional treatments ineffective- a process exacerbated by the current misuse of antibiotics in agriculture and healthcare. To combat AMR, Lambert iGEM created SHIELD: a versatile toolbox for developing novel antimicrobials that combat antibiotic-resistant diseases. SHIELD uses the CRISPR-interference system to silence critical genes in target organisms, alongside a toehold biosensor to measure the extent of gene silencing. We also developed SWORD: a machine learning software tool to optimize toehold design, and LabPilot: a frugal liquid handler to automate experimentation. SHIELD enables researchers to rapidly develop multiple antimicrobials for a single disease by targeting several genes, circumventing the emergence of resistance in a single gene without compromising overall treatment effectiveness, thus SHIELD empowers researchers to outpace antibiotic resistance.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School
students: Aditya Lagu, Andrew Jimerson, Aria Im, Avani Karthik, Avi Karamchandani, Claire Lee, Harsha Poonepalle, Jenny Christopher, Jeremy Chen, Julia Rho, Kavya Parimi, Matthew Murad, Nicholas Lockhart, Reva Badkundri, Sahasra Tatavarti, Sankalp Yeleti, Sarvajith Kujuluva, Sean Lee, Shashwat Balamurali, Srijyoth Ashok, Srishti Iyer, Swadha Surange

title: pHish and CHIPs
abstract: The CHIPS and Science Act is accelerating development of new semiconductor chip fabrication plants throughout the country; two are being built near Oneonta. Water is crucial to the process of manufacturing of these chips. Prior to release or recycling, fabricators purify their wastewater, processing millions of gallons of wastewater daily by adjusting pH and removing other contaminants. Real-time pH adjustment is a challenge at this scale. The goal of our project, pHish and CHIPS, is to build a pH-sensitive wastewater system using synthetic biology. In the presence of pH extremes, our device will "turn on" and release buffers to neutralize the water. With this device, pHish and CHIPS aims to promote sustainable manufacturing technologies for semiconductor fabrication. Our team is also investigating the ethical and regulatory landscape related to our project and how to better inform the public on what our project is about.
PIs: Kelly R. Gallagher, Eric Cooper, Jill Fielhaber
advisors: Andrew Piefer, Dan Patrone, Jazmine Reyes, John Dudek, William Vining
students: Adrianna Dugan, Alexia Darby, Ali, Blake Dieckmann, Chris, Connor Hanington, Elber Lopez Hernandez, Jena Dookie, John Reichel, Kayla, Kelly Acen, Makenna Ventuleth, Marie Box, Nick Aliani, Runyararo Chaora, Sarah, Taylor Schroeder, Zach

title: At Home Iron Level Detection Using Salivary Ferritin
abstract: Iron deficiency anemia affects close to 25% of the global population, most heavily those of lower socioeconomic status (StatPearls). Currently, iron levels are most commonly detected through serum samples which can be expensive and time consuming. We're creating a non-invasive method to measure iron levels by detecting salivary ferritin, a protein that stores iron, using a peptide or DNA aptamer. We are creating an inexpensive, electronic biosensor which binds to ferritin in the saliva sample, emitting a fluorescent signal proportional to the concentration of the ferritin analyte. This signal is then read by an Arduino sensor and readable iron level results are displayed. The aptamers were found through extensive literature review and computational docking. We're currently testing both aptamers using direct biotin-streptavidin ELISA and DNA shift assay as well as building the hardware component through optical methods and Arduino with a 3D printed casing.
advisors: Basia Fellner-Dublin, Sumanth Dara

title: Nucle.io: A DNA-Computing and CasX-Based Diagnostic Platform for Sepsis
abstract: Sepsis, a life-threatening immune response to infection accounting for 20% of all global deaths. Rapid, accurate diagnosis of sepsis is crucial: every hour of delayed treatment decreases the chance of survival by 7.6%. Current sepsis diagnostics--blood cultures, PCR--can take days to provide results. Sepsis is an evolving issue, with emerging antimicrobial resistances and high regional variation in pathogen prevalence. Nucle.io is a rapid diagnostic device that merges DNA computing and CRISPR to identify bacterial pathogens and antimicrobial resistance markers by amplifying RNA biomarkers, performing a sepsis panel in one reaction. Taking a blood sample, physicians can know within hours what species of bacteria is causing an infection and what antimicrobial resistance markers it carries. Three pillars-Catalyze (CasX), Compute (strand-displacement amplifier), and Classify (DNA-based Winner-Take-All Neural Network)-underlie its function. With this broad, modular, and re-engineerable diagnostics platform, McGill iGEM hopes to apply this diagnostic to and beyond sepsis.
nominations: Best Diagnostics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Part Collection, Undergrad+Best Software Tool, Undergrad
advisors: Chandler, Dan Voicu, hedizhou, Jasmin Coulombe-Huntington, Lukas Oesinghaus, Yueming Dong

title: BALANcE: Bowel Anti-inflammatory for Livestock utilizing Antimicrobial-peptide-based EcN
abstract: Our team visited a ranch and deepened our understanding of how chronic enteritis affects livestock production. We found that livestock suffering from chronic enteritis often exhibit significant dysbiosis of gut microbiota and strong inflammatory responses, similar to human inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Given the similarities between chronic enteritis of livestock and human IBD, we drew inspiration from the more mature human IBD therapy ideas to develop an efficient and low-cost treatment strategy for livestock. We utilized Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 with the SoxR/SoxS oxidative stress-type promoter to synthesize and secrete antimicrobial peptides (AMP) and Anti-TNF-?, reducing intestinal mucosa inflammation by targeting harmful bacteria and inflammatory factors. We engineered a PhiX174E cleavage protein module to release AMP and Anti-TNF-? extracellularly at the right time, and we confirmed its effectiveness through modelling. For biosafety, we also designed a suicide switch to prevent engineered strains from polluting the environment.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School
student leaders: Bowen Yao, ZAI NIU, ZIMU ZHANG, Ziqi Mi
students: Feiran Bian, Kevin, Matthew Tunan Jiang, Mengze Li, Pengyi Shao, Qianrong Yao, qiman yang, Sijia Liu, SITONG HE, Suya LYU, WENQIN QU, XU ZHU, YAWEN ZHENG, YIRONG WANG, Yuhan Shi, Yunuo Luan, ZEYUE XUE, zijun xu

title: progRAM: Programmable RNA Access Memory
abstract: Molecular recording is a novel way of tracking cellular signals in their biological context, alternative to microscopy and genomics. Our system, ProgRAM (Programmable RNA Access Memory), is based on RNA and thus a faster, transient and non-disruptive alternative. By employing the dCas13-ADAR system, it is possible to precisely record cellular events with a fluorescent protein "traffic light" readout, controlled by shifting the open reading frame resulting from sequential deamination of the start codon AUG to GUG. This allows for real-time visualization of cellular changes without invasive techniques like sequencing, following cell lysis. ProgRAM outperforms DNA-based systems by operating in the cytoplasm, enabling rapid responses and capturing transient signals that DNA systems miss. We extensively optimised our 5' UTRs and protein sequences for high-yield multi-frame expression. As verified with academic experts, our system could have promising real-world applications for temporal monitoring in developmental biology, conditional therapeutics and gene therapy quality control.
nominations: Best Software Tool, Overgrad

title: Project Ash Guard: Developing a Bioinsecticide to Combat the Invasive Emerald Ash Borer (EAB)
abstract: Project Ash Guard aims to develop a targeted, eco-friendly bioinsecticide to combat the invasive Emerald Ash Borer (EAB) beetle. By leveraging natural ecosystems and microbiomes, the project seeks to protect ash trees without relying on chemical pesticides, cutting, or burning, preserving the ecosystem and ash forests. EAB, a highly destructive beetle from Asia, threatens ash trees, which are essential to the environment, ecosystem, and economy. Current EAB management methods, such as chemical pesticides, pose significant environmental risks. Ash Guard utilizes the Cry8Da toxin, originating from Bacillus thuringiensis, which specifically targets the gut cells of EAB. We are engineering E. coli, Bacillus subtilis, and Saccharomyces cerevisiae to produce Cry8Da, with the goal of using S. cerevisiae, a yeast that naturally exists on ash tree bark. This approach will enable the bioinsecticide to naturally reside on ash trees, providing protection against EAB while minimizing environmental harm.

title: CerviCare - Urine-Based, Point-of-Care Cervical Precancer Screening
abstract: In 2022, lower- and middle-income countries (LMICs) bore 94% of cervical cancer deaths, highlighting global disparity in treating the fourth-most common cancer in women. Screening access is a major contributor to decreased mortality in higher-income countries; however, existing tools rely on equipment and personnel inaccessible in LMICs. We propose CerviCare: an accessible, urine-based point-of-care cervical precancer screening tool that bridges the screening gap by avoiding barriers like cost, refrigeration, patient discomfort, and reliance on specialized equipment. To screen for precancer, we target an emerging biomarker - microRNAs (miRNAs), which are increasingly viewed as viable targets. Through review, we identified three upregulated miRNAs in cervical precancer patient urine. We utilize miRNA-optimized toehold switches, RNA riboregulators that allow downstream protein expression when bound to a target RNA, to detect these miRNAs. By deploying these toeholds alongside a low-cost portable reader, users can screen themselves for cervical precancer in an accessible manner.
student leaders: Abhi Senthilkumar, Aditri Gadigi, Graham Ferguson, Jonathan Wu, Jonathon Meyer, Lauren Applegate, Mahita Kamalahasan, Mia Jocic, Navya Bansal, Renee Jaranson, Sarah Firdaus
