title: A Bacterial Approach to Gastrointestinal Pathogen Treatment
abstract: Bacterial antimicrobial resistance is a silent pandemic that is responsible for the deaths of millions of people annually and is a threat that continues to magnify. The UOregon iGEM team is developing a probiotic therapeutic to replace antibiotics in the treatment of gastrointestinal (Gl) tract infections. Our genetically modified strain of E. coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) is a modular platform that selectively identifies and destroys a targeted Gl pathogen. Our EcN probiotic will specifically recognize EHEC cells and deliver a malicious DNA payload through a type of horizontal gene transfer known as conjugation. As antibiotics decrease in efficacy over time, the development of a comprehensive treatment for bacterial infections is crucial and our EcN probiotic seeks to fill this growing need.
advisors: Andrew Holston, anissa benabbas, Keane Deas, Natanya Villegas, Samuel Rowe hinton
students: Aurélien, Bella Albiani, Drew, Eloy Vetto, Enoch, Favour, Jacob Villa, Katelyn Anderson, Maggie Trail, Yanapat

title: miRADAR: a paper-based test to simplify MS diagnosis
abstract: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a neurological disease that impacts nearly 3 million people worldwide. For 10% - 30% of patients in the Netherlands alone, proper diagnosis can take months or even years due to the lack of a specific MS biomarker. To simplify MS diagnosis, miRADAR designed an accessible diagnostic test based on dysregulated miRNA patterns in blood. To detect these miRNAs, our test consisted of miRNA amplification, an RNA threshold detection system, and output signal generation using toehold switch logic gate circuits. Through multiple models we found eight unique miRNA biomarkers distinguishing MS from similar diseases, and designed optimal logic gate circuits. As a proof-of-concept, we developed a cell-free paper-based test that successfully detected an MS-relevant miRNA. With our test, we provide a modular framework for miRNA-detection to improve diagnosis of MS and many other diseases.

title: Cell-free biosensor for endocrine-disrupting compounds using human hormone receptors
abstract: Endocrine Disrupting Compounds (EDCs) are a group of harmful chemicals that cause developmental and fertility issues, with potentially severe cumulative effects on public health in the near future. For the 2024 iGEM competition, the DTU Biobuilders are addressing this problem with ENDOSENSE, a low-cost, cell-free, novel biosensor based on the ROSALIND system. Our sensor utilizes human hormone-binding receptors and operates as an effect-based system capable of detecting non-predetermined targets. Its design allows for a rapid, cost-effective solution suitable for on-site applications. Additionally, we developed SENTINEL, a tool that uses natural language processing (NLP) to identify EDC interactions with target proteins, helping researchers analyze literature more efficiently and accelerating research. With ENDOSENSE and SENTINEL, DTU Biobuilders contribute to improving water quality, enhancing public health, and protecting marine biodiversity (SDGs 6, 3, 14), moving closer to a future where drinking tap water is safe for everyone.
nominations: Best Bioremediation Project, Overgrad+Best New Composite Part, Overgrad+Best Software Tool, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
PIs: Kristian Barrett, Aafke van Aalst, Lasse Wrang Meyer, Noël Jung, Signe Vangsgaard
students: Anna Lifousi, Antonios Otapasidis, Bartosz Dulski, Cristian Solimando, Dalimil Ott, Georgios Retsinias, Katerina Ciko, Konstantinos Mengos, Lumi, Mikkel Lyskjær Jensen, Reinis Muiznieks, Romisa Fakhari, Sirio Vittorio Feltrin, Tabea Schröder, Taisiya Baranova

title: BioMoon: a microbial biostimulant to grow plants on the Moon
abstract: We, the BioMoon team, have addressed one of the major issues for long-duration space travel: sustainable food supply. We have developed a biostimulant based on an engineered bacterium Pseudomonas Fluorescens that uses in situ resources to support plant growth directly on lunar soil. As a substrate for growing bacteria, we chose creatinine, a molecule present in human urine. We identified genes to metabolize creatinine, creA and crnA, and created a new strain that was able to grow on creatinine as the sole carbon and nitrogen source. The new pathway was implemented in silico into a genome-wide model of P. fluorescens that helped us predict metabolic fluxes. Moreover, we demonstrated that our engineered strain survived and could promote growth of a model plant in the laboratory on a lunar soil simulant. Capitalizing on these results, we built an entrepreneurship strategy to commercialize our biostimulant for space and terrestrial agriculture.
awards: Top 10+Best Space Project+Best New Composite Part

title: SurPFAS
abstract: SurPFAS tackles the issue of PFAS contamination, sadly notorious on our territory as well as in many other districts of the world. SurPFAS acts against the pollution of these synthetic chemicals in ground water, with a 360-degree overview on all the aspects involved in the purification process. SurPFAS derives from "surface", as we intend to surface-express two classes of degradative enzymes, laccases and dehalogenases, in Escherichia coli chassis. The best enzymatic candidates will be carefully selected through bioinformatic analysis. Genetic sequences will then be cloned into Escherichia coli, generating two populations of bacteria exposing PFAS-degrading enzymes on their surface. Our system also involves PFAS filtration from ground water and the following desorption from filtering substrates. The gathered PFAS will finally meet our engineered bacteria in a bioreactor, where the breakdown reaction will take place. We have also implemented a novel technology and sensor for PFAS detection throughout our pipeline.
nominations: Best Bioremediation Project, Undergrad

title: KN2OCKOUT - design of a system for reduction of nitrous oxide
abstract: Nitrous Oxide (N2O) is a potent greenhouse gas, with 300 times the 100-year warming potential of CO2. KN2OCKOUT aims to reduce emissions by using nitrous oxide reductase (N2OR). Our team enhanced the N2O reduction pathway in denitrifying bacteria by designing a two-plasmid system using the nos gene cluster from P.stutzeri ZoBell, with nosZ and nosR in the first plasmid, and nosC, nosDFY, nosL, ApbE and tatE in the second. In the lab, we built and transformed another insert to synthesise ComR in DH5? E.Coli. Upregulated comR leads to the downregulation of comC and more copper in the periplasm, thus increasing the rate of enzymatic activity. We also built a GFP reporter insert capable of measuring the efficacy of ComR. The design proposed would be a step forward in N2O bioremediation if achieved, specifically within the National Health Service, which annually releases 150,000 tonnes of N2O.
nominations: Best Model, High School
student leaders: Ewan Andre Frazao Pinheiro Astier, Lili Bi-bi Ghaffari-Gandy, Reya Karpe

title: The Affordable Library-based Pipeline for Accelerated Creation of single-domain Antibodies (A.L.P.A.C.A.)
abstract: Nanobodies are powerful tools because of their advantages over conventional antibodies, but their potential remains untapped due to lengthy and expensive development processes that employ animal immunisation and inefficient screening techniques. Addressing this, iGEM Leiden is introducing an efficient and animal-free pipeline for the development of nanobodies: ALPACA. This novel approach uses yeast surface display of bispecific nanobodies to screen a synthetic nanobody library for binders to an antigen-of-choice. ALPACA assesses the antigen-binding abilities of library nanobodies based on steric hindrance between the binding of the antigen to library nanobodies, and GFP to GFP-binding nanobodies. Desired antigen-binding yeast cells with reduced green fluorescence are collected through fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS). DNA of antigen-binding nanobodies is then easily retrieved for further development and production. Our ALPACA system supports the widespread implementation of nanobodies, removing large obstacles in their development, and foregoing the need for animal testing entirely.

title: Multi-Pathway Approach to a Bioengineered Fluorescent PFAS Sensor
abstract: PFAS (poly and per-fluoroalkyl substances) are contaminants characterized as "forever chemicals" due to their inability to break down, so increasingly widespread where 97% of Americans have traces in their blood (NHANES 2015). The health risk PFAS creates is not fully understood but has been implicated in several things including cancers. Our team attempted to combat this problem through three approaches attempting to develop an optimal PFAS detection circuit: the first uses the promoter prmA as it has been documented to upregulate gene expression when exposed to PFAS; the second uses a FAB-GFP-containing gene circuit which was hypothesized via molecular dynamics simulations to bind to PFAS because of its fatty acid structure; the third uses a synthetic transcription factor that responds to estradiol in yeast as PFOA may be a strong estrogen receptor agonist. Our wet lab results showed inconclusive for all of our constructs, thereby requiring more experimentation.
PIs: Scott Arico, Kalina, Michael Martin, Sabine Waigel
students: Akhila Nalladimma, Arjun Nalladimma, Aryan Shah, Bryan O'Toole, Charvi Nambi, Chaturya Sree Paladugu, Daniel Jiang, Edward Kim, Emma Hyman, Gowshik Lavan Ramanathan, James Marshall, Joanna Lee, Kalp Poladia, Leon Guo, Samuel Kingston, Shlok Jena, Shruti Senthilnathan, Vishwaa Kannan

title: MINERAL
abstract: Mineral is dedicated to addressing heavy metal contamination in water. We engineered *E. coli* to efficiently absorb nickel ions by introducing modules for nickel absorption and tolerance. Additionally, we created a reaction vessel by loading hydrogenase into carboxysomes, enabling efficient nickel reduction. To supply hydrogen for the reaction, we established an adhesion system between *E. coli* and cyanobacteria. These concepts have been well-validated, and the project's safety was tested using *Caenorhabditis elegans*. We also conducted inclusive education targeting the autism community. The project's commercial potential has been developed effectively, and we created validated software to simulate the stress different parts impose on chassis organisms.
nominations: Best Bioremediation Project, Undergrad+Best Measurement, Undergrad+Inclusivity Award, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad

title: flouroshield
abstract: engineer yeast and pseudomonas flourescens to construct a dual microorganism system to fight chytrid fungus. among them , the yeast should has a fungal hormone activated lactose synthesis pathway, and will produce lactose when chytrid fungus exists. while the P.F.will contain a lac operating system controlled anti fungal peptide secretion function, it will produce Brevenin1-Ma when recieving the lactose signal.

advisors: Xiangyu Wang
students: Amina, Boxuan Han, chenziqi, Gao Geman, GuoRun Wu, Jiahao Xu, Jincheng Liang, Junya Zhan, Ruixuan Yuan, Ruiyou Yuan, Siyuan Wei, Weiwei Lian, Xin Li, Yanlin Ren, Yehan Qu, Yiliang Wu, Yuan Gao, Yujiao Han, Yujie Shi, Yunduo Hao, Zhang Xinyuan, Zhe Jing

title: ReFiBa - Enzyme based Recycling of textile Fibers using Bacillus subtilis
abstract: The exponential growth in global textile production has led to a worrying increase in textile waste, requiring the development of efficient recycling methods. Our team is addressing this issue by focusing on the degradation of the main components of clothing, cotton (cellulose) and polyester (PET), using cellulases and PETases. The prokaryotic model organism Bacillus subtilis is applied for protein expression. We are exploring two enzyme expression systems: first, screening of different secreted and intracellular enzymes for the most promising and suitable candidates, and second, using these enzymes for immobilisation on the surface of endospores, providing resistance to harsh conditions and improving enzyme reusability. Both approaches aim to facilitate the degradation of mixed textiles into reusable chemicals. Through our project ReFiBa, we aim to develop a circular economy concept that promotes sustainable textile recycling and offers a promising solution to the global textile waste problem.
nominations: Best Fashion & Cosmetics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best New Composite Part, Overgrad
student leaders: Aaron Anselmi, Cosima Sagurna, Lilli Kratzer, Tatiana Khorovich
students: Gabriel Pinto, Jenny Sauermann, Josephine Borbás, Julia Schmidt, Katrin Lehmann, Linda Krause, Lucas Kullmann, Lukas Minack, Matti Lehmann, Max Herrmann, Paula Müller, Rico Steinert, Sophie Zieschang, Wenjing Tao

title: BovEco: A Novel Approach to Fighting Enteric Methane Emissions via Engineered Microalgae and GMO Crops
abstract: Enteric emissions from ruminants are a major source of methane, a greenhouse gas 84 times more potent than carbon dioxide. Certain feed additives exist with methane-reducing effects, however these products suffer from low uptake due to the high cost and lack of incentives for farmers to purchase them. The Waterloo team presents BovEco, a novel, sustainable, and conceptually cost-effective methane-reduction solution. Our work involves 2 delivery methods of a prophage-derived lytic enzyme proven to target methanogens and induce a rumenal microbiome shift. First, we are engineering C. vulgaris microalgae to express this protein: the cells will stabilize the protein but degrade in the rumen, simultaneously releasing the active enzyme and providing nutritional benefits. Our final vision revolves around GMO crops already fed to ruminants, intended to minimize production and cost-related challenges.
student leaders: Aaren Arasaratnam, Bethany Chan, Emma Llewellyn, Mahnoor Butt, Sasha Dhingra, Yash Soobarah
students: Aadila Zakir Hussain, Akshay, Alexandra D'Souza, Aliyah Warsi, Amberlee Morgan, Anh Mai, Athena Chong, Ayana Pak, Ayesha Waseem, Brianna Thomas, Chloe Ding, Curtis Yeung, David Makarczyk, Douglas Moulton, Elysia Wang, Emily Wang, Felix Tham, Hannah Tao, Ian T, Isabella D'Costa, Jashan Khangura, Kaviya Gopalakrishnan, Lauren Robinson, Leigh Hannah, Michael, Milena Gojsevic, Naomi Eshetu, Noura Abdelrazec, Ray Shamshoum, Rebekah Xing, Rhyan McLean, Shilpa Rao, Stefan Grinchenko, Stephanie Kpordzih, Sydney Sherwood, Timea Siket, Trisha, Veran, Yusra Pervez

title: An Engineered Probiotic for Gliadin Degradation: A Novel Approach for Celiac Disease Management
abstract: Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder affecting approximately 1% of the global population triggered by gluten, a protein found in various grains. For those affected, gluten ingestion damages the small intestine, resulting in severe inflammation. Currently, the only effective treatment is a strict gluten-free diet, a challenging endeavor given gluten's prevalence in various foods. Inspired by Austin's vibrant gluten-free community, we aim to develop a probiotic to degrade gliadin, the primary immunogenic component of gluten. We are engineering a bacterium that will colonize the gut and secrete gliadin-degrading enzymes for sustainable and localized degradation of gluten. Our project centers on the transformation of lactic acid bacteria with enzyme and secretion constructs under the control of fine-tuned constitutive promoters. Additionally, we've isolated novel strains from fermented foods to expand our library of gluten-degrading bacteria. Our solution will shield those with celiac disease against cross-contamination, reducing stress associated with their dietary restrictions.
nominations: Best Food & Nutrition Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Anthony VanDieren
student leaders: Annie Yu, Ariana Hernandez, Paul Andega, Syna Sogi
students: Daniel Kazour, Dhruv Aggarwal, Elizabeth Suh, Eunsu Kim, Eva Buck, Francesca Abraham, Naveen Pillai, Ranudhi Nanayakkara, Rohan Sharma, Romanus Ike, Rosie Du, Soumya Appalla, Sushma Dadlani, Varshitha Lalam

title: Magnifica mirifica: pathway to puerarin!
abstract: The Thailand-RIS team aims to make neurodegenerative disease treatments more accessible by developing a sustainable method for producing puerarin, genistein, and daidzein, all isoflavonoids with neuroprotective properties. Currently, the production of these isoflavonoids is costly, labor-intensive, and time-consuming. This process would be made more efficient by transferring the key enzymes in the isoflavonoid pathway responsible for producing these compounds from its native plant, Pueraria lobata v. mirifica, to a more sustainable and less resource-intensive plant, Nicotiana benthamiana, through Agrobacterium vector-mediated infiltration. The enzymes transferred include chalcone synthase (PmCHS), chalcone reductase (PmCHR), chalcone isomerase (PmCHI), isoflavone synthase (PmIFS), 2-hydroxyisoflavanone (PmHID), and C-glycosyltransferase (PmC-UGT). The team successfully modified N. Benthamiana and established proof of concept by finding traces of all 3 of the targeted compounds, with genistein being the most prominently detected and puerarin being minimally detected.
nominations: Best Part Collection, High School
students: Aiko, Chalat (Jotun) Lertrattanachaikij, Great, Jia Lee, Keith, Natprima (Wawa) Sae-Heng, Natthaya Soponpitsut, Nick, Pinrhada (Pin) Nantakwang, Rattanawalee Limsomboon, Siravij Ninyawee, Tanatpat Chakratok, Tarawin (Win) Kiatlertpongsa, Thamonnut Ampornkotchakorn, Tyna MacPherson Sethaputra, Voranan Puengchanchaikul, Yongnian(Tony) Xu

title: REBolutionising Drug Delivery: Repurposing Mechanical Proteins for Endosomal Escape
abstract: Endosomal escape is a crucial rate-limiting step for the cellular uptake of drugs; this greatly diminishes the panel of potential drugs that can be used, as cells degrade the vast majority of molecules they might sequester in their endosomes or lysosomes. We looked to refractile bodies (R bodies) for a solution -- these are enormous bacterial polymer proteins that have been shown to burst paramecial food vacuoles in acid-activated extension. We envisioned that this mechanism could be repurposed to rupture endosomes and lysosomes to administer therapeutics directly into a cell's cytosol. We have designed a series of R body proteins with conjugation handles to attach drugs or excipients to them, and conducted a series of in vitro assays to demonstrate their potential as a modular chassis for drug delivery. We believe our simple, brute-force mechanical solution to endosomal escape will improve drug potency and minimize off-target toxicity --REBolutionising drug delivery.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, Undergrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Undergrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad
students: Adnan Hajdarpasic, Albert Tang, Carlo Famularo, Catherine Curry, Eleana Xu, He-Shyan Balnave, Jade McClure, Lior Yoffe, Marco de Paulis, Victoria Kolmac

title: BioGlimmer: Synthetic Guanine Crystals for Sustainable Cosmetics
abstract: iGEM Stockholm presents BioGlimmer: a synthetic biology solution for growing guanine crystals using E. coli. The cosmetic ingredients guanine crystal and mica are commonly sourced from either fish scales or mining, respectively. Both acquisition methods come with problems: fish scale harvesting is non-vegan and disruptive of ecosystems, and mining is harmful to the environment and has commonly unethical labor practices. A recent research article by Pavan et al. (2023) described native guanine crystal production in Aeromonas strains. We sought to transfer the genetic principles of these bacteria to E. coli, a more manageable and industrially scalable strain. In our model, we transform the bacteria with two genetic systems: guaA and guaB genes to enhance guanine synthesis, and CRISPRi silencing of the guanine degradation genes guaD and xdh. In concert, these two systems we hypothesise will result in guanine accumulation and eventually vegan and ethical guanine crystal formation.
students: Alex, Carmen de Ancos Jimeno, Diandra Daumiller, Dimitrios Tsagkogiannis, Edna Lam, Hongge Wang, Jiaxin Wu, Juliana Baranova, Mai Nguyen, Maria Gustavsson, Meghana Bhat, Teodora Pavlicu

title: Developing a novel, rapid, on-site, diagnostic test for Bovine Tuberculosis
abstract: Bovine Tuberculosis (bTB) is a chronic infectious disease predominately infecting cattle and is endemic in South-West England. Testing regimes are critical to managing this disease, however the most common testing system is low in sensitivity, slow, and stressful for cattle and farmers. We hope to improve the wellbeing and protect the livelihoods of farmers by developing a rapid and more specific bTB test. To do this we are developing two testing methods, one with an engineered Cas13a protein to detect RNA immune response biomarkers and the other using a Cas12a protein to detect specific bTB bacteria DNA sequences. These will both have the effect of cleaving the fluorophore from the quencher of the fluorescent probe to create a fluorescent response in the case of a positive result. Our designs have been informed and altered based on the input of relevant stakeholders throughout the entire process
nominations: Best Diagnostics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Measurement, Undergrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad
PIs: John Love, Chloe Singleton, Mark Hewlett
students: Anouska Hall, Benjamin Holdstock, Ellin Lee, George Lancaster, Louise Brown, Nigella Marx, Oliver Parker, Rebecca Kilmartin, Ruby Croxton, Talia Khan, Thomas Morris, Yara ElMenyawy

title: Reeform - Engineering the Coral Microbiome
abstract: Corals, though occupying less than 1% of the ocean's surface, support a quarter of marine life. They are increasingly threatened by rising temperatures and diseases. Coral microbiomes play a key role in traits like heat tolerance and pathogen defense. This research seeks to enhance these traits using synthetic biology. Genes related to heat tolerance and pathogen defense were overexpressed in Symbiodiniaceae and Endozoicomonas. We conducted over 40 bacterial transformations, building 17 transcriptional units via Golden Gate Assembly. Additionally, we developed a bioinformatics pipeline, identifying over 500 gene regulatory elements. Lastly, we designed a microfluidic electroporation device, improving its fabrication with 3D printing to increase transformation efficiency.
nominations: Best Conservation Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Yong-Ak Song, Andras Gyorgy, Ibrahim Chehade
student leaders: Afomia Mengistu, Fatima Rebh, Sevinch Rakhmon-Zoda
students: Abdullah Salman, Aknur, Diana, Heesung Tae, Jheel Thanki, Mandy, Milena Bisenic, Sanshika Garg, Swostik Pati, Tariro Gurudza, Yugmee Gidiya

title: Albumin binding proteins for improved administration of cephalosporin class antibiotics
abstract: Antibiotics can trigger a variety of adverse drug responses. Many of these can be dose dependent. Our team looked at the case of several cephalosporin class antibiotics which normally are quickly removed from the bloodstream and thus require administration multiple times each day. We designed proteins to carry the antibiotics via linkers and to bind to human serum albumin(HSA) in order to extend the lifetime of drugs. When bound to albumin the antibiotics will not be filtered from the bloodstream. Our team then modeled the necessary binding parameters of protein to albumin needed in order to create a feasible solution that would both reduce the overall amount of antibiotic used as well as the excess concentration in the blood.
student leaders: Addie Lomax, Elena Baraznenok, Emily Sperry, Ethan Cheney, Katherine Lai, Madeline Ho, Om Sahaym, Owen Knight, Xinyi Wang
students: Aimee Furlan, Akira Morishita, Alex Gratch, Andrew Kesapradist, Angela R. Zheng, Daphne Suen, Ethan Tran, Grace Hwang, Grace Kusol, Gurnoor Sandhu, Heidi Neuman, Ivy Lee, Jaiden Poon, Kristan Dela Cruz, Nathen Qing, Rittika Saha, Simon Du, Wendy Wang, Wenyu Shi, Zijing Wei

title: MetaboMender: a comprehensive probiotic platform for treating gut dysbiosis
abstract: The human gut microbiota contains trillions of microorganisms, and it influences the human health from various aspects. Gut dysbiosis is caused when the balance of gut microbiota is disrupted, leading to disease conditions. In China, gut dieases and dysbiosis are becoming more prevalent, meaning the need for treatment. MetaboMender is designated to detect, monitor, and regulate the concentration of specific gut metabolites through a food input in order to cure and prevent gut dysbiosis. We designed two programmable genetic systems for beneficial and harmful metabolites. Both system use deoxycholic acid as an indicator of food intake to trigger the subsequent responses. We focused on butyrate and indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) as the beneficial and harmful metabolites, respectively. When butyrate level is low, our platform will supplement butyrate by expressing butyrate-producing enzymes. On the other hand, when IAA level is too high, our platform will express IAA-degrading enzymes to reduce excessive IAA.
nominations: Best Wiki, High School
PIs: Ning Kong, Guanqiao Ding, Wanji Li
instructors: Chujing Wu, Haoyang Diao, Huyang Zhang, Shuo Zhu, Yuan Xia, Ziyue Lei
