students: Canice Yeo, Chenyi Yang, Chi-hua Xing, Feike Lu, Gengzi, Guochen Dong, Jifei Yang, Jingle Hu, Juhuan He, Keyu Wang, Mufeng Han, renata, rongkuang, Weining Li, Yinuo Li, Yuehan Huang, Yu He

title: Eat Methane!
abstract: Greenhouse gasses play a significant role in climate change, with carbon dioxide contributing to 79.7% of total emissions. However, while CO2 is abundant, it is not the most potent greenhouse gas. Methane has 86 times the warming impact of CO2 over 20 years yet comprising only 11.1% of emissions. Its severe environmental impact contributes to the formation of ground-level ozone, which damages crops and poses significant health risks. Thus, reducing methane emissions offers a more effective climate change strategy than focusing solely on CO2. Landfills are major methane sources, contributing to 17.1% of emissions in the United States. Our project aims to address this issue by genetically modifying the soil bacterium Bacillus subtilis to produce enzymes that convert methane into compounds that boost soil fertility. This innovative approach reduces methane emissions while enhancing soil health.
advisors: Wilfred Tang
students: Alyssa Tang, Anandita Mukherjee, Anjali A, Anvesha, Aurovik, Khushi Thakkar, MeiLin Hansen, Sameer Rajdev, Seerat, Yuvraj Singh, Zoya Khare

title: SanaGel: Targeted ductal carcinoma bacteriotherapy
abstract: SanaGel is an innovative targeted ductal carcinoma bacteriotherapy developed using synthetic biology, ??molecular biology, and materials science methods. The system comprises non-pathogenic Escherichia coli genetically engineered to produce a tumor-targeting peptide that selectively binds cell surfaces of cancer cells and forms pores, leading to tumor cell burst and eradication. Aside from the peptide's efficiency, we have implemented a Kill Switch (Suicide Gene) to ensure higher levels of safety control. Modified bacteria are encapsulated into agarose and chitosan-based hydrogel scaffolds, solidifying upon temperature rise after the intratumoral injection. Due to the careful fine-tuning of the gel's pores and sol-gel transition temperatures, hydrogels minimize bacterial leakage and ensure the system's local action. The project has the potential of opening the door to the development of novel sustainable cancer therapeutics that are not only efficient but also exhibit reduced systemic side effects on the healthy cells of patients.
nominations: Best Oncology Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Hardware, Undergrad
students: Abylaikhan Seraliyev, Adil Ispambetov, Akbota, Alan Berdigaliyev, Alexandr Alpatov, Anastassiya Tyazhelova, Anuar Ulakov, Arailym Myrzagaliyeva, Artyom German, Assel Kenzhebay, Assem Zhannatova, Dana Khairetdinova, Diana Bekeshova, Dulat Minas, Gulnaz Ingkar, Ilnur, Ilyas, Kamilya Beisembayeva, Makpal Akishova, Mukhammeddulat Olzhabay, Nuriya Nurlankyzy, Rauan Muratuly, Temirlan Karatay, Tomiris Kudassova, Yernur Kenzhegazin

title: An in vivo SARS-CoV-2 nsp5 inhibitor screening platform
abstract: The COVID pandemic has very serious consequences, killing more than 7 million people worldwide since its initiation in 2019. Despite the worldwide efforts leading to effective control of the pandemic, the continuous emergence of viral variants has necessitated the ongoing development of SARS-CoV-2 inhibitors. The main protease nsp5 plays a major role in the virus's life cycle, and also serves as an important drug target for the virus. Our project primarily aims to develop an efficient and reliable in vivo nsp5 inhibitor screening system based on FlipGFP. Additionally, we also desire to investigate the possibility of using nsp5, a sequence-specific protease, as a tool enzyme for removing recombinant tags during protein purification
advisors: Annie Zhang, Eva
student leaders: Arthur, David, Serina, Yintong Chen, Yvette
students: Alan Xu, Andrew, Charles, Creeper, Douglas, Henry He, Jingwen Cai, Kara, Langyan Zhu, Leah, Leah, Leon, Linda, Peini Dai, Shani W, Tim Mu, Wayne, yiran liu, Yiya Zhu, Zhang Yuyan, !Zoë, ???, ??, ???, ???

title: SHEDer(Saliva-Based HBV Early Detector)
abstract: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection remains a global concern, even with the implement of HBV vaccination. The current HBV detection is mainly blood serum-based, which is invasive, expensive and needs some waiting time to obtain the test results. Our project aims to develop a rapid, reliable, and low-cost detection system for HBV virus infection using the CRISPR/Cas12 and RPA technologies combined in one-pot assay to facilitate the screening and treatment of Hepatitis B disease.
advisors: Juan SANG
student leaders: Alina, Andy, Jerry, Jialin Tian, Qiyun Zhang, Yuying, Zenas Deng
students: Ailin Jiang, desiree, Ethan, Fang, Fannie Zheng, Fred, gloria, jagger, Leo, Luke, Rebecca Wang, Richard Zhang, Wang Xinming, Wang Yuchen, William, Yuanxiang Liu, Zack, Zhang, Zhangcensijia, Zhihan Lou, ????, ???

title: AgroNeedle: Harnessing Synthetic Biology and Microneedle Technology for Advanced Antimicrobial Solutions in Agriculture
abstract: AgroNeedle integrates synthetic biology with microneedle technology to deliver nutrients, pesticides, and antimicrobial agents directly to plants, revolutionizing agricultural practices. By enabling precise, localized delivery, this approach enhances the efficiency of nutrient and pesticide use while minimizing environmental impact, such as runoff and overuse of chemicals. The microneedles, designed for plant-specific applications, allow controlled release of agrochemicals, promoting sustainable farming practices. Additionally, leveraging synthetic biology enables the incorporation of advanced antimicrobial solutions, targeting plant pathogens effectively while reducing the reliance on traditional chemical treatments, contributing to healthier crops and ecosystems.
advisors: Fang Ba
student leaders: Andrew Wu, Jiaqi Shen, Julia, lzsnn, Penny, Zeyu Chen
students: Abby, ALEX, Cindy, Daniel Lin, Danny, Dorothy, Ethan, Fiona, George, Gilbertdb11, Harry, Huanghao, John, Melinda, steve, Taylor, yang, Yolanda

title: D.N.Aid: Repairing UV Radiation-Induced DNA Damage
abstract: UV radiation poses a threat to many populations, from astronauts to marine organisms, in the form of DNA damage in cells. Preventive measures have primarily focused on minimizing exposure to harmful UV rays. Sunscreen formulations, which contain UV-filtering compounds, represent a widely adopted approach to protect human skin. For our project, we decided to focus on maximizing the ability of photolyase to repair common types of DNA damage, particularly cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers (CPDs) and pyrimidine-pyrimidone (6-4) photoproducts, within human skin cells. We plan to combine a cell penetrating peptide (specifically the TAT peptide from the HIV virus), a nuclear localization signal (from the SV40 Large T-antigen), and either a 6-4 photolyase protein (from Arabidopsis thaliana) or a CPD photolyase protein (from zebrafish) in one fusion protein, with linker sequences between each component to allow the protein to fold properly.
students: Aadit Jain, Andy Ryou, AndyTol, Joyce Kwack, Lauren, Madhav, Mason, Megan, Peyton Slape, Pukaphol Thienpreecha, Robert Morrison, Ryan, Ryoka, Simeon, Soyun, Thomas, William, Yubin

title: REPARO: Resolution of Eco-friendly Paper-purification, Alternative Recovery and Optimization
abstract: The rapid population growth has driven heavy demands for paper, leading to extensive deforestation and disturbing the ecological balance, thereby exacerbating the climate crisis. Enhancing the recycling of waste paper can mitigate deforestation, offering a significant contribution to addressing the climate crisis. Inspired by this, our project aims to investigate the current state and challenges of waste paper recycling in our REPARO project, we designed and developed an unprecedented deinking method based on synthetic biology, which could serve as a viable alternative to the chemical method on the industry scale. The implementation of our project holds immense potential to propel technological advancement and industrial upgrading within the waste paper recycling industry. Our project aims to introduce advanced biotechnology and environmental protection concepts to enhance the entire industry's production efficiency, product quality, and environmental protection level, thereby strengthening the industry's competitiveness and promoting the development of the circular economy.
nominations: Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad
instructors: Jiacheng Huang, Junhong Chen, Langxing Liao
advisors: CHERNFANG CHENG, Hao Li, Honglin Song, Kaiyang Wu, Kun Yang, Limin Qiu, Liuqin Wu, Suhang Xu, Tantan Cheng, Xinyi Yang, Yanhao Chen, Yannan You, Yihan Lu, Ziyan Han
students: Chenxin, JIA LI, Jingwen Wang, Mingzheng Fang, Rongqi Chen, Ruohan Jiang, S_sf, Xiaoxiao Zhang, Xinran Lyu, Yifei Yin, Yi Zhang, Yuhan Zou, Zhengyang Mo, Zimo Liu

title: COALES - Clinical on-target Adhesive LLPS engineered system
abstract: It is often said that if a medicine has no side effects, it's unlikely to work. Some of the most serious side effect causing drugs are chemotherapeutic drugs. COALES introduces a novel solution through targeted cancer therapy, leveraging Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation (LLPS) to enhance drug delivery precision. We aim to concentrate therapeutic agents like doxorubicin specifically, improving its effectiveness and reducing side effects. Traditional cancer therapies often result in severe toxicity and are costly, limiting access for many patients. With COALES, we hope to offer a more affordable, scalable, and accessible treatment alternative. COALES holds the potential to be adapted for various cancer types, offering an alternative to how cancer could be treated in the future. Throughout our project, we engaged in various activities related to Integrated Human Practices and Education to raise awareness and to obtain comprehensive knowledge.
advisors: Alba, Shiqi Wang
students: Ardalan Rahimipour, Mahin Irfan, Nicholas Farrell Wijaya, Sazzad Shahrear, Shamila Hussain, Umamaheswari Umasankar, Viivi Mäkinen

title: VIPR: Virus-Inspired Particle Recombinant Vaccine for Schistosomiasis
abstract: Schistosomiasis is a World Health Organization (WHO)-listed Neglected Tropical Disease characterized by the blood-dwelling helminths. Currently, all schistosomiasis vaccine candidates based on recombinant subunit antigens have encountered setbacks at various stages of clinical trials, underscoring the formidable challenges in vaccine development. Critically, these subunit vaccines lack the three-dimensional macrostructure necessary for optimal recognition by B cells as pathogenic. Drawing inspiration from Professor Mark Howarth's group's SpyCatcher-SpyTag system, a protein couple tool for peptide and protein ligation, our objective is to conjugate schistosomiasis antigens on virus-like-particle (VLP) scaffold to create high-density antigen nanoparticles to enhance vaccine immunogenicity. Together with a batch of novel antigens discovered in January 2024 through unbiased phage display, our aim is to present a diverse range of schistosomiasis antigens on VLPs. Thanks to the modularity of our VIPR, we hope to accelerate vaccine development and antigen screening for helminth diseases with a complex life cycle.
nominations: Best Infectious Diseases Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
student leaders: Clara Deimling, Isabella O'Reilly, Joshua Pixley, Miguel Saucedo, Sneha Agarwal, Symonne Liu, Theresa Christiansen, Tommy Walsh, Xavier Rousseau
students: Bloom Lerngutai, Della Waldman, Emily Scott, Ethan Eig, Henry Bloom, Jaimny, Jessica Martinez Martinez, Manya Lalwani, Melody, Nick Emerton, Nico, Nicole Liu, Pierce Hoenigman, Rishi Basu, Shaherzad Chawdree, Shaniya, Sofia, Ugonna Egbuchulam, Yazeed, Zane

title: MycoMiners Remediations
abstract: In a country built largely on resource extraction, mining continues to shape Canada's landscapes and its people. Unfortunately, the impacts of mining cannot be ignored. Mine effluent - water originating from mine sites negatively impacts ecosystems and the communities living along contaminated waterways. Treating mining effluent is critical to maintain sustainable mining practices, conventional systems are often expensive and ineffective in reaching the small concentrations of contaminants required. We aim to sequester heavy metals from mining wastewater using a microbial process. A major problem with current mining practices is that they create highly acid environments that many organisms cannot tolerate. To create a bioremediation vector, we need to address the highly acidic environment that allows our microbe to be used in situ. While our initial goal is heavy metal sequestration, we are considering possible future methods for recovery of metals for circularity in the mining industry.
advisors: Anastasia Gherghi, Brittany Greco, Gabriel Aguiar-Tawil, Zoe Katz
student leaders: Aiden, Amanda Catherine Peragine, Nicol Asya Lulkin
students: Alex, Andrae, Buddha, Dorothea Davidson, Herschel Patel, Huyen Tran Pham, Karin Etemadi, Mark, Michelle Polonsky, Natalia Romanova, Nguyen Bach Huyen Dinh, Noah Kestenbaum, Peter Abou Kassam, Queena Ying-En Ng, Rev, Sarah Alvarez, Vassilios Michailidis

title: ENEducer
abstract: In recent years, initiatives like the Artemis Project have explored the potential for extraterrestrial resource acquisition and human habitation. However, due to the detrimental effects of space radiation and ultraviolet light, conventional microorganisms struggle to survive, necessitating a synthetic biology approach that is radiation-resistant. Our project addresses the critical challenge of energy production in space, proposing a solution through synthetic biology. We engineered Shewanella, an electrochemically active bacterium, by incorporating the ENEducer mechanism to not only protect it from radiation but also convert that radiation into usable energy. Additionally, a kill switch was integrated for biosafety. This system offers promising potential for developing microorganisms capable of producing valuable substances in space while converting radiation into energy, with broad applicability across various microbial species.
students: Ayano Kashiwakura, Harima Takeuchi, Haruki Inoue, Jalin Mitsuyosi, Jun Yamanoha, Kanna Yasunobu, Manaka Suzuki, Riona Asaeda, Ryunosuke Hoshide, Saho Takahashi, Saki Ikebuchi, Shunta Saito, Shunya Yoneyama, Yasunari Watanabe, Yui Naito, Yui Tamanaha, Yuki Matsunaga, Yuta Baba

title: CAAPI: Coffee ArabicA Protected by Iturin
abstract: Coffee Leaf Rust (CLR), caused by Hemileia vastatrix, severely impacts global coffee production, threatening farmers' livelihoods. Our project addresses CLR by enhancing the production of Iturin A, an antifungal lipopeptide from Bacillus subtilis ATCC 13952. Using homologous recombination, we aim to replace the native Iturin operon promoter with a stronger dual-promoter to boost Iturin A synthesis. This modification will be integrated into the chromosomal DNA of B. subtilis for stability. Additionally, we are developing a machine learning model that predicts coffee yields by analyzing historical data and environmental conditions. By offering a sustainable alternative to chemical fungicides, our approach not only targets CLR directly but also minimizes environmental harm. This project has the potential to protect coffee crops, improve farmers' livelihoods, and serve as a model for addressing other agricultural diseases through genetic interventions.
advisors: Aditi Balasubramani, Akanksha kelkar, Aritro Biswas, Pooja Agarwal, Riyaa Ganla, Vidhula Jessica I
students: Angela, Anirudh Saravanan, Deepali Vengala, Harini, Hita, Karan, Kaushika, Lavanya Dalmia, Mihika Chitre, Navya Subramanian Anantharaman, Nithya, Ram P Shetty, Sania Serrao, Shyaam Haridas, Tanaya Sengupta, Varshith Jalla, Vignesh Vijaysekhar, Zaid

title: Click Virus
abstract: To reduce the difficulty of mammalian virus engineering in synthetic biology, we have successfully created an easy-to-customize viral chassis, named Click Virus, based on the principles of artificial translation and click reaction. Click Virus is a genetically engineered vaccinia virus with modified A27L membrane protein containing three 4-azido-L-phenylalanine (AzF) residues. To incorporate the unnatural amino acid AzF to A27L, we mutated three phenylalanine codons to amber suppressor codons (TAG) which were then translated into AzF by an artificial translation system involving amber suppressor tRNA and azidophenylalanine-specific tyrosyl-tRNA synthetase. The azido groups can be covalently linked to any customized molecules via click reactions of azido and dibenzocyclooctyne (DBCO), to obtain different engineered viruses for a wide variety of applications, such as targeting delivery of genes, oncolytic virus and vaccine carrier. Using folate-linked Click Virus, we achieved the directed infection to cells overexpressing folate receptors, preliminarily verifying the reliability of Click Virus.
PIs: Ye Qiu, Haijun Tu, Huairong Pan, LIYANG SHI, Zhenming Jin
advisors: Lian Zhonghao, Xuyang Gu
student leaders: Kailin Yang, Wenrui Gao, Yixue Wu, Yuchen Liang
students: Dufeng Xiong, Jia Liang Yang, Jianan Li, Liu xinkai, Qihao Zong, qisheng huang, Ruihong Qu, Ruyi Shen, Weicen Hao, Xiangyu Liu, Yupu Ge, yuqi Wu, zhang ke jia

title: BIOSnare : when bacterial cellulose meets a colored bioglue producing yeast
abstract: Given global challenges like food insecurity and environmental degradation, it's needed to protect agriculture and households from harmful insects to reduce food waste. BioSnare addresses this problem by developing a 100% bio-based and biodegradable adhesive patch designed to capture pests. Using a co-culture of Komagataeibacter rhaeticus, a cellulose-producing bacterium, and genetically modified Saccharomyces cerevisiae, our system produces functionalized cellulose equipped with adhesive properties and specific colors to attract target pests. The yeast is engineered to secrete a fusion of the barnacle-derived protein Cp19k and spider silk-derived Masp1 for strong adhesion, alongside yellow chromoprotein fwYellow to attract insects like the Suzuki fly. Cellulose-binding domains (CBD) ensure that these proteins adhere to the cellulose matrix, creating a biodegradable trap. BioSnare provides a versatile concept promising alternative to conventional insecticides and traps, which pollute the environment. It aims to protect agriculture and households while promoting environmental sustainability.
advisors: Alexandre Soulard
students: Aymeric Perrel, Camille Sarrazin, Flavie FILECCIA, Haidi Hadad, Jeanne Lorrain, Jess Philippon, Lilya Wreyford, Marion Fiorucci, Morjiane TABOUT, Perrine Ferdinand, Samira Zaazaa

title: ROSA: A Riboswitch-Based Biomarker Detection System
abstract: Gene-circuit-based sensors have significantly advanced medical diagnostics by enabling sensitive and specific biomarker detection. However, developing point-of-care diagnostics that are timely, cost-effective, and minimally invasive remains challenging. Our project, ROSA (Riboswitch Operated Sensor Apparatus), addresses this by creating a versatile, proof-of-concept detection method applicable in various medical settings. We engineered a riboswitch-based system to detect the biomarker CA125, demonstrating the simplicity and adaptability of novel riboswitch development. The biosensor functions in a cell-free system, where trehalase expression catalyzes the hydrolysis of excess trehalose into glucose, which can then be quantified using a standard glucose meter. This glucose meter-based reporting mechanism underscores the potential for adaptable, point-of-care diagnostics with broad applications in healthcare.
student leaders: Lucas Craig, Lucas Ng, Tanvee Deshmukh
students: Alexis Weipert, Charvi Patel, Erin Horack, Liam Woods, Molly Smock, Nikitha Kanumuru, Tyler Buzanowski, Zhongxu Liang

title: Blight Busters- Harnessing Darobactin and infection sensitive plasmids for Fire Blight treatment
abstract: Fire Blight, an infectious disease caused by gram-negative bacteria Erwinia Amylovora devastates Rosaceae plants, including apple and pear trees. Our team proposes the use of darobactin, a novel antibiotic discovered to inhibit gram-negative bacteria by acting on the BamA protein by Yu Imai et al. at Northeastern University in 2019. We are the first to test darobactin on E. Amylovora and to design an infection-sensitive plasmid so that in the event of an E. Amylovora infection, the plasmid will be triggered by an infection-sensitive promoter to express the darABCDE operon that encodes for darobactin A production. Our goal is to explore the use of a P. agglomerans plasmid to express darobactin A to target E. amylovora in Rosaceae plants.
student leaders: Jaehee Park, Natalie Sun, Sophie Geierstanger, Yunji Kim
students: Aditi, Austin Xu, Brandon Jimin Hahm, Brianna Baek, Chloe, Cindy Li, Claire Lim, Claire Wang, Deren Qian, Ella Yan, Emma Lee, Harini Iyer, Jihoo Hyun, Joyce Tan, Kate Lee, Krish Mandadi, Linda Yu, Marine Sevel, Maya Aryanfar, Minkyu Tak, Nithiyashri Chandran, Rhea Rupareliya, Rithika Kapila, Ryan Smith, Sophie Tsui, Stephanie Choi, Will

title: KlothY
abstract: Project KlothY focuses on developing a modular system to synthesise a textile fabric made of bacterial cellulose produced by Komagataeibacter xylinus. K. xylinus was genetically modified, to be able to regulate cellulose production. To modify the properties of the cellulose fabric, Saccharomyces cerevisiae acts as producer of metabolites, which impact flexibility and colour of our final product. We worked on integrating plant genes involved in hemicellulose biosynthesis and modified chromoproteins. Three chromoproteins attached to a cellulose binding domain would be used, to dye our fabric in a range of colours based on the CMY color model, also used in printers. The goal for the project is to contribute to the reduction of the harmful environmental impact of textile production globally, by focusing on local production and cutting down on the need for pesticides, emissions through transportation, high water usage and environmental toxic pollutants, used in bleaching and coloring processes.
PIs: Markus Pauly, Guido Grossmann, St. Elmo
advisors: Antigoni Mouratidou, Ben Lenkewitz, Can Karka, Deniz Yi?it Karag?z, Florian Hänsel, Joëlle Boecker, Max Denter, Niklas Küppers, Oliver Kraft, Yannik Grans, Yasemin Baran
student leaders: Robin Schüren, Tim Velden, Zio Kim
students: Annika Mass, Bianca E., Darrel Narta, David Fettinger, Deniz Öztürk, Justin Böhm, Kayra Sofie Rüffer, Luisa Tenter, Meggie Weber, Melanie Schreiber, Noah Ben Bulawa, Said Laibacher, Violetta Antczak

title: MycoBite: Integrated Enzyme Engineering and Molecular Modeling for Polyethylene Degradation Using Mycoremediation
abstract: Polyethylene related plastic pollution is a serious environmental problem in Ohio, where just 2% of plastic waste is recycled. A potential solution is mycoremediation, which makes use of fungi's capacity for substrate degradation. The laccase enzyme of Pleurotus ostreatus, which has the ability to degrade polyethylene polymers, is the main focus of the MycoBite project. Our objective was to enhance the thermal stability and affinity of laccase on PE surfaces by utilizing a combined computational method that included protein engineering and enzymatic and molecular modeling. We suggest using Saccharomyces cerevisiae to express the optimized laccase, promoting increased enzyme activity while supporting creative approaches to the management of plastic waste and environmental sustainability. MycoBite hopes to offer a novel solution to PE bioremediation and contribute to sustainable waste management practices.
advisors: Lindsey Shimoda
student leaders: Amer Abdelbaki, Chethana Yerramsetty, Jinju Kim
students: Anna Bontempo, Belide Saketha Ram, Dhruti Shah, Ella Vannelli, Ellie Schroer, Emma Masters, Jasritha Guddanti, Josef C, Michael Karpov, Nolan Dwenger, Nolan Dwenger, Olivia Sullivan, Parker Haskett

title: Tyro Tweezers : An Enzyme Replacement Complementary Treatment for Type 1 Hereditary Tyrosinemia
abstract: Type 1 Hereditary Tyrosinemia (HT1) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations disabling the activity of the fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH) protein, crucial for tyrosine metabolism. While nitisinone is the standard treatment for the disease, it imposes significant dietary restrictions, leading to dissatisfaction among patients surveyed from the Groupe d'Aide aux Enfants Tyrosinémiques du Québec (GAETQ). Tyro Tweezers proposes an FAH enzyme replacement therapy to complement nitisinone. After consulting with experts, we chose a subcutaneous injection strategy for delivery. We attempted to express human FAH in E. coli but we encountered challenges and unfortunately failed to produce a recombinant plasmid with the FAH gene. We aimed to optimize the ligand-protein binding affinity. We performed molecular dynamics simulations on FAH. 26 candidate mutations were identified by bioinformatics tools. We planned to use Rosetta Flexddg to compute the binding affinities for each mutated protein but time constraints prevented us from conducting the analyses.
instructors: Benjamin Ouellet, Éloïse Lagüe, Sabrina Gentil
advisors: Eleonore Lemieux
students: Andréanne Beaulieu, Athéna Croteau, Christophe Dussault, Francielton Lima, Hiba Mameri, Jacob Cote, Joseph Descarreaux, Julianne, Julie Desroches, Mathieu Giguere, Oscar Andrés Bernal Campos, Ouissal

title: Limnospira-inspired Foundational Technologies (LIFT)
abstract: The 2024 UCSC iGEM project, LiFT (Limnospira-inspired Foundational Technologies), aims to advance cyanobacteria engineering using new technology we call "accelerators." Limnospira fusiformis (SAG 85.79) is a promising chassis for developing nutrient-rich, cost-effective infant formula, addressing global malnutrition and high formula costs. While initially focused on creating a genetic system in L. fusiformis, Synechococcus sp. (UTEX 3154) was chosen for its well-characterized bio-engineering pathways. To overcome the lengthy transformation processes caused by polyploidy and restriction-modification systems, we remove restriction sites using statistical testing. Modular cloning is employed to build accelerator plasmids, including Cas12a and Argonaute, to speed up genetic recombination. Our project involves three accelerator designs: Cas12a single plasmid, Cas12a double plasmid, and Argonaute double plasmid. The UCSC iGEM team aims to apply this research to L. fusiformis in the future, creating a foundation for efficient cyanobacteria engineering.
students: Aurko Mahesh, Brenda Yu-Chuen Lai, Cesar Duarte, Daniel Yankin, Emmet Benaryeh, Jacob Bautista, Joseph Garcia, Kayla Kennamore, Kendra Krueger, Marshall Sekula, Neely Pfeiffer, Nivriti Bopparaju, Vibi Nandakumar, Zaden Yet

title: ALEBBRIGE (Active Linked Edible Biopeptides in Bacillus subtilis: Recombinant Integrated Genetic Engineering)
abstract: In Mexico, where 1 in 6 adults is affected by type 2 diabetes and food insecurity remains a significant challenge, the iGEM TEC CEM team presents ALEBBRIGE: Active Linked Edible Biopeptides in B. subtilis: Recombinant Integrated Genetic Engineering, a cutting-edge recombinant dietary supplement developed to assist in the prevention of diabetes and its associated complications. Drawing inspiration from Mexico's vibrant alebrijes, ALEBBRIGE integrates a diverse array of bioactive protein peptides, designed to provide precise nutritional support. By leveraging the capabilities of Bacillus subtilis as an efficient system for protein production, our multipeptide supplement aims to enhance metabolic health and support the prevention of diabetes-related conditions.
nominations: Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad
PIs: ANA LAURA TORRES HUERTA, Aurora Antonio Perez
instructors: Alberto, Carlos Eduardo Gomez Sanchez, Juan, Wetlab mentor
advisors: Leonardo S Gómez, Maria Mujica, RAMON, Roberto Duran
students: Aarón, Adalberto Briseño Bautista, Alma Paola Castorena Zorrilla, Almudena Rojas Pompa, Álvaro Axel Mardóniz Díaz, Cinpaus10, Diego A, Elizabeth Andriano, Gabriela Araceli Rosas Espinoza, Giovana Andrea Osorio León, Jorge V, José Antonio Almaraz García, Mariana Jacqueline Negrete Vilchis, Santiago Makoszay Castañon, Valeria Rojas Amador

title: CHELO
abstract: Early detection of diseases is crucial to ensure timely treatment and avoid severe outcomes. To address this, we developed CHELO, a device capable of detecting multiple diseases using biosensors. We focused on leukemia, where hematopoietic stem cells abnormally proliferate, affecting the patient's health. Each year, around 29,000 adults and 2,000 children are diagnosed with leukemia, with acute cases progressing rapidly and requiring early detection. Our project identifies biomarkers for AML using our model, Artemis' Eye. We discovered CD97 as a key biomarker and designed short peptides that bind to it. These peptides are expressed on our engineered E. coli, BELO. When CD97 binds to these peptides, BELO emits an electrical signal, indicating detection. This system alerts users to potential disease risks, enabling prompt medical attention. In the future, we aim to optimize the peptides, broaden disease detection, and enhance accuracy, helping patients worldwide receive timely treatment.
PIs: Wen-Liang Chen, Hsiao-Ching Lee, Huai-En Lu
advisors: Wendy Chan
students: BO-YU CHANG, CHENG-HSUN CHOU, CHIAO-YI CHAO, EN-CHI CHANG, LIAO, CHUN-YI, LU, CHEN-WEI, Meng-Yen,Tsai, Pin Syuan, Li, Po-Yo, Chen, TSENG, BAO-SHIUAN, YI-JEN, WU, YU-CHEN TSENG, YUN-HSIN, KUO

title: Metalytic - Easy Automated Metal Biosensor
abstract: Our project tackles heavy metal contamination in Hong Kong, inspired by incidents like lead in public housing water and contaminations from various origins such as agricultural land pollution, misconnection of pipes, and sewage water pouring into storm drains. These concerns highlight the need for affordable, user-friendly biosensors to detect metals like lead, cadmium, mercury, and zinc. To ensure visual detection in our biosensors, we focused on using chromoprotein reporters. Then, we identified metal-inducible promoters from literature and the iGEM database, studied their characteristics, and integrated them with the chromoprotein reporter system. We successfully developed a lead biosensor and a cadmium biosensor and demonstrated that the lead biosensor is concentration-sensitive. Additionally, our hardware team developed an automated machine using IoT and AI technologies. It can cultivate the biosensors and features an automated detection and warning system, ensuring practical and accessible monitoring of heavy metal pollutants in various settings.
nominations: Best Wiki, High School
PIs: Paul Lau, Kwok Hei WONG, Fan Kei Chu, Tsui On Lai, Wong Yan Yee
students: Aaron Lin, Alan Lau, Andy Leung, Anna, Austin Wu, Benjamin Yip, Chan Ka Long, Chan Tsz Yiu, Chan Wing Hang, Chau Chiu Yi, Cheng Nga Man, Chen Tsz Kin, Cheung Ho Yan Lucas, Cheung Wing Lam, Vincy, Fong Ho Yin, Fung Yat Hei, Hebe Ho, Hilary Lee, Hu Yui Ham, Joy Wen, Lai Tsz Yan, LAM SUM YING, Lan Minyue, Lee Tsz Ming, Leung Ka Man, Leung Lok Yi, Li Jingyue, Liu ShiTian, LuiPakLam, Lu Kwun Yu, Mandy Hon, Masa, Matilda, Mehak, Mo Chun Lok, Morris Yiu, Ngai Hoi Tung, Ng Ka Hin, Ng Ka Yiu, ophelia, Peng Wai Ki, PeterKAN, Puiyu, Regina, Shek Mei Ling, Siu Hung Lau, Sze Kam To, Tony, Tsang Pui Ki, Tsang Tin Long, Vanessa Yau, Venus chu, Wong Wai Cheng, Wong Yuk Chiu, Wong Yuk To, Yu Kok Fai, Yu Kok Fai, Yumiko Cheung

title: MaGenTa - Designing a spatiotemporal system capable of controlling gene expression using magnetic fields
abstract: Spatiotemporal gene control is a crucial technique utilised by academics in a variety of fields, ranging from neuroscience to stem cell research. However, the tools available for the control of gene expression in cell-based systems are limited - whether by timescale, spatial resolution, cost, or a combination of the three. To overcome these limitations, we have designed our MaGenTa technology: a spatiotemporal targeting system capable of activating gene expression using a combination of magnetic fields, magnetic nano particles (MNPs) and genetic AND gates. Our system relies on the activation of cellular pathways that function independently from one another. For this, we identified 3 viable pathways: thermal, mechanical and magnetic.
nominations: Best Hardware, Undergrad
instructors: Chi Ki Leung, Georgeos Hardo, Jarrod Shilts, Johann Sora Blakytny, Kavi H Shah, Yuen Shan Ho
advisors: Kieran Abbott
students: Cenyujia Wang, Dhriti Krishna Rao, Fergus Molyneux, Holly Bristow, Jamie Terry, Linhan Lei, Lisa Milne, Will Cassie, Zijiao Wang

title: cosmobiome - a CO-culture with Silicon MObilization for BIOmanufacturing using Martian rEgolith
abstract: One of the grand challenges in space synthetic biology is in situ resource utilization (ISRU). This eliminates the need to transport materials from Earth, which can be expensive and cumbersome. Another challenge is the manufacture of valuable compounds, like platform chemicals and pharmaceuticals, in space. We present a novel co-culture system of silicon-solubilizing bacteria (Pseudomonas fluorescens) and diatoms (Phaeodactylum tricornutum) that can use the silica present in Martian soil to drive their growth and produce compounds of human interest. As a proof-of-concept, we have engineered our bacterium to produce 4(S)-limonene. We also present Astrolabe, a first-of-its-kind software for applications in space synthetic biology and biomanufacturing.
student leaders: Anirudh Rao, Niharika Balasubramanian, Twisha T S
students: Aadityanshu Abhinav, Alan Royce Gabriel, Aldis Daniel, Bharvi Arora, Ganesh, Harsha, Hitesh Kandarpa, Ishaan Yadav, Jerry Jose, J V Shreya, Minkuri Ridhima Reddy, N T SANJANA, Oviya Suresh, Pesala Sreelatha, Pranav Ram PS, R Karthik, Rohan Krishnan, Ruchir R, Shreya Patki, Shreyas Balakarthikeyan, Skandaagraja Sundhar, Vaidehi Sharad Patil, YASWITHA REDDY DUGGU

title: Glycemic Stabilizer
abstract: Glycemic Stabilizer is a treatment project for type 1 diabetes patients. We have designed an AND part that can secrete insulin to reduce blood glucose during high blood glucose levels. To prevent low blood glucose, we have also designed a NOT part that can block excessive insulin secretion in a timely manner, thereby achieving precise regulation of blood glucose levels. We validated the feasibility of the plan through biological experiments. We also conducted social research and promoted knowledge of synthetic biology. In addition, we constructed a scientific model which is visualized of the project, designed user-friendly software with practical value and educational significance, and developed a blue light instrument which is successfully applied in experiments.
PIs: Jia-Da Li, Chi-Yu Li, Faxiang Li, Guodong Chen, Jiaojiao Wang, Jieqiong Tan, Shengjie Sun, Xiaoqing Peng, Ye Liang, Zhenhua Liu
advisors: Jiayi Cao, Tianyi Feng, Xiaoying Liu, Ya-Ru Wang, Zihang Zheng
students: Boyuan Xie, Chengcheng Wang, Chengyang Zhu, Fan Guan, Jiahui Yao, Jialin Jiang, Ling Shang, Nan Jiang, Qinyun Song, Rongyu Gao, Ruihan Fang, Ruijing Zhang, Shu Gao, Sihan He, Siyu Liu, Xiaoyang Tan, Xin Liu, Xinyu Shui, Yifei Jiao, Zekun Cheng, Zhi Jin, Zihan Qin, Zirui Zeng, Ziyi Luo

title: The PET Degradation STORM: Unleashing PETase's Power with PET-Binding Peptides
abstract: Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic pollution poses a global environmental issue, and enzymatic degradation is an ideal ecologically friendly solution, yet its efficiency is restricted by limited substrate accessibility of corresponding enzymes. Therefore, our project applied the STROM strategy to boost the degradation ability of PETase towards PET by PET-binding peptides. Initially, sixteen potential PET-binding peptides were screened using deep learning models. Subsequently, fusion proteins of these PET-binding peptides with PETase were constructed to test PET microplastic degradation and binding efficiency, identifying three efficient peptides. Through optimization, the expression levels and PET degradation properties of these fusion proteins were further enhanced. Finally, with the aid of the Mutcompute-super model, these three peptides were re-modified, further improving the expression levels and PET microplastic degradation efficiencies of their fusion proteins, with the optimal degradation efficiency reaching 207.49% of PETase. Our project provides insights and support for the biodegradation of PET plastics.
advisors: Jianan Wang, Jianghua Chen, Leyi Zhang, Mengrui Tao, Minhao Wang, Wen Li, Xinheng Wang, Xinran Tang, Yuanhao Wang
students: Hanzhi Weng, Jianqiang Hu, Junqing Han, Jun Wan, Shuting Cheng, Xiaoyan Chen, Xinyi Zhou, Yao Lu, Yewen Wu, Yihang Shen, Yuehan Zhou, Yueheng Niu, Yundi Tang, Yuqi Cao, Zhijun Yi, Zhixuan Jin, Zhiyu Shen

title: DHA Express - DHA Production from Oleaginous Yeast
abstract: Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) is an essential nutrient needed for human health and development, however, dietary intake is proven insufficient in many populations. Current DHA supplement sources include fish oil and microalgae, in which the former is susceptible to pollution and predicted to decline in productivity due to global warming, and the latter faces high production costs. To provide an alternative method of efficient and sustainable DHA production, our team selects oleaginous yeast Yarrowia lipolytica, a safe, commonly used organism for industrial fatty acid production as our chassis. We integrate the gene cluster encoding a specific DHA-synthesizing enzyme complex from Schizochytrium sp. into the yeast's genome. We then apply the following strategies to optimize the DHA yield: peroxisomal PEX10 gene knockout by homologous recombination to inhibit DHA degradation; control of gene expression level and production stages via promoter characterization and design; replenishing reactant NADPH supply through GapC gene introduction.
PIs: King L. Chow, Jessica C.M. Tang
advisors: Changxin Fan, CHEN Hsi Chen, Fung Ching Nam, Lau Hoi Ying, Ngai Man Yee, PANG, Chun Pan Terry, Sherman Chau, Wong Kei Hong, Wong Nga Man, Yeung Sen
students: AYUSH DALMIA, Chloe Chan, Constance Zhang, Daeun Suh, Dayeong Yoon, Hei Ching Iu, Henry C.H. CHOY, Jacksen Wijaya, Jingjun ZHU, Liu Amanda LIANG, Lok Yi Cheung, On Yee LEUNG, Qinghua HUANG, Samantha Kaitlyn Ng, Tianyue WU, Wai Ying OU, WU Ming Chun, Yanlin Sun, Yanni Yuan, Yanyu CHEN, Yerim Song, Zhengyu Ding

title: SWEETEIN: Recombinant Thaumatin Made in Tomato Factories as the Future of Sugar Substitutes.
abstract: With increasing concerns over the health risks associated with excessive sugar consumption, the use of sugar substitutes has become widespread. However, recent studies have identified significant safety issues with many common substitutes. In response, the SZU-China team seeks to develop a safer alternative by producing Thaumatin, a natural, highly efficient, and fully digestible sweet protein. We have implemented an innovative production method within tomato fruits, utilizing two key systems: an expression system driven by the fruit-specific and ripening-induced E8 promoter for precise temporal and spatial control of Thaumatin production, and a storage-targeting system that directs Thaumatin to the vacuole using the SPS-NTPP targeting peptide. This approach enables the direct extraction of Thaumatin from tomato juice, eliminating the need for complex purification processes. We have named this protein 'Sweetein' and hope it will inspire further advancements in the sugar substitute industry by offering safer, natural alternatives for consumers.
PIs: Weizhao Chen, Beixin Mo, Xuedong Liu
advisors: Chen Ruoyu, Jielin Li, Rongsong Ling, Ruiyue Chen, Tangkun Zhu, Xinyi Hao, Xinying Zhang, Yan Huang, Yutong Chen, Zuxin Chen
students: Amelia Wei, Guangbin An, HAOSHENG DENG, Jiachun Chen, Li Kexin, Qizheng Liu, Ruohan Chen, Siyuan Guo, Yitong Li, Yuanrun Liu, Yuntian Wu, Zhengyue Hong

title: Enhance The Synthesis of SCFAs & GLP-1 to Regulates Glycolipid Metabolism
abstract: We are concerned about T2DM, a chronic disease with serious complications and a rising incidence rate worldwide. We focus on BcoAT to enhance the synthesis of its SCFAs and program the glucose responsive secretion of GLP-1 to build a synthetic biological reactor through the method of synthetic biology, with the probiotic ECN1917 as the chassis. When blood sugar levels rise after each meal, GLP-1 is released to rapidly lower blood sugar to baseline levels. In order to achieve the above functions, this project designed a GLP-1 recombinant protein, with PelB as the lead sequence connected to GLP-1 to enhance its extracellular secretion function. DnaK, a key protein of the blood glucose control module, is expressed at the tail of GLP-1 through flexible linker peptides to achieve its programmed release. During the experimental phase, the release of GLP-1 regulated by glucose concentration was validated through gradient dilution and ELISA quantitative detection.
PIs: Yatao Liu, Chao Li, Jianming Tang, Rongbing Tang, Weilin Jin, Xiaodong Xie, Xiao Lyu
advisors: Minhua Yao, Shuting He, Weihan Kang, Weihui, Weining Wang, Wenqi Ruan, Yibo Yu, Yijing Jiang, Yuan Lyu, Yujia Liu, Zhaocheng Li, Zhongyu Yang, Zihan Li
students: Borong Li, Chenchen Li, Chunling Fan, Fan Yang, Hanyu Xie, jinsenwei, Kaiyan Liu, Mao Liao, Meiyin Zhou, Qi Bi, Shenhan Yu, Wenxuan Shao, Xiangyu Wang, Xiaoye Zhao, Xuanqiao Wang, Xun Huang, Yichen Feng, Yifan Wang, Yifeng Lin, Yingqi Ma, Yuhan Wang, Ziang Zhang

title: Enhancing The Complement System Against Leptospira
abstract: Leptospira, a genus of motile gram-negative spirochetes, causes leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease that significantly impacts resource-poor populations. Transmitted through contaminated environments, it affects high-risk groups like agricultural workers and water sports enthusiasts. Clinical manifestations range from mild flu-like symptoms in anicteric leptospirosis to severe complications in icteric leptospirosis (Weil's disease). The complement system is crucial for immune defense; however, some Leptospira proteins evade it, complicating host responses. Recent studies have identified specific microRNAs (miRNAs), such as hsa-miR-144-3p and hsa-miR-21-5p, which down-regulate important immune components, including toll-like receptors and complement factor H. This project aims to investigate the interaction between these miRNAs and their targets to design synthetic miRNA mimics/inhibitors. The goal is to enhance the immune response, particularly TLR2 and complement factor H activity, improving defenses against leptospirosis. Over two years, this research seeks to provide insights into potential therapeutic strategies for managing the disease and its complications.
PIs: Ng Sze Ho, Leung Kai Man Clement
advisors: Zhang Mandy
students: Annabel Lam, Bonnie, Cheung Zhiqing, Cindy Chen, Evan Xia, Eva Zhuang, Jack Mak, Lee Chun Hei, Lurin Yu, Melody Ng, Owen Wong, Samantha Lau

title: Rest Easy
abstract: The NASSZ iGEM team, in its inaugural year, aimed to address a common issue among secondary students: sleep difficulties. Through surveys, the team identified problems with falling asleep and waking up refreshed. To tackle this, they proposed using aromatherapy, focusing on mint and vanilla scents to enhance focus and sleep quality. The team plans to engineer yeast to synthesize menthol and vanillin using recombinant DNA techniques. Additionally, they are designing a light-sensitive system where yeast would produce menthol or vanillin based on exposure to red or blue light. A device with a timer will allow students to switch between scents for better sleep and focus.
advisors: HJ
students: bingyu ji, Carson Wan, cube, Linqing Huang, Martina, Michael He, Puru, YanChong, zhuoxian song

title: NOsquito - The Ultimate Bug Fix
abstract: Mosquitoes are the single most deadly animal to humans due to their role as vectors for parasitic and viral diseases. The least polluting method of controlling this epidemic is the use of insect repellents. However, their current production relies on petroleum and toxic intermediates, posing a major threat to the environment. So, we developed a biosynthetic pathway to produce a promising alternative to current repellents: NBP. We designed and partially constructed an enzyme cascade to produce NBP from sugar feedstocks. To improve the catalytic activity of our key enzyme, we devel-oped the software tool 'seq-mutator', which bridges the gap between AI-assisted protein engineering and real-world data, ultimately resulting in a variant with about a five-fold increase in activity. We also explored the use of black pepper as a sustainable production chassis by developing novel transformation protocols, and by producing NBP in Nicotiana benthamiana as proof of concept.
nominations: Best Model, Overgrad+Best Plant Synthetic Biology, Overgrad
instructors: Jannis Bröker, Moritz Gansbiller, Pia Lanvers
advisors: Lasse Middendorf, Tobias Bröker
student leaders: Annika Potthoff, Cara Jaeckel, Louis Noel Schanzmann
students: Anton Schindel, Cielia Zukina, Emil Beurer, Evelyn Tchoub, Frieda Fröb, Jan Albrecht, Jen Kuprianow, Johanna Kötter, Johanna Siebers, Josefine Vahlberg, Julia Hildebrecht, Julius Hennemann, Lara Schmidt, Leo Trau, Maya Sperling, Michael Jöst, Michel Stevens, Michel Westermann, Nele Niemand, Niklas Boehm, Niko Stanke, Sandrina Zech, Simon Krumrey, Tom Gross

title: BHBetter - Production of the ketone ester ?-hydroxybutyrate for health supplement industry
abstract: The ketogenic diet offers numerous benefits, including enhanced cognitive function, improved exercise performance, and appetite suppression, making it attractive for weight management and athletic performance. However, its requirements for low carbohydrate intake and prolonged fasting render it impractical for most individuals. To address this limitation, we have engineered E. coli to biosynthesize d-?-hydroxybutyrate (BHB), a ketone body, which can substitute the need for a strict ketogenic diet to reach ketosis. Our modified bacteria first produce the polymer poly hydroxybutyrate (PHB), which is then converted to BHB through the expression of PHB depolymerase. Through rigorous testing, we successfully detected BHB production from our engineered cells, demonstrating the feasibility of our system. By facilitating easier access to the benefits of ketosis without dietary constraints, our project capitalizes on the recent development of safe and orally bioavailable ketone monoester drinks, highlighting a significant market opportunity.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School
advisors: Ekaterina
students: Amy Wang, Ashley Yu, Austin Tang, Ellen Zhao, Harper Cryer, Jaewon You, Jayden Lau, Joanna Du, JoonSoo Hwang, Julien Seng, Rei Ang, Sarah Pan, Sean Jiang, SeoHyung Ryu, Sophie Gong, Steve Yin

title: OUROBOROS
abstract: In the 21st century, climate and energy issues have increased the demand for lithium-ion batteries. Yet, their disposal poses safety and environmental risks, and metal scarcity highlights the need for recycling. Conventional recycling is inefficient and polluting. We propose a synthetic biology approach to recover metals (Li, Mn, Co, Ni) from used batteries. A. niger ferments to produce acids for metal leaching, yeast displays peptides to selectively bind and separate ions, and E. coli's urease helps precipitate ions as carbonates for new anode production, creating a sustainable metal recovery loop.
nominations: Best Bioremediation Project, Undergrad+Best New Basic Part, Undergrad+Best New Composite Part, Undergrad
advisors: Dong Meng, Li Xinyun, Longhaitao, NiuZhang, Shi Wentao, Sun Qiuyan, Xiangyin, Xiao Ning, Xulin Gong, Yunyun DU
students: HAORAN QI, JINGTIAN CAO, peng peng, Sihui Liu, siyu zhu, Wenda Qian, xinghaoyue fan, Yancheng Zeng, Yu Wenjing, Zeng Cheng, Zhirong Wang, Ziwei Xu, ?? ?, ??

title: Genome-based synthetic biology & site-directed editing of genes cultivating nutrient-fortificad rice
abstract: Strategically, we utilize the dose-response of rice genes and the transcriptome regulatory network of endosperm storage protein synthesis genes to guide the reprogramming of rice endosperm storage protein component protein ratios through modeling and prediction. We only mutate the coding genes of two storage proteins without introducing any exogenous genes to improve the nutritional quality, food safety, and taste quality of rice. Technically, we induced rice polyploidy to tetraploid by colchicine, and then mutated glutelin B1 and globulin coding genes OsGluB1 and OsGlb by CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing technology. As a result, the total protein and lysine content were increased (improving nutritional quality); The content of glutelin remained basically unchanged, and globulin almost disappeared (food safety was improved); Increased alcohol soluble protein content (improved taste quality).
advisors: Chengxu Song, chentianyi, gui yan, Mengqi Liu, mingxuan yang, Tongliqi, Yahe Xie, Yanni Yin, Yingzhuo Lv
student leaders: Kai Yang, wang weilin, Yangyu He, Ziying Qiu
students: BenHuan Wu, chenxi zhu, He liushang, Ke Chen, Qianhe Jian, Qingni Xue, Siwei Liu, song tao, Xinyi Wei, Xinyu Wu, Yifan Ju, Yufan Cheng, Yufei Wang, Yuxiang Zhang, Zhixin Jia, Zihao Zhou

title: BANANA GUARD-Banavac
abstract: Bananas, being triploid and reliant on asexual reproduction, lack genetic diversity, making them highly susceptible to pathogens like Fusarium oxysporum, which threatens entire banana industury. Traditional sterilization methods (sunlight, chemical disinfectants, soil isolation) are ineffective and unsustainable. Instead, our project focuses on coexistence through competition. We genetically modify Fusarium oxysporum by removing the FUB1 toxin gene and introducing the RiCLE symbiotic gene from Rhizophagus irregularis, creating a strain that promotes banana growth while protecting against wild-type pathogens. The modified fungus acts as a vaccine, occupying ecological niches to fend off harmful strains. To prevent biohazard, we designed a kill switch system using tetracycline to control spore production within a specialized fermentation tank. Spores are produced safely. Waste water is disinfected with disinfectant and air is disinfected with filter membrane and UV light, ensuring controlled and bio-safe application. Our final product is a spore suspension kit with dry spore powder.
advisors: Runjin Mao, Xichen Wang
student leaders: Haoxiang Yang, Jinwen Guo, Juyao Zhang, Michelle Jialin Cen, Xinying Li, Yichen Liu, Ziming Ye
students: ANGELINA ANZHUO CHEN, Fuxin Liu, Jialu Mei, Lingyue Zhang, Mingchen Yang, Runing Guan, Sarah, TIANYI HU, Wenhan Shi, Xinjie Luo, Xinzi Luo, Yi Yang, Ziyu Zhou

title: Use of Aptamers for targeting of artificially Misfolded pTau
abstract: We produced recombinant hTau in BL21 E. coli culture. The purified Tau was randomly phosphorylated to match the levels of phosphorylation in case of Tauopathies and collected at different intervals of incubation (18 hrs, 22 hrs, 24 hrs, 27 hrs etc). The phosphorylations were confirmed by band shifts. Using a variant of EMSA, we showed the binding of the Aptamers to 231 pTau. Parallelly, we clicked C8 alkyne dCTP and [S,R,S]-AHPC-PEG1-Azide. This versatile compound is theoretically expected to be incorporable into Aptamers making an aptamer-based PROTAC, but our algorithmic calculation of radius of gyration showed the possibility of a coiled moiety. We also tried to establish a newer protocol of SELEX by optimising an improvised random mutagenesis protocol. We also obtained various structural predictions of pTau for different combinations of phosphorylation on majorly addressed phosphorylation sites.
advisors: Aditya Kamath Ammembal
students: Achintya Mathur, Adithya, Aishik Nath, Anurag Sarkar, Anushka Jain, Arjun Karmakar, Asmita Guha, Avani, Debanjan Saha, Geeth Sameer Batta, Kabyadeep, Kalpit, Krishna Agarwal, Manya Ganapathy, Milan Vijay, Parth Kumar, P K HARRISHNARAYANAN, Samyak, Shouvik Datta, Souptik Das, Swarnava Chakraborty

title: IsPETase-HiCutinase Fusion Enzyme
abstract: Concerned about plastic pollution in our city Thessaloniki and its global impact we decided to tackle this problem using synthetic biology. Our projects includes creating a fused enzyme, by the two enzymes: PETase from Ideonella Sakaiensis and cutinase from Humicola Insolens, in order to accelerate the rate and efficiency of PET biodegradation. This fused enzyme was expressed in E. Coli through TA Gene cloning in pMiniT 2.0 vector. We tested our project using gel electrophoresis and spectrophotometry.
advisors: Eleni Antonakou
students: Anna Filindri, Athena Chortareas, Cornelia-Maria Vogiaza, Despoina Chatzimoysi, Ioanna Karatziovali, Michalis Kontoulis, Nikolas Koptsis, Tatiana Kontopoulou, Theodosis Tousis, Vassilis Kosmatopoulos

title: Phosphix: Defeating The Phosphogeddon
abstract: Modern agriculture relies on the availability of synthetic fertilizers to feed an ever-growing global population. Unfortunately, one of the key components of these fertilizers, inorganic phosphate (Pi) is a finite resource that the world is set to run out of in the coming decades. This impending "Phosphogeddon" crisis will require new methods for recycling phosphate. We propose that phosphatase enzymes like PafA from Flavobacterium johnsoniae will allow us to recycle naturally-occurring organophosphates found in soil. First we set out to characterize PafA, then employed AI-guided protein redesign tools to enhance its expression, stability, and industry-readiness. By deploying our phosphatase with a high-affinity phosphate binding protein (PiBP) in a future waste-water treatment system, we can both effectively convert organophosphates back into inorganic phosphate and captured it for reuse. Overall, our project addresses the looming threat of "phosphogeddon" by both introducing a new source of inorganic phosphate and method for its capture
advisors: Anirudh Jakhmola, Brooks J Rady, Isaac White, Mario Javier Garcia Duarte
students: Alwin, Coleen Parakattil, Jacob, Julia, Mary, Saoirse, Thomas

title: Expression and purification of Tachypleus tridentatus clotting factor G for (1?3)-?-D-glucans measurement system
abstract: Horseshoe crabs currently face extinction due to blood harvest for medical research. Sourcing natural horseshoe crab hemolymph, which is involved in endotoxin and fungal infection detection systems, are therefore ecologically unsustainable. In this study, we recombinantly produced Tachypleus tridentatus clotting factor G, a heterodimeric protein consisting of alpha and beta subunits, to reconstruct the (1?3)-?-D-glucans (BDG) assay system for fungal infection. We optimized and cloned the alpha and beta subunit sequences into pET-28a, pET-Duet1, and pFastBac1 vectors, hoping to express them in both Escherichia coli and Sf9 insect cells. Assay with SDS-PAGE and mass spectrometry indicated the successful expression of both subunits in E.coli cells. The protein would then be purified and tested for BDG-dependent activation. Our findings contribute to the development of alternative diagnostic tools for fungal infection while addressing ecological concerns.
students: Boyue Deng, Chengyang Zhang, DANG MEISUN, Fangming Liu, Iris Wang, Jingyuan Ma, Junru Huang, Lisiqi Ye, Nancy Zhao, Qingshu Wu, Xirui WANG, Yiming Wu, Yinuo Qi, YUJIA CHEN, yushan Mei, Yuxuan Wu, Zhaoyuan Wu, Zihe Chen

title: PACIFY
abstract: Itchiness, or pruritus, is a common discomfort that can escalate into a persistent and challenging issue when caused by specific factors like Staphylococcus aureus. This pathogen not only leads to inflammation and redness but also triggers relentless itching, severely affecting the quality of life. The itch disrupts daily activities, sleep, and emotional well-being, often leading to anxiety and depression. Current anti-itch products, mostly focused on antibiotics and medications, don't always provide quick or significant relief and may have side effects like skin thinning and pigmentation. Recognizing the urgency and importance of this issue, we are committed to using Escherichia coli as a model to simulate the itch caused by Staphylococcus aureus and identify effective substances to alleviate the discomfort. Our goal is to develop a safe, user-friendly product that soothes itching and aids in treatment without interfering with conventional methods, providing a more comfortable and pleasant experience for those affected.
PIs: Wei Shen, Haitao Yang, Yan Gao
advisors: Kaijun Wang, Keyu Chen, Shenxi Cao
students: Boqian Zhang, Chenfei Liu, Gaoshenyuan, Huang Wei, Jingting Zhang, Kun Zheng, Liang Xu, Linzheng Tang, Qihang Yan, Qizhen Liu, Sihan Cheng, TeddyAster, Wang Tianyi, weihang li, Wenye Xiong, Yijia Zhong, Yiping Zeng, Yuchen Hao, Yuyan Zhao, Zhang Xinyi, Zhejing Huang, ???

title: PETilizer -- A Metabolic Coupling System for Concurrent Microplastic
abstract: As plastic use escalates, agriculture faces increasing threats from microplastics, which originate from films, irrigation, wastewater, and compost. These particles compromise soil structure and quality, leading to reduced crop yields and altering crucial properties such as bulk density and water retention. More severely, crops may absorb these microplastics, impairing their ability to take up nutrients and water effectively. To combat these alarming issues, we introduce PETlizer--a groundbreaking solution featuring engineered E. coli BL21 to break down microplastics and Pseudomonas putida KT2440 to convert the byproducts into rhamnolipids. Rhamnolipids are powerful surfactants that enhance microbial adhesion, improve soil water retention, inhibit pathogens, and assist in pollution remediation. We hope this innovative approach will not only address plastic contamination but also boost agricultural productivity.
PIs: Yu Zhou, Kang Ning, xiexiaoman, yanyunjun
advisors: Xingyi Wen, Yue Wu, Yundi Chen, Zeyang Li
students: Bie Yutong, Cathy, Feng Liting, Fengzilu, jiangsuyuan, Jiayue Su, Lai Shi Jie, Li Yizhe, Lucas, lwstkhyl, Nanxi Yi, Pinrong Qian, QIYUXUAN, Shaoheng Lyu, shuo YAN, Sunlongcheng, SuTong Fan, Tianxi KANG, TIANXU, Wu Jiarui, Xinghao Xiong, Xiong Yifeng, YANG Yiting, Yingying He, Yuhan Zou, Zeng Xihong, Zeyu Miao, ZHANG Jiayin, Zihao YANG, ???, ???, ???, ???

title: Targeting Antimicrobial Resistance Genes using Toehold Switch Detection, RNA-Based Silencing Systems, and Graphene Oxide-Mediated Delivery
abstract: In recent years, there has been a rapid emergence of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) at a global scale. Therefore, it is of great importance to develop new strategies to combat infections caused by antimicrobial resistant bacteria. The aim of this project is to develop a detection system utilizing toehold switches, and to establish an RNA-based gene silencing system. The ambition was to create and examine the efficacy of four different RNA-based silencing systems: sRNA, hammerhead RNA, CRISPR/Cas9, and CRISPR/Cas13a. Three antibiotic resistance genes, AAC(6')-Ib, ErmC, and Tet(A), were chosen for the purpose of testing these systems. Our results demonstrate that the sRNA system successfully represses the expression of ErmC and Tet(A), restoring the susceptibility of these bacteria to antibiotic treatment. Additionally, we explored a novel approach of transforming plasmid DNA using graphene oxide.
students: Caesar Nelson, Cornelius Rehoboth Echehomos, Emil Björkqvist, Gabriella Nilsson, Josefin Ewerman, Juni Hain, Louise Elmberg, Moa Carlsson, Neha Kanduri, William Lager, Yixuan Xu

title: E.lectrode: Recombinant Skin-Specific Nanowires to Improve Signal Detection in Human-Machine Interfaces
abstract: How can synthetic biology revolutionise our connections to machines? Our bodies use electrical signals for cellular communication, and myoelectric prosthetics can translate electrical signals generated from muscle contractions in the residual limb into movement using dry metal electrodes. However, a critical limiting factor for these electrodes is the overreliance on direct contact with the skin, making them vulnerable to interference from sweat and movement. This results in the electrodes moving out of place, leading to inaccurate signal interpretation (motion artefacts), causing lagging limb movement. We aim to improve the electrode's interface using electrically conductive pili (e-pili) derived from Geobacter sulfurreducens. By combining the e-pili's PilA monomer with a skin-specific protein-binding tag on the carboxy-terminal end, we will create nanowires that adhere to the skin surface. These nanowires would decrease the distance electrical signals would need to travel without a conductor, minimising motion artefacts and improve signal detection in human-machine interfaces.
advisors: alec banner, Erik Hanko, Faisal Giwa, Gabriel Ragala, Jack Andrew Connolly
students: Alia Atanacio, Damian-Andrei Ungureanu, Devika Shenoy, Francisco Sobral Correia, Janet Xu, Thomas Dong, Usrat Nubah, Yuliia Anisimova, Zainab Atique-Ur-Rehman

title: Bacillus Lipase Integrated Secretion System (BLISS)
abstract: Exocrine Pancreatic Insufficiency (EPI) is a condition where the pancreas fails to produce sufficient digestive enzymes, leading to malnutrition. It is treated with pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, an oral drug containing porcine-derived pancreatic enzymes. As a more ethical and economic treatment option, we present the Bacillus Lipase Integrated Secretion System (BLISS), a probiotic that secretes synthetic digestive enzymes suitable for the human body. We plan to transform B. subtilis with the human pancreatic lipase and procolipase genes, along with a glucose-mediated switch mechanism for inducible expression. We have also developed a comprehensive model to determine the timescale of enzyme production and secretion. Our device also contains a biocontainment mechanism to prevent the device from functioning in unintended environments. In addition to our wet lab efforts, our team has developed a comprehensive education handbook as a synthetic biology resource for the homeschooled community.
students: Connor Sandall, Elizabeth MacPhail, Elizabeth Mills, Hannah Shen, Kaylin, Matt, Michael Mao, Nithin, Siena, Stephanie Zhang

title: SaPh:IRES (Satellite Phage: Integrated Real-world Engineering Solutions)
abstract: As synthetic biology advances from the lab to real-world environments, it is in need of novel parts, circuits, and devices that increase levels of control in unpredictable, complex conditions. Satellite phages present a vast ensemble of unexplored machinery with the potential to meet these emerging needs. Our project, SaPh:IRES (Satellite Phage: Integrated Real-world Engineering Solutions), addresses the significant foundational gap by pursuing two key objectives: developing novel identification tools for satellites both bioinformatically and experimentally, and utilizing their unique mechanisms to address specific challenges in synthetic biology. To do so, we use different phage satellite systems in mycobacteria and E. coli for three specific applications: sequence-specific population level control, overcoming prophage immunity, and increasing phage host range. We test our concepts in silico with the first of its kind mathematical model, in vitro, and in situ in simulated real-world environments to showcase their functionality at different levels of complexity.
nominations: Best Foundational Advance Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Software Tool, Undergrad
students: Caden Sanko, Emma Holley, Josh Levin, Keertana Senthilkumar, Kira Stotts, Namitchandra Nallapaneni, Rachel McCarley, Rebecca Zheleznyak, Sophia Stagarescu

title: BOOMcoli: A Therapeutic Model for Ulcerative Colitis by Probiotic-Mediated Release of IL-10
abstract: Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic autoimmune disorder of the colon, affecting 5 million people worldwide with increasing incidence. Current treatments, targeting periods of remission and flare-ups, often fall short, with only 20-30% of patients seeing significant improvement. Our project, BOOMcoli, introduces a novel therapeutic model using bioengineered E. coli probiotics for targeted release of IL-10 in the colon. By utilizing a biomarker-sensitive promoter and quorum sensing, our engineered probiotic binds to inflamed sites identified by elevated calprotectin levels, an inflammation marker. Once localized, quorum sensing triggers synchronized lysis, releasing IL-10 precisely in the inflamed areas. BOOMcoli intends for a fast-acting, highly specific, and minimally invasive treatment that can be administered regularly to manage UC symptoms as they arise. Beyond UC, this method could be adapted for other large intestine diseases, including colorectal cancer, or other organs for broader therapeutic applications.
PIs: José L. Avalos, Jared Toettcher, Beatrice Ramm
students: Arra Ju, Camille Perez, Daniel, Dowon S., Emma Schrier, Evelyn Chen, George, Jingjing Wang, Kenzo, Lakshmi Mahalingam, Manna Sam, Rebekah, Remy Garcia-Kakebeen, Ryan Miner, William Sebastian Gil

title: PETal: Valorizing PET plastic to sandalwood oil
abstract: The fashion and cosmetics industries are highly consumer-centric, impacting nearly everyone worldwide. These industries consume vast quantities of raw materials and can significantly harm the environment. Indian sandalwood oil is one such sought-after raw material in the beauty industry. PETal presents a novel solution by integrating plastic waste management with the production of sandalwood oil, using synthetic biology. Using engineered Pseudomonas putida that can metabolise the monomers of polyethylene terephthalate (PET), i.e. terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol (EG), we aim to synthesise santalene and santalol, the major components of sandalwood oil. This offers a sustainable alternative to conventional sandalwood oil extraction, reducing the strain on natural populations and providing a novel method for plastic upcycling. By creating a value-added product from PET plastic waste, PETal has the potential to reshape waste management strategies, promote biodiversity conservation, and simultaneously meet the global demands for sandalwood oil.
awards: Best Fashion & Cosmetics Project+Best Project Promotion Video
advisors: Aabha P Shams, ASWATHY, Pratham Kapavarapu, Rohit Kumar
students: Angel CJ, Gouri Sandhya, Ilaksha Pahwa, Irin Treesa Binoy, Jagruti Digambar Bamble, Kalyani Kore, Keerti Buge, Mayukh Mitra, Minnu Manoj, Nalin Mathew, Paarth Manoj, Shreya Salunkhe, Shrushti Baba Kanse

title: Xeroderma Pigmentosum Complementation Group C Ultraviolet Resposive Genetic Switch
abstract: Our project aims to develop a genetic switch that responds to ultraviolet (UV) light and utilize this gene switch for the treatment of Xeroderma Pigmentosum Type C. Our project is mainly divided into three modules: First, we verified the interaction of UVR8, COP1, and RUP2 in mammalian cells and their response to ultraviolet light; Second, we successfully constructed a UV-responsive gene switch that activates the expression of target genes upon UV irradiation and demonstrated that RUP2 can dissociate the interaction between UVR8 and COP1, thereby stabilizing the expression level of the target gene to a certain extent; Third, through modeling, we obtained results predicting the expression of the target protein after sequence optimization of RUP2, and successfully constructed plasmids with different numbers of rare codons added to the RUP2 gene, which will be validated through wet lab experiments.
instructors: Chuan Xu, Xi Mo, Yushu Wang
advisors: Kexin Zhang, Xianghai Jiang, Zhenxi Yang
students: Enran Li, Ge Wang, Hanyu Xu, Haoyang Cheng, Hongguo Tang, Hongyu Wei, Janie Fu, Jiayi Yao, Ran Tu, Xiang Gao, Yihao Cui, Yuxian Zheng, Zezheng Zhao, Zidong Shu

title: AFPScan: Use deep learning to guide the research of antifungal polypeptides
abstract: With the global incidence of fungal infections rising each year, over 300 million individuals are currently afflicted by severe fungal infections annually. The treatment success rate of antifungal drugs is only 67.4%, and the resistance is becoming increasingly critical. In response to this challenge, SWU-China team is focused on developing an innovative and efficient method for the high-throughput screening of antifungal peptides (AFP) utilizing deep learning techniques. The team employs the DeBERTa model to rapidly identify potential antifungal peptide sequence patterns from existing AFP data and predict the activity of candidate antimicrobial peptides from the NCBI database. Compared to conventional wet-lab methods, this model-driven approach offers significant improvements in both screening efficiency and accuracy. Through this project, we are committed to raising public awareness regarding fungal infections and antibiotic resistance. Simultaneously, we aim to provide novel solutions for medicine development, reducing the global health risks associated with fungal infections.
students: chen qiyao, Chen Yang, Dezhi Kong, Grant Wu, hongyu Zhu, Jiaying Jiang, Qiuhan Fu, Wei Yixuan, Xingyu Yan, xu rong kang, Youhao, Yuhong Wang, yurong Hua, Zishan Wang

title: Dienamite: ceasing the destruction of spider mites to revitalize gardens and plantations
abstract: Spider mites are notorious pests that destroys worldwide agriculture and horticulture. With abundant progenies and a short life cycle, they develop resistance to chemical pesticides at an exponential rate, making them difficult to exterminate using current strategies. Determined to resolve this global challenge, GreatBay-SCIE thus proposed a thorough solution called Dienamite, which shields plants at multiple stages including pre-, mid-, and post-infection stages. By bio-synthesizing 7-epi-zingiberene, 9-hydroxy-zingiberene, 9-hydroxy-10,11-epoxy zingiberene, mite venom peptide, spider venom peptide, and harpin protein, Dienamite is capable of establishing progeny-reducing effects on spider mites, exterminating adult mites with high target-specificity, and boosting plant immunity simultaneously. Ultimately, we wish to bring prosperity back to gardens and augment agricultural production. We also believe that the emergence of Dienamite can reduce reliance on chemical pesticides, minimizing toxic residues and preserving the environment.
awards: Finalist+Top 10+1st Runner-up+Best Integrated Human Practices+Best Presentation
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School+Best Entrepreneurship, High School+Best Wiki, High School
advisors: Dong AoYang, Echo Chen, LI XINYU, Luxi Cai, Ni Weizhao, Ye Siyi, Zhang HuiXin, Zhang Yuankai, Zi Huan Luo

students: Jialu Xu, JO-YU WANG, Qianyue Jin, SHENG NAN, Sophia Ding, Xichen Ma, XIE HUNGYUEN DANIEL, YANCHUN FANG, Yeesen Wong, YUNCHUN LU, ZIHAN ZHU, Zile Song

title: CuraPack: A Novel Antimicrobial First Aid Kit Developed to Combat Resistant Wound Infections in War
abstract: The global rise in wars and natural disasters increased the prevalence of wound infections. Moreover, the misuse of antibiotics and their resistance-prone mechanisms of action led to the spread of resistant pathogens that significantly increased the severity of infections, resulting in amputation or death. Current first aid kits do not possess any means of infection prevention other than resistant-prone antibiotic ointments. However, defensins, a family of antimicrobial peptides, possess antimicrobial activity while having lower risks of resistance due to their unique mechanisms of action. This year, we engineered a collection of fusion proteins capable of forming antimicrobial coatings on first aid kit items by attaching domains that could bind to a wide range of first-aid materials to defensins and developing an innovative release mechanism using the SUMO tag. We envision our resistance-free antimicrobial CuraPack to provide protection against infections in diverse scenarios and propagate first aid knowledge throughout the world.
nominations: Best Part Collection, High School+Best Model, High School
advisors: CAI ANDREW CHEN, Steven
student leaders: Heming Gao, Hugo Jiang, PEIYU LIANG, TANG LI TING, TONG DING
students: Amanda, Amy Geng, Austin, Carl Chen, Catherine Li, Chelsea.liu, Elodie, Esme, Henry Li, Kaiyan Liu, Kitty Zhang, Miracle Wang, Qiao, sabrina Y, Tony, Wanghao Zhang, XIYAN CAI, YAWENTAN, ZHANG BAOHENG HENRY

title: Moskilla - A novel ATSB as a vector control method for mosquito-borne diseases
abstract: Mosquitoes transmit various infectious diseases, such as malaria and dengue fever, and current control measures are often inadequate. While attractive targeted sugar baits (ATSBs) have shown promise, they are not sufficiently appealing to blood-feeding mosquitoes, the main disease vectors. AIS-China introduces Moskilla, an optimized ATSB enhancing attractiveness by incorporating HMBPP-producing E. coli and RNAi-based targeted shRNA mosquitocides. The engineered E. coli overproduces HMBPP through an enhanced MEP pathway and the use of sRNAs to downregulate the expression of downstream enzyme IspH, yielding 0.45 mM HMBPP, while shRNAs, produced in yeast, achieved a 100% mortality rate in mosquitoes within three days. To ensure biosafety, a kill switch using the ?X174-E gene was developed for E. coli, enabling control outside laboratory settings. Moskilla, supported by a hardware device to limit GMOs use, represents an eco-friendly and effective solution for preventing and controlling mosquito-borne diseases, making it a promising innovation for our startup.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, High School+Best Hardware, High School+Best Entrepreneurship, High School+Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School
advisors: Dong AoYang, Kayden Ye, Tianshu Liu, Yuhan Gan
student leaders: Hairu Ma, Henry Wang, Mia Chen, Sharon Cheng, Wanyang (Sarah) Huang
students: Alex, Alex Liu, Emma, Emmy, Jack G, Jack Lin, Jerry???, Jessica, Jonathan Xu, Karen, Tony Su, Wendy

title: Muscure
abstract: As the incidence of IBD is increasing globally, the poor therapeutic experience, which the patients are required to receive long-term hormone injection and biologic combination therapy, is determined to seek a breakthrough. Our team stands to develop a more favorable treatment experience. Relevant studies have shown that lactic acid has an inhibitory effect on abnormally activated dendritic cells and cytotoxic T-cells in autoimmune diseases, and thus is expected to improve the symptoms of IBD patients. Based on the research, we designed a yeast engineered bacterium. We introduced a muscone detecting switch in the engineered yeast and activated the downstream pathway to express lactate dehydrogenase to produce lactic acid. Ultimately, the engineered bacteria will colonize the small intestine, enabling the patient to treat IBD by inhaling muscone gas in vitro therefore induces the yeast to synthesize a low amount of stabilized lactic acid in vivo.
nominations: Best Therapeutics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Model, Undergrad+Inclusivity Award, Undergrad
advisors: Haochen Zhong, Xinyi Li
students: Chalen Wakim, Changqi Fan, Haoran Chang, HauErn Lien, HouTeng Chan, Jiahui Chen, Shisu Li, Wang Yiming, Wanpeng Wu, Xiao Weihan, Yuhang Shen, Yuhan Xie, Zhefu Li, Zhouyuan Ji, Ziyue Li

title: Green production of active folates
abstract: A subset of pregnant women is unable to metabolize folic acid into its active form, a deficiency that can result in congenital malformations. These women require supplementation with the active form of folic acid. However, the production of active folic acid is hindered by low yields, high costs, and potential food safety concerns. Our project seeks to overcome these challenges by using genetic engineering to develop bacterial strains capable of expressing the enzymes required to convert folate into its active form. This approach has the potential to enable large-scale biological production of active folate. In the future, our research may provide a viable health supplement for pregnant women with impaired folic acid metabolism.
advisors: Deng Ziheng, Ding Tianyu, Jin Luming, Wang Shaowei, Wang Yihan, Xie Yongheng, Xu Pianhong, Xu Yinuo
