title: Engineered probiotics regulate short-chain fatty acids in the gut to alleviate depression
abstract: According to statistics from the World Health Organization, there are about 280 million depression patients in the world. Among them, the depression of school-age teenagers is more serious. How to improve the condition of patients is a major problem currently faced. The content of propionate and acetate in the intestine is believed to be related to a variety of diseases, including depression. In this study, we modified the metabolic pathways of the probiotic ECN to increase the content of other short-chain fatty acids such as acetate and propionate, helping to confirm the possibility of incorporating this technology into human practice. In the future, our project could serve as a body regulator used in probiotic capsules to help individuals improve or alleviate the negative effects of depression.
advisors: LI YANXI, Wang Zihang
student leaders: DUAN WENYAN, SUN TIANYU, Yichi Zhang, Yuan Yin
students: ANQI ZHAO, ANYI GE, Chen Shuai, GUANPING LIU, LI SHUHAN, LIU YUJIA, LIU YUSHI, LIU YUSI, LIU YUTONG, LU XIAOKE, Meng Fanda, Yanxun Wang, YingRan Han, ZHANG JUNSHENG, ZHIMING CAO

title: In Vivo DNA region-specific Semi-Random Mutagenesis: A Blue-Light-Controllable Basic Platform for Metabolic System Evolution
abstract: [Background] Gene mutations enhance biodiversity and agricultural benefits, but unpredictable mutagenesis methods pose risks, preventing their use in animals or humans. There are few methods available to introduce random mutations in specific genomic DNA regions without impacting other areas. [Design] We hypothesize that fusing Cytosine Base Editor (CBE) with blue-light-sensitive elements (p-Mag/n-Mag) and split T7 RNA polymerase (RNAP) could create a blue-light-controlled, DNA region-specific semi-random mutagenesis system. [Results] We used GFP as a real-time reporter and developed a fluorescent-based high-throughput screening workflow to select positive mutations. We applied the CBE-Mag-RNAP system to the NADPH, spermidine synthesis, and nicotinate degradation pathways in Escherichia coli. GFP-negative and selection-survived colonies, followed by next-generation sequencing, identified "gain of function" mutations. These enhanced Caenorhabditis elegans longevity through NADPH and spermidine pathways, while mutations in the nicotinate pathway restored lifespan in a high-nicotinate environment. [Conclusion] We established the CBE-Mag-RNAP mutagenesis system and a functional mutation library.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School
advisors: Jiarong Wang, Ziming Tian
student leaders: Chenyu Zheng, Daisy, Max, Ruoxi Du
students: Chloe, Judy Li, Lulu He, Si Chen, songyinuo, Steven Yibo Wang

title: Fluorofighters: A novel protein designed to bind and excrete PFAS from the blood
abstract: Our team aims to develop a therapeutic protein designed to eliminate concentrations of perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), with a specific focus on targeting perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA). Our novel protein is designed to work by binding to PFOA in the bloodstream and then removing it by excretion into the mucosa. This involves engineering a novel chimeric protein with two domains: one has a high affinity for PFOA while the other facilitates transcytosis of the whole peptide. After binding to PFOA in the bloodstream, this protein will facilitate its transcytosis across epithelial cells for excretion via the mucosal lining.
advisors: Ellie Wilson
students: Ana Isabel Lopez Murillo, Annika Heng Shi, Anusha Gupta, Aryan Kokkanti, Corinne Drabenstott, Danielle Nares, Dominic Kubissa, Elizabeth Krist, Evan, Ishita, Jack Titus, Julia Zhu, Keshav, Lahari Pokala, Layla Gusa, Logan Amos, Moiz Chomelawala, Osvaldo Linares, Pristine Onuoha, Samantha Carew, Sriya Darsi, Uditi Patil, Zaid Syed, Other, Hyunjun Yang

title: Improving quality and quantity of essential oil extraction using engineered E. coli
abstract: Essential oils have been used widely in daily life products (such as shampoo and soap). Currently, 93% of essential oils are extracted with steam distillation. While this method does not involve toxic chemicals, the yield of essential oil extraction is very low, usually less than 2% of the plant materials. Previous studies identified enzymes which could break down plant cell walls, increasing yield and preserving the quality of the oils. However, these enzymes are not stable during the boiling-hot steam distillation. We here used various engineered E. coli to produce thermostable enzymes (pectinase and cellulase) which allowed substantial enzyme activities during steam distillation, and significantly improved the yield. In addition, we produced lipases to esterify extracted oils, which enhanced their anti-bacterial properties. We also interacted with multiple industrial and academic partners, filed a patent, and designed hardware and models to ensure our project could be launched to the market shortly.
PIs: Wai Man Cheong, Lok In Lo, Seak Chi U
instructors: Fong Iao Nam, Fong Tin Cheng, KOU HIN KIT, LEONG WENG I
advisors: Lee Tsz On
students: Ana Guo, Camellia Cheong, Carina Tong, Cheng Seng Hei, Cheok U Lei, CHIEN-YUEH LIU, Clovis Chang, Iek Tong Lui, Ka Cheng Chan, lam ian cheng, Lok Man Chiu, Lou Chi Kuan, Mei Wai Kuok, Natalia Do Espirito Santo Lo, Olivia Lin, ON KEI CHU, Si Fong, Yik Sam Hei Jacynth

title: ErythrO2
abstract: ErythrO2 addresses the global blood shortage by developing a strategy for the recombinant production of Lumbricus terrestris erythrocruorin (LtEc), an extracellular oxygen carrier found in earthworms, in order to contribute to the development of a shelf-stable, non-toxic, and efficient hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier (HBOC). Our project focused on cloning and expressing the six protein subunits comprising LtEc in a yeast and E. coli chassis--the first time this has been done. We successfully cloned five subunits for expression in Pichia pastoris and four subunits for expression in E. coli. We achieved successful expression of one subunit in Pichia pastoris and three subunits in E. coli. Additionally, we designed a shuttle vector for recombinant expression in Pichia pastoris, which future teams can utilize for their synthetic biology projects. In the dry lab, we tested linker truncation and established the possibility of a modified LtEc structure with higher binding efficiency.
nominations: Best Entrepreneurship, Undergrad
students: Ferzam Mahmood, Giovanna Acosta, Graciela Emmanuelle Manalili, Jodh Atwal, Kfir Lerner, Luis Martinez Hoyos, Maren, Morgan, Nirmal Cheema, Saqib Syed, Si Chen Pan, Tina

title: Dux. -- Developing Novel Treatment for Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy via Competitive Inhibition
abstract: Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy (FSHD) is a rare neuromuscular disorder affecting approximately 1 in 12,000 people, causing progressive and highly variable loss of skeletal muscle, as well as debilitating pain and fatigue. The root cause of FSHD is the aberrant expression of the DUX4 gene, which encodes a transcription factor that activates a cascade of hundreds of typically silent target genes. The DUX4 transcription factor comprises two main parts: the DNA-binding domain (DBD) and transcriptional activation domain (TAD), which is responsible for activating downstream target genes. Our approach is centered on overexpressing a modified form of the DUX4-DBD lacking the TAD. DUX4-DBD competes for DUX4 binding sites, inhibiting pathogenic DUX4 and stopping downstream gene activation. We are also modulating the components of our engineered protein, exploring the use of fusing a KRAB (Krüppel Associated Box) repressor domain to maximize our therapeutic potential as a suppressor of DUX4-activated genes.
nominations: Best Therapeutics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Education, Undergrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad
PIs: Drew Endy, Huijun Ring, Phillip Kyriakakis
advisors: Ngoc Tran
students: Amanuel Geremew, Ayushi Mohanty, Heloise Hoffmann, Maria Fernanda Velasquez Rolleri, Michael Liu, Vanessa Chiprez Meza

title: BioXane: Engineering Bacteria in Bioreactors to Remove 1,4-Dioxane from Water Systems
abstract: 1,4-Dioxane is a Group 2B carcinogen that poses immediate risk to human health and is a byproduct of many common industrial processes. For over two decades, 1,4-dioxane was improperly disposed of into a tributary that feeds into the Huron River, the primary water supply for the city of Ann Arbor, Michigan. The current remediation method is expensive and inefficient. Additionally, it introduces bromate, another carcinogen, to the water in the process. Our team engineered and optimized a freshwater bacteria (Pseudomonas putida S16) with a tetrahydrofuran monooxygenase gene complex (THFMO) known to naturally degrade 1,4-dioxane. Our bacteria are suited to operate within a bioreactor, which we aim to implement in tandem with existing infrastructure. Our ultimate goal is to improve the sustainability, efficiency, and efficacy of the current water treatment process.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, Undergrad
advisors: Kareem Aboulhosn
student leaders: Aditi Ganesan, Henry Zhang, Jaclyn Carrannanto, Joel Groves, Kimberly Lillios, Sashider Rajesh, Schuyler Byrn, Sophia Tesic, Sriram Sai Garapati
students: Allison Myers, Amita Gowda, Aryan Kini, Avi Patel, Brady Braund, Chaitra Moolaveesala, Hania Timek, Haniya Farooq, Harini Ram, Leah Jankoska, Mahadev Josyabhatla, Malik Alabbas, Mihika Rayan, Minha Kim, Nikhil Myers, Noah Black, Saad Alrazzi, Temmie Yu, Vamsi Gollapalli, Xuan An Le, Yashwanth Bajji

title: TIME2ACT: Transformative innovation in material enzyme engineering to advance carbon capture technology
abstract: Our team consists of 50 passionate mentors and students from three academic institutions in Gatineau, Québec, Canada. In our inaugural iGEM season, we have focused our efforts on tackling plastic pollution and the climate crisis, exploring how to position our project and outreach activities to maximize our impact on these urgent environmental issues. Our project, TIME2ACT, leverages PET-degrading enzymes to transform poorly recycled PET plastic waste into durable and high-performance mesoporous materials, with applications in carbon capture and electrochemical storage and conversion industries. By utilizing our newly acquired skills in synthetic biology, entrepreneurship, and communication, we strive to give new value to the plastic debris that pollutes our forests, lakes, and rivers, while also contributing to global efforts to combat climate change and raise awareness in our community that it is indeed TIME2ACT.
advisors: Camille Letang, Catherine Hallé, Frederique Marcotte, Josee Pennober, Mathieu, Michel Halloran
students: Alexis Gravelle, Alphonce Mechaalani, Ana Necrasov, Axelle Santerre, Béatrice Rousseau, Chloé Périard, Dania Cryans, Daphnée Marshman, Émilie Stuart, emma jeanne morinville, Emmanuel, Faustina Rodriguez, Gabriel Juteau Couture, Gaya Teklal, Grace Ntidjouo Wété, Hillary Sonon, Ines Ayad, Inès Bosse-Thompson, Juliette Gaudreau, Justin Dufour, Kaliana Enos, Laurence Nadeau, Lily-Rose Comtois, Maeva Leluan, Mansoor Bin Atya, Maroun Mechaalani, Matis Nadon, Mia Novakovic, Nadia Hébert, Nicholas Mo, Nico Poirier, Nylane Faye, Rosemarie Proulx, Samar Hattab, Sofia Hughes, Other, Angelo Pool Rodriguez

title: ATLAS - Antigen Triggered Ligand Amplification System
abstract: CAR-T cell therapy has demonstrated remarkable success in treating blood-based cancers, but faces significant challenges in combating solid tumors. ATLAS (Antigen Triggered Ligand Amplification System) is a genetic circuit designed to enhance the efficacy of CAR-T cell therapy in difficult cancers. The system addresses antigen loss, a major challenge where tumors reduce or lose expression of target antigens, that limits CAR-T efficacy. ATLAS combines two synthetic receptors, low-affinity CAR and high-affinity synNotch, to amplify antigen availability at the tumor site. Upon synNotch activation by tumor-specific ligands, the system secretes soluble antigens that stimulate nearby CAR-T cells, creating an activation feedback loop. This process recruits immune cells to the tumor through cytokine release, enhancing the immune response in tumors with diminished antigen expression. By increasing the local concentration of antigens, ATLAS aims to improve CAR-T persistence and effectiveness to treat solid tumors.
students: Alexander Diefes, Ashi Jain, Bashir Sbaiti, Bowen Kim, Daliya Rizvi, Kay Lyon, Palak Jolly, Robert Kaptur, Rohit Suresh, Yi-Chen Lin

title: Bio Si-ment
abstract: The USAFA iGEM 2024 team is focused on optimizing biosilicification by expressing the INP-silicatein-? gene in E. coli to address global and local environmental challenges, such as CO2 production in the cement industry, desertification, and agricultural topsoil degradation. Our efforts are divided into three key areas: dust mitigation, plant growth in biosilicified soil, and cement brick formation. We verified that SiO2 formation is catalyzed by our new part. We were able to eliminate the use of urea in biocementation and our biosilicification produced less ammonium than microbially induced calcite precipitation while allowing plant germination in biocemented soil. Throughout the project, our team engaged with the community by participating in local science events, consulting with farmers, and receiving insights from a rotorcraft mechanic. Our work has contributed valuable research to genetic engineering and sustainable development.
PIs: Victoria Morrison, Melanie Grogger, J. Jordan Steel, Joel Coffman
students: Aaron Kim, Anna Greer, Asha, Bridger Grothe, Cathy, Damer, Dominic Senft, Hannah Grover, Jaina Swann, Luke Maki, Maddie, Megan Leong, Mychele D, Raj Raghulan, Robert McDougal, Taylor McManus, Thomas, Veda Raja, Other, Dixie Holmes

title: Transgenic Silkworms Promoting PET Plastic Degradation
abstract: In modern society, PET plastic plays an increasingly significant role in our daily lives. Correspondingly, the challenge of effectively degrading PET plastics has drawn the attention of researchers and environmentalists, among other people who concern about the environment. Building on previous research, we created a new silkworm strain by microinjecting recombinant gene expression vectors containing the Fast-PETase and MHETase enzymes, which have been proven to facilitate the degradation of PET plastics. Through further experiments, we demonstrated that the transgenic cocoons secreted by these genetically modified silkworms could effectively degrade PET plastic products. This outcome provides a new solution for biodegradation of PET plastics. Our long-term goal is to achieve industrial-scale production of this new transgenic silk and promote sustainability by enabling the recycling of PET plastics through their degradation byproducts, such as TPA, MHET, and EG, as they are also the raw materials of PET plastics.
advisors: Blake
students: Bowen Ye, Bruce, Clara Tao, Daisy, Rachel Gong, serafina, Serein Luuu, Sinky Tong, Thomas Zhu, yuezongguang, ???

title: The Future of Agriculture
abstract: Ningxia, China, faces significant agricultural challenges due to high evaporation rates, resulting in crop failures. To address this issue, we propose a novel approach utilizing genetically engineered E. coli to produce hyaluronic acid hydrogels. Hyaluronic acid is a naturally occurring polymer known for its exceptional water-retention properties. By applying hyaluronic acid into the agricultural sector, we aim to create a cost-effective and sustainable solution to combat drought-induced crop losses. Our strategy involves genetically modifying E. coli to express enzymes that are crucial in producing hyaluronic acid. The modified bacteria will produce hyaluronic acid, which can be extracted and used to create hydrogels. These hydrogels will be designed to absorb and retain moisture in the soil, reducing water loss and improving soil hydration levels. The ultimate goal of this project is to assist farmers in drought-prone regions, such as Ningxia, with a practical and affordable tool to enhance crop yields.
nominations: Best Education, High School
PIs: Kin Tak Samuel Cheng, Man Wo Sau
instructors: Li Qian Xin Andreas, Yu Wing Hin
advisors: Irene
students: Alice Chung, Andy Tse, Arin, Fung Long Yin, Helen Ng, Ho Ying Tung, Joseph Tin Lok Chau, Ko Tik Kesniel, Wong Chun Ning Davin, Wong Janice, Wong Yu Fei Hanna, Yan Hoi Shun

title: MIDAS: Modular Infectious Disease Annihilation System
abstract: Craspase, an RNA-activated protease, integrates a Cas enzyme (gRAMP) and the Csx29 protease to target specific proteins upon RNA binding. This project explores utilizing Craspase, delivered via lambda bacteriophages, to neutralize antibiotic resistance genes in bacteria, particularly ampicillin resistance. Specifically, we will employ an engineered fusion protein to modulate Runella bacterial gasdermin protein, inducing cell death through pyroptosis in response to mRNA indicative of ampicillin resistance. With the rising threat of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, innovative approaches such as bacteriophage therapy are crucial. Our strategy involves modifying a plasmid to express both the Craspase system and the fusion protein anchoring the gasdermin, which will be introduced into ampicillin-resistant E. coli. We aim to monitor bacterial responses on agar plates supplemented with ampicillin. This work aims to demonstrate the effectiveness of phage-mediated delivery of Craspase and fusion proteins in targeting antibiotic resistance, offering a novel approach to combat multidrug-resistant infections and enhance medicine.
student leaders: Austin Thrasher, Elena Zobel, Jenna Mueller, Julian Foat, Lindsay Schneider, Lucas Navarro, Tristan Crawford
students: Alex, Anjana Goli, Ava, Ben, Caleb Stanford, Cooper Healy, Drake O'Leary, Elizabeth Bone, Ellie, Erik Bergstrom, Ethan, Ethan Beane, Gavin W, John Neely, Mary Lucy, Mercury Lusk, Rachel, Sam, Samantha Tordilla, Skylyn, Star Nedved

title: Hydrolink: An Engineered Living Wound Dressing that Targets Infected Wound Sites
abstract: As of 2023, over 6.5 million people in the United States alone suffer from chronic wounds. This means that annually, around 40 million people deal with painful, slow healing or recurring wounds that are expensive to treat. With Hydrolink, we aim to engineer Lactobacillus reuteri to be able to detect staph. aureus, the most common wound pathogen, and respond by secreting targeted antimicrobial proteins. This detection is achieved with autoinducing peptide (AIP), which is used by staph. aureus for quorum sensing. After achieving successful transformation, the bacteria can be integrated into a hydrogel material to form a living wound dressing. This method has advantages over alternatives like traditional wound dressings, which must be taken off to check for infection, causing pain and inefficiency. In addition to our wet-lab research, we performed computational modeling and developed a fluorometer to be used with the hydrogel product.
nominations: Best Entrepreneurship, High School+Best Integrated Human Practices, High School
advisors: Dave F, Mustafo Mustafokulov
student leaders: Alexa Seltzer, Damini Rosenblatt, Daniel Yi, Malika Mustafokulova

title: Ligninolytic Enzymes Plus Nanozymes: A Sharp Weapon for Lignocellulose Degradation
abstract: Modern global warming has posed serious threat to climate and related life on earth. The greenhouse gas emissions caused by fossil fuels are the main culprit of global warming. It is of great urgent to develop renewable and green energy to solve this issue. Lignocellulose biomass is promising precusor for developing renewable energy to cope with greenhouse gas emissions. However, the current lignocellulose degradation methods are limited by low efficiency and are environmentally unfriendly and energy consuming. What can be done with synthetic biology? In this project, we engineered the tgenes of cytochrome C mature protein (Ccm) operon and transformed into P. putida, creating a cellular factory that produce abundant ligninolytic enzymes, which simutaneously produce manganese oxide acting as ligninolytic nanozyme. Finally, the enzymes plus nanozyme sucessfully realize lignin degradation with high efficiency.
PIs: Lianbing Zhang, WEINING NIU, Yao Chen

title: Engineered E. coli for Heavy Metal Removal in Water Treatment
abstract: Heavy metals pose serious health risks, including neurotoxicity, kidney damage, and cancer. Our team enhances bioremediation by engineering E. coli to express rice metallothionein (OsMTI-1b) for effective metal binding and genes from Sporosarcina pasteurii for Microbiologically Induced Calcite Precipitation, turning heavy metal ions into easily removable precipitates. Our engineered bacteria are designed for use in facilities or regions requiring heavy metal remediation, such as industrial wastewater treatment plants. This approach ensures that the solution is practical and scalable, providing a greener alternative to conventional methods and contributing to safer water supplies worldwide.
nominations: Best Hardware, High School+Best Sustainable Development Impact, High School

title: EcoSweet: Biosynthesized Allose - Sweet & Sustainable
abstract: Faced with the problem of diabetes, which is skyrocketing globally due to excessive intake of sucrose, we would like to use a natural sugar substitute, allose, as a healthier alternative to sucrose. However, the cost of natural extraction and production methods for allose remains high, and to address this challenge, our team developed an allose biosensor based on alsR transcriptional regulators. The sensor has been rigorously tested and demonstrated specificity and high efficiency to convert allose production into a real-time fluorescence response. Meanwhile, we have further optimized the sensor performance by using computational prediction and molecular docking techniques, combined with random mutagenesis, which lays a solid foundation for achieving low-cost and large-scale microbial synthesis of allose.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Leyu Xu, Yaoyao Liang

title: Heart Bodyguard: Yeast heterologous synthesis of active ingredients of Salvia
abstract: The incidence of myocarditis has increased after COVID-19, posing a threat to public health. Traditional Chinese medicine, Salvia miltiorrhiza (Danshen), its active compounds, such as tanshinone, and a similar structure diterpenoid carnosic acid, which is also extracted from Salvia, have proven effective in treating cardiovascular diseases, including anti-inflammatory and cardioprotective benefits. However, traditional production methods are limited by high cost and time-consuming. To address this issue, we use Saccharomyces cerevisiae, leveraging its inherent MVA pathway to construct a novel synthetic pathway for the efficient production of tanshinone and carnosic acid. This sustainable, scalable method may revolutionize cardiovascular drug production, expanding applications in drug development and combating cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Siqi Yang, Zhang Zhaoxia
student leaders: Frida Sun, Hanqing Yang, Yu Zhe
students: Catherine Zhang, Huanming Zeng, Jiamin Cao, Jingqiu Sha, Jingtian Shi, Pengrun Gu, Wanyi Jiang, Xiangren LI, Yiran Zhao, YUANSHI JI, Yuxuan Zhang, Zhihuan Fang, Zi Ye

title: AHL Assassins: Engineering Bacillus subtilis to Disarm Aquaculture Pathogens
abstract: The huge aquaculture industry in China faces serious threats from Aeromonas hydrophila, a pathogenic bacterium that can cause motile septicemia in aquatic animals. This pathogen utilizes AHL molecules to activate quorum sensing and express virulence factors. To combat A. hydrophila, we introduced AHL lactonases from various bacteria to Bacillus subtilis. By degrading AHL, our engineered B. subtilis can reduce the virulence of A. hydrophila and protect aquaculture animals. In the future, we hope that this approach could be scaled up for widespread application, potentially integrating with existing aquaculture practices to provide a sustainable and effective solution against bacterial pathogens.
nominations: Best Entrepreneurship, High School
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Kexin Fei, Yuqi Fu
student leaders: Luning Feng, Zijun Mu, Ziyue Wang
students: Chenxuan You, Congyu Yang, Dora, Emma Hu, Kaden Xuan Wang, Keyan Chen, Kuang Xiao, LuoYuheng, Ruoxi Sun, siyutan, Tianyi Wang, Xiao Fucheng, Xuan Lai, Yuwen Shan, Zitong Fu

title: Design and Application of Recombinant Human Serum Albumin for Enhanced NIR-II Imaging Probes
abstract: Our project focuses on developing an optimized near-infrared II (NIR-II) imaging probe using a recombinant human serum albumin (rHSA) mutant. By mutating the cysteine residue at position 476 to glycine (C476G), we successfully disrupted the disulfide bond between Cys476 and Cys487, exposing a reactive thiol group. This modification significantly enhances the covalent binding efficiency between rHSA and NIR-II dyes, particularly the Cn-1080 family (such as CO-1080). Our research includes computational simulations and experimental validation, demonstrating improved binding affinity, stability, and imaging performance in deep tissues, such as the blood-testis and blood-brain barriers. The probe simplifies preparation under mild conditions and has broad applications in biomedical imaging, tumor surgery navigation, and diagnostics. This novel approach offers a robust and reproducible solution for advancing NIR-II imaging in complex biological environments.
students: Du Yijing, Jiawei Gao, Li Jiaying, Minghan Liu, Tianye Guo, yilin sun, Yushan Liu, Zetao Dang

title: LuminAid
abstract: Today, humanity is confronted with numerous challenges, which makes space exploration increasingly urgent. Nevertheless, the current astronaut suits have deficiencies in guaranteeing the safety and long-term survival of astronauts. Inspired by this, our team has designed an integrated Luminescent Rescue Life Support System by applying the principles of synthetic biology. The LuminAid in the project is a photosynthetic autotrophic fluorescent life-saving device, applicable to both marine and space scenarios. In the marine context, it is a collapsible bag containing engineered bacterial powder, which proliferates and glows when encountering seawater, enhancing the visibility of the person in distress. In the space setting, the symbiotic system of algae and bacteria enables the astronaut suit to emit light for illumination and orientation, and it can also produce oxygen and organic substances to supply the life activities of astronauts and meet emergency demands. The project is widely applicable and innovative.
nominations: Safety and Security Award, Undergrad
PIs: Shi Hu, Changhai Lei, Ruixue Mao, Wenyan Fu
advisors: Yujun Qu
students: Anqi Hu, Bufan Ying, Chencan Fang, Jiatong Li, Mengcan Sun, Ruhan Li, Ruitong Liu, Xinyue Yang, Xinyue Yu, Xinyu Shen, Xuanrong Liu, Yinuo Zhang, Yitian Zhou, Yukai Cheng, Zhangdong Liu, Zihan Ding

title: One-for-All Synbiotic Therapy (OAST)
abstract: In the contemporary world, chronic diseases such as hypertension, diabetes, and colitis are progressively emerging as significant global health threats. The engineering strain chosen for our project is Zymomonas mobilis, primarily due to its anaerobic fermentation capability and high tolerance towards sugar and acid. This strain exhibits enhanced suitability for the intestinal environment and produces fructooligosaccharides, which can effectively promote the growth of gut microbiota and potentially achieve targeted colonization. By employing targeted metabolic engineering design, modification, testing, and application of Zymomonas mobilis, we aim to develop a synbiotic microbial therapy that integrates prevention, diagnostic reporting, and responsive treatment modules. Compared to conventional treatment methods, synbiotic therapy offers superior levels of safety, stability, adaptability, and targeting. Moreover, the duration of its medicinal effects is prolonged, effectively addressing the requirement for patients to adhere to specific timing and dosages in traditional treatments.
PIs: Qiaoning He, Haimou Zhang, Jingwen Zhang, Mengqi Liu, Shihui Yang, Xia Wang
students: anna dai, Chunyan Xie, Deijiang Chen, Dengle Xiong, Han Wang, Jingxian Zhu, mandos, Ma zihui, Niexin Zhou, Qianyu Wen, RUIYAN WU, Shan Zha, Shiwen Yang, Sihang Wang, Siyun He, songxixi, XiaoYue Li, xixisong, Xi xuan Yang, Xiyue Zeng, Yixuan Liu, Yuxin Zhang, Ziyan Shi

title: Tea's Odor Alchemy: Osmanthus Enzyme Magic
abstract: This project is committed to developing an innovative aromatic product aimed at relieving stress. Our core ingredient is ?-ionone, a fragrant molecule found in a variety of flowers, which has been demonstrated to have significant sedative and mood-soothing effects. Through synthetic biology techniques, we have genetically modified Escherichia coli to express Osmanthus fragrans carotenoid cleavage dioxygenase 4 (OfCCD4), an enzyme that can convert carotenoids into ?-ionone. To achieve sustainable development, our project has adopted an innovative method: using discarded tea leaves or tea dregs, which are rich in carotenoids, as substrates for the synthesis of ?-ionone. Our final detection experiment successfully verified the synthesis of ?-ionone through gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) analysis. Our project not only focuses on the functionality of the product but also emphasizes a design philosophy that values health, fashion, and environmental sustainability.
advisors: Danfeng Zhang, Huijia Li, Penghao Han, Wenjie, Xianfu Zeng
student leaders: Tengyu Cui, Youjie Fang, Zhou wuxinrui
students: Jiaen Shi, JIA RUINING, Jiawen Zhang, Ruiheng (Rae) Yu, TIAN YUANMUGE, Yaqi Shao, YULIN XU, Yutianle Piao, Zhou He

title: Methane ReMOOver - Reducing Methane Emissions from Cattle
abstract: Cattle release around 80 million tons of methane into the atmosphere annually, significantly contributing to global warming. The methane is produced by methanogens in the cow's rumen as a by-product of enteric fermentation, also resulting in energy loss for the animal. We aim to reduce the methane emissions from cattle by synthetically engineering Cupriavidus necator to produce bromoform, a known methanogenesis inhibitor. The engineered bacteria would ideally colonize the rumen and become a permanent member of the microbiome, continuously inhibiting methane production from within. Our gene insert consists of a bromoperoxidase gene originating from marine bromoform-producing organisms, as well as a hydrogen peroxidase gene to supply the required substrate for bromoperoxidase. While we successfully transformed our simplest construct, only one bromoperoxidase showed protein expression. However, in-vitro co-culturing of C. Necator with methanogens showed decreased methane production, probably due to its competition for the same resources as methanogens.
nominations: Best Climate Crisis Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
students: Abbe, Anna Magnone, Beritan Sert, Borja Medina de las Heras, Emma Stafilidou Hedlund, Faidra Alefantou, Hadiqa Inam, Husam Jamal, Johanna Pehrsson, Lydia Bucher, Mikael Seibold, Olov Nilsson, Xiaotong Jiang

title: Herbal Code----Construction of a biosynthetic pathway for Salvia divinorum phenolic acids in model organisms
abstract: Danshen, the root of Salvia miltiorrhiza, is widely recognized as an effective medicine for treating cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, but there are many limitations in the extraction of its active components. To overcome these limitations, our project employs synthetic biology techniques to design two synthetic pathways. Utilizing endogenously produced 4-coumaroyl-CoA in tobacco as the acyl donor, we introduce key enzymes and precursor substances exogenously to synthesize rosmarinic acid. In pathway one, we introduce danshensu, SmRAS10, and SmCYP98A14; in pathway two, we introduce 4-hydroxyphenyllactate, SmRAS10, SmCYP98A14, and SmCYP98A75. LC-MS/MS results indicate that both pathways are capable of synthesizing rosmarinic acid in tobacco leaves. Moving forward, the project will focus on further optimizing production efficiency. This not only provides a new strategy for the sustainable development of Salvia miltiorrhiza but also suggests that this method can be applied to the production of other medicinal components.
advisors: Penghao Han, Yufan Chao, Zhou Tan
student leaders: kejia chen, Lingchuan Wang, Zihan Hua
students: Beatrice, CHAI ZHIHAN, Jacky, Jiahao He, Jinhan Liu, Wendy, Wenjie, wuyou Shi, YANG?ZHUOER, Youxuan Qu, Zhang Shenrui

title: Microbiological manufacturing, Protect skin health
abstract: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are toxic byproducts of oxygen metabolism and a major cause of skin aging. The skin has a natural defense system to eliminate ROS, but as we age and with increased UV exposure, these protective substances diminish, allowing more free radicals to accumulate and cause cellular damage. Studies have shown that neoagarooligosaccharides (NAOS) possess antioxidant properties and can effectively inhibit excess ROS. Our project involves designing an E. coli prokaryotic expression system to produce ?-agarase (AgaA), an enzyme that specifically cleaves the ?-1,4 glycosidic bond between D-galactose and 3,6-anhydro-?-L-galactose residues in agarose, generating the antioxidant NAOS. Using the ABTS method, we confirmed the antioxidant capability of NAOS. This antioxidant can be incorporated into skincare products to eliminate excess ROS in the skin, thereby protecting skin health.
advisors: Danfeng Zhang, Huijia Li, Ningyi Zhang, Penghao Han, Wenjie
student leaders: Mike Shen, Tang Zhuo, YINGBO XU
students: Gloria, HAO JIANG, liu yueng, Lou xin lei, MIAOCHEN ZHANG, Nico Ni, SIJIA GAO, Thomas, Xinyan Lu, Yanni, yitong Lin, Yubo Sun, Zhang Mengqi, Zhangtong Xiao, Zhang Yuqi, ?? ?

title: Scentinel: Fragrance for Empowerment
abstract: Scentinel is an innovative project that harnesses synthetic biology to produce aromatic compounds aimed at improving the lives of visually impaired women. The name "Scentinel" combines "scent" and "sentinel," symbolizing how our fragrance-based solutions act as a guardian for women's health, particularly during their menstrual periods. By engineering yeast to biosynthesize terpenes like limonene and nerol, we develop products that emit specific scents, helping women detect the onset of their menstrual periods. This empowers them to manage their menstrual health with greater independence and dignity. Additionally, our products include fragrances designed to alleviate anxiety and stress during menstruation, along with antimicrobial properties to ensure hygiene. Through this project, we aim to combine science and empathy, creating solutions that address both physiological and emotional needs, ultimately enhancing the quality of life for this underserved community.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School+Best Wiki, High School
PIs: Yu, XU JUNMEI, Wanjun Chen, kong qing, Qiao Guo
advisors: Mingsheng Zheng, nmy, Xiaojuan Wang
student leaders: Alyse, chenquqing, Crystal Zhao, Daniel Lin, Moxuan Lu, Vicky Tian, zilingxu
students: DaisyDu, Dengsiyu, Ethan, Jerry, Katherine zhang liyu, Kingsley SJ, Luyang, Serena Lou, Shi Xiaotang, Yunjia Zhang

title: Petalglow - to comfort, to companion, to inspire
abstract: Anxiety disrupts the ability to relax, leading to difficulties in falling asleep. Traditional night lights, which many rely on for comfort. Exposure to light before bed can suppress melatonin levels, making it harder to fall asleep. PetalGlow was designed to offer a unique and holistic approach to mental well-being. At daytime, PetalGlow incorporates the therapeutic benefits of horticultural therapy. It arrives as a young plant, ready to grow under your care. Daily tasks like watering and caring for PetalGlow's growth create a mindful routine that alleviates mild anxiety and stress, promotes relaxation, and enhances mood. As night falls, PetalGlow takes its therapeutic effects a step further by emitting a soft, calming bioluminescent light that creates an ideal pre-sleep environment. Unlike harsh night lights, PetalGlow's subtle glow provides just enough illumination to ease you into a restful state without disrupting the darkness needed for sleep.
PIs: Xiaojuan Wang, Wanjun Chen, Lichuan Chen, Kai Wang, Yueqi Zeng, Zhang Rui
advisors: Aoruan, Mingsheng Zheng
student leaders: Amy fu, Jeff li, Juliette, Kevin Raymond Ye, Mu Xingzhu, WangKaiyuan
students: Chengcheng, Guangbo Lu, Hannah Xu, Han ZOU, Jinrui Liu, Lijunhao, Peng Yujun, Robert, Yuxiang Long, Zoey

title: Morpheus
abstract: Morpheus project aims to tackle the degradation of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) into bioproducts yielding high industrial value, in order to address the pressing plastic crisis in today's world. To achieve this, our objective is to create a mutant strain of a single-cell algae, Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, competent to bioconvert PET into terpenes, specifically vanillic acid, for its appealing use in satisfaction of the rising demand of various end-use industries. The biodegradation pathway involving these enzymes has already been discovered in the bacterium Ideonella sakaiensis. However, our innovative approach consists of integrating this pathway in a green component of the natural cycle, by a transformation process with a plasmid constructed by us containing the fusion protein of PETase-MHETase enzymes. This step is followed by the conversion of the product of terephthalic acid (TPA) to vanillic acid, leaving a byproduct of ethylene glycol (EG), lucrative for industrial and pharmaceutical uses.
students: Alexis FRANCOIS, Alizée Fernandes Pereira, Amira Chabani, cremer manon, Dominique Baran, IOANNA DIMITROPOULOU, Maria Avtodeeva, Nicole Alizade, Oceane Li, Polina Filchak, Selma Aichour, Thomas Louvet, Thrinethra Shankar, Trayana Hristova, Ysilde Capet--Virbel

title: VersaTobacco
abstract: The high chlorogenic acid accumulation in Nicotiana benthamiana limits its potential for synthesizing other products. To develop tobacco as a versatile chassis for the short-term, efficient synthesis of desired plant natural products, we first constructed a genome-scale metabolic model (GSMM) and used COBRA algorithms to formulate the best metabolic flow adjustment strategies. Subsequently, the critical gene NbHQTs for chlorogenic acid synthesis in tobacco was knocked out using CRISPR/Cas9, and a low chlorogenic acid level tobacco chassis was obtained. We then introduced heterologous synthetic pathways for phaselic acid, resveratrol, and crocin into the chassis and improved the synthesis capability by engineered critical enzymes. The chassis could quickly synthesize the desired functional products to fulfill different requirements and is expected to be developed into an efficient biological reactor for the biopharmaceutical industry, thereby promoting the green transformation and upgrading of the traditional tobacco cultivation industry.
nominations: Best Foundational Advance Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
students: Bohan Yu, Chenyu Yang, ChenZhe Fu, Chong Yao, Chuanyan Zhang, Danning Zhang, Haoen Gao, Jiachen Wei, Jiajun Xiao, Junqiao Song, Junxian Li, Le Dong, Luyao Deng, Qisha Yang, Shanshan Yao, Shifeng Chen, Sining Wang, Siyuan Wang, Weizhen Li, Yuhan Tang, Yuwen Zhao, Yuzhao Liao, Zhangyu You, Zhitong Lu

title: Team has withdrawn
abstract: Team has withdrawn
students: Hao Jiaqi, Yixin Cai, Yujia Jacqueline Fu

title: HaloWorld: An efficient microbial electrosynthesis system for bio-utilization of carbon dioxide-derived electrolyste by engineered Halomonas
abstract: In an endeavor to mitigate the escalating crisis of global carbon dioxide emissions, we have engineered Halomonas TD, a salt-resistant microorganism, to efficiently synthesize multiple bioproducts from carbon dioxide-derived electrolyte(CDE), which primarily consisting of acetate. In the course of our project, we have incorporated the formate assimilation pathway and enhanced TD's tolerance to acetate through adaptive laboratory evolution (ALE), thereby augmenting the conversion rate. Owing to the absence of efficient dynamic control tools in TD, we have constructed a thermosensitive bio-switch (T-switch) tailored to its requirements. By leveraging the modified TD, we have successfully achieved the production of P34HB, Tyrian purple, SOD, and PhaP. To address the issue of high-density induction failure encountered during large-scale production, we have developed a fermentation model capable of real-time feeding. Concurrently, we have also created a software application for genome neutral locus screening, which has been seamlessly integrated into our project.
advisors: Chi wang
student leaders: Hao Li, Jun Wang, Ziyang Zhang
students: chang yixin, Chromatic_Vizier, FuHaicheng, Jiawen Peng, Jing Guo, kzk, LEYI YE, Yixun Huang, YSJ, Yujiao Yang, ???, ? ?

title: PLASTICOPS
abstract: Microplastic pollution is a global threat. Humans, on average, are exposed to 2012 ± 598 microplastic particles, through ingestion, inhalation, or dermal contact, causing serious health issues like reproductive abnormalities, oxidative stress and neurotoxicity. To address this issue, we propose a three-stage solution utilising the affinity between peptides and microplastics: modeling, expression and deployment. Interaction between shortlisted peptides and microplastic particles were studied using molecular dynamics. The most efficient peptide's sequence was cloned into expression host E.coli BL21(DE3). The recombinant peptides, containing hexa histidine tags bind strongly to Ni-NTA affinity resins. The his-tags aided purification and in deployment. The resin-peptide complex efficiently captures hydrophobic microplastics upon contact. Microscopic and spectrofluorimetric analyses of the recovered resin-peptide complex would demonstrate the successful removal of microplastics from the test sample. This method is simple, avoids harmful chemicals, and works under various conditions.
advisors: Rhea Harry William
students: Ajay Karthik M, Eniya A M, Jeevananthan M, JEOTHILASHMI ANNADURAI, Jothi Murugan S, KADHIRAVAN S, Kamakshi Balasubramanian, Keerthika Sathish Kumar, Lokaveenasri D, MANOJ M G, Nandhithaa Narayana Pillai, Naveen K, Pradeep, Priyadharshini Sakthivel, Purushothaman, Saikrupa Vijay shankar, Sanjeevan Hari Sudhakar

title: nuCloud: The New Nucleotide-Based Data Storage Cloud
abstract: As global demand for data storage skyrockets, studies report that traditional data centres are projected to be incapable of meeting the demands of the near future. They also cause environmental damage by depleting natural resources. nuCloud is a synthetic biology-based DNA data storage platform that addresses the unmet demand for global data storage. Inspired by the high storage density, durability, and efficiency of DNA, nuCloud offers a solid-phase enzymatic DNA synthesis system using a thermostable TdT variant. Combined with an automated microfluidic system and error-correcting software pipeline, nuCloud can encode digital information into nucleotide sequences, synthesize corresponding DNA strands, and decode it back to binaries for its users. This innovative approach provides a sustainable and scalable biomanufacturing solution to meet the data storage demands of the future.
nominations: Best Biomanufacturing Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
students: Achint Lail, Ada Jiang, Aden Chan, Aoniya Colynn, Burak Ozkan, Charlotte Lee, Chloe King, Daniel Hinatsu, Diego Perez Hidalgo, Jessica Xin, Karen Lin, Keheng Wang, Lucy Hao, Matthias Wong, Pattarin Blanchard, Piyush Awasthi, Qing Ru Kong, Ran Tao, Riya Alluri, Samuel Salitra, Sebastian Hyland, Yejin Lhee

title: Plasmid.AI: An intelligent platform to write new life
abstract: This year at iGEM Toronto, we are developing Plasmid.AI - a platform that uses generative AI to create new, functional DNA sequences. Our ultimate goal is to write entirely new genomes to create novel organisms that have fine-tuned phenotypes. To make headway towards this challenging task, we are starting with the simplest proof of concept - the generation and validation of new plasmid components. To do this, our dry lab team employs sequence-based machine learning approaches to generate novel plasmid sequences. Key plasmid components, such as the origin of replication, are generated and validated in silico. The wet lab team then assesses the viability of these components in vitro - the results of these assays refining dry lab's next iteration of sequences. Concurrently, the hardware team develops high-throughput tools for automated plasmid testing, supported by a comprehensive human practices education campaign and entrepreneurship initiatives to bring AI-driven solutions to market.
nominations: Best Foundational Advance Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad
advisors: Elliot Schrider, Ethan Tang, Kaitlyn Wong, Kenneth Ting, Xinyi (Marry) Xuan

students: Adibvafa Fallahpour, Alisha Imtiaz, Ally, Alston Lo, Angela Leung, Anthony Dinglasan, Ayalinch Jonathan, Chau Nguyen, Claire Cui, Daisy Thomas, Dawei Wang, Dorothy Cheung, Elisse Liu, Fatima Masood, Francesca, Hanul Kim, Holly Wen, Huy Giang, Jacqueline, Jasmine Jing, Jenny Hoijin Kwon, Jessica Wu, Joe, Joyce Kexin Qian, Julianna Lopes, Kaitlyn Chen, Karththigan Pushparaj, Kashmeena Mangal, Kris Shivkumar, Latisha, Lauren Altomare, Leah Tang, Linda, Lucas, Mariam Itani, Michael Chan, Oscar Sun, Patricia Rea, Peiyu Liao, Rebecca Tam, Robinson Meng, Rodrigo Adolfo Reyes Feregrino, Rushil Dua, Samantha Hossain, Sania, Selena Persad, Shayana Ramachandran, Taylor Markel, Tigran Bleyan

title: Curmino: Applying unnatural amino acid incorporated CsgA for prodrug click-to-release
abstract: Cancer is a major global public health issue. Bacterial therapy has attracted much attention due to its ability to colonize and proliferate specifically in the tumor microenvironment (TME). As an amyloid protein, CsgA can be secreted and form fiber structure on the surface of E. coli. By combining Genetic Code Expansion (GCE) technology, we tried to insert the Unnatural Amino Acid (UAA) Tet v2.0 into CsgA. In the principle of click chemistry, prodrug TCO-Dox would site-specific release in the TME, thus effectively killing tumor cells. With the potential to improve efficacy and reduce side effects, this innovative strategy provides new possibilities for cancer treatment.
nominations: Best Oncology Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Mingyu Liang, Tao Yuan
students: Canpu Chen, Han Hou, Hao Zou, Huaizhi Wang, Jiaxin He, Jingxuan Zeng, Kelibinuer·Kuerban, Murong Lei, Shengwen Ding, Tao Ma, Wensi Zhang, Yanbo Jing, Yishenghui Li, Yong Jie Tan, Yufan Wang, YunQi Xing, Zhenghao Liu, Zheping Zhang, Zhichao Deng, Zifeng Qiao, Others, Man LU, Shuxiang Song, xiaomengshi, Xiaomin Zou, Yuanxia

title: POIROT -POInt-of-care miRNA detection device for Ophthalmic diseases Tracing-
abstract: If your vision changes, your life will change. Glaucoma is a serious eye disease that can affect anyone. Even with modern medical technology, there is no cure for the disease, and the purpose of treatments is only to slow its progression. Late detection renders treatment delay, leading to a decline in QOV (Quality of Vision) with symptoms such as blurred decreasing vision, and even blindness. POIROT is aimed to detect glaucoma biomarker miRNA easily at home. We adopted a protein-based cell-free system to achieve rapid social implementation. The series of reactions proceeds isothermally, and test results can be visually determined by color changes, with useability emphasized. Furthermore, POIROT has potential applications for other diseases, as it can efficiently quantify disease-specific (tiny amounts) nucleic acids in body fluids.
nominations: Best Diagnostics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Takashi Okada, Chikara Furusawa, Tsuneakwa Yuji
advisors: Kazuto Yoshimi, Tomoji Mashimo

title: Aqua Guardian^2
abstract: The main aim of our project is to degrade PET and double enrich the degradation product TPA. We first use engineered E. coli BL21 strain to secrete turboPETase. After that, another engineered E. coli BL21 strain is responsible for enriching TPA and indicating the level of enrichment by expressing fluorescence after it transports TPA into itself. Next, we use C. elegans, a model organism that feeds on E. coli, as our recycler and amplifier. After two engineered E. coli BL21 strain have achieved the expected processing of PET and absorption of TPA, we introduce the C. elegans that feed on the engineered bacteria to avoid biological leakage, then further achieve the goal of enrichment and recycling. Meanwhile, the engineering of C. elegans is ongoing-we are attempting to create a kind of C. elegans with the ability to transport TPA into their intestinal cell, in order to further enrich TPA monomers.
PIs: Jianfeng LIU, Jianmiao LIU, Lei Chun, Shangxian Xie

title: LUNA Pad
abstract: Our project, Luna Pad, addresses the critical issue of late diagnoses of gynecological diseases by transforming menstrual pads into non-invasive screening tools. Integrating test strips that utilize lateral flow assay technology, the pads detect biomarkers such as CA126 and IL-6, indicative of inflammations and cancers. We adopted single-chain variable fragment (scFv) antibodies designs for improved synthesis in E. coli. Designed for ease of use and affordability, the Luna Pad aims to encourage regular health monitoring and early detection, potentially saving lives by prompting necessary medical interventions.
advisors: Leng Zhe, Zha Yi
students: Chunman Li, Cindy Wu, Dalai Xu, Dong ZiHao, HAOJIA XUE, Heyu Wei, Jiaheng He, Lai Wei, Max and his skink, MingQing Han, Qianyu Liu, Qiyuan Chen, Shi Dong, Shulin Lyu, Sihan Huang, TIANLANG YANG, Yi-Fei Gao, Yijia Xu, ZHANG SHUHE, Zhitong Ning, Ziqi Zhou

title: STAR: Synthesis of Theanine for Anxiety Relief
abstract: Project STAR is targeted at anxiety among high school students and the global population by harnessing L-theanine, a naturally occurring amino acid in tea leaves. To overcome the limitations in traditional synthesis methods, we developed a de novo synthetic biology approach to produce L-theanine in E. coli BL21. We've designed a pathway involving five enzymes to synthesize L-theanine starting from glucose with an ATP regeneration system for efficiency. We investigated the implementation of the product as candies, and explored delivery methods. We expanded the scope of our care via community events of promoting anxiety awareness.
advisors: Enshi Xu, XAVIER WANG RUI
students: Boen Liu, chufeng zhang, Dongchuan Wang, Haoshi Wang, Haotian Liu, Jiming Yu, Leyi Li, Qimeng Wang, Rui Fan, Ruoxi Li, Tongtong Wu, Wanchen Kai, Xiwen Xiong, Yibing Gu, Yuxuan Ma, Ziao Su

title: Plastivorous - Promoting Sustainable Development by Reducing Microplastic Pollution
abstract: Microplastic particles are not only posing a threat to the ecosystem but also invisibly infiltrating our daily lives. In our efforts, we decided to focus on degrading microplastics using PETase. With the help of AI tools, we successfully designed and constructed sequences of PETase that efficiently degrade PET. To have a sustainable production of the enzymes, we further introduced these sequences into cyanobacteria. The cyanobacteria are then placed in bioreactors alongside rhodobacteria, creating a system capable of breaking down microplastics more effectively and sufficiently. Alongside the achievements within the lab, we also organized a range of different human practice events to support our program development and guide our experiments while conveying our core value and raising public awareness about this invisible threat.
advisors: Aaron Wang, Cindy Ranxin Tian, Helen Yu, Huang Jingwen, Jiangxin Wang, Ruomu Xu, Sichen Li, Weizhao Chen, Xinran Xia, Yanguo Zhao, Yan,xingzhe Jerry
students: Allen Yang, Emily, Fred Zhang, Guo Hening, Harry, Mingce Yang, Miya Yang, Rachel Lu, Ray, Shen Liu, Sophia Li, Stephanie Oseakhumen Emhenya, Summer Wu, tianlin wen, Tsz Yam Liu, Yangzihan Chu, Yu-Lin,Elaine,Xin, ZHANG RUOCHEN, Zihuai zhao

title: PICasSO: CRISPR/Cas-Mediated 3D Genome Engineering via Programmable DNA-DNA Interactions
abstract: Cells interpret identical DNA sequences differently depending on the 3D genome organization, leading to diverse cellular phenotypes and even determining between health and disease. While synthetic biology provides powerful methods to engineer the genome sequence, tools to sculpt the genome's spatial architecture are lacking. We address this profound gap by introducing PICasSO, a toolbox for rationally engineering the 3D genome organization. Using different CRISPR/Cas orthologs and new, engineered fusion guide RNAs, we created "Cas staples" that bind and connect otherwise non-interacting genomic regions. To streamline the development cycle of new Cas staples, we developed DaVinci, a multi-faceted model integrating both local and long-range DNA-protein interactions into a unified pipeline. Combining PICasSO and DaVinci, we recapitulated mechanistic core principles of enhancer hijacking - a driver of tumor development. Our comprehensive part collection and extensive education program enable the next generation of iGEMers to efficiently adapt PICasSO and engineer genomes in 3D.
awards: Grand Prize Winner+Finalist+Top 10+Best Foundational Advance Project+Best Model+Best Part Collection+Best Wiki
nominations: Best Education, Undergrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad
instructors: Benedict Wolf, Jan Mathony, Marcel Pott
advisors: Alewtina Towara, Jakob Then, Luis Herfurth
students: Alexa Weikert, Anastasia Warken, Dana Levi, Frido Petersen, Kaloyan Staykov, Kathrin Klaßen, Lena Koch, Marik Mueller, Maximilian Fidlin, Noemi Tigrato, Rammukund Kishore Kumar, Samuel Novák, Simon Westermann, Viktor Bonin

title: "Memory&happiness Puzzle"----Engineered bacteria used for the treatment of central nervous system diseases
abstract: In the present study, we engineered probiotics to produce small molecules for treating depression and Alzheimer's disease. For depression, utilizing molecular docking and SPR, we identified inosine as a molecule capable of decoupling SERT-nNOS. We engineered Lactobacillus plantarum L168 to produce inosine by incorporating the key enzyme gsk. The engineered probiotics release inosine in the gut, which then travels through the bloodstream to the brain, disconnecting SERT from nNOS to alleviate depressive symptoms. Regarding Alzheimer's disease?we identified tetrahydrofolate as an effective LilrB3 binder and produce it using the key enzyme sequence folKE. Tetrahydrofolate binds to LilrB3 receptor, preventing APOE4 interaction and inhibiting A? deposition. Accordingly, we genetically engineered Lactobacillus plantarum L168 to biosynthesize theanine and niacin, aiming to develop therapy for Alzheimer's disease and depressions, respectively. Our aim is to assist patients suffering from depression and Alzheimer's Disease in reclaiming their cognitive functions and emotional well-being.
PIs: Xingyin Liu, Chuan Su, Li Yuan, Ran Huo, Zhibin Hu
advisors: Mengqi Chen, Qianyue Yang, WenYe Huang, Xiaoting Luan, Xiaoyi Wang, Yiran Wang
student leaders: He Zhang, Xichen Wang, Zhiyu Wen
students: Guanjie Wang, Haoran Cai, Haoran Shen, Jiamin Wang, Jiayi Li, Juntong Ye, Ran Tang, Ruixi Qian, Shuwen Li, Xiangyu Meng, Xinyu Chen, Xinyu Zhou, Yihui Zhou, Yishi Jia, Zhangsiyu Tang

title: The treatment of Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm based on CBASS system engineering
abstract: Cyclic-oligonucleotide-based anti-phage signaling system (CBASS) is a type of anti-phage defense system that is homologous to the animal cGAS-STING innate immune pathway. The CBASS system consists of two parts: oligonucleotide cyclase and effector. During phage infection, oligonucleotide cyclase produces signal cyclic oligonucleotides, and the effector is activated by the cyclic oligonucleotide, which causes cell death through membrane damage, DNA degradation, and other means. We use a variety of methods such as the type IV secretion system to introduce the CBASS system into the Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm through plasmid transformation, and use virulent phages for infection to achieve the purpose of treating Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The project verified for the first time that the CBASS system can assist phages in the treatment of biofilms, and its significance lies in providing the world with strategies for biofilm-related infectious diseases.
students: Beisi Han, Bingzhe Hu, Dalu Wang, Haotian Ding, Hongbo LIN, Hongqian Zhang, Lin Liuyi, Longtian Shi, Mingwei Chen, Qikun Gao, Rui Xiang Xu, Shiwen He, Shuo Fang, Songyan Yu, TJX, Xiafei Zhang, Xinyu Lyu, Yao Chen, Yibang Wu, Yinan Wang, Yinuo Gao, YOU ZHOU, Yujie Zhou, Zhijie Lu, Zihao Lei, Zilu Wang, Ziyi Liu

title: FluoroFind
abstract: Currently, advancements in synthetic biology are often limited by the lack of biosensors. Recently, a paper presented a library of ~2000 E. coli promoters fused to GFP. The goal of this project was to test 10 different molecules with each promoter as a starting point for biosensor development. First, we screened each molecule-promoter pair to identify which ones produced the highest fluorescence. Then, the top few promoters for each molecule were titrated under increasing concentrations of their respective molecule. Due to inconsistencies in the data, we created fresh strains, made uncontaminated media, corrected mislabeled promoters, and regrew promoters with low cell growth. A Deep Learning model was created to predict whether any promoter-molecule pair would produce significant fluorescence in the initial screen. Prominent strains were also analyzed with molecular docking and used to create theoretical parts for future experimentation. In general, this research makes important contributions to biosensor development.
students: Anwita Bandaru, Avika Prasad, Claire Wang, Eliza Hong, Faiza Alam, Jason Gao, Lauren Chen, Lilian Zeng, Nithika Vivek, Nupur Bhalla, Prakruti Bhatt, Risha Guha, Saanvi Dogra, Shawn Kim, Tanvi Movva

title: HydroMel
abstract: Black fungi which appeared in the wastewater from Chernobyl suggests that melanin may possess radioprotective properties within microbial organisms. In daily lives, radiation comes from sources such as ultraviolet rays, electronic products, medical radiation procedures, and even nuclear wastewater. Furthermore, radiation in space exploration is undoubtedly set to become a key topic of focus in the future. To search for methods of radiation protection, we are planning to employ the tools of synthetic biology to identify effective strategies for radiation defense. We have constructed different strains of microbial organisms to find best solution to produce melanin and have tested their ability of radiation resistance. Also, we are working on hydrogel material which supports microalgal-bacterial co-culture. Our goal is to offer new perspectives and solutions to tackle the challenges of radiation. We firmly believe that through persistent endeavors, we can ensure the safety and success of humanity's journey through the cosmos.
advisors: Cheng
students: chenyucheng, GuoBeibei, Kaden.Cao, leijialin, Song Minyang, tangyingmei, Zhang Di hao, zhanghaichang, zhangjianing

title: RNA SenSor based Analysis system in Yeast
abstract: We use adenosine deaminase acting on RNA(ADAR) to construct a RNA sensor in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, trying to build a toolbox to better understand and utilize the information provided by RNA. This sensor is expected to sense any RNA signal we want and express any selected gene. By confocol microscopy, flow cytometry and other experiments, We successfully proved the activity of our sensor, which can be well expressed in yeast and show high signal intensity. We further apply RNAssay into multiple applications: in situ detection of multigene expression; engineering strain security system; in vivo monitoring of splice variants. Our result shows that RNAssay holds the potential to be a powerful tool for in vivo RNA sensing, easy to operate, and widely applicable.
advisors: Guangyuan Lin, Weihao Wang
student leaders: Chengxue Zhang, Weijie Li, Zirui Liu
students: Danyang Ma, Jialin Liu, Jianting Gong, Jiayi YANG, Keyue Zhang, Qilong Wang, Qingmin Li, Shengjie Quan, Siyuan Jiang, YA WEN, Yingqi Tan, Yi Zhu, Yuhan Liu, Yuling XIAO

title: Renalzyme - Combating kidney stones with enzymes
abstract: Kidney stones affect over 10% of people, with pain often compared to childbirth. The problem with current treatments is their invasive and sometimes painful nature and their cost, making them inaccessible to many. Worse, 50-80% of sufferers experience recurrent stones. To avoid people having to endure having kidney stones multiple times. We propose using GMO Lactic acid bacteria, engineered to express oxalate oxidase. The bacteria will be administered through yogurt since it is a widely consumed beverage in arid parts of the world where low water quality and high temperatures lead to increased kidney stone formation. To prove the concepts behind our idea, we successfully transformed our bacteria and proved the enzymes ability to break down oxalate. Furthermore we designed four new programmes to ease the process of conducting docking simulations for future iGEM'ers.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School
students: Anna Baltzer Rose, Caitlin Read, Dicte Kirstine Hemmingsen, Isabelle Boutrup, Johannes Friis, Jonathan Pries, Karoline Krone, Lou Bork, Mads Ming Rørby Grothe, Marie Immisch, Oskar Xie, Patryk Sztolc, Pauline Alling Andreassen, Peter Bennetzen, Sara Bettio, Viktor garde-tschertok

title: SYNHESION - natural bacterial adhesives
abstract: Our global consumption of adhesives will reach 24.7 million tons, but most are made from toxic, non-biodegradable chemicals. Synhesion offers a solution with natural, biodegradable adhesives. We develop a recombinant manufacturing system in E. coli for the efficient and tunable production of the strongest naturally found glue - holdfast. Our system is multiple-fold faster, more controllable, and predictable than the natural one. It uses cost-effective, widely accessible, and renewable feedstocks - glucose, while the strongest available chemical glue, epoxy resin, requires expensive oil-based chemical precursors. Additionally, we developed a new E. coli strain by eliminating competing pathways, enhancing adhesive yield. Our proteins have potential in the medical field and targeted drug delivery systems. We also developed educational tools for diverse audiences. We partnered with Universities of Third Age, launched the "MinkMit?" podcast, a mobile game "Bacteriomania", organized the "SynFolk" event cycle, and created a children's book to inspire scientific curiosity.
nominations: Best Part Collection, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad
students: Agata Kipran, Aust?ja Klevait?, Edgaras Zaboras, Emilija, Evelina Prosevi?i?t?, Fausta Michnevi?i?t?, Gintare Zvejyte, Kristupas ?eika, Linas, Migl? Paulikait?, Migl? Šarpilo, Rokas Bružaitis, Uršul? Barkauskait?

title: PreCyse | Redefining Cystic Fibrosis Gene Therapy with Next-Generation mRNA-Based Prime Editing Technology
abstract: Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is the most prevalent inherited disorder, characterized by mutations in the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator (CFTR). In human lungs, dysfunctional CFTR leads to a decrease in mucociliary clearance, ultimately resulting in organ failure and death. Current treatment strategies are limited in terms of speed, precision, and effectiveness, often failing to achieve long-lasting improvements. Additionally, high costs and limited accessibility of pharmaceuticals contribute to a poor prognosis for many patients worldwide. PreCyse offers the next generation of prime editing technology (PrimeGuide) and our optimized lipid nanoparticle (AirBuddy) for the lung-specific delivery of therapeutic mRNA. We introduce our highly sensitive and context specific reporter system to measure Prime Editing Efficiency. We improved our technology in organoids from human nasal epithelial cells of CF patients, targeting the most common genetic alteration (F508del). Our efforts contribute to a future where cost-efficient, easy-to-use, and accessible therapeutics counteract promote personalized medicine.
awards: Best Integrated Human Practices+Best Presentation+Safety and Security Award
advisors: Felicitas Zimmer, Lucas Haverkamp, Maximilian Leo Huber, Utkarsh Anil Mahajan
students: Anna Baack, Asal Sahami Moghaddam, Christian Michalek, Isabell Alexandra Guckes, Kai Kanthak, Kathleen Susat, Kaya Lange, Liliana Sanfilippo, Lisa Wiesner, Malte Lenger, Michael Gröning, Philip Mundt, Vera Köhler, Vincent Carl Stöckl

title: Protector Program
abstract: In the wake of the outbreak, people have become more concerned about how diseases are transmitted and have developed good mask habits. However, it is worth noting that some pathogenic bacteria can be transmitted through the respiratory tract for infection and other routes such as the digestive tract. In this project, we pay special attention to the transmission of pathogenic bacteria at the excretory opening, and based on Escherichia coli Nissle 1917, we strengthened its defense and attack system through synthetic biology methods, and developed a product that can effectively occupy the ecological niche and continuously inhibit pathogenic bacteria.
advisors: Dr. XIA Li, Jinming Lin, Zhiwen Lv
student leaders: Danyuan Yang, Peixin Cai, Songlin Ye
students: Bixia Huang, Danting Zhan, Dezheng Yao, Jiani Fan, Jing Hua, Lin Tan, Mingchun Guo, Shuqi Li, WenXiang Fan, Xiaoli Zheng, Yili Xiao, Yiqing Huang, Yongguang Su

title: SUPERB-Sustainable upcycyling of PET to produce economic and promising bacteria cellulose
abstract: SUPERB, by using machine learning , predicts potential efficient mutant types and the glycosylation mutation sites from the known PET hydrolase database to enhance the efficiency of plastic degradation in mild and acid conditions. Furthermore, molecular docking is performed with the mutated enzyme and PET, HEMT to identify the most optimal mutant variant. At the same time, by optimizing the chassis cell Pichia pastoris and expression elements, a strain with high expression of plastic degrading enzyme was constructed. Combined with the way of biological transformation, the plastic degradation products of terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol (EG) are synthesized into bacterial cellulose to realize the recycling and upcycling of plastics.
nominations: Best Software Tool, Undergrad
PIs: Xueyun Zheng, Jun Dai, Lan Yao
advisors: Huize Wang, Kevin Schlei, Xiang Kong, Yi Han, Yiming Jiang
students: Guangyu Liu, Guiting Li, Jinru Luo, Kexin Ni, Nimeng Zhang, Pingyuan Ge, Ruisi Nan, Siqi Chen, Xinyi Xiong, Xinyi Xu, Yantong Meng, Yingjie Liu, Yingying Shu, Yixuan Liu, Yi Zhang, Yuan Li, Yufei Wang, Yuhang Jin, Zirui Wang

title: RhyzUp - Drought Resistance Through Biofilm Enhancement
abstract: Global food systems are increasingly pressured by climate change, unsustainable agricultural practices and social pressures, such as political instability and population growth. Key challenges including environmental instability and desertification threaten food security. RhyzUp presents a sustainable solution by enhancing biofilm production in rhizobacteria to improve plant resilience under stress conditions like drought. Our project makes use of the symbiotic relationship between plants and rhizobacteria to optimize biofilm formation only when in proximity to plant roots, which improves water retention, nutrient uptake, and protection against environmental stressors. By genetically modifying Pseudomonas sp. IsoF, we aim to increase the production of cyclic di-GMP (c-di-GMP), a second messenger involved in the formation of biofilms. This is done by upregulating diguanylate cyclases (DGCs) to increase c-di-GMP production and inhibiting a phosphodiesterase (PDE) to prevent its degradation. Our goal is to create a sustainable approach by leveraging synthetic biology to enhance agricultural resilience.
nominations: Best Agriculture Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
instructors: Gabriel Cervera Arriaga, Zaira María Heredia Ponce
advisors: Alexandra Maximsdottir, Atilla Schreiber, Julia Wyss
students: Ekaterina Tocheva, Jessica Goetschi, Linus Zwahlen, lukas bösch, Mattia Morandi, Maurin Widmer, Meera Bobzin, Mikael Samuelsson

title: ASPINE: Ai for Sequence-based Predictions and Identification of Neoantigen Expression
abstract: Breast cancer remains a primary global health concern. Dendritic Cell (DC) vaccines are a promising immunotherapy that targets tumors using neoantigens. However, personalizing these vaccines requires mRNA sequencing, which is likely unavailable. ASPINE aims to address this issue by developing a machine-learning model to predict neoantigen expression using DNA sequences. We conducted four experiments using the Xpresso model, the first two using an obtained genome sequence and the latter two using an acquired patient data. The second and the fourth experiments have a shorter input sequence length to control for our shorter WES data in experiment four. With acquired patient data, the third experiment yielded an R-squared of 0.329 (RMSE: 0.440). The fourth experiment had an R-squared of 0.294 (RMSE: 0.443), showing improved performance compared to non-patient data. Future work will focus on optimizing the model and refining transcription start site classification to improve prediction accuracy.
advisors: Kittipoch Saengsai
students: Atigunt Hualcharoenthon, Isha, Issariya Issariyawanich, Korn Hemrungrojn, Natchanon Rotarwut, Pitpiboon Luksiri, Suphachat Sriharan, Supitchaya Hemrungrojn, Teejuta Sriwaranon, Theerapas Apinankul, Wipu Setthawong

title: Synplode: An Innovative Approach to Landmine and UXO Clearance
abstract: Post-war landmines and unexploded ordinances (UXOs) can cause injuries or death, pollute land and restrict economic activity long after conflicts have ended. Synplode aims to address this problem. We have engineered bacteria designed to detect and break down TNT and RDX, the two most common explosives found in degrading landmines and UXOs. Our solution is designed to achieve three tasks: first, it detects the explosives and signals their presence; second, it breaks down these explosives into non-explosive derivatives; and third, it confirms the UXO is safe. To deploy this system safely and efficiently, we have built an aerial bio-drone capable of dispersing our bacterial solution over contaminated areas. This provides a scalable, cost-effective, and risk-free method for clearing UXOs. We believe that our approach has the potential to revolutionize the demining process, offering hope to communities still living under the threat of landmines and UXOs.
nominations: Best Hardware, Overgrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad
PIs: Brian D McCabe, Joanna Dembska, Pitt Meyer, Rebecca Smith
students: Alexandre, Antoine Schlüter, Ariadna Davila, EdgarAellen, Francesco, ines amri, Samuel Williams, Yasmine Basti

title: Endometriosis treatment by inducing apoptosis in endometriotic tissue with a designed treatment plasmid.
abstract: We aim to develop a minimally invasive, non-hormonal treatment for endometriosis by using a plasmid to induce apoptosis in endometriotic tissue while sparing healthy endometrial cells. Studies show that estrogen receptor ? (ER?) is upregulated >100-fold in endometriotic cells, while estrogen receptor ? (ER?) is downregulated. Both are regulated by estrogen. We aim to create conditions where increased ER? and decreased ER? expression activate the ER? promoter, leading to BAX gene transcription from the plasmid. BAX is a protein involved in apoptosis, and its increased expression should induce cell death in endometriotic cells. In healthy cells, where ER? is upregulated and ER? is downregulated, BCL2 gene transcription is promoted by the ER? promoter, helping protect healthy cells from apoptosis. This approach aims for selective treatment of endometriotic tissue without harming normal cells.
nominations: Best Education, Overgrad
instructors: Catharina Bang Jensen, Florian Pruckner, Jacob Fredegaard Hansen, Joan Falandysz Skøtt, Lina Malou Sörensen, Moritz Schaefer, Signe Heegaard Hundborg, Tina Kronborg
students: Anna Kristensen, Christina Lorentsen, Daniel Manchado Fagan, Francisca Ayivor Addo, Kathrine Dømler Rasmussen, Pelle Bording, Sofia West Levisen, Susan Sadat, Syzana Lushtaku, Tobias Kuntz

title: Ecorin: Sustainable Heparin Biosynthesized in E. coli
abstract: The reliance on porcine-derived heparin poses significant risks, including contamination, supply chain volatility, and ethical concerns. Our team engineered a novel, scalable bacterial system using E. coli Nissle 1917 to biosynthesize heparin. By introducing key enzymes involved in the heparin biosynthesis pathway, we enable E. coli to produce heparin from its naturally occurring precursor, Heparosan. This personalized approach eliminates contamination risks from similar polysaccharides while ensuring a reliable supply of high-purity heparin. Our design not only addresses the ethical and religious concerns surrounding porcine products but also offers a sustainable alternative for global heparin production.
nominations: Best Measurement, High School+Best Education, High School
advisors: Michael Taylor
students: Aaditya Aryan, Adam, Aneesha Aryan, Anuj Joshi, Ashley Choi, Carlos Umanzor, Damla, Erin Suh, Faria Ashrafi, Leo Mayorga, Mana Hayashida, Michael Zhu, Nathan Kirokwa, Nicolas Rojas Taborda, Rayan, Sathvik, Shaanveer Gupta, Shiv Meiyur, Sidharth Nair, Vidyuth, yossra

title: EcoMeGa:DHA-PC
abstract: DHA is a crucial omega-3 fatty acid vital for brain and retina health, especially for cognitive function and fetal development. It exists in various forms, including natural triglycerides, ethyl and monoglycerides, and phosphatidylcholine, each differing in bioavailability. Phospholipid forms are generally considered more efficiently absorbed. XJTLU-CHINA's current focus is on biosynthetic phospholipids, particularly DHA lysophospholipids, to innovate industrial production methods. By improving the synthesis and availability of these forms, the team aims to enhance DHA's health benefits, contributing to advancements in biotechnology and its application in human health.
instructors: Lizhe Chen, Xiaohan Zhang, Ziwen Xie
advisors: Aurora, Jiyi Wang, Lexuan Li, Ning Yifan, Shouye Zhu, Weizhuo Chen, Yiran Wang, Yongtao Zhu, Zixin Rong
students: Can Wang, Chenxi Xu, Haotian Zheng, Hao Wu, Jintong Zhang, mingchen sun, QiuDaShuai, Ruiqi Cao, Yuchong Yan

title: ChatParts
abstract: iGEM parts registry is an open database containing DNA elements after years of uploading and contribution by iGEM teams. However, the internal data quality is uneven, and some parts have low integrity and only contain sequences without description, optimization, and contribution. In addition, within the iGEM parts registry, the presentation of the result includes text and pictures that lack clear index and quick screening. Therefore, we design an AI Agent, 'Chatparts', that integrates iGEM parts information utilizing RAG (Retrieve-Augmented Generation) system to re-organize the information management and retrieval of parts. After the implementation of RAG, fine-tuning is another essential part of our model training, intending to make the model perform better in particular domains. We also developed a community called iGEM ChatParts Community to establish a platform for the usage of our AI Agent and the communication of iGEMers.
advisors: FanYuehang, Hao Liu, LiZhiqin
students: Haiyue Pu, Hu Yixin, Qiayi Zha, Siying Han, Yifei wang

title: Mercurito to the Rescue! Detecting Mercury in the Bolivian Amazon.
abstract: Bolivia is facing a severe mercury contamination crisis, largely due to artisanal and small-scale gold mining (ASGM), which poses significant threats to local ecosystems and human health. Conventional mercury detection methods are costly and complex, limiting their accessibility for affected communities. To address this challenge, iGEM Bolivia proposes a bacterial biosensor capable of detecting mercury contamination. This innovative technology enables real-time monitoring and provides a portable, sensitive solution for detecting organic mercury--the most toxic form to living organisms. By empowering Amazonian communities, protecting biodiversity, and enhancing public health, the biosensor directly aligns with several Sustainable Development Goals, including SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-being), SDG 6 (Clean Water and Sanitation), and SDG 15 (Life on Land).
instructors: Adriana Calvo Bueno, Daniel Salas-Veizaga, Densy Pelaez Pacheco, Harold Rosado Mamani, Joseph Paola Montaño Sanchez, Mayra Fernanda Ocampo Valdivia, Rodrigo Rosario Cruz, SAID EDUARDO PEREZ POPPE
