student leaders: Angelica Sueli Bejarano Paz, Dana Valdez Tapia, Estefania Lorena Mansilla Flores, Pilar Montealegre Vargas, Roberto Antonio Guzman Chiri
students: Alejandra Guzmán Jaldin, Alvaro Rafael Cuellar Wieler, Ariana Herrera, Dulce Valeria Claure Villca, Gabriel, Gabriela Choque, Harold Montaño, Jhanet Condori Huanca, Marcos Daza, Rossi Ponce

title: Application of SBD in drug resistance TB diagnosis
abstract: Currently, around 2 percent of deaths are caused by tuberculosis, especially those possessing drug resistance. Efficient identification of drug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis is urgently required for a fast and scientific treatment. The prevalent polymerase chain reaction (PCR), the chief method used in drug-resistance testing, relies on high-cost equipment and lacks sample point-of-care testing (POCT). Along the research work of Deng Academician's group, our team utilized the sulfur binding domain (SBD) technique to develop a new POCT tool. This protein category embeds sulfur into its hydrophobic cavity and recognizes phosphorothioate DNA(PT-DNA) by hydrogen bonds and electrostatic interactions between the SBD and the DNA. Our project aspires to test SBD's binding capacity to select target-oriented proteins. In the future, these proteins will act as the main ingredient for one detection kit for drug-resistant tuberculosis and contribute to better and timely treatment for patients.
student leaders: JIAHAO LI, XINYI CHEN, YILEI LI
students: MINGYI LI, RUIHAN YANG, RUINING LIANG, SHANGRONG DU, XINCHEN XIANG, YIXUAN ZHU, YONGLING KE, YUDONG YAN, ZEYU WANG

title: E2 SAFE?A temperature-sensing biocontainment system for mobility and growth arresting for engineered photosynthetic Cyanobacteria.
abstract: Our project developed a biocontainment system integrating a temperature-based mobility arresting and logic gate-based killing "double-safe" system, eventually achieving goal of minimizing environmental risks due to the unintentional leakage and consequences of engineered chassis organisms from the lab. The logic gate based killing system coupled the temperature-sensitive regulatory system PR-cI857 regulatory system with a genetic circuit employing toxin-antitoxin systems, to ensure that the engineered cyanobacteria are not able to survive in non-permissive conditions, such as natural environments with night temperature typically below 30°C, but grow normally under laboratory conditions (37°C). The mobility arresting system is constructed based on the crRNA (CRISPR-dCas12a) targeting cell pili. Our temperature sensing system avoids the addition of any exogenous chemical inducer, not only cutting down the cost but also decease any secondary chemical contamination. Our system could also be implemented in many other bacterial chasses readily with minor modification.
students: Elizabeth Wang, Emma Zhang, LINDA SU ZHAO, Michelle, Nina Sun, Ruthie Chen, Yuchen Yuan

title: AstroVita - Providing Nutritious Food in Space
abstract: To make long space exploration missions possible, we cannot rely on continuous shipments from Earth and life support systems need to be regenerative. Currently, oxygen and water are recovered and regenerated on the ISS but long missions call for closing the carbon cycle as well. Growing plants for this purpose requires large amounts of resources in the space setting. At the same time, cellular agriculture is emerging as a promising new technology for producing food on Earth with low land use and resource requirements. Could we utilize this technology in space? This is the question we set out to solve. In our project AstroVita, we mapped out potential opportunities and challenges in utilizing cellular agriculture in space, developed a synthetic biology solution to improve the vitamin content of microbial food and modeled a microbial system for use in space.
nominations: Best Education, Overgrad
students: Aarni Mäkelä, Anni Huhtala, Inkeri Mentula, Lauri Suominen, Ofelia Sarlund, Saana Leikkola, Sallianna Öztürk, Salli Salolahti, Sanni Uusitupa, Sonja Orkola, Stella von Plato

title: CaptuREE
abstract: Rare earth elements include scandium, yttrium, and fifteen lanthanide elements, which are valuable natural resources. The scarcity and importance of rare earth elements draw our attention to how to sustainably mine, recycle, and utilize them. This year, the HiZU-China team from Zhejiang University is committed to developing sustainable biomining technology for rare earth elements, achieving efficient recovery through the integration of bioleaching, biosorption, and biosafety modules. Ultimately, we are dedicated to building a future of clean production and sustainable utilization of rare earth elements, allowing them to better serve the development of human society.
nominations: Best Biomanufacturing Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best New Basic Part, Undergrad+Best Hardware, Undergrad+Best Measurement, Undergrad
PIs: Zehua Bao, Lidan Ye, Jiazhang Lian, Haoran Yu

title: Knight: a designer-cell based drug screening platform for MTNR1A agonist discovery
abstract: In light of an increasingly aging population, numerous of individuals are experiencing insomnia symptoms precipitated by endocrine imbalances. Intensifying pressures and escalating workloads are also disrupting adults' natural sleep patterns. Insomnia caused by circadian rhythm disorders have emerged as a significant health conundrum. Melatonin is widely recognized as the first-line treatment for insomnia, but excessive consumption can lead to adverse effects like headache and dizziness. Notably, MTNR1A receptors paly a more directly role in regulating circadian rhythms, whereas MTNR1B participate in various physiological activities. A drug specifically targeting the MTNR1A is needed to treat insomnia caused by circadian rhythm disorders. Inspired by synthetic biology principles, an innovative small molecule drug screening platform has been developed. This platform introduces a novel exogenous melatonin signaling pathway, enabling the screening potential MTNR1A agonists and natural essential oils that activate melatonin receptors. Our project provides a robust foundation for developing therapeutic agents targeting insomnia.
PIs: Lingyun Zhu, LU Min, Xinyuan Qiu
advisors: Changsong Gao, Chi-Yu Li, Xi Hu
student leaders: Bingshun Shi, Jiabo Cai, Jiajie Lu, Xinrui Huang
students: Bolun Su, Chenxi Peng, Chuanpeng Zhou, Guoping Xu, Handi Yang, Jiayi Guo, Jie Wang, Jinhong Tan, Jin Zhexu, Lan Wen, Liangshun, MaoHanyue, Miaomiao Long, PengYu Zheng, Renjie Zhang, Wang Teng, Xu Zihan, YichunWang, Yifei Li, Yongheng Jiang, Yuanpeng Ma, Yuxin Zhao, ZhuWentao

title: Polyethylene Microplastic Shredders
abstract: Bioenzymatic degradation of polyethylene is expected to become a new means of harmless plastic treatment in the future because it is able to convert plastic wastes into carbon dioxide, monomers, and value-added compounds, which is more environmentally friendly and in line with the sustainable development strategy than some chemical recycling strategies that require high temperature and high pressure as well as a large amount of toxic reagents. In this experiment, the polyethylene degradation effect of polyethylene-degrading enzymes produced by 16 laccase sequences, 2 hydrolase sequences and 5 alkane monooxygenase sequences was finally verified by using synthetic biology and bioinformatics methods. It provides new insights into the mechanism of polyethylene pollutant degradation by bioenzymes from XJU-China.
advisors: Jianhua Zi, Ning Wang, Tong Xu, Yaxin LI, Yuxin Wang
students: Detianjun Liu, Hanghang Zheng, Jiaqi Xie, Litong Zhang, Runquan Yu, Sea, Xinyue Li, zichen wang

title: Modules for Optimized Viability and Efficacy of RNA pesticides (MOVE)
abstract: Pesticides play a crucial role in modern food production. However, current chemical pesticides face various challenges, including environmental changes due to climate change, the issue of resistant species, and their impact on the environment. RNA pesticides, which use the principle of RNA interference, are gaining attention as a means to address these problems associated with chemical pesticides. However, their low durability in natural environments poses a barrier to practical application. MOVE is a module that encapsulates RNA within membrane vesicles, which are surface-presented by functional proteins. Through MOVE, the effective duration of RNA pesticides is extended, maximizing the impact of the RNA. We are pioneering the future of agriculture by doing the following: MOVE RNA pesticides, MOVE pest control, MOVE agriculture.
PIs: Yoh-ichi TAGAWA, Masayuki Yamamura, Nobuhiro HAYASHI, Yoshihisa Matsumoto
students: Chiharu Hagiwara, Fuga nakai, fukiho, Haruki Aoyama, Hazuki Baba, iwabuchi takuto, Kai Takita, Kazuki Yamamoto, Kimbara Kazuki, kotaro-ito, kou-hashimoto, Leonardo Ken Okumura, Miku Yasuhara, Mumu Kato, Naoki Chiba, Okamoto Yuma, Ricardo, ryo akiba, Ryosuke, Ryosuke Nishiyama, Shu kenjo, Takeru Yuasa, Tatsuya, YokoyamaMako, Yota Kashima, Yuichiro Nakai, yuki, Yuma Nishimura, Yumi Watanabe, Yusuke Ikemi, yuto, Other, KAVYA PRATHAP KUMAR

title: Skin Angel
abstract: Seborrheic dermatitis (SD) is a chronic, recurrent skin disease influenced by factors such as genetics, immune status, and skin microbiota. Our project introduces a novel treatment using engineered Lactobacillus reuteri expressing the MFP5 adhesive protein from mussels, enhancing adhesion to the skin. This modified L. reuteri promotes antimicrobial peptide (AMP) expression to target and kill Malassezia, a key contributor to SD. Using deep learning, we design AMPs and optimize the promoter and operon to sense extracellular fatty acid concentrations, enabling precise gene expression. Once Malassezia's substrate is depleted, it dies, achieving biological control of SD.
student leaders: dididididi, Jialong Xie, Junjie Shi, Yi Ding, Zhangyi Yang
students: Cynthia Zhou, fu ai yong, GuoRui Zhang, hjt, Jiarui Bai, Jingyao Liu, Lichee, lzm, Molly Lee, Qianying Miao, Ren, Shangyi Yang, Shaohan Ye, Shenyuan Li, siying Xie, Siyu Han, TXYN, Wang Zishuo, Xiaoling Yang, Xuliqin, Yangxiaoying Guo, Yazhi He, yilinliang, Yuqiong Zhang, YuXinDuan, Yuxuan Liu, zhang shengwei

title: Dual-Targeting Gemcitabine-Resistant Pancreatic Cancer with Novel Engineered Nanobody
abstract: Pancreatic cancer has the lowest survival rate among common cancers, with a five-year survival rate below 7%. In addition to curative surgery, chemotherapy such as gemcitabine is applied to patients at advanced stages. The poor prognosis of this disease can be attributed to the lack of targeted therapies and emergence of chemotherapy resistance. Our project aims to address these treatment challenges by using an innovative approach to generate dual-targeting nanobody called Panobody which targets EGFR and c-MET simultaneously, to inhibit pancreatic cancer cell growth, and to overcome gemcitabine resistance. Our pilot data not only improved therapeutic efficacy but also significantly reduced production costs and time, thus enhancing accessibility. Through various outreach activities and stakeholder consultations, we have systematically engaged the broader community to inform our research, ensuring that our proposed solution is not only scientifically rigorous, but also promises substantial social and economic benefits.
nominations: Best Oncology Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best New Composite Part, Undergrad
PIs: Terence Kin Wah Lee, Alan Chun Kit LEE, Ching Mei CHEUNG, Clarence Tsun Ting Wong, Clare Yan, Quanhua Mu, Wong Wai Ting
advisors: Chen Zihao, Li Minxi, QIN Shengjia Vivian
students: Chenyi Liu, Hiu Yeung Au, Muhammad Waris Shaikh, Pinxuan Li, Qiwen Deng, SI YA Zhu, SUN Jiayan Eurus, Swastika Chapagain, Xiangyi Li, Xinrui HU, Yin Yan Chan

title: Lactochoccus: I Can't Believe It's Not Chocolate
abstract: More than 70% of the world's cocoa production originates from Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana. The process involves clearing out large sections of African rainforest for cocoa plantations. Furthermore, cocoa farming generally involves child and slave labor. To combat this, we are creating a synthetically produced chocolate flavoring that will eliminate the need for natural cocoa farming. We chose four of the most prominent flavors in chocolate (theobromine, pyrazine, furaneol and phenylethylamine) and worked to produce them in Lactococcus bacteria. To do this, we started by cloning the genes onto a plasmid, inserting them into the Lactococcus, inducing gene expression with the compound nisin. To evaluate our results, we will use GC-MS to measure the levels of each compound present in our bacteria. Furthermore, we interviewed and incorporated feedback from various experts and nonprofits into our project, which allowed us to have a more comprehensive understanding of stakeholder needs and perspectives.
instructors: Jacob D. Bibik, Lydia Stamato, Nina Rajpurohit

title: Defeating Peach Tree Gummosis
abstract: The implementation of precision medicine in cancer requires precision diagnosis and precision therapy. Given the severity of peach gummosis as a disease of peach trees, coupled with its association with age, and taking into account our school's proximity to the prestigious World's First Peach Garden, we have taken a pioneering approach by considering peach trees as our cancer patients and implementing precision medicine strategies. For this year's competition, we studied the literature and carried out field research to gather as much information as possible. We have completed the hardware part of a simple fluorometer that can be used to diagnose gummosis disease in peach trees. However, we still need to learn as much related knowledge and bioinformatics skills as possible to search for treatment targets, and we need to collect more data to complete the software part of our simple fluorometer.

title: Artificially Synthesizing Caddisfly Silk in Yeast as an Alternative Surgical Mesh
abstract: With over 90% of cosmetic surgeries requiring the use of plastic-based meshes for soft tissue support and securing implants, the risk of introducing microplastics and their subsequent adverse health effects runs high. It is clear that there is a need for a bio-based alternative. We propose a silk-based mesh, dubbed Caddisgraft, to solve this issue. Caddisfly silk is a wet adhesive secreted by aquatic caddisfly larvae to protect against the elements, and thus boasts a high tensile strength, biodegradability and non-cytotoxic properties. Our team hopes to develop a yeast strain capable of expressing caddisfly silk for purification and mass production into Caddisgraft surgical meshes. This yeast strain would be created through a novel synthesis method that stitches together highly repetitive silk protein motifs until the desired number of repeats is reached. Ultimately, Caddisgraft hopes to reduce post-operative pain and encourage better tissue regrowth in cosmetic surgery patients.
student leaders: Lucy Wu, Siyona Mishra, Vara Qi Gunananthan
students: Adina Jailova, Alexander Kim, Alisa, Iris, Justin Blumenthal, Katie Hong, Marika Abe, Melina Mohammadi, Olga, Prisha, Sophia Xu, Tarini Basireddy, Yiwen(Melody) Jin, Youying Dong, Yuki Matsumoto

title: Lantern: Programmable Logic Framework Based on Recombinase and CRISPR Interference
abstract: Programmable Logic Devices (PLDs) have become pivotal in the development of digital circuits. Unlike traditional digital chips, which have fixed internal circuits that cannot be modified post-production, PLDs allow for manual reconfiguration after manufacturing, enabling them to perform various logic functions. A primary objective of synthetic biology is the application of electronic engineering principles to cellular and biomolecular systems. By manipulating different genetic circuit modules, cells can be engineered to perform specific tasks akin to digital devices. Integrating PLDs into cellular systems opens the possibility of programming cells to exhibit reliable, robust, and diverse behaviors. Existing powerful tools in biology, such as recombinases--a robust recombination framework--and CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), an effective NOT gate widely used in gene circuit design, facilitate this endeavor. This project aims to utilize recombinase and CRISPRi to construct programmable logic pathways in organisms, thereby enabling the systematic programming of cellular behaviors.
advisors: Binwen Liu, Bowen Liu, Cao Yaozhong, Ji Sun, zhaoziyi, Zhichen Guo
students: Chi Tianjian, Huang Lintaihui, Jinsheng Xu, Kehan Wang, Meng Wang, Xingyu Chen, Xinyi Li, Xinyue Ding, Xuanting Wu, Yifan Jiang, Yijie Li, y q, Yuming Luo, Yutong Liu, Zhiqian Li, Zimou Li, Zitao Qiu

title: Enrichment of lanthanides for electronic waste recycling by engineering a chemotactic system in Methylobacterium extorquens
abstract: Less than 10% of rare earth metals are recycled from electronic waste. We present an engineered strain of Methylobacterium extorquens that is able to enrich lanthanides from a homogenous mixture. M. extorquens was engineered to display chemotaxis towards the affordable amino acid aspartate. This biological system facilitates the movement of lanthanides towards an aspartate plug. Lanthanide uptake was optimised via the expression of the protein LanM, which reduces the cellular stress caused by lanthanides. Genetic engineering parameters were informed by mathematical and computational models, including a gene regulatory network model; agent-based and PDE models were also employed to evaluate the experimental setup. This concept can be implemented industrially to enrich lanthanides from electronic waste for recycling. Additionally, the principles can be applied to other biologically rare elements in the same waste mixture to enrich multiple metals simultaneously.
students: Aaron Lee, Amanda Jashanica, Andreea Cernei, Daniel Dunbar, Ellen Tsang, Francesco Papini, Laiba Wahab, Magdalena Godzina, Marina Lazic, Talitha Van Beek

title: Utilising Chromoprotein Expression to Counteract Coral Bleaching: An Innovative Light and Temperature Apporach
abstract: Coral bleaching, exacerbated by rising sea temperatures and intense light exposure, threatens the survival of coral reefs worldwide. Existing solutions often lack scalability or interfere with coral physiology. We, offers an innovative synthetic biology approach to enhance coral resilience. We engineer the symbiotic bacteria Endozoicomonas to express a light-shielding chromoprotein in response to environmental stressors. This protein reduces excessive light reaching zooxanthellae, the photosynthetic algae within corals, thereby mitigating oxidative damage without disrupting essential cellular functions. By incorporating a regulated genetic circuit sensitive to heat and light, we ensure the chromoprotein is produced only under stress conditions, preserving normal coral and bacterial activity otherwise. This strategy mimics the natural protective effects observed in turbid waters, where reduced light intensity lessens bleaching events. Our solution aims for sustainable, long-term integration into coral ecosystems, offering a scalable method to combat coral bleaching induced by both high temperatures and intense light.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Undergrad

title: Sanalgesic
abstract: There are over 300 million cases of General Anxiety Disorder (GAD) worldwide, causing stress and physical symptoms like pain and insomnia. Aromatherapy, particularly with Sandalwood album oil (SAO), can help relieve these issues. However, SAO is scarce and expensive due to low yields and the endangered status of its source plant. We aim to address this by engineering E. Coli and C.Serevisiae to produce SAO's key chemicals, creating a sustainable and accessible alternative to traditional methods that take 25-30 years. This project could make SAO's therapeutic benefits more widely available.
advisors: Hui Zhang, Keitatsu Osone, rdao, ?? ??_??_??

title: MARINE- Microplastic cell degradation factory based on phage display technology
abstract: The increasing prevalence of plastic pollution, particularly marine litter, poses a significant environmental challenge. As highlighted, an estimated 5.25 trillion plastic particles, weighing over 268,000 tons, are estimated to be present in the world's oceans. Microplastics, which are particularly problematic due to their small size and difficulty to degrade, can induce a range of toxic effects, including oxidative stress and metabolic disorders in marine organisms. The innovative approach of employing genetically engineered E. coli BL21 (DE3) expressing surface-displayed PETase and TfCa encapsulated within the BASH device represents a promising strategy to tackle the growing issue of microplastic pollution in marine environments. By combining advanced genetic engineering techniques with a robust encapsulation system, this project has the potential to enable practical and sustainable solutions for plastic waste degradation. The proposed framework aims to provide an effective biological method for degrading harmful microplastics.
advisors: Hui Zhang, Paris Yuan
student leaders: Azuo Zhao, Benjamin Yang, Geng Jialin, Joyce Zhang, Leo Shen, Tiffany, Zichen Niu
students: Angel???, Clark, Gordonlle, Isabella, Jason, Jason Zhang, Jayden Chen, Leo Y, Marcus Lian, Timmy Peng, tina, Yiya Xiang, Yunlin Cui, Zexuan Gu, Zoe Chen, ???

title: Foodborne-stress induced secretion therapy(FIST)- Engineered Lactobacillus transplantation for T2DM treatment
abstract: We have chosen food-grade Lactobacillus NZ9000 as the chassis cells and designed two protein expression systems: (1)Foodborne-stress induced expression system for FGF21(fibroblast growth factor 21) -LMWP (low-molecular-weight protamine). As the concentration of cholate in the intestine increases after meals, the GroESL promoter initiates transcription and promotes the secretion of fusion proteins by the engineered bacteria. The LMWP facilitates the entry of FGF21 into the bloodstream, and FGF21 improves tissue insulin resistance. (2)Constitutive expression system that displays Akkermansia muciniphila P9 protein on the membrane. P9 protein binds to the ICAM-2 receptor on intestinal epithelial L-cells, releasing GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1), which promotes insulin secretion. We hope that our engineered intestinal Lactobacillus can provide a novel approach for the long-term relief of T2DM by coordinating and leveraging the body's glucose-lowering mechanisms in a non-invasive, long-lasting, and more humane way, thus aiding in the alleviation, control, or even cure of diabetes.
PIs: Hongyan Qin, Chunchen Gao, Fan Fan, Junlong Zhao
students: Cheng Hao, HU YING DONG, Lei Xiao, Qinghong Yuan, Tianyao Wang, WenqingLi, WRY, Xiangchen Li, Xikun Lu, Yifei Huang, Yuhao Cao, Yunhai Xu, Zihan Chen, Zishuo Xie

title: Bluebear Bio - Making Cell-Free Expression Systems Accessible
abstract: Cell-free transcription and translation (TXTL) is a powerful tool that enables biomolecule production directly from DNA, bypassing the need for living cells. This allows for faster prototyping and production. Our project builds on recent TXTL advancements by using a genetically modified E. coli BL21(DE3) autolysate strain, featuring tardigrade protein genes CAHS 107838, CAHS 106094, and CAHS 94063. These proteins enhance lysate stability at higher temperatures, eliminating the need for costly cryogenic storage. Additionally, we optimized the energy buffer to lower costs, making expensive equipment unnecessary. This opens up TXTL technology to broader use, especially in resource-limited settings. Our improved system is also ideal for educational purposes, as it reduces the financial burden of maintaining specialized lab infrastructure. These advancements make cell-free systems more affordable and accessible, driving further innovation in synthetic biology across academic, industrial, and low-resource environments.
nominations: Best Biomanufacturing Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
advisors: Aukse Gaizauskaite, Emma Crean, Imre Banlaki, Jan Lars Kalkowski
student leaders: Mara Valverde, Marten Meckelburg, Sara Hanson, Zakh Roth
students: Abdelrahman Saleh, Jiaming Li, Kilian Kunert, Mira Shankar, Osama Mansoor, Philipp Goldemund, Sanidhya Pai, Stephen Morton, Youssef S. Abdelaziz

title: Zymetec: Cultivating Tradition, Empowering Maize with Biotechnology
abstract: Maize, a staple feeding over 3 billion people globally, holds deep cultural, economic, and social significance, especially in Mexico, where it's intertwined with identity. However, climate change and water scarcity threaten maize, affecting 40% of global crops and endangering food security. To combat this, Zymetec, a biostimulant, enhances maize's stress resistance by boosting the production of osmoprotectants like proline and glycine betaine by activating the metabolic route, improving water use and reducing oxidative stress. Zymetec safeguards maize's nutritional value, ensuring food security, preserving jobs, and supporting cultural traditions, particularly in regions where maize is central to life.
nominations: Best Food & Nutrition Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Undergrad
PIs: Cynthia Lizeth Gonzalez Trevizo, Gladys Guadalupe Lopez Avalos

students: Edgar Aviles, Erwin Vázquez, Leopoldo Escárcega, Luis Alberto Payan Porras, Mauricio Morán, Myriam Muruato, Paulina Xochitiotzin

title: Mangroves PE&CO2 Hunters
abstract: The global problem of microplastic pollution has become a significant challenge for marine and coastal ecosystems, with research shows that mangroves not only effectively block plastic debris but also gradually accumulate it in their soil and sediments. Therefore, the microplastic content in mangrove soils is significantly higher than in other coastlines or marine sediments. To address these issues, we introduce "Mangroves PE&CO2 Hunters", a project that has engineered two distinct bacterial species to tackle this environmental challenge. The first, P. aeruginosa, has been genetically modified to more effectively break down PE microplastics. Furthermore, we have engineered R. palustris to sequester CO2 produced during the plastic degradation process. Mathematical modeling, machine learning, biokinetic simulations, neural networks, LLM, and RAG are used to explore the project. Besides, we designed iHP tRi-Cycle to better understanding real-world needs thus refine our project.
nominations: Best Bioremediation Project, Undergrad+Best Model, Undergrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad
instructors: Bo Wang, Hongyu Shen, Sainan An, Yinghua Cao
advisors: Peisong Wu, Wu Wen, Yan Su, Yunyan Zeng, Yuqing Su

students: Anqi Wang, Chenlu Zhang, Haobo Cao, Haosheng Lin, Jiakai He, Jiayi He, Junjie Liao, Kexin Yu, li wang, Qiaoyao Lin, Qinghao Wang, Rui Chen, Siyan Jiang, Yifei Lyu, Yuxuan Wu, Zejun Cai, Zhengqian Zhou, Zibo Huang, Zile Huang

title: PETase Powerhouse: Crafting the Ultimate Enzyme Factory for PET Demolition
abstract: PET is a widely used plastic. However, its extensive use has also caused severe environmental pollution. In this project, through multiple rounds of engineering cycles, we optimized the promoter, signal peptide, and culture conditions, successfully constructing a highly efficient ICCG expression system. First, we created an ICCG-GFP fusion protein and used fluorescence intensity to characterize ICCG protein expression levels. During promoter optimization, we generated a Mtac promoter library through random mutagenesis and used a CNN-LSTM model to design and optimize the novel DMtac promoter. For the signal peptide, we screened and optimized the nfaA signal peptide and designed MnfaA mutants using a Markov transfer frequency matrix model. By combining high-throughput screening systems with predictive models, we significantly improved the expression efficiency of ICCG, providing valuable components and tools for future synthetic biology research.
nominations: Best New Improved Part, Undergrad
PIs: Zefang Wang, Yanyan Wang, Yunjie Xiao

title: In-Vivo Biosynthesis of Peptide-Based Therapeutics (GLP1 Agonists) through Nicotiana benthamiana
abstract: Phytogene aims to provide an affordable and sustainable alternative for synthesizing pharmaceutically and commercially relevant peptides through plant-based production (i.e. biopharming). Specifically, this project focuses on the transient heterologous production of GLP-1R agonists in Nicotiana benthamiana. Our platform consists of three key steps: cloning, plant expression, and purification. Cloning involved the design of plasmids for easy gene insertion and integration (1), plant expression was achieved through Agrobacterium-mediated transformation (2), and purification was completed through the harvesting of leaf crude lysates, followed by affinity chromatography (3). Finally, SOLIDWORKS, a computed-aided design tool, was used to design and simulate a scaled version of the agroinfiltration vacuum chamber. Through the use of an integrative design process, and by making improvements based on finite element analysis (FEA) results, Phytogene can prove its commitment to making biopharming more accessible, providing a scalable and cost-effective solution for peptide synthesis in the synthetic biology community worldwide.
nominations: Best Biomanufacturing Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Plant Synthetic Biology, Undergrad
students: Alex, Amelia, Ananya Jain, Annabelle Tian, Bryn Robins, Camille Chartrand-Pleau, Chris A, Daniel Anderson, Diana Munteanu, Kamron Yunusov, Neeharika, Norah St-Fleur, Patrick Fakhouri, Pooja Narula, Raymond, Sammy, Sarah Bukhari, Sarah Rehmani, Thalia Lamberti, Valmik Duvadie, Ziad Elhassan

title: SAC: Standardized AI-Powered Platform for Carbon-Negative Spider Silk Production - Weaving Innovation, Shaping Sustainability
abstract: Discover how NTU-Taiwan's SAC project is revolutionizing the production of spider silk through AI-driven innovation. By creating a carbon-negative, scalable, and customizable biomaterial, we're addressing critical environmental challenges while meeting the diverse needs of various industries. Join us on our journey to weave a more sustainable future.
students: CHUANG,YUNG-HSU, Evan Chu, Jean Huang, Jou-Min Hsieh, Meek, Po Wei, Tim Chao, Tzu-Ning Hung, Wayne Chen, YI-JEN WANG

title: SOLAR - Save Our Lives And Reefs: Sustainable Production of Reef-safe UV Filters
abstract: UV radiation is a leading cause of skin cancer, affecting over 1.5 million people annually. While sunscreens protect the skin, UV filters pose environmental dangers, particularly to marine ecosystems, by contributing to coral bleaching. About 14 tons of these filters enter oceans yearly, harming marine species like mussels, fish, and dolphins, and threatening coral reefs, which support vast biodiversity and human livelihoods. Additionally, these chemicals can disrupt human endocrine systems. To address this, SOLAR offers a sustainable solution using mycosporine-like amino acids (MAAs), naturally occurring in marine organisms, as UV-protective agents. Through synthetic biology, we aim to produce MAAs using E. coli, optimizing production and UV absorption ranges via Petri Nets and NRPS bioengineering, respectively. SOLAR aims to create scalable, reef-safe UV filters without compromising environmental or human health.
nominations: Best Fashion & Cosmetics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Sustainable Development Impact, Overgrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Overgrad
advisors: Adrian Romberg, Carolin Parthun, Christian Kolland, Julia Hanna Grass, Mathilde Deweirdt, Olivia Mozolewska

Schleiter, Artem Sakhniuk, Aurelia Rana Baur, Christoph Mousel, Claire von Keitz, Felix Haidle, Jannis Oetken, Laura Topcic, Leyla Ibrahimova, Lucas Koch, Maëlys Alemany, Miguel Valle-Inclán Cabello, Pavel Vychyk, Tatjana Hofmann, Tim Stadager, Timur Makarov, Vanessa Zurek

title: Nailiva: Revolutionizing Nails with Microbial Elegance
abstract: After conducting thorough research into the potential health risks and environmental impacts of existing nail polish products, our project has innovatively developed a unique nail polish. By precisely producing enzyme-induced red, yellow, and blue pigments using engineered bacteria, we enable the free expression of vibrant patterns, offering personalized nail art options to users. Furthermore, we have developed a groundbreaking eco-friendly adhesive material, "AMS," which integrates mussel hybrid protein with hydrogel to enhance both adhesion and environmental performance, providing users with a new, aesthetically pleasing, and healthy nail polish experience.
student leaders: Jinling Yuan, Shurui Ning, Xindi Chang, Yitong Wu
students: Huaizhe Zhan, Jingwen Xiao, Jingyi Sun, Ke Fang, Ruichen Han, Shuangmeng Jia, Wenduo Zou, Xia Hua, XiaoWen Chen, Xinyuan Cao, Xinyue Zhang, Yujin Zhu, Zhenhua Bai, Ziwen Yao

title: Thaelia: Guardian of the Olive Groves
abstract: Olive trees hold deep cultural and economic importance in Greece, accounting for 79% of the country's tree crops. In our region, Thessaly, they are crucial to the stability of farmers' livelihoods. However, olive trees face a significant threat from Verticillium dahliae, a fungal pathogen that causes severe yield losses and tree mortality, especially in the Mediterranean. The lack of effective treatments has resulted in substantial economic losses, posing challenges to farmers' way of life and threatening the environment. With this in mind, our team developed THAELIA, a modular bacterial system that produces dsRNA to precisely target and silence essential fungal genes. By disrupting the growth and virulence of V. dahliae, THAELIA offers a sustainable new approach to fungal control. This approach protects olive trees during critical periods, ensuring the safety of biodiversity, human health, and the environment.
nominations: Best Agriculture Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Education, Overgrad
advisors: Christina Malamou, Claire Tsitsigianni, Dimitrios Eleftheriou, Grigoris Karypidis, Theofilos Terzopoulos
students: Chrysi Touchtidou, Evangelos Ananiadis, Ioannis Xesfingoulis, Maria - Asimina Kakadiari, Maria Nefeli Stoupa, Maria Tzanaki, Myrto Veligratli, Nikolaos Chatzoudas, Panagiota Koutsandrea

title: N. Factory
abstract: Over a third of the world's population can't afford healthy diets due to poverty, trapped in a dilemma between low income and malnutrition. Nodule Factory produces nutrients with rhizobia, innovatively addressing both issues. Rhizobia are symbiotic bacteria of leguminous plants, and the symbiotic structure of nodules has a naturally microaerobic environment, while DHA and EPA are high-value and microaerobic substances. We deleted specific enzyme genes to increase precursor substances and added regulatory sequences and synthetic gene clusters to enable them to produce DHA and EPA under low-oxygen, high-nitrogen conditions in nodules. Proper inoculation and nitrogen fertilization ensure the efficiency of Nodule Factory, providing impoverished regions with high-added-value legumes for income and nutrition. In the future, we aim to transfer these nutrients to soybeans to further empower the soybeans. Our modular Nodule Factory will pioneer sustainable and microaerobic production, significantly contributing to global sustainability.
nominations: Best Part Collection, Undergrad+Best Sustainable Development Impact, Undergrad
advisors: Hua Xinying, Qianhui Sun, Xiangjun Liu, Xu Linjie, Yao-han Huang, Yuxiao Liu, Zhang Xiyuan

title: NanoDisguiser: Redefining Broad-Spectrum Antiviral Therapy with Nanodisc Technology Platform
abstract: Nanodiscs are tiny, disk-shaped structures engineered as drugs, antibodies, or in vitro biological components. Our project introduces a groundbreaking nanodisc-based antiviral therapy, NanoDisguiser, designed to tackle the limitations of traditional methods, such as viral drug resistance. By using broad-spectrum nanodiscs therapy with virus-specific receptors, these nanodiscs act as decoys, luring and disrupting viruses before they can infect cells. This cutting-edge approach provides a powerful and versatile defense against a wide range of viruses, including new and mutant strains. We're also working to validate and commercialize this technology as an injectable antiviral solution, aiming to redefine antiviral therapy in a post-pandemic world.
instructors: Dong Yang, Lu Dong, peipei yin, Xudong Zhu
advisors: Dou, Ruixiao Tan, Yixin Huang, Yixin Zhu

title: VEBATIN-Engineering bacteria to inhibit solid tumor proliferation by competing VEGF
abstract: One of the major challenges in the treatment of solid tumors arises from the immunosuppressive nature of the surrounding tumor microenvironment?TME?, which weakens the immune system's cytotoxic ability. Currently, therapeutic strategies targeting the solid tumor microenvironment have gained extensive attention, while most existing treatments still confront with challenges such as off-target risks. Our team has noticed that harmless Escherichia coli Nissle 1917(EcN) can automatically colonize the tumor microenvironment, demonstrating excellent targeting potential. Therefore, we plan to utilize the angiogenesis mechanism driven by vascular endothelial growth factorin ?VEGF?in the human body. We plan to genetically modified EcN to express VEGF competitive binding receptors under ideal conditions of TME and conduct a surface display in ECN. By integrating and consuming VEGF in the tumor microenvironment, we plan to reduce its concentration in the TME, thereby effectively inhibiting angiogenesis in tumor areas and ultimately suppress tumor proliferation.
advisors: Chuhan Peng, Fengyuan Yang, Jiamin Dong, Shi Han, Yuxiang Lao, Zeyue Jia
student leaders: Jiacan Ma, Tianyue Chen, Wanyang Yu

title: BioALA+: Advanced 5-ALA Synthesis for Sustainable Agriculture
abstract: The supply of grain is the foundation of people's livelihood. However, with many agricultural fields in various regions suffering from drought, diseases, pests, and other attacks, many people still live in hunger. Using biopesticide to enhance crops' resistance to abiotic and biotic stresses, while promoting crop yield is an available solution. 5-aminolevulinic acid (5-ALA) is a sophisticated and sustainable biopesticide, especially when compared to the various highly toxic and non-degradable chemical pesticides currently in use. The exploration of the biological manufacturing of 5-ALA in recent years has driven our research. However, issues such as the stability of ALAS gene expression, the obsolescence of targets, and the low efficiency of screening for target strains still persist. This project addresses these three issues by utilizing CRISPR-associated transposon system, enzyme-constrained model, and droplet microfluidic high-throughput screening technologies to explore solutions.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, Undergrad
PIs: Yuetong Wang, Tian-qiong Shi, Chi Zhang, Guang Yang

title: BIOTARGET: Bacterial Iterative Optimized Therapy and Assisted Resistance Guard Enhancement Technology
abstract: JLU-NBBMS 2024 has developed the BIOTARGET, an advanced biological system iteratively engineered using bacteria. This system integrates modular design concepts from synthetic biology, RNAi technology, attenuated Salmonella, and nanotechnology to precisely target and treat chemotherapy-resistant cancer cells. It enhances tumor recognition with a targeting module, suppresses chemoresistance gene expression with a gene regulation module, ensures Salmonella's controllable behavior within the body through a safety module, and facilitates precise drug delivery via a nanoparticle-mediated module. We have further validated the metabolism, dynamics, and efficacy of the BIOTARGET using mathematical models and cell experiments to ensure its safety and efficacy, aiming to provide personalized treatment options for patients and enhance the effectiveness of chemotherapy drugs.
instructors: Jiaying Yang, Li Fukuan, Quan Chengshi, Zhang Yuetao, Zhao Wuchao

title: Mo-Base: Multi-Omics Bioformatics Analysis SynthEsis Platform
abstract: We are attempting to build a highly interactive and comprehensive bioinformatics service platform. The platform includes a fully optimized single-cell analysis pipeline that can be applied to synthetic biology research requiring transcriptomics analysis. In addition, we have explored the current applications of deep learning models, and have also integrated a community within the platform to allow users to communicate and discuss with each other at any time.

title: Natronaut: Harnessing Nitrate Assimilation for Single Cell Protein (SCP) Production and Coastal Eutrophication Bioremediation
abstract: MSP-Maastricht is addressing coastal eutrophication, a local and global issue. Excessive fertiliser run-off from agriculture, a key economic sector of the Netherlands' economy, has polluted waterways, spreading into marine ecosystems. This leads to ocean acidification, anoxia, and harmful algal blooms, which intensify climate change and disrupt biodiversity. Natronaut focuses on engineering the marine bacterium Vibrio natriegens to mitigate nitrate pollution in coastal waters. By harnessing its rapid growth and metabolic capacity, we aim to assimilate excess nitrates and convert them into single-cell proteins (SCPs), which can serve as sustainable livestock feed. This innovation reduces the need for conventional feed crops and fertilisers, promoting resource efficiency and circularity. Our project addresses the environmental challenge of eutrophication by not only reducing eutrophication but also working to prevent its recurrence. Ultimately, we aim to convert agricultural waste into valuable biomass, turning the tide on nitrate pollution.
advisors: Mike Gerards

title: Manipulate Astrobiology for Revolutionary Synthetic-survival ?MARSs)
abstract: Mars is a potential destination for human migration. However, future explorers will face significant challenges, including the lack of natural food resources and oxygen, toxic and poor soil for crop production, and limited synbio toolkit. We proposed solutions across four key areas inspired by a series of human practices. First, to provide sustainable nutrition, we aim to co-culture engineered yeast and cyanobacteria to produce essential compounds such as lycopene, nerol, and limonene. Second, to convert Martian soil into arable land, we isolated nitrogen-fixing bacteria and used directed evolution to enhance bacteria's resistance to Martian toxins. Third, we introduced updates to our TTTT system, released in 2023, which now reduces plant transformation time by up to 50%, encouraging more iGEM participants to engage in plant synthetic biology. Finally, as a creative endeavor, we applied DNA data storage to archive significant records of Earth's biodiversity and culture for future generations
advisors: Hui Zhang, Juan SANG, Lei Yingjie, Siwei Yan, Wenyuan Liu
student leaders: Chenghao Bian, Dingxuan He, Haoyun Zheng, Suyu Gou
students: Annie, Boyi Xu, Chen Li, Cynthia Zhao, Huijing Yang, Jialei Wang, Jinlei Wang, Kexin Huang, Leyi Huang, Mingda Wang, Shiqi Liu, Yiheng Gao, Yiren Lu, Yiwen Zhu, Ziming Zhong, Ziyan Wang

title: NeuroMuSceteer: "all for one" against Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: Multiple Sclerosis is an increasingly prominent, multifactorial disease that affects almost 3 million people worldwide,with that number being expected to increase exponentially. Its treatment is currently centered around symptom management and decelerating its progression, as there is no available cure. Recognising this major gap in modern therapeutics, we developed NeuroMuSceteer; a modular, precision medicine, holistic therapy. It involves T- cells that are engineered to selectively target specific disease antibodies and act as immune regulators (Tregs),boosting the immune system and the CNS. Furthermore, we included two molecular structures, one that detects and one that releases microRNA agents in target cells, repairing nerve damage. The design was made in collaboration with various stakeholders in both research and healthcare, with the purpose of tackling all aspects of Multiple Sclerosis with accuracy and safety. Its modularity also allows it to be adapted for various autoimmune disorders, making it a useful tool for future researchers.
advisors: Ioanna Choustoulaki, Kallisti St John, stathis pateras
students: Anastasia Trygouti, Antonios Tsiorvas, Eva Chasekidou, Ioanna Karampela, Maria-Christina Tsilia, Maria Kefala, Panagiotis Boutos, Vasileios-Panagiotis Theocharopoulos, Other, Maria-Louiza Takatzoglou

title: SkinBAIT: Innovative Approach for Targeting Skin Parasites and Infestations Using Engineered Skin Microbiota
abstract: The SkinBait project aims to develop an innovative approach to treat skin diseases caused by external organisms, with a current focus on scabies, a condition caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei. It involves engineering the skin bacterium Cutibacterium acnes to produce toxins that are lethal to scabies but harmless to humans. Our project had two main parts: the expression of Cry proteins and the expression of endolysin regulated by an RNA thermometer. We optimized gene circuits for Cry toxin production using C. acnes and E. coli, developed safety mechanisms using RNA thermometers and the endolysin, and designed experiments to evaluate Cry toxin efficacy and biocontainment strategies. Several mathematical models were included that simulate what effect our approach would have. Through this design, we aim to create a safe, effective, and biologically contained treatment for skin parasites, setting the foundation for broader applications in skin disease treatment.
instructors: Carles Bayod Giron, Guillermo Nevot, Lorena Toloza, Marc González, Maria Artigues, Maria Pol, Marta Palau, Matsuri Rojano-Nisimura
students: Blanca Marco, Carlos Pérez de Arenaza, David Ribalta, Helena Sánchez, Inés Matheu Zorrilla, Jose Luis Pérez, Keysha Urgel, María Cortés Díaz, Oriana Castillo Ferreira, Pau Figuera Belmonte, Roger Planell, Other, Regina Lopez

title: The Pentacone; Coastal Defense, Engineered by Nature.
abstract: Coastal erosion and plastic pollution are growing threats to coastlines worldwide, and Ghana is no exception. These environmental challenges have severely impacted communities near the coast, destroying homes and infrastructure, displacing families, and burdening the economy heavily. Despite efforts to address these issues, current solutions have proven ineffective in providing lasting relief. The Sea Titans aim to deliver a groundbreaking and sustainable solution to combat plastic pollution and coastal erosion. Our innovative approach involves the Pentacone, a structure equipped with advanced biotechnology designed to decompose PET plastic in the sea and reduce coastal erosion. This Pentapod is designed to self-regenerate when damaged, ensuring longevity. This circular approach not only cleans our seas but also strengthens coastal defenses. As Sea Titans, we want to create a future where our oceans and coastlines are cleaner, more resilient, safer for coastal communities and contribute to the global fight against pollution and environmental degradation.
advisors: John Kwesi Tetteh, Prince Edem Samoh
students: Brendon Nqobani Dolobo, Daniel Tunyinko, Eldad Opare, Leslie Konlack, Nicole Uzile Sibanda, Obadiah Safi, Tanatswa Mhiribidi, Thembani Ngwenya, Vanessa Logan Berinyuy Anabi, Victor Asum

title: Caffeine Cycle
abstract: This project focuses on the reutilization of food waste by employing directed evolution of key enzymes to improve the production of 7-methylxanthine (7-MX), a high-value compound, with caffeine from coffee grounds as the substrate. This research not only provides an innovative and sustainable solution for the reutilization of coffee grounds, thus promoting the sustainable development of the circular economy, but also opens up new possibilities in the biosynthesis of methylxanthine compounds.
nominations: Best Entrepreneurship, Overgrad+Best Sustainable Development Impact, Overgrad
advisors: Chang Liu, HUGE GU, Huizhe Zhao, Jinlin Wu, Peipei Liu, Qianwen Jin, Ruilin Zhang, Shangci Zuo, Xiaoyu Zhang, Xuanye Li, Yao Li, Yuting Gao

title: BEST-ABfree: Efficient synthesis of ?-glucan to reduce antibiotic utilization
abstract: Livestock farming has long been essential for providing high-quality protein and other animal by-products. Antibiotics are extensively used in this industry to ensure stable production. However, misuse of antibiotics leads to environmental residues and the emergence of antibiotic-resistant superbugs, posing significant human health risks. ?-glucans, naturally occurring ?-D-glucose polysaccharides found in grains, bacteria, and fungi, offer a potential alternative to antibiotics due to their immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory. ?-glucans, particularly from Aureobasidium melanogenum BZ-11, can be efficiently produced via fermentation. This fungus isolated from mangroves secretes extracellular polysaccharides, including ?-glucans, but also melanin and pullulan, which complicate the purification process. Using synthetic biology techniques, we employed Cre-loxP to block the secretion of melanin and pullulan, enhancing the purity of ?-glucans. Additionally, introducing an oxygen uptake system improved yield. Our optimized fermentation process allows for the efficient production of ?-glucans, presenting a viable antibiotic alternative for livestock feed, potentially mitigating antibiotic misuse.
advisors: Jiashuo Zhang, Jing He, Yufei Qiao
students: Hongcheng Liu, Honglin Shao, Ping Wang, QiChen Zhang, Ruihuan Ou, Runqi Zhang, Yaxin Liu, Yidan Chang, Yidi He, Yunpeng Wu

title: The Revolutionary Tea -VitaliNK; Using Traditional Japanese Food "Natto" to Prevent Thrombosis
abstract: Thrombosis accounts for one in four deaths worldwide. "Thrombosis" is a general term for diseases caused by blood clots obstructing blood vessels, including myocardial infarction, stroke, pulmonary embolism, and cardioembolic stroke. This is a significant issue in Japan, which is experiencing an aging society. Among the G7 countries, Japan has the highest percentage of elderly people within its total population. However, current treatments for Thrombosis consist of side effects that heavily affect the body. which is why we decided to use nattokinase, which is found in the Japanese traditional food, "Natto". Nattokinase demonstrates strong thrombolytic activity by enhancing the effects of the fibrinolytic enzyme plasmin present in the body, therefore easy to consume the body, less resistant from consumers, and is a new preventative solution for Thrombosis. Our product form of tea is easily consumed daily and without health issues as barriers.
students: Arisa Tani, Ayaka Kotajima, Kan Soda, Kei Hato, Miruhi Tsumiyama, Misaki Ozawa, Mizuho Sakai, Riko Kasai, Rikuto Fukushima, Ryuzo Kijima, Saki Tsuchiya, Shiori Kajikawa, Shoya Inoue, Tatsuhiko Akiyama, Wingdor Doria Lee, Yukiya Horiba

title: Reneurish: A novel cell therapy to restore neural tissue damage post-stroke
abstract: Reneurish aims to genetically modify neural progenitor cells (NPC) to overexpress BDNF -a potent neurotrophic factor- to tackle the challenges attributed to neural transplants; low neuronal integration and cell survival. This overexpression is achieved through the infection of NPCs with an AAV vector. Donor's NPCs are kept in a reservoir and infected after stroke takes place, then transplanted into the patient's damaged brain region to enhance regeneration, improving integration, synapsis and minimizing tissue death. During our investigation, the need for precise monitoring led to the development of a customizable reporter transfection cassette, which can be easily removed during the humanization of the vector. This study concluded that BDNF can be overexpressed in human NPCs for over 50 days. We observed that an increase in BDNF levels correlates with a higher neural activity, better axon connectivity and higher cell count, without generating aberrant networks.
advisors: Arnau Vila Bertomeu, Júlia Aguilar García
student leaders: Ares Font Guixé, Santiago Ramos Bartolome
students: Alba Cartró Peris, Àlex Roger, Andrea Cami Bonet, Emma Esquirol Albalá, Irene Agudo Zamora, Jaume Ros Miralles, Laila Olivella, Luna Goulet, Marc Fabrellas, Marc Magem, Sergi Fornós Zapater

title: Hydro Guardian: A Biosensor for Detecting ?-Lactam Antibiotic and Heavy Metal Residues
abstract: We developed a cellular sensor using genetically modified HEK cells to detect both heavy metals and antibiotic residues. The Hydro Guardian integrates the eukaryotic metal-binding transcription factor 1 (MTF1) pathway for heavy metals and the PASTA domain from prokaryotes, which is sensitive to beta-lactam antibiotics. The sensor was optimized through a sophisticated spectroscopic analysis pipeline and refined using a detailed differential equation-based model, enabling the determination of minimal residue detection limits. Throughout the design process, we collaborated with stakeholders from various fields and contributed over 20 new parts to the iGEM Registry. To validate the sensor concept, we successfully demonstrated the expression of distinct fluorophores, activated by specific promoter-regulator pathways for the MTF1 and PASTA domains, confirming the functionality of the system in detecting target contaminants.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Overgrad
instructors: Anna Seidler, Lara Gentemann, Niklas Rüprich, Soeren Donath
student leaders: Leon Kasperek, Lisa Marie de Sousa Miranda

title: Neovio Dye----A new type of dyeing implemented by light induction system
abstract: ZJU-China has designed a new and interesting microbial staining method. On the basis of synthesizing Violacein's highly efficient metabolic modification and addressable RNA scaffold, it uses light-induced DNA recombinase and light-sensitive transcription factors to realize memory pattern drawing, hoping to bring the color of synthetic biology to the fashion industry. Please join us to find fashion!
advisors: Qinyao Yan, Zhenning Yang, Zhijian Yan
student leaders: Chenchen Huang, Haoyang Liu, Zhang Liting
students: Chenxi Tang, He Yichen, Jiawei Wang, Jimeng Zhang, Jinyuan Fu, Sibo Xiao, Xuanhao Wang, Yiwei Yang, YuFei Xie, ZHENGHAO LI, Zhenyu Hu

title: General disease detection with Protease and Aptamer (GPA)
abstract: Aimed at creating a new methodology for disease diagnosis, GPA combines AI with protease-based circuits to accomplish modularization, the core value of synthetic biology, which is embodied in the design of our system?the variable biomarker recognition part and the constant signal amplification and output part. For the first part, featuring on flexible structures, aptamers (i.e., single stranded nucleotides) recognize variable biomarkers. Additionally, an AI tool?MAGA, has laid foundations for applying aptamers to biomarker binding. With MAGA, given a biomarker of a specific disease, we can obtain different aptamers recognizing it with high affinities. For the second part comes the protease-based circuits to transform and amplify signals. For the third part, a special designed gold colloidal test serves as the output. With GPA, we envision a future where the primary disease diagnosis takes fewer time, costs lower, prioritizes user-friendliness and ensures everyone a healthier life.
advisors: Haobin Zhu, Luxuan Liu
students: Fu Jiachen, Jingyi Dong, Junting Zhou, Kairui Bi, Shuyang Hou, Sirun Li, Wenqing Yu, Xiangkai Jin, Xiyue Zhang, Yiyan Liao, Yiya Wang, Yufei Zhao, Yunhang Xiao, Zewei Song, Zhiyu Wu

title: "Gut Guardian" - A Probiotic Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 That Can Sense and Treat IBD
abstract: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic intestinal inflammation of unknown etiology and incurable nature. This project utilizes Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 as the chassis cell, employing six functional modules to address IBD. The sensing module, regulated by the SoxR/SoxS promoter, detects excessive NO, ensuring that the gene circuit is activated only in the IBD environment, thereby enhancing safety and specificity. The therapeutic modules include the immune module (PD-L1), adhesion module (Mfp), and antioxidant module (SOD), which are designed to suppress immune responses, repair damaged intestinal tissues, and eliminate reactive oxygen species, respectively. The lysis module automatically lyses probiotic cells upon their accumulation at the inflammation site, releasing therapeutic proteins. The safety module activates the expression of the MazF toxin via a blue light-responsive promoter, ensuring the engineered bacteria die upon excretion, thus mitigating potential risks.
PIs: Honghua Jia, Guannan Liu, Ren Hao, tianjing wang
advisors: Yao Yao
student leaders: Tao Wang, Xinquan Zhou, Xinyi Yang, Yang Gu, Zihao Chen

title: Genetically engineering Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans for effective biomining
abstract: Given the global increasing demand for mineral resources and the ore grades decline, there is an increasing utilization of microorganisms in biomining to extract valuable metals from low-grade ores and electronic waste. Biomining offers a sustainable and environmentally friendly alternative to conventional mineral processing technologies. However, it faces challenges like long leaching cycles, low extraction efficiency, and unspecific bioleaching. The genetic engineering of microorganisms can enhance their capabilities for improved biomining performance promisingly. Acidithiobacillus, a genus of extremophilic acidophiles commonly inhabiting mining process waters and acid mine drainage, is a promising chassis for metal recovery and bioremediation of metal-contaminated sites. In 2024, CUG-China aims to enhance biomining efficiency for nonferrous metals by genetically engineering Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans. This engineered strain incorporates a cyclic di-GMP synthesis module for the enhancement of bacteria-ore interactions, a gold-specific detection module for targeted recovery, and an electron transfer module for further improving biomining processes.
PIs: Yidan Hu, Yiran Dong, Yongguang Jiang, ZhouJiang
advisors: Jian Liu, Jiaqin Li, Xi Han, Yuchen Zhang, zhou wei, Zhuangzhuang Yue
student leaders: Fangjun Liu, Lele Geng, Yanbo Yue
students: Changhong Chen, chen, Doris, duke, Gem, Lijiao Mao, Peiyao Li, PVBLIVS AEQVALITAS GRACCHVS, Ruiyi Jiao, Run Liu, Shuoyuan Huang, Xinyi Li, Xinyi Shi, Xuelan Feng, Xu Kaiyi, YuFan, Yuxuan Wu, Zimo Deng, ZiQing Zhu

title: Engineering E. coli to Secrete Protease Inhibitors to Mitigate Pseudogymnoascus destructans in Bat Populations
abstract: White-Nose Syndrome affects five of the nine bat species located in Michigan: the Little Brown bat, the Big Brown Bat, the Tricolored bat, the Indiana bat, and the Northern Long-Eared bat. The disease is caused by the fungus Pseudogymnoascus destructans, which infects bats during their hibernation period, causing the collagen in their noses to slowly degrade due to proteolytic enzymes produced by the fungus. This causes the bats to become active from hibernation prematurely, which results in lethargy due to the limited resources. Without the necessary means to sustain life available in the winter season, death is often a result. There is currently no widespread treatment to prevent P. destructans infections in bats. We aim to engineer E. coli that secrete a serine protease inhibitor(s) to prevent collagen degradation.
students: Alice Hutchins, Anakin Brittain, Anna Smith, Anna Thornburgh, Blaise Armstead, Charlotte Howald, Devyn Whitford, Emily Smith, Hannah Gyolai, Ichrak, Isabell Bryans, Isha, Jackson Hall, Joseph Colucci, Jose Pinacho, Lailah Wiltz, Mina Buchkowski, Nayeli Santana-Venegas, Owen Denk, Paige Lamoreaux, Reagan Keyser, Scott Sparks, Skye Wilcox, Timothy Salley

title: Engineering Shewanella oneidensis MR-1 for Polylactic Acid Degradation to Generate Electrical Energy
abstract: Many researchers have challenged the degradability of the biopolymer Polylactic Acid (PLA), hugely popular in 3D printing. To address PLA's environmental persistence, we are working to engineer the bacterium Shewanella oneidensis MR-1 to degrade PLA and generate power from its breakdown. S. oneidensis is a gram-negative, facultative anaerobe capable of extracellular electron transfer, and can break down organic material and generate electricity in microbial fuel cells. It utilizes lactic acid as its carbon source to produce electricity. Therefore, we engineered S. oneidensis with genes encoding for PLA depolymerases from 4 bacterial strains. When expressing these genes, we expect that S. oneidensis will be capable of depolymerizing PLA to lactic acid, then using the lactic acid as a substrate for electricity production. The S. oneidensis strains that were successful in degrading PLA will be used in a microbial fuel cell for electricity production with PLA as the carbon source.
PIs: Michaela TerAvest, Bjoern Hamberger, Masako Harada
advisors: Emma Boismier, Sarah González Henao
students: Caroline Erpelding, Hien Le, Leland Huber, Minh Anh Dang, Nayan Mallya, Nayeema Siraj

title: Broccoli Master :Sustainable de novo synthesis of sulforaphane in Saccharomyces cerevisiae
abstract: Cancer is a major health issue, and chemotherapy, while a primary treatment, often has severe side effects and limited effectiveness. Sulforaphane, an isothiocyanate found in cruciferous vegetables like broccoli seeds, has strong anti-cancer properties with minimal side effects. However, its production from plants leads to land waste, high costs, and unsustainable practices. We aim to synthesize sulforaphane de novo in Saccharomyces cerevisiae and use computational and synthetic biology to enhance its yield. This approach will reduce costs, land waste, and deforestation, offering a sustainable alternative that supports global climate change efforts and improves human health.
PIs: Xiaolin Shen, Jia Wang, Yifei Zhang-BUCT, Zhengjun Li
advisors: Jihua Wei, Sharon Zou, Wenjun Xie, Yanyan Wang
students: Baili Wang, Bokai Xu, Fangxian Chen, Fanqi Jia, Han Cao, Jiahui Song, Junbin Li, Kunyi Chang, Li Liu, qinmu wang, Rodrigo Salvador Ventura Cruz, Rongjing Zhou, WanLian Chen, Xiaoye Liang, Xinru Yuan, Xintao Li, YANG CHUBING, Yicheng Zeng, zhangyifan, Ziang Cai, zihao li

title: Aflatoxin B1 Real-time Crasher
abstract: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) is a highly toxic and carcinogenic foodborne pollutant, which seriously threatens food safety and public health. In order to degrade AFB1 that may be generated during the transportation, storage and processing of food, feed and so on in real time, we take Lactobacillus rhamnosus as the chassis, and let the nano-fluorescence system that can specifically bind to AFB1 and the light-induced VVD photosensitive system work together to activate the expression of laccase (CodAGold) that degrades AFB1, so as to achieve real-time degradation of AFB1. In addition, MazF is under the control of a glucose sensitive promoter, to prevent the escape of engineered bacteria and ensure biosafety. This method is expected to provide a valuable strategy for agriculture, animal husbandry and food safety to realize real-time harmless treatment of AFB1.
students: Lanmeng Zhang, Li Mengxi, Man Su, Nuo Xu, peixin Li, qinyu wang, Ruiyu Wan, Shiyue Sun, Siying Chen, Songchen Mackville Ma, Sun Yiyang, Xingzhi Luo, xinyu zhang, Xutong MAN, Yuke Deng, zonghuan li

title: BYEbuprofen - for cleaner water
abstract: Pharmaceutical pollutants, particularly nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen, and diclofenac, and hormones such as estrogen, have been increasingly detected in aquatic ecosystems, where they threaten wildlife and disrupt ecological balance. Current wastewater treatment processes are often insufficient for removing these contaminants, leading to their accumulation in water bodies. The objective of this project is to develop an innovative solution using immobilized laccase, to degrade pharmaceutical pollutants in wastewater. Additionally, this project aims to lay the groundwork for the development of a biosensor to detect and monitor ibuprofen and diclofenac, providing a novel method for assessing water contaminations. The use of enzymatic degradation and improved pollutant detection represents a sustainable and cost-effective approach for the enhancement of wastewater treatment processes, thereby reducing the environmental impact of pharmaceutical contamination. This project supports the broader goal of enhancing water quality worldwide and preserving aquatic ecosystems.
students: Agata Wisniewska, Artea Gkyli, Bin Liang, David Dang, Dunja Dragojevic, Elias Gradischnig, Felix Weimar, Florian Hellmann, Franziska Fazekas, Jan Haschka, Julian Reicher, Katharina Pütz, Kesjan Hoxholli, Lara Biezunski, Lea Mautner Markhof, Lena Niederbacher, Lucia Ahcin, Manuela Forthuber, Mika Zugcic, Niki Menelaou, Nóra El-Khayyat, Romana Tepla, Sophia Mattitsch

title: Bright Ideas Come in Nanocompartments: Detecting Johne's disease with Split-luciferase Fused Encapsulins
abstract: Johne's disease is caused by Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP) and causes Crohn's disease-like symptoms in ruminants. MAP2121c is a novel Type 2A Encapsulin that readily forms multimeric cages to protect a cysteine desulfurase from environmental oxidative stress. Exploiting this cage formation, we fused encapsulin monomers to two parts of a split-luciferase to develop our bioluminescent test. Cage formation between the two luciferase-linked encapsulins allows the luciferase to form and upon the addition of the substrate, a bioluminescent signal would be observed, indicating a negative result for Johne's disease. The introduction of wild-type encapsulin from an infected bovine blood sample would disrupt split-luciferase binding and reduce the bioluminescence, yielding a positive test result for Johne's disease. Our light detection kit is intended to be used to detect the bioluminescence on-site, with potential for farmers to use in the future.
advisors: Jovarn Sullivan, Peter Prendergast
students: Amy Dellow, Bree Drinkwater, Isabel Bradley, Maddie Barrett, Matthew Goodwin, Myles Landon, William Oakley

title: PullulanElite, a synthetic platform for high-molecular-weight pullulan production
abstract: Aureobosidium melonogenum Pl6 is on unconventionol yeost. In ourexperiment, we adopted o method to increose the moleculor weight ofpullulon produced by Aureobosidium melonogenum Pi6 ond further improvethe yield. We look forword to our production method ond engineering yeostshining in the future production of pullulon, providing higher quality pullulonfor the public and society. In oddition, we hove developed on engineeringyeost screening mechonism bosed on phosphofructokinose deficiencywhich greotly mointoins screening pressure, reduces contominotion ofontibiotics ond ontibiotic resistonce genes torgeting eukoryotes, ond sovescosts. Besides,ofter onolysis, this screening mechonism con be opplied todifferent fungol microbiol engineering, especiolly in yeost, ond hos broodopplicotion prospects, It also provides useful ideos for the subsequent iGEM team.
