title: iEraser--Erase the Pain of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
abstract: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic intestinal disease, known for its complex pathogenesis. Currently, it remains incurable and has a high prevalence worldwide, affecting an estimated 8 million individuals.We are an iGEM team from China, and we are committed to synthesizing E. coli with gene expression vectors, recombinant with selected inflammatory priming factors, adhesion factors, and anti-inflammatory factors for the treatment of IBD. Hope we can use the knowledge of synthetic biology to find a way out for IBD patients.
students: Fangxi Lin, Hongbo Zhang, junru chen, Li Siyao, Sirui Fu, Xiaochen Kuang, Xinrui Li, Xuanwei Huang, Yibin Chen, Yuhang Dong, YuLu Ma, Zaichun Zhang, ziting Zhu

title: DetectiMOL - a Continuous Cortisol Monitoring Patch
abstract: Cortisol is a hormone involved in immune response, regulating the body, and stress response. Continuous cortisol measurements can give important insights to imbalances in this hormone signalling, for example in Addison's disease or stress. While many approaches are being investigated, no final continuous wearable cortisol measuring device is publicly available yet. In this project a molecular mechanism around the use of the glucocorticoid receptor that binds cortisol specifically is being developed. In the future the basic molecular mechanism for cortisol ligand binding measurements could be done by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Here the receptor is attached to a gold electrode and changes conformation upon ligand binding, which changes the resistivity of the electrode and therefore electric signal. This concept is then implemented into a small wearable device that resembles a glucose monitoring device worn by diabetes patients to go with a publicly already established design.
PIs: Dirk Linke, Athanasios Saragliadis, Kirsten Borse Haraldsen
students: Bror Johannes Tidemand Ruud, Espen Opseth, Marianna Khodabandehlou, Marlene Elisabeth Metz, Michelle Vera Castellanos, Sigurd Graarud, Sigve

title: Bevatech: Rapid Anti-Counterfeiting Aptamer-based Lateral Flow Device for Detecting Bevacizumab
abstract: Drug counterfeiting has been a significant global threat in recent decades, accounting for over 6000 counterfeit cases in 2021. This issue poses a critical threat to cancer patients in vulnerable regions, including war regions and developing countries that do not have sufficient facilities for testing. In previous years, The U.S. The Food and Drug Administration identified more than 19 medical facilities distributing Bevacizumab, a vital cancer drug that explicitly targets Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF). To tackle this problem, our team designed an aptamer-based lateral flow test strip that provides a rapid, affordable, and sensitive point-of-care device that can be distributed globally and operated without specialized expertise. We optimized a DNA aptamer sensor that sensitively binds to Bevacizumab active ingredients and immobilized it onto the LFA membrane. Through this innovation, potential improvement in patient treatment quality assurance can be achieved, ensuring access to genuine cancer treatment for all.
nominations: Best Therapeutics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad
advisors: Abdul Raffay, Danis, Ho-Jung CHOE
student leaders: Bermet Abylova, Jocelyn Madolen, Maryana Yarshova, Yi LU
students: Darrell Hartanto, Gayeon Choi, Jiyeun Kim, Julia Ying, Kenneth, Lee Huijong, Polina Chernova, Valensia Nadya Anthony

title: Bacillus Gemini: Plant Guard and Nematode Buster
abstract: Nematode infestations are among the most destructive pathogens in agriculture. According to estimates by FAO of the United Nations, global losses in food and fiber crops due to nematode damage amount to approximately 12.3% annually. We have engineered Bacillus velezensis and Bacillus subtilis as chassis organisms based on their own characteristics. These bacteria work in concert to enhance plant immunity and exert nematocidal effects. Using Bacillus subtilis, we employ virus-like particles conjugated with immune-activating proteins through spontaneous covalent coupling. They can widely distribute from the plant's roots to the phyllosphere, serving to activate the plant's own immune response induction. Bacillus velezensis can detect changes in the level of phytohormones (salicylic acid) produced by plants in response to nematode damage. Upon sensing the signaling stimulation, the engineered bacteria are capable of producing antinematodal proteins, trans-aconitic acid, and antisense RNAs targeting important genes in nematode's life cycle, attacking nematodes from multiple aspects.
advisors: ZhaoHong Liu
students: Beier Tu, Chuyi Tu, haiqisun, Haozhen Liu, Liuyi Wang, Lize Chen, Muyang Li, shanshanguo, Shiyu Wang, Shunyao Zeng, Tao Chen, wangruijia, Wentao Yang, Xi Chen, Xincong Sun, Xinyi Geng, Yuqian Yang, Yuxiang Wang, Yuyue Ying, Zekun Luo

title: Surface Display of Tumor Targeting Proteins on Engineered Bacteria for Fighting Triple Negative Breast Cancer
abstract: This project is aimed to display tumor-targeting SIRP? on surfaces of E coli that has an inner membrane and an outer membrane separated by the periplasm. The transport unit of an outer membrane autotransporter called adhesin involved in diffuse adherence-I (AIDA-I) is chosen as the carrier for SIRP?, which facilitates the export across the cell envelope and anchor onto the bacterial cell surface with proper surface exposure. A short peptide GGGGS is designed as a flexible linker between gene-encoding sequences, including the signal peptide of cholera toxin B subunit that has high binding affinity with raft-associated ganglioside as well as a His tag for the verification of protein expression with immunofluorescence. A mathematic model has been developed for the elucidation of dynamic proteomic changes. Integrated human practice has been conducted. A wearable thermal ablation and portable diagnostic device has been established for early treatment and diagnosis.
PIs: Hongying Zhong, Mingfeng Hu, Qisong Zhang
instructors: Xiaoyuan Hu, Xingchen Huang, Xin Zhou
advisors: Brian DeDecker, Jianmin Wu, Mingyang Gong, Mingyue zhang, Tianci Huo, Xinyu Jiang, Xue Feng, Zhuolin Zhang
student leaders: Bo Zhang, Haorui Mi, Huiyao Zhang, Luping Zhu, Miaomiao Feng, Ruoyang Jiang, Yuqi Liu
students: Honglin Lai, Huiqi Chen, Jiangtao Li, Jingke Lu, Jinyang Li, Kehui Xu, Keyi Li, Liangzheng Jiang, Linlin Guo, Ning Wang, Qiang Zhao, Rui Liu, Xiang Liao, Xiaoying Liang, Xiaoyuan Zeng, Xia Ye, Yanrui Gu, Yanyan Lu, Yixuan Zhan, Yujia Shan, Zhiyong Qiu, Zhiyun Wei, Zihang Zhang

title: Using thermostable and active Fast PETase enzyme to degrade PET plastics in simulated marine environment
abstract: Due to the influx of microplastic pollution in water systems, the abundance of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastics in the oceans causes issues for both marine and terrestrial life. The enzymes, PETase and MHETase, found in the bacterium Ideonella sakaiensis, have shown degradation of PET plastics. However, because I. sakaiensis is found mainly in soil, it is not an ideal host when attempting to degrade PET plastics in the ocean. By introducing Fast PETase (a more thermostable and active form of PETase) and MHETase into Alteromonas macleodii, a marine bacterium, there is the possibility of degradation of PET in saltwater conditions. Using the Loop Assembly method, plasmids were constructed with FastPETase and MHETase into E. coli, and conjugated into A. macleodii. Ongoing experiments comparing Fast PETase and PETase will demonstrate the possibility for a more efficient plastic degradation reaction, with degradation measured through concentration of hydroxyl groups in FTIR Analysis.
students: Aanya Panchal, Aiden Itakura, Anika Bose, Anna Kim, Anna Ly, Anne Xie, Brandon Crowell, Camila Soto, Chakri, Derek Lam, Elijah Anil, Felix Zhang, Jaelyn, Jay Yasuda, Kaden Chang, Kayla Ong, Kevin Chapman, Leo Meng, Ngoc An Tho Tran, Pranaya Anand, Saya Schmitigal, Shayna Mehta, Shravya Bharathwaj, Suhani, Thomas Tong, Tina Tian, Zeren

title: A Gene Editing Therapy of Hepatitis B Based on High-precision CRISPR Nuclease
abstract: Viral hepatitis B is a common infectious disease affecting the world, the cause of which is hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection and induced autoimmune reaction. HBV cannot be eradicated with traditional chemical treatments, but it is possible with the safety-enhancing CRISPR-Cas gene editing tool. Aiming at curing hepatitis B with CRISPR-Cas gene editing technology, our project mainly carried out the following work: (1) On-target, off-target and gRNA were designed according to HBsAg gene. A high-throughput screening system consisting of three plasmids was constructed by optimized sacB and other screening genes. (2) A library of MAD7 mutants was constructed by zero-shot mutational effect prediction and error-prone PCR. A high-precision and high-activity MAD7 nuclease mutant (HF-MAD7) was screened out by high-throughput screening. Compared to MAD7(WT), the off-target rate is reduced by 96.80% and the editing activity is 59.51%. The project provides a reliable gene editing therapy for viral hepatitis B.
PIs: Jun Yang, Lihan Zi, Rongming Liu
instructors: Hui Wu, Liya Liang, Steven, Yaming Cao
advisors: Haonan Zhang, Tianxiang Yang
students: Aiqi Liu, Ge Bai, Guangning Liu, Jiarui Zhang, Quandi Liu, Tianyi Guo, Xutao Che, yiman liu, Yixuan Lai, zefei wu, Zhang Xinru, Other, Zhang huamei

title: InfinityF? - an intranasal mRNA delivery system for Factor VIII using ionizable lipid nanoparticles
abstract: InfinityF? delivers the mRNA sequence for factor VIII encapsulated by a lipid nanoparticle that serves as a carrier for the medicine. When the nanoparticle reaches its target in the body, the cells will take it up into an endosome and break the LNP preserving the genetic sequence inside. After that, the cell produces the protein factor VIII from the mRNA and releases it into the blood. The factor VIII mRNA is produced with in vitro transcription using factor VIII pcDNA as a template. Our ionizable lipid nanoparticles contain synthetic lipids as well as an ionizable lipid, which is essential for the release of the mRNA in the cells.
advisors: Tom Bloemberg
students: Adrian Belichenov, Henriete Kere, Lea Omtzigt, Maksym Haniev, Thijmen Isken, Timofej Paramonov Bliki, Vasileios Krassas

title: Mechanism of creation and application of prokaryotic polyploid minimal chassis cells
abstract: In this study, we designed a novel prokaryotic polyploid minimal chassis system capable of stably maintaining both engineered and wild-type chromosomes. Morphological analysis revealed increased length, volume, and surface area in polyploid E. coli, with intracellular enrichment of metabolites like phenylalanine. This system showed enhanced stress resilience under high temperatures and varying pH levels, suggesting potential for evolutionary adaptation. Additionally, the chassis demonstrated improved carbon and protein metabolism, enhancing production of heterologous proteins such as GFP and poly-?-hydroxybutyrate PHB, with output exceeding that of streamlined and wild-type strains. We also developed a genome-scale metabolic network model for DGF-298 and its polyploid counterpart, integrating transcriptomic data to refine growth rates and biomass yield. Multi-objective optimizations within the metabolic model, combined with a deep learning-aided environmental model, enabled real-time PHB production predictions in fermenters via multi-sensor arrays.
advisors: FangYaning, Hannuo Shen, Wendi Xu, Xin Jin, Xuanmu Chen, Yanbing Wang, Yaping Gao, Yutong Wang
students: Fangkun Zeng, Jingchen Li, Lina Wang, Linjie Xu, Lirui Zhao, Longao Yang, Xi Zhang, Xuanshuo Liang, Yandong Yang, Yifan Zhu, Zhaoyi Chen

title: Platelet-based Therapeutic to Recognize and Degrade Circulating Tumor Cell (CTC) Clusters
abstract: The 2024 MIT iGEM team focused on developing a therapeutic to target and degrade CTC clusters to reduce metastatic potential in cancer patients. The team's innovative solution involves engineering platelets to recognize and bind to both CTCs and neutrophils. Once both binding events occur, the engineered platelets release cytotoxic signals to degrade the CTC clusters, thereby aiming to reduce metastasis. We conducted multiple proof-of-concept experiments testing the Syn-Notch and CC-GEMS systems using HEK293 cells as a model and documented our parts collection of robustly tested Syn-Notch systems in the iGEM Registry. In addition, our team established frameworks for both diffusion gradient modeling and background architecture for computational fluid modeling. As part of our human practice, we compiled a Genomic Privacy Handbook and collaborated with physicians and medical researchers to offer scientific and bioethical frameworks for both present and future iGEM teams.
advisors: Josh Abramson, Matthew Feng
students: Andrew, Emily Hu, Sora Shirai, Sruthi, Winnie Zhou

title: IMPROViSeD : Integrated Modelling of Protein Complexes Via Single-shot registration using DREAM
abstract: The exploration of protein-protein interactions and their implications in cellular functions is pivotal for the development of effective therapeutic strategies. This project introduces IMPROVISeD, an advanced platform designed for the modeling of protein complexes. We create models in one shot by directly incorporating geometric constraints from extracted experimental data to orientate the structure of the subunits (proteins) forming the complex. The approach uses significantly less time compared to contemporary algorithms that employ sampling-based approaches. The approach was tested for both synthetically - and experimentally-derived constraint data. The method is permissive to missing and ambiguous constraint data. The underlying nonlinear optimization formulations, including one-shot registration, make IMPROViSeD's approach computationally efficient, robust, and scalable. The availability of modelled complexes provides key insights into the structure, function, and interactions of subunits and establishes a solid framework for designing targeted therapies. The tool can also be leveraged for modelling heterogeneous macromolecular complexes.
students: Aditya Arsh, Akshita, Anirudh Gupta, Ayush Raina, Balaji, Kuldeep Jatav, Mrigank Pawagi, Naveen Maurya, Rahul Chavan, Saksham Maitri, Susmit Roy, Trishna Kodamasingh, Yash Kamble

title: P-CASE
abstract: P-CASE is an innovative multiplex biosensor designed for the detection of pancreatic cancer using Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) technology. It integrates three detection chambers, each targeting a specific biomarker: CA19-9, Glypican-1 (GPC1) mRNA, and miR-206. The first chamber utilizes a DNA aptamer to bind CA19-9, the second employs a CRISPR-dCas13a system for GPC1 mRNA, and the third features a complementary ssDNA probe for miR-206 with a poly-A tail for enhanced sensor surface stability. This configuration enables simultaneous, real-time monitoring of these biomarkers, improving sensitivity and specificity for accurate diagnosis. P-CASE offers a novel approach for early pancreatic cancer detection and monitoring through a combination of synthetic biology and advanced diagnostic technologies.
advisors: Carlos Contreras-Paredes, Ricardo Enrique Buendia Corona
student leaders: Jordan Escobar, Melisa Arreola Cordova, Sagrario Linares Melo, Victor Hugo Flores Rojas, Víctor Manuel Gaspar Martínez
students: Anahi Najera, Fernando Iván Ramírez Luna, Jazmin Melendez Yahuitl, Jorge Belchez, Jose Pena, Meli Prieto, Susana Valencia León, Ximena Romero Toxqui, Xquenda Rios, Yahel Ramírez, Zoe Zenteno

title: Smart Algicidal Bacteria to Control Water Blooms
abstract: Eutrophication of water bodies can lead to cyanobacterial blooms, which cause serious harm to water ecosystems and the safety of drinking water. Algicidal bacteria (e.g., Bacillus subtilis) is a kind of bacteria that can directly or indirectly kill algal cells or inhibit their growth. Although algicidal bacteria can inhibit the growth of cyanobacteria and solve the problem of water blooms, the overgrowth and proliferation of any kind of microorganisms may hurt the natural environment. This project aims to develop and design a controllable ‘smart algicide bacteria' that can inhibit the spread of bloom and also regulate the growth of algicide bacteria to prevent secondary pollution to the environment. We hope to provide an efficient and safe solution to the cyanobacterial problem and demonstrate the potential of synthetic biology applications in environmental governance, opening up new possibilities for future ecological protection and resource management.
nominations: Best New Improved Part, High School
advisors: YAN ZIYU, YUXIN GONG
student leaders: DU ER, JIN ZIYUE, SHI LU, TSANG SHAM KI
students: CHENG QIAN, CHEN ZHIXUAN, CHEN ZHIZHONG, GAO XUANHAO, JIANG XINGLE, LIU ZHONGZHENG, WANG XIAOYUE, WANG ZIFAN, XU RUOYUN, YAO QINXIAN, YIHENG HE, YU XINNUO, ZHONG LANG, ZHOU QIANYU

title: Gassle
abstract: We have devised Gassle, an E. coli that detects nitric oxide (NO), which is produced in large quantities during inflammation. This research explores the possibility of diagnosing Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) through characteristic fart odors. Early immunosuppressive therapy has been shown to improve response to treatment and reduce adverse outcomes. This is because it leads to mucosal healing, reduced hospitalizations and surgeries, and improved quality of life. Our Project has three main components. First, development of E. coli that detects elevated nitric oxide concentrations during inflammation and produces propionic acid. Second, control of E. coli proliferation using Herpes Simplex Virus Thymidine Kinase/Ganciclovir system(HSV-TK/GCV) system. Third, development of a capsule to deliver E. coli to the colon.
students: Daichi Tabaru, Keita Namba, Mika Natori, Nanako Goto, Nao Morita, Ryoma Tanaka, Shiryu Yazawa, Shona Takayama, Shougo Oone, Shusuke iwata, SIYI WANG, Souta Nakagawa, Tatsuya Nakamura, Tomoharu Sakata, Tomoki Gouda, Yukihiro Ono, Yuri Takeuchi, Yushin Ogawa, Yuzhe Chen

title: Rational Construction of Saccharomyces Cerevisiae Strain for Utilization of Xylose
abstract: Fuel ethanol, with its high octane number and clean combustion, is a promising biofuel alternative to petrochemical energy. A sustainable approach involves cellulosic ethanol production from lignocellulosic biomass, known for its tough texture and complex structure. After pretreatment, it releases both glucose and xylose, but wild-type Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a key strain for ethanol production, cannot naturally utilize xylose. Enhancing its ability to metabolize xylose requires introducing metabolic pathways for xylose isomerization, often achieved through laboratory adaptive evolution, which can be time-consuming and may lead to unstable strain phenotypes. This study aimed to overcome these limitations by reconstructing the xylose utilization pathway in S. cerevisiae. We identified the NFS1I492N gene mutation and integrated the multi-copy xylA gene, which encodes xylose isomerase, to enable efficient xylose metabolism. This approach seeks to develop more robust S. cerevisiae strains capable of efficiently converting xylose into ethanol, contributing to more sustainable biofuel production.
students: Aimi Ma, Jinhe Xu, Ronnie, ruiyang wang, Shiruo Huang, tang, Tsz Ching Lam, Yingxuan Li, Zhaorun Hu

title: CarvengerX?Novel exosomal tumor therapy using bidirectional calcium overload platform built with synthetic biology
abstract: UM_Macau utilized synthetic biology to construct a controlled calcium overload system for killing cancer cells. We selected the MscS and hTPRC1 ion channels, which are sensitive to ultrasound, as the target proteins and introduced their gene sequences into different plasmids to express these ion channel proteins on the chassis cell HEK293. After successfully expressing the channel proteins, we used the lamp2b protein to package the them, also synthesized using synthetic biology, into vesicles (EVs) using exocytosis. We then allowed the vesicles to fuse with the target cell. Finally, we induced the calcium ion channels on the cancer cell membrane and the endoplasmic reticulum calcium release channel (RyR) in the cancer cells to open under the combined action of ultrasound and hNOS2, significantly increasing the intracellular calcium influx and releasing the calcium the endoplasmic reticulum. This triggered calcium overload in cancer cells, leading to cell death and achieving an anti-cancer effect.
advisors: Xiuyi Wu
student leaders: Daoming MA, SONGHAN YANG, Tang Yuan, Walter Jin, WEI NING, WONG SI IEONG
students: CHAN CHON MAN, CHEN SIYU, Emma JIANG, Fung Shing Tsz, Gigi, James Tiemsin, Jiawen Sun, Joyce H, Luna, Mendy, Rachel, SEK IO LAM, Sicheng Zhou, TIANZUO YUAN, Tilly, Wang ziguan, WONG CHI I, Xiao Yixuan, Zhang Yiyin?Kelsey, Zoe, ???

title: PalettEmo
abstract: PalettEmo is composed of "Palette" and "Emotion", aiming to combine AI emotion weighting algorithm and synthetic biology art. We innovatively constructed Quorum sensing with Fluorescence Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET), which can achieve quantitative control to produce mixed fragrance automatically. As for model, we not only successfully constructed a Facial Expression Recognition model with an accuracy rate of up to 92%, achieving new state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance and surpassing the previous best models, but also integrated model and Wet Lab closely to assist in selecting FRET linkers. Starting from the mechanisms of FRET and visual perception, we created a theoretical attraction method for scent molecules and emotion, and explored the biological processes behind color recognition and emotional changes. We delve into society to receive feedback and spread education to the world, building PalettEmo influence and promoting global welfare.
PIs: Zhicheng Wang, Yonggang Zhang, Fangming Gu, Bo Yang
instructors: Huan He, Minghui Sun, Yannan Shen, Yunyun Cheng
advisors: Qi Tingting
students: Haobo Lin, Haotian Zhang, Jinping Yin, Jiyu Zhang, Kaixin Wu, Peilin Liu, ShuYu Zhong, WangDongyang, Xinyu Liu, Yueran Cui, Zhao Bingzhuo, Zitian Fan

title: Metabolic engineering and synthetic biology ?approaches for L-DOPA ?production in Nicotiana benthamiana? using BaMV-based vector
abstract: Our project explores innovative approaches to produce and test L-DOPA, a critical drug for Parkinson's disease treatment, using plant-based methods. In the first experiment, total RNA was extracted from beet. Then the BvAD6 and BvADH genes were cloned into plasmid vectors, and introduced into Agrobacterium tumefaciens. These transformed bacteria were then used to infiltrate Nicotiana benthamiana. The infiltrated leaves were analyzed to assess L-DOPA content using HPLC. Building on this, the second experiment tested the efficacy of the L-DOPA in treating Parkinson-like symptoms in zebrafish embryos. L-DOPA was obtained from tobacco overexpressing L-DOPA, as well as from industrial synthesis. The study aimed to validate the potential of transgenic plants to produce sufficient quantities of L-DOPA and to assess and to evaluate whether plant-derived neurodegenerative drugs are more effective than industrially synthesized drugs in alleviating symptoms of related diseases.
PIs: YU-FAN LIU, Ting-Hsuan Wu, YingWen Huang
students: Ai-Ning Tsao, CAN-LING JIANG, Jhuo Wang, Jou-Hsi Lai, Lai Hiu Tung, Mino Wu, Zhilin Lan, ???, ???

title: ReguROS
abstract: Our project focuses on developing a versatile platform for early detection and treatment of diseases by targeting reactive oxygen species (ROS). Elevated ROS levels are a common indicator in both plant and human diseases. The platform aims to engineer probiotic E. coli Nissle 1917 and the yeast S. cerevisiae to detect high ROS levels and produce therapeutic agents or visible signals. by implementing high-pass filter behavior in promoters bound by the transcription factors OxyR, Yap1 and TGA2. This innovation seeks to improve disease management and outcomes in agriculture and medicine, addressing case study problems of fireblight in plants and chronic inflammation in humans.
advisors: Tsvetan K
students: Camille Membrez, Elias Nehring, Tim Andermann, Tim Lennart Appel

title: SepScan: a rapid, quantitative, point-of-care-test for Sepsis and acute kidney injury
abstract: Sepsis contributes up to 11 million preventable deaths annually. The burden of disease is particularly concentrated in India, where advances in rapid-diagnostics is a neglected path to improving health outcomes. Recognising this, the UCL iGEM team developed asepsis scanning tool (SepScan). SepScan is a point-of care-test (POCT) to provide a quantitative read out of biomarker concentration for distribution in low and middle income countries. By using nanobody-nanoluciferase fusion proteins, we offer a new modality for lateral flow that can be adapted to suit other biomarkers, with further potential applications in pandemic preparedness. With a particular emphasis on sepsis and acute kidney injury in India, SepScan aims to provide a rapid readout of urinary cystatin c. By aiming to increase the information capital of clinicians in resource constrained environments, this can be used to aid healthcare or community workers with triaging, managing risk, and ultimately saving preventable deaths in underserved communities.
PIs: Stefanie Frank, Chris P Barnes, Jack Jeffries, Rana Khalife
advisors: Ferdinando Sereno, Gregorio Queiroz, Vladimir Kalinovskiy
students: Ayushmaan Sharma, Can Ding, Eshaan Saigal, Hannah Deol, Jacob Breuer-Weil, Mirriam Baranova-Gurvich, Yiming Sun, Yunning Yuan

title: Logical Gate-Based Synergistic Toxicity Detection System
abstract: Environmental endocrine disruptors (EDCs) are chemicals that can mimic or interfere with natural hormones, primarily affecting organisms through endocrine disruption by interacting with hormone receptors. However, studies suggest they may also induce oxidative stress and other effects, causing more profound impacts. Traditional detection only monitors single endocrine disruption effects, neglecting the combined toxicological effects within organisms. We aim to assess these complex effects using a microbial sensor based on multiple logic gates. We've developed a hormone-sensitive intein to detect endocrine disruption and used the recA element from the SOS response to identify oxidative damage. An AND gate detection circuit with HRP regulation network enables the simultaneous detection of both effects. Additionally, we've designed a high-throughput, automated, portable fluorescence detection platform for our biosensor. Our project helps identify EDCs and monitor their oxidative damage effects, which is crucial for a comprehensive assessment of their potential impacts on organisms.
advisors: JIANG HAO, Li Anyi, Qian, wang kun, Zihan Yan
student leaders: Baoqi Fang, LEE KUAN LUNG, Shuai Fan, Wang Jianing
students: Chuan Jin, Jingbang Sun, Junjie Wen, Lingyue Zhang, li tian, Peng Gao, Qiheng Wang, Selina Lee, Tong Cai, Xiaohang Zhu, xichang Lee, Xinbo Zhou, Xingyu Peng, YAOYX, Yongyu Huo, Yuan Cui, Zhuohan Li, Zulpikar Wupur

title: NOVA by Agrinova: Microbial SOILutions for Precision Agriculture
abstract: NOVA is an innovative device that combines hardware and synthetic biology to enable real-time detection of heavy metal contamination, specifically cadmium and manganese, in agricultural settings. Engineered E. coli plasmids with metal-sensitive promoters trigger the expression of fluorescent reporter genes upon detecting these metals. This fluorescence allows NOVA to generate measurable signals corresponding to the concentrations of cadmium and manganese. Designed as a versatile, cost-effective fluorometer, NOVA is accessible to a wide range of users, including student researchers and small-scale farmers. By integrating microfluidics and sensitive optical sensors, the device offers an efficient, user-friendly way to detect fluorescence. Its stepper motor enables multiple parallel tests, improving efficiency while maintaining accuracy. NOVA's affordability and scalability make it a valuable tool for real-time heavy metal detection and broader environmental monitoring, offering a practical, low-cost solution for research and educational purposes.
advisors: Juan Jose Robayo Yepes, Kristen Sheldon, Yangruirui Zhou, Yazmin Camacho
students: Abby Smith, Brenda Kim, Kevin Li, Meritxell Ortodo, Trinity Olander

title: Pandage - An intelligent approach to infection disease control on skin wound healing with probiotics
abstract: Bacterial skin wound infections are a global health issue, in addition to the overuse of antibiotics has led to antimicrobial resistance (AMR), causing significant global mortality, with infections in hospitals and military settings being particularly severe. Traditional wound management has been a "reactive" process, and often results in slower recovery or even serious medical complications. Here, we have developed Pandage, designed for individualized wound infection control and healing. Pandage integrates monitoring, automatic drug delivery, and wound healing promotion. We used engineered probiotics (Lactococcus lactis) to secrete growth factors (GM-CSF) to promote wound healing.To assess wound condition, we utilize anti-LPS aptamer biosensors to detect harmful bacteria, releasing antimicrobial peptide (AMP) after the Pandage Intelligent Treatment Modeling. In addition, Pandage is also equipped with Bluetooth module to enable mobile health (mHealth) operation. We hope Pandage can tailor treatment to each patient's specific wound condition for optimizing wound care managemen
advisors: An-Jie, Liu, Chih-Cheng Hsu, Jhih-Kai Yeh, Ji-Ting Jang, Kuang-Yi, Shih, Lo-Chueh, Chu, [LUO] [YI-WUN], Pei-chi Huang, Pei-Yun, Hsieh, Ping-yu Yang, TSUNG-YU, CHEN, Tzu-Wei Wang, YIN-WEN YEN, Yu Yen Huang
students: Chia-chien Tsai, CHIWEI LIN, CHUN-HUNG CHENG, HsuanYu Ma, LI YU LIN, Pin Che Huang, Samuel Zheng, Ting-Wei Lin, TING-YI CHEN, Yan Shiu Lin, Yi Chen Shen, YiHsun Huang, Zih Chen Ciou

title: Tumor-Targeting Salmonella-Mediated Apoptosis Therapy (T-SAT)
abstract: Westlake team has developed a novel cancer therapy, Tumor-Targeting Salmonella-Mediated Apoptosis Therapy, utilizing an attenuated strain of Salmonella (VNP20009) to deliver a targeted therapeutic system. This strain is engineered with a surface-displayed single-chain variable fragment (scFv) to recognize cancer-specific antigens, enhancing its invasion efficacy. Upon internalization, a bacterial auto-lysis circuit is activated, releasing plasmids that form a cancer-specific killing system. This system includes an effector gene for inducing apoptosis and a bio-switch to regulate effector gene expression based on intracellular signals. To optimize the therapy, a mathematical model was developed to simulate the diffusion, growth, and bactericidal effects of the engineered Salmonella within the tumor microenvironment. The model provides insights into optimal dosing and timing, aiming to maximize therapeutic efficacy. This approach holds promise for treating cancers with limited treatment options, such as liver and metastatic breast cancer.
students: Carson Campbell, Chenlu XUE, Fan YANG, Jiawei ZHOU, Jiayan Wang, Junbo QIAN, Kun Zhao, Shiye DU, Weiyan CHENG, Xinlin Wang, Yishan ZHOU, Yuhao WANG, Zebang WU

title: CalciCapture
abstract: Developing synthetic biology based carbon capture solutions using marine coccolithophore Emiliania Huxleyi. Our project aims to enhance the process of calcification in E. huxleyi to increase its carbon capture capacity. Through computational modelling, we have identified key cellular and environmental factors that promote calcification.
nominations: Best Climate Crisis Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Saket Choudhary, Kiran Kondabagil, Arnab Dutta
advisors: Ajay Kumar, Kirti
students: Aakash Gupta, Aditya Shrungarpure, Anuj Waje, Arushi, Ashish Avinash Zantye, Diksha, Hitesh Meena, Ishita Gurjar, Kadambari Bhide, Navya, Pranav Prakash, Prashast Chitravanshi, Ramandeep Singh, Shahab, Vexahm, Yash, Other, Maya

title: New Tagatose-4-epimerase with high conversion rate through gene mining and protein engineering
abstract: D-Tagatose, a functional sugar, holds promise as a therapeutic agent for type II diabetes. However, the current fructose-catalyzed production of tagatose faces challenges, including limited enzyme sources and low conversion rates. In this project, gene mining was utilized to identify sequences with potential tagatose-4-epimerase activity, resulting in an increased tagatose yield of 24 g/(L·h) and a conversion rate of 37% through iterative mutation. The enzymatic properties of the most effective mutants were subsequently analyzed. Additionally, this project tackled the issue of inclusion bodies arising from the expression of the new enzyme by employing molecular chaperones, pro-fusion labeling, and fermentation optimization. The new enzyme and the best mutant components developed in this project can be utilized by future iGEM teams.
PIs: Ling Jiang, Liying Zhu, Wei Liu, Yang Sun, Zhi Zhou
advisors: chenyao, Gongrui Meng, Jiaqi Ji, Li Yang, mengyu Li, rui long, zhangjie
student leaders: Lin Li, Yufan Zhou, Zeyu Yan
students: Chenxi Lu, Heyu Liu, Jiaqi Zhang, Keying Wu, QianSui Gu, Yan Xu Jie, yi Cao, ying zhang, YONGYE WU, Yuan Fang, Yue Dai, YuHao Sun, yuting Lu, ???, ???

title: Prometheus: Large Language Model for Synthetic Biology
abstract: Over the past fifty years, synthetic biology has achieved significant advancements, with last year marking the 20th anniversary of iGEM. Despite these accomplishments, the complexity of components and disorganized knowledge structures have hindered its full potential. As we enter iGEM's new decade, NJU-China's 2024 goal is to unlock synthetic biology's potential using new tools. We utilized a knowledge graph as the foundational database architecture and leveraged a large language model to facilitate processes such as raw data cleaning, database retrieval, and natural language dialogue with users. We developed Prometheus, a professional-grade, novice-friendly synthetic biology language model. Prometheus helps users retrieve components, construct plasmids, and guide experimental design, thus promoting synthetic biology. After completing the development of Prometheus, we successfully promoted the model among a wide audience through extensive Human Practice activities, unleashing the fire of synthetic biology.
PIs: Chen Xi, Jing Shi, Zhen Zhou
advisors: Qi Zeng, Xiaoyu Hou, Yijie Chen
student leaders: Gui Yang, he feng, Shiyuan Chen, Xinjie Shen
students: Anchang Jin, Deting Tang, Jerry Sun, Mingyue DENG, Yifan Miao, Yourong Shi, Zecheng Guan, Zhen Tang, Zhuxi Wang, Zien Cheng, Zixuan Zhao, ???

title: Tumor-Specific Gene Nanoparticles
abstract: Two signals are required to induce T cell activation and proliferation: binding of CD3 to the TCR to form the TCR-CD3 complex to deliver the first activation signal and the second signal generated by synergistic co-stimulatory molecules, mainly CD86. We designed a tumor-specific gene nanomedicine such that it expresses only anti-CD3 scFv (?CD3, CD3 activator) and anti-CD86 scfv (?CD86, CD86 activator) on the surface of tumor cells while mobilizing the tumor cells to secrete IL-2, a cytokine for T-cell proliferation and survival, in order to activate the T-cells and to enhance the immunotherapy effect. This study provides a strategy to maximize immunotherapy efficacy independent of tumor heterogeneity.
PIs: Xiaoling Fu, Kunyu Zhang, Cong-Fei Xu
student leaders: Xu wenqi, Yifei Wu, Ziqian Bai
students: Chenrui Zhang, Chunyu Ji, Guangyue Li, Hanyu Yu, Haojun Liang, Minzi Guan, Ruiting Lee, Rui Xiang, Yan Jiang, Yuhan Jiang, Yu Jinghe, Zhiyuan Lian, Zhong Zihao, Zhou zixuan

title: Addressing Cutibacterium acnes acne by genetically altering E. coli to secrete PFK1 acting on biofilm
abstract: Acne is the most common skin condition in the US. Recent research provides significant insight into the mechanisms Cutibacterium acnes to developing acne, including the ability of C. acnes to form a biofilm. The biofilm matrix of C. Acnes is composed of 62.6% polysaccharides, 9.6% proteins, 4.0% DNA, and 23.8% other compounds. By manipulating the innate carbohydrate degradation of C. acnes, the degradation of the extracellular matrix can hypothetically be promoted. This study evaluated modified E. coli strain .By using a plasmid which will be engineered to synthesize and secrete PFK1 (catalyst of glycolysis) that can degrade polysaccharide found in C acne. Since the biofilm is rich in carbohydrates, increasing the glycolytic activity of E. coli by inserting a catalyst will allow for degradation of the biofilm. In the future, we aim to utilize a hydrogel or enzymatic transporter to administer this catalyst to C. acnes.
students: Aashni Katari, Isha Malli, Rohan Bojja, Saanvi Agarwal, Soumini Kandula, Tarun Tata, Tejas Manoj

title: Toward the COSMIC Dream: Space ‘Tai Chi'
abstract: Humans have a growing desire for space exploration. For astronauts, there are still some tricky problems, such as circadian rhythm disorder and circulatory disorder. iGEM Tianjin 2024 created ‘Space Tai Chi'?which was inspired by Chinese traditional culture. We constructed two plasmids and transformed them into one yeast, aiming at providing melatonin and crocetin for astronauts. We designed a blue light-galactose dual-factor orthogonal system to regulate the synthesis process. On the one hand, melatonin synthesis is controlled by optogenetics. Utilize blue light to induce photosensitive protein to activate the enhancer, thereby promoting the expression of melatonin synthesis gene. On the other hand, when exogenous galactose is added?it will induce the expression of crocetin synthsis gene. We also constructed fusion proteins through EBD to reduce leakage in the system. In the future, life support system based on synbiomanufacturing will escort human exploration of the cosmic world?
PIs: Yi Wu, Mingzhu Ding, Yingxiu Cao
instructors: Bingyu Tang, Bingzhi Li, wangnan, Wenhai Xiao
students: Boxue Li, Chunhao Wang, Fengyuan Liu, Gao Ruiqi, Hang Chi, Hongxuan Li, Jiancheng Liu, Joshua Tang, Lang Jingran, LiuMiaomiao, LiXiang, Mingxiao Shangguan, WenRenkui, Wu Zhengjin, Yishan Yue, Yi Sun, Yukun Zhang, Zhao Shiqi, Zhenzhen Zhang

title: Yeastea - An oscillatory yeast-derived skincare solution for enhanced skin barrier repair
abstract: Sensitive skin affects approximately 60% of the global population, leading to an increasing demand for safe and effective skincare solutions. However, natural ingredients like (-)-?-bisabolol, known for the anti-inflammatory properties, are costly when combined with yeast extracts. To address this, we designed "Yeastea", a novel 2+1 yeast-fermented skincare product combining (-)-?-bisabolol, ceramides, and yeast extract for enhanced skin barrier repair. We engineered Saccharomyces cerevisiae to produce the key ingredients via the genetic oscillator that reduces cytotoxicity and enhances the yeast lifespan. We increased ceramide production by 37%. This innovative yeast-fermented skincare product offers an affordable, sustainable solution for sensitive skin, with a broader future in the skincare and cosmetic industry.
nominations: Best Fashion & Cosmetics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Wenwen Huang, Jiazhang Lian, Ming Chen
advisors: Shihan Xiong, Ximeng Zheng, Yiyang Zhang
student leaders: Chen Wang, Di Wu, Haoyang Yu, Kexuan Kong, Zihang He
students: Bo Yang, Jiaying Zhu, Jinpeng Chen, Mingyang Xiao, Mingyuan Wang, Ruiling Xu, Shihong Yuan, Shuhan Ji, Siyuan Gong, Siyuan Lyu, Xiaohan Zhang, Xiaoran Cao, Yaqi Wang, Yifan Gao, Yijun Yang, Yue Cao, Zimo Liu

title: Enhancing Bone Repair: Solving the Burst Release Problem in Regenerative Materials with Fusion-Expressed Cell Factors
abstract: Bone injuries, scoliosis, and bone defects are major health issues in China, caused by trauma, infections, tumors, or congenital diseases, causing functional impairment and pain. Current treatments like autografts, allografts, and artificial bone materials have limitations. Autografts are limited by donor availability and need extra surgery. Allografts risk rejection and infection. Artificial bone materials lack biocompatibility and bioactive components. Our study aims to develop a dual-cell factor(VEGF&BMP-4) release system with collagen-binding properties, addressing the limitations of artificial bone materials, to ensure safe and rapid bone formation, reducing risks of oncogenesis and ectopic ossification. The innovative dual-cell factor release design allows for the enhancement of repair efficacy while reducing the side effects associated with non-sequential release, to offer a far more efficient and safer bone repair solution. The proposed system illustrates significant potential for broad clinical applications, by elevating and refining the treatment of bone defects and associated conditions.
instructors: Dong Xu, Luxuan Liu, Yuliang Huo
advisors: Enze Zhang, Hua Chen, sunyu, Xu Yiling
student leaders: Angelina Wang, Qixuan Gong, Yan Yan
students: Alexander Zhou, BingWen Zhao, Bochen Wei, James, Keyu Liu, Langning Xu, Ruby, Shuying Yu, Sophia Peng, Xuran Wang, Yiqi Meng, Zidong Ge

title: Application and development of nanomedical drugs based on RNA interference technology in inhibiting pan allergens
abstract: Populus tomentosa allergy, common in Beijing and northeastern China during spring and fall, often leads to allergic rhinitis and asthma (Liu et al., 2010). Our product utilizes RNA interference (RNAi) technology to suppress two key pan-allergenic proteins: Heat Shock Protein 70 (HSP 70) and Profilin 3 (PFN 3), effectively reducing allergic reactions. The siRNA vector is delivered via polyethyleneimine-modified carbon quantum dots (PEI-CDs), a nanoparticle system that facilitates siRNA delivery into plant cells. We are exploring leaf and trunk injection methods for real-life applications, with potential for a spray method in the future to target a wider range of plant species. The targeting of HSP 70 and PFN 3 provides a generalized application for trees with these allergenic proteins.
nominations: Best Integrated Human Practices, High School+Best Wiki, High School
advisors: Li Yikun, Qiuyao He, Tianze Ma, Zicheng Zhou
student leaders: LIANG ZHIQI, REN BOHAN, Sophia Zheng, YAN KEXIN, ZHANG PEIJIAO
students: FANG QIUTONG, Liu Yuyang, WANG QIANAI, WANG YUQING, WANG ZIYU, XIA LUOTE, XING ZHITONG, Yuan Cheng, YU SAMUEL HEHUA, ZHUO YANZHEN

title: Spidey Microbe: Adhesion and interaction Network drug-delivery platform for Parkinson's Disease treatment
abstract: We have engineered a superhero--Spidey Microbe. We have analyzed probiotics by constructing databases and software packages, and screened for Escherichia coli Nissle1917, Lactococcus lactis F44, and Lactobacillus plantarum ATCC 8014.This includes a biotin-affinity based gut adhesion system and a quorum sensing-based interaction system, allowing the probiotics to "weave webs" and adhere the gut as well as Spider-man. We aim to design genetic circuits to control the expression of mucin binding protein in EcN and facilitate inter-probiotic adhesion to control Spidey Microbe's "spider silk" in the gut. Additionally, we plan to endow Spidey Microbe with enhanced superpowers, so we are developing cell factories in Lactococcus lactis F44 to express various therapeutic agents. Spidey Microbe will challenge the disease "monsters"--Parkinson's Disease.
instructors: Jianjun Qiao, Qinggele Caiyin, yutao tian, ???
advisors: yizhe, Yongsheng Zhou, Yutong Lu
students: Binjian Ma, Chi Yongjie, Dong kelu, Jarvis, JiaXin Gao, Jingwen Lan, Lei Zhang, Lin Lu, Mengyi Li, Minhao Zhang, Mu Xing, Shixian Hu, SHUO HU, Sikai He, Wang Zhifei, Xiao Fang, Yirui Yang, Yuqing Shi, Zhang Xianliang, Zhao, zhuoya jiang, ???

title: Opening the Door to Self-Induced Chemical Synthesis with Riboswitches
abstract: Our project addresses critical challenges in the biomanufacturing industry, where dependence on costly exogenous inducers limits production efficiency. We have developed a self-induced production system that utilizes riboswitches and the LacI repressor (New Composite Parts), incorporating two distinct lysis mechanisms (New Improved Parts). By employing these innovative riboswitch systems, we improved the expression of biosynthesis gene clusters in response to their products, leading to a significant increase in product titers: riboflavin production reached 414.31 mg/L (versus 66.16 mg/L in the control), while TPP production reached 364.59 mg/L (versus 65.14 mg/L). Additionally, our improved thermally inducible lysis system achieved a lysis rate that was 30.45% higher than that of the previously constructed arabinose-induced system. We also optimized a quorum-sensing (QS) lysis system, which outperformed the earlier light-sensing system in both lysis efficiency and operational effectiveness. These innovations provide novel solutions for enhancing efficiency in biomanufacturing, reducing costs, and streamlining operational workflows.
instructors: Kan Zhan, Pei Qiao, Qiu Meng, Shuang Liu
advisors: Jingtong Wang, Jing Xie, Pengyu Rao
students: Biyao Ling, Chenghan Ye, Gutian Cao, jiahua xu, jiaying Jiang, Jiayue Xu, jing yang, Jingyi Yang, jinning zhang, Jiyue Hu, ling hao, Pengbo Zheng, yi wang, Yuetong Lu

title: Liver-Brain Guardian: Engineering Bacteria to prevent Hepatic encephalopathy
abstract: Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) , which develops from liver cirhosis, causes increasing mortality worldwide and places huge burden on patients and the society. However, preventing HE has been challenging, with medication mainly focus on alleviating syptoms after developing HE and have long-term side effects. Here, we demonstrate a synthetic biology-inspired probiotic therapeutic, Liver-Brain Guardian, to automatically respond to the level of HE biomarker and initiate the degradation of HE pathogenic factor, and could improve intestinal barrier function and epithelial recovery. Our results showed that the engineered bacteira(EcN) can successfully sense the rising level of PEA, a reliable risk factor in HE patients , and activate the FeaR-TynA inducible promoter system to initiate the downstream metabolic module to degrade ammonia. Our approach offers an exciting and promising way to help cirrhosis patients with high risk of developing HE from progressing and start in-time treatment.
PIs: Ling Li, Jian Sun, Hua Zhang, Xiaolong He
instructors: Kun Liu, Qingfeng Zhu, Sheng Shen
advisors: Jiajin Li, Wenrong Wen, Yingying Chen, Yuhao Lin, Zhiling Wu
students: Feier Tian, Guozhuo Cai, Jianhua Zhang, Junhao LI, Kang Wang, KeLiu, Keyi Zhan, Luming Huang, Meitong Han, Min Zhu, Pan Zhao, Runze Wen, Shenglin Chen, Wan LI, Weihuan Li, Wenyi Guan, Xingan Zhao, Yanqiu Cai, Yifeng Wang, Yihan Wu, Yijingxuan Duan, Yingying Yang, Ziyuan Liu

title: Soil-IQ: An In-plant Soil Nitrate Indicator for Producers in the Developing World
abstract: Farmers in the developing world currently lack affordable, intuitive systems for optimizing fertilizer use. As a result, many under or overfertilize, harming their yields, and damaging the environment. Many sustainable development practices make farmers feel like they have to choose between their livelihoods and the environment, leading to decreased results of efforts to alleviate poverty or to protect the environment. Soil-IQ utilizes a novel nitrate detecting promoter and an intuitive colorimetric reporter to help farmers know when they have fertilized enough to maximize their yields without harming the environment. Designed for farmers and by farmers, Soil-IQ removes the guesswork in fertilizer optimization and helps farmers be both sustainable and more productive. As a result, Soil-IQ helps protect those at most risk from climate change and environmental degradation while simultaneously enabling them to create more resilient and efficient farms, making sustainable development a win-win for both farmers and other stakeholders.
students: Andrew Jones, Andrew Ziegenhorn, Breckin Forstrom, Isaac Nitchman, Jordan Moore, Kaden Parker, Lauren Kimball, Magda Imerlishvili, Mitchell Casey, Neilson Borchardt, Parker Smith, Wesley Edwards

title: Engineering Fate for Myogenic Lineages
abstract: Here we show a synthetic biology system for the engineering of the fate of myogenic lineages from normal fibroblasts. The ultimate goal would be the creation of a synthetic driver-detector system that could be deployed in induced pluripotent stem cells to drive to muscle formation for therapeutic applications. We have used Normal Human Dermal Fibroblasts (NHDF) cells as the starter cell line on which we construct our system for overexpression of MYOD-1 induced by doxycycline. Initial results obtained suggest that these lineages can be engineered efficiently and future work will couple secreted luciferase reporters for efficient and high-throughput detection of lineage commitment.
advisors: Hayley
students: Abby Maher, Alex, Anthony Noyes, Cole Tavares, Josh Barry, Malickae Audry, Renato, Taylor, Tess Ozga, Vic

title: Engineering probiotic OMVs with encapsulated CRISPR/Cas9 ribonucleoproteins for targeted gene editing
abstract: Gram-negative bacteria naturally produce spherical nanovesicles known as outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) during their growth. These OMVs, due to their nanoscale size, efficient cellular uptake, and ability to protect biomolecules, are ideal for drug delivery. In this project, we aim to genetically modify E. coli Nissle 1917 (ECN) to produce OMVs with surface-displayed targeting elements and encapsulated Cas9 RNPs. By filtering through molecular sieves, we obtain OMVs capable of targeted gene-editing complex delivery, potentially revolutionizing precision medicine.
students: enju zhu, Furong Huang, hanyue Zhang, Hong Yang, Qingyi Wu, Rui Liu, SiYi Tian, Wenrui Zhang, Xinyi Tian, Xinyu Liu, xu chengming, Yahang Lei, Yanru Ding, Yifei Yan, yuyanyan chen, Zhe Feng

title: GHK: HEP(Hair Expecto Patronum)
abstract: At present, the problem of hair loss is becoming more and more serious, and the trend of younger age is serious, which seriously affects the physical and mental health of patients. Copper peptide (GHK-Cu) is a tripeptide ultra-short peptide, which has significant effects on hair follicle repair and hair loss treatment with less side effects, and is widely used in the beauty industry, and.is a current research hotspot. This year, our team adopted series expression to efficiently express copper peptides in engineered bacteria, and adopted quorum sensing technology to build a controlled bacterial ecosystem, trying to improve its production efficiency. In addition, we use microemulsions coated with copper peptides to present the product. The application of this series of innovative technologies aims to effectively solve the problem of hair loss with minimal side effects and help people get rid of hair loss.
advisors: Qinglan Lan, Tianxing Li
students: Anki, Chang Wang, Guan yuan yan, Jinyi Fu, Jin Yujin, Juetong Chen, Lei Wang, Limbo Li, Oliva, Ruyue Deng, Shihan Liang, syifan, Wendy, WYY, Xu Huang, Xu Jiejie, yangyifan777, Yichen Shi, Zhiyan Song, ???, ???

title: HBUT-Wuhan: Manufacturing a hypoglycemic peptide Vglycin for diabetic patients
abstract: There are over 540 million people suffering from diabetes mellitus globally. Although numerous medications have been approved to control blood glucose levels, the side effects present huge challenges for their application. P37, a novel oral hypoglycemic peptide group derived from soybeans, has been shown to improve blood glucose in mice and in clinic. However, direct extraction from soybeans is problematic due to low yields, complex processes and high cost. HBUT-Wuhan plans to use synthetic biology to produce Vglycin (Vg), a member of P37 family that have huge potential to be innovative medicine. Finally, we successfully constructed the GS115 expression system of Vglycin, and optimize the parts in the construct to improve its yield. Our findings also indicated that the mutation at position 28 to Ala has stronger affinity with the receptor. In the future we would like to further study the expression of mutational Vg in Pichia pastoris.
advisors: Cefan Zhou
students: Jiafan Zhang, Jiayi Zhao, Liesheng Xie, Mengqi Li, Pengju Liu, Qianqian Chen, Qiwen Huang, Sichen Li, Si-Yuan Huang, WenmengZhao, Xinyu Xiao, Yening Guo, Yuling Huang, Zhuohang Yu, Ziyi Tong

title: From Longan to Astaxanthin---- A Curious Fusion of Science and Nature
abstract: With the attention to health, astaxanthin has entered our field of vision. It is a keto carotenoid, known as the "king of antioxidants." However, at present, in addition to the high content of astaxanthin extracted from Rhodium pluvium algae, the content of astaxanthin extracted from other sources is relatively low. Therefore, our team proposed a scheme to extract astaxanthin from longan leaves. We introduced the target genes from Chlamydomonas rheinensis and Rhodococcus pluvialis into longan leaves for expression to improve astaxanthin extraction. We will apply the exploration of this proposition to the beauty industry. At the same time, we conducted a series of publicity activities and the production of popular science videos to pass this exploration to more groups and let more people know about this research and development results.
PIs: Shijiang Cao, Peng Liang, Houxi Zhang, Kehui Zheng, Qinghua Zhang, Yuling Lin
advisors: Feng_KUN, Jiehui Huang, luhui

students: Congda Ye, Huihuang Xu, Jiayi Cai, Jiayi Chen, Kehan Yang, Kunpeng Xu, Mengying Xie, Shumei Pan, Sirui Leng, Sizhi Zhou, Tengzhi Zhang, Weihao Zhang, Xin Wang, Xinwei Lin, Xinyu Zhou, Yichao Dai, Yifan Xiong, Yihan Chen, Yue Tang, YueXiang Qiu, Yumeng Kong, zhouxuan lu, Zifeng Zhang

title: Intereting pathway to chenolic compounds degradation
abstract: Inshore pollution concerns scientists and governments. The inshore ecosystem is vital but suffers more pollution. Public awareness of marine protection is growing, yet phenolic compounds are overlooked pollutants. Phenols can damage organisms and are hard to degrade. In this year, QS-FMI aims to solve phenols pollution by designing a synthetic biological pathway.
advisors: Skyler Woo
students: Chong Chak Jiang, Cindy, Miumiu

title: IchthyoCare - Providing a Substitution Therapy for the Skin Disease Ichthyosis
abstract: Ichthyosis is a group of rare, genetically inherited skin disorders characterised by severe dryness, scaling, and disrupted skin barriers due to malfunctioning enzymes. Current treatments are limited and time-consuming, often requiring individuals to spend hours each day managing their skin. Our project, IchthyoCare, aimed to tackle the underlying cause of ichthyosis by developing an enzyme replacement therapy utilising liposomal drug delivery technology. Our evidence suggests that we have encapsulated purified 12R-LOX, expressed in an E. coli system, within large unilamellar vesicles. This would hopefully improve the skin, and moving forward the idea is that the encapsulated enzymes would be applied topically, with liposomes facilitating fusion with skin cells to deliver the therapeutic enzymes directly. This strategy will hopefully lessen the symptoms and decrease the time affected individuals need to spend taking care of their skin.
students: Alexandra Lindgren, Felicia Wedlund, Isac Kreku, ?ucja Biecho?ska, Melker Wändahl, Moa Ackemark, Nils Westlund, Ossian Ekelund, Tess Wiglund, Theo Lindblom

title: Entero Guard, a probiotic system for safe and efficient detection and treatment of IBD
abstract: To address the shortcomings in current treatments for IBD, we presented Entero Guard, an automatic engineered probiotic system that can diagnose and treat IBD efficiently and safely. We first designed a biodiagnosis strain that contains ThsS and ThsR to form a signaling network after detecting sulfide to detect inflammation. We then added a CRISPR based editor system to amplify the signal reaction by controlling our drug--AvCystatin's expression, which plays a crucial role in regulating macrophage immune responses, activating cellular MAP kinase and inducing the expression of IL-10 and IL-12/23, thereby effectively alleviating gut inflammation. To control drug expression, we designed a suicide switch with PnorV, a key biobrick that can detect the level of nitric oxide in gut and eventually activate a toxic protein, MazF, which leads to cell apoptosis. we wish this idea can bring new possibility for IBD treatment and help IBD patients return to a normal life.
PIs: Xun Li, Jiexi Yan, Xin Wang

title: Enzymatic DNA
abstract: This project aims to advance DNA synthesis technology by developing a novel enzymatic approach utilizing Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT). Despite TdT's potential for template-free DNA synthesis, its random nucleotide addition limits its practical application. We will harness directed evolution to enhance the catalytic activity and capacity of the wild-type TdT from Zonotrichia albicollis (ZaTdT). Additionally, we will design and synthesize deoxynucleotide substrates with reversibly protected 3' termini, allowing for controlled nucleotide incorporation. This combination aims to achieve precise and orderly enzymatic DNA synthesis, addressing the efficiency and purity challenges associated with traditional chemical methods. By integrating these innovations, our project seeks to establish a greener, more efficient DNA synthesis platform, paving the way for advancements in genomics, synthetic biology, and data storage technologies.
student leaders: Andrew Yang, JINGZHUO SUN, Luca Gao, YULIANG MA
students: AIZHU ZHANG, HEYU LI, Kaiyuan Xu, Louis, MOHAN HUA, NIANTONG, Ruoshui Du, Tian Sun, Yonghan Chi, Zitong Zeng, ZIXUAN MA

title: HERMES - An Improved Bacterial Delivery System for Targeting Solid Tumours
abstract: Cancer remains the second leading cause of death worldwide. Chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and surgery remain front line treatments however, their systemic toxicity remains a notable concern as over 65% of patients suffer from severe adverse side effects. McMaster_Canada aims to utilize the oncogenic nature of bacteria to develop Hermes, a platform technology that localizes and regulates therapeutic delivery at the tumour site. Our team designed a synthetic protien inspired by FAP2 on Fusobacterium nucleatum (F. nucleatum/Fn), that allows the our chassis, E. coli Nissle 1917, to colonize and co-exist in the tumour by binding to the overexpressed sugars - Gal-GalnAC. Once colonized, Hermes is equipped with a tumour microenvironment sensor that selectively triggers the production of a therapeutic agent at the site of the tumour. Using Hermes, we aim to improve clinical application of in-sera bacterial delivery system by reducing the dosage while maintain specificity for tumour colonization.
student leaders: Alesha Singh, Andrew Chami, Anjana Sudharshan, Ashley Qian, Chantal Luo, Derin Sayin, Fanxiao Liu, Helen Peng, Jessie Liu, Kevin, Mya George, Myra Godara, Rand Al-Wazzan, Vanessa Lai
students: Abby Benyair, Alice Pao, Anh Bui, Bohdan, Cynthia Duan, Haram Akram, Hassan Hassan, Isabella Valentini, Jacob Stotland, Jiawen Ren, Jonathan Guan, Kaia Seet, Mahnoor, Marco Tan, Michelle Giang, Morgan Puusaari, Navid Farkhondehpay, Rubani Suri, Samaneh Hajigholam, Zoha

title: Detection of Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. cubense through an Optimized Lux and Hardware System
abstract: Our project addresses the issue of the Panama wilt disease caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp cubense (Foc). This disease clogs the plant's xylem vessels; leading to water and nutrient deprivation, defoliation, and plant death. Panama is a significant banana producer in Latin America, yielding approximately 2.5 million tons annually, contributing about $200 million to Panama's economy. Foc TR4 has rendered Cavendish susceptible to Fusarium Wilt and little can be done through isolation due to it being largely asymptomatic. Our solution involves engineering bacteria for early detection of Foc through signal detection, amplification, and propagation. A genetic circuit is activated by fusaric acid produced by the fungus through an inducible promoter. Upon detection, the signal is amplified by a positive feedback loop of AHL through Lux quorum sensing. Signal Propagation is achieved through an optimized BRET reporter protein triggered by the AHL-LuxR activator and its compatibility with the hardware.
PIs: Daniel Alejandro Garcia Loaiza, Carlos Lopez, Ediner Fuentes Campos, Mariana Franco
advisors: Erika Arauz, Marivi Ow de Gondola, Mary, Tisha
student leaders: Armaan Melwani, Gabriela Jimeno, Karol Jimenez, Maria Isabella Perez

title: B.A.R.B.I.E. Bioengineered Aquatic pollutants Removal and Bio-sensing through Integrated Eco-filter
abstract: The B.A.R.B.I.E project (Bioengineered Aquatic pollutants Removal and Bio-sensing through Integrated Eco-filter) addresses the growing threat of micro and nanoplastic (MNP) pollution in drinking water. Improper disposal of plastic waste leads to environmental degradation, as larger plastics break down into microscopic particles that infiltrate freshwater ecosystems. These pollutants bypass conventional filtration systems and enter our homes, posing serious risks to human health. B.A.R.B.I.E 4.0 offers an innovative solution to this issue by integrating a bio-inspired water filter with an impedance-based biosensor to detect and remove MNPs more effectively. The Eco- filter features a spider silk spidroin matrix combined with AI-designed plastic-binding proteins (PBPs) to enhance MNPs capture. Additionally, the project provides a molecular toolbox for designing pollutant-specific proteins using bioinformatics tools. By leveraging advanced technologies, bioengineering and social responsibility B.A.R.B.I.E aims to provide a flexible, sustainable and scalable solution to water pollution, helping protect human health and addressing environmental concerns.
nominations: Best Bioremediation Project, Overgrad
instructors: Alexandre Borin, Paola Ferrari, Pedro Sader Azevedo, Renato Sousa Lima, Vitória Yumi Uetuki Nicoleti
advisors: Aline Tieppo, Felippe Colombari, Juliana Naomi Yamauti Costa, Leandro Merces, Mariana Morais, Paulo Jose Correa Freire

title: Electrosynthesis Biomineralizer
abstract: Climate warming is progressively issuing a severe warning to humanity through its multifaceted and immense threats. We designed an efficient algal-bacterial co-culture system to convert carbon dioxide into calcium carbonate, achieving carbon sequestration for millennia. This system highlights the extracellular electron uptake pathway of Shewanella oneidensis and the experimental use of Vibrio natriegens to synthesize various complex calcium carbonate precipitation regulators (CCPR). We aim to integrate hardware with biological systems, utilizing solar panels to generate electricity and activate the electron uptake pathway (EEU) in Shewanella oneidensis. This will make it able to synthesize formate. Vibrio natriegens can utilize formate or sucrose and efficiently produce carbonic anhydrase (CA), coral acid-rich proteins (CARPs), and Cabp-Chbd. These proteins will significantly propel the precipitation of calcium carbonate. The sucrose from cyanobacteria serves as an additional carbon source, enabling the efficient metabolism of two other engineered bacteria.
PIs: Zhirui Zeng, Yuze Wang, Chuanlun Zhang
advisors: Jiayi Yang, Jiulin Chen, Kaisheng Zheng, Lingfei Li, Yidong Wang
students: Bohan Zhou, Congrui Yuan, jiali Qiang, JianRui Zhou, Jingtong Chen, JINGYI ZHOU, Kong Weiye, Qinyuzhou, Ren Jiaxi, ren zitian, Shangheng Song, Shengyun Feng, Shu Ming Alex Xu, Shun Hong yu, TIANLING XU, Wei Jialin, XINGYING ZHU, Xintong Shen, XinYi Zeng, Yuan Feng, YUHAO YE

title: SAMUS: Self-healing Adhesive Materials for Underwater Soft-robot
abstract: NAU-CHINA 2024's project is SAMUS, Self-healing Adhesive Materials for Underwater Soft-robot. Considering the numerous challenges soft robots faced in the ocean exploration process, we developed a biomaterial with both self-healing and adhesive capabilities for soft robots. For the self-healing module, we used a RNA cyclase ribozyme mechanism to increase the repeated times of tandem repeat polypeptides with n repetitions (TRn) derived from squid ring teeth proteins, which increase the self-healing capability of our material. For the adhesive module, we connected mussel foot protein 5 (Mfp5) with TRn4 to create a new fusion protein that acts as a "double-sided adhesive", enabling our self-healing material to adhere to the substrate of underwater soft-robots. This material autonomously repairs damage, aids underwater exploration and helps protect the marine environment.
instructors: Dongli Sun, queligang, Wang Jin, Wang Jufang, xuchengbao, Yuanyuan Liu, zhangjin, Zhao Jing, Zhe Wang
