students: Changwei Du, Chaoran Li, Duo Yu, Guo Lin, Jiayi Chen, Jingya Zhao, Jinmeng Liu, Lujie Yan, Minqi Wang, Qijia Ren, Xiaofen Wang, Yue Qiu, Yuyan Zhang, Zhijian Wang, Ziyi Guo

title: AmyloShield: Fortified Sweet Potatoes for Glycemic Control
abstract: The International Diabetes Federation indicates that in the Western Pacific region, 1 in 8 adults has diabetes. China alone accounts for one-quarter of the world's diabetic population. While treatments and medications are available, there is insufficient focus on prevention and everyday dietary care. To address this issue, we have engineered sweet potatoes, one of the most starch-rich root crops in the world, known for its high yield and strong adaptability. Crops with a higher amylose content are excellent sources of resistant starch, which can lower diabetes risk and promote health. Our goal is to use gene editing technology to knock out the gene responsible for synthesizing amylopectin in sweet potatoes, thereby increasing the amylose content. The high-amylose sweet potatoes will be incorporated into affordable sweet potato flour, biscuits, and cakes to reduce postprandial blood sugar fluctuations, supporting both diabetes prevention and the dietary needs of those affected.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Xu Min, Zhang Zhaoxia
student leaders: Thinker Si, Xiaoxi Wang, Zhuojin Mao
students: Botao Wang, Cheng Xu, Jingyu Shan, Kexin Chen, Ke Zhang, Mingkai Zhu, Pinan Chen, Xiaoran Hu, Xinjia Shen, Xinyi Wu, Yujia Li, Yuliang Wang, Yuliang Zhong, Zien Wang, Zihan Chen, Ziqing Ye, Zixuan Qu

title: Evolving T7 RNA Polymerase
abstract: The focus on mRNA technology has heightened due to its recent applications in vaccines for COVID-19 and other diseases. Our project aims to further evolve T7 RNA polymerase, a critical enzyme involved in this production. In our project, we developed a robust reporter system, aimed at evaluating the wild-type T7RNAP and the ancestral sequences generated. Through the iGEM engineering cycle and our engineering success, we were also able to refine the expression of T7RNAP to stable levels through the addition of regulatory elements such as antisense oligonucleotides to knockdown the expression of T7 RNAP. With this compatible expression and reporter system, our project aims to generate a diverse library of RNAP variants using different methods such as site-directed mutagenesis, ancestral reconstruction, and random mutagenesis. These variants will then be screened using our reporter system to identify for better-performing variants.
student leaders: Jie Hao Ong, Xue Jia Xin Angelina
students: Frederick Chong, Juhwan, Katelyn Low, Nivey, Peter Ho, Sannan Kanwar, Sichen Lin, Victoria, Xian Chun, Xin Rui Chan, Yee Han, Yu Yuan Tew

title: Oral dual-therapy for prevention of obesity
abstract: Obesity is a rapidly growing global health issues that causes a multitude of potentially fatal chronic health problems. In this project, we propose a oral-dual therapy for obesity via Lactobacillus Casei gene modification as well as RNAi therapy. L. casei, commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract of humans, is widely used as a probiotic. Our team successfully expressed human FGF19 and FGF21 into L. casei. The FGF products generated suggest L. casei may possess anti-obesity properties. Our experiments also showed that exosomes containing pre-miRNAs targeting adipocytes show promise to increase inflammation and browning. We engaged with diverse communities and fostered dialogue around relevant topics. We conducted interviews with many different stakeholders to explore interdisciplinary perspectives, ensuring our project is socially responsible and impactful. Some of our educational activties included an MUN debate addressing synthetic biology and obesity, and hands-on DNA extraction labs, sparking interest in science in high school students.
PIs: Stephen Kwok-Wing TSUI, Hannah Hui, YW Kwan
advisors: Daniel Pang
students: Alikhan, Bindhiya Thiruvenkadam, Celeste, Felicia, Kara, Lucas, NetaniahPinto, Vania, Yoyo

title: PROMISE: Precision Oncology - Modular Immunotherapy using Surface-Engineered bacterial membrane vesicles
abstract: Immunotherapies offer great potential for treating immune-mediated diseases, but often lead to resistance and adverse effects. To address this, iGEM TU Eindhoven is developing PROMISE, a novel trained immunity vaccine utilizing antigen-functionalized bacterial membrane vesicles (BMVs). Building on the Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine, PROMISE reprograms innate immune cells for a stronger, broader immune response, overcoming immune evasion and providing long-lasting protection. Unlike the live bacteria in the BCG vaccine, our BMVs are safe for systemic use because they cannot replicate. By functionalizing BMVs with disease-specific antigens, PROMISE also activates adaptive immune responses, ensuring a targeted and durable therapeutic effect. Initially focused on non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), the platform's modular design allows for adaptation to other diseases. Advanced computational modeling tools identify highly immunogenic, patient-specific antigens, enabling personalized vaccines. Supported by expert collaborations and protected by a provisional patent, PROMISE has a clear path toward clinical translation and further development.
nominations: Best Oncology Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Undergrad
PIs: Maarten Merkx, Luc Brunsveld, Tom De Greef
students: Christy Fredrix, Joyce Mendes Pols, Lizette van der Ziel, Lucas van Osenbruggen, Luna Raskovic, Marijn ter Weeme, Milou Meulendijks, Simon Rose

title: Innovative CO2 Reduction and Sustainable PHB Bioplastic Reduction Using Synechocystis Sp.
abstract: Each year, over 350 million metric tons of plastic waste pollute our planet. To address this, Korea-HS focuses on utilizing the cyanobacterium Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 to produce polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB), a biodegradable plastic. Synechocystis naturally absorbs atmospheric CO?, providing both a sustainable plastic alternative and contributing to climate change mitigation. We optimized PHB production through Adaptive Laboratory Evolution (ALE), selecting strains that thrive in high-pH environments, enhancing both carbon fixation and PHB synthesis. Our results show a peak PHB content of 31.3 wt% at pH 11.0, compared to 20.0 wt% at neutral pH, supported by RNA sequencing data revealing that fructose and mannose metabolism-associated genes were upregulated. Beyond the lab, Korea-HS promotes public awareness through social media, online conferences, and an Awareness Policy Framework, aiming to educate and encourage the adoption of sustainable alternatives like PHB in the fight against plastic pollution.
nominations: Best Measurement, High School
advisors: Claire Kim, Clare Chaeeun Park, Ellen Kim, Eyoung Kim, Kyunghwan Roh, Siyoon Kim, Young Elizabeth Min, Yubin Son
student leaders: Alyssa Han, Charlotte Im, June Choi, Mirae Do, Seoyoon Chung, Yerin Cho, Yuri Kang
students: Jaeyun Kim, Jay Park, Jinah Chung, Ji Yoon Park, Jiyul Lee, Joseph Park, Kyungjin Oh, Minjune Choi, Minseo Kang

title: Using Bacillus subtilis as a DNA-Based Biosensor for the Grape Vine Pathogen Plasmopara viticola
abstract: Plasmopara viticola, commonly known as downy mildew or Peronospora in Italian, is one of the most destructive pathogens affecting grapevines. Current methods for managing this pathogen rely heavily on the repetitive use of chemical pesticides, which pose significant risks to both the environment and human health in vineyard regions. In this study, we explore the use of genetically modified Bacillus subtilis as a DNA-based biosensor for the early detection of Plasmopara viticola, allowing for proactive disease management before grapevine infection occurs. To prevent direct contact between the modified bacteria and plants, a specialized device was developed to house the biosensors. Additionally, a fiber-optic system incorporating a sol-gel matrix was used to enhance the detection signal, addressing the challenges of signal transmission typically encountered in bioreactor systems. This innovative approach offers a sustainable alternative to current pesticide-dependent strategies, with potential applications in precision viticulture.
advisors: Luca Nerva, Orlando Lucii
students: Alessandro, Chiara Ferrara, Davide Pio Lomonaco, Emanuele Rossi, Giorgia Di Santolo, Marcello Lattanzi, Marco Pasquini, Niccolò Pietrantoni, Noemi Loffredi, Riccardo Masetti

title: e-PHAESTUS
abstract: In recent years, the volume of e-waste has been constantly increasing, leading to an emerging crisis. Conventional methods for metal extraction from e-waste are environmentally unsustainable, due to their high energy demands and the generation of harmful by-products. e-PHAESTUS, our innovative bioleaching project, aims to protect the environment and public health from the compounds found in electric and electronic equipment, but also to create a novel method for the production of glutathione-metal nanoparticles, derived from e-waste upcycling. To achieve this, the iGEM Athens team has transformed a strain of the E. coli bacterium, using recombinant plasmids, containing two genes necessary for the synthesis of the tripeptide glutathione, which can bind to metals and dissolve them.
nominations: Best Entrepreneurship, Overgrad
advisors: Nikolaos Georgakis
students: ANNA NIKOLETA GRIVA, Athanasios Bouzoukas, Charikleia Karaousta, EFSTATHIOS ALONARIS, Eleni Krassa, Evangelos Stamos, Kanella Papakosta-Sampatakaki, Kristian Verdhi, Maria Konstantina Tzioti, Panagiotis Vasileios Papadopoulos, Stavros Karvelas

title: siRNAs that targeting TEAD4 serve as an emerging drug for the treatment of colorectal cancer
abstract: Colorectal cancer is a leading cause of cancer-related mortality worldwide. This project focuses on developing a novel targeted therapy by inhibiting the TEAD4 gene, a key regulator in the Hippo signaling pathway that plays a significant role in colorectal cancer progression. We have designed two plasmids that efficiently suppress TEAD4 expression. Our results indicate that elevated levels of TEAD4-targeting siRNAs in the colorectal cancer cell line SW480 lead to inhibition of tumor cell proliferation and migration, as well as increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) expression. These findings suggest that this RNA interference vector could serve as a promising therapeutic candidate for colorectal cancer treatment.
advisors: Gezhi Ma, JiQi Xia, YU-MIN CHIANG
student leaders: Jiayu Yu, Qiancheng Yu, Senho Ma, Yang YuHan
students: Hayden Li, Yiming TAO, Yuhan FENG, Yuqiu Zhou, Zhu Shuyan

title: KNACC-Kelp: Nature's Answer to the Climate Crisis
abstract: Kelp holds immense potential! Facing a series of greenhouse effect issues, we aspire to efficiently capture carbon dioxide and convert it into valuable products. As a blue carbon biomass, kelp offers significant advantages: it can absorb large amounts of carbon dioxide and is part of the third generation of biomass resources, characterized by sustainable utilization. However, its potential for biotransformation remains largely untapped. To expand kelp's applications, we focus on operating synthetic biology techniques to address several challenges: the inefficient utilization of kelp's unconventional carbon sources, the low value of products directly converted from kelp and the lack of an effective pretreatment process to feed yeast. We pioneer a Saccharomyces cerevisiae chassis cell capable of utilizing kelp carbon sources to synthesize limonene, and develop a complete processing route from raw kelp to limonene products. We have achieved a significant breakthrough from 0 to 1 and now to 10!
advisors: Yanying Liu, YiJia Li
student leaders: Long Zhou, Shengtao Wu, suyan pang
students: Fangjun Ge, Hangtian Sun, Jiaying Xiao, Jiying Liu, Meifeng Dong, Tianqi Yang, Wenqi Cai, Xiaotong Huang, Xiaoye Zhang, Xinyi Zhou, Yajie Zhou, Yingyi Tan, Yuhan Zhou, Yunqi Tang, Yuxi Yang, Zilong Pan, Ziyou Liang

title: The Biodegradable Bioplastic From The World of Tomorrow: An Answer to Harmful Petroleum Plastics
abstract: The current world is plagued by modern microplastics. From wrecking our ecosystems to wrecking the health of organisms across the globe. These non-degradable microplastics not only cause serious risks to our biomes, but also to our own personal health. This goes even without mentioning the amount of carbon-based emissions are spent using oil for the creation of our modern plastics. What if there was a way to ensure we as humans could create a plastic that was both climate-friendly and biodegradable? Introducing: our PHB-based biodegradable bioplastic! The PHB lipid is created through a culture of modified C. reinhardtii and E. coli so it is both eco-friendly and oil-free. This PHB is the precursor to a bioplastic that could be created commercially worldwide, creating an impact globally. Fully biodegradable, this plastic can solve many of the burgeoning issues of modern plastics and can change the world if implemented!
advisors: Chloe Benjamin, Tyrell Bowens
student leaders: Carlos Gomez, John W. Biggs III, Walter Samuel Burger, Zixuan Li
students: Alex, Amina Aliou, Amy Nguyen, Berenice, Daisy, Haoqi Wang, Haozhe Yao, Hieu Nguyen, Jasmine, Jiewen Wang, Jingyi Xia, Juliette, Leyao Wang, Li Xu, Matthias, MiaoFeiYin, Minkuan Chen, Nicole Thorpe, Rui Gong, Sabine Gai, Salem Mutata, Sebastian Haines, Shiqi Li, Soham Darji, Tai, Ting Du, Valerie, Wanqi Wang, Weixu Chen, wenhao, Will Switzer, Yasamin Baseery, Yibei Wang, Yingzhou Ji, Yuchong Yang, Yufeng Gan, Yumin Min, Zheyi Tao, Zihan Zhou

title: ShowgNs
abstract: The nitrogen issue is one of the most critical problems these days. Excess nitrogen introduced into the environment by human activities causes eutrophication, negatively impacts aquatic ecosystems, and contributes to climate change in the form of the greenhouse gas, dinitrogen monoxide (N2O). The main source of this nitrogen influx is nitrogen fertilizers used in agricultural fields. To solve the nitrogen issue while maintaining productivity through fertilizers, in this project, we worked on developing a cell-free nitrogen biosensor for optimal fertilization management. By combining a cell-free biosensor with hardware for sampling, we aimed to accurately measure the concentration of ammonium (NH4+) and nitrate (NO3-) in the soil. Additionally, we have developed a platform that can be applied to the development of other biosensors.
nominations: Best Agriculture Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Hardware, Undergrad
advisors: Hayato Mitoma, Kaho Maeta, Ryohei Ishibashi
students: Haruchika Iwata, Haruki Minamiyama, Haru Okamoto, Haruto Nakamura, Haruto Segawa, Hiroaki Yagi, Jiale Song, Kazuma Yabuki, Kei Hasegawa, Mana Nakai, Mari Hashimoto, Masamune Okamura, Mayu Harada, Mayu Kataoka, Moe Baba, Nanaha Ogura, Nichika Nakamura, Rei Suzawa, Ren Mori, Taiki Odo, Taiyo Okayama, Taketo Ota, Youta Oka, Yuri Sato, Yuta Inagaki

title: CFastDx: A Rapid Diagnostic Solution for Cystic Fibrosis
abstract: Cystic fibrosis (CF) poses a significant public health challenge, with increasing cases driven by low awareness and late diagnosis. Our research introduces CFastDx, an innovative rapid detection kit designed to identify cystic fibrosis efficiently. Utilizing a straightforward buccal swab process, CFastDx enables quick and accurate diagnosis, improving patient outcomes through early intervention. This project explores the molecular underpinnings of CF, focusing on CFTR gene mutations responsible for its debilitating symptoms. Despite advancements in medical science, the prevalence of CF continues to rise, highlighting the urgent need for better detection methods. By raising awareness and promoting early diagnosis, CFastDx aims to empower individuals and healthcare providers to act swiftly against this genetic disorder. Our approach combines cutting-edge diagnostic technology with community engagement, ensuring that no one faces CF alone and transforming the landscape of CF management for a healthier future.
PIs: Prof. M. Sivanandham, Nakkeeran E, Divakar K
students: Abinaya T., Adhavan Ramsundar, Arun Pravin.C.V., Dharini Deepkumar, Fahir Ubaythul Rahman, Gilford Thomas I, Nivethaa Jayasri Magesh, Niwin Rakshith L V, Sriram M, VAISHNAVI MADABHUSHI

title: Team has withdrawn
abstract: Team has withdrawn
advisors: Alex Gillard, Oluwatinufemi Tope-Awofeko, Ryan Riopel, Sammy Kalny
students: Amrita Mosale, Bazzi Qureshi, Domenica Vizcaino, Emma, Hannah Fransen, Ian Polard, Jamie Durow, Kyle Xander Co, Liv Utigard, Mehak Parihar, Olivia Bagnall, Sarah Swaters, Trinity Nguyen

title: Illuminating the brain: Discovery of cyclic N-aminoluciferins (cyL) for brain tumor bioluminescence imaging
abstract: Brain tumors can cause neurological impairments and death, stressing the necessity for ongoing research and enhanced therapies. Bioluminescence imaging, a non-invasive imaging technique, is employed in tumor research, gene expression, drug screening, and other fields. However, substrates like D-luciferin and aminoluciferin have short red-light emission (tissue-penetrating), insufficient in vivo bioluminescence duration, and inadequate blood-brain barrier permeability, resulting in bioluminescence imaging for brain tumors challenging. This study develops cyclic N-aminoluciferins (cyL) as firefly luciferase substrates with improved bioluminescence via rational design and organic synthesis. Due to its red-shifted bioluminescent emission, prolonged bioluminescence duration and enhanced blood-brain barrier penetration, 7-cyL is a promising candidate for bioluminescence imaging of brain tumors after biological evaluations. In summary, our approach allows direct brain tumor progression imaging and fills a long-standing gap in real animal imaging. We believe that these cyL compounds will improve bioluminescence imaging and help us understand brain tumor growth and treatment.
advisors: Minyong Li
student leaders: Hanwen Zheng, Isabella Qianya Li, Shuhao Zhang, Xiaohe Li, Yiduo Chen, Yisen Wang, Yuning Wang, Yuxuan Li
students: Chenxuan Zhao, Fanyi Meng, Huanru Liang, Kongchao Wang, Muyang Yang, Xiaohan Sun, Ximing Hou, XINPENG ZHANG, Yichen Ren, Yuanbei Sun, Ziyang Zhou, Ziyue Wang

title: HypoSense - a hypoxia-responsive biosensor for precision tissue microenvironment profiling
abstract: The complex relationship between low oxygen levels (hypoxia) and cellular function plays a key role in many biological processes and diseases. Our project aims to create a biosensor to quantitatively measure cellular oxygen levels and help better understand how hypoxia changes in the microenvironment, especially in tumors. Harnessing the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) pathway, we engineered yeast reporter cells that emit a fluorescent signal under hypoxia. This foundational research has the potential to help us better understand how hypoxic conditions influence metabolic adaptation, gene expression, and cellular responses. By adjusting the number of hypoxia responsive elements (HRE) in our biosensor, we aim to build a flexible tool for high-speed screening and analysis. This work not only contributes to our knowledge of hypoxia but also lays the groundwork for future medical applications, potentially guiding treatments for diseases affected by low oxygen conditions.
advisors: Andrii Shekhirev, Anna Stikane, Inese Cakstina-Dzerve, J?nis Edmunds Daugavietis
students: Agnese Gabriela Celma, Aleksandrs Iva?i?kins, Aleksandrs Marks Krusts, Anete Patricija Raiskuma, Anna Novosada, Darija Demcenko, Elizabete Beta Esenvalde, Ennata Viluma, Eva Blumberga, Everita Elina Sinicina, Karlis Blums, Kristaps Pinkovskis, Martins Marcis Rubenis, Roberts Karklins, Sintija Ozola, Viviana Liva Kalnina

title: Biotraction, Self-assembly of Artificial Organelles for in vitro Rubber Biosynthesis
abstract: Rubber is an industrially important raw material, yet the production of which is experiencing environmental and social challenges, such as deforestation and geographic limitations. These, coupled with rising global demand, create a dire need for sustainable alternatives. Previous attempts at natural rubber bioproduction yielded low efficiency and insufficient chain length, likely due to the absence of rubber-particle-like organelles in the engineered organisms. The Imperial-College iGEM team addressed this by genetically engineering E. coli to enable natural rubber bioproduction. By understanding the molecular mechanisms of rubber synthesis, artificial organelles were designed to create optimal conditions for rubber biosynthesis in vitro. These designs were cloned and tested, revealing exciting preliminary results indicative of successful artificial organelle synthesis and rubber production. Future exploration of their approach offers a scalable, eco-friendly solution that bypasses the unsustainable traditional production processes and strengthens global supply resilience.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Undergrad
advisors: Içvara, Livia, Zhou Yuming
students: Cansu, Chinmay, David David, Diyan, Eileen Chandra, FUZHI LI, Jixiao Wu, Larissa Potapova, Lucie, Remy, TIANLANG CHEN, zhining

title: The bio-friendly production of vitamin B6 based on the cell-free expression system
abstract: We have developed a green production method of VB6 based on a protein expression system without cells, in which the biological raw materials (including glycerol) are derived from the lysate of E. coli, and the DNA transcription template is artificially designed and optimized. The DNA template contains the DNA sequences of the key proteins PdxA and PdxJ required for the full synthesis of VB6.
students: CAO LIYOUYOU, CHENGYUAN LI, CHENRUI CUI, HUA FUYI, HUIZHI WANG, JIAXUN WANG, JIAYI LIU, JINGYANG, JUNHAN XIAO, RUNCHENG WANG, SHANGCHEN LI, TIANYI GENG, XIAO ZHANG, YIFEI GAO, ZILIN TAO

title: Construction of a Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell factory for high ?-carotene production
abstract: ?-carotene is a terpenoid compound with important medical, food, and industrial values. Traditional physical extraction methods are time-consuming and cumbersome, and the cultivation of ?-carotene-containing crops requires geographical location and growth cycle. Chemical synthesis of ?-carotene may be toxic, limiting its application. Microbial fermentation for the synthesis of ?-carotene is currently the most promising and promising synthetic method. Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a recognized food-safe grade microorganism with the advantages of easy molecular manipulation, rapid growth, and good tolerance, has been adapted for the production of various terpenoids including ?-carotene. In this study, we targeted the ?-carotene synthesis pathway, optimized the synthesis pathway genes, arranged and combined the candidate gene species sources, constructed the corresponding strains, tested the ?-carotene yield of the resulting strains, and obtained the optimal gene combinations for the construction of a high-yielding ?-carotene brewer's yeast to assist in the commercial production of ?-carotene.
advisors: Huang Xuanlin, Li Liyang
students: BAI IRENE, HUANG CHUYE, LUO ZHI, MO JINXI, SUN GEYANG, SUN ZiYi, XIE XINRUN

title: Image-Based Machine Learning of Keratin-Intermediate Filaments: A Novel Tool for Skin Cancer Metastasis Risk Stratification
abstract: This project aims to develop an innovative machine learning model to predict skin cancer metastasis by analyzing keratin filament structures in keratinocytes. Skin cancer is a prevalent global health issue, with millions of cases diagnosed annually. While less lethal than other cancers, its potential to metastasize poses a significant threat. Current prognostic methods have limitations, including reliance on traditional examinations, pathologist shortages, and potential for false results. The project focuses on keratin, a family of proteins crucial for cell mechanics and signaling, as changes in keratin expression have been linked to increased cancer cell invasiveness and metastatic potential. By leveraging image-based machine learning to assess keratin structural features, the goal is to create a more accurate prediction tool for metastatic potential, enhancing risk stratification and guiding treatment decisions in skin cancer management.
advisors: John Kim, Sophie Kim
students: Aiden Minseo Ha, Alice, Bisong Ko, Dahee Yoon, Daniel Sun, Erwin, Eunsu Lee, Ikon, Jeff, Jisu Park, Julia, Luke, Minwoo Jeong, Shue Park, Yuna Jung

title: BAC'ATTACK
abstract: BAC'ATTACK is an innovative tool designed to combat plant viruses. This system can specifically detect viruses circulating in aphid vectors and eliminate virus-carrying aphids that pose a threat to spreading the virus across a field. It consists of a VIRBAC detection system (Virus Binding Activation Complex) expressed in Bacillus subtilis within the insect's microbiome, and the METALE system (Modulate Expression of Toxins And Lytic Enzymes), which aims to kill the aphid by secreting perforating toxins into its gut. BAC'ATTACK respects biodiversity by targeting only virus-carrying aphids, safeguards farmers' health by avoiding chemical substances, and is cost-effective for users.
students: Alice Charbonnier, Alice Olivier, Duchemin Lisa, Lila Verdu, Maurine Legland, Robin MENOU, Romain Hoareau, Thibault PERRIN

title: Engineering coral symbiotic bacteria with dynamic catalase expression systems to combat ROS induced bleaching
abstract: Coral bleaching, the discoloration of coral due to the expulsion of symbiotic microbes, is an environmental crisis that affects the Australian ecosystem, economy, and First Nations People. However, current conservation strategies are either too ineffective or slow to guarantee the survival of coral reefs. Although much research has focused on genetically engineering coral to survive heat waves, they may be slow to distribute and have permanent effects. Engineering symbiotic bacteria may be a less intrusive and fast deploying strategy to combat coral bleaching. Transgenic catalases were introduced to a bacterial model system and combined with a promoter system that responds dynamically to intercellular ROS levels. The ROS tolerance of engineered bacteria were tested under controlled conditions with H2DCFDA dyes.
advisors: Anthony Barancewicz, Dan, Hugh Ashley, Jack Dalton, Kelvin, Sabrina, Yolanda Yau
students: Ajaay, Izzy, Kyle C, KyogoS, Mikhail Danilov, Tom, Zahra

title: Proteosnail: Turning Golden Apple Snails from Pests to Helpers & Keeping up with Climate Change
abstract: Faced with the growing challenges of climate change, it's becoming increasingly important to improve the resilience of crops to extreme temperatures to secure global agriculture. Our project seeks to introduce cold shock proteins (OtsA and OtsB) and heat shock protein (HSP70) from the golden apple snail into plants using synthetic biology techniques. By initially using E. coli as the delivery vector, and later transitioning to Agrobacterium, we aim to enhance plants' ability to tolerate both cold and heat stress. This strategy is inspired by existing research on cross-kingdom gene transfer, which uses bacterial vectors to introduce stress-resistance genes from animals into plants. With this innovative approach, we hope to bolster crop survival in the face of increasingly unpredictable environmental conditions
advisors: CHUN-YU CHEN, Ju-Yi,Chiang
students: Alisa Ng, Amber, Ariel Isabel Lim, Felisha Liang, Gabriel, HSU, KAI-EN, Ling-Hsiang Kao, Olivia Hsu, Peng-Yu

title: E. Solei
abstract: E.solei is an innovative foot-care product that combines cosmetic benefits with health advantages. It features genetically modified E. coli BL21 to produce Linalool, a mono-terpene with antimicrobial, analgesic, anti-inflammatory properties, and a pleasant fragrance. The bacteria are housed in a nutritive medium placed within an insole, between layers of the foot sole. Linalool diffuses through a porous membrane, reaching the crevices and inter-digital spaces without direct bacterial contact. Using the Mevalonate pathway for Linalool production and Quorum Sensing to regulate the bacterial population, E.solei ensures sustained efficacy and a longer shelf life. Safety is prioritized with auxotrophic strains, a kill-switch, and a design that prevents bacterial escape or any harmful interaction with the foot. Additionally, we are designing the surrounding layer such that only Linalool molecules to pass through, preventing any potential bacterial contamination. This product offers an automated, low-maintenance solution for foot care, combining hygiene, comfort, and cosmetic appeal.
nominations: Best Fashion & Cosmetics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Supratim Datta, Anindita Bhadra, Susmita Roy
advisors: Aniket Sabar, Avijit Majumder, Baivab Kumar Saha, Mani Gupta, Tannistha Roy
student leaders: Fathima Anjum E C, Gitanjali Das
students: Anushka Mishra, Ayantik Kundu, Divyanshu Kumar, Sampoorn Pandey, Shamba Chakraborty, Sharanya Chatterjee, Smrutimayee Prusty, Utkarsh Aryan, Others, Aditya Kumar, Anuprovo, Arpan Gupta, Dipanwita Chowdhury, Diya Raj N, Jibitesh, Kusumita, Nandita Sriram, Tejendra Singh, Vaibhavi P

title: NuScent: Engineering Bacteria for Promote Wider Composting Adoption
abstract: One common barrier to composting is the unpleasant odors it produces, discouraging wider adoption. To address this, the NU iGEM team is using synthetic biology to engineer soil bacteria that produce pleasant scents, encouraging more people to compost and supporting urban waste reduction. We will engineer Escherichia coli to synthesize menthol, the compound responsible for the peppermint smell, by introducing the well-studied eight-step biosynthetic pathway. This scent could also deter mice, making composting more effective in urban areas. Additionally, we aim to produce linalool, a floral compound found in lavender, known to repel mice. By integrating these aroma-producing pathways into bacteria, we hope to create composting systems that smell better and function more efficiently in cities.
student leaders: Karina Millican, Mia Weisman, Zoia Okulova
students: Ankee, Annabelle Chung, Brielle Quigley, Diti Patel, Jade, JiaJia Fu, Kimberly Tso, Lavanya Gupta, Lily Bahrehmand, Navya, Oliver Stearns, Preethi Mahendrakumar, Zach Harrington

title: ReneWool: Utilizing enzymatic degradation to upcycle mixed fabric waste into spider silk in E. coli.
abstract: Fast fashion trends are accelerating the expansion of the textile industry and giving rise to a global environmental crisis. Only 15% of the 92 million tonnes of textile waste produced annually are recycled or repurposed. However, these methods are largely inefficient as they release harmful chemicals and produce carbon dioxide emission. To combat this, we have created a two-step system that uses E. coli as a chassis to produce enzymes that can efficiently degrade keratin and cellulose based mixed fabrics into its monomeric amino acid and sugar subunits, which are then used as a feedstock for the production of spider silk proteins. Functionally similar to native dragline spider silk from orb-weaver spiders, this value-added commodity is sought after in the fashion, military, aerospace, firefighting, and biomedical sectors. Through this process, our system promotes the renewal of fabrics into high-value commodities, reducing waste accumulation in landfills.
advisors: Fabian Rondon, Maryssa Iacobelli, Neel Patel, Nina Deschner, Rachael Rieberger, Soren Skaret
students: Abby Hill, Alycia Johnson, Amy Wang, Annie Tang, Anthony Shin, Ashwin Anand, Audrey Johnson, Austin Pirie, Brittany Green, Christos, Cody McCloy, Dev Patel, Ian Harding, Joy Cao, Katya Moroziuk, Kian Kyars, Nathan Correia, Neethu Dax, Nima Shariatzadeh, Raymond Kwok, Ruoyi Jia, Sajjad Syed, Venus Patel, Youssef Mohamed

title: Glyco-insideout: A new approach of protein glycosylation
abstract: Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive sphingolipidosis caused by mutations in the GBA1 gene, leading to a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme breaks down glucosylceramide into ceramide and glucose, and its deficiency results in the accumulation of glucosylceramide in macrophages, forming Gaucher cells. These cells can infiltrate organs like the bone marrow, liver, and spleen, causing anemia, bone destruction, and other dysfunctions. Treatment involves enzyme replacement therapy with imiglucerase, velaglucerase, or taliglucerase, but production is costly and limited due to the complex glycosylation process in animal or plant cells. The project proposes bioengineering microorganisms, such as Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Escherichia coli, to produce N-glycosylated proteins, including ?-glucocerebrosidase, as a proof of concept to evaluate glycosylation efficiency and therapeutic potential. This approach could reduce costs and increase access to treatment by enabling microorganisms to transfer the human-like Man3GlcNac2 polysaccharide, improving large-scale production of therapeutic enzymes.
PIs: cristiane Rodrigues Guzzo Carvalho Carvalho, Mario de Barros, Rita Ferreira
advisors: Guilherme Pompeu, Henrique, Larissa de Souza Kawanisi
student leaders: Caue Augusto Boneto Goncalves, Davi Gabriel Salustiano Merighi, Lucili Albarez Souza
students: Anna Carolina Herd Hwang, Beatriz Lauriano de Oliveira, Bianca Bossi, Bruna Sayuri Cardoso Ogusku, Edson Galdino do Nascimento Filho, Eduardo Utiyama, Eliane, Elisa Linardi, Gabrielle Narcizo Nascimento, Giovanna, Isabela Gonçalves Trevelin, Isabella, Larissa Brujas, Marcelo Mesa, Marcelo Reginato, Nathan Silva, Pedro Antônio França Henrique, Raphaela Machado, Uili Mare, Victoria, Other, Anacleto

title: OptoPACE: Developing Accessible Tools for Protein Engineering
abstract: Protein engineering is the cornerstone of novel biologics, medicines, and enzymes, with the two most common approaches being directed evolution and de novo design. Despite its importance in the field of synthetic biology, the specialized equipment, complexity of computational tools, and overall high costs limit access for researchers outside of well-funded labs. The 2024 ASU iGEM team aims to remove these barriers to entry by developing optogenetic biological circuits, low-cost bioreactor hardware, and user-friendly computational tools to open the field to new researchers.
student leaders: Kylie Hartana, Patrick Jiang, Rori Hoover
students: Abigail Tang, Alexander Egan, Brianna, Francisco, Manal Ijaz, Meghna Nair, Michelle Kim, Nicole Salazar, Ryan Crane, Sophie, Tate Isaacs

title: Poros Vaccine----a Vaccine Colonized in Fish and Secrete Antigen Protein
abstract: As global population is projected to exceed 10 billion by 2050, ensuring adequate food supply is critical. Sea fish, particularly the highly nutritious flatfish species like the large halibut, are increasingly farmed in China. However, the industry faces significant challenges from viral, bacterial, and parasitic diseases, leading to substantial fish mortality. Our research highlights a unique approach using Edwardsiella piscicida as a vaccine carrier, engineered to be non-pathogenic, guided by the predictions from large language models. We called it "Poros-vaccine," which uses harmless signal molecules to induce sequential antigen release. Initial studies indicate potential benefits, but challenges remain in vaccine efficacy and public acceptance. Ongoing outreach efforts have improved understanding and acceptance among various demographics. With further optimization and clinical trials, our project aims to contribute significantly to sustainable aquaculture and intelligent agriculture.
PIs: Qiyao Wang, Hui Wu, Jiaofang Huang, Mian Zhou, Pengfei Li, Peng Zuo, Shuai Shao, Yibei Zhang, Youyuan Li, Yue Ma
instructors: Jianhua Fan, Xiao Wu, Yue Peng
students: Ameng, Bernie, Cherry, Haibin Zhu, hanyufeng, Haoning Jia, Jialuo Wang, Jiawei E, Jiming Fu, Linguo Jin, Linjie Ji, mm, QinYue Zhang, Ruoyi Zhang, WanShu Lai, Xinling Shen, Xiran Yang, Yao Liu, Yipeng Ye, Yiyang Gu, Zhenyue Huang, ??, ??

title: RePET: turning plastic pollution into valuable resources
abstract: At RePET, we tackle the global crisis of plastic pollution with groundbreaking solutions. Using advanced biotechnological methods, we break down harmful plastics like PET and transform them into biodegradable alternatives, such as PHA, by using bacterial technology in the form of both enzymes and live bacteria. Our project is built on the principles of the circular economy, ensuring that waste is not just managed but converted into valuable resources.
nominations: Best Measurement, Undergrad
advisors: Álvaro D. Ortega Moreno, Jessica Gil Serna, Selene Pérez García, Sonia Mato Díaz
students: Álvaro Ferrero Veintemilla, Patricia Mayo Magro, Paula Sánchez-Blanco Sánchez, Paula Sánchez Custodio, Rafael Jiménez Juárez, Raúl Marín Torralba

title: PET TWINS -PETase The Way to ImplementatioN Success-
abstract: Concerned about the microplastic problem and uncovering various issues in plastic recycling through numerous interviews, Waseda-Tokyo has proposed PET TWINS (PETase The Way to ImplementatioN Success) as a new approach to realize the practical application of PETase. It consists of two components: the BIND-PETase Module and the ElectroCount Biosafety Module. BIND-PETase Module is expected to promote plastic recycling in the future, contributing actively to waste disposal problems and the resolution of the microplastic issue. Additionally, based on evolutionary engineering insights, Waseda-Tokyo designed BIND-bearPETase and verified its superior functionality through wet experiments, energy simulations, and mathematical models. Furthermore, we introduced the concept of the ElectroCount Biosafety Module, which induces the expression of two genes through electrical input. This system is expected to deal with barriers to the introduction of BIND-PETase, and its feasibility has been validated through mathematical models. The integrated system, PET TWINS, will drive the social implementation of PETase.
awards: Top 10+Best Bioremediation Project+Best New Composite Part
nominations: Best Model, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad
advisors: Daisuke Kiga, Sota Okuda
students: Ayaka Sasaki, Chiharu Seida, Daisuke Kondo, Eito Yamamoto, Hanna Watanabe, Haruka Harada, Haruka Nakamura, Itsuki Togawa, Joseph Yokobori, Jun Kawabata, Juri Kawazu, Masahiro Chiba, Ryota Abe, Ryoto Miyamoto, Sei Tsukamura, Sena Takahashi, Shietsu KO, Shota Yamamoto, Sodai Nao, Taito Horiuchi, Tomoyo Handa, Victoria Toko Okazaki, Wakana Namba, Yuko Ota, Yuto Toriyama

title: BOROHMA: A L-Borneol-based Minicell Insect-Repellent Fragrance.
abstract: Our island home, the tropical country of Taiwan, is seasonally plagued by insects such as mosquitoes, ticks, flies, and mites. During the hot and humid summer months, mosquitoes and other insects breed in abundance, causing anything from minor itches to infectious diseases. Conventional active ingredients in insect-repellents such as DEET, while effective and cheap, have an unpleasant odor, cause allergies, and aren't environmentally friendly. As a country with an increasingly vibrant lifestyle, we also noticed the ever-rising popularity of fragrances. Our project, BOROHMA, combines insect-repellency and great aroma to create a customizable insect-repellent fragrance; we do so by biosynthesizing L-borneol, a pleasant-smelling and insect-repelling camphor derivative, and encapsulating it into specially engineered bacterial minicell to create a safe borneol-release system. This system is then mixed with different ingredients to craft smells that people love. By using borneol, we also honor our country's booming camphor industry in the early 20th century.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School
instructors: Bryan Tsai, Tim Chao, Y-C Liao
advisors: Edward Lu, Kenneth Hsiau, Ruei Jie Hu, Wayne Chen
students: Alston Chang, Alvin Chung, Athena Pong, Cindy, Daniel Kua, Ella, Emily, Emma, Enyu Hsu, Eric Lin, Jenson Huang, Jocelyn Weng, julie, Justin, Nina, Phoebe, Sophie, Timothy, Youshin Loh, Yu-Li He

title: AQUASENS - FRET Biosensor for Emerging Contaminants
abstract: By 2050, the global population will grow by 2 billion, increasing pressure on freshwater resources. Currently, agriculture consumes 92% of the world's water, jeopardizing food systems due to rising competition. Wastewater reuse becomes critical, but 80% is not properly treated, and 11% of crops, especially in the Global South, rely on it. In Mexico, only 5.4% of wastewater is reused, with limited research on emerging contaminants. To tackle this issue, we present Aquasens, a portable system that efficiently detects water contaminants using FRET technology. It features a biosensor that identifies changes in fluorescence when contaminants are detected in a sample. In this project, we present lab results using a FRET system to detect rifampicin, cadmium, and ibuprofen, along with a new version of the device from the previous team. We also conducted social activities to raise awareness about Jalisco's water situation and developed a business plan for future commercialization.
PIs: Julio Cesar López Velázquez, J. Donato Garcia-Garcia
student leaders: Ana Paula Valle Arce, Enia Verónica Montaño Del Muro, Faith Guadalupe Rodríguez Sánchez, Jorge Armando Soto Sandoval, Juan Pablo Muñoz Villaseñor, María José Gómez Carrillo, Pamela Sánchez Arellano
students: Adhara Renata Cruz Tenorio, Alesandra Almada Puig, Ana Benavente Zermeño, Andres Benjamin Antelis Moreno, Cecilia Gabriela Cruz Pérez, Clarissa Lizbeth Duarte Araque, Diego Cota Barocio, Fernanda Valdez Lozada, Isaías Arturo Murillo Martínez, Jesús Alexis Ruiz Zavala, Jimena Arguello Valadez, Juan Osvaldo Sanchez Valdivia, Karen Dayana Delgadillo Piña, Kathia Paulina Pedroza González, Liliana Karely Aguilar Sánchez, Regina González Pérez, Rubén Valenzuela Sánchez, Valeria Mata Silva

title: PCas-Detect & Kill Prostate Cancer in one fell swoop
abstract: Prostate cancer is often diagnosed only after symptoms appear, and existing screening methods tend to be either costly or unreliable. Our goal is to develop a new, affordable, and user-friendly screening technique that also targets and eliminates prostate cancer cells. We use PSMA as a biomarker to detect these cells, and a plasmid that triggers the release of Gaussia Luciferase (GluC) in the patient's urine. Additionally, the plasmid promotes the release of an apoptosis regulator (Bax) to help kill the cancer cells. Another important aspect of our project is education. We have created a lesson plan aimed at sparking junior secondary students' interest in synthetic biology and encouraging their future involvement in the field. Teaching these students in September also provides us with valuable insights from them.
PIs: Fung Chi Tuen, LIN MEI YU, Vincent Tse
advisors: Mok Pui Fung
students: Anvin Fu, Cheung Wing Tung, Chong Tsz Shun, Chung Yin Ivan Chong, Ho Chun Chan, HO PAK LONG, Howard Lam, Kwan Cheuk Kiu, Lau Chin Wan, Marco Kwong, Matthew Chan, Paak Hei Cheung, Ryan Shih, Skye Wong, Tsz Yung Leung, TY Yip, Wai Ching Cheng, Wong Chi Wang, Wong Pak Yin, Wong Tsz Wing, Yeung Cheuk To, Yiu Yat Pun, Yuen Shan Chan, Yu Lok Man

title: Aroma Alchemists: Optimising vanillin biosynthesis in E.coli
abstract: Vanillin is an aromatic aldehyde used in food, beverage and cosmetics applications. Worldwide consumption exceeds 16,000 tons annually, with 0.25% from natural extraction from vanilla orchid pods, and the remainder from organic chemical synthesis. The biotechnological production of vanillin offers a promising alternative. In this project, we design and test four different biosynthesis gene clusters to manufacture vanillin from tyrosine in bacteria, using a cumate-inducible control system and a low-copy number broad-host-range plasmid; preliminary LC-MS data indicate that we were successful in making small amounts of vanillin, and that the caffeate-> ferulate reaction (COMT) was rate-limiting in our system. Further evidence for functional expression of the HpaBC monooxygenase was seen from production of a brown melanin-type dye as a side-reaction; we believe this indicates that HpaBC is acting on tyrosine (to make L-DOPA, which polymerises) in addition to the intended reaction on 4-coumarate to make caffeate.
students: Ainaz, Faith Marian Orbeta, Faiza Chowdhury, Jack Ryan, Jenny Dang, Sara

title: Healios: A Brighter Future for Healing
abstract: This year, the OKstate iGEM team created Healios, a novel treatment designed for the targeted destruction of multidrug-resistant bacterial pathogens, such as Staphylococcus aureus. Healios uses an engineered M13 phage to target specific bacteria. The non-infective phage can be conjugated with Rose-Bengal, a photosensitizing dye, which, when activated by a free-moving LED lamp, produces reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill the bacteria. Due to time limitations, we were unable to complete the pilot system, but we have clearly documented all our designs on the wiki. Throughout the year, the OKState team actively engaged with scientific experts and received valuable advice on project design and how Healios can extend beyond the bench. Importantly, the impact and potential of synthetic biology in public health were demonstrated by engaging K-12 students in the local community. We are OKState Healios!
PIs: Paul Kirchberger, Kevin Wilson, Ihsiu Huang
advisors: Alex, Kali Ware
students: Adriahna Blackburn, Austin Ashley, Cheyenne, Dustin, Ethan, Ike, Jacob, Jenny Le, Jester, Josh, Julia, Kevin, Lucas Boren, Melissa, Tariq, Trenton Ratts

title: LuminiTouch: A novel mechanoluminesence biosensor
abstract: Inspired by bioluminescent bay, Jilin-China developed a novel mechanoluminescent hydrogel biosensor. Using luciferase-producing bacteria in sodium alginate hydrogels, the material converts pressure into light. This is a novel approach to translating pressure into light, with applications ranging from eco-friendly touchscreens to cost-effective heart rate monitors, and beyond. We believe it will advance technology and illuminate everyone's future.
PIs: Yan Chen, Ali Hou, Yang Zhan
students: Chengyu, Coraline Cai, Feiran Yu, Junrui Zhang, Kaiwen Zheng, Minglu, Muxi Han, shihong li, wanghongyang, Wang Shuai, Xuanjie Jiang, Xu Yichen, Yalin Zhu, Yu Fu, YUXUAN WANG, ZhangRonggang

title: Engineered E. coli for Comprehensive Glyphosate Degradation via Transport, C-P Cleavage, and AMPA Detoxification
abstract: This project aims to create genetically engineered E. coli strains for efficient and comprehensive glyphosate degradation. The system integrates three key modules: a glyphosate transport mechanism using the phnE1 and phnE2 genes to facilitate rapid uptake, a degradation pathway via phnJ for C-P bond cleavage that converts glyphosate into non-toxic phosphate and glycine, and an AMPA detoxification system employing the phnO gene to further degrade the harmful byproduct aminomethylphosphonic acid (AMPA). Together, these modules ensure efficient glyphosate absorption, degradation, and detoxification. Experimental data confirm the strain's ability to significantly reduce glyphosate and AMPA levels, providing an environmentally friendly solution for herbicide contamination in agricultural settings.
students: CQaoz808, Dian, Matthew, Tom, zhuyuanzhang, ???

title: Engineered Bacteria for Efficient Phosphate Adsorption and Recovery
abstract: This study focuses on developing an engineered phosphate recovery system using two bacterial strains. The first system, PhosLock 1.0, utilizes ice nucleation protein (INP) to anchor phosphate-binding proteins (PBP) on the cell surface, allowing efficient phosphate adsorption. The second system, PhosRegen 2.0, optimizes PBP secretion using the PelB signal peptide, which guides PBP into the extracellular medium. Both systems were experimentally validated for phosphate adsorption and desorption under varying pH and temperature conditions. PhosLock 1.0 demonstrated efficient phosphate binding, but faced challenges with bacterial stability. PhosRegen 2.0 addressed these limitations by coupling PBP with NHS-activated beads, improving both adsorption and desorption efficiency. This dual approach offers a promising solution for wastewater phosphate recovery and lays the foundation for scalable, sustainable environmental remediation technologies.
students: jg, kxsn1379, Olivia, Siyu Jin, xiongziliang, Yvonne, yweif

title: ALIVE: ESTER as the next-gen solution for endocrine disruptors in wastewater
abstract: The contamination of aquatic environments with 17?-ethinylestradiol (EE2) presents serious ecological and public health concerns due to its endocrine-disrupting effects. To address this issue, we have engineered a novel transcriptional regulatory protein, the Estrogen-Sensitive Transcriptional Element Regulator (ESTER), designed to selectively activate gene expression in the presence of EE2. Several computational tools, including AlphaFold 3, Rosetta, and Chimera, were employed to design this EE2-sensitive protein.
PIs: Jesus Hernandez-Perez, Cesar Armando Puente Garza
advisors: David Melendez
students: Daniela Machiana, Diego Hernández Ynurreta, Eduardo Betancourt, Jacqueline Cruz, Jazmín del Real, Jose David Ovalle Jaimes, Karla Sofia, Nadia Colodro, Oderay, Paulina Lopez Verduzco, Rogelio Lara, Romina

title: CBDynamics: Optimization of the Synthetic Production of Cannabidiol
abstract: In recent years, cannabidiol (CBD) has gained significant recognition in the medical field as a key component as an adjuvant in treatments for various conditions, including psychotherapeutic therapies. However, in Brazil, the cultivation and commercialization of Cannabis sativa, the plant source of CBD, face strict legal restrictions. This project proposes an alternative method to produce CBD using synthetic biology, bypassing the need for the plant. The plan involves synthesizing cannabidiol through recombinant gene technology in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (yeast), which will express cannabidiolic acid (CBDA), a precursor of CBD. The process utilizes two metabolic pathways: the geranyl diphosphate (GPP) pathway and the olivetolic acid pathway. These precursors are combined in enzymatic reactions to form cannabigerolic acid, which is then converted into CBDA. The CBDA can be purified and transformed into CBD, offering a more efficient production method without the legal complications of Cannabis cultivation.
advisors: Jean Lucas Ribeiro, Pedro Ribeiro Faria
student leaders: Gustavo Nascimento de Araujo, Júlia Lóris Senosien Redígolo
students: Annah Gabriela Carneiro, Beatriz Rodrigues Padula, Bianca Henriques de Oliveira, Edison Henrique Pimentel Serapião Batalha, Gabriela Tanaka Kiura, Larissa Miyuki Katsumata, Luisa Kuymjian Belentani, Luiz Ribeiro, Manuela Bernardes de Oliveira, Maria Luiza Gamboa, Marina Querino Andraus, Maryana Bizarria da Silva, Sophia Carboni Tavares, Thiago Gugliotta Kimaid

title: Smart Sweets
abstract: The global issue of obesity continues to rise, affecting numerous countries. In China, for instance, more than 20% of adults are overweight. Obesity contributes to various health problems, including hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and diabetes, posing significant risks to human health. One of the leading causes of obesity is excessive sugar consumption, yet many struggle to reduce their sugar intake. To address this, our team has proposed a practical solution aimed at lowering calorie consumption. This year, we have developed a synthesis method for producing low-calorie sugars by converting widely available glucose into tagatose, a healthier alternative. Through this approach, we hope to combat the obesity epidemic globally.
advisors: Xiaoyu Zhang

title: Containing chemical tablet is helpful in repairing damaged esophageal epithelial cells after hot pot
abstract: Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is a serious health concern, especially for people who enjoy hot pot. In our previous study, by analyzing blood samples and sophageal cancer tissue from clinical ESCC patients, we screened out sensitive proteins related with fatty acid metabolism, which were necessary in repairing esophageal epithelial cells injury, the level of functional protein played key roles in inhibiting inflammation and malignant lesions in esophageal tissues. Thus, in our present project, we firstly designed exogenous plasmid and constructed a high-level expression system in Escherichia coli, to express high-level of functional protein. Then the protein nanoparticles were prepared with oleanolic acid. Through constructing esophageal epithelial cells injury model, the relieving effects of MFG-E8 protein was evaluated in vitro. By this method, MFG-E8 protein is eventually integrated into containing tablets, which effectively alleviates esophageal epithelial cells damages caused by hot and spicy stimuli, and reduces the incidence of ESCC.
advisors: Huishuang Tan, Riva Yan
student leaders: Cindy Ma, Flora, ?HANHANHUI, Mandy Ma, Xinwen Zhang

title: Rose flavonoids tea bags help circadian rhythms disrupted people staying away from AD
abstract: Due to increased pressures, staying up late and insomnia have become common across all age groups. This chronic circadian rhythms disruptions are proven to accelerate pathological progression of Alzheimer's disease (AD). What can we do in suppressing the adverse progression? In our previous study, by using an AD mouse model with artificially disrupted circadian rhythms, we proved that rose flavonoids had significant inhibitory effects on the adverse progression. Thus, in the present project, we create "ROSE" plan to develop functional tea drinks and alleviates circadian rhythms disruption injuries, including: Firstly, Recreate an cellular AD model with A?42 protein; secondely, Observe and identify specific genes by transcriptomics; thirdly, Supplement rose flavonoids into cells and measure expression levels of protein and signal pathway; lastly, Evaluate the inhibitory effects on AD progression and prepare functional tea. Our team innovatively provides dietary intake regulations in reducing AD risk of circadian rhythms disrupted people.
PIs: Yufan Liu, Jihang Cai, Yu Han

title: "Jeans Care Kit" , an Eco-Friendly and Cost-Effective Way to DIY Your Jeans
abstract: Denim jeans, a timeless fashion staple, often require treatments like bleaching, fraying, and stain removal. Traditional methods, such as chemical bleaching and mechanical fraying, pose environmental and health risks, including water pollution and excessive resource use. To address this, our iGEM team, "New Jeans," developed an enzyme-based solution using engineered E. coli BL21. We produce laccase for bleaching, cellulase for fraying, lipase for stain removal, and catalase to boost laccase efficiency. This eco-friendly "Jeans Care Kit" reduces chemical reliance, cuts water usage, and allows consumers to customize denim care at home. Our approach promotes sustainability by extending denim's lifespan and reducing waste, with cost-effective large-scale enzyme production.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, High School
students: Dean, Guiping Huang, Kaylee, Lin, Marcel, Thomaswang, YunZhi Lin

title: A Dual-Plasmid Biosensor for Copper Ion Detection Using Synthetic Biology
abstract: Copper ion contamination is an increasing threat in China, affecting food safety and agriculture. In response, we developed a dual-plasmid biosensor using synthetic biology to detect copper ions. Our system employs the E. coli endogenous copper sensor CueR to regulate a signal plasmid. Upon binding with copper, CueR activates the pCopA promoter, expressing a fluorescent protein, mVenus, in proportion to copper concentration. Additionally, we fine-tuned the system using a promoter library for CueR overexpression. This portable, low-cost biosensor offers a reliable solution for monitoring copper pollution, ensuring safer food and water for consumers.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School
advisors: Jay
student leaders: EasonFang, Sarah Huang, Yin Richard, yixin shi, Yu, Zihe Chen
students: Aria, Bienna, Connor, fengziyu, guoyanzi, Jessica Liang, Jessie Jiang, Kelsey, Liam Zhao, Ma Dongyang, Olivia Lu, rangjiu, Ruby, Ryan Z, Sam Chen, VickyWu, Vincent, Wangxinzhao, yanghaoxiang

title: Open-Source Modular POCT System for Multi-Biomarker Detection & Future Expansion
abstract: Our team initially addressed the challenges of chronic disease management, focusing on hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, and obesity. We developed a home-based Point-of-Care Testing (POCT) system for detecting key biomarkers like glucose and uric acid using plasmid-based biosensors engineered with synthetic biology. These biosensors offer enhanced accuracy and reduced recalibration compared to traditional electrochemical methods. To complement the biosensors, we designed a hardware platform that seamlessly integrates with biomarker detection. Human practices shaped the system's key performance specifications, such as affordability, compactness, and biosafety. As the project evolved, we incorporated modularity, allowing for multi-biomarker detection and scalability. This flexible, open-source platform enables easy biomarker replacement and broader health applications, contributing to future innovations in personalized diagnostics and for the iGEM community..
nominations: Best New Composite Part, High School+Best Hardware, High School+Best Integrated Human Practices, High School
advisors: Daniel Zang, Jay

title: Modular Bacterial Cellulose Modification Machine in Use and AI Safety Framework in Synthetic Biology
abstract: LCG-China 2024 enhanced the 2014 Imperial College bacterial cellulose modification system by resolving legacy issues and developing a modular decoupling platform to improve protein-cellulose interactions. Our system incorporates a bacterial cellulose scaffold (curlisfiber-spytag) with fusion proteins (spycatcher-fusion protein of interest), allowing for efficient binding of proteins that typically do not bind with cellulose. This modular design supports future upgrades of individual components, increasing the system's versatility for various applications. Utilizing this platform, we developed a biodegradable adhesive bandage functionalized with antimicrobial peptides, addressing limitations of traditional wound care products. Additionally, to ensure safe AI use in synthetic biology, we established an AI safety policy guideline and a proposal specifically for the iGEM community, providing a robust framework to mitigate risks in AI-driven bioengineering projects.

title: OneRing Oxford - Combatting AMR using Conjugative Transfer of Modular Plasmid for Targeted Bacterial Elimination
abstract: The rise of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) presents a critical global challenge, demanding innovative approaches to combat resistant bacterial strains. With the deluge of new AMR bacteria and the slowdown in antibiotic discovery, the human and economic cost of AMR is increasing at a worrying pace. Our project addresses this by leveraging the RP4 conjugation system to selectively transfer the engineered OneRing plasmid into target bacteria. This modular plasmid encodes CRISPR-Cas12a and a guide RNA array, enabling targeted bacterial killing through precise DNA cleavage. This precision ensures a targeted approach to bacterial killing without harming surrounding bacteria in the microbiome. By modifying the guide RNA array, OneRing can be adapted to tackle various types of bacteria. This versatility allows for a range of applications across human health and livestock farming. Our design's modularity also enables future expansion to address diverse bacterial challenges in other fields.
nominations: Best Infectious Diseases Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
students: Aritra, Devon Darley, Dima, Eunice Ho, Julia Tondera, Vedat Habib Papo

title: AflaxOFF: facing an unknown threat
abstract: Aflatoxin B1 is a potent mycotoxin produced by Aspergillus fungi, which is commonly found in cereals and feeds, posing significant risks to public health and the food industry. Its persistence through high temperatures and food processing makes it challenging to eliminate. Chronic exposure to AFB1, even in small amounts, can accumulate in the body and increase the risk of liver cancer and other diseases by damaging DNA through its reactive metabolite, AFB1-exo 8,9-epoxide (AFBO). The AflaxOFF project addresses this issue by engineering Saccharomyces cerevisiae to act as a biosensor, providing early detection of AFB1 contamination in food, as well as a probiotic, preventing AFB1 absorption in the intestines, thereby protecting both humans and animals from the toxin. AflaxOFF actively engages with stakeholders, including farmers and food industry professionals, to ensure that the technology meets real-world needs and fosters community awareness about AFB1 risks.
instructors: Alonso Molina Calvo, Antonia Belén Del Valle Fierro, Carmen Jiménez Amores, Paola Morales Gonzalez, Patricia Zarza Herrero, Piedad Valverde Guillén

students: Adrián Gómez Lara, Álvaro Acedo Espejo, Jimena García Arca, Juan Antonio de la Cruz Bellido, Lucía Aguilar Rosso, Lucía Campos Sánchez, Pablo Fernández Serrano, Rubén Ipiña Rivas, Víctor Cerván Bueno

title: Iravi
abstract: The project tackles the public health challenge posed by high UV Index levels in Vellore, Tamil Nadu, which contribute to around 300,000 annual cases of non-melanoma skin cancer. While traditional sunscreens effectively block UV radiation, they often contain harmful chemicals that can disrupt hormones and damage the environment. This project proposes engineering Escherichia coli to overexpress genes in the Xanthophyll pathway, enabling the production of carotenoids like zeaxanthin and violaxanthin. These natural pigments offer antioxidant properties and can be integrated into skincare products for broad-spectrum UV protection. By employing recombinant DNA technology, this project aims to provide eco-friendly alternatives to chemical synthesis, addressing both skin health and environmental sustainability. The incorporation of these carotenoids into cosmetics aligns with the rising demand for safe, plant-based beauty solutions, ultimately contributing to a healthier market in India while mitigating skin cancer risks associated with UV exposure.
students: Aadithya Hrudhay Anand, Ananya Pai, D K Harish Naaraayan, Johan George Varghese, Mohak Bhattacharyya, Naisarg Patel, Neha Sivakumar, Prakriti Shah, Suchita Lathe, Swasti Tyagi, Tanvi Duarah, Tejaswini Deshmukh, Urvi Sinha, Utkarsh Srivastava

title: Integrated Bioremediation of Petroleum Contamination Using Engineered Microbes and Plants
abstract: Our project addresses the critical issue of petroleum pollution by developing an innovative bioremediation system. We engineered E. coli and B. subtilis to degrade residual oil using enzymes like AlkM and laccase, while also enhancing efficiency with surfactants. Additionally, we integrated plant-microbe cooperation by utilizing E. coli to produce the plant hormone IAA, promoting phytoremediation. To ensure biosafety, we incorporated a suicide system to prevent gene leakage. This multi-faceted approach offers a sustainable and scalable solution for addressing petroleum contamination.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, High School+Best Sustainable Development Impact, High School+Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School
students: Claire, Jenny, Jiayun Sheng, Jolly, Libra Xie, Muyang Kong, Peter, Pingkang Ding, Queeny, Ribera, Sara, Shanning, Siqi Wang, xingyu chen, Zhengda Wang

title: In Silico and In Vitro Models of Bone Marrow Pathophysiology in a Septic State
abstract: To further the global understanding of sepsis, our team developed in silico and in vitro bone marrow organoid models. In silico, we were able to successfully simulate the growth and differentiation of induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) into a healthy steady-state iPSC-derived bone marrow organoid. We also implemented a pathogenic function into the model and achieved states of aseptic death and full recovery to an altered equilibrium. This model predicted and quantified the immune system's cellular and inflammatory response to a sepsis-like infection. Additionally, we improved the biomanufacturing of in vitro iPSC-derived bone marrow organoids by optimizing iPSC culture and organoid production techniques. We established an improved four-phase differentiation protocol that enhanced aggregation, oxygen level tolerance, organoid viability, and morphology. The development of these dual ex vivo platforms provides deeper understanding of the cellular changes triggered by sepsis in human bone marrow.
student leaders: Alexandra Davidov, Caleb Faison, Julia Jamieson
students: Abigail Leon, Anuj Master, Isabella Morse, Jae Sarner, Jonathan French, Kalyan Ratnakaram, Lucy Pellenbarg, Michelle Lee, Sanandan Ojha, Sharad Patel, Shuyu Chen, Tyler Montgomery

title: ScabBrewer: Modifying yeast to detoxify deoxynivalenol while brewing beer
abstract: Beer, a popular alcoholic beverage, uses grains like barley, oats, and wheat, which can be affected by Fusarium head blight (FHB) in warm, humid conditions. FHB, also known as scab, produces mycotoxin DON, posing a threat to human health and economies. It is urged to seek control methods to eliminate DON pollution in foods and feeds. We engineered a new yeast with extrachromosomal plasmids to separately enhance the cell wall adsorption and the DON enzymatic degradation efficiency in Saccharomyces pastorianus. To analyze the molecular mechanism of yeast DON adsorption and discover gene loci related to yeast's ability to adsorb DON, we constructed a model to predict the DON adsorption ability of different yeasts.
advisors: Pengchao Wang
students: chenzixin, guojiajia, Haichuan Dong, Jiayu Shen, Junjie Liu, Juntong Zhu, Lu Jiahe, Luyao Yu, Mengdi Xu, Mengyao Qi, Qiaoxin Wang, ROY chen, Xiaolei Zhang, Xiao Ma, Xiaoqi Li, xieyuyan, Xin Ruan, Xinyue Huang, Xinyue Zhao, Xiran Wang, Yichong Zhu, ???

title: LETHE
abstract: The Lethe project proposes a new therapeutic approach in gene therapy for the treatment and management of Alzheimer's Disease. By targeting the dephosphorylation of tau proteins, we increase the chances halting the disease and reversing the underlying neurodegenerative course. Our goal is to enhance the activity of the phosphatase PP2A, which is related to the process of tau dephosphorylation. This up-regulation will be facilitated indirectly by microRNA-195, a molecule associated with various pathological processes of the disease. We will introduce microRNA-195 into nerve cells using rAAV-carrying exosomes, modified with the RVG29 peptide that binds specifically to target nerve cells. These modified exosomes will interact with the surface of the target cells and release rAAVs expressing microRNA-195, inhibiting the processes responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.
nominations: Best Therapeutics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad
instructors: Konstantina Nika, Nikolaos Savvopoulos, Sylvia Mangani

title: ACQuIRE: Adaptive Cell-Free Quorum Integrated Release Engine
abstract: Adaptive Cell-Free Quorum Integrated Release Engine (ACQuIRE) is a modular platform designed to improve safety and scalability in synthetic biology, particularly for bioremediation and biomanufacturing. ACQuIRE encapsulates engineered Escherichia coli within biocompatible PEG-Ficoll protocells, enabling controlled protein production and quorum sensing-triggered lysis at a defined population density. This system enhances biosafety by retaining genetic material within the protocell, reducing the risk of horizontal gene transfer. ACQuIRE offers a reliable alternative to traditional kill switches, utilizing a density-dependent lysis mechanism to minimize the risk of mutations and uncontrolled proliferation. The platform's use of minimal media reduces autofluorescence and side reactions, improving experimental clarity and reproducibility. ACQuIRE provides a scalable, standardized method for safe and controlled production of genetically modified organisms, addressing critical challenges in synthetic biology.

title: Double-stranded RNA Sentinels: Guarding Against Rhizoctonia solani
abstract: Corn sheath blight caused by Rhizoctonia solani is one of the most destructive fungal diseases, causing serious losses to corn grain production. Although traditional chemical fungicides can effectively resist sheath blight, they also bring a series of environmental and other problems. Spraying double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) to induce gene silencing (SIGS) is a potential new tool for sustainable and environmentally friendly plant disease control. This project designed a sequence that can target and silence pathogenicity-related genes, RsCAT (R. solani catalase), constructed it into an expression vector, and used E. coli HT115(DE3) to produce dsRNA. Experiments have shown that after spraying RsCAT-dsRNA, the transcription level of the RsCAT gene was downregulated, and corn showed obvious disease resistance. In summary, Our project not only provides a novel strategy for the management of corn sheath blight but also carries significant potential for broad-spectrum application in the control of a variety of crop diseases.

title: Cellular Homeostasis Balancer
abstract: Our team has created a modular, tunable mRNA platform tool that empowers the platform with cell-selective and protein-regulatory functionality.

title: SUPERMOM: Protecting Infants by Detecting and Detoxifying Harmful Contaminants in Breast Milk
abstract: The breastmilk meant to nurture new life could be exposing infants to invisible dangers - But what if we could change that? Breastmilk can be contaminated with endocrine disrupting contaminants (EDCs) like BPA, PCBs, and dioxins. These harmful compounds can accumulate in breastmilk and pose a risk to infants. Without proper disposal, these toxins can cause long-term health issues. Inspired by the liver, we present SUPERMOM, a yeast-based contaminant-induced system that detects and detoxifies harmful EDCs in breastmilk. SUPERMOM uses biosensors and phase I and phase II liver detoxifying enzymes to keep breastmilk safe for infants. We envision SUPERMOM to be integrated into everyday breastfeeding products, such as milk bottles or nipple shields, through a dual-layer encapsulation system. This system ensures that while breastmilk interacts with SUPERMOM, the yeast remains securely contained, offering parents a safe and effective way to detect and detoxify contaminated breastmilk.
nominations: Best Food & Nutrition Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Best Part Collection, Overgrad+Best Model, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad
advisors: Matteo Soana, Nanna Heinz
students: Celine, Christian, Fabio, Kara, Kate Escobar, Kristine Aspehaug Høyen, Louise, Stavaniya, Thanh, Victor Bay

title: Increasing the Thermostability of RuBisCO Activase for Increased Crop Yield
abstract: As global temperatures increase, human populations rise, and food insecurity worsens, there is a need for immediate action to sustain humanity. Scientists aim to increase crop yield to battle the current circumstances, focusing on improving RuBisCO, a key enzyme in photosynthesis. However, they often overlook RuBisCO's chaperone RuBisCo activase (RCA) which creates thermal limitations. The activase regulates the activity of RuBisCO by removing inhibitory sugar phosphates, RuBP, from RuBisCO's active sites to maintain RuBisCO's catalytically active form. While RuBisCO is thermostable at temperatures above the optimal carbon dioxide assimilation rate, RCA is highly heat-sensitive, so our project aims to enhance RCA's heat resistance. To detect the heat-sensitive regions of RCA, we used machine learning (MutCompute) and implemented point mutations in those regions. Though we were unable to use our assays due to time constraints, our research serves as a strong foundation for further study on this topic.
students: Amrita Rai, Anna Huang, Anushree Thirukumaran, Brian Altrichter, Burak Unlu, Dharshini Senthil Nathan, Doruk Elbeyli, Elaine Zuo, Erin Kang, Rohan Sivva, Subiksha Srinivasan Vidya

title: Agropip
abstract: This project aims to develop an environmentally friendly pesticide that poses less risk to human health compared to existing products in Cosalá, Sinaloa, Mexico. We will use Saccharomyces cerevisiae for the production of piperamides, bioactive compounds derived from black pepper (Piper nigrum). These piperamides have been proven effective against the larvae and eggs of the fall armyworm (Spodoptera frugiperda), the most significant pest of maize in Mexico and globally. We have integrated insights from climate experts, politicians, farmers, and other stakeholders to shift our perspective towards considering sustainable alternatives. We don't just embrace our solution; we embrace solving the problem. Our diverse models provide strong evidence that bioinformatics and mathematics are powerful tools for developing impactful solutions, from differential expression analysis to molecular dynamics simulations and ODEs simulations.
advisors: Carlos, Christopher, Cyn, Edith Lozano Perez, Heriberto Prado, Itchel
students: Gerardo Cendejas, Israel Castro, Lilia, Santiago Jara, Sofia Villarreal, Tatei Werika Wimari

title: Coli Bond
abstract: Our project, "Coli Bond," explores an innovative approach to information security by leveraging genetically engineered E. coli bacteria. We developed a method to encode data within DNA sequences, disguising the information as natural protein sequences to evade detection. To enhance security, we designed a multi-layered system that ensures bacterial strains only grow under specific conditions and includes a self-destruction mechanism triggered by elevated temperatures. This prevents unauthorized access and maintains data integrity. Additionally, our project addresses the challenges of encoding complex logographic languages like Chinese by integrating unique input methods. Our work demonstrates a promising application of synthetic biology in the field of information security, combining advanced genetic engineering with practical data protection strategies.
advisors: Kristin Liang, Susu, Wanbin Xing
student leaders: Jinchen Han, Jingxuan Hu, Sonia Song, Vanessa Xue Er Hu, Xuefeng Xiao
students: Jerry Wu, Jin Chen, Kaiyun Cao, Kalin, Kayuet Hu, Menglu Shen, Shenghao Zhao, Xinyue Cao, Xizheng Zhou, Xujia Dong, Yue Fei, Yuze Zhang, Zixin Zhou

title: Youth Magic?the Skin's Time Machine
abstract: The program aims to address skin aging in menopausal women due to a decline in estrogen. For menopausal women, estrogen is especially important in skin care, and common beauty and skin care products on the market do not solve this problem. Our team selected E. coli Nissle 1917 as the chassis microorganism and constructed three systems, including genistein production system, bacterial cellulose production system, and light-controlled induced suicide system. Genistein can supplement estrogen, bacterial cellulose is used for hydration, and the light-controlled suicide induced suicide system ensures biosecurity. Through special production and use methods, the products provide a safe and efficient skin care experience for middle-aged and elderly women.We are also actively promoting STEM education for women, helping them to achieve holistic growth from the inside out.
nominations: Inclusivity Award, High School
advisors: Jingjing
student leaders: QIN SIQI, RUI HUANG, Tommy, Weihan Song, WuWenYi, Zhang XuDong
students: Anne Qin, Fance Gao, Gai Yuxian, JackH, JIAJUN WENG, Jia Ting Yu, Jiazi Ran, Jinze Lyu, Junyu Gan, Lin Kexin, Liwenle, Min Zhou, Yifan Zhang, Yiting Wang, Yuan Kun, Yuru Wang, Zheng jiabei, ZHIHAO HE, zhouxinyi

title: Joy-filled Drink - the application of kaempferol and GABA
abstract: The JIASHU-SouthChina team is developing an innovative solution for stress relief and depression management through the Joy-filled Drink project. By engineering E. coli Nissle 1917, we have successfully produced kaempferol and GABA, two compounds known for their positive effects on mood and mental health. To optimize kaempferol production, we explored the use of fusion enzymes and tested various linkers (GGGS, GGGS2, TPTP, TPTP2), identifying those that significantly improved the kaempfero yield. Additionally, we examined the impact of multi-copy genes and found that F3H boosts production while FLS has the opposite effect. Our vision is to integrate these compounds into fruit tea, bringing an accessible and natural option for emotional well-being to the market. This project showcases the power of synthetic biology in addressing mental health challenges.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School
advisors: sissie, zhaoqingqing
student leaders: Chen tingyi, Dikangluo, Ganchuhan, Qingyue Hu, Ye zi han, Zhao hanyi

title: ClusterControl
abstract: We are developing modular bacterial regulators by integrating structural Biochemistry with bioinformatics approaches based upon structure predictions, molecular dynamics aswell as evolutionary information based analyses such as shannon entropy and direct coupling analysis. Bacterial LuxR family regulators have been proven to be modular, with a typical domain architecture consisting of a signal reciever domain in the form of for example a two component system signal reciever or small molecule binding domain, aswell as a LuxR family DNA binding domain. Multiple Studies did show that it is possible to swap DNA binding domains of these regulatory proteins under specific circumstances, achieving an altered DNA binding specificity, and therefore an altered regulatory output for any given signal. Our Plan is to develop and apply metrics to guide the design of such "rewired" bacterial regulators.
students: Aaron Refisch, Charikleia, Florian Vögele, Julia, Lara Frenk, Mareike Giese, Vijayasarathy Sampath Kumar

title: SPETEX: A Specialised, Precise and Efficient Way to Exterminate PET
abstract: The UESTC-China research team has successfully developed an innovative colorimetric biosensor utilizing microplastic anchoring peptides, thereby providing a rapid and user-friendly method for the detection of microplastics. Furthermore, by employing advanced synthetic biology techniques, the research team implemented a streamlined "one-pot" process that integrates a surface display system with a multi-enzyme system to convert PET plastic waste into high-value vanillin, thus fostering environmental sustainability. Through the integration of cutting-edge technologies, including machine learning and directed evolution, the project significantly improved the detection accuracy of the anchoring peptides as well as the efficiency of PET plastic degradation processes. Ultimately, this project realized an integrated solution that encompasses both detection and degradation, complemented by real-time data visualization, thereby offering a comprehensive and sustainable framework for the reutilization of plastic waste.
PIs: Lixia Tang, Hao Lyu, Juan Feng, Xuelian Zheng, Yong Zhang
advisors: Wenyan Xin, Xu Tang, Yan Pan, Yuning Luo
