title: Magical world of cucumbers: secret of how CsTBH-CsPAL allows epidermal trichome to produce flavonoids
abstract: In order to achieve the goal of using cucumber epidermal hairs to synthesize flavonoids, the problem that this project needs to solve is: Is it possible to modify the key gene CsTBH and flavonoid metabolism gene (PAL) of cucumber epidermal trichome. By using synthetic biology and analyzing the difference in product content, it is possible to determine the effect of the CsTBH-CsPAL system on the synthesis of flavonoids and produce more flavonoids in cucumbers.
PIs: Yuepeng Song, XINYI ZHU, XINGWANG LIU

title: A CRISPR-Cas13d Antiviral System Targeting West Nile Virus-Induced Encephalitis via NFAT-Regulated Gene Expression
abstract: West Nile Virus (WNV) is a neuroinvasive pathogen responsible for severe encephalitis,with no specific antiviral treatment currently available. In this study, we propose an innovative antiviral strategy utilizing the RNA-targeting Cas13d system to combat WNV-induced encephalitis. Our approach involves designing guide RNAs (gRNAs) through a custom algorithm, tailored to efficiently target WNV RNA sequences. To enhance the safety and specificity of the Cas13d system, we integrate a regulatory mechanism involving a synthetic NFAT (nuclear factor of activated T-cells). This engineered NFAT ensures that Cas13d expression is induced only upon viral infection, levaraging the calcium influx triggered by WNV entry, which activates endogenous NFAT signaling. By linking the antiviral response to WNV-specific cellular changes, this system minimizes off-target effects and reduces the risk of unintended immune activation. This regulated antiviral platform holds potential as a novel therapeutic approach for treating WNV-induced neurological disroders.
nominations: Best Infectious Diseases Project, Undergrad & Overgrad+Inclusivity Award, Overgrad+Best Education, Overgrad

title: Dual-Specific Engineered T Cells Targeting Hepatocellular Carcinoma and the Immunosuppressive Microenvironment
abstract: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the leading causes of cancer-related deaths globally, and China has a high incidence of liver cancer. In 2020, new cases and deaths from liver cancer in China accounted for approximately half of the global total. Traditional treatment methods such as surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy have limited effectiveness in advanced HCC. Despite significant breakthroughs in T cell immunotherapy in the treatment of hematologic malignancies, the tumor immunosuppressive microenvironment is a unique feature of solid tumors, and a key factor in inducing tumor immune escape, setting them apart from hematologic malignancies. Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) are the primary organizers of the immunosuppressive microenvironment and promote HCC immune escape through various mechanisms. In this project, a dual-specific engineered T cell named "Bispecific T-cell Leaper" has been developed to target HCC and CAFs, aiming to disrupt the immunosuppressive microenvironment and reverse HCC immune escape.
advisors: Xinyu Lu
students: Chen DeFeng, Jay W, Weixin Liu, Yingshi Li, ?? ?Murphy

title: Decreasing histamine level in human tissues and liquid food
abstract: Histamine is one of the key factors of starting an inflammation process. Limiting the level of histamine effect can be an appropriate approach in those cases, where you can anticipate the histamine level increase. On our skin this includes some chronic diseases such as psoriasis, but more often would be useful in handling the acute increase of histamine level, such as a wasp bite. Aspiring the decrease in oral histamine administration may also help to prevent some acute GI inflammation and smoothing the symptoms of some chronic bowel diseases. Our group main aim is to create a complex synthetic biology solution attacking the biologically functional histamine. The solutions we plan to use, are using DAO and HNMT enzymes and ssDNA aptamers known from the scientific literature.
students: Albert Csupor, A.Levente, Anna Horvath, Attila, Attila, Attila Nagy, Barnabas U., Bence Sandor Gulyas, Bereczki Lili, Csongor Darvasi, Dalma, Emese Bakos, Erdei-Strohner Enik?, Erik Szogi, Fakan Péter, FanniRoszik, Gellert Zadori, Gy Akos, Hanga Katalin Toth, Heizer Panna, Konya Mate, Kristof Tamas Nagy, krisztinabudai, Maja Patkos, Marton K., Mez? Levente, N. Nyeste, Noemi Guth, Orsolya Simonyi, Sara Simonka, Vojtech, Zsuzsanna Hamori

title: SugarCare
abstract: Our project focuses on the development of a groundbreaking diagnostic method for early Red Rot detection, utilizing smartphone iSPR to quantify DNA-Protein interaction signals. This innovative approach offers a cost-effective means of identifying ITS rDNA Biomarkers from C. falcatum fungus, addressing the critical need for early diagnosis of a fatal disease, called "Cancer of Sugarcane", Red-Rot. By harnessing the unique binding properties of ZAP1 protein with our specific rDNA sequence, we aim to create a highly specific and sensitive diagnostic tool that can detect Red-Rot's related DNA in soil or stalk sample. This project seeks to revolutionize Red-Rot detection by providing a convenient, accessible, and accurate point-of-care solution, with the potential to transform farmers life decreasing the probability of spread of the disease and the loss caused by it.
students: Aadi Jeevaraj, Aadit Kumar Sahoo, Adit Khare, Aditya Chauhan, Anirudhan, Anukriti Jaya Sinha, Gitanjali Agarwal, HANUMA NIHAR, Hardik Narang, Hima Shashidhar, Kanika, Kshitij, mofa_iitr, Natansh Ken, Prateek Prakash Jha, Prisha Sinha, Sreesh, Suryadeep, Vansh, Yash Bansal, Yash Drall

title: Rh block
abstract: Blood transfusion mismatches, particularly involving the Rhesus D (RhD) blood type system, can cause severe hemolytic reactions, posing significant medical risks. The availability of RhD-negative (RhD-) blood is limited in many regions, creating challenges for emergency and routine transfusions. This study aims to develop universal red blood cells by preventing the recognition of Rh antigens by anti-D antibodies. Using bioengineering techniques, we designed smaller, more efficient forms of anti-D antibodies, such as single-chain variable fragments (scFv) and single-domain antibodies (sdAb). Additionally, we developed a conversion kit to streamline the blocking of Rh antigens. Experimental methods included plasmid digestion with XhoI and NdeI enzymes, ligation into the pET-28a vector, and transformation into competent Escherichia coli B cells for protein expression. This approach aims to create a universal blood supply, mitigating transfusion complications associated with Rh incompatibility.
students: Adrian Shih, Catherine Hsieh, Chih-Shu Wu, Grace Chang, I-Chun Lin, Jia-Yu Kao, Joanna Chen, Melanie Wang, Melanie Wang, Sharon, Sunny Chen

title: WGX-50 activates heat shock proteins longevity pathway in Caenorhabditis elegans
abstract: WGX-50, a previously reported drug candidate for Alzheimer's disease, is derived from Zanthoxylum bungeanum Maxim. Since that time, its pharmacological actions for the long-run benefit of human health had been extensively investigated. However, in terms of its anti-aging effect, there are very limited studies for reference. In this work, WGX-50 was first reported to extend lifespan in C. elegans, and it conduces to heat shock proteins (HSPs) longevity pathway, in which key genes like hsf-1, hsp-16.2, and hsp-90 were transcriptionally upregulated. Importantly, hsp-90 was revealed as a putative target for WGX-50 using molecular dynamics simulations. Four novel hits, namely F44E5.4/.5, sri-40, F59B2.12, K09C6.9 revealed by RNA sequencing, were first tested to be irrelevant to the lifespan extension effect of WGX-50 through RNA interference. Thus, our results offer primary insights on the medicinal application of WGX-50 in long-term and anti-aging healthcare.
advisors: Eva, Hui Zhang, Yahan
student leaders: cui, YIJIA HUANG, Yuesi Xu, Zikuan
students: Andi Hu, Azalea, Chengjun Jiang, Chenming, Emma Peng, Hamo Wan, HaoNan Deng, Jeffrey, Jianing, Jiayang, Joshua, Kendrick, Qiyun, Rudy, Su Hang, Vera, Wang Chang, Xiaoman Li, Xiao Yanzhi, Yihao, YUFAN DONG, Zita

title: PfAgo-Based Human Enterovirus EV71V Detection
abstract: Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common infectious disease caused by enterovirus, such as EV71,which is common in children. Due to the immature immune system and imperfect hygiene habits of infants and young children, the disease is easy to spread in this vulnerable group and lead to serious consequences. We use a novel programmable nuclease Argonaute and synthetic biology techniques to develop a simple, rapid and accurate assay. The speed and affordability of the method will ensure that all educational institutions and medical institutions can use it, and it will better improve the prevention and control of infectious diseases in epidemic education institutions.
advisors: Liu Yurui, Mingyang Yuan
students: Bella, enyuli, JinyangShi, Junru Zhou, lidan0625, Xiaoyi Fu, xinyuewei, Zhuohengli

title: ExoCureMPS II - Engineerd Exosome Delivery of IDS Enzyme to Treat MPS II
abstract: Mucopolysaccharidosis type II (MPS II) is a rare X-linked recessive disorder, classified as severe or mild based on central nervous system involvement. Current treatments are limited, costly, and risky for severe MPS II patients. Exosomes, extracellular vesicles (30-150 nm), have shown promise as drug carriers, particularly engineered exosomes, which are used in treating brain diseases and cancers due to their low immunogenicity, targeting, and ability to cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB). This year, the NWU-CHINA-A team investigated the enzyme-carrying capacity and BBB penetration of engineered exosomes, offering new therapeutic ideas and applications for drug delivery systems.
advisors: Goujunjie, Jinpeng Wu, Yang Lu
students: Chen Yiling, Feng Yating, Han Yishan, Hu Yueyang, Liu Qi, Pan Yue, Qu Yitong, Sun Cheng, Wang Haoyang, Wang Yaoyao, Wang Ziquan, Yao Jianhan, Zhao Fanghui, Zhao Yafei, Zhou Yifen, Zhu Youfu

title: The Power of Nature: Pioneering a New Approach to Diabetes Treatment with Isoorientin
abstract: Diabetes mellitus is a global health issue. Isoorientin, a plant-derived compound, has shown potential in managing diabetes by promoting insulin secretion and improving insulin sensitivity. However, its low natural concentration limits large-scale production, highlighting the urgent need for alternative biosynthesis methods. To address this challenge, our study focuses on the biosynthesis of isoorientin by engineering E. coli to express the C-glycosyltransferase Gt6CGT. The Gt6CGT gene was initially cloned into the pET-21a(+) expression vector, and a recombinant plasmid was constructed using seamless cloning technology. This plasmid was subsequently transformed into E. coli Rosetta (DE3) competent cells, where protein expression was induced by IPTG. After expression, the enzymatic activity of Gt6CGT was confirmed through microplate reader and HPLC analysis. This system provides a robust foundation for the efficient biosynthesis of isoorientin and supports its potential large-scale production as a natural therapeutic for diabetes.
advisors: Jing Shi, Penghao Han, Wenjie
student leaders: Xinyu Yu, Yuhan Shen, Zixin Cheng
students: Blair, Blair, Chenjiahe Yu, Dong Canran, Jason Lin, Kevin Wang, LIU LUYAO, Lucy Xu, Qinqi Xie, Shiyu Xu, Tianyou Pan, Tianyou Wang, Tianyu Zhu, Xiangnan Liu, Xingjian Wang, Xinyu Li, Yinuo Zhang, Zhiran Fu, ZIMO WANG

title: Inexpensive EGFR Mutation Detection Kit for Early Diagnosis of Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
abstract: Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer-related deaths, with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounting for 85% of cases. Current detection methods are either invasive or costly, limiting accessibility. Our project aims to develop an affordable, non-invasive diagnostic kit for early detection of NSCLC by targeting EGFR mutations, a key biomarker. Using padlock probes and rolling circle amplification (RCA) coupled with a split lettuce probe detection mechanism, the kit amplifies and identifies the mutated sequence in cell-free DNA from patient blood samples. This process eliminates the need for expensive PCR equipment, making the test accessible in low-resource settings. The fluorescent signal generated by the lettuce probe binding to the amplified product indicates the presence of the mutation. By providing a preliminary diagnosis, this kit can help identify high-risk individuals earlier, increasing the chances of timely treatment before the cancer advances to critical stages.
advisors: Afroditi Skevi, Ioannis Retalis
students: Aaria Garhwal, Apsara Baume, Buse Toksoz, Kei Hayashi, Lucas, Pat, Stefano, Victor Demyanyuk

title: ATLAS.Y:Advanved Targeting Localization Assistance System for Yeast
abstract: ATLAS.Y is a specialized tool designed to optimize protein subcellular localization within yeast. It uses signal peptide and linker databases to engineer fusion proteins with precise localization signals. The software employs the ESM-fold model for fast 3D structure prediction, the Rosetta model to assess protein stability, and the CAD-score to ensure functional consistency. DeepLoc 2.0 assists in verifying localization accuracy. Additionally, ATLAS.Y uses a graph-based deep learning algorithm for directed evolution, allowing proteins to adapt to specific microenvironments. For applications requiring precise control, the system offers a dynamic version integrating optogenetics for spatiotemporal regulation of protein localization.

title: CelluGuard: Desert Tree Survival Enhancer
abstract: The area of global desertification is expanding at a rate of 23 football fields per minute, posing a significant threat to the availability of land. Over the years, China has actively fulfilled its commitments under the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification and has made notable progress. However, the global rate of desertification remains alarming, severely threatening ecological security and sustainable development. As a group of high school students committed to a responsible future, we have engineered Komagataeibacter xylinus to produce bacterial cellulose (BC) more efficiently. BC possesses exceptional water-retention properties, is environmentally friendly, and does not hinder the growth and development of tree roots, making it an ideal candidate as a water-retaining matrix material for afforestation in deserts. By enriching BC around the roots of tree, we aim to enhance the drought tolerance and survival rate of newly transplanted trees, thereby contributing to the mitigation of land desertification.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Xu Min, Zhang Zhaoxia
student leaders: Xinyi Wang, YANLIN GU, Yuemeng Li
students: Dongyun Fan, Haobin Yao, JINGRAN XU, Muyan Li, Ruoxin Yang, Shiran Liu, Sifei Chen, WEIER QI, Yichen Zhao, YU CHEN, YUHENG XIE, Yujia Shuai, YUTONG TIAN, Zheren Xu

title: LA&N: Yeast-Derived Human Lactoferrin and N-Acetylneuraminic Acid as Supplements for Infants
abstract: In the face of economic pressures and epidemic challenges, China's breastfeeding rate is a concern. The high cost and limited nutritional value of formula milk have placed a financial burden on many families. This project aims to use Saccharomyces cerevisiae for the low-cost production of two important nutrients in the growth of infants and young children: lactoferrin and N-acetylneuraminic acid. We introduced the human lactoferrin synthesis gene and the high-yield Neu5Ac synthesis gene into Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells using the pESC-URA plasmid vector, respectively. Subsequently, the functions of the engineered cells were verified using a variety of methods, including kits and SDS-PAGE, and the production of the target product was finally confirmed. Our goal is to provide economical nutritional supplements that promote the health and well-being of infants and relieve the psychological stress of mothers who are unable to breastfeed themselves.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Siqi Yang, Yaoyao Liang, Yuqi Fu

title: SynBio missile : barrier clearance and immune enhancement strategy targeting OSCC tumor microenvironment
abstract: Regarding cancer solutions, remodeling the tumor immune microenvironment (TIME) and enhancing the activation of immune-infiltrating cells through multifaceted strategies is considered one of the most promising avenues to overcome these challenges. Currently, a series of immune checkpoint inhibitors have gained clinical acceptance to improve the immunosuppressive environment within the tumor and enhance the anti-tumor effects of CD8+ T lymphocytes. And synthetic biology serves as a possible approach to enable the coordinated release of defective cytokines in the tumor microenvironment (TME) to be able to produce similar immunomodulatory effects. Targeting the OSCC tumor microenvironment to achieve barrier clearance and immune enhancement through specific components or structures in the TME that induce tumor immunosuppression has aroused our interest. Through studying the literature and communicating with expert predecessors, we focused on choosing the bacterial-encoded hyaluronidase Hy and flagellin FlaB as our key research molecules.
PIs: Yatao Liu, Hui Cai, Kai Jiang, Xiao Lyu

title: ChloroNova: Proposing Algal Chloroplast as the New Status Quo for Biopharmaceutical Peptide Production
abstract: As the climate crisis intensifies and the cost of living rises, the demand for a circular economy has never been greater. Project Chloronova leverages microalgae as a scalable carbon-sequestering organism by partnering with major industrial polluters in our hometown of Hamilton, Ontario to reduce carbon dioxide emissions while producing high-value biomolecules. Unlike bacteria, microalgae offer the unique ability to perform post-translational modifications, make multiple heterologous proteins and withstand antimicrobial mechanisms. Inspired by our human practices research, Chloronova engineers microalgae to produce antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), thus addressing the alarming rise of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and the urgent need for sustainable bioproduction. Using PEG-mediated transformation in a cell-wall deficient strain of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (cw15+), we are able to introduce our plasmid into the chloroplast DNA of the microalgae. By optimizing AMP production within C. reinhardtii, we are creating a scalable, modular biofactory. It's a new day, and algae is here to stay.
student leaders: Aiman Dhiloon, Alice Payne, Aqsa Rahim, Binjal Pradhan, Josh Tony, Matthew Hammond, Nikita Jacob, Nimrat Sanghu, Parneet Deo
students: Anam Biabani, Arnica, Bogdana Borysova, Chloe Shivaani William, David Liu, Jiya Kaemra, Kiranpreet, Meher, Mike Cho, Mwai M'Mbijjewe, Pankti Bhatt, Renee Vucemilo, Richelle Antonythasan, Shlok Panchal, Simran Dev, Simran Shergill, Tanvir, Tazeen, Thomas Kells

title: Thermoguard: A Novel Treatment for Skin and Soft Tissue Infections(SSTIs)
abstract: Skin and Soft Tissue Infections (SSTIs) encompass a broad spectrum of infectious conditions that affect the skin and underlying soft tissues. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) accounts for over 50% of SSTI cases. In the United States, SSTIs affect more than 14 million outpatients annually, with 900,000 requiring hospitalizations. The rise of antimicrobial resistance threatens the efficacy of antibiotics used to treat SSTIs, prompting the search for alternatives. Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), especially those produced by thermophilic bacteria, have gained attention as potential solutions. In our project, we utilized bioinformatics tools to identify novel AMP genes in the genome of the thermophilic bacteria Brevibacillus borstelensis AK1, a thermophilic bacteria isolated from a hot spring in Saudi Arabia. We then designed a plasmid to contain these AMP genes and cloned them into Escherichia coli for heterologous expression, aiming to develop a novel AMP-based treatment for SSTIs in the face of rising antibiotic resistance.
advisors: Nawal Alshahrany
students: Abeer Alloush, Amal, Amjad, Btoul Alkhalil, Jood, Rimas hamad Alqahtani

title: CaraCOS: To produce versatile COS from waste carapace with the application of dual-enzyme synergistic catalysis
abstract: The accumulation of shrimp and crab carapaces waste poses serious environmental hazards. Despite the potential to convert these chitin-rich materials into high-value chitooligosaccharides (COS), the scarcity and high cost of recycling technologies mean that these carapaces are often overlooked. By selecting from Bacillus species and site-directed mutating, we will obtain high-activity chitin deacetylases (CDA) and chitosanases (CsnB) and improve the enzymatic method to produce COS from chitin, thereby enhancing the recycling and utilization of waste carapaces.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, High School

title: Biosynthesis of Interleukin-18-Binding-Protein for the Treatment of Inflammatory Bowel Disease
abstract: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is a group of autoimmune diseases that involves the inflammation of the digestive tract. It is currently becoming much more prevalent in Asia due to rapid urbanization and the adoption of Western dietary habits. IBD has a lower onset age than most other chronic diseases. However, there is no effective treatment for IBD. In this context, we utilized genetic engineering techniques to produce a macromolecular drug, Interleukin-18-binding-protein (IL-18BP) to treat IBD. In our project, human IL-18BPa and IL-18BPc genes were modified with SUMO to improve the protein stability, Fc to achieve potential targeted drug delivery, and His tag for purification. Our research results revealed the protein's ability to successfully lower IFN-gamma levels (a sign of inflammation), demonstrating its anti-inflammatory effect and potential application in IBD treatment.

title: Engineered Probiotic for Targeted Tumor Therapy
abstract: Tumors pose multifaceted harm, including life-threatening risks, organ damage, complications, psychological impact, and reduced quality of life. Genetically engineered bacteria have emerged as a promising strategy for disease diagnosis and treatment. These engineered bacteria have been used to monitor cancer liver metastases, liver dysfunction, and various gastrointestinal disorders, such as inflammation and infection. Certain bacteria, like Salmonella and Escherichia coli Nissle (EcN), can selectively colonize tumors due to their ability to infiltrate the hypoxic cores of immune-deficient tumors. In this study, we utilized a lactic acid-responsive promoter to control the expression of anti-PD-L1 antibody or azurin killer protein. EcN was engineered as a tumor-specific drug delivery system to target tumors and locally release drugs, thereby inhibiting tumor growth and reducing both drug dosage and cost. This approach could provide new insights and strategies for cancer treatment.
nominations: Best Part Collection, High School
student leaders: HU CHENGKAI, Michelle Muxiao Wang, WU PEIRAN
students: JIANG RAN, Li Jialiang, LI TIANYI, LIU LANXIN, QU JIAKANG, SIYUAN WU

title: Colorfold
abstract: Our project addresses environmental and health concerns associated with synthetic dyes by exploring biological alternatives. We aim to reduce the toxic chemicals used in dye production by focusing on two objectives: the discovery of new biological pigments from environmental microorganisms, and the mutation of new colours in existing chromoproteins for large-scale production. Specifically, we are targeting AmilCP to make new colours more suitable for industrial use. Using size exclusion chromatography, SDS-PAGE semi-native analysis and bioinformatics, we aim to identify novel chromoproteins using AI tools for protein engineering. Synthetic dyes, widely used in textiles and other industries, are major pollutants, especially in water systems. Biological pigments offer a sustainable alternative. Inspired by previous research into microbial pigments, our project aims to contribute to a greener future by providing scalable and environmentally friendly solutions to current dyeing practices.
nominations: Best Measurement, Overgrad
students: Alex Johansson, Alva, Andreas Magnusson, Athanasios Toros, Elsa Nilsson, Greta Melander, Jesper Magnusson, Lovisa Wigertz, Otto Isaksson, William Wallén

title: Pichia Pastoris Production Plant for Healthy Sugar SubstituteD-Psicose
abstract: Traditional sweeteners have become a research focus due to issues such as high calorie content and high blood sugar levels .D-Psicose,as an emerging low calorie sweetener, combines good sweetness with health benefits such as reducing fat and lowering blood sugar. Due to its scarcity in nature, there are two synthetic methods: chemical synthesis, which pollutes the environment, and biological synthesis, which is highly favored for its environmental friendliness and efficiency. However, the existing enzyme species of the key enzyme in the biosynthesis of D-Psicose, 3-isomerase, have poor thermal stability and low expression.In this study, we selected the coding genes of D-psicose 3-epimerase from different sources, induced the expression and purification of the target protein in Pichia pastoris, and detected its enzymatic properties to screen D-psicose 3-epimerase with good thermal stability.
students: CHEN PEIQI, GONG RUI, GU LANTANG, HU XINZI, JIAYI GONG, JIN CHENGKAI, TAO JIAYU, WANG YAEN, XIAO HANYU, YANG FEIYANG, YUXUAN QI, ZICHENG WANG

title: A New Fungal Probe: Innovation of a rapid eco-friendly, and visually fungal-detecting approach
abstract: As a widely distributed eukaryotic microorganism found in nature, some fungi have posed significant threats to food safety and human health through infections. Current fungal detection methods, like DNA isolation and gram staining microscopy, require specialized equipment, experimental conditions, and high costs. Lacking direct visualization capabilities also limits their broad use in food safety inspection and clinical diagnosis. Moreover, the accuracy of microscopy can be affected by difficulties in differentiating various fungi from background noise. To address these issues, we designed a fungi-detecting probe utilizing carbohydrate-binding modules (CBMs) for their special affinity to fungal cell wall polysaccharides and chitin. By combining CBMs with fluorescent proteins, this probe enables rapid, eco-friendly, and visual in situ detection of fungal contamination in samples from different scenarios.
advisors: Cheng Zhibo, Deng Yicheng, Emily Qixuan Wang, Ma Haoran, Wang Shaowei, Zhou Yile
student leaders: DONG XIWEN, WANG YUENING, YIHE XU

title: Engineering and Development of Collagen-based Rotavirus Subunit Vaccines
abstract: Rotaviruses are the most common causative agents of severe gastroenteritis in children under five years of age. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent Rotavirus infection. It was previously shown that the outer capsid viral protein (VP4) is an essential target for developing a recombinant rotavirus vaccine as it mediates the attachment and penetration of rotavirus. However, the current live rotavirus vaccines show reduced effectiveness. Here, we focus on crafting a recombinant rotavirus vaccine with improved efficacy and safety. The coexpression of a human collagen type ? with VP4 in Escherichia coli was employed to generate oligomerization of recombinant rotavirus vaccines. Further, a stable hydroxyproline-free ABC heterotrimeric collagen mimetic system was used to produce a polyvalent rotavirus vaccine. Importantly, these newly designed vaccines utilize non-infectious virus-like particles with enhanced immunogenicity and protection, which could be considered viable candidates for further development to become a parenterally administered rotavirus vaccine.
advisors: Deng Yicheng, Gong Lehan, Jiang Jialin Lisa, Jin Renchi, LI JUNYUE, Wang Yihan, Wen Haohan
students: BAOQI WANG, CHENBIN XU, HANTAO HU, LYU QIAN, RUITONG XIAO, SIQI ZHANG, TENGZHEN CAO, TIANYU WANG, XIA SIQI, XUANXIN LI, YEZI LIU, YIN HAOTIAN, YU YIHAN, ZIYOU WEI

title: Golden solutions: the power of AuNPs@PBP in the detection & sterilization of foodborne bacteria
abstract: Nowadays, food safety has not been comprehensively guaranteed mainly due to the severe health risks foodborne bacteria bring. However, current bacterial detection methods are time-consuming and less accessible. Our team believes that these limitations can be improved by developing a more efficient and effective product by coupling gold nanoparticles that have useful physical properties, with Phage-derived bacterial-binding protein (PBP). This biosensor rapidly binds to three specific bacteria (Escherichia coli, Salmonella, Staphylococcus aureus) within thirty minutes, analyzes their concentrations via RGB values on a smartphone app, and sterilizes bacteria using near-infrared (NIR). Additionally, it achieves efficient antibacterial effects under 808 nm light irradiation for 10 minutes. This study is significant for the detection and elimination of foodborne pathogens for both synthetic biology development and practical influences in the food industry. Furthermore, we will investigate the target market to ensure a pragmatic and applicable product is available to our potential consumers.

title: Early screening products for Parkinson's disease
abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is one of the most common neurodegenerative diseases. Early screening of the disease is a key measure to prevent the occurrence and development of the disease. NF-L is a universal marker of nerve damage and is elevated in a variety of neurodegenerative diseases, including PD. In the early stages of PD, elevated NF-L levels can be detected. Using ?-synuclein, A?42, and NF-L as biomarkers simultaneously can improve the sensitivity and specificity of PD diagnosis. Each marker provides a different pathological perspective, making the comprehensive analysis more comprehensive. This study intends to obtain PD-specific markers ?-syn, A?42, and NF-L through genetic engineering, and use ELISA to verify the accuracy of the obtained proteins, which can lay a good foundation for the acquisition of specific antibodies and the construction of early screening kits in the future.

title: CALIMOD - GIX
abstract: Drug addiction is a chronic condition characterized by compulsive drug seeking and use despite negative consequences. Extensive research shows that surges of dopamine during pleasurable activities affect the brain's reward circuits. G9a, an under-researched gene, regulates dopamine production and release, influencing how the brain responds to addictive substances. Elevated levels of EHMT2 (the coding gene for G9a) are observed in addiction, and our research aims to reduce these levels using RNAi technology, specifically small-interfering RNA. Through a three-component system involving the construction of plasmids altered for overproduction of our gene to be expanded in further research on addiction, siRNA technology tests for optimal concentration and conditions, and a concept model of lipid-nanoparticles as a delivery method, we hope to contribute to the possibility of creating an accessible therapeutic to solve this problem.
students: Adam, Brian Huang, Cynthia, Evelyn, Irene, Jake Kang, Joshua Wu, Matthew, Megan, Naina Singhal

title: Targeted intracellular delivery of LshCas13a using bacterial DTA toxin-based platforms into targeted non-synthetic HIV-1 strains
abstract: Targeted delivery of therapeutic proteins toward latent HIV-infected cells remains a major challenge in eradicating HIV. Leading therapies block entry via envelope proteins or coreceptors, as well as reverse transcription. We developed a protein-based delivery system using a detoxified single-chain diphtheria toxin (DTA) as a translocation carrier across the cell membrane. This system delivers large protein cargoes, such as Cas13a, into cells in a receptor-dependent manner. A GP120 gene fragment was added to the fusion protein to act as the ligand for CD4+ T-helper cell receptors. These systems remain under development and low expression of Cas13a-DTA in E. coli (10-beta, Rosetta, and W3110 strains) poses challenges in extraction. Our research complements gene editing and external protein therapies to evaluate HIV cleavage in mimic CD4 receptor cells (HEK293). Quantifications of ssRNA cleavage via RT-qPCR will be presented, suggesting how effectively this treatment could extend to pharmaceutical applications.
PIs: J. Peter Gergen, Gabor Balazsi, Kathryn Gunn
advisors: Christopher Helenek, Joshua Rest, Manuel Marques Vilar, Melanie Cragan
students: Ann Zhang, Benjamin Costa, Bevis Jiang, Coco Gao, Doorva Garg, Duaa Zeeshan, Hamza Raja, Jessy Zhang, Leslie Liu, Meha D, Parker Fording, Rachel Liu, Randhula Wickramasinghe, Samuel Li, Shalom

title: Yeast Medics?Hydrogel Wound Dressing Infused with Engineered Yeast's Healing Arsenal for Diabetic Wound Regeneration
abstract: Globally, nearly 588 million people live with diabetes, and up to 25% of them suffer from chronic, non-healing wounds, facing risks of infection, gangrene, and even amputation. Current conventional therapies are ineffective and cumbersome, exacerbating patient suffering, while advanced treatments remain inaccessible due to high costs, limited functionality, or lack of dynamic regulation. To address this, we introduce "Yeast Medics"--an innovative injectable dressing based on engineered Yarrowia lipolytica and L-DOPA-modified thermosensitive chitosan. This system dynamically senses wound status, displays antimicrobial peptides (Pexiganan) on the yeast surface, and programmatically releases both anti-inflammatory (IL-4) and pro-angiogenic (VEGF) factors. It synergistically addresses the three major challenges of infection, inflammation, and regeneration on a single platform, providing diabetic patients with an integrated, self-driven, low-burden healing solution.
PIs: Guanglei Liu, Pengfei Cui, Ya Liu

title: Adipocyte for Breast Cancer Surveillance(ABCS)
abstract: Adipocytes can be transformed into cancer-associated adipocytes (CAAs) by cytokines from cancer cells. As CAAs demonstrate distinct gene expression pattern, we aimed to engineer adipocytes that could report such pattern. Systematic analysis revealed that the optimal combination to identify CAAs is PLOD2 and LIF, which could be induced by PAI-1 and CXCL8 respectively. We designed a RADAR sensor that targets the transcripts of PLOD2 and LIF simultaneously and delivered this sensor into differentiated adipocytes. These engineered adipocytes responded to the combined stimulation of PAI-1 and CXCL8 only. Most importantly, these engineered adipocytes responded to the treatment of the conditioned medium from breast cancer cells, revealing the potential of these adipocytes to respond to actual cancer microenvironment. We chose Gaussia luciferase (Gluc), an enzyme to generate luminescence, as output reporter. As Gluc could be secreted into urine, it offers a convenient way to report the results of in vivo cancer monitoring.
nominations: Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad+Best Diagnostics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad

title: SILK:Stability-Integrated Industrialization Leveraging Key plasmids
abstract: The SILK project (Stability-Integrated Industrialization Leveraging Key plasmids) addresses the critical challenge of environmental sensitivity in industrial fermentation by harnessing Xinjiang's extremophilic microbial resources. Xinjiang's diverse environment has fostered highly tolerant bacterial communities, whose natural plasmids encode evolutionarily shaped stress-resistance mechanisms. By isolating and sequencing these plasmids, our team identifies functional gene elements--such as tolerance to extreme pH levels--to construct standardized expression modules for industrial strains. Integrating nature's evolutionary solutions into bioreactor frameworks, the SILK project aims to enhance fermentation stability, reduce energy consumption for environmental control, and expand the synthetic biology toolkit for extreme environments--transforming Xinjiang's "microbial silk" into industrial resilience.

title: InkSight
abstract: Tattoos have long served as markers of identity and belonging. InkSight repurposes this historical medium for modern medicine as a platform comprising engineered mammalian cells encapsulated in a hydrogel matrix for intradermal delivery as a tattoo. This system enables the real-time, equipment-free detection of circulating biomarkers through direct interrogation of the interstitial fluid. The engineered cells express a Modular Extracellular Sensor Architecture (MESA) for target recognition, which triggers one of three engineered contrast-change mechanisms: expression, assembly, or agglomeration. This response is driven by synthetic melanin-producing compartments, specifically encapsulin nanocages that house tyrosinase to enable localized and safe melanin production, resulting in a visible shift in tattoo contrast. InkSight constitutes, to our knowledge, the first paradigm for a continuous, cell-based tattoo biosensor with a visible output, establishing a foundational platform for decentralized diagnostics and personalized medicine.

title: An Inhalable Probiotic Platform for RNA-Mediated Silencing for Asthma Management
abstract: Asthma is a very common respiratory disease, its severe form is often characterized by uncontrolled or corticosteroid-resistant inflammation. To overcome this, we developed PRESS, a modular therapeutic platform combining a probiotic delivery system (Lactobacillus plantarum) with an siRNA-based silencing tool (CO-BERA) targeting the inflammatory alarmin TSLP mRNA. Our engineered L. plantarum senses airway inflammation through dual inputs (Hydrogen peroxide and acidic pH) and, upon activation, synthesizes CO-BERA to silence TSLP and suppress downstream inflammatory pathways. For efficient administration, we designed a dry-powder inhalation system, optimized by computational fluid dynamics and validated for aerosol behavior and bacterial viability. PRESS adapted multi-layered biosafety measures, including a toxin-antitoxin kill switch to ensure containment. Reinforced by modeling-guided design and educational outreach with achieving eight UN SDGs. PRESS showcasing how engineered probiotics can function as living inhalable therapeutics, providing a safe, sustainable, and targeted solution for asthma and other inflammatory lung diseases.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, Undergrad

title: Slupeer: Removal of Cadmium From Sludge
abstract: Cadmium is a severe heavy metal pollutant in several regions. Its effect as a pollutant threatens food safety, notably causing 14-17% of global cropland to be affected. Among sources of cadmium pollution, sludge is particularly detrimental with exacerbated consequences from downstream damage to human health and ecosystems. Within the sludge, there only exists trace yet still harmful concentrations of sludge, causing general heavy metal remediation methods to be ineffective against it. Simultaneously, it is the most significant ecological risk amongst heavy metals. Our team targets sludge and removes the pollutant cadmium by engineering Pseudomonas putida to express metallothioneins on its surface. Our team has introduced this metallothionein to the iGEM Registry and characterized it through Wet Lab Data and Dry Lab modeling. Supported by extensive Human Practices work, our team hopes to demonstrate the potential of our work and it as a promising and sustainable heavy metal bioremediation method.
PIs: King L. Chow, Jessica C.M. Tang

title: Treating End-Stage Liver Disease via Synergistic Co-delivery of miRNA-Engineered Exosomes
abstract: Human umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell (hUC-MSC)-derived exosomes can ameliorate liver disease via their diverse effector cargo. While individual miRNAs like miR-455-3p and miR-148a-5p are known anti-fibrotic agents, their therapeutic synergy is uninvestigated. This study co-delivers two distinct exosome populations, each artificially supplemented with one of these miRNAs, to assess their combined efficacy.

title: Glycosy-N-ation: Developement of microbial plataforms for the production of recombinant glycoproteins
abstract: N-glycosylation, the attachment of glycans to asparagine residues, is a critical post-translational modification that influences protein folding, stability, signaling, and activity. Over half of human proteins are glycosylated, yet current therapeutic glycoprotein production depends on eukaryotic hosts, as common models such as Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Escherichia coli are unsuitable. E. coli lacks an N-glycosylation pathway, leading to insoluble proteins, while S. cerevisiae produces hypermannose glycans that are immunogenic in humans. To overcome these limitations, we are engineering optimized microbial platforms for glycoprotein synthesis. In yeast, glycan chain extension is disrupted to generate simpler structures, and in E. coli, a de novo glycosylation system is reconstructed using modular Golden Gate-compatible parts. Both systems aim to produce the universal precursor Man?GlcNAc?. We developed 24 yeast mutants to evaluate growth, fitness, morphology, protein production, and glycan transfer, and incorporated archaeal oligosaccharyltransferases into E.coli to explore their ability to transfer glycans to human-like sequons.

title: CRUSTA: Circular Reutilization of Untappable Seafood-shell: Transfomation into Antimicrobial-preservatives
abstract: In our CRUSTA project, we designed and developed an innovative COS-based bio-preservation technology using principles of synthetic biology. This technology provides a green and efficient alternative to traditional chemical preservatives in the food industry. In our project, we achieved chitosan degradation via a secretion system, enhancing the antibacterial performance of the degradation products by 7.96-fold compared to the wild-type. This project not only has the potential to propel technological innovation and catalyze industrial advancement in food preservation but also aims to introduce advanced concepts of synthetic biology and eco-friendly preservation. These initiatives are expected to improve preservation efficiency, elevate food safety standards, and enhance environmental sustainability, thus bolstering market competitiveness and fostering the sustainable growth of the green food industry and the circular economy.
nominations: Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Food & Nutrition Project, Undergrad & Overgrad

students: Cairui Chen, Enduo Jin, Jialin Chen, Jiaxuan Peng, Jiayao Chi, Jiayue Qu, Keshuo Zheng, Meihan Li, Nanqin Lin, Ruichen Shen, Yanlinxin Guo, Yijie Liao, Yunxin Wang

title: Synbio-MuralShield----Using synthetic biology to restore microbial damage to murals
abstract: As an ancient art form, murals possess significant historical and artistic value. However, factors such as climate change and human activities frequently lead to microbial outbreaks on mural surfaces, resulting in issues such as discoloration of mineral pigments, powdering and flaking of painted layers, and organic staining, which severely threaten their preservation. We have developed a microbial platform capable of producing antimicrobial peptides to inhibit the growth of fungi and bacteria, as well as generating enzymes to degrade organic pigments including melanin and carotenoids. This platform utilizes a pH-inducible switch to transcribe different products under varying pH conditions and incorporates a toggle-switch-based containment mechanism to ensure that our engineered bacteria survive only under specific conditions, thereby preventing environmental release.
PIs: Jing Ji, Bo Cheng, Xiangkai Li
instructors: Fasi Wu, Jingwen fan, Wanfu Wang
students: chenyu Zhou, Geyi Zhu, Hao Quan, Jiameng Huang, Jiayi Kang, JiaYue Sun, Jinze, Jinzuo Han, Kaiwen Wang, Kui Peng, Lishaoyang, PangYifei, Pengyu Jin, Qian Chenyang, Qihao Chen, Qu Zhang, Shangwen Hu, wangluyi, yating yang, Yinghao Liu, Yujie Wei, Zhong Zixi, Ziheng Ye, ???

title: Engineered bacteria for PFAS degradation and dectection
abstract: Forever chemicals, or PFAS, are synthetic compounds composed of carbon-fluorine bonds that are nearly impossible to break down. First produced in the 1940s for their exceptional stability and resistance, they are now ubiquitous--in cookware, textiles, and firefighting foams--leading to their accumulation in the environment and human bodies. Long-term exposure has been linked to cancer, hormonal disruption, and immune dysfunction. Yet, no scalable, low-energy solutions currently exist for PFAS degradation. FluoroBreaker aims to address this challenge through two complementary strategies targeting PFOA and TFA. First, we used an AI-assisted bioinformatics docking approach to identify key mutations in a dehalogenase enzyme to enhance TFA degradation. Second, we engineered reporter bacteria carrying a promoter responsive to PFOA, enabling fast, user-friendly detection of PFAS in water. Together, these innovations pave the way for a sustainable, biotechnology-driven response to the PFAS pollution crisis.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, Overgrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Overgrad+Best Bioremediation Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Agnes Rodrigue, Bastien Doumeche, BG_IGFL, Emmanuel Bettler, François Rousset, Marion Fiorucci, SH_IGFL, Tanaïs Moreau, Xavier ROBERT
students: Adèle Hamelin, ANDRIAMISETRA, Baptiste CLEMENT, Coline, Elisa Afonso, Hugo Dupuis, Jérémi, Lou-Anne Bénéton, Maëva, Noémie, Paloma Bert, Romain Héraud, Sarah, Simon Henninot, Waliya Basson Hadjeris

title: DOCTOR?Diagnostic Optimization & Chemical Treatment Of Rhinosinusitis
abstract: Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a widespread yet underestimated disease that causes severe discomfort and lacks effective clinical solutions. To address challenges in early diagnosis and precise treatment, we focused on Granzyme K (GZMK), a key enzyme driving CRS progression. Centered on this target, we established an integrated diagnostic-therapeutic framework. A colloidal-gold rapid test strip enables early and accessible detection, while small-molecule inhibitors achieve precise enzymatic inhibition and inflammation control. In parallel, we developed two supporting technology platforms: Prometheus, for de novo protein design, and Nexus, for high-throughput affinity measurement. They enable efficient design and validation of high-affinity protein binders, contributing more powerful research tools to the field of synthetic biology.
nominations: Best Measurement, Undergrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Foundational Advance Project, Undergrad & Overgrad

title: CASPER -- A Synthetic Platform to Combat Antimicrobial Resistance
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a silent pandemic claiming millions of lives each year as more pathogens evade existing treatments. CASPER (cell-based antimicrobial screening and programmable elimination response) offers an integrated platform that unites diagnostics and therapeutics into a single, accessible system. The diagnostic module overcomes limitations of PCR and lateral flow assays by using a two-step reaction that screens for bacterial presence and produces a clear color change as a visible output. This enables rapid, broad-range, and equipment-free detection suitable for low-resource settings. The therapeutic module introduces programmable mini cells and extracellular vesicles as DNA delivery shuttles capable of selectively recognizing bacterial targets and triggering cell death from within. By combining detection and response, CASPER provides a scalable and affordable solution to antimicrobial resistance with the potential to transform infection control and save millions of lives worldwide.
students: Alara, Alexander, Aramis, Omer Mihovi?, Rhonda Tse, Shivam Singhal, Yu, Zhen Yi

title: Cohera: A New Foundation For Engineered Multicellularity
abstract: One of nature's greatest feats is multicellularity--joining together single cells into a whole that is greater than the sum of its parts. Cohera is a complete toolkit for multicellular engineering, allowing synthetic biologists to access the full potential of cell-cell adhesion. Our system enables the creation of microbial networks that can be formed and dissolved on command using a collection of membrane-displayed proteins. Our Model, CoheraTune, expands the range of environments in which our tool operates by strengthening the core of our project at the molecular level. At the macroscopic level, bioengineers can leverage Cohera to solve problems in diverse fields. To facilitate the use of our system as a foundational tool, we developed human-centred roadmaps for applications spanning all iGEM plazas. Cohera streamlines the process of engineering cell-cell adhesion, unlocking endless possibilities.
nominations: Best Part Collection, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad+Best Foundational Advance Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Dustin Myskiw, Lee Marie Raytek, Natalya
students: Adrian Yehia, Alexandra Mclean, Annie Dang, Camille Heaney, Chloe Wei, Dante Garcia, Elizabeth Kourbatski, Evelyn, Jeremy Lachance, Johanna Turton, Jung Hao Cau, Kai, Laura Sun, Lucy Wiggers, Malak, Mercy Ajibola, Mollee Ye, Naomi, Rhianna Jiang, Salena Sun, Sophia Chen, Victoria Ma

title: Pepcitrus: Peptides in defense of Citrus
abstract: Orange production faces severe losses caused by Greening, Green Mold and Sour Rot, threatening food security and vitamin C availability. Especially in Brazil, leader of orange juice and fruit production, this directly affects livelihoods. To tackle this challenge, we focused on CTX, an antimicrobial peptide from Brazilian Cerrado biodiversity, and engineered three different hosts: E. coli, S. cerevisiae, and A. oryzae to optimize its production through coupling-strategies. To guide CTX application, we developed a mathematical model simulating Greening progression in the phloem and designed Sniffer, a hardware device combining an electronic nose and machine learning for rapid field diagnosis. Performing economic analysis to assess industrial scalability of approaches we demonstrated cost-effectiveness through solid-state fermentation using orange peels residues. Thus, Pepcitrus bridges laboratory innovation and real-world application, incorporating different perspectives from farmers, industry, and society to save oranges.
nominations: Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Overgrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Overgrad
advisors: Camila, Davi Gomes, Juliana Galhardo, Lara Hissa, Lucas Garbini Cespedes
students: Amanda, Ana Paola, Ana Sandano, Bruno Batista, Daniela Silva, Enrico Baeta Theodoro, Gabriel, Gabriella Gonçalves da Silva Rezende, Heloysa, Isaque, Laura Diniz, Lilian Lee Depieri, Maria Eduarda Tichauer, Maria Fernanda Perrotta, Marina Victoria, Ramon Brison

title: DeathCapTrap: a modular nanobody-based antidote against ?-amanitin
abstract: 90% of mushroom poisonings are caused by ?-amanitin, one of the deadliest mushroom toxins which can be found in the death cap mushroom. Just half a mushroom can be fatal, as the toxin inhibits RNA Polymerase II, blocking protein production and causing severe organ damage, especially to the liver and kidneys. Although treatments exist, there is no specific antidote yet. Our iGEM project, DeathCapTrap, aims to develop a modular nanobody-based antidote to neutralize ?-amanitin in the bloodstream and protect liver cells. In the WetLab, we established a pipeline to produce a nuclear-targeted nanobody in E. coli. We also explored lipid nanoparticles for delivery and designed a testing protocol with liver cell models. In the DryLab, AI tools helped us design toxin-binding proteins. Our goal is to create a life-saving therapy and a versatile platform to fight intracellular toxins, while raising awareness of the dangers of mushroom poisoning.
nominations: Best Therapeutics Project, Overgrad
advisors: Boy Hansen, Lennert Weber
students: Berdan, Evangelos M. Masis, Joel Martins Ribeiro, Laurenz J. S. Stammel, Mariia, Marius, Milo Krömer, Ole Hunke

title: Gut Health Guardian: Engineered Probiotics for the Treatment of Perioperative Intestinal Microecological Dysbiosis
abstract: This project aims to develop an intelligent engineered bacterium for the precise treatment of perioperative gut microbiota dysbiosis. Using the safe Lactobacillus casei as the chassis, we have integrated a multifunctional genetic circuit. First, by introducing the accA and OLE1 genes, the engineered bacterium can synthesize and release oleic acid--beneficial for gut barrier repair--under the specific regulation of the bile salt-responsive promoter P16090. Simultaneously, the bacterium expresses the antimicrobial peptide defensin DEFB4A to precisely suppress opportunistic pathogens. To ensure biosafety, we designed a bile salt-responsive Hok/Sok toxin-antitoxin "kill switch" system, controlled by the same P16090 promoter. This mechanism ensures that the engineered bacterium only colonizes the gut; any leakage into the external environment triggers its automatic clearance. Together, this living therapeutic platform is equipped with functions for barrier repair, pathogen suppression, and self-regulation, setting a new standard for targeted, safe, and intelligent interventions.
PIs: Yatao Liu, Xingwen Han, Chao Li, ChungHau Juan, Jianming Tang, Rongbing Tang, Xiaodong Xie, Xiao Lyu
advisors: Furen Pan, Hanyu Xie, weitao wang, Yazhen Hao, Yibo Yu, Zhaocheng Li
students: Chengru Kong, Jiaping Huang, JiaxiangChen, jinsenwei, Liling Chen, Liting Zhao, Lysandra, Mao Liao, Peitong Jiang, Qianhui Gao, Shuai Ni, Tao Lin, Tina, Ting Pan, Weibo Zhao, Xiangyue Zhou, Xiaoya Zhou, Yanyan Yang, Yaofang Zhang, yao liu, Ye Zhang, Yongkang Feng, Yu Cao, Yufei Wu, Yu Zheng, Zhao Jiarui, Zhirui Huang

title: Hyaluronext
abstract: Hyaluronic acid (HA) is a biomolecule widely utilized in healthcare and cosmetic applications. Traditionally, HA is extracted from animal or bacterial sources. Research has examined the potential of microbial production using non-pathogenic bacteria. These methods could be a promising ethical and scalable alternative. Given current demand, HA yields remain insufficient. We aim to maximize production efficiency through Multiplex Automated Genome Engineering (MAGE) and specialized E. coli. MAGE enables rapid, high-throughput modification of multiple genomic sites simultaneously, facilitating metabolic pathway optimization and synthetic biology applications. However, MAGE is hindered by high cost, complexity, and limited versatility of existing hardware. Our group is developing the Open-Source Automated Genome Engineering (O-SAGE) platform, leveraging affordable, commercially available components and open-source parts. The goal is to engineer E. coli capable of efficient HA production using O-SAGE, providing a safe, ethical, and scalable source of HA while also democratizing access to advanced genome engineering technologies.
students: Aaron De Silva, Anh Vo, Ashkan Mosabeb-Omran, Ayden McCue, Enrique Zaki Olvis, Eugene Gu, Jan, Mikaela Erickson Aguilar, Odin schaefer, Sabrina, SarahAnn, Sonia Ahuja

title: BiOilRo: Sustainable Biosynthesis of Ginsenoside Ro for Valorization of Low-Value Carbon Sources in Waste Oil
abstract: Ginsenoside Ro is one of the rarest and most valuable bioactive compounds in ginseng, celebrated for its potent antioxidant properties and multi-target therapeutic potential. However, its natural abundance is extremely low, and traditional extraction methods are both costly and environmentally unsustainable. To address this challenge, we engineered a recombinant Saccharomyces cerevisiae system capable of converting waste oil-derived carbon sources, such as glycerol and fatty acids, into Ro through an optimized three-step biosynthetic pathway. By integrating metabolic engineering, enzyme evolution, and modeling-guided optimization, we achieved a substantial enhancement in Ro yield while reducing resource consumption and environmental footprint. This platform exemplifies the principles of a circular bioeconomy, transforming industrial waste into high-value pharmaceuticals. Combining strong environmental benefits with significant economic potential, our work establishes a scalable, sustainable model for advancing green manufacturing and the future of synthetic biology-based healthcare.
nominations: Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad+Best Biomanufacturing Project, Undergrad
advisors: Keyan Wang, Shuqi Zhou, Wei Jiang, Xiaoyu Zhang, Yingtong Wang
students: Chen Wang, Chen Yichun, Ding Ma, Dongchen Jiang, En Chen, Fanfei Liu, Fanzhuo Xu, Hangxuan Li, Haoran Zhao, Huiyan Xu, Jiayin Sun, Jie Song, Jingning Wang, Jintong Zhu, Junxi Chen, liumingwan, Mengxin Zhao, molinfeng, Naichen Yao, Quanhao Wang, Shaohang Sun, Sixuan Li, Tong Zhu, Xinyue Chai, yangyifeng, Yingxuan Min, Yirou Gong, Zheyang Xie

title: POLYGONE: Development of marine high-efficiency polyester-degrading enzyme
abstract: Polyester plastics (PET/PBAT/PLA) persist in marine environments and form harmful microplastics. To tackle source-level persistence and end-of-pipe remediation we combined marine-enzyme discovery, computational protein redesign and AI-driven mutation design, inorganic CaCO?-SiO? immobilization compatible with melt processing, and an E. coli dual-anchor surface-display (adhesion + SpyTag/SpyCatcher-tethered hydrolase). A marine hydrolase ("2013") was mined, characterized and redesigned to a soluble active variant (SEQ4); immobilization conferred thermal robustness with ?40% activity retained after brief high-temperature treatment, supporting processing compatibility. Enzyme-containing films exhibited accelerated surface erosion in 28-day real-seawater assays; the dual-anchor strain enhanced local TPA release versus controls; and a rapid hydroxylation-Fenton fluorescence assay enabled sensitive TPA quantification. Future work will optimize kinetics for high-crystallinity PET, scale immobilization/compounding to pilot, integrate a genetically encoded TPA biosensor, and assess environmental fate, safety and regulatory pathways.
nominations: Best Education, Undergrad+Best Bioremediation Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Yifei Zhang-BUCT, Jia Wang, Xiaolin Shen, Zhengjun Li
advisors: Linwei Yu, Muhammad Ali, Sharon Zou, Xiaoye Liang, Yicheng Zeng
student leaders: Junbin Li, Li Liu, Rodrigo Salvador Ventura Cruz, zihao li
students: Aayush Atishay Lal, Boyuan Ma, Changye Wu, Chengxuan Wu, Chenhan Wang, Kangrui Long, Mengmeng Wang, Pingwei Li, Tuantuan Li, Xingxing Zhou, Xinyan Yang, Xinyuan Jiang, Yuxin Zhou, Zengrong Tang, Zhengyang lin, Zihan Wang

title: Tuneable Dream Drive
abstract: Tuneable Dream Drive: To address sleep disorders caused by circadian rhythm disruption during space missions, the JLU-CP team engineered a multi-layer regulatory melatonin synthesis system using Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) as a chassis. This system integrates a red-light-controlled genetic circuit with the serine recombinase Bxb1, enabling reversible promoter inversion to switch between serotonin production and melatonin biosynthesis. A pharmacokinetic (PK) model optimized dosage under simulated microgravity, while deep-learning-driven enzyme engineering enhanced HsAANAT catalytic efficiency. We then built an expression model to predict melatonin yield under light conditions for controllable production. For biosafety, the design includes a hypoxia-activated toxin-antitoxin module and tryptophan-auxotrophic safeguard. Additionally, we developed iTutor, the most inclusive-iGEM LLM trained on iGEM Wiki, PubMed, and arXiv data, provides real-time computational and experimental guidance. This engineered probiotic functions as a gut-colonizing "biological clock calibrator," enabling precise, red-light-induced melatonin release to support astronauts' circadian health during spaceflight.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Undergrad+Best Education, Undergrad
PIs: Zhicheng Wang, Yonggang Zhang, Fangming Gu, Bo Yang, Yannan Shen
instructors: Huan He, Jinhua Li, Yunyun Cheng

students: Chen Chen, Chenjiao Diao, Feiran Yu, Jingyi Kang, Kai Gong, Kaiwen Zheng, Tianqi wang, Tong Cui, Weishan Du, Xinyi Wang, Xuanhao Chang, Yalin Zhu, Yiran Huang, Yutong Li, Yuxuan He, ZhangRonggang, Zhichao Li, Zhiqi Zhang, Zhiyuan Jin

title: NomNomNylon: towards a sustainable future for nylon waste
abstract: Fast fashion has accelerated the accumulation of synthetic textile waste, with nylon being among the least recycled fractions. Landfilling and incineration are the current disposal methods, producing microplastics and emitting greenhouse gases. NomNomNylon proposes a bio-upcycling strategy that couples enzymatic pretreatment with microbial valorisation. To enhance depolymerization, we developed a protein engineering pipeline to increase thermostability and activity while exploring nature's enzymatic diversity through sequence mining. These variants and homologues were tested in vitro using a cell-free assay on raw nylon. We employed a bioengineered Pseudomonas putida strain to metabolise nylon-derived oligomers and channel carbon flux toward indigoidine, a sustainable alternative to petrochemical indigo. Beyond lab work, we integrated feedback from experts, policymakers, and NGOs, and raised awareness among the public and youth through educational initiatives. We have shown that nylon waste can serve as a valuable feedstock for high-value products, contributing to a greener textile future.
nominations: Best Model, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
PIs: Kristian Barrett, Aafke van Aalst, Lasse Wrang Meyer, Signe Vangsgaard

title: Squoilene
abstract: Squoilene tackles waste oil (WO) pollution and the high cost of squalene production by integrating experimental work, model and hardware into a cohesive synthetic biology project, engineering Yarrowia lipolytica into an efficient cellular refinery.Through human practice and interdisciplinary communication, we refined design and promoted implementation. We established TriScale, a hierarchical in silico pipeline integrating signal peptide-linker-based peroxisomal targeting design, rational tHMGR enzyme engineering, and system-level growth modeling for predictive and knowledge-guided prototyping. Building on this framework, we developed a compartmentalized metabolism strategy, relocating the entire MVA pathway into peroxisomes to enhance flux and isolate toxic intermediates. To bridge lab design with application, we created the low-cost, automated Integrated Fermentation & Processing System (iFPS), streamlining production from inoculation to crude lysate collection. Our integrated approach demonstrates a sustainable, economically viable route to convert pollutants into valuable cosmetic ingredients?while contributing innovations in culture analysis and fermentation processing.
PIs: Yu Zhou, Kang Ning, xiexiaoman, yanyunjun
advisors: Anna, Lucas, Wu Zhengdong
students: Alexander, AlexSong, Aoru Yang, Haixi ZHAO, huangpeng xie, Jiayi Gao, leadergun, Leo, Ma Yichuan, MiNato, Sunlongcheng, Wu Jiarui, YANG Yiting, Yilong CHEN, Yixuan Wang, Yuyao ZHOU, Zhaowenhui, Ziheng Yu, ???, ???, ???

title: "AMIGO": CRISPR-Cas9-Mediated Metabolic Engineering of Aureobasidium melanogenum for Glucose Synthesis from Methanol
abstract: In response to growing climate concerns, biological CO2 capture and utilization technologies have attracted significant attention. Beyond direct CO2 fixation, the biological assimilation of the liquid one-carbon compounds, such as methanol, offers a promising alternative route for converting CO2 into value-added products. Aureobasidium melanogenum, a kind of poly-extremotolerant yeast-like fungus, exhibits remarkable potential for producing diverse bioproducts. Here, we established a CRISPR?Cas9 gene?editing system for A. melanogenum and elucidated the mechanisms underlying its methanol metabolism. By reprogramming key metabolic pathways, we constructed an engineered strain capable of synthesizing glucose from methanol. Furthermore, to optimize the cultivation of A. melanogenum, we developed a real-time methanol monitoring and automatic feeding device based on a gas-liquid exchange model, enabling convenient and accurate methanol concentration measurement. This study provides a foundational framework for leveraging A. melanogenumin the bioconversion of C1 compounds toward chemical production, highlighting its potential for sustainable carbon utilization.
advisors: Yingfang Yuan, Zhaorui Jiang
students: Fenghua Su, Guanghao Cui, Li Ruiqi, Weilin Man, Yifei Shao, Yingbo Zhang, Yizhou Zhang, Yueyang Sun, Zitai Wei

title: PHAntom: PHA Novel Tools for Off-world Manufacturing
abstract: Since the Mariner 4 flyby, Mars has inspired interplanetary exploration, but high payload costs limit human settlement. Our team proposes PHAntom, a synthetic biology system using engineered E. coli to convert Martian CO? into bioplastics and metabolites. Our two-strain E. coli system converts CO? into PHBV via an acetate intermediate. Strain 1 autotrophically fixes CO? and secretes acetate using the pta-ackA pathway. Strain 2, aided by tdcB/tdcE for propionyl-CoA supply and tesB/yciA to balance 3HB/3HV monomers, converts acetate into PHBV. A bicarbonate-responsive cAMP-CRP mechanism enhances transcription under high HCO??, while CRISPRi knockdown of gltA diverts acetyl-CoA from the TCA cycle, optimizing acetate production and PHBV yield. Team PHAntom has built a clinostat to simulate non-Earth gravity conditions and an extrusion system to convert PHBV granules into printable filaments. PHAntom enables sustainable off-world biomaterial production through integrated carbon capture, adaptive metabolism, and on-site manufacturing
nominations: Best Hardware, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Undergrad+Best Space Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Alexis Stein, Allison Lopatkin, Anthony Renzi, Elio Abbondanzieri, Elizabeth Martin, Lacie Low, Zack Vanderhoff
students: Cassidy Garibaldo, Clare Liu, Daniel Oh, Hannah Lee, Jackson Zhao, Jessica Wang, Maia Kurti, Michael Townsend, Owen Oxley, Sevarakhon Umarova, Shailey Guddeti, Soham Bandyopadhyay, Sophie Black, Victoria Wang

title: HydroGuard
abstract: Catheter associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) are the most common hospital infection, disproportionately affecting vulnerable populations such as those in long-term care homes or the critically ill. While the standard treatments for these infections rely primarily on antibiotics, the increasing prevalence of antimicrobial resistant infections demands for an alternative solution. To combat this issue, we have developed HydroGuard, a biocompatible, infection-responsive hydrogel with controlled phage release. Our hydrogel, made up of gelatin methacryloyl, degrades in the presence of gelatinase (gelE), a protein naturally produced by E.faecalis during infection. The degradation of gelatin in the hydrogel releases the embedded phage cocktail, which targets and eradicates the biofilm. Using a combined wet-lab and computational approach, our work demonstrates the viability of this solution by incorporating the gelE gene into E.coli for lab-safe proof of concept solution.
advisors: Madison Thomas
student leaders: Aadila Zakir Hussain, Akshay, Ayana Pak, Isabella D'Costa, Mahnoor Butt, Rhyan McLean, Shilpa Rao, Trisha, Wallace Lee
