title: Integrative Melatonin and Bioengineered Wax-Coating System for Lychee Preservation
abstract: Lychee deteriorates rapidly after harvest due to high respiration, browning, and fungal decay. Current preservation methods rely on costly cold chains and chemical additives. Our project proposes a sustainable synthetic biology solution integrating melatonin biosynthesis and bioengineered wax coating. Engineered Bacillus subtilis produces melatonin to reduce respiration, delay browning, and enhance lychee immunity. Meanwhile, a LacI-lactose regulatory system promotes fatty acid accumulation, enabling the formation of a protective wax layer that retains moisture and prevents microbial invasion. Complemented by AI-assisted dry-lab tools--BactaGenome for bacterial genome analysis, SynbioMCP for intuitive biological design, and a drone-based spraying system for large-scale application--our approach provides an eco-friendly and intelligent lychee preservation platform that extends shelf life and reduces postharvest waste.
PIs: Julie Qiaojin Lin, June Junyu XU
advisors: Hua XU, Jianhao Ruan, Jian KANG, Quanying MI, Ruiming XU, Shiyao Guan, SZE LAI, Yilin LIU, Zhuoyang Chen
student leaders: Isak Shanzheng LIU, Jane Jingen GUO, Jingyao Zhao, Lesile Siming HUANG, Tongen Huang, Yuqing CUI
students: Ben, Beverly Tingwen Liu, Haoyu Ruan, Jinghan ZHAO, Junyu Pan, Qingyang LI, Shutao DAI, Van Hongtao Fan, Xinzhi WU, Xueyi Wang, Yiran Dong, Yongshan WU, Yuan Wang, Yucheng Ge, Yuhe Wu, Yunuo Wang, Zhiyi Chen

title: SurFactory: A Sustainable Pulmonary Surfactant Innovation
abstract: Premature newborns often face respiratory distress due to underdeveloped lungs, requiring pulmonary surfactant for survival. Current treatments are costly, rely on animal-derived sources, and remain inaccesible to many healthcare systems wolrdwide. Our project uses synthetic biology and biomanufacturing to create an alternative surfactant that is animal-free, affordable, and scalable. By engineering microorganisms to produce key surfactant proteins, we aim to deliver a sustainable solution that bridges health inequities and reduces dependence on traditional animal-derived products. This approach not only addresses a pressing medical challenge but also introduces an ethical and environmentally responsible production pipeline. Through our work, we envision a future where every premature infant, regardless of geography or economic status, can access life-saving pulmonary surfactant demonstrating how synthetic biology can transform global health challenges into opportunities for innovation, sustainability, and equity.
advisors: Bruno Victoria, Diana Rosalba Sánchez Hernández, Eduardo Zúñiga-León, Elizabeth Valencia Alvarez, Jose Luis Martinez Vaquero, Juan Manuel Herrera Hernández
student leaders: Aide Michelle Cuellar Huerta, Angel Yered Rodríguez Rojas, Enya Paola Guzmán Rosas, Mariana Hernandez Cruz
students: Adrián Álvarez, Angel, Ari Rodríguez, Carlos pazos, David Francisco, Isaí Figueroa, Jéssica Paola Sánchez Díaz, Julett Herrera, Julio, Laura Hernández, Leilani Morales Serrano, LidiaGP, Lucina Tecuapetla, Lya Torres Sánchez, María Juárez, Mariana, Meg, Pily, Tonantzin Fernanda Moreno Lara, Valeria Loza, Valeria Sánchez Zapoteca, Vanessa, Yarely, yoa

title: Optogenetic Activation System for Intelligent Surfactin expression?OASIS?
abstract: Harmful algal blooms (HABs) pose severe threats to marine ecosystems, aquaculture, and human health. Traditional control methods are often inefficient, environmentally risky, and prone to secondary pollution. To address these challenges, the SUSTechOCEAN team developed an intelligent and controllable HAB mitigation system that integrates artificial intelligence prediction with synthetic biology intervention. Using a deep learning-based OI-SwinUnet model, we predict the risk of HAB occurrence from environmental parameters such as nutrient concentrations, temperature, and dissolved oxygen. When the predicted risk exceeds a defined threshold, engineered Bacillus subtilis expresses Surfactin C14--a biodegradable, low-toxicity biosurfactant with strong algicidal activity--under blue-light induction. Meanwhile, red light activates the expression of the phage-derived YonE protein, which depletes intracellular NAD? and triggers cell death, ensuring biosafety. This system achieves intelligent linkage between "prediction" and "intervention," providing a sustainable, eco-friendly, and safe synthetic biology solution for marine ecosystem protection.
advisors: Louis Yu, Yuan Feng
students: Ann, Benxiang Xiao, Caroline, Dottie Sun, Eileen, Elisabeth Ye, Farui Ru, GuojingKai, jiali Qiang, Ju Crystal, Kai Ao, Linyao Xu, Li Yixue, Lucia, Mingqian Zhong, Moqi Tang, Nancy, Nordlich, Quan An, Renee Lu, TIANLING XU, Tracy Lin, Xintong Shen, ???

title: Rational Engineering of Novel Ultra-Efficient Amidohydrolases for Ochratoxin A Degradation
abstract: By integrating enzyme engineering with synthetic biology, we have developed a highly efficient and specific biodegradation platform with exceptional potential. Starting from ADH3--the most active OTA hydrolase reported to date--we rationally designed the S88E mutant, whose additional hydrogen-bond network increases catalytic efficiency (kcat/KM) by 3.7-fold. To surmount the remaining catalytic bottleneck, we mined the sequence space of ADH3 and identified the homologous enzyme LIADH (73 % identity) that possesses twice the native activity of ADH3. Structure-guided redesign of LIADH yielded the I326A variant; removal of the ?-branched side chain relieves steric congestion at the acyl-enzyme intermediate, affording a further 75 % improvement in activity. Collectively, we obtained two high-performance biocatalysts--ADH3-S88E and LIADH-I326A--and accomplished the first comprehensive structural, kinetic, and mechanistic characterization of any OTA hydrolase.
PIs: Yumei Hu, Haimou Zhang, Longhai Dai, Wenshan Ke, Zhifan Yang
advisors: mandos
students: Aoxue Huang, Baichuan Jiang, Binyu Guo, chenyuxi, Deyi Feng, enyuli, Guorong Tan, Jinbing Yao, Keyi Yang, Qiyi Zhang, shiyi wang, SiyaoYu, Wenchao Dai, Wenrui Zhang, wuxing, Xingyu Xie, Xiong Yvxuan, Xueqin Xi, Xueyan Rui, yaping jin, Yijun Wu, Yiming Wu, Yiou He, Yuan Xiao, Yu Fan, Yupei Zhang, zheng huixin, Zihan Jin, ???

title: O! Super Carpet
abstract: Green tides caused by Ulva prolifera have become a seasonal ecological disaster in Qingdao. The traditional physical salvage methods are time-consuming and laborious. So our team's project uses a synthetic biology solution to address green tides at the source--spores, a key driver of bloom recurrence.? Since the core of our project is "capture spore", we rearranged letters and named our project "O! Super Carpet". It is composed of three main modules. We would like to name them after spells from Harry Potter. First, the 'Ennervate' survival spell ensures that our engineered bacteria can survive in high-salinity seawater. Second, the 'Permanent Sticking' functional spell is responsible for efficiently capturing Ulva spores with specificity. Finally, the 'Avada Kedavra' biosafety spell guarantees safety of the project in open environments. By combining synthetic biology with ecological insight, our project aims to demonstrate how engineered microbes can offer sustainable solutions to marine environmental crises.
nominations: Best Conservation Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
instructors: Lizhe Chen, Xiaohan Zhang, Zixin Rong
advisors: Aurora, Baiding Chen, Hao Wu, Jianing, jiaqian, Jintong Zhang, Jiyi Wang, Lexuan Li, mingchen sun, Qiayi Zha, Ruiqi Cao, Shenghan Sun, Shouye Zhu, Weizhuo Chen, Xiaojun, yimeng sun, Yimin Wan, Yiwei Yang, Yuchong Yan
students: Boao, Hanqi, Jingan, LingBin, Lingyu, Shu, Sihan Fan, Xiaoyu Zhang, zixuan zhou

title: Pure Era - XJTLU-Software 2025
abstract: Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are essential natural molecules with broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity. To accelerate AMP discovery, we developed SPADE, a Systematic Platform for Antimicrobial peptide Database with Evaluation, integrating and standardizing data from four major AMP repositories (APD3, DRAMP, DBAASP, and LAMP), resulting in over 39,000 curated peptides. After rigorous cleaning and unification of experimental conditions, we established the AMP-Oriented Six tasks (AMPOS) dataset and the AMP-Oriented Multi-Property Prediction Task (AMPPT), covering classification and regression subtasks including MIC, half-life, and hemolytic activity. We further designed the AMP-Oriented Multi-task Model (AOMM), achieving state-of-the-art performance across all AMPPT subtasks. Additionally, a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system was implemented to enhance intelligent AMP searching. Overall, SPADE provides an integrated, reproducible, and extensible foundation for AMP data analysis, model benchmarking, and AI-assisted peptide design in modern bioinformatics.
nominations: Best Software & AI Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Baiding Chen, Jianing, jiaqian, Yimin Wan
students: changliu, Haoze Ma, Jingan Tan, Kewu.Li, Qi Guo, Yilin

title: Plaszyme: AI-Powered Discovery of Plastic-Degrading Enzymes
abstract: Plastic pollution represents a growing global crisis, while biodegrading enzymes provide a sustainable route to plastic recycling. To accelerate enzyme identification, Plaszyme integrates AI-based models that learn from both biological and chemical representations to predict enzyme-polymer interactions with interpretability and precision. Our framework combines machine learning classifiers and structure-aware dual-tower neural networks, enabling multi-level prediction from amino acid sequences to 3D enzyme-polymer compatibility. A lightweight Web App offers browser-based batch prediction, visualization, and interpretability without local setup. In parallel, we curated and released PlaszymeDB, an open-access database compiling verified enzyme-plastic pairs, sequences, structures, and physicochemical descriptors under FAIR principles. Through continued development and open dissemination via iGEM and the Web App, Plaszyme establishes a unified resource for data-driven exploration of plastic biodegradation and sustainable material recycling.
instructors: Wenlong Yan, Xuefei Zhao, Ziwen Xie
students: Aixue Wang, Jiaqi Zheng, Shang Wang, Shulei He, Yan Long, YichenTang, Other, Zimu.Xie

title: Lacbutler
abstract: Lactose intolerance, a prevalent global condition, causes symptoms like diarrhea and abdominal pain due to lactase deficiency in the gut. Current dietary management lacks long-term efficacy and impacts life quality. We propose a sustainable synthetic biology-based therapy using engineered Bifidobacterium. This strain is modified with a optimized bgaB lactase and LacY lactose transporter for efficient lactose metabolism. It also incorporates a genetic circuit with a deoxycholic acid-inducible MucBP adhesion protein and an AI-2/CcdB-mediated population control system. This design enables stable colonization at an appropriate density, ensuring continuous lactose breakdown for long-term management of lactose intolerance.
students: Bangyu Liao, Houjun Wang, Jingshu Zhang, Luyao Yu, Mantong Zhao, Ruisong Shi, Ruyao Xu, Shubei Lai, Xiaoxiao Wang, Yi Liu, Ziqi Liu

title: Glow to Grow
abstract: Desferrioxamine is the most economically important siderophore, used in life-saving chelation therapy for thalassemia patients and iron overload disorders, plus industrial applications like gallium recovery from wastewater. However, high production costs limit its accessibility. Current production relies on Streptomyces pilosus, which suffers from slow growth, low yields, and complex lifecycles that complicate industrial-scale fermentation, making it unsuitable as a production platform. Our team is transferring the desferrioxamine biosynthetic gene cluster to Rhodococcus, which doesn't naturally produce desferrioxamine but is well-established in industry for producing complex secondary metabolites. Rhodococcus offers fast growth, high scalability, and excellent fermentation characteristics. Both species belong to Actinobacteria, sharing similar genetic architecture, codon usage, and metabolic frameworks necessary for expressing the desferrioxamine pathway. To confirm successful pathway integration and transcriptional activity during transfer, we designed a split-GFP monitoring system. We aim to reduce desferrioxamine production costs and increase its accessibility for medical and industrial applications.
advisors: Lindelo Mguni
students: Henrik Dülberg, Jesse, Julia Petric, Klim Glebov, Lasse Neumann, Leon Welz, Luca Macagnino, Maria Sviridova, Yannik Kubsch

title: CyanoSense: Microcystin Detection and Degradation with Acinetobacter baylyi ADP1
abstract: Rapid growth of algae in response to environmental pressures, such as climate change, has increased cyanotoxin prevalence in freshwater ecosystems, exceeding safety standards. The most prevalent cyanotoxins produced are microcystins, known to cause harm to humans and animals upon ingestion. Current methods of identifying microcystins involve complex and expensive quantitative assays, which are impractical for field deployment. Our team explored a method to safely detect and degrade these toxins by engineering Acinetobacter baylyi (ADP1) to perform as a biosensor and biodegrader. The system detects environmental DNA (eDNA) released by microcystin-producing cyanobacteria. Upon detection of a target region of DNA within the microcystin gene pathway, the biosensor will activate genes responsible for enzymatic microcystin degradation, providing a potential strategy for eliminating microcystins.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, Overgrad
advisors: Ariana Hernandez, Ranudhi Nanayakkara, Syna Sogi
students: Ahnsa Campbell, Ella Steinborn, Issac Koshy, Jazmyn Koenst, Jose Martinez - McIntosh, Juan Andres Hinojosa, Nick Rhyan, Nithya Vegiraju, Phuong Le, Ryan Dinh, Shivali Chava, Zaynab Bashir

title: RGBio: Trichromatic Optogenetic Regulation of Gene Expression in E. coli
abstract: RGBio focused on creating an "optogenetic toolkit" allowing regulation of three genes or regulons using red, green, and blue light. This toolkit uses three optogenetic switches to orthogonally regulate gene expression in response to each type of light stimulus. Our team applied this toolkit to bioplastic synthesis and modulation of polymer properties. Bioplastics can be made from standard carbon sources or from waste carbon, making the system robust and allowing for remediation of molecules like waste acetate that are produced in large amounts yearly. Other teams and researchers can use our optogenetic toolkit to regulate their genes of interest without the need for induction molecules, and can easily remove or replace components of our optogenetic switches through a simple restriction digest and Gibson Assembly-compatible insert.
PIs: Ed Eisenstein, Dr. Brian Blair, Jason D Kahn
student leaders: Abhi Senthilkumar, Aditri Gadigi, Brennen Le, Graham Ferguson, Jonathan Wu, Lauren Applegate, Mahita Kamalahasan, Rebecca Lu, Renee Jaranson
students: Abraham, Archita Naik, Chloe Connolly, Elizabeth Chuang, Haider Hussain, Hannah LaPadula, Jennifer Qiu, Joshua Duong, Julia Y. Chen, Liam Cooney, Matthew Q., Patrick Hong, Soma Hebbar, Vishal

title: NCLOSE
abstract: With our project NCLOSE, we are tackling the growing global challenge of nitrate pollution. Agriculture is one of the main drivers: synthetic fertilizers and animal manure release large amounts of ammonium, which soil microbes convert to nitrate. NCLOSE aims to counteract this by producing ?-polyglutamic acid (PGA), a natural polymer capable of reversibly binding ammonium, directly in manure. This reduces nitrate leaching while providing crops with a slow-release nutrient source. We introduced three genes encoding PGA synthetase into Clostridium cellulovorans, an anaerobic, cellulolytic bacterium, well-equipped for growth in manure. Additionally, we created resources to make this chassis more accessible for future teams, including adapted workflows, a genome-scale model and a taxonomic analysis. The development of a solid biosafety concept was also a central aspect. Through integrated human practices, we ensured NCLOSE remains safe, sustainable and socially responsible, turning manure from part of the problem into part of the solution.
nominations: Best Wiki, Overgrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Overgrad+Best Agriculture Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Lars M. Blank, Ulrich Schwaneberg, Wolfgang Wiechert
students: Alexa Stermann, Alissa Jonas, Amelie Thoma, Arthur Hehner, Christina Ness, Florian Kummer, Franka Enke, Hannah Kahlen, Ihssan Achoukhi, Lilli Vierk, Mohamed Wehbe, Natalie Benic, Taya Coban

title: APHiGO-A Next-Generation RNA Pesticide Platform for Citrus Aphid Control
abstract: As the world's largest citrus producer, China contributes one-quarter of global citrus output, yet faces severe threats from the concealed brown citrus aphid. To address this, we present APHiGO--an RNAi-based platform for sustainable aphid control, integrating smart monitoring with precise molecular intervention. APHiGO's early-warning module uses engineered Bacillus subtilis to detect honeydew and emit volatile signals, monitored via IoT sensors. Upon detection, RNAi molecules targeting vital aphid genes are delivered via trunk injection. Packaged in engineered virus-like particles, these molecules are efficiently ingested, silencing key genes and impeding development. For localized outbreaks, modified Metarhizium fungi deliver dsRNA externally and internally, enhancing lethality and delaying resistance. By combining biosensing, RNAi targeting, and biocontrol, APHiGO transitions pest management from chemical reliance to intelligent, sustainable precision agriculture.
nominations: Best Conservation Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Amelia Wei, Chen Ruoyu, HAOSHENG DENG, Jielin Li, Jinxv Wang, Mingliang Wang, Qixian Zeng, Ruiyue Chen, Siyuan Guo, Xuedong Liu, Yan Huang, Yongsheng Bai, Yuanrun Liu, Yuxiang Xiong, Zhengyue Hong
student leaders: Haocheng Li, Jiachun Chen, Liu Yuxuan
students: Bingying ZHU, BU SHUJING, CHENMINWEI, Jiaxun Lu, Jindi Feng, Qizheng Liu, Ruohan Shi, XINYUE FENG, YANGZIQI, Yutong Chen, ZHOU XIAYING, Ziyuan Li, Zou Zhuoming, ZZQ, ???, ???

title: Pause-aware Codon Design Assistant
abstract: Protein translation proceeds discontinuously, with ribosomes pausing to enable co-translational folding of nascent chains. Although ribosome profiling (Ribo-seq) has revealed widespread translational pauses, existing mRNA design frameworks largely ignore these kinetic features. Here, we identify conserved pausing sites across multiple human cell lines using EIF-based Ribo-seq and propose that such pauses facilitate proper protein folding. We developed PACD (Pause-Aware Codon Design), a computational framework that incorporates ribosome pausing information into mRNA optimization. A neural model trained on pausing sequences enables predictive integration with LinearDesign to preserve beneficial pauses during codon optimization. While pause-constrained designs slightly reduce mRNA stability and CAI, they are expected to enhance folding efficiency. This study represents the first systematic attempt to link translational pausing with codon design, providing a foundation for engineering "pause-aware" synthetic genes with improved structural fidelity.
advisors: Yuman Li
students: Eduardo Miao, LiuYinkuan, Shihong Yang, Sihang Huang, Siqi Tu, xingyu, Yixin Hu, Zihan Xu

title: Pyronix - The Next Generation of Firefighting
abstract: Wildfires present major global challenges, from CO2 emissions and ecosystem destruction to severe public health impacts. Current firefighting methods also carry significant drawbacks. Pyronix offers a new approach, harnessing synthetic biology to create a more sustainable solution. We engineered a hydrogel-based fire retardant assembled from components produced by microorganisms. The gel structure is composed of cellulose and chitosan. Silica nanoparticles and a fire-retardant protein are embedded in the gel to improve its fire resistance. To deploy the hydrogel, we developed an artificial intelligence equipped drone for safe and automated firefighting, supporting life-saving decisions made by the operators. We engineered yeast strains for enhanced chitosan production, bacterial cells building up silica nanoparticles, and expression systems to produce fire retardant proteins. We assembled the components into a gel-like structure to study its fire-retardant properties. Pyronix provides a solid foundation for developing sustainable firefighting methods from production to deployment.
awards: Finalist+Top 10+1st Runner-up+Best Climate Crisis Project+Best Measurement+Best Presentation+Best Software Tool+Best Sustainable Development Impact+Best Wiki
students: Andrea, Cynthia Rabay, David, Elyse Peguret, Julie Delis, Khaoula, Milo Sanders, Nafi Anna, Sarah Bianchi, Tessnim

title: Splintein
abstract: The lack of precise control over post-translational modifications in synthetic protein production is a significant obstacle in research and biomanufacturing, especially in the development of biopharmaceuticals. To overcome this we developed Self Integrating Scaffolds (SIS), protein fragments flanked by split inteins. This project aims to insert a glycosylated SIS in Immunoglobuline G. To optimise our SIS, it's necessary to test how efficient two pairs of inteins can be used together. Because of that, we have designed a FRET assay, which enables us to test split intein pairs in high-throughput for their quantitative kinetic compatibility in real-time using only a plate reader. In addition, we applied dynamical modelling, docking simulations, structural comparisons, mathematical modelling and programming in R-studio to provide a more in-depth understanding of all these aspects regarding our SIS and FRET assay. Together, our results lay the foundation of using split inteins to change the world of protein engineering.
nominations: Best Education, Overgrad
students: Adriana A. Anguelova, Gelijn Brandjes, Iris Niestadt, Julianna, Kimberly Zaal, Louke, Tijn Looij, Xavian

title: Unravelling PET at the Seams
abstract: To alleviate the problem of plastic pollution and mitigate the serious impacts made by plastic on our environment, our team worked on multiple DNA combinations to break down PET. Our solution is HotPETase, an enzyme that can degrade PET plastics readily at high temperatures. We have paired it up with the genes BaCBM2 and CsgA respectively, then combined all three genes together to form our final gene combination. Out of all gene constructs, HotPETase-BaCBM2 showed the best performance, having the greatest increase in absorbance and the largest decrease in mass of the PET fragment at 70°C. Our main target gene combination, CsgA-HotPETase-BaCBM2 showed promising results during the absorbance test, having the second highest increase in absorbance at 60°C. SEM imaging was conducted on the PET samples, with irregular cracks being observed on the PET surface, in contrast to the smooth surface of the control.
advisors: Drake Fan, Kin On Christopher Wong, Oscar Cheung
student leaders: Chan Siu Hang, Damian Lin, Fong Hoi Lap James, Leo Wong Him
students: Chiang Ka Him Ryan, Chris Chan, Ethan Ho, Harold Leung, Isaac Chui, Jack Du, Jason Leung, Jay Jen, Kingsley Cheng, Mason, Maverix Poon, Michael, Nathan, Noah Yuan, Sean Yu, Tsang Tsz Hei

title: PURPLE - Plastic Upcycling to Reduce Pollution and Loop the Economy
abstract: In response to the global challenge of plastic waste, our iGEM project aims to develop innovative biological pathways for the upcycling of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic into high-value products, such as BHB (Beta Hydroxybutyrate). Our approach designs synthetic pathways in E. coli and P. putida, enabling them to convert PET waste into Polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) and later BHB. Utilizing computational tools and Flux Balance Analysis (FBA), we will optimize the engineered pathways to enhance the flux towards PHB production. This will include the use of kinetic models to predict and refine enzyme activity based on varying substrate concentrations. By designing and constructing novel biological parts, we aim to establish an innovative production pathway that aligns with circular economy principles. This will not only facilitate the conversion of PET plastic waste into valuable products but also provide a sustainable solution to a pressing environmental issue.
nominations: Best Village Project, High School
student leaders: Amy Wang, Jayden Lau, Rei Ang, Sarah Pan
students: Austin Tang, Claire, Ellen Zhao, Elsie, Emily, Ethan, Hana, Hanwon Kim, Ingrid Lee, Jerry Liang, Megan, Sean Jiang, Sieun, Sophie, Zoe

title: GumEraser+?Combat Peach Gummosis Initiative
abstract: Peach gummosis seriously harms peach tree health, mainly triggered by fungal infections and environmental stress. It causes bark cracking and gummy exudation, weakening trees severely or even killing them. Current controls depend on chemicals and agricultural management, but problems like drug resistance and pollution remain, leaving a gap for efficient, eco-friendly solutions. ‘GumEraser+' proposes to manipulate three key factors required for disease occurrence: 1) Apply specific RNA-based biopesticides to inhibit the activity of pathogens; 2) Promote the cultivation of disease-resistant host varieties; 3) Promote pruning of peach trees to improve orchard air circulation. The ‘+' symbol here stands for three aspirations in addressing it: 1) Boost farmers' income; 2) Enhance personal growth; 3) Promote knowledge transfer.

title: DNA-Based Biosensors for Cardiovascular miRNA Detection with Machine Learning-Integrated Design Tool
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) remain the leading cause of global mortality, highlighting the need for rapid and sensitive diagnostic technologies. We developed an integrated nucleic acid-based biosensing platform that detects CVD-related microRNAs (miRNAs) with high specificity. The biosensor combines three-way junction (3WJ) probe recognition and a split G-quadruplex (G4) DNAzyme switch, where target-induced linker release reconstitutes the G4 structure. The G4/hemin complex catalyzes the oxidation of TMB, producing measurable electrochemical signals on a portable reader. The system achieved a limit of detection of 480 pM, demonstrating strong sensitivity and specificity. To accelerate probe optimization, machine learning (ML) models trained on experimental datasets (2500 miRNA-specific 3WJ probes and 728 split G4 probes) reached 83% accuracy for the 3WJ model and 80% for the split G4 model. This data-driven biosensor framework bridges biosensing probe design and ML prediction, enabling rapid, customizable, and cost-effective miRNA diagnostics for cardiovascular and other diseases.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School

title: ColoTrace
abstract: Significance Colorectal cancer (CRC) is one of the most ubiquitous types of cancer in Hong Kong, with approximately 10,000 new cases diagnosed annually. Early detection can significantly improve prognosis, with successful treatment rates exceeding 90%. However, the current mainstream screening methods, such as colonoscopy, FOBT, and FIT, have their limitations of being invasive and inconvenient. Project Mechanics Our project aims to create a tool that detects CRC in its early stages. Our ColoTrace kit detects overexpressed microRNAs (miR) of CRC in the faecal samples, and create coloured proteins that indicate a positive detection. Engineering and Results Six toehold switches that detect miR-92a-3p and miR-135b-5p are designed, and one of the ligated toehold-plasmids was successfully cloned in E. coli, and two of the toehold-plasmids showed strong expression when triggered by the target microRNA.
PIs: Yat Shing Lee, WING KA WONG, Constantine Wing Heng Lau, Allen Tse, Ka Hei Chan, Tsui Shing Yan, Wai Yin Lau, Wong Shuk Ling, Yee Tung Chan, Yuen Tin Yat

title: Aptagenix: One-Pot Isothermal Assay for EGFR Mutation Screening in Lung Cancer
abstract: The project aims to develop a low-cost, rapid, and user-friendly diagnostic kit for detecting EGFR mutations in circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA), which are associated with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The system integrates Recombinase Polymerase Amplification (RPA) with CRISPR-Cas9 amplicon cleavage and a Lateral Flow Assay (LFA) readout, enabling a one-pot, isothermal assay that delivers a visual result without specialized equipment. This approach aims to make early molecular screening for NSCLC accessible, especially in resource-limited regions.
students: Aaria Garhwal, Alan S, Apsara Baume, Avery Xiao, Bade, Buse Toksoz, Caroline Hyde, Dashiell, Grisha, Iain, Kei Hayashi, Lucas, Olympia Betts, Pat, Tim, Victor Demyanyuk

title: Crypto-Knight: A Novel Point Of Care Colourimetric Diagnostic Test For Cryptosporidiosis Based On LAMP
abstract: One of the most neglected tropical diseases, Cryptosporidiosis kills an estimated 200,000 children every year and 10 million disability adjusted life years lost annually. It is caused by a parasite, and spreads through infected water samples globally. Current methods, such as qPCR, are expensive, unreliable and affected by inhibitors in faecal samples, with the most common methods having a sensitivity of around 40-60%. Using Loop Mediated Isothermal Amplification, we designed a novel point of care diagnostic for the 18s rRNA of Cryptosporidium, designing an efficient primer set, and four new fusion Bst polymerases, with subdomains designed to increase reverse transcriptase activity, thermostability and inhibitor tolerance. Targeting 18s rRNA allows the test to detect 1 oocyst/gram of faecal sample (compared to qPCR's 300/gram). Results are shown colourimetrically for easy use. With our model and education work, we made the test even more accessible. It's time to shine a LAMP On Cryptosporidiosis!
students: Ada Nielsen, Aishe, Alexander Avaliani, Harriet Chubb, Henry Bartter, Jamie Marini Howells, Lucinda, Luke, Maahika, Mars, Platon, Rajan Philip, Rish, Sriya, Zack, Zara Leghari

title: REEvolutionaTe
abstract: Rare earth elements (REEs) and tellurium are essential for high-tech and renewable technologies, yet less than 1% are currently recycled. To address this, we developed a sustainable, bio-based strategy to recover these elements from e-waste streams. We engineered a modular system using amyloid protein fibers displaying REE-binding proteins, achieving high-affinity capture of REE ions and creating a powerful part collection. Mathematical modeling and molecular dynamics simulations guided design optimization, while a business plan and market analysis evaluated commercial viability. For tellurium recovery, we harnessed the Ter operon to efficiently reduce toxic tellurite into elemental tellurium. To promote our project and raise awareness of synthetic biology, we conducted extensive outreach through exhibitions, workshops, educational activities, blogs, podcasts, and interactive games across hospitals, museums, and schools. Thus, our project demonstrates an integrated synthetic biology platform for the biological recovery of REEs and tellurium from electronic waste.
nominations: Best Education, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad+Best Biomanufacturing Project, Overgrad
instructors: Albane Schmid, Astri Kusumawardhani, Georgia Petsiou, Jung Hun Park

students: Chloé Shan, Elisa Krasensky, Emma S. Castelli, Hugo Marchant, Ilhaan Yaasin Xasan, Jérémie Ducrocq, Julien Vujevic Martinez, Lisa Mauron, Michaël Schwendimann, Paul Lachat, Tian You, Xulia Maillot Rodriguez, Yvan Marbach

title: RePLAce with PLAstic: Enabling On-Site PLA Degradation
abstract: Through IHP, we identified two key challenges from stakeholders' perspectives: insufficient efficiency of PLA-degrading enzymes and unclear recycling classification. To address the first issue, we engineered recombinant enzymes (AC, CA, DP, PK) and developed an auto-induction measurement system for high-throughput screening, with PK variants showing the most promising activity. For the second issue, we aligned with the SDGs by organizing a target field to test PLA usage in isolation and submitting a citizen proposal to advocate for clearer waste management policies and the establishment of industrial composting facilities in Taiwan, providing a practical solution to misclassification. Our project demonstrates the integration of enzyme engineering with community engagement to advance PLA degradation and sustainable waste management.
PIs: Pei-Hong Chen, CH Lee, I-Hao Wen, Yawen, Lo
students: Brian, CHEN YI ZHEN, Chih Han Ting, CI-EN HUANG, Emily, Evan Chiu, Irene Tsai, Jeffery, Joyce Wang, Ju - Ting Hsieh, Leonardo Chang, Marat Wang, Solomon, Wu Tsan Fu, YEN-SHUO FENG, Zih-Ting, Lin

title: MeowTrack: A Probiotic Platform for Feline Gut Health
abstract: Cats are among the most popular companion animals worldwide, yet many of their health issues remain undiagnosed due to subtle symptoms and limited diagnostic tools. Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), often aggravated by hairball accumulation, is a prevalent chronic condition that compromises digestive health. To address this, we developed MeowTrack, a programmable therapeutic probiotic platform that detects, treats, and records feline gut health. The system senses taurocholic acid (food intake) and calprotectin (IBD biomarker) and integrates these inputs through an AND logic gate, ensuring responses occur only under disease conditions with food available. Upon activation, MeowTrack expresses keratin-degrading enzymes to remove hairballs, butyrate-producing enzymes to restore gut balance, and chromoproteins or fluorescent proteins to visualize disease states in feces. Additionally, a Retro-Cascorder module records transcriptional events linked to inflammation, while a smart litter box equipped with fluorescence detection enables seamless, at-home monitoring of feline gut health.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School+Best Village Project, High School
PIs: Ning Kong, Chun Zhang, Chujing Wu, Haoyang Diao, Tingzhen Liu, Wanji Li

students: Cathleen Bingruo Zhang, Hehe Xiao, Jessica Xu, Jingfang Yu, Kuanning Zhang, Kunhang Li, Lucy Liu, Sijing Chen, Xiaoman Zhang, Xinyao Ma, Yihan He, Yining Hu, Yixuan Chu, Zihan Guo (Mika)

title: antiBACjacket
abstract: Plastic cling films are widely used in food preservation but pose long-term environmental risks due to poor degradability, while microbial spoilage continues to cause significant food waste. To address these challenges, SMS-Shenzhen is designing a biodegradable and antimicrobial cling film using synthetic biology. We introduced the pls gene from Streptomyces albulus into Bacillus subtilis to enable ?-polylysine (PLL) production and introduced PPK2 and lysC311 to enhance the productivity. A kill switch is constructed by knocking out the alrA gene, rendering the strain auxotrophic and limiting its survival to controlled conditions. In parallel, we are developing a bilayer film by combining purified PLL with chitosan and sodium alginate-based materials. Our goal is to create a cling film that is both antimicrobial and biodegradable, offering a safer and more sustainable alternative to traditional plastic packaging.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School

students: Devon ZOU, Jingxi Zhang, Johnappleseed, Kaixin You, Michael Du, Muxu Zhang, Ou Jiacheng, Qiu Zichen, ???

title: LL-37 -- the Human Antimicrobial Peptide?
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) poses a severe global public health threat, with drug-resistant bacteria increasingly endangering human health.The human antimicrobial peptide LL-37 offers a promising solution due to its high safety, low resistance potential, and immunomodulatory activity. Our project employs Saccharomyces cerevisiae as a chassis cell, integrating genetic engineering, fermentation optimization, and a D2P cell-free system to achieve high-yield biosynthesis of functional LL-37 at a significantly lower cost than chemical synthesis.We developed the CytoFlow platform, integrating biodynamic simulations, reinforcement learning, and diffusion models. This platform optimizes S. cerevisiae cultivation and designs LL-37 variants with superior antimicrobial performance. We also developed the EFUV-Cycle and RLAI-Cycle, and designed the educational game Cytopia Defense, the "Life Glow" bio-art activity, and the handbook Busting Rumors about Synthetic Biology to enhance the project's impact in both Integrated Human Practices and education.
advisors: Hanzhi Weng, Jianqiang Hu, Ke Tong, Shuting Cheng, Xinyi Zhou, Yao Liu, Yihang Shen, Yueheng Niu, Zhijun Yi, Zhiyu Shen
students: Feixiang Xu, Haoyu Pang, Jieqing Jiang, Jinyang Li, Jinyi Wang, Lexin Li, Liuxia Zhang, Mengyao Chen, Peiyi Feng, Tianyu Liao, Wenshu Fan, Xinyue Shao, Xuan Liu, Xuan Wang, Ying Zhu, Zihao Guo

title: RSAV-Recombinat Scorpion Antivenom
abstract: Envenomation by venomous animals remains a global health concern, with scorpionism being particularly critical in Mexico, causing around 300,000 stings and around 1,400 deaths each year. Our project proposes an integrated three-system approach to address this issue. First, we aim to develop microbial production systems for recombinant antivenoms as sustainable and ethical alternatives to animal-derived ones. Second, we implement educational and social strategies to promote prevention and awareness within vulnerable communities. Third, we apply data modeling and optimization tools to improve healthcare logistics and accessibility in marginalized regions. Experimentally, we constructed an expression vector using the pPICZ? backbone under AOX1 promoter control for expression in the Komagataella phaffii strain OPENPichia pep4 yps1. Alongside, our outreach and modeling efforts connect synthetic biology and community engagement, working toward a future where preventable deaths from scorpionism in Mexico are reduced as much as possible.
advisors: Janette González
students: Alexis Mejia, Annel Serna, Carlos Felipe Coello Castillo, Daniela Hernández, Dira Barragán, Edgar Uriel, Karen Morales, Lizeth Fajardo, María Pérez, Miguel Jiménez, Natalia Brauer, Romina Miranda Delfin, RuthvRR

title: SnaPFAS
abstract: Perfluoroalkyl and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) contamination is a global concern due to their persistence in water, widespread presence in daily life, and long-term health risks. Among them, perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) is the most prevalent and hazardous pollutant. By developing an integrated PFOA & fluoride ions biosensor, optimizing PFOA-degrading enzymes, and designing a systematic hardware platform, we aim to establish a PFOA governance system that integrates detection, biodegradation, and safe processing, providing a practical solution to mitigate environmental and health impacts.
advisors: Cindy Ranxin Tian, Fred Zhang, Guo Hening, Mingce Yang, Sophia Li, Summer Wu, Tsz Yam Liu, Weizhao Chen, Xinran Xia, Yanguo Zhao
students: CHENHAO ZHOU, FU YUCHENG, Gong Yifan, JINSHU ZHAO, Lucy li, Mary Xu, Qianyu Jiang, Qingci Luo, Siqi Wang, Tang Shuoyan, Tony, Wenzheng Guo, Yi XiaoYa, Yixuan Cheng, YIYI WANG, ZHUOZHEN YAN, Zipei Wang, Ziqiao Zhu

title: Project SeQUESTer: Engineering a Yeast-Based Biosystem for Toxic Heavy Metal Detection and Removal
abstract: Project SeQUESTer aims to develop a sustainable, bioengineered filtration system to combat toxic heavy metal (THM) contamination in water, with an initial focus on lead (Pb). Lead pollution arises from industrial activity and aging infrastructure, posing persistent health and environmental hazards, especially in under-resourced communities. SeQUESTer introduces an innovative genetic sensing and sequestration platform using Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Our system integrates a riboswitch that detects lead ions, a reversible genetic memory switch that records exposure events, with the future direction to incorporate metal transporters that enhance cellular uptake and immobilization of lead. These engineered yeast cells are embedded within a porous agarose-zeolite scaffold housed in a scalable, modular biofiltration unit. This design enables simultaneous detection and removal of lead while maintaining environmental safety. SeQUESTer provides a low-cost, accessible, and eco-conscious alternative to conventional water treatment technologies.
student leaders: Arman Arciaga, Emilia, Erica Firouzbehi, Kaitlyn Root, LUCA TAYLOR, Noa Maerov, Sukhman
students: Aayah H, Abbas, Angie, Ashmit, Bhramana, Cole Noble, Debra Ayeni, Diana Kulyniy, Emily, Esha Reddy, Ethan Silva, Gabriela, Garima, Hafsa, Hailey, Imani, Isabella, Jamie, Janelle Chan, Julia, Kylie, Lillian Hy, Lucas, Madhurika, Mads, Makenna Hall, Mallory Steinburg, Mia Moniz, Muskaan, Olivia, Pamela, Phillip Seweify, Rachel, Rawan, Robert, Sam, Sama, Sheil, Simon, Soha, Talha Malik, Tameem, Uma Morriswala, yousif, Zahra Hussain, Zainab

title: LANCET: A novel diagnostic and therapeutic combating Lyme Disease
abstract: 89,000 cases of Lyme disease were reported to the CDC in 2023, yet experts estimate that nearly half-a-million Americans are infected with Borrelia burgdorferi annually. This significant underdiagnosis is due to the rapid dissemination of the bacteria into tissue, causing current tests to rely on antibodies produced weeks post-infection. However, the outer surface protein, CspZ, persists in the bloodstream, allowing for early detection through LANCET. Our diagnostic workflow begins with proximity-dependent ligation to detect CspZ and produce DNA, which is then amplified by recombinase polymerase amplification. Cas12a targets this DNA, providing a user-friendly output through a lateral flow assay. Even with improved diagnosis, treatment continues to rely on antibiotics, contributing to antimicrobial resistance and failing to address post-treatment Lyme disease. LANCET offers a novel approach through a multiplexed CRISPR-interference system to silence critical genes, effectively killing the bacteria. Our initiative also includes community education, fostering proactive behaviors against Lyme.
nominations: Best Model, High School+Best Education, High School+Best Wiki, High School+Best Village Project, High School

title: Filaggrin: an alternative solution for eczema
abstract: Atopic Dermatitis (eczema) stems largely from filaggrin (FLG) mutations, causing skin barrier failure. Current treatments only manage inflammation. We propose synthesizing artificial FLG to directly repair the barrier, delivered via jojoba oil for optimal topical application. This targets the condition's root cause, the skin barrier dysfunction.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School+Best Entrepreneurship, High School
PIs: Ng Sze Ho, Leung Kai Man Clement

title: ArMOLDgeddon, Safe and Efficient Mold Eliminator
abstract: Accounting for up to 20% of all respiratory allergy cases in humid areas, reaching a pervalence of around 30% in many countries around the world, indoors mold problem comprises one of the most serious threat to public health. To tackle this risk, GreatBay-SCIE 2025 devised a brand new mold killer, ArMOLDgeddon. Harnessing the antifungal properties of enzymes chitinase, glucanase, lysozyme and monoterpenoid geraniol, ArMOLDgeddon provides a safe and effective alternative to current mold removers. Chitinase and glucanase degrade critical structural polymers of the mold cell wall, while lysozyme magnifies the damage through cationic interaction with the cell wall components and disruption of fungal membranes. Geraniol, apart from furthering the attack on fungal membrane, provides a pleasant fragrance. Furthermore, with the help of artificial intelligence and strong carbohydrate binding domains, ArMOLDgeddon evolves and improves, expediting towards the goal of the annihilation of mold-related diseases, and eradicating this pervasive global health threat.
awards: Grand Prize Winner+Finalist+Top 10+Best Village Project+Best Education+Best Integrated Human Practices+Best Model+Best Wiki

title: QURES: Quorum-sensing Utilizing Reprogrammed Engineered Symbionts for Atopic Dermatitis
abstract: As the incidence of atopic dermatitis is increasing, the poor therapeutic experience of patients relying on long-term steroid use and immunosuppressants requires a breakthrough. Current treatments face a high recurrence rate. We stand to develop a more favorable treatment experience. Relevant studies have shown that the microbiome plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of atopic dermatitis, particularly the presence of Staphylococcus aureus and its inflammatory effects. Based on this, we designed a therapeutic system using engineered Staphylococcus epidermidis. We genetically modified Staphylococcus epidermidis to sense the AIP-C secreted by S. aureus and activate two downstream therapeutic pathways. The first pathway produces an nanobody that targets and neutralizes the inflammatory cytokine, while the second secretes AIP-C to suppress the virulence of S. aureus. Together, our system offers a safe and long-lasting therapeutic strategy, representing a paradigm shift in atopic dermatitis management - moving from symptom suppression to microbiome-mediated disease prevention.
advisors: Enran Li, Ge Wang, Yuxian Zheng
students: Jesse, JH Lin, Jingyi Yan, Mukaddas Abduaini, Rundi Qi, Sarah Sun, Shi Chang, Tingyi Huang, Ximeng Li, Xinchun Li, Yaoye, Yile Yao, Yuling Zhou, Ziting Zhao

title: SOLARIS
abstract: Billions of years ago, cyanobacteria transformed Earth's atmosphere through carbon fixation, enabling the metabolic foundation of modern ecosystems. Yet, despite its central role, photosynthetic carbon fixation has not changed much since its origin. With SOLARIS, we reexamine this long-standing process from the perspective of synthetic biology, foundationally changing and advancing CO? fixation in cyanobacteria. Our solution lays the groundwork for photosynthesis 2.0 to overcome the kinetic and oxygen-sensitivity limitations of RuBisCO by introducing a distinct carbon fixation cycle supported by a carbonic anhydrase system we newly identified and confirmed for activity. This has the potential to make cyanobacteria far better at fixing CO? from the atmosphere and turning it into biomass. SOLARIS offers the tools and methodologies for rewriting core metabolic pathways with synthetic biology for optimizing synthetic carbon fixation cycles in vivo and in vitro, a foundational step toward programmable photosynthesis and a new generation of engineered phototrophs.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Overgrad
PIs: Ioana Grigoras Popescu, Cecile Fischer, Soumaya NAJAH

title: Clotho: Weaving a Cure for PDAC
abstract: Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma (PDAC) causes nearly half a million deaths worldwide each year, with incidence and mortality rates almost identical, reflecting the lack of effective treatments. To address this, we developed Clotho, a modular gene therapy designed to cure PDAC. Using an adeno-associated virus, we deliver a therapeutic transgene that activates exclusively in cancer cells. Once inside, it produces circular RNAs and the enzyme Cytosine Deaminase. The circular RNAs act as sponges for tumor-promoting miRNAs, enhancing cancer cell sensitivity to treatment. Meanwhile, the enzyme converts the harmless prodrug 5-fluorocytosine into the toxic compound 5-fluorouracil, selectively killing malignant cells. Complementing this, our software platform Kathesis generates patient-specific circular RNA sequences based on individual genetic profiles. This dual approach enables precise, personalized, and targeted therapy, reducing off-target effects and introducing a novel strategy to overcome drug resistance in PDAC and potentially other diseases.
nominations: Best Entrepreneurship, Undergrad

title: Plants vs. PET: Combatting Microplastic Pollution with Plant-Based PETase
abstract: Thailand ranked sixth in the world for mismanaged plastic waste, sending over a million tonnes into the oceans each year (Labcom et al., 2024). Microplastics are now found throughout the country's ecosystems--from marine animals to water, air, and farmland--threatening wildlife, food safety, and human health (Chanpiwat, 2021). The most common culprit is polyethylene terephthalate (PET), making up 37% of poorly managed waste. In 2016, scientists discovered PETase, an enzyme from Ideonella sakaiensis that can break down PET. However, such microbial hosts are inefficient, unsafe, and unsustainable. Therefore, the Thailand?RIS iGEM 2025 team explored a different approach--producing PETase in plants--of which we present the first successful demonstration. Although stable transformation is still underway, we achieved transient expression of PETase fused with an alpha?amylase 3S signal peptide in Nicotiana benthamiana, resulting in extracellular secretion. This proof of concept lays the groundwork for scalable, sustainable plant-based strategies against forever-increasing plastic pollution.
nominations: Best Education, High School+Best Sustainable Development Impact, High School
advisors: Adhityo Wicaksono

title: CML2-Powered: A Niche-Adaptive Biosensor for Precise Arsenic Detection in Rice Paddies
abstract: Arsenic contamination in rice paddies threatens food safety and environmental health. Traditional large-instrument-based monitoring is costly and unsuitable for on-site rapid screening. To solve this, our project develops a novel arsenic biosensor via the "niche-matching" principle, sourcing key elements from Cupriavidus metallidurans CML2 (a rice endophyte adapted to paddies). We construct an "AND-gate-like" genetic circuit with a split-GFP system to reduce basal leakage and boost signal-to-noise ratio, and optimize performance through multiple "Design-Build-Test-Learn" (DBTL) cycles for sensitive, specific arsenic detection. This biosensor enables on-site paddy arsenic monitoring and lays a foundation for future "detection-remediation" microbial agents, aiding sustainable agriculture and environmental protection.

title: SKIPPIT: Harnessing the power of RNA to unlock translational-level control.
abstract: As synthetic biology positions itself as a field of the future, the need for new tools that allow better control of protein expression and new options for genetic engineering is clear. SKIPPIT is a platform that harnesses the full power of STOP Codon Readthrough elements, from both characterising them to making them into a tool: a first-in-class readthrough riboswitch. STOP Codon Readthrough elements interact with the ribosome at the STOP codon site, leading to the STOP codon being decoded by a tRNA instead of the termination complex, allowing translation to continue beyond the STOP. Designing this switch has only been possible thanks to the development of a cutting edge Software: TADPOLE. This software uses computationally-predicted RNA structures to optimise the design of RNA switches from just two RNA sequences.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, Undergrad+Best Software Tool, Undergrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad+Best Foundational Advance Project, Undergrad & Overgrad

title: KIT: CRC-Killer In and ouT
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer death globally. Despite advances in chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy, treatment remains limited by drug resistance and toxicity. This study presents the "CRC-killer in and out" integrated delivery kit, combining endogenous oral capsules with engineered bacteria and exogenous intelligent microneedle patches for comprehensive CRC therapy. The "in" module enhances intestinal targeting and bioavailability via peptide-mediated accumulation, while the "out" module employs minimally invasive microneedles with iontophoresis-enhanced transdermal delivery and responsive drug release. Together, they enable individualized administration, improved compliance, and non-professional usability. The dual-path system merges home-use convenience with scalable applicability, reducing medical burdens? which offer an innovative approach for CRC home-based and large-scale treatment.

title: CO2llectors--Overexpressing cmpABCD Fusion Bicarbonate Transporters Improves the Carbon Concentrating Mechanism in Cyanobacteria
abstract: Greenhouse gas emission is a major factor driving climate change. Considering the limitations of conventional mitigation approaches, our team proposed a synthetic biology approach by genetically modifying cyanobacteria Synechococcus elongatus PCC 7942 to enhance CO2 fixation efficiency. Our strategy involves overexpressing the cmpAB and CD fusion genes containing a light-sensitive promoter to increase the amount of bicarbonate transporter 1 (BCT1) within the cyanobacterial carbon concentrating mechanism (CCM). Ultimately, we aim to increase inorganic carbon uptake and saturate RuBisCO's CO2 binding sites, facilitating photosynthetic CO2 sequestration. Coupling protein modeling and functional assays performed on wild-type cyanobacteria to obtain a dry lab model quantifying the cyanobacterial carbon intake, we envision integrating the engineered cyanobacteria into a carbon fixation photobioreactor. In addition, besides evaluating the scalability and sustainability of our hardware from a scientific and economic perspective, we also extended our outreach into the local and global community by educating about synthetic biology.
PIs: Tarn Parker, Sebastian Griesing, Grace, Yahsin Chang

title: Pestacheck: An Improved Pesticide Residue Detection Test Strip
abstract: Pesticide residues on food pose serious health risks to the whole world, yet current detection methods remain inefficient and unstable. Recognizing this issue, we developed Pestacheck, a rapid, low-cost pesticide residue detection test strip based on the enzyme-inhibition principle of acetylcholinesterase (AChE). Through Alanine-scanning mutagenesis, we engineered AChE mutants via Cell-Free expression system. The optimized enzyme was immobilized with Gold Nanoparticles (AuNP) to improve sensitivity and integrated into a colloidal gold-based test strip for visible colorimetric detection. Together, Pestacheck provides a user-friendly synthetic biology solution for on-site pesticide residue detection.
advisors: Jia Li, Tengyu Zhang, Tianxing Li
students: Andy Gao, Anny Yang, Chris xu, Corrine Yang, Jiarui Li, Ji Qi, Lifu Liu, Lydia Han, Ningxi Zhao, pxb, Ruihao Ma, Yinan Guan, Yuci Peng, Yuelun Zhou, Yukun Sun, Zixuan Zhou, Zixun Huang

title: LarVase: Bioengineering Cellulase with YebF-Mediated Secretion for Sustainable Manufacturing and Efficient Food Waste Degradation
abstract: Food waste has a huge impact on our planet. It destroys habitats, emits huge amounts of greenhouse gases, and threatens society deeply. Currently, one of the most sustainable methods is using black soldier fly larvae to degrade food waste. However, black soldier fly larvae are unable to efficiently digest cellulose, suggesting that improving the degradation process could enhance overall conversion efficiency and lower the costs associated with food waste treatment. LarVase aims to mass-produce endo-1,4-?-glucanase, a cellulase originating from Bacillus subtilis, through cloning into an E. coli BL21 expression vector. With our specially designed plasmids, we used YebF, a carrier protein having a similar function as a signal peptide, to be able to transport endo-1,4-?-glucanase outside the cell. This will lower the current costs of enzyme production while maintaining environmental sustainability.
students: Aaron Tsai, Abigail Chen, Adam, Ariel, Bokari, CHENG-TAI LU, Chen-Hsi, Chao, CHIA CHUN WU, Li ,Guan-Yu, TING-WEI CHEN, Yun-Hsuan, Chang

title: PestiGuard - The Smart Aptamer Biosensor
abstract: PestiGuard is an innovative biosensor that puts food safety directly into the hands of consumers. To address the global health risks from pesticide residues, we have developed a simple, on-site detection system. At its heart are engineered bacteria containing a specialized RNA aptamer. When a specific pesticide is present, it binds to the aptamer, suppressing a fluorescent reporter gene and resulting in a dimmer glow. This provides an intuitive visual signal: brighter means safer, dimmer means contaminated. For precise results, we created companion software and hardware. A photo of the test sample is instantly analyzed, comparing the color intensity to a safety reference to display clear contamination levels. By integrating synthetic biology with smart technology, PestiGuard transforms complex lab testing into an accessible, user-friendly process, empowering everyone to make informed decisions about their food.
nominations: Best Model, High School+Best Software Tool, High School+Best Village Project, High School

title: SPROUT - Smart Peptide Release On Unique Triggers
abstract: Fungal pathogens pose a major threat to agriculture, causing significant economic losses and straining global food systems. Climate change worsens these challenges by creating warmer, more humid conditions that favor fungal infections. Conventional fungicides often harm beneficial organisms, disrupt ecosystems, and drive pathogen resistance, threatening long-term food security. We propose a more precise and sustainable alternative. Using a modular sensor system with a genetic AND-gate, our engineered bacteria detect pathogen-specific signals tied to physiology and secretome, releasing antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) only when needed. This ensures targeted action while minimizing off-target effects. SPROUT is a scalable, precision-based platform for next-generation plant protection. Its modular design allows easy adaptation to diverse crops and pathogens, enabling efficient, on-demand AMP release. By combining specificity, adaptability, and sustainability, SPROUT offers a practical and innovative approach to strengthening agricultural resilience against fungal diseases.
nominations: Best Agriculture Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Alexander G. H. Schleiter, Carolin Parthun, Felix Haidle, Lucas Koch, Melike Aydin
students: Alina Lapkovskaya, Andreas Fetzer, Belén Said, Caroline Jez, Franziska Höfer, Johanna, Johannes Miller, Julian, Julian Kraus, Julia Wentzell, Lela, Moritz von Kolczynski, Natasha, Nina Kiefer, Sebastian, Tom, Valentin Runge

title: Xylego
abstract: We developed Xylego, an engineered E. coli Nissle 1917 designed as a low-burden synbiotic therapy for Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). Xylego integrates three key modules: (1) Colonization support - enables selective growth using xylitol, reducing administration frequency; (2) Mucosal healing - secretes epidermal growth factor (EGF) to promote epithelial repair and break the inflammatory cycle; and (3) Inflammation-dependent kill switch - a tetrathionate-sensing restriction-modification system that self-destructs after inflammation resolves, preventing long-term risks and antibiotic gene transfer. Xylego is expected to enhance remission rates, improve adherence, and provide a safe, adaptable platform for patient-tailored probiotic therapies.
PIs: Yoh-ichi TAGAWA, Masayuki Yamamura, Nobuhiro HAYASHI
students: Aoi Mizukami, DDS3110, Haruki Aoyama, Hazuki Baba, matsuba, Ryo Doi, satouseitarou, takumi, Yuichiro Nakai, Yuma Nishimura, Yuto Sasaki

title: AureoLyze
abstract: Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) forms biofilms that protect bacterial cells and confer strong resistance to antibiotics, making them a major cause of chronic and persistent infections. These infections are particularly harmful in immunocompromised patients, exacerbating conditions such as cystic fibrosis, tuberculosis, and catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs). Staphylococcus epidermidis (S. epidermidis), a common skin commensal, secretes an extracellular serine protease (Esp) capable of cleaving autolysin, an essential factor in biofilm formation responsible for extracellular DNA (eDNA) release, which enhances biofilm stability. However, Esp also targets human biofilm components and other host proteins, limiting its therapeutic potential. To make Esp a viable therapeutic agent, it must selectively cleave bacterial biofilm proteins--specifically, autolysin--without degrading human substrates. To achieve this, we aim to engineer Esp through site-directed mutagenesis (SDM) to enhance its substrate specificity toward the autolysin. By introducing targeted mutations based on Esp-autolysin (Atl) interaction analyses, we seek to reduce its off-target activity against human proteins while maintaining its biofilm-degrading capability, enabling its safe use as an anti-biofilm therapeutic.
advisors: Ishika, Shivam
students: Aarohi Gupta, Angel Singhvi, Arhan Khade, Arth Agrawal, Aryan, Deepan N Balaji, Diksha, Durva Saraf, Gaurish, Jennifer esbel mary, Madhur, Nandini, Pari Soni, Ranit S Sooraj, Riya Joglekar, Sabarish S, Shreya Agrawal, Shrishti Havaldar, VivekTeja

title: ClaresO: Purification of Martian water from toxic perchlorate.
abstract: Mars has long fascinated humankind. With the growing interest in its exploration, the use of local resources, especially water, is becoming increasingly important. However, its huge natural water resources are contaminated by toxic perchlorate salts and thus unusable. Therefore, we engineer Bacillus subtilis 168 to detoxify perchlorate fully and convert it into harmless chloride and oxygen. To measure perchlorate concentrations, we established an in vivo perchlorate quantification assay that functions via organic phase extraction. To understand the underlying biochemistry, we characterized perchlorate degradation enzymes in vitro and investigated the effect of rational mutations to improve their performance. To enable practical implementation of our project, we built and tested a low-cost DIY anaerobic bioreactor. In order to simulate Martian microgravity, we designed, built and verified a random positioning machine from scratch. This device enables biological studies in simulated microgravity environments.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Overgrad+Best New Composite Part, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Space Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
instructors: Bea Marie Spiekermann, Iryna Gerasymenko, Lara Steinel
advisors: Caroline Schmidt, Christian Hake
students: Alex, Andrea Martellone, (Dina) Napath Sarleepimon, KALAIARUL, Leoni Bajraliu, Leon Köglmeier, Lorenza, Luisa Hertwig, Robin Thomar, Sina Block

title: Nereis
abstract: Nereis' project focuses on conserving the marine environment by degrading the pollutant naphthalene, a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). We identified salt-tolerant genes encoding proteins that help organisms survive in high sodium environments, as well as a catabolic pathway that uses naphthalene as a carbon source. Our goal is to genetically modify Pseudomonas putida, to be both salt-tolerant and capable of enhanced naphthalene degradation. These modification would allow the bacteria to function effectively in marine conditions. The naphthalene degradation pathway is found in P.putida G7, specifically in the NAH7 plasmid, which encodes the necessary degrading enzymes. Major challenges include adapting P. putida to high sodium concentration and introducing the large NAH7 plasmid. First, we will modified the bacteria with salt tolerant genes and test its tolerance to different sodium concentration. Second, we want to introduce the degrading enzymes in the salt-tolerant strain and assess the effectiveness of naphthalene degradation.
students: Alexis Hureau, Alizée Fernandes Pereira, Amelie Nallathambi, Augustin, Ber villasenor, Camille Mayen, Coralie Delporte, Emy Denorme, Göksu, halilardaevliyaoglu, Hana, Hanna Kleinmann, ines.lecat, Inès Radelet, LaraS, Laura Ciampi, Louise.Descamps, Luna L, Maï DIROU, Noémie Vignes, Paul Mauger, Rojin, sarah.hiruthayaraj, Tessa Tessier, Théo, Yovan Grabovac

title: TroGen: A commensal bacterial platform for intracellular drug delivery in TNBC
abstract: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype, with rapid progression, poor prognosis, and no effective targeted therapies, highlighting urgent need for new strategies. Building on Prof. Shang Cai's work on intracellular commensal bacteria--especially the tumor-targeting potential of Staphylococcus--we developed TroGen, an intracellular delivery platform using engineered commensals. To enhance invasion, we introduced the `fnbA` gene into non-pathogenic Staphylococcus to express S. aureus FnBPA, exploiting integrin-mediated endocytosis for efficient TNBC entry. Two biosafety modules confine bacterial survival and therapeutic payload expression to the tumor microenvironment. Using AlphaFold-Multimer, MD, MM/PBSA, and phylogenetic analysis, we selected the optimal FnBP from multiple candidates. We formulated a reaction-diffusion-convection coupled PDE and used COMSOL Multiphysics to simulate intratumoral bacterial diffusion. Human Practices informed iterative design, and outreach activities fostered scientific curiosity.
nominations: Best Wiki, Undergrad+Best Oncology Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
instructors: Kanghui Ruan, Lijuan Liu, Yongjie Sha, Ziwen Xie, Ziyang Lu
advisors: Guang Cai, Haibo Zhang
students: Hanming Hu, Jie Zhong, Jimin Hong, Rui Chen, Shuning Dong, Tianran Chen, Yaqi Zhang, Yifan Hou

title: Antitumor Immunotherapy Using Guanylate Cyclase-Based Engineered Bacteria to Target the STING Pathway in Macrophages
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is characterized by an immunosuppressive, hypoxic tumor microenvironment (TME) dominated by M2 macrophages. To address this, we engineered the probiotic E. coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) as a targeted living therapeutic. Our engineered auxotrophic EcN strain incorporates two synthetic genetic circuits: a hypoxia-responsive plasmid for tumor-specific production of the STING agonist c-di-GMP, and a synthetic "suicide" circuit for AHL-inducible bacterial lysis and payload release with essential metabolic gene thyA and dapA knockout. This triple system ensures precise immune activation within the tumor and provides a crucial biocontainment mechanism. We further developed a mathematical model to simulate AHL diffusion and its kinetic relationship with therapy, and designed a gut-on-a-chip device for physiologically relevant testing. This work establishes a safe, modular platform for targeted CRC immunotherapy.
PIs: Liang Yang, Haihua Liang, Vishwesh, Xingyin Liu, Xuan MENG
advisors: Hongqian Zhang, Mingwei Chen, Qikun Gao, Shuo Fang
student leaders: Aonan Xing, Chen Xiang, Li Yuxuan, Wang Xiyu
students: Chengyu Zhang, Gao, Huang Qilin, Liang Chenxuan, Miaoyi Liao, Qirui Liu, Ruichen, ShiQi Fu, Sijie, Wang Xindi, WeiJin, Xiyu, Xu Shenghao, Yishi Yang, Yue Xing, Yunjian MENG

title: ARMOR: Astro-Resilient Multi-Operational Recombinant-gel
abstract: Space exploration requires lightweight and durable materials to be manufactured in situ. Current chemical-based materials rely heavily on Earth supply chains. To address this gap, we engineered fusion proteins combining hagfish intermediate filament (HIF) and mussel foot protein (MFP) domains. Expression was induced in E. coli BL21 (DE3) and proteins were purified using Ni-NTA column. The best estimated yield reached 193 mg/ml. Co-assembly showed hydrogel formation, and the adhesive performance quantified by maximum force measurement recorded strength near 20,000 N/m², comparable to commercial glues. Adhesion was strong at space walking temperature (120 °C) but rapidly decline when below -20 °C. We developed SHIELD--a 3D-printed, low-cost fermentation device achieving cell densities upto OD600~20. Besides, we modified the fusion protein's structure, removing one of the terminal domains, and explored the structure-property relationships with preliminary results. With ARMOR, we are excited for the potential of syn-bio for next-generation space materials.
nominations: Best Hardware, High School+Best Village Project, High School
advisors: Dongchuan Wang, Enshi Xu, Haotian Liu, Jiming Yu, Leyi Li, Tongtong Wu, XAVIER WANG RUI, Ziao Su

title: Project Opthera
abstract: Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide, characterized by progressive optic nerve damage and often asymptomatic until significant vision loss occurs. Current treatments primarily address elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) but fail to halt the underlying retinal ganglion cell (RGC) degeneration. To address this dual pathology, we developed a novel, non-invasive eye drop formulation containing two fusion peptides: FT, which lowers IOP, and BC, which provides neuroprotection by reducing RGC apoptosis. This dual-therapy approach simultaneously targets both key disease mechanisms, offering a more comprehensive strategy to slow glaucoma progression. Our project integrated human practices to ensure viability and societal impact. We engaged patients, clinicians, and bioethicists to refine our work ethically. Through stakeholder dialogue and targeted outreach, we balanced diverse needs and raised glaucoma awareness. This created a positive feedback loop, strengthening our project's purpose and laying the groundwork for future innovation.
PIs: Leung Hoi Yan Wendy, KWAN SIN KEI, Steven Chau, Yeung Wai Lok Wesley
