title: NitroDuck
abstract: Dairy farmers are struggling to keep their farms profitable - the protein feed, the most crucial element, is also one of the most expensive components for them. The most popular protein source is soybean. It contributed to the loss of natural ecosystems in Brazil's tropical savanna. Duckweed, the fastest-growing plant on Earth, contains as much protein as soybeans and grows 10x faster. It is set to provide an affordable protein source for every farm. But duckweed, as promising as it looks, cannot match 3000 years of selective breeding of soybeans. To make it a crop, we need SynBio. We are developing a method for 5x faster genetic engineering of duckweed, constructing an autonomous cultivation system and a yield prediction model, simplifying the scaling of duckweed. The first steps toward unlocking the massive potential of this tiny plant... To save farmers' money, the Cerrado savanna, and to make plants truly scalable.
awards: Grand Prize Winner+Finalist+Top 10+Best Agriculture Project+Best Plant Synthetic Biology+Best Presentation
nominations: Best Hardware, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
advisors: Arturo, Helene Robert Boisivon
students: Andrej, Anna, Barbora Gavendová, David, Hanka, Jonáš Pospíchal, Klárka, ?ubomír Gallo, Marko Me?ava, Martin Pavella, Mat?j, Matúš Grieš, Michaela, Michal Šim?ák, Miro, Ondra, Peter Schmidt, Pravoslav, Tereza, Zdenka Vilhanová

title: DR. sTraTeGY: Engineering Multicellular Yeast for Drug Resistance Mutation Tracking
abstract: DR. sTraTeGY is built on "Grape Yeast" chassis, designed to track fungal drug resistance mutations. It transforms the evolution of fungi from a static snapshot into an observable spatio-temporal lineage tree. Its current version has two functions: mutation event recording and cell lineage tracing. Our optimized transcription unit - pSTM1-driven EMSfp499, combines a mutation-sensitive promoter with an EMS-resistant fluorescent protein, enabling high-fidelity recording of mutation dynamics. We developed YeastVerse, a modeling and simulation tool, to predict key parameters such as fluorescent protein expression and maturation, which allows dry-lab simulation to guide subsequent wet-lab experiments. In addition, we have established a DBTL cycle that integrates mathematical modeling with AI-assisted reasoning. We engage rare disease communities, through collaborative art and sensory-inclusive activities, fostering an accessible and participatory scientific environment. By integrating synthetic biology, computing, and community engagements, DR. sTraTeGY provides a new strategy to address the global challenge of fungal drug resistance.
nominations: Inclusivity Award, Undergrad
advisors: Xujie Tan, Yi Shi
students: Han Yufan, Huizhen Du, Jihua Tang, Peining Wu, Xiuqi Tian, Yining Zhao, Yixuan Lu, Yue Yue, Yuxin Duan, Zhongyi Huang, Zuyao Wu

title: Targeting DDRs: Modular Biomanufacturing of Collagen
abstract: Type III collagen (COLIII) not only supports tissue elasticity but also regulates the tumor microenvironment by transmitting dormancy signals to cancer cells. To overcome the limitations of animal-derived collagen, we established a synthetic-biology-based microbial production system to produce humanized COLIII, achieving biosafety and functional customization. By introducing the GVMGFO motif, a specific binding site for Discoidin Domain Receptor 1 (DDR1), we engineered COLIII to precisely target DDR1 on tumor cell surfaces. Using molecular modeling, docking, and dynamics simulations, we selected the recombinant COLIII variant (rCOL III) with the most stable structure and highest binding affinity for DDR1.The selected rCOL III was successfully expressed in Pichia pastoris and showed preliminary intervention effects on breast cancer cells in vitro, demonstrating a potential inhibitory role. This project integrates synthetic biology, protein engineering, and computational design, providing a green and modular biomaterial strategy for breast cancer intervention and prevention.
PIs: WeiNa Li, FanDaidi, Junfeng-hui, Lin Wang
advisors: JiaCheng, Li, YaQian-Zhang
students: Jiaju Lei, JingWen Zhai, LinMiao Song, Min Yang, QiYi Jiang, XinYue Deng, ZeWen Chang, Zhaoyang Wang

title: PhytClub
abstract: Pepper foot rot is a devastating disease that affects black pepper (P. nigrum) vines. Caused by the oomycete Phytophthora capsici, the infection leads to extensive yield loss and mortality in Karnataka and Kerala. Globally, plantations in Vietnam and Indonesia also suffer a similar fate. Chemical fungicides and current biocontrol measures are ineffective and unsustainable, driving the need for an innovative solution. MIT-MAHE has developed a targeted, preventative solution that curbs foot rot. PhytClub implements small interfering RNA (siRNA) that are specifically designed to silence the bZIP transcription factor in P. capsici, through the RNA interference mechanism. Chitosan nanoparticles encapsulate the siRNA to confer stability and aid their uptake into the pathogen. Furthermore, the team has automated the siRNA design process and combined it with a model that predicts the stability of an siRNA-nanoparticle complex, providing a foundational software tool that helps future researchers seamlessly build gene silencing systems.
nominations: Best Agriculture Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Dr. Ritu Raval, Dr. Fayaz SM
advisors: Akshay Parmar, Anirudh Saravanan, Deepali Vengala, Navya Subramanian Anantharaman, Ram P Shetty, Shyaam Haridas, Tanaya Sengupta, Varshith Jalla
students: Aditi Rishiraj, Amogh Thale, Ananya BS, Ankith Suhas Rao, Armaan Gupta, Arya Binu, Chaithanya Padmar, Harshini Musuvathi Kishore Kumar, Keena Ravi, Meena Cindamani, Neha Sahajwani, Sanvi Gupta, Shreya Ghosh, Tanvi Rege, Varun Leju Chacko, V Sai Pallavi

title: LOGIC: Lasting Optimized Genetic Input Calculator
abstract: Biological computing holds great promise, yet past engineered bacterial circuits for logic gates have suffered from excessive complexity, cumbersome operation, and reliance on multiple input substances. Our LOGIC project overcomes these problems by developing a novel approach to constructing a biocomputer--utilizing quorum sensing and spatial diffusion to form logic gates. For addition calculation, we construct high-pass and band-pass genetic circuits based on the quorum sensing (QS) system. Through the diffusion of QS molecules in solid media, we can build various logic gates and connect them to perform multi-bit binary calculations. For repetitive operation, we engineer a light-induced QS molecule degradation enzyme and a protein degradation tag to refresh the calculator. Building upon the calculator, we can also build accessories like result storage, decimal result display and latches, demonstrating its extensive prospects. Furthermore, we construct a LOGIC Toolkit with visualization software for future research.
advisors: Anya Zhu, Jiaze Liu, Jingcheng Wang, Zixuan Ding, Ziyan Peng
students: Arcueid, Boxiang Luan, ChenHongyu, Enoch-Menuroh, Hongbo Wang, Huang Xiangyu, Jerry, Jiangyue Niu, Junxi Zeng, Lingjia Qiu, Ryyo, ShiraishiHara, Wang Yan, Xiaozheng, Yaxuan Zhang, Yuan, YuXinyang, Zhihe Guo

title: PROTATO: Proteolysis-based Detection for Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato Affected Tomato
abstract: Early detection of plant pathogens is essential for reducing crop losses, yet most diagnostic systems remain laboratory-bound. We developed PROTATO: Proteolysis-based Detection for Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato Affected Tomato, a cell-free and protein logic-based biosensing platform enabling on-site pathogen detection. PROTATO integrates a coiled-coil-mediated chain exchange reaction as its molecular logic core and a dual-input AND gate that responds specifically to the pathogen effector AvrRpt2 protease and the phytotoxin coronatine (COR), reconstituting split luciferase, GFP, or trehalase reporters. A positive-feedback loop amplifies protease activity, improving detection sensitivity and signal strength. To enable field deployment, we engineered the PROTATO KIT, a 3D-printed electrochemical device that converts glucose signals into electronic readouts via glucose oxidase-modified electrodes and microcontrollers. Portable (Air) and scalable (Pro) versions support diverse agricultural applications. Our project establishes a generalizable framework for cell-free protein logic, advancing low-cost biosensing for crop protection and beyond.
advisors: Binwen Liu, Cao Yaozhong, Shuai Qin, Xinyue Ding, Zhichen Guo, Zhuo Chen
students: Chang Li, Chi Tianjian, Dongchen Liu, Huang Lintaihui, MengYuan Ni, Minzhuo Yang, Shixuan Zhang, Wu Jingyan, Yichen Li, Youdu Liu, Yufan Zhang, Yuming Luo, Yutong Liu, Yuxuan Pan, Zhang Jiaming, Zhenyan Zhu, Zhiqian Li, Zhiyi Wang

title: Com-bat-ing White-Nose Syndrome: Engineering E. coli to Secrete Protease Inhibitors Against Pseudogymnoascus destructans
abstract: Pseudogymnoascus destructans is a pathogenic fungus that causes White-nose syndrome (WNS), one of the most devastating wildlife diseases in modern history, responsible for mass bat mortality across North America. Locally in Michigan, 5 of our 9 bat species are affected--with repercussions for biodiversity, agriculture, public health, and environmental stability. WNS develops in bats during their hibernation period when proteolytic enzymes produced by the fungus degrade the collagen in their nose, ears, and wings, causing them to wake prematurely from wintertime hibernation, leading to energy depletion, lethargy, and death by starvation due to the lack of necessary resources in winter. There are no effective treatments currently. We propose engineering Escherichia coli to secrete serine protease inhibitor(s) targeting the virulence factor of the fungus. These inhibitors would block collagen degradation, allowing bats to maintain uninterrupted hibernation, thus improving survival outcomes for one of our most essential, if silent allies.
student leaders: Anakin Brittain, Hannah Gyolai, Isabell Bryans, Joseph Colucci, Mina Buchkowski, Nayeli Santana-Venegas, Reagan Keyser
students: Ananya, Annie, Chloe Leaman, Emily, Gagandeep, Grace, Hiba, Isabel L, Jose Pinacho, Katie, Khai, Megan Walch, Monique, Morris, Olivia, Owen Denk, Phoebe Ledbetter, Toby

title: Snaccine
abstract: Snaccine is a novel type of vaccine, ideal for vaccinating chickens against avian influenza (bird flu). Genetically modified bacteriophages are taken orally, in a stomach acid-resistant pill. They reproduce inside gut bacteria, while also producing RNA packaged within armour (an MS2 virus-like particle coated with cell-penetrating peptides). This RNA enters (eukaryotic) host cells and works just like an mRNA vaccine, tricking the cell into producing an antigen. This antigen is detected by the immune system and teaches it to recognise and fight the original pathogen. Snaccines share many of the same advantages that mRNA technology has over traditional vaccines. But where typical mRNA vaccines have to be kept in freezers, Snaccines can be stored and transported at room temperature. Together with their cheaper production and oral administration route, Snaccine is an ideal technology for fighting bird flu.
advisors: Gabi van Leersum
students: Franek, Krzysztof Zab?ocki, Tessa Ernst, Viktor, Zofia Wojciechowicz

title: BEATS?a Biohybrid Engineered Anti-cancer Therapeutic Serratia
abstract: This project addresses the critical challenges of drug resistance and systemic toxicity in conventional cancer therapy by developing a novel live bacterial delivery system based on an engineered Serratia marcescens strain. We leveraged the native capacity of this bacterium to synthesize prodigiosin--a potent antitumor compound--while implementing biosafety enhancements through msbB gene knockout to reduce endotoxin production. For precise tumor targeting, we functionalized the attenuated strain with carboxymethyl cellulose encapsulation and the KP101 homing peptide. To support quantitative analysis and predictive modeling, we developed a comprehensive computational toolkit including an automated fluorescence image segmentation pipeline, a ConvLSTM-based spatiotemporal prediction model, and the integrated OncoPredict Suite platform. Guided by responsible innovation and the SEEK framework, our project combines synthetic biology with translational tool development to offer a targeted and adaptable strategy for next-generation cancer treatment
PIs: Wei Wei, Dijun Chen, Xiuxiu Wang
advisors: Jiaxin Li, Yajin Li, Yuanfang Xiang, Zhengyun Zou, Zhi Ding, Zongyu Guo

title: Trashformers - Enzymatic Glycolysis of Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) textile fibres, and upcycling of terephthalic acid.
abstract: Polyethylene terephthalate (PET), the main component of polyester textiles, dominates global fiber production and generates millions of tons of waste annually. Current recycling methods rely on energy-intensive chemical processes. Our project, Trashformers, tackles this challenge by developing a synthetic biology system for PET textile recycling and upcycling, designed to provide all the reaction components needed for efficient depolymerization and upcycling. We focus on enzymatic glycolysis to depolymerize PET into bis(2-hydroxyethyl) terephthalate (BHET), a monomer suited for re-polymerization. To achieve this, we designed a system based on E. coli BL21(DE3) and devices utilizing PETase hydrolases. We design two complementary systems in parallel. The first employs enzymatic hydrolysis to degrade PET into terephthalic acid (TPA), and ethylene glycol required for subsequent glycolysis. The second uses rational enzyme design to create a novel enzyme that activates TPA with coenzyme A Paving the way for PET upcycling through metabolic and chemical valorization.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, Overgrad+Best Fashion & Cosmetics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
students: Agnes Warmuth, Arnab Choudhary, Edu Amo, Edvin Erlandsson, Eleni, Emma Esping, Hilya Iman, Isis S, Jimena Rodríguez, Måns, Marta Rozwens, Michelle Kusnadi, Mo, Nan wu, Sena Cevapovic, Shantanu Kartha, Sixten Ljungklint Ekman, Svante Wiktorsson, Tomasz Dabrowski

title: DopaMine: Engineered Saccharomyces cerevisiae for Self-Regulated L-DOPA Biosynthesis: A SynBio Approach to Parkinson's Disease Treatment
abstract: Parkinson's Disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by the progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons, leading to motor impairments such as tremors and rigidity. Current treatments rely on L-DOPA supplementation, but long-term use results in decreased efficacy and severe side effects. To address these limitations, we propose engineering Saccharomyces cerevisiae (S. cerevisiae) to biosynthesize and regulate L-DOPA production using the yeast codon-optimized CYP76AD6 gene from Beta vulgaris partnered with the AR2 gene from Arabidopsis thaliana. By integrating metabolic engineering and synthetic biology, our system aims to improve L-DOPA bioavailability while reducing treatment-related complications. The system incorporates sophisticated feedback mechanisms to maintain optimal L-DOPA levels, offering a potentially groundbreaking approach to PD therapy.
advisors: Wiam Benadder, Yuqing Cheng
students: Alexia, Corinne Moran, Hanchen Ye, Houda, Kewei Zhang, Malak Musabeh, Matyas, Siyuan (Anthony) Cao, Wenmei (May) Zhao, Yicheng, Yining (Elina) Wang, Yuchen, Yueting Xiong, Yuntian Lu, Zhiwei (Vivi) Li, Zimeng, Ziyan Zhao

title: Totally [Fe]rocious
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance is currently a major global health crisis. To counter this issue, alternatives to antibiotics must be developed. One promising strategy involves the use of siderophores, iron-chelating molecules naturally synthesized by bacteria. We aimed to hack this system by adding a gold nanoparticle to one of Klebsiella pneumoniae's siderophores, aerobactin. These nanoparticles can then be activated with NIR lasers to kill bacteria. Our team focused on cloning aerobactin in Escherichia coli. We also performed in silico analyses to optimize aerobactin biosynthesis and deepen our understanding of the siderophore's internalization by K. pneumoniae. A genome-scale metabolic analysis of aerobactin's citrate production, along with biomolecular modeling of the TonB-dependent transporter embedded in the gram-negative bacterial membrane, was conducted. The next steps of this project would involve the synthesis of gold nanoparticles followed by their conjugation with aerobactin.
students: Alison Ouellet, Alyson Guillemette, Athéna Croteau, Cyril Fraser-Laflamme, David Tremblay, Elodie Fortin-Hurtubise, Félix Bégin, Galadriel Germain, Justine Lefrançois, Laurence, Olivier Thériault, Oscar Andrés Bernal Campos, Phénix

title: AromaWell: Customize Your Signature Aromatherapy Essential Oil
abstract: The core components of rose essential oil are geraniol and citronellol, while that of lavender is linalool. These three components share highly similar terpenoid biosynthetic pathways. This commonality provides us with an unprecedented technical opportunity: by modifying microbial cell factories, we enable yeast to produce geraniol (the common precursor substance) and Escherichia coli to synthesize citronellol and linalool. By enhancing the supply of precursor substances and introducing selective catalytic enzymes, we construct a metabolic network that can efficiently synthesize geraniol, citronellol, and linalool. The key lies in the introduction of regulatable promoter systems and artificial gene circuits, which allow for precise regulation of the metabolic flux of each synthetic branch through external induction and culture parameters. This enables end-users to dynamically adjust the synthesis rate of each component according to their personal preferences, and ultimately obtain personalized mixed essential oil components in a single fermentation system at one time.
advisors: Ruilin Liu, Wang Zishuo
student leaders: BaoHang Huang, Jingxiang Feng, Junqi Guo, Niu Jundong, Yishan Li, ziyu li
students: Fanghao Xu, Jiaming Zhang, JI XINTONG, LANYI SHAN, LingFei Zhang, Liu Yihan, Sun Jiayi, Xing Haoting, Yawen Liu, Yuxuan Zhuang, Zhong Jinke, ZiTong Song

title: E.P.I.C : Epigenetic Programmable Intervention & Control
abstract: Targeted DNA methylation is a promising approach for programmable gene regulation. To explore this, we designed and expressed a novel fusion protein, dCas9-Dam (DNA adenine methyltransferase), in E. coli. dCas9 was directed to user-specified loci with the help of guide RNA, enabling targeted adenine methylation at GATC sites. We constructed a plasmid encoding dCas9-Dam with guide RNA and a reporter plasmid containing a GFP gene downstream of a methylation-sensitive promoter. Co-transfection into E. coli allowed us to assess whether dCas9-Dam could induce targeted methylation and regulate GFP expression. Our results will test the ability of dCas9-Dam to perform locus-specific DNA methylation and alter reporter gene expression.The system can be extended to other methyltransferases in bacteria, opening avenues for applications in biomanufacturing, therapeutics, and diagnostics. By enabling precise epigenetic editing, this approach holds potential for developing novel treatments for diseases linked to aberrant methylation, such as cancer, neurodegenerative disorders,and imprinting-related syndromes
students: Abhishek Raj, Ashwin Philip, Bhagyashree, Bhavyasri, Harsha, Harsh Vardhan Gupta, Joshua Bage, Kaarthik Ellappan, Karthik A P, Minkuri Ridhima Reddy, Mogith, Oviya Suresh, Pranav Ram PS, Rohan Krishnan, Ruhaib, Sanjana Ramkumar, Shravan, Shreyas Balakarthikeyan, Shyam, Skandaagraja Sundhar, Tej Acharya, Tharunika, Tia Anand, Vaidehi Sharad Patil

title: Optimizing Heparosan Biosynthesis in E. coli BL21 By Use of an RBS Library
abstract: Heparosan is a key polysaccharide precursor in the synthesis of heparin, an essential anticoagulant widely used in medicine. However, current methods of heparosan production rely on inefficient microbial strains. Our project aims to design and optimize synthesis of heparosan in a more commonly used strain - BL21 (DE3). We are reconstructing the heparosan synthesis pathway found in E. coli K5 by expressing four essential genes--kfiA, kfiB, kfiC, and kfiD, and inserting them onto a single plasmid, incorporating a library of degenerate ribosome binding sites (RBS) on our primers. Using degenerate DNA sequences for our RBS allows us to synthesize a library of varying ribosomal binding affinity for each gene, which in turn, gives us a wide range of gene expression. This allows us to determine the optimal activity level for each gene to produce the most heparosan.
student leaders: Elisabeth Spongr, Nikitha Kanumuru, Shifra, Zhongxu Liang
students: Aerin Yoder, Aziz Alhadab, Matthew McGinn, Maya Anderson

title: ILXIR: IL-10 In Response
abstract: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is a chronic condition characterized by inflammation in the gastrointestinal tract. The cause of IBD is an overreactive immune response, leading to prolonged inflammation and tissue damage. A key regulator of such inflammation, Interleukin-10 (IL-10), plays a fundamental role in modulating inflammation and maintaining cell homeostasis by protecting the body from an uncontrolled immune response by inhibiting pro-inflammatory cytokines like TNF-? and IL-6. However, IL-10's therapeutic potential is severely limited by its structural instability due to its homodimer nature and easy degradation within the body. This instability reduces its effectiveness as a long-term treatment leaving patients with limited options for prolonged IBD treatments. To address this issue, we propose a probiotic-based approach, engineering a mutated more stable form of Il-10 (MIL-10). Delivered through dairy products like yogurt, this system would provide MIL-10 production in reaction to pro-inflammatory cytokines, ensuring sustained inflammation control for diseases like IBD.
students: Adam, Amelia Wang, Austin To, Daniel Zhang, Evelyn, Felicia, Felix, Fiona Dai, Irene, Irene Eun, Jake Kang, Jian, Joshua Wu, Julianna Phung, Kenneth Gong, Matthew, Megan, Natalie Tien, Teddy, Yifan

title: ExAway: A Protein Binding Inhibitor for Exotoxin A
abstract: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA) is a pathogenic bacterium that is responsible for an estimated 7% of all healthcare-associated infections. Exotoxin A (ETA) is one major virulence factor of PA. As a result, therapeutics targeting the inhibition of ETA activity are under development. ETA enters human cells through the CD91 receptor, activates via furin cleavage, and modifies eukaryotic elongation factor 2, inhibiting protein synthesis and inducing apoptosis. Although some inhibitors show signs of success, they consist of either small-molecule inhibitors, which have significant off-target effects, or antibodies, which cannot be produced efficiently due to size and folding properties. To address these limitations, we utilize RF diffusion, Protein MPNN, and AlphaFold to create a protein inhibitor that binds specifically to ETA's receptor binding domain. We tested these computationally designed inhibitors by expressing and purifying them, assessing their binding affinity to ETA and evaluating their ability to prevent ETA-mediated cell death using cell-based assays.
student leaders: Addie Lomax, Akari Iwamoto, Akira Morishita, Andrew Kesapradist, Antara Garai, Ethan Tran, Ivy Lee, Jacqueline Wu, Jaiden Poon, Samaira Bakshi, Winnie Lin
students: Aashna Doshi, Aimee Furlan, Alex Devgan, Alvin, Anu Marimuthu, Arjun Naik, Cate Baum, Cici Situ, Derek, Eliza Dawley, Eva Trapido, Gurnoor Sandhu, Jane McKelvey, Joanna, Joshua Huber, Kristin Chen, Nathen Qing, Neel, Noah, Rania Sundramurti, Sophia Nguyen, Summer Zhang, Tanvi Penubothu, Teo Fine

title: Oncoligo: Modular Antisense Oligonucleotide Lung Cancer Treatment
abstract: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide, and many patients still lack effective long-term treatment options. Oncoligo introduces a modular therapeutic platform that harnesses antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) to selectively silence essential cancer genes within a synthetic-lethality framework, enabling the targeting of tumor-suppressor-driven and intracellular cancers. Our computational pipeline integrates molecular dynamics, machine learning, and algorithmic optimization to design all parts of the platform. We specifically design potent ASOs, which are conjugated to antibodies for targeted delivery. Within each antibody, tumor-associated epitopes stimulate immune activation and memory. Experimentally, our designed ASOs outperform commercial ones, showing superior knockdown at the mRNA, protein, and cellular levels. In parallel, we optimized antibody expression systems and developed a dedicated software tool that facilitates ASO design across diverse genes and organisms. By uniting synthetic biology, computation, and entrepreneurship, Oncoligo pioneers a versatile, scalable framework for precision oncology - redefining how we treat cancer.
nominations: Best Model, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad+Best Oncology Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
students: Ariella Nouman, Din Saadon, Ester Buderovsky, Gal Aziel, Hillel Charbit, May Lieber, Michael Kovaliov, Niv David, Roni Zarakhovsky

title: safeTEA: safe Targeted Extraction via Aptamers
abstract: In order to address the global challenge of mycotoxin contamination in food and drink products, we aim to develop a detoxification system adaptable to diverse agricultural communities and food systems worldwide. Our methods focus on aflatoxin B1, the most carcinogenic mycotoxin and a major burden to resource-limited communities. Once bound, toxins can be removed through simple, inexpensive, and widely available cellulose-based materials that can be safely composted after use. As part of the plasmid design process, we introduce NOODL (Novel Optimization Of DNA Linkers), a Julia-based genetic algorithm that generates custom spacer sequences for single-stranded DNA. This tool simplifies spacer design by minimizing unwanted interactions and secondary structures between functional ssDNA components for synthetic biology applications. By combining computational design and genetic engineering, our work offers an impactful approach to improving food safety while providing adaptable tools that foster innovation across synthetic biology.
students: Aleek M Tekehyan, Ally Hoogs, Amanda Ferguson, Anisha Jaiswal, Benjamin Liu, Christine Lau, Judah Tapert, Kunal Amin, Lynn Fonseca-Batalla, Nishad Chavan, Srishta Hazra, Srushti Patil, Tejal Oza, Vaishnavi Venuturimilli

title: One Health Outaouais
abstract: By 2050, antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is expected to kill 10 million people each year, making it a major global threat. Here in Québec, our farmers follow strict rules for antibiotic use--they require a vet's prescription. Even with these measures, resistant bacteria still emerge, particularly in manure and wastewater. When we started our One Health Outaouais (OHO) project, our plan was to develop a test for AMR genes to map the region's resistome. But conversations with farmers, veterinarians, and experts helped us realize our approach was too academic. They didn't need more data; they needed practical tools to make better, faster decisions for their animals. So, we transformed our test into a product: the VIGIL | FARM platform. VIGIL | FARM will provide farmers with on-site rapid diagnostics and reliable information, helping them use antibiotics more precisely and only when necessary -- protecting both animal health and public safety.
advisors: Catherine Hallé, Frederique Marcotte, Hasna Hocini, Josee Pennober, Mathieu, Michel Halloran, Navoun
student leaders: Alexis Gravelle, Dania Cryans, Emile Monteau, Émilie Stuart, Gabriel Juteau Couture, Jessica Côté-Gagné, Katérina, Sofia Hughes
students: Adem, Alexis, Anahid, Angélique, Anna Yasnitska, Chloé Laël Matiké, Élia-Claude, Émile Croteau, Gabriel Savard-Landry, Hadrien, Henri Lauzon, Ivi Boudreau, Jeanne Tardif, Leonie Bargiel, Liam, Lina, Mackenzie Gravel, Maélie, Mansoor Bin Atya, Meghan, Nicholas Mo, Nicolas, Nico Poirier, Rosalind Borg, Ruici, Samar Hattab, Sara Kadri, Other, Guylaine Bonicalzi

title: The Cysteinator -- a biological device to enhance biohydrogen production.
abstract: The effects of climate change underscore the need to develop sustainable energy technology. Hydrogen (H2) based sustainable energy solutions decarbonize high-heat industrial processes and long-distance transport. However, current H2 production is land and water-intensive, and largely reliant on fossil fuels. Dark Fermentation (DF)--an anaerobic process where glucose is converted to H2--is a sustainable alternative that can be integrated into waste-to-energy (WTE) streams. Currently, DF cannot produce H2 in commercially viable quantities. Our device, "The Cysteinator", solves this challenge by supplementing DF bioreactor feedstocks with precise concentrations of L-cysteine. L-cysteine lowers the oxidation-reduction potential in DF feedstocks, helping hydrogen-producing bacteria propagate and increasing hydrogenase function. Our device is accompanied by a multi-scale model that characterizes its behavior and informs its implementation in a variety of WTE streams. Our project includes thorough analyses on the Cysteinator's impact on WTE streams, DF market viability, and the UN's Sustainable Development Goals.
students: Ananya, Eric Hegg, Katie Nichols, Michael Hunter, Priya Shan, Shikha Raghuram, Shravya Etta, Zach

title: Microbial Electrosynthesis of Glycerol from CO? via Engineered Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans
abstract: Facing the dual challenges of greenhouse gas accumulation and renewable energy intermittency, electrochemical CO? reduction presents a promising solution by converting electrical energy into storable chemicals. The CUG-China 2025 project engineers the acidophilic bacterium Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans - which naturally thrives in extreme acidic conditions (pH<2) - to create a novel electricity-driven carbon fixation platform. This engineered strain incorporates three key synthetic modules: enhanced extracellular electron uptake, efficient glycerol synthesis from fixed carbon, and optimized CO? fixation via the Calvin cycle. When integrated into a microbial electrochemical system, the platform achieves efficient CO? conversion while producing valuable chemicals, offering a sustainable approach to simultaneous carbon mitigation and energy storage.
PIs: Yidan Hu, Yiran Dong, Yongguang Jiang, ZhouJiang

students: Doris, dyc, EnShang LI, menglin, Ronja, Ruiyi Jiao, Run Liu, Sophia, Wan, Xinyi Li, yuhan, Yuxuan

title: NRPieceS - Unlocking Nature's Antibiotic Toolbox
abstract: We present NRPieceS, a versatile synthetic biology platform for rapid generation of large non-ribosomal peptide (NRP) libraries with minimal cloning effort. By integrating advanced NRPS engineering techniques, NRPieceS enables efficient combinatorial biosynthesis of potential bioactive peptides. The platform encompasses a complete Design-Build-Test-Learn workflow, including heterologous expression, derivatization, activity screening, and computational guidance through our software mATChmaker. The accompanying plasmid collection (160 plasmids, including 35 donor constructs) facilitates modular NRPS assembly and rational engineering. mATChmaker models and visualizes native and hybrid NRPS condensation complexes, providing structural and phylogenetic insights to guide module compatibility and design. Using NRPieceS, we generated and screened peptide libraries against ESKAPE pathogens, identifying antimicrobial hits. Furthermore, a Trojan horse strategy employing siderophore conjugation via click chemistry might enhance bacterial uptake. NRPieceS unites wet-lab and computational tools in a sustainable framework, accelerating antibiotic discovery and enabling accessible NRPS engineering for the broader research community.
nominations: Best Part Collection, Overgrad+Best Software Tool, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
PIs: Lars Matthias Voll, Adrian Bunzel, Helge Bode, Isabelle Bekeredjian-Ding
instructors: Christian Schelhas, Melina Flakowski, Patrick Gonschorek, Simon Klute
advisors: Clemens Boehm, Denis Hamburg, Flo, Kholoud Abdelfattah Mohamed
student leaders: Lea Helfrich, Yaro Fokken, Yossr Salama
students: Amalia Barsegian, Anna Rydzeck, Evmorfia Solakoudi, Felix Künzer, Hans Christian Groß, Jaisaiarun Prathapam Srinivasan, Jannik Johannes, Joelina Gärtner, Johannes Wichert, Jonghak Im, Kardelen Sabanoglu Koroglu, Lena Jakobi, Namaz Davrishov, Pascal Lindemann, Rowena-Elen Günther, Vishal Amith Kannan, Yaroslav Smetana, Zeynep Umut

title: PlasMission: Re-sensitizing Beta-Lactam Resistant Bacteria
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a critical global threat, causing 1.27 million deaths annually and projected to reach 10 million per year by 2050. To address ?-lactamase-mediated resistance, PlasMission engineered a conjugative microbial system that transfers a plasmid encoding Beta-Lactamase Inhibitory Protein (BLIP) between bacteria. BLIP binds to ?-lactamase enzymes, restoring bacterial sensitivity to ?-lactam antibiotics. Using E. coli S17-1 as the donor, our system successfully delivered BLIP-I and BLIP-II plasmids into E. coli DH5?, causing ampicillin-resistant recipients to lose viability under antibiotic selection. We envision expanding this system into a conditional survival circuit with inducible BLIP expression, enhancing biosafety and enabling applications in biocontainment, therapeutic bacteria, and biosensing. Ultimately, our S17-1_BLIP system serves as a promising synthetic biology tool for re-sensitizing resistant bacteria, supporting rapid resistance detection, and contributing to safer, programmable antimicrobial interventions.
advisors: YI-CHEN, CHIU
student leaders: Bertie, Chloe Cheng, Jui-Yu, Tiffany Chen, Tiffany Ting
students: Bella Fu, Cynthia Chuang, Elaine, Justin Chou, Justin Lee, Marina, Mia, Olivia, Ray Ku, Venus Chou, Veronica Lin, William Lu

title: DuCon?A Dual-microbe system for vinasse recycling through Conversion to succinate
abstract: The treatment of Baijiu vinasse, which contains hard-to-degrade carbon sources, is a significant environmental challenge. For our iGEM project, we designed an innovative dual-microbe system to tackle this issue and produce high-value succinate. We genetically engineered Trichoderma reesei to secrete laccase (from white rot fungus) and its native cellulase. This enables the simultaneous breakdown of lignin into short arenes and cellulose within the vinasse. Subsequently, the engineered Pseudomonas putida is introduced to uptake these arenes and direct them into its modified TCA cycle. We specifically engineered this pathway to overproduce succinate and added an efflux channel for its secretion. This system promises efficient vinasse decomposition while generating a valuable chemical, balancing environmental sustainability with economic benefit.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, Undergrad
advisors: Changqi Fan, Jiahui Chen, Jinhao Liu, Shisu Li, Xinyi Li, Yuhang Shen
students: Beichen Jin, Chunjiang Li, Jijia Dou, Jinxia Zhu, Linshan Ye, Mingyuan Yao, Siqi Chen, Weixin Dai, XU XIN, Yanpeng Song, Yuanbo Shi, Yue Liu, Yupei Yuan, Yuxuan Jiang, Zekai Wu, Zhefu Li

title: Revitalyze: Restoring Glycosylation, One Vesicle at a Time
abstract: Congenital disorders of glycosylation (CDGs) are a group of rare metabolic diseases caused by defects in various stages of the glycosylation pathway. Errors in glycosylation can confuse cellular interactions, causing serious malfunctions in multiple organs and organ systems. The most common type of CDG is PMM2-CDG (or CDG-Ia), where the mutation in the PMM2 enzyme, which converts mannose-6-phosphate to mannose-1-phosphate, leads to decreased glycosylation rate. As a comprehensive solution to this problem, Revitalyze proposes engineering probiotics that deliver the functional PMM2 protein to the patient's body cells via bacterial extracellular vesicles (bEVs), thereby allowing an enzyme replacement therapy that minimizes disruption in the patients' daily lives. Starting with PMM2-CDG, our delivery system can be expanded to any other type of CDG caused by mutations in enzymes, and potentially other disorders as well. Revitalyze is more than a treatment; it's a step toward hope for all rare disorders.
PIs: Yong-Ak Song, Andras Gyorgy, Ibrahim Chehade
student leaders: Abdullah Salman, Heesung Tae, Milena Bisenic
students: Aman Sunesh, Aneeka, Arda, Bethel, Deborah, Diperson, Hiyath, Jehan Nakaweh, keya, Lily, Nataliya, Salma, Sara Badar, Udaya Pandit, Zhenjun Kong

title: CONCAVE: Generating and Applying Antibody Alternatives
abstract: Antibodies play a crucial role in immunity by binding to specific antigens. Despite their widespread use, the production of antibodies remains costly and time-consuming, and dependent upon animal use. Our project, Concave, seeks to overcome these challenges by developing a modular synthetic biology platform to design customized binding proteins that mimic the versatility of antibodies and can be efficiently produced in E. coli. We are developing a scalable system for generating highly diverse leucine-rich repeat (LRR) proteins known as Repebodies, which are synthetic variants of lamprey VLRs that function similarly to antibodies. By combining this with retron-based mutagenesis, we enable continuous, in situ diversification of LRRs without manual intervention, allowing us to generate Repebodies that bind virtually any antigen. In order to use the Repebodies' target binding, we are designing Repebody-nanobody fusion proteins that interface with mammalian degradation machinery. This system is designed for degradation of membrane-bound or cytoplasmic proteins.
awards: Top 10+Best Foundational Advance Project+Best New Basic Part
nominations: Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
advisors: Amelie Stange, Isabelle Tipp, Ivana Rozi?, Jan Zielinski, Nicole Kucera, Niels Geipel
students: Ana Luiza, Christopher Träumer, Diana Traute, Eric Gildersleeve, Eva Müller-Rachor, Francesca Garafulic, J. Oliver, Jonathan K, Keno T, Max Wunderlich, Yang-Yun,Chen

title: Pyricon - Spinning a Future with Spider Silk towards more sustainable construction materials
abstract: Cement production accounts for about 8% of global CO? emissions (Kajaste & Hurme, 2016), and demand is expected to rise (Castro-Alonso et al., 2019; Lanjewar et al., 2025). At Pyricon, we address this challenge by creating a sustainable, bio-based alternative to cement bricks. We engineer Bacillus subtilis to produce spider silk proteins that enhance microbially induced calcite precipitation by another bacterium, forming a durable biocement. Using a novel PCR-free DNA assembly strategy and codon harmonisation, we aim to efficiently express highly repetitive silk genes. Our approach not only enables eco-friendly construction materials but also advances synthetic biology by providing a robust method for assembling reptitive DNA sequences. Scaled adoption of Pyricon's biocement could significantly cut embodied CO? in masonry and small-scale construction while extending material lifespan, offering a practical path toward a lower-carbon built environment.
student leaders: Constantin Hammer, Lilli Nina Worster, Marcel Syre, Maxim Emelianov
students: Alissa Bocanegra Petry, Aljoscha Bertram, Clara, Henry Dekorsy, Jessica Amy Li, Johannes Grau, Latifa Rezzouk, Marius Mergard, Moritz, Yara Collel

title: STREAM
abstract: Bioproduction forms the basis of industries from food to textiles and pharmaceuticals, yet fluctuations in metabolite output and limited access to advanced equipment remain major challenges. STREAM addresses these by integrating proof-of-concept metabolic control with affordable, modular hardware, open-access software, and a predictive model. Our system enhances continuous metabolite production through a ratiometric biosensor that monitors concentrations in real time, enabling feedback-driven control. When product formation declines, inducers are added to overcome pathway bottlenecks and stabilize productivity. A mathematical model simulates inducer effects and metabolic dynamics, while an optimization algorithm balances inducer use and yield to minimize costs.An intuitive open-source software allows for easy hardware control. Together, these components demonstrate how low-cost, modular hardware combined with biosensor-guided feedback control can stabilize cultures, reduce metabolic stress, and enhance the reliability of bioproduction - making continuous bioprocessing more accessible, reproducible, and sustainable for teams and labs worldwide.
nominations: Best Biomanufacturing Project, Overgrad
advisors: Can Karka, Deniz Öztürk, Florian Hänsel, Kayra Sofie Rüffer, Niklas Küppers, Yannik Grans, Yasemin Baran
student leaders: Emma Tullius, Evan Seidler, Kacper Glowacki
students: Amy, Anna Koerner, Anthea, Bela, Clara Berta Claaßen, Elias Schumacher, Elisabeth Grönert, Jan Krischer, Lavinia Dzombic, Mareen Krügel, Meshkat, nele, Niklas Steinbach, Stefana Dukic

title: RhizoRetention: Creating drought-resistant Brassica napus through bacteria-mediated RNA interference
abstract: In Alberta, more than 14,000 farmers grow over 6.6 million acres of canola each year. As Canada's most valuable crop, canola contributes nearly $30 billion annually to the economy. However, climate change, particularly persistent drought, threatens productivity. Developing drought-resistant canola could help secure the sector's future. One promising strategy combines plant-growth-promoting rhizobacteria with RNA interference (RNAi) to silence genes that reduce drought tolerance. A 2020 study in Arabidopsis thaliana found that overexpression of the transcription factor bHLH61 impaired drought tolerance, while loss of function improved it. Since a homologous gene exists in canola, targeting it may enhance drought resistance. Our approach engineers Arthrobacter globiformis to produce small-interfering RNA (siRNA) against bHLH61. Incorporated into seed coatings, the bacteria colonize canola roots and deliver double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) to silence the gene. This method could improve drought resilience in canola and help mitigate the impacts of climate change.
students: Agrim Paudel, Amira, Anna, Avi, Bobby Zhao, Charlotte Fink, Dana Omar, Elyse Burgess, Gabe Anoos, Ian Benkoczi, Jaki Sadr, Jerry Wang, Jovin Bach, Maya Walton, Mazen, Mercy Awosoga, Nora Laird, Raafae Rasool, Selina Sun

title: ParkinSolve
abstract: Parkinson's Disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by dopaminergic neuron loss and microglial-driven inflammation. Current treatments only alleviate symptoms without halting disease progression. To address this, we engineered CHO cells to secrete anti-inflammatory proteins (IL-1RA, IFN?R-Fc, and TLR4-Fc) that modulate microglial activation and protect neurons. Using a Tet-On 3G system, we achieved precise, doxycycline-inducible control of therapeutic protein expression. Conditioned media from transfected CHO cells improved BV2 microglial survival under rotenone-induced oxidative stress, with TLR4-Fc showing the strongest neuroprotective effect. This system demonstrates a controllable mammalian cell-based platform for adaptive, anti-inflammatory therapeutics in neurodegenerative disease.
student leaders: Cindy Li, Claire Lim, Jaehee Park, Jihoo Hyun, Marine Sevel, Mimi Zhao, Yunji Kim
students: Aanika, Annie Luo, Brianna Baek, Emma Lee, Harini Iyer, Jayna Lee, Jeongan Choi, Joyce Tan, Kaylee Byun, Kyra Malik, Lifu, Linda Yu, Meera Pant, Ryan Smith, Shoshana_R, Shravya Mandadi, Sophie Tsui, Suhui Kim, Toby Wang, Will, Yoyo

title: UNIglobin: A Portable Enzymatic Kit for Universal Blood Conversion
abstract: As an essential medicine, blood should be "available at all times, in adequate amounts and in appropriate dosage forms, with assured quality and affordability," according to the World Health Organization (WHO). However as it stands in 2024, blood still fails to meet the availability and safety qualities in over half the world's countries. Our solution is a compact, field ready ABO blood conversion kit. We have identified, cloned, and characterized activity for glycoside hydrolase enzymes from Akkermansia muciniphila. These enzymes have the ability to cleave off the A and B blood antigens and their extended antigen groups and can be lyophilized for long term storage. Our complete kit also includes a filtering system made of biological materials to remove immune reactive white blood cells and a Miniaturized Electronic Antigen Biosensor (MEAB) for rapid quantification of ABO antigens. Together these technologies can process safe, universally compatible blood available, anytime, anywhere.
student leaders: Michelle Kim, Nicole Salazar, Ryan Crane
students: Agostina, An, Anna Hanus, Bhavana Yeedubilli, Brayan, Ella, Francesca, Lina, Mary Crawford, Meghna Nair, Nova Rubio Coronado, Pranav Vippagunta, Ryan Dolphin, SB, Shreya Manjre, Therese Thomas, Z Choy, Zikang Chen

title: CERES: Computational Enzymes Research and Exploring System
abstract: We developed a novel machine learning model named "LEAPS" that enables efficient protein function improvement from limited datasets. Conventional protein engineering requires large-scale experimental data, extensive expertise, and prolonged trial-and-error processes, making research execution heavily dependent on institutional funding and human resources. Consequently, significant barriers remain for student teams and small-scale laboratories attempting to engage in protein engineering. LEAPS substantially reduces these constraints and provides an accessible environment for researchers to perform multi-objective optimization of proteins. This model enables student teams participating in iGEM and researchers with limited resources to undertake functional improvements such as enzymatic activity enhancement and antibody affinity optimization, dramatically expanding research possibilities. Furthermore, we have developed and publicly released LEAPS as a web application, establishing a platform accessible to the broader research community. This model has the potential to promote data-driven protein engineering and accelerate research and development across all fields of life sciences.
nominations: Safety and Security Award, Undergrad
students: Haruna Ama, Haruna Oka, Hayashi Kensho, Hinami Kusano, Hinata Tamesui, Hino Haruka, Hosotani Tamaki, Inagaki Hiroto, Koushi Mizota, Le Yao, Masahiro_Suzuki, Masateru Sakakibara, Masato Yoshida, Mikoto, Mizumoto Chihiro, Nada Kawano, Nitta Shoichi, Oi Soraha, Riku, Sakuya Tomida, Sarara Shimazu, Sawako KUNISAKI, Shimada Erika, Suzuki Sumire, Takuya Ishizaki, Tomoro Saito, Wakana Yoshida, Yamada Asahi, Yoshihisa Sunto, Yukiko Maeda, Yushi, Yushin, Zijie Zhou, ????
