title: Solving Barnacle adhesion to a ships hull through Biotechnology whilst expanding biotechnology learning.
abstract: We aimed to combat marine biofouling to reduce wasted fuel in the shipping industry caused by drag. We identified cp19k from previous iGEM projects as a key adhesive protein in barnacle cement. We optimised expression of cp19k in E. coli BL21 (DE3), then tested a range of proteases to identify which one(s) degrade it most effectively. This high school project did not benefit from usual university collaborations, and we attempted to complete all experiments in house, we created a programme to develop skills in younger students that would equip them for later involvement in the iGEM. We aimed for a safe, inclusive and collaborative environment advertising the team widely and keeping costs to a minimum for all. We have educated the school community and beyond through the iGEM process.
students: Asger Fischer, Evelyn, Jayden Leung, Jayden Liu, Jing Jing, Joanna Chang, kwaiyd, Lifu Zhang, William Yang, Zahara Greener

title: SAUR-eus
abstract: Antibiotic resistance is one of the biggest threats to modern medicine, and Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) stands at the center of this crisis. Conventional drugs are losing effectiveness, and broad-spectrum treatments often harm the beneficial bacteria we rely on. Our project takes a new angle: instead of fighting MRSA with traditional antibiotics, we use bioinformatics and computational modeling to uncover weak points in its biology using Staphylococcus aureus as a model organism. By mapping its genome and key metabolic pathways, we identify genes essential for building and maintaining its cell wall, which are targets that are unique to the pathogen and absent in healthy microbiota. With these insights, we aim to design next-generation antimicrobials that are precise, sustainable, and less likely to drive resistance. Project SAUR-eus isn't just about tackling one superbug; it's about rethinking how we fight infections while protecting the delicate balance of our microbial world.
nominations: Inclusivity Award, High School
students: Angel, Iwin, Joseph Xu, Kate, Kate, Mind, Pep, Petch, Pim, Pirada Bisalputra, Tyme, Vee

title: AMADRYADS:A (CRISPR-Cas13d) Mediated Antifungal treatment ,Deploying a Riboswitch, Yielding Apoptotic Defense in a Systemic way.
abstract: Canker stain represents one of the most devastating threats to forest ecosystems worldwide, affecting all species of the genus Platanus, regardless of their size or age. It is a fungal disease caused by Ceratocystis platani. AMADRYADS is a chitosan-based nanocarrier system that encapsulates a plasmid. The plasmid cassette, delicately designed, contains a toehold-controlled Cas13d gene (a CRISPR/Cas ortholog that targets single-stranded RNA) and a gRNA array targeting two key fungal transcript, the products of the LysM and Res1 genes. With an emphasis on safety, we developed a non-GMO, biodegradable solution that operates on two specificity levels. First, it targets unique sequences found only in the fungus through gRNA modeling. Second, the toehold-controlled Cas13d gene is translated only in the presence of a species-specific toxin, ceratoplatanin (CP). Through these design features, combined with the high collateral activity characteristic of Cas13d, AMADRYADS aims to induce a total transcriptomic collapse of the pathogen.
PIs: Theologos Michaelidis, Dimitrios Alivertis, Amalia-S. Afendra, Chris Andreadis, HARALAMBOS STAMATIS, Kalliopi Stara, Petros Marangos
instructors: Anastasia Skonta, CHARALAMPOS TSIOS, IOANNA KOUTSOTOLI, Viktoria Sizikova
advisors: IOANNA KARACHALIOU, Ioannis Rizos, MARIA-MAVRETA KOKOLA
students: Angeliki Boulala, Aristotelis Michalakis, DIMITRIOS BLAKOS, Eva, iliana rapti, IOANNIS VASILEIOS ELAFROPOULOS, MARY, Panagiotis, PANTELIS, Sokratis, Stella Dimitriou, THOMAS KATIKOS, Vasiliki Rafaela Savvidou, Yorgos Skordakis, Zisis Psalidas

title: Bioreactive heritage protection using engineered E.coli with enhanced sulfur reduction and biosilica coating
abstract: Recently, more and more cultural heritage sites used microorganisms for biocleaning and protection. Our project leverages synthetic biology to develop a sustainable solution to protect heritage sites from environmental deterioration. Our project comprises two parts. Firstly, we addressed acid erosion by engineering sulphur reduction pathways. We engineered E. coli to reduce sulfate and sulfite to cysteine. We utilised two genes, YdeD, which exports cysteine out of bacterial cells, and YhaM, which degrades cysteine, to drive the reduction pathway. Secondly, we employed silicatein-expressed E. coli to catalyse the formation of biosilica from tetraethyl orthosilicate. This biosilica could fill cracks in structures and improve structural integrity. We also adopted csgA adhesion domain, which ensures our engineered E. coli adheres to building surfaces under acidic conditions. Together with our hardware for crack-repairing and models to estimate corrosion, we believe our project can bring new insights for future heritage protection projects utilising synthetic biology.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School
PIs: Wai Man Cheong, Lok In Lo, Seak Chi U
instructors: CHIEN-YUEH LIU, Fong Tin Cheng, Jimmy Cheong, LEONG WENG I
advisors: Catherine Lam, Lee Tsz On
students: Camellia Cheong, Chan Chi Cheng, CHENG I LEONG, Cheng Un, Cheok U Lei, Clovis Chang, Iek Tong Lui, Jerry Chen, Ka Cheng Chan, Katie Lao, Kin Hang Yuen, lam ian cheng, Liona Tong, Lok Man Chiu, Lou Chi Kuan, Lucas, Marco Ka, Natalia Do Espirito Santo Lo, SAM IEK HUN, Seng Hei Cheng, SI MEI LEONG, Tiffany Ao, Winston Cheng WONG

title: TRACE - Redefining STI testing through portable, paper-based diagnostics
abstract: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) remain a growing global health challenge. Despite being treatable when detected early, testing rates are low due to asymptomatic cases, limited awareness, high costs, and inconvenient diagnostics. TRACE reimagines STI testing through synthetic biology by developing a cell-free, paper-based self-test that works without laboratories or trained personnel, enabling frequent use in low-resource settings. By uniting accessibility, sensitivity, and ease of use, TRACE empowers individuals to test frequently, reduce transmission, and improve global sexual health. The system combines rapid, room-temperature nucleic acid amplification via recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) with a specific colorimetric readout. Both CRISPR-Cas and a novel DNA hybridization-based detection approach were evaluated to optimize cost, durability, and specificity. Extensive human practices research guided design and implementation, incorporating feedback from users, healthcare providers, and stakeholders. Through modeling, stakeholder consultation, and market analysis, we ensure real-world feasibility.
advisors: Gabriel Cervera Arriaga, Maurin Widmer, Seraina Müller
students: Alex Lecoq, anna, Gabriela Toscani Fernandes, George, Selina Gubler, Tatia Khornauli, Tiziana Baumgärtner

title: Aquarius: Channeling SynBio from the Lab to Aquatic Environments
abstract: The flow of water is essential to life on Earth, but can also carry negative consequences. Water movement transports pollutants to lakes, spreads harmful microbes through household plumbing, and corrodes infrastructure. Synthetic biology offers powerful solutions, yet few have been implemented in real-world aquatic environments. The lack of SynBio deployment in water environments stems from limited understanding of how engineered organisms function in dynamic environments, in which they must compete within native microbial communities, withstand shifting nutrient levels, and endure various physical stressors. Our project addresses this challenge through an integrated approach of chassis analysis software, predictive mathematical modeling, comprehensive RNA-seq meta-analysis and experimentation with engineered constructs in laboratory and aquatic settings. By analyzing how synthetic circuits behave in flowing water compared to laboratory settings, we uncover foundational design principles that will enable the development of safe, effective synthetic biology applications to tackle pressing global challenges linked to aquatic environments.
PIs: Margaret Saha, Eric Bradley, Greg Conradi Smith
advisors: Caden Sanko
students: Madeline Eibner-Gebhardt, Olabisi Bashorun, Sean Emmett, Vandana Kalithkar, Xinyu Hu

title: Sterosaurus
abstract: Our project proposes a novel system that tackles the climate crisis by repurposing carbon dioxide (CO?) emissions from manufacturing industries, transforming this waste into a valuable resource. Specifically, we utilize CO? to fuel algae bioreactors that produce high-value pharmaceutical compounds. By recycling industrial CO? and converting it into ergosterols, a precursor of steroid hormones, we create a circular economy model that emphasizes sustainability, innovation, and improved efficiency in pharmaceutical production.
advisors: Akara Adelino-Roux
student leaders: Aiman Dhiloon, Alice Payne, Arnica, Binjal Pradhan, Bogdana Borysova, Mike Cho, Osha Joaquim, Renee Vucemilo
students: Adriana Baric, Akshan Santhakumar, Andrea Lalu, Chloe Lim, Efe Yencilek, Eryn Bantugon, Ethan Kozak, Henry Tsai, Kenny, Kobe Li, Lavan, Mahi Prajapati, Malvika Nair, Michelle Alves, Mrudula, Muhammed, Prisha, Rachel, Reem, Via Iseppon

title: CRIKIT: Developing a rapid CRISPR-based diagnostic kit for detecting antibiotic resistance
abstract: Antibiotic resistance is one of the most critical emerging threats to global healthcare, with current projections indicating it will surpass cancer as a leading cause of mortality in the coming decades. Conventional methods for identifying antibiotic resistant infections are time-consuming, as they depend on culturing bacteria in the presence of antibiotics. This diagnosis delay often leads to trial-and-error treatment strategies, which not only compromise patient outcomes but also promote the spread of resistance. To address this challenge, we are developing CRIKIT, a rapid and versatile diagnostic tool based on using Cas13 and programmable guide RNAs (gRNAs) directly from cell lysate to target bacterial transcripts of specific antibiotic resistance genes. By adding a fluorescent reporter we use Cas13's collateral cleavage activity to generate a measurable fluorescent signal. This approach will enable clinicians to make rapid, targeted decisions about antibiotic therapies, reducing the reliance on empirical treatments and improving clinical outcomes.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, Overgrad+Best Measurement, Overgrad+Best Diagnostics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Andy Thunnissen, Gert Moll, Julia Kamenz
students: Alex, Andre Athayde Gimenes, Daniël Kassab, Daria Alexa, Ema Jungová, Luigi, Margherita Bonan, Mihai Fracea, Pendo Anna, Tudor Tirnoveanu, Yaprak Yigit

title: TRAPS - Targeted RNA Activated Phase Seperation
abstract: RNA is a versatile biomolecule functioning as both messenger and catalyst. Understanding its dynamics, localization, and expression in living cells is crucial for decoding cellular function. Existing RNA imaging methods often require fixation or genetic modification and struggle to detect low-abundance RNAs due to poor signal-to-noise ratio. Here, we introduce TRAPS - Targeted RNA Activated Phase Separation, a novel and modular approach for in vivo RNA detection. TRAPS uses catalytically inactive Cas13 fused to GFP-tagged scaffold domains, forming fluorescent condensates upon multivalent RNA binding. This enables simple, real-time visualization and flexible adaption. Our system allows detection of endogenous RNAs with improved sensitivity and temporal resolution. As proof of concept, we targeted mCherry mRNA in S. cerevisiae. Combined with our software SEASTAR (Side-Effect Aware Sequence Targeting & Ranking) for optimal site selection, TRAPS offers an accessible, versatile platform for RNA studies in living cells and future iGEM applications.
nominations: Best Software Tool, Overgrad
students: B.Pfeiffer, Celina Stitz, Doro, Dylan, Fabi, Franz Müller, Georg Jannes Pöppich, Joe, Jule, Julia, Julius, Konrad Wilms, Liesa, Li Jing, Ludwig, Lukas, Malte Werner, Matilda, Melle, Niklas, PaulS, Zane

title: PhytoBlock - Let's Save the Future of Chocolate!
abstract: Black Pod Disease, caused by Phytophthora species, destroys up to 30% of global cocoa yield each year and threatens the livelihoods of farmers. Our project, PhytoBlock, harnesses the natural power of Bacillus subtilis, that is engineered to secrete antimicrobial peptides upon detection of Phytophthora species, hereby preventing Black Pod Disease. By offering an alternative to chemical fungicides, PhytoBlock protects cacao crops, reduces accumulation of chemicals in the environment, and supports long-term agricultural resilience.
advisors: Jena Amand, Joris Kenis, Juan Cossio, Mary Anna Nishiotis
students: Adithi Ravikumar, Agathe Pourprix, Amalia Villar Jakobsen, Beatriz Pinho, Brindha Basker, Daniel Steukers, Guglielmo Pessano, Joshua Ijidakinro, Mauricio Lamoyi, Olga, Valeria, Others, Iebe nijs, Joenne Spreuwers, Robert Callens, Surya Narayan Dash

title: SPIKY'MUNE- An edible anti-cholera vaccine implemented in cactus
abstract: Each year, cholera causes thousands of deaths in developing countries where access to clean water remains insufficient. Available oral vaccines depend on a strict cold chain (2-8°C), a fragile system that collapses in areas exposed to extreme temperatures and power outages. Climate crisis worsens this situation: flooding and droughts promote Vibrio cholerae proliferation. Spiky'Mune provides an innovative alternative: transforming Opuntia ficus-indica (prickly pear cactus) into an edible vaccine producing CTxB protein, a non-toxic immunogenic fragment of cholera toxin. This approach relies on the cactus's exceptional properties: tolerance to arid climates, rapid growth, and massive biomass production (200 tons/ha/year). Its cells naturally protect proteins against gastric degradation. Our strategy includes CTxB expression validation in E. coli, transient transformation of Nicotiana benthamiana, then stable cactus callus transformation. By eliminating refrigeration requirements and promoting local production, Spiky'Mune addresses logistical, economic, and climate challenges while pioneering edible vaccines against enteric pathogens.
students: Agathe PORCHERON, Gabin Verdier, Jeanne Bourgeois, Jehlysa Albert, Julien Decodts, Julien Mercy, Kenly, Lily rose Charnley, Manon, Manon Perez, Mathias, Mathieu Cimolaï, Mathilde Job, Morgane Inthavong, Nora Durand, Pariente, Sacha Levy, William Potié

title: Unlocking Hidden Nutrition in Seeds with AI and Promoter Engineering
abstract: Micronutrient deficiencies (hidden hunger) affects over two billion people globally. This happens from a lack of vitamins and micronutrients, even in diets sufficient in calories. Seeds provide energy, but are often poor in essential vitamins. Plants can synthesize certain vitamins, but some of the key genes for the biosynthesis are not active in seeds. We aim to unlock the natural potential of seeds by engineering the promoters of key genes for vitamin biosynthesis in soybeans. To predict the gene expression patterns in seeds, we trained a machine learning model using seed and non-seed specific gene promoters. This simulates mutations in native gene promoters and predicts whether a mutation can increase the gene expression in seeds. To test this, we introduced a RUBY reporter system. When a mutated promoter activates the target gene, it produces red pigment in the seed. We will test this in Arabidopsis, and then move onto soybeans.
PIs: Tianhu Sun, Aruna Kilaru, Bob Standaert
students: Connor, Cristiana Martinez, Elliot Fry, Emma, John Flaifel, Trent Lewis

title: REEnaisance: Reimagining Rare Earth Element Extraction Through Bioabsorption
abstract: Rare earth elements (REEs), often referred to as "industrial vitamins", possess unique physicochemical properties that make them vital components in high-tech industries including optics, electronics, and magnetism. However, conventional extraction and separation techniques--such as sulfate roasting, alkali leaching, and ammonium salt leaching--are associated with severe environmental pollution and ecological damage. In response, microbial bioleaching and biosorption using bacteria represent a promising green alternative, offering an eco-friendly, cost-effective, and sustainable strategy for REE recovery. In this project, we first validated the REEs adsorption capacity of Pseudomonas kunmingensis (P. kunmingensis) HL22-2T, and subsequently engineered the strain with key genes involved in polyphosphate metabolism. By reprogramming its phosphate regulatory network, we aim to enhance the strain's ability to adsorb REEs, aligning with the principles of sustainable biotechnology.
students: Avy, Baiting Song, Mei Yang, MINGYUE HU, Xizun Tang, Xuyiyi, YANZE WU, Yihan Jing, Yuchen, Zhichen Xue

title: Phospho-NO: Preferential Binding of Phosphorylated Proteoforms In Vivo
abstract: Phosphorylation is a critical post-translational modification that modulates key cellular processes, yet selectively isolating and studying specific phosphorylated proteins remains a major challenge. Existing tools like phosphorylation state-specific antibodies often lack absolute specificity and require extensive validation. To address these challenges, our project introduces a novel approach that integrates the phosphorylation-specific binding capacity of 14-3-3 proteins with a synthetic binder engineered for high affinity and target specificity. This combination enables precise recognition of a single phosphorylated protein isoform. Coupled to an E3 ligase recruitment system, this 14-3-3-Degradation Complex could facilitate selective ubiquitination and degradation of the phosphorylated target, offering a versatile platform for both phosphoprotein characterization and therapeutic targeting. Using C-Raf as a model substrate, we demonstrate enhanced site-specificity, highlighting the potential of this system to advance phospho-proteomic research and targeted cancer therapies after further research is performed.
student leaders: Bloom Lerngutai, Eva Lim, Manya Lalwani, Nicole Liu, Nipputi Thongthai, Nora, Sneha Agarwal, Tommy Walsh
students: Alexander von Kumberg, Andrea Kim, Aneesh, Arthur Costa, Della Waldman, Ephraim, Evalds Viguls, Gerard, Jack Goetzman, Jacob, Kiran, Leyton, Matthew, Max Huang, Nico Rose, Sofia, Tommy Elliott

title: BloomBusters
abstract: Cyanobacteria are photosynthetic microorganisms that can form harmful algal blooms. These blooms can lower oxygen levels, resulting in mass wildlife mortality. Microcystis aeruginosa, a common bloom-forming species, also produces the hepatotoxin microcystin, which accumulates in the food chain and induces severe physiological effects. Through rounds of discussion with experts, we found that early detection of microcystin is critical for effective management but remains limited. Current methods are slow, inconsistent, expensive, and unable to distinguish toxic from other strains. BloomBusters introduces a novel detection method based on CRISPR-SHERLOCK: an RNA-based fluorescent biosensor targeting toxin biosynthesis genes in Microcystis. This system enables rapid, sensitive, and specific detection of toxin-producing cyanobacteria within hours, allowing timely interventions and improved water safety. We demonstrated detection in mcyE/B RNA targets from Microcystis, allowing detection and management of toxic blooms using synthetic biology approaches, protecting ecosystems and public health before it's too late.
nominations: Best Part Collection, High School+Best Sustainable Development Impact, High School+Best Village Project, High School
students: Aarika Singh, Aashrita, Aneesha Aryan, Anuj Joshi, Arthur, Betel, Cindy Ma, David Wang, Ivy Xia, Min, Ren Gao, Sathvik, SophiaZ, Sumukh Shankar, Vaibu, Vidyuth, Willow

title: A Dual-Approach, Synthetic Biology Solution to ALS, Targeting Neural Stress Granules and TDP-43 Aggregation
abstract: TAR DNA-binding protein 43 (TDP-43) aggregation driven by stress granule (SG) accumulation is a hallmark of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Our work addresses this through two complementary strategies: antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) for knocking down proteins implicated in the formation of stress granules and RNA aptamers for limiting TDP-43 aggregation. We identified three proteins whose knockdown reduces SG assembly. For each, we developed, generated, and validated a panel of ASOs through computational modeling and in vitro testing. ASOs targeting DAZAP1 and FAM98A, two critical stress-granule-associated proteins, demonstrated significant protein knockdown and SG suppression. We also developed a machine learning model to predict ASO efficacy for increased wet-lab efficiency. In parallel, we generated RNA aptamers targeting TDP-43's C-terminal domain through a computational pipeline; top candidates bound to TDP-43 with high specificity in vitro. Our dual-strategy approach offers a layered therapeutic strategy for ALS and establishes a novel framework for future disease research.
student leaders: Lilian Zeng, Nithika Vivek, Nupur Bhalla, Prakruti Bhatt, Risha Guha, Saanvi Dogra, Tanvi Movva
students: Anwita Bandaru, Celine Wu, Claire Wang, Eliza Hong, Eshan Patibandla, Olivia Li, Rohan Bojja, Ronith Kumar, Ruta Sirdeshmukh, Shawn Kim, Vasanth Rajasekaran, Yash Parikh

title: Development of an environmentally friendly polypeptide-based termite pesticide
abstract: Termites endanger the development of sustainable, safe, and resilient communities and our team is developing an environmentally friendly solution for their control. Unlike conventional chemical pesticides, which pose significant hazards to ecosystems, humans, and animals, our approach uses biodegradable polypeptides, ensuring both high efficacy and ecological safety. The project is structured into two components: attraction of termites and their targeted elimination. The attraction mechanism uses the Cytochrome P450 enzyme from Bacillus megaterium to catalyze the conversion of phenol into hydroquinone, a phagostimulant to enhance termite feeding behavior. For the control strategy, two approaches have been devised: (1) disruption of the termite's symbiotic protozoa within the gut via antimicrobial lytic peptides Hecate and Melittin; and (2) inhibition of digestive processes via an Enterolobium contortisiliquum trypsin inhibitor, which blocks key digestive enzymes. By utilizing biologically-based alternative toxins, our team aims to target and suppress termite infestations while achieving sustainability and environmental protection.
instructors: Jack CL Lei, Lyon, Tzu-Ming LIU
students: Althea, Ashley, Coco, Ella, Emily, Jasmine, Lettey, Moon, Rye, Sofia, Sophia, Sri, Thomas

title: "DElMOS": Degradable Exoskeletons of crayfish for in-situ utilization & Mars Operations System
abstract: As space pioneers take one step after another toward fulfilling our dream of exploring the cosmos, do we truly understand the conditions they face? Bland and monotonous food choices, unmet social and psychological needs... Perhaps, we can bring a taste of home to fill this void!? Through an integrated "aquatic plant-crayfish" co-cultivation system, we aim to establish crayfish farming on Mars. Utilizing synthetic biology, we've also designed a system for recycling crayfish shells. First, by using Aspergillus niger and engineered E. coli capable of secreting protease, we can achieve demineralization and deproteinization of the shells. After purifying chitin, it can be used for in-situ material production. Finally, biological resources can be degraded into monosaccharides by chitinase-producing bacteria, feeding back into the food production system. Our ultimate goal is to serve steaming plates of spicy crayfish to astronauts, letting them savor a true taste of home in space.
student leaders: Qixin Yan, Xianye Wu, Xinyue Zhang, Yifeng Wu, Yuman Yuan
students: Baoxiang Huang, Chuanbo Shen, Chuntian Feng, Heminxi Wu, Jiaxi Li, Kuo Li, Qingyu Zhou, Qisheng Xu, Ruoxin Li, Xiangyu Xiao, Xinyu Shen, Yanzhen Chen, Yuehan Zhao, YU-EN HSU

title: ProgERASE - Engineering hope for progeria
abstract: Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome (HGPS) is a rare genetic disorder causing premature aging, with patients typically passing away in early adolescence from cardiovascular complications. The Uni-Padua-IT team, inspired by a fellow student and researcher affected by HGPS, chose to develop ProgERASE. Our project aims at promoting the degradation of progerin, the aberrant version of lamin A responsible for the disease, in a PROTAC-like system. We first designed progerin interactors using an innovative computational pipeline that employs the latest AI-based reverse folding software. We later validated their interaction in yeast (Yeast Two-Hybrid) and the overall system functionality in mammalian cells. Our project made us realize the true impact of science and the need to make it accessible to everyone. For this reason, we developed E.A.S.Y., a guide to make scientific papers more understandable to a wider audience. We believe that diversity of scientific perspectives is what makes research truly groundbreaking.
advisors: Barbara Arfé, Claudia Del Vecchio, Cristiano De Pitta, Guido Papa, Raffaele Lopreiato
students: Alessio Canazza, Anna Cenedese, Arianna, Claudia Sciacca, Gabriele Maschio, Gloria de Buzzaccarini, Irene Apulei, Manuel Palamin, Marco, Mattia Boci, Michael Bellitto, Milica Glusac, Nicolò Donà, Silvia Capra

title: A Modular CRISPR-Cas12-Gold Nanoparticle System for dsDNA Detection
abstract: The FHNW team's project focuses on developing a pathogen detection tool that harnesses the sequence-specific activity of the CRISPR/Cas12 enzyme system to target bacterial DNA. The assay is combined with DNA-gold nanoparticle (GNP) technology, providing a simple and rapid visual readout. Initial development and validation with laboratory strains (e.g., Pseudomonas putida) demonstrated sensitivity down to sub-nanomolar genome DNA concentrations, with distinct fluorescence and later with GNP-based signals. The system was then adapted for Arsenophonus sp., a pathogen affecting potatoes and other root vegetables. Tests under realistic conditions indicated the tool's potential for in-field diagnostics, supporting faster decision-making and more timely interventions. Challenges remain, particularly in improving sensitivity and ensuring robust readouts in complex biological samples. Nonetheless, this proof of concept highlights a promising direction for accessible and field-deployable pathogen detection.
students: Angelica Bebing, Daniela C, Domi, Jan, Jaspar, L. Einsiedler, Lucas, Philipp, Sebi, Stefanie

title: PreserVEG
abstract: Every year, 1.3 billion tons of food are wasted globally, with fruits and vegetables making up 45% of this loss. Fresh produce keeps respiring after harvest and is very sensitive to gases like ethylene. Climacteric fruits release ethylene, which accelerates their ripening and deterioration nearby produce. Since we often judge freshness only by appearance, edible food is sometimes thrown away. And if deteriorated food is left alone, safety risks like foodborne illness increase. To solve this problem, we developed PreserVEG, a Cre/loxP-based three-in-one system for climacteric fruits and vegetables. It has three key functions: Protection -- nisin stops harmful bacteria; Sense -- detection of ethylene gas; Visualization -- GFP is expressed when deterioration begins. Using the Cre/loxP system, nisin protects produce while fresh, then ethylene triggers GFP to show spoilage. PreserVEG helps keep fruits and vegetables fresh and reduces global food waste.
advisors: Daiki Haraguchi, Yuki Iwasaki
students: Aimi Kanamori, Akito Katsui, Asuka, hiroto, Kano, Kaoru Yoshida, Kazuma.Y, Kobayashi Ryoei, Koko, Koshiro kuwai, Kuga takahashi, Kwon BoHyun, Miku Katata, Misa, Nanami Shibata, Nono Takata, OS, Rihito, Rikuta, Rinka Nagao, Saaya Kino, Saku, Shoya, Sonoka Osaki, Sora, Takumi, Tatsuhi Hiramatsu, T ONO, Tsubasa Okura, Yan

title: The Bed Bug Epidemic in Hong Kong: A Proactive Solution
abstract: Inspired by the human impact of Hong Kong's bed bug crisis, our research identified significant barriers to treatment: high costs for residents and limited institutional support. This drove us to develop an accessible, preventative solution to empower communities. Our project investigates L-lactate as a chemoattractant for the preemptive detection of bed bug infestations, enabling early intervention and decontamination. To ensure a sustainable and low-cost supply of this attractant, we developed a microbial production platform by genetically modifying E. coli to synthesize L-lactate. This approach aims to bypass the financial and systemic hurdles that prevent effective bed bug control.
PIs: Yu Wing Hin, Lam Yan Yi
student leaders: Andy Tse, Ho Ying Tung, Ko Tik Kesniel, Wong Yu Fei Hanna
students: Chilam Cheung, Daisy LAM, Dickson Wong, Esther Leung, Gioia Chiu, Jan, Kardia, Kung Tin Yan, Ng Sau Hei Bernard, Raiden Cheung, Russell, Walden

title: GluClear
abstract: GluClear addresses the challenge of accidental gluten exposure, a major concern for individuals with celiac disease and gluten sensitivity. Our project focuses on Bga1903, a naturally gluten-degrading enzyme found in bacteria, and improves its stability and efficiency under gastrointestinal conditions through in silico modeling and protein engineering. By optimizing multiple variants and expressing them for experimental validation, GluClear aims to ensure reliable degradation of trace gluten introduced through cross-contamination. With this approach, GluClear has the potential to support a safer daily life for patients, offering a practical and innovative solution that reduces health risks and increases confidence in food safety.
advisors: Bora Ciner, Gizem
students: Azra ?encan, Batu, Derin Senbayrak, Derya Yener, Dila Baydas, Duru Karabulak, ?dil Erden, Ipek, Iris Copuroglu, Lal, Mina, Yusuf Ulas

title: Inara - Illuminating Early Pregnancy and Miscarriage
abstract: The majority of miscarriages, such as those resulting from genetic abnormalities in the miscarried fetus, are explainable. But in a significant number of cases, even scientists don't have all the answers to why miscarriage happens - partially due to stigma that drives women into silence and inhibits research. Progesterone, a female sex hormone whose levels exhibit within-day variability, is correlated with miscarriages, but no technical platform exists to monitor these levels in real time. We aspire to illuminate early pregnancy and miscarriage by developing such a platform using synthetic biology - specifically, impedimetric aptamers. We anticipate that this platform will expand women's health research, empowering women with better health tools and more opportunities for self-advocacy in early pregnancy. We validated our chosen bio-impedimetric aptamer system beyond the extent of existing literature. We developed hardware, human practices, and a business plan to minimize technical and market risk and maximize ethical impact.
students: Audrey Gold, Blake Grimshaw, Bryson Leary, Ethan, Heinen Louis, Henry Tullis, Isaac Nitchman, Jordyn, Philip Sun

title: ARBOGuard: Dual-Pronged Modulation of the Skin Microbiome for Long-term Mosquito Repellence and Arthropod-Borne Disease Prevention.
abstract: Arthropod-borne diseases (ABDs) such as malaria, dengue, and Zika cause over 1 billion infections and 700,000 deaths annually, with rising incidence due to urbanization and climate change. To address the limitations of existing repellents, we developed ARBOGuard: a synthetic biology platform that reprograms the skin commensal Staphylococcus epidermidis to reduce mosquito attraction. Using CRISPR-Cas9, we disrupted ldh to lower L-lactic acid production (a mosquito attractant) and introduced genes for geraniol biosynthesis (a natural repellent). To enable in-situ modification of S. epidermidis, we engineered Khosrow, a recently discovered lysogenic bacteriophage specific to S. epidermidis, to deliver both constructs. Multiple topical delivery formats incorporating phages into sprays, aerosols and creams were tested, demonstrating effective application across multiple user-friendly products. Ultimately, ARBOGuard demonstrates the feasibility of engineering the skin microbiome into a durable barrier that protects against ABDs, establishing a framework for longer-lasting, innovative topical repellents.
nominations: Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad+Best Infectious Diseases Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Adam Damry, Adam Rudner, Chris Boddy
advisors: Theo
student leaders: Ananya Jain, Teagan Thomas, Victor Boddy

title: Mystiphage: A generative phage bank packaged in a pill to counter drug-resistant infections at scale
abstract: Antibiotic resistance is a growing global threat that requires new antimicrobial solutions. Phage therapy offers promise but is limited by the slow process of matching phage receptor-binding proteins (RBPs) to bacteria. Current prediction models lack generalizability and reliability. Mystiphage's PHORAGE platform uses generative AI to identify and design synthetic RBPs for specific bacterial targets. By leveraging a curated RBP dataset and combining ESM-3 hallucination, Boltz-2 co-folding, and Markov Chain Monte Carlo validation, PHORAGE develops high-affinity RBPs. These predictions are validated through a wet lab pipeline including cloning, expression, and phage spotting assays. The EVADE hardware system delivers targeted therapy to the gut microbiome, connecting computational prediction with biological validation. This integration reduces the time from design to therapeutic use from months to hours. Mystiphage's approach enables scalable, adaptive, and personalized phage therapies to combat bacterial pathogens.
nominations: Best Model, Overgrad
advisors: Jeff Chen
student leaders: Amogh Manivannan, Anthony Dinglasan, Anya Mathur, Claire Cui, Esha Mohan, Henrik S. Zimmermann, Jaden Bhogal, Jasmine Jing, Noah Selda, Patricia Rea, Rebecca Tam, Robinson Meng, Rodrigo Adolfo Reyes Feregrino, Tigran Bleyan

title: Detection and Bioremediation of Polychlorinated Biphenyls
abstract: The goal of our project is to develop a synthetic biology-based system for the detection and bioremediation of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs)--persistent organic pollutants that pose environmental and health risks. We are engineering Pseudomona putida to express genes from the bph (biphenyl degradation) pathway, enabling them to enzymatically break down PCB compounds into less toxic intermediates. To complement this, we are designing a biosensor circuit that uses synthetic aptamers--short nucleic acid sequences that specifically bind PCBs--to initiate a response via a CRISPR-Cas12a-based system. This dual-function system will allow our engineered organisms to both sense and respond to PCB contamination in a controlled, efficient, and field-deployable manner.
PIs: Qingshan Wei, Nathan Crook, Aditi, Alexandra Imre, Zidan Li
students: Adith, Aidan, Akshaya, Annmarie, Audrey, Farhad, Kaushya, Nicole Nienaber, Nithya Burisetty, Patrick Cardona-Cosner, Sanjana, Trinity, Zoya

title: Wood-fed yeast, youth increased, no more aging tease! Xylose operon-regulated two-stage enzymatic biosynthesis of Pro-Xylane
abstract: Pro-Xylane is highly valued in cosmetic and dermocosmetic applications owing to its notable biological activities, including anti-inflammatory and anti-aging effects. Conventional production, however, relies on environmentally unfriendly chemical synthesis or limited natural extraction with low yield and high cost. To address these challenges, we developed a biosynthetic system in engineered Komagataella pastoris. By co-expressing high-performance xylanase and Pro-Xylane synthase, our chassis enables direct, value-added conversion of xylan into Pro-Xylane. The system features a smart xylose-inducible module that dynamically regulates a modular enzymatic cascade through tailored metabolic pathways. Integrating synthetic genetic circuits with native pentose metabolism and applying modular control strategies, we established an efficient, sustainable, and tunable production system. This approach highlights the power of synthetic biology-driven cell machines for high-value biotransformations and provides a proof-of-concept platform for the programmable biosynthesis of Pro-Xylane.
instructors: FanZhang, Gao Shan, JIANG SHANFENG, MENGRU CAO, Yuan Gao
advisors: GanHaisheng, Kaixuan Li, Yanxiong Wang, Yongyi Ye, Zhijie Liu

title: CASPIA
abstract: CASPIA is an intelligent, fully automated platform that transforms raw genomic data into kinetics-aware genome-scale metabolic models (GEMs), serving as digital twins of cells. It integrates genome annotation, parameter prediction, model construction, and optimization in one pipeline. CASPIA comprises four engines: GEMFactory, assembling stoichiometric models with kinetic and thermodynamic constraints; CASPred, predicting missing parameters (kcat, Topt) via a geometric vector perceptron trained on ~90k records; CASPIAgent, a natural-language-driven agent executing modeling and design tasks; and CASPIA-RAG, extracting quantitative data from literature. CASPIA upgrades GEMs to enzyme-constrained models (ecGEMs), supports flux simulation and multi-scale optimization (FBA, PFBA, FVA, OptKnock, FSEOF), and enables deep mutational scanning. Validated on Saccharopolyspora spinosa, it autonomously designs gene knockouts, overexpression, and enzyme mutations. A public web server allows asynchronous task submission, making high-fidelity metabolic modeling widely accessible.
students: Eryu Peng, Haonan Huang, Haoran Wu, Jiayi Lang, Jilai Cheng, Jingyuan Gao, Peining Chen, Rongpeng Zhu, Sile Chen, Wang Ru, WX.Li, Xiran Wang, Yuexuan Li, Yuxuan Li, Zhe Gao, Zhiyu Zhang, ZhuoNi, ZiYuan Yin

title: AD-TMA Brain-Gut Axis Engineered Yeast Therapy: Neuroinflammation Regulation Based on TAAR5 Receptor
abstract: Conventional therapies for Alzheimer's Disease (AD) show limited clinical efficacy. Emerging evidence suggests neuroinflammation driven by the primary genetic risk factor, APOE4, is more fundamental. In this study, an active engineered living therapy (ELT) targeting neuroinflammation was systematically designed through the gut-brain axis system. We engineered Saccharomyces cerevisiae for intelligent AD prevention and early intervention. The system's core is a high-specificity AND-gate sensor that identifies two biomarkers in the intestines of early-stage AD patients (including MCI): reactive oxygen species (ROS) and trimethylamine (TMA), then activates a five-enzyme butyrate synthesis pathway comprising four heterologous enzymes. To ensure long-term safety, a pro-apoptotic protein Bax based elimination mechanism is integrated as well. Finally, we integrated multi-scale computational models to systematically evaluate the design's credibility, feasibility and therapeutic efficacy in silico. This sense-compute-actuate design philosophy promises to be a platform technology applicable to an innovative prophylactic and therapeutic AD strategy and other disorders.
advisors: junru chen, Yijun Gu
students: ckr, FSY, Geng Jiayao, Gu Weihao, hejh, Jiayi Zhang, Jinqiao Song, JinZQ, nanyili, NKU-Deng Yanzhuo, Ricky Wang, Roy, ST Cai, Xuanwen jin, yujiawen, Zhaoyi Liu, Zheng Shizhao (Ary), Zixuan, zn

title: BCoated
abstract: Agriculture is changing fast, and farmers everywhere are feeling the heat. Every crop faces different issues, from abiotic stressors like drought to biotic stressors such as pests. Traditional breeding for resilience takes years; a quicker solution is needed. Seed coatings are commonly used for uniform seed size, germination, and delivery of active compounds, but they could reduce the severity of many more problems. Therefore, we developed a modular material without microplastics to create a platform for all seed coating applications. Desired properties can be selected before production, such as altered water holding capacity or biodegradability, but also added active components or proteins. During fermentation, the functionalised bacterial cellulose (BC) is made, which can be applied directly to seeds. This way, BCoated is creating a fast, farmer-friendly support for crops: Customizable bacterial cellulose (BC) coatings that protect seeds and boost resilience, tailored to meet the challenges of today's and tomorrow's fields.
awards: Top 10+Best Biomanufacturing Project+Best Entrepreneurship+Best Integrated Human Practices
nominations: Best Part Collection, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
PIs: Robert Smith, Enrique Asin-Garcia, Nico J Claassens

students: Andra Stoica, Camile van Harmelen, Daan van den Bor, Iris Gormezano, Jochem Feith, Niels van de Sande, Rick Markus, Thapasvi Anirudhan Hriteesh Puvvada, Tifara Elaine Trisna, Varsha Saravanan, Yoerik van den Bergh

title: StrawTopia - A value-adding solution converting agricultural straws into fashionable textile
abstract: Straw, the dry stalks of cereal crops left after harvest, represents a massive global agricultural by-product with approximately 5.3 billion tons generated annually worldwide. 2025 LINKS-China has developed an integrated chemical and enzymatic process to extract high-purity cellulose from straw. We employed Pichia pastoris to express enzymes-- Laccase, VP and LPMO--and utilized a yeast surface displayed protein-scaffold enabling synergistic enzymatic action for degradation of hemicellulose and lignin. We successfully produced Lyocell fibers from extracted corn straw cellulose. We engineered two recombinant proteins: HBP from squid beak and EV1 from bagworm silk?for fiber enhancing. The fiber with EV1 protein achieved a remarkable tensile strength of 2.56 cN/dtex, meeting the requirements for textile applications. Through comprehensive interviews with farmers, textile industry professionals, and fashion designers, we have developed a complete business plan. We envision that these vegan, sustainable, and biodegradable fibers will pioneer a green revolution.
nominations: Best Part Collection, High School+Best Entrepreneurship, High School
advisors: Chelsea.liu, Tinac Xing, Wanyang (Sarah) Huang, xiongqian, Yuhan Gan, ZHAMAN
student leaders: Bonica Lee, Duan Xinhe, Linda Qi, Naomi Zhang, Yueran, shi
students: Alice, Alina Liao, Amber, Emma Huang, Jack Pang, Jade, Jeffrey, Jerry Lau, JIANG?JINLIANG, Lily Lai, Lily Luo, Liyuan Zhang, Randolph, Siruichen, Zhangjiaquan, Zhang Zixia

title: HullGuard: An Eco-friendly Antifouling Solution with Biosynthetic Zosteric Acid
abstract: Biofouling--the unwanted accumulation of marine organisms on ship hulls--reduces fuel efficiency, increases CO? emissions, and accelerates corrosion. Conventional antifouling paints, mainly copper- or organotin-based, release persistent toxins into seawater, harming marine ecosystems. HullGuard, developed by AIS-China 2025, provides a sustainable biological alternative through microbial biosynthesis of Zosteric Acid (ZA), a natural, non-toxic antifouling compound. Using metabolic engineering, enzyme optimization, and fusion-protein design, we enhanced the catalytic efficiency of key enzymes (TAL and SULT1A1) to boost ZA yield. Rationally engineered mutants and flexible linkers led to a notable improvement over the wild type. Through field research, industrial collaboration, and policy engagement, we ensured environmental feasibility and industrial scalability. HullGuard showcases how synthetic biology can replace toxic marine coatings, advancing sustainable industry and cleaner oceans.
awards: Top 10+Best Village Project+Best New Improved Part+Best Sustainable Development Impact
nominations: Best Model, High School
advisors: Henry Wang, Yuhan Gan
student leaders: Alisa Tan, Jaycee, JJ, Li Chengxi, Paisley Huo, Qiyou, Victoria Lin, william wu, Zoe Yang
students: Alex, Angel Li, Eric, Gavin, Hugo Zhang, Ivy, Judy, kenny, Mia Niu, Shingcho Yip, SHU.MIAO, Zhaohaoyu, Zhao YiZhuo

title: HERO
abstract: Our project involves the design of HERO (High-Performance Engineered Rhodococcus Opacus), an engineered Rhodococcus opacus PD630 strain designed as an advanced chassis for bioremediation applications. Specifically, we designed a genomic Cre/LoxP-based system for a precise, safe genes integration. In addition, we expanded both the wet lab and dry lab tools available for this organism, enabling more efficient genome manipulation and metabolic engineering for pollutant degradation. More precisely, we have developed a library of characterized promoters for controlled gene expression. To support its practical application, we created two complementary platforms: a rapid colorimetric biosensor for quantifying triacylglycerol accumulation, which is a key indicator of R. opacus growth and metabolic activity, and a computational tool for predicting optimal metabolic pathways and identifying candidate genes for pollutant degradation. Our project aims to enable HERO to be customized and easy-to-used for diverse environmental pollutants, bridging the gap between fundamental research and real-world bioremediation solutions.
PIs: Martina Cappelletti, Andrea, Davide Roncarati, ElisaMichelini
advisors: Francesco Bonacini, Marilisa Cortesi, Pietro, Stefano Bertacchi
students: Alice, Andrea Polazzi, Arianna, Egle, Giacomo Balducci, Giulia, Greta, Iolanda testa, Irene, Michele Babini, Samuele Biguzzi

title: Developing Scalable Perchlorate Removal in Martian Regolith via a Novel Microbial Coculture and ARC Bioreactor
abstract: Martian soil is rich in perchlorates, a molecule found to be toxic to both plant growth and human homeostasis. This compound serves as a significant barrier to Mars exploration and long-term colonization. Team Cornell proposes PRoSPER, Planetary Removal of Soil Perchlorates and Enrichment Remediation, as a means of establishing future Martian settlements through bioremediation and traditional agricultural development. PRoSPER utilizes a microbial coculture of E. coli with a genetically engineered perchlorate reductase pathway, and Synechococcus sp. PCC 7002 to uptake the resulting chloride byproducts. This coculture will be housed in a novel Adaptive Reaction Chamber bioreactor family that is easily adjusted to optimal growing conditions. PRoSPER improves the viability of Martian settlement by not only removing a key obstacle to plant growth but also encouraging a dual-market strategy approach that can be used to advance the future of space exploration.
advisors: Isaac Chang, Jatin A. Mukerji, Michael Constant, Rachel Cannata

title: Phasea: recombinant antifungal peptides encapsulated in chitosan microparticles for next-generation biofungicides
abstract: Plant diseases caused by fungi threaten global food security, causing severe yield losses and dependence on chemical fungicides that harm the environment and human health. Anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum genus, exemplifies this problem. Despite advances, sustainable and precise disease management tools remain limited. Phasea addresses this challenge through a next-generation biofungicide that combines recombinant antifungal peptides with chitosan-based microparticles for controlled, prolonged release. Its formulation integrates the synergistic action of CaLTP1 + PDF1.2 and PvPGIP2, engineered for broad antifungal activity, while biodegradable chitosan ensures protection, stability, and gradual delivery in crops. To optimize formulation, we developed a mathematical model coupling peptide release kinetics with fungal inhibition dynamics, enabling data-driven design and predictive testing. Beyond the lab, Phasea integrates a sustainability-oriented business model targeting distributors and farmers. Together, Phasea unites synthetic biology, human practices, and entrepreneurship to foster safer and more resilient crop protection.
PIs: Cynthia Lizeth Gonzalez Trevizo, Dana Gomez

title: RESPIRA: Responsive Engineered Strain for Polymicrobial Infection Recovery in Airways
abstract: Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) arises when antibiotic-resistant bacteria form biofilms on endotracheal tubes, shielding pathogens from treatment. RESPIRA is a Bacillus subtilis-based living therapeutic engineered to detect and dismantle these biofilms at their source. Triggered by pathogen quorum-sensing signals, RESPIRA activates a synthetic gene circuit that drives secretion of enzymes to degrade the biofilm matrix, restoring bacterial susceptibility to antibiotics and immune attack. Our team integrated wet lab, modeling, and ethical design. We assembled quorum-sensing circuits, optimized B. subtilis transformation, and built clearFoam, an open-source reaction-diffusion simulator linking gene-circuit activation to biofilm degradation and BioBrick parameters. Sensitivity analysis and experimental diffusion data validated this framework. Guided by clinicians and ethicists through a responsible research framework, we prioritized receptor-based circuit feedback, gel delivery, and biocontainment. Together, these innovations make RESPIRA a programmable, safe, and clinically informed therapy that converts biofilm infections from persistent to treatable.
nominations: Best Software Tool, Undergrad
advisors: Melanie
students: Aidan Baydush, Arya Krishniah, Ashi Jain, Cierra Min, Daliya Rizvi, Jennifer An, Kay Lyon, Nicolas A. Zepeda, Norah Shen, Rohit Suresh, Sean Gao, Sriya Sridhar

title: LacThera - Lactobacillus therapy.
abstract: The vaginal microbiome is crucial for reproductive health, mainly dominated by Lactobacillus spp., which protects against pathogens by producing antimicrobial compounds. Disruption of this balance can lead to infections like UTIs. And 30% of women with UTIs experience recurrent infections. While antibiotics are the main treatment, resistance and microbiome disruption limit their effectiveness and don't address the problem of recurrent UTIs. Probiotics using Lactobacillus strains can help restore balance, but often struggle against pathogens. We chose to augment Lactobacillus crispatus with peptide inhibitors that target pathogen adhesion mechanisms, helping prevent colonization.
advisors: Camille Prefontaine, Jessica Marinelli, Kartik Sachar, Kevin Lim, Oliver Peters, Reid Homik

title: Construction of a chitinase expression genetic system and its application in biomass resource degradation
abstract: Chitinases, which catalyze the degradation of chitin, have the ability to degrade fungal cell walls and insect exoskeletons and produce N-acetylglucosamine oligomers or monomers. Therefore, they play an important role. In this project, we screened three chitinases and chitin deacetylases from microbial sources. We then constructed a genetic system expressing chitinases by recombining the in vitro synthesized genes into plasmids and expressing them in Escherichia coli. By testing chitin expression and enzyme activity, as well as the optimal reaction conditions for enzyme activity, we optimized the constructed E. coli genetic system and adjusted the expression conditions to increase chitinase production and activity. By degrading these chitin wastes, chitin can be recovered into valuable products such as amino acids, calcium lactate, and high-purity chitin, thereby improving the utilization of biomass energy. Furthermore, we combined chitin exonucleases or endonucleases with chitin deacetylases to explore the synergistic effect of enzymes on chitin degradation.
advisors: Antonio, KUANZHI LI, LANXIN CUI, PAN XIWEN, Quorra Li, WANG ZIMING, XU JIAHE, ZHANG GUOZHONG

title: A CRISPR/Cas9-based knockout of TEAD4 enhances breast cancer therapy
abstract: Breast cancer remains one of the most prevalent cancers and a leading cause of cancer-related deaths among women worldwide. The Hippo signaling pathway, which includes key components such as large tumor-associated kinases, and the transcriptional coactivators Yes-associated protein (YAP) and TEAD4, plays a critical role in regulating cell growth. Recent studies have identified TEAD4 as a crucial player in breast cancer development. In our research, we utilized the CRISPR-Cas9 system to design specific single guide RNAs (sgRNAs) that target and knock out TEAD4 in breast cancer cells. This genetic manipulation showed promising results in inhibiting cell proliferation, migration, and invasion. Furthermore, our bioinformatics analysis reinforced the critical role of TEAD4 in tumorigenesis.

title: Mars Farm: Sowing New Hope in Adversity
abstract: With the advancement of space technology, human migration to Mars may become a reality in the near future. However, the extreme dryness and temperature conditions on the Martian surface make it impossible for Earth's crops to grow normally, jeopardizing human survival. To address this challenge, the WUXI-DSAS team has proposed a solution: endowing plants with tolerance to the Martian environment. By integrating genes with various stress-resistant functions into plants, their ability to withstand extreme conditions is enhanced, thereby reducing the energy and water consumption of plant greenhouses. Ultimately, this could enable plants to be directly cultivated on the Martian surface. Additionally, this technology can be applied to crop cultivation under extreme conditions on Earth. We firmly believe that one day, we will sow seeds of hope on the surface of Mars.
advisors: Xianfu Zeng

title: ProbiEase: AI Platform of Probiotia Design for Diseases
abstract: Probiotics hold clear therapeutic promise, yet the evidence base is fragmented and hard to query; single-strain approaches also suffer from weak in vivo colonization and limited robustness, undermining durable efficacy. We therefore move from single strains to rationally designed consortia, empowered by synthetic biology. To enable data-driven decisions, we curated literature and clinical data and built ProbiEase, a platform that integrates a knowledge graph, strain search, and an AI chat interface to generate traceable, citable candidates. We then conduct a second-stage triage via metabolic modeling, evaluating coexistence and cross-interaction potential to derive synergistic strain sets. Using Parkinson's disease as a case study, we showcase an end-to-end workflow--evidence aggregation ? platform prioritization ? modeling-based vetting--and, targeting PD-specific needs, propose intranasal nose-to-brain delivery of an engineered probiotic consortium with a modular design spanning adhesion, therapy, control, and safety.

title: Syn-Sweet Tech
abstract: Confronted with the increasingly severe issues of obesity and metabolic diseases in China, as well as the limitations of traditional artificial/natural sweeteners in terms of safety, tolerance, and functionality, this project aims to employ synthetic biology techniques to construct highly efficient E. coli engineering strains for the expression of ?-agarase (AgaE) and endo-inulinase (Inulinase), respectively. By optimizing expression conditions and fermentation processes, the soluble expression of these two enzymes will be achieved efficiently. Subsequently, a green biomanufacturing process will be established for the large-scale production of novel functional sweeteners--agaro-oligosaccharides (AOS) and fructo-oligosaccharides (FOS)--which exhibit both a low glycemic index (GI) and significant prebiotic properties. This technological approach is designed to fundamentally address the health controversies and application challenges associated with existing sweetener products, offering the food industry a safer, more efficient, and cost-effective healthy sweetening solution.

title: Improve Cyclic Lipopeptide Production through Random and Rational Mutagenesis
abstract: Plant diseases pose a major threat to global food security and economy. Chemical pesticides cause escalating pathogen resistance and environmental contamination. Cyclic lipopeptides (CLPs) produced by Bacillus species offer a promising and sustainable alternative. However, their large-scale application remains limited due to the low production titers of native strains. In this project, we engineered Bacillus velezensis through an integrated synthetic biology pipeline. ARTP mutagenesis and high-throughput screening were used to isolate high-yield mutants. Key gene mutations were identified and reconstructed in the wild-type strain. A dual-gRNA system was designed to efficiently delete long gene fragments. Furthermore, a computational protocol was designed for NRPS communication (COM) domains prediction and used to direct gene cluster mutagenesis. Overall, our work establishes a modular engineering framework for optimizing and innovating CLP-based biopesticides, offering effective and sustainable solutions for crop protection and contributing a versatile genetic toolkit to the synthetic biology community.
PIs: Sen Liu (Sam), Aron, Juanping Wang, Sean

title: Caseinova - Biocompatible Matrix for Burn Wound Healing
abstract: Burn injuries affect over 10 million people annually, often resulting in infection, scarring, and long-term disability. Existing treatments - silver-based creams, conventional dressings, and biological materials - each have limitations in infection control, biocompatibility, and regenerative support. To address these challenges, we are developing biocompatible, multifunctional wound-healing system integrating structural, protective, and antimicrobial functions. The system combines an electrospun recombinant casein-propolis scaffold that mimics the extracellular matrix and supports tissue regeneration with a casein-hyaluronic acid hydrogel layer loaded with bacteriophages for targeted antibacterial action. This dual-component design maintains a moist environment, prevents infection without antibiotics, and promotes natural tissue repair. By merging regenerative biomaterials with specific and broad-spectrum antimicrobial mechanisms, our approach offers a patient-centered, cost-effective alternative to conventional burn care - minimizing pain, reducing dressing changes, and mitigating antimicrobial resistance risks.

title: Textile Fighters - An Integrated Enzymatic Route to Degrade PET in Textiles
abstract: Our project aims to address the recycling challenge of PET in textiles through enzymatic degradation. We engineered the recombinant enzyme Thermobifida fusca cutinase (TfCut2), expressed in Escherichia coli BL21. Guided by rational mutagenesis and machine learning approaches, we engineered and evaluated six TfCut2 variants with the potential for enhanced degradation performance compared to the wildtype. To improve accessibility of the textile substrate, we apply mechanical disintegration and chemical pre-treatment, followed by enzymatic treatment using cellulases for the cotton fraction and TfCut2 variants for PET. Ultimately, the process seeks to degrade blended textiles into the monomer terephthalic acid (TPA), which can then be repolymerized into PET textiles, enabling closed-loop recycling for sustainable management.

title: ROBIN----Rhizobium Orientation and Biological Inhibition of Nematode
abstract: In leguminous crops, root-knot nematodes and rhizobia interact competitively and cooperatively: nematodes damage roots to reduce rhizobial nodulation, while nodules alter root structure to aid nematode entry. Our project aims to promote rhizobial colonization and expel nematodes. We constructed a luteolin de novo biosynthetic pathway in engineered Bacillus subtilis, and screened soil-derived mild phages to regulate luteolin synthesis and programmed cell death of the bacterium via the cre-loxp system. For nematodes, salicylic acid (released when roots are damaged) acts as a switch to trigger the bacterium to express cry5-cry6 fusion protein, whose insecticidal effect was validated in Caenorhabditis elegans survival assays.

title: LACMA?Lactate-responsive Module and Application
abstract: Our project addresses the lactate-rich tumor microenvironment by engineering a lactate-responsive module that enables immune cells(e.g., CAR-T cells in Car-T therapy) to secrete lactate oxidase (sLOx) and reduce excess lactate. To build this module, a lactate sensing protein is split to two fragments, which are fused to the N-terminal and C-terminal fragments of TEV-protease, respectively. High lactate induces TEV-protease reconstitution, which then cleaves a GV-2ER fusion protein to release the transcription factor GV (Gal4-VP64). GV enters the nucleus and activates sLOx expression, lowering lactate concentration and enhancing immune cell anti-tumor efficacy.
PIs: Jia-Da Li, Chi-Yu Li, Huadie Liu, Jingping Hu, Ye Liang

title: Engineering Heat-Tolerant Algae to Address Global Warming
abstract: Global warming is becoming an increasingly serious problem, primarily due to the massive emission of greenhouse gases, especially carbon dioxide, resulting from human activities. Microalgae, as photosynthetic aquatic organisms, hold significant potential for carbon dioxide fixation. However, the rising prevalence of high temperatures associated with global warming poses a serious threat to the survival of many plants and crops, including microalgae. To address this challenge, we are overexpressing the endogenous gene CPN60C in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. CPN60C is a mitochondrial galactose-binding protein that enables Chlamydomonas reinhardtii to survive and maintain photosynthesis under heat stress. In this project, we transformed Chlamydomonas reinhardtii with the plasmids containing CPN60C, generating transgenic strains that overexpress the gene. This enhanced their ability to withstand high temperatures and photosynthesize efficiently. Our long-term goal is to develop heat-tolerant algae capable of surviving elevated temperatures and fixing carbon dioxide efficiently, thereby providing a practical approach to mitigating global warming.
advisors: Dr. Amber, Wenjing
students: Alina LI, Angel, Evan, fanny, Jaelyn, Joy Zhang, Lihao zhu, Mona, Simon he, Tianyou Dong, Zhengqin Chen, ???

title: Engineered Biocatalytic Platform for Sustainable Textile Dyeing
abstract: The textile dyeing industry relies heavily on synthetic dyes, which generate toxic effluents and pose serious environmental and health risks. While bio-enzymatic dyes represent a sustainable alternative, their industrial use has been limited by unstable color output and narrow chromatic range. Inspired by the ecological tradition of Xiangyunsha silk dyeing, we developed an innovative biocatalytic platform based on a engineered fusion of tyrosinase and a self-assembling scaffold protein. This system forms reusable enzymatic "nanofactories" that convert tyrosine derivatives into non-toxic, melanin-inspired pigments, yielding a broad spectrum of colors from browns to reds. The immobilized enzyme demonstrates excellent operational stability over multiple cycles, drastically cutting water consumption and eliminating the need for heavy metal mordants. By merging synthetic biology with green chemistry, EnzColor offers a scalable, eco-friendly, and ethical pathway toward a circular textile economy.
advisors: Danfeng Zhang, Xianfu Zeng
students: Bojan, Caroline, Cathy, Christina, Elaine, Harry, Hikari, Lesley, Michelle, Nefert, Weihang Lu

title: Construction and Application of Red Light Induced Nanobody Production System
abstract: Cancer has emerged as a global public health challenge. In recent years, nanobodies have garnered significant attention in anti-tumor therapy due to their high affinity, low immunogenicity, and excellent tissue penetration. While commonly used production systems include mammalian cell and yeast expression platforms, they remain costly and intricate. Consequently, developing a safe, controllable, and efficient antibody production system is crucial for advancing tumor therapeutics. This study aims to develop an efficient and controllable nanobody production platform utilizing a red light-induced gene expression system in Escherichia coli. By integrating red light-mediated gene regulation technology with the robust protein production capacity of E. coli, we will achieve precise control over nanobody expression. This system will enable real-time regulation via red light signals, reducing production-associated side effects and energy consumption, while significantly enhancing the efficiency and quality of nanobody production.

title: Helicobacter pylori Nanobody Therapy
abstract: Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection can lead to severe health complications. Current treatments primarily rely on antibiotics, but increasing resistance due to overuse has resulted in frequent therapeutic failures, potentially progressing to more serious conditions. Urease is a critical factor for H. pylori colonization and pathogenicity in the stomach, making its inhibition essential for reducing infection risks. This study focuses on constructing a gene expression system for recombinant nanobodies targeting the H. pylori urease subunit (UreB) and exploring their production in food-grade probiotic bacteria. By delivering these nanobodies via live probiotics, the approach aims to achieve direct and precise prevention and control of H. pylori infection. The research establishes a solid foundation for developing immune-based therapies against H. pylori, demonstrating significant innovation and application potential.

title: Four-in-one Dual-signal Amplification Nanoflower - Smartphone-powered Ultra-sensitive Detection of Bacteria
abstract: We plan to develop a special "nanoflower" capable of rapidly and accurately detecting bacteria. This nanoflower has two key functions: first, it uses "phage tail fiber proteins" to precisely bind to bacteria; second, its interior contains peroxidase, enabling a colorimetric reaction. The large specific surface area of the nanoflower and the gold-platinum nanoparticles amplifies the signal, making the detection result more pronounced. Afterwards, a dedicated mobile app can scan the colorimetric result and analyze the RGB values to directly determine the presence of bacteria.

title: Microbial Detection and Remediation of Hexavalent Chromium
abstract: We aim to design a biosensor for detecting hexavalent chromium (Cr) using synthetic biology techniques, while utilizing soluble flavoprotein ChrR and YieF to achieve effective reduction of hexavalent Cr in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3); A biosensor based on the pigment protein AmilCP is used to detect the presence of hexavalent Cr, and the concentration of reduced hexavalent Cr is determined using the diphenylcarbazide spectrophotometric method; By employing a safe microbial method, this approach achieves a more efficient, convenient, and environmentally friendly mitigation of hexavalent Cr toxicity.
nominations: Best Part Collection, High School+Best Education, High School+Best Presentation, High School+Best Village Project, High School

title: Research on the Application of Mussel Adhesive Proteins in Antibacterial Coatings for Medical Devices
abstract: Mussel foot proteins (Mfps) are a class of proteins secreted by mussel byssus, featuring exceptional underwater adhesion, waterproofness, toughness, and durability. They exhibit great application potential in fields such as biomedicine, cosmetics, and medical coatings. However, the current production of Mfps mainly relies on direct extraction from mussels, a process that is costly, inefficient, and unable to meet the demand for high yield and consistent quality. To overcome this bottleneck, the present study aims to explore the use of Escherichia coli as a biosynthetic platform for the efficient production of Mfps through a heterologous expression strategy. Furthermore, by applying sequence-based molecular design, we seek to construct functional fusion proteins with strong adhesiveness, enhanced antibacterial activity, and good biocompatibility for the preparation of antimicrobial coatings for medical devices.

title: Using SELEX technology to screen targeted molecular probes for detecting brain-derived tau protein
abstract: Alzheimer's Disease (AD) poses a global challenge with over 56 million affected, yet early detection remains limited by invasive or costly methods. Our project combines synthetic biology and CRISPR-Cas12a technology: using SELEX to screen DNA aptamers specifically targeting BD-Tau, a key AD biomarker, and coupling this with CRISPR's trans-cleavage activity for sensitive, low-cost detection. This approach enables non-invasive, precise early AD screening, aiming to improve diagnostic accessibility and patient outcomes.

title: Parkinson's disease treatment - new probiotic therapy
abstract: Current treatments for Parkinson's Disease primarily rely on levodopa (L-DOPA), a dopamine precursor, to alleviate symptoms. However, traditional L-DOPA synthesis methods, including chemical methods and plant extraction, are inefficient and environmentally unsustainable. Microbial biosynthesis has emerged as a promising alternative, although its efficiency is limited by the conversion of chorismate to L-tyrosine. This study aimed to enhance L-DOPA production by optimizing the expression of the tyrA gene in Escherichia coli and screening different RBS. Furthermore, given that gastrointestinal symptoms are a common side effect of L-DOPA, constructing a probiotic strain capable of efficiently expressing L-DOPA could not only mitigate side effects by modulating the gut microbiome, but also achieve the goal of treating and alleviating Parkinson's symptoms through continuous drug release.

title: Production of 3'-Sialyllactose (3'-SL) Using Soy Whey
abstract: Based on synthetic biology principles, this project aims to construct an E. coli that uses low-cost soy whey as a fermentation medium and leverages the natural galactose in soy whey to achieve an auto-induction expression system. The experiment is mainly divided into the following three parts. First of all, at present, E.coli can't use carbohydrates (such as sucrose and stachyose) in soy whey as carbon sources, which makes it difficult to use this rich food industry by-product as fermentation medium. Secondly, we want to construct a self-induced protein expression system. Based on this system, bacteria can directly use galactose in the culture medium as an inducer, thus spontaneously inducing the expression of downstream proteins. Finally, we need to transfer the synthesis module of 3'-SL into plasmid, so that bacteria can synthesize 3'-SL protein in soy whey.
instructors: duan rong rong, Xiudong XIA, Zhe Wang

title: Production of Natural Food Preservatives Containing Lysozyme and Antimicrobial Peptides Using Synthetic Biology
abstract: With the continuous growth of the global population, food safety has gradually become a key concern worldwide. The development of natural, green, and non-toxic preservatives has emerged as a crucial trend in the food industry. Lysozyme and antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), as natural antibacterial components, have become research hotspots in food preservation due to their excellent antimicrobial properties and high safety profile. Lysozyme functions by catalyzing the hydrolysis of glycosidic bonds in bacterial cell walls, primarily targeting Gram-positive bacteria. Antimicrobial peptides, on the other hand, disrupt bacterial cell membrane structures, inhibiting pathogen growth with broad-spectrum antibacterial activity.This study aims to explore the combined preservative effects of lysozyme and antimicrobial peptides in food applications. The goal is to develop a green, safe, and natural food preservation technology.
advisors: CHEN SIRUI, JING SIHAN, SUN GAORUNZE, Wang?Yifei, Xuecheng Jiang, Zheng Xiangyi

title: Sweetness without burden
abstract: As the world places increasing emphasis on health and sugar control, sugar-free recipes have sparked a trend across major platforms. The global "SugarSmart" initiative has also been launched, leading to growing discussions and use of sugar substitutes. In our project, we employed genetic engineering techniques to develop microbial strains that produce Thaumatin, a protein-based sweetener. Thaumatin is a natural sweet-tasting protein--a low-calorie, plant-derived sweetener--meaning this technology holds promise for alleviating health issues caused by sugar consumption. Through experiments, we tested the protein's activity under various conditions, thereby validating the feasibility of applying this technology in practice. In the future, our project could be developed into sugar-reducing food products to help people maintain better health.
nominations: Best Entrepreneurship, High School
students: CHE KAIYUE, HUANG YUNNI, KANG QINHAO, LI XINYANG, PAN YANXI, WANG YOUJIE, WANG ZIBING, WU WENRAN, WU XINKE, XU YIHAN, ZHANG FENGSHANG, ZHOU YUANRUI, ZIQI CHEN

title: Bio?based carbon capture reactor - Dancing JJ
abstract: We developed a bio-based carbon capture reactor using Emiliania huxleyi to enhance CO? fixation through synthetic genetic constructs and audio stimulation. Three gene vectors, DGA1 for biofuel synthesis and NCE103, CA9 for biomineralization for bio-concrete, were expressed and validated in yeast kluyveromyces marxianus. A smart photobioreactor was engineered with an ESP32 microcontroller, integrating temperature regulation, timed illumination, turbidity/thermal monitoring, audio stimulation, and cloud-based data logging. Beyond laboratory validation, the team assessed potential industrial applications via carbon credit modeling aligned with SDGs and developed an educational board game to promote public understanding of carbon trading. This multidisciplinary platform demonstrates a novel integration of synthetic biology, digital systems, and socio-economic tools for scalable carbon capture and sustainability education.
instructors: Hunt Hung, Leeven Chang, Mark, Nico, Rick, Victoria
advisors: Anderson Chao
student leaders: Alex, Kyle C, Luke Chang, Rachel, Vincent Kang

title: Microorganisms produce degradable PHA particles
abstract: The plastic microbeads widely used in cosmetics have difficulty in degradation and continuously exacerbate the pollution of microplastics in the ocean, posing a serious threat to the ecosystem and human health. Polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA), as a biodegradable material, have potential for substitution, but their poor controllability of particle morphology and high production costs limit their practical application. This project utilizes synthetic biology technology to design programmable and controllable engineered strains, developing environmentally friendly PHA-based microbeads as alternatives, aiming to provide sustainable solutions for the cosmetics industry and exploring innovative paths for biomanufacturing technology in pollution control.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School+Best Village Project, High School

title: Immunotherapy specific for allergies to pollen, dust mites and seafood
abstract: Allergic reactions are becoming an increasingly serious public health issue worldwide, especially in Guangdong. The incidence of allergic diseases is continuously rising, which not only affects the quality of life of patients but also imposes a burden on the medical system. Polyvalent vaccines are an important direction for future vaccine research and development. They have significant advantages in enhancing immune efficacy, reducing the number of vaccinations, increasing vaccine coverage, and reducing costs. This project, based on genetic engineering and nanotechnology, combines allergic immunotherapy to develop polyvalent vaccines, aiming to reshape the body's immune system and improve the body's immune tolerance to allergens.
advisors: DU ER, JIN ZIYUE, TONG DING

title: Bioinformatics-Driven Optimization of Plastic-Degrading Enzyme Activity
abstract: Plastic pollution has become a global environmental challenge, yet existing plastic degradation technologies suffer from low efficiency and are difficult to scale up. To address this issue, this project aims to screen and engineer high-efficiency plastic-degrading enzymes from microbial sources, construct optimized enzyme genes using synthetic biology approaches, and validate their practical effectiveness in plastic degradation. Through large-scale screening of microbial plastic-degrading enzymes, combined with bioinformatics and gene optimization strategies, this research seeks to enhance degradation efficiency and provide novel approaches for the bioremediation of plastic pollution.
nominations: Best Part Collection, High School

title: Algalith
abstract: This project aimed to engineer a self-flocculating strain of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii to enable cost-effective, chemical-free algae harvesting by expressing the bacterial adhesion pair Z17/Z18 and the yeast flocculation protein FLO1 under a salt-inducible promoter. Throughout the project, E. coli and C. reinhardtii were used as model organisms to evaluate different flocculation systems, including FLO1, Z17/Z18, and the endogenous adhesion pair FUS1/MAR1. Although the FLO1 construct assembly was hindered by repetitive sequence regions, the Z17 protein was successfully expressed and purified in E. coli. Expression of Z18 and cloning of the GP1 anchoring protein were not achieved due to sequence complexity. In parallel, electroporation parameters for C. reinhardtii transformation were optimized, and a flocculation assay was established to assess aggregation efficiency, providing a foundation for future development of auto-flocculating microalgae strains for sustainable biotechnology.
students: Ahmed, Alva Sjöström, Arina Vakhrameeva, Ebba Ganslandt, Eloïse Chafer, Esther Melvine Nginyu, Linn Herman, Matthew Redmayne, Oskar Brännholm, Sefora Gebrekidan, Sofija Gabrilaviciute, Tomas Estvall

title: Redefining Fatigue: Synthetic Biology Captures Sports Science Signals in Sweat
abstract: As more people pursue fitness to improve their health, the lack of scientific training guidance remains common. Without real-time feedback, many unknowingly overtrain, increasing the risk of injury. Lactate--a key marker of fatigue, training intensity, and anaerobic metabolism--is still mainly detected through costly instruments and invasive blood sampling, limiting its everyday use. To solve this, we developed a synthetic biology-based biosensor using engineered E. coli to express lactate oxidase, enabling detection of lactate in sweat through either a visible color change or an electrochemical signal. Our goal is to make scientific, precise training accessible to everyone. Whether for beginners or professional athletes, our sensor provides real-time insights into physical status, supporting smarter workouts and healthier progress.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Siqi Yang, Yaoyao Liang
