title: TardiGuard: Tardigrade-Powered Solutions for Better Cell Storage and Transportation
abstract: Tardigrades can survive harsh conditions by entering cryptobiosis under protection of several proteins, which we found has the potential to improve current cell storage and transportation methods. Inspired by it, we designed a project to improve cells storage and transportation in biotech programs by introducing these proteins through Bac-to-Bac system. Through DNA-electrophoresis, qPCR, Western-Blotting and phenotypic tests, we confirmed that these proteins could effectively protect cells and improve viability, suggesting that tardigrade-derived proteins offer a potential solution of better and cheaper cell storage and transportation. Based on such results, we designed a prototype for commercialization. Then, we summarized demands through lab interviews and investigation, which guided us to improve our prototype and develop marketing strategies. Beyond commercial practices, we also explored the project's educational potential. We promoted our project on social media to spark public interest and designed tardigrade-featured gifts and interactions to reach researchers and the public.

title: CaroteneCraft: Synthetic Biology for Vision Protection
abstract: The World Health Organization reports that at least 1 billion of the 2.2 billion people with vision impairment have preventable or unaddressed conditions. Visual health problems such as dry eyes, night blindness, and myopia are increasingly prevalent, particularly in East Asia. To address this, we engineered Saccharomyces cerevisiae to biosynthesize ?-carotene de novo using CRISPR-Cas9, achieving a titer of 128.1 mg/L. Through spatial metabolic engineering, we localized carB and carRP to lipid droplets, increasing production to 318.4 mg/L. A color-based monitoring hardware enabled automated process control, and 5-L bioreactor optimization further elevated yield to 1.8 g/L. Guided by human practices, we engaged over 30 stakeholders across research and industry. Through education initiatives featuring AI-powered content, games, and community programs, we reached more than 30,000 participants. To commercialize, we created POCO, a youth-oriented personal care brand that transforms our synthetic biology achievements into a scalable and sustainable solution for vision health.
PIs: Ronnie Huang, Jing Zhou, Rui Guo
student leaders: Chen Si, David Yu, Tianyu Zhong
students: Bowen Chang, Coco Luan, Damien Hsieh, Daoke Zhou, Eric Lu, Hongming Chen, Jackey Zhang, Jingen Wang, Junye Wang, Kip Shao, Peiyang Wang, Sizhe Liao, Tianyue Zhang, Yong Ding, Zirui Lu

title: ALSense
abstract: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) remains one of the most urgent challenges in neurology, with no curative treatment and an average diagnostic delay of <12 months that severely limits therapeutic opportunities. ALSense aims to change this paradigm through a synthetic biology-based biosensor capable of detecting ALS-specific biomarkers from a small blood sample. The system combines neurofilaments, which reflect axonal injury, with cryptic peptides derived from TDP-43 dysfunction, a molecular hallmark of ALS. This dual-biomarker strategy provides a rapid, minimally invasive, and affordable diagnostic tool that can support early detection--potentially even before symptom onset. Beyond diagnosis, ALSense enables disease monitoring, accelerates clinical trial enrollment, and reduces the economic burden of late-stage care. By uniting innovation, accessibility, and clinical need, ALSense reimagines ALS diagnosis as a precise and scalable solution with potential expansion to other neurodegenerative disease. ALSense seeks to give patients and families what medicine still cannot: more time, options, and hope.
students: Andrea Fuentes, Andreu Boix, Claudia Fernandez, Julianna, Lucia Badenas, Mariona Frigola, Martina, Mireia Cortés, Roger Solsona, Xavi Bernal

title: PFAway: the end of forever pollutants
abstract: PFAS, also known as "forever chemicals," are man-made compounds found in countless everyday products. Their remarkable resistance to heat, grease, and water comes from exceptionally strong carbon-fluorine bonds. But this stability comes at a cost: PFAS do not break down. Contamination is now global, and calls for a solution. We introduce PFAway, a real-world PFAS degradation process relying on two bacterial strains immobilized in carbon-activated beads. A newly identified strain, Labrys portucalensis F11, is first used to degrade long-chain PFAS into short-chain PFAS. Pseudomonas putida KT2240 then defluorinates short-chain PFAS through an engineered dehalogenase obtained by hypermutagenesis in E. coli. Dehalogenase variants are screened based on a fluoride biosensing aptamer implemented in droplet microfluidics. Improved dehalogenases are finally expressed in a modified P. putida that is made resistant to fluoride ions through the overexpression of the fluoride transporter FluC. This end-to-end process paves the way towards industrial-scale PFAS decontamination.
instructors: Koloina Rabemanantsoa, Laura Sierra Heras, Lucas Devlin, Stephanie Heux
students: Augustin Dufour, Candice Barroue, Emma de Antonio Gironès, Florian Jabally, Julien Ramuscello, Leïla Sobierajewicz, Marie Perrin, Morganne Piffero

title: Electricity generation using bacterial consortium to integrate microbial fuel cells into sustainable hydroponic greenhouses
abstract: The iGEM UdeS 2025 project aims to integrate a microbial fuel cell into a hydroponic system using Geobacter sulfurreducens, an electroactive bacterium capable of converting organic waste into electricity. This innovative system enables the simultaneous production of green energy and sustainable crops. Addressing today's major challenges in energy transition and food autonomy, it offers a local solution for agricultural greenhouses while also holding global potential for isolated or developing communities seeking resilient and eco-friendly technologies.
nominations: Best Presentation, Undergrad
students: Delphine, Élisabeth, Heidi, Laurie, Marc-Antoine Gauthier, Margot, Mariane Lachance, Marie-Anne Henri, Raph

title: Sustainable Use of Synthetically Produced Antibodies for Cancer Treatment
abstract: SUSPACT advances sustainable antibody production by engineering Chlamydomonas reinhardtii to express a humanized Cetuximab single-chain variable fragment (HumcetFv). The fragment retains high EGFR-binding specificity while reducing immunogenicity, offering a cost-efficient and eco-friendly alternative to mammalian expression systems. To achieve this, the team created organism-specific DNA parts optimized for Chlamydomonas codon usage, secretion, and post-translational modifications, establishing a foundation for future antibody and protein production on this platform. Valuable insight from bioreactor experiments opened up possibilities for industrial scale production volumes. Beyond research, the team actively engaged in education and outreach through workshops, school visits, public events, collaborations, and media contributions, while also developing creative learning tools like a scientific card game. Together, these efforts highlight both the technical innovation and societal impact of the project, positioning Chlamydomonas as a versatile platform for sustainable biomanufacturing.
advisors: Lea, Maximilian Messmer
students: Henry Fuchs, Julia Beck, Liza Ledzianiova, Marvin Guisl, Maximilian Braun, Mila Jacobaufderstroth, Sophie Amann, Tobi, Vanessa Vejt

title: Metlock: A Biomining Library
abstract: Metlock is a modular synthetic-biology platform for programmable zinc uptake in E. coli. It decouples the high-affinity ZnuABC transporter from Zur repression by placing a synthetic znuA/B/C operon (no Zur boxes) under an AHL-activated LuxR-pLuxR gate, letting uptake capacity be set on demand without disturbing native homeostasis. First-principles models that span promoter dynamics, translation initiation, ribosome traffic, decay, and dilution predict absolute mRNA/protein levels and map inducer-to-transporter dose responses under burden constraints. Performance is quantified with a dual-plasmid, dual-reporter scheme: one tracks pLuxR activity (GFP), while a second constitutively expresses LuxR; both are tunable via promoter, RBS, and terminator strength. Standardized parts, low-copy backbones, and optional split-plasmid configurations yield predictable, tightly gated zinc uptake for biomining, biosensing, and materials recovery. By pairing modeling with modular design, Metlock delivers an engineering-grade toolkit and calibration workflow that convert sequence choices into quantitative control of metal transport.
student leaders: Austin Thrasher, Elena Zobel, Jenna Mueller, Julian Foat, Lindsay Schneider, Lucas Navarro, Tristan Crawford

title: Remedix - Monitoring and Remediation of Pharmaceutical Contamination in Water Sources
abstract: Improper disposal of pharmaceuticals and contamination from medical and agricultural sources have resulted in rising levels of pharmaceutical pollution across diverse environments. This project aims to develop integrated biosensor and bioremediator systems to detect and mitigate pharmaceutical contaminants. We designed cost?effective biosensors using visible reporters in engineered Escherichia coli for the detection of compounds such as tetracycline and salicylate. Beyond detection, synthetic organisms were constructed to degrade these pollutants, enabling effective bioremediation. Furthermore, an AI?assisted automated system was developed to bridge the gap between biotechnology research and practical applications, enhancing the accessibility, scalability, and real?world impact of our work.
nominations: Best Hardware, High School
PIs: Wong Yan Yee, Paul Lau, Kwok Hei WONG, Ho Ho Ting, Heidi Ngai, Fan Kei Chu

title: Rock The Plastics
abstract: Microplastics are increasingly widespread. Jambeck et al. find that 5 to 12 million tons of plastic pollute the ocean annually. Plastics put into landfills degrade into microplastics that leach into the environment. These microplastics travel up the food chain, with the average person eating, drinking, or breathing between 78,000 and 211,000 microplastic particles every year. At the same time, the U.S. Geological Survey reports that 1 billion tons of limestone are quarried yearly in the United States alone. Our team addresses both of these issues by engineering E. coli to co-express plastic-binding curli fibers and a biomineralization pathway, effectively capturing microplastics in in situ limestone formations. We are using microbially induced calcite precipitation (MICP) for biomineralization, investigating a carbonic anhydrase pathway and a urease pathway. The resulting product of our engineered E. coli can immobilize microplastics while replacing non-renewable resources like sand for construction and backfilling projects.
nominations: Best Village Project, High School
advisors: Galen Kim Davis, Jenny Mae Samson, Ph.D., Wilfred Tang
students: Alexei Manuel, Alisha, Alyssa Tang, Anandita Mukherjee, Aria, Avery S. Davis, Khushi Thakkar, MeiLin Hansen, Nikhil, Paul, Rohan Vijendran, Sameer Rajdev, Sara, Shreeya, Uday, Zoya Khare, Other, Dr. Rohit Khare

title: Smart Fluorescent Probes: Bacteria 'Invent' Themself, Real-time Monitoring of NO, Blocking Cardiovascular Crisis
abstract: This study innovatively developed a novel genetically encoded NO fluorescent probe based on synthetic biology. The probe utilizes genetically engineered E. coli as a biological vector, coupling a precisely designed NO-sensing protein module with a fluorescent reporting system to achieve highly sensitive and specific real-time monitoring of nitric oxide (NO). As a crucial signaling molecule in cardiovascular diseases, this technology provides a groundbreaking dynamic monitoring approach for early diagnosis of conditions such as atherosclerosis and hypertension.Compared with traditional detection methods, this probe demonstrates significant advantages including simple operation, low cost, and capability for long-term continuous monitoring.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, High School
advisors: Grace, HM Li, Xianfu Zeng, Xiaoying, Yun YIN
student leaders: Kate, KEXIN LIU, Motong Chen, Stephen, Yimiao Cai
students: Alistair, Brandon, cathy, Chris, Eleven, Nina, Penghan Chen, Rain zhang, Shan Hongqin

title: Microbial Synthesis of the Healthy Sweetener Erythritol Using Dual Substrates
abstract: Erythritol, as a natural sweetener, exhibits unique physicochemical properties--it avoids the aforementioned health hazards while offering additional benefits such as low caloric value, high stability, and no gastrointestinal discomfort. For erythritol production, chemical synthesis methods are economically unviable, leading to growing research focus on microbial biosynthesis. Current studies primarily aim to improve erythritol yield and production efficiency. Addressing this challenge, our work first enhances and integrates the erythritol biosynthesis pathway in bacteria through molecular biology techniques. Additionally, we introduce a glycerol metabolic pathway, which serves dual purposes: reducing byproduct formation and expanding the utilization of low-cost substrates by redirecting carbon flux toward erythritol production. Glycerol, an abundant and low-value renewable resource, has recently gained attention as a promising substrate for erythritol fermentation. This study explores its potential to enable cost-effective and sustainable erythritol biosynthesis.
students: CHEN , ZIYANG, KANG, MUROU, WANG, LECHUAN, WEI, TIANYAO, ZHANG, YU, ZHOU, PINQIU

title: Research on the Application and Combined Effects of Papain Isoenzymes in Skincare Products
abstract: Our project aims to enhance skincare formulations through the utilization of isoenzymes derived from papain, a cysteine protease renowned for its gentle exfoliating and moisturizing properties. Our research focused on identifying papain isoenzymes that exhibit optimal activity across diverse skin types and pH conditions. Ultimately, five cysteine proteases were chosen for their promising suitability in skincare applications: those derived from Abrus precatorius, Actinidia eriantha, Cicer arietinum, Cajanus cajan, and papain itself. These enzymes are expected to act synergistically to enhance the efficacy, stability, and safety of enzymatic skincare products.
advisors: XINYI CHEN
students: BAO LINGXI, FENG WEIYA, LIN ZHEYA, LI YUELIN, PAN ZHIZHEN, QIAN YANGXINYUE, WANG ZI MING LOUIS, YANG XINHENG, ZHANG XIYUE

title: SlimSpore: Revolutionizing Fat Management
abstract: Obesity is the main cause of many diseases, and the number of obese people worldwide is increasing at an alarming rate. In China, issues such as adolescent obesity have seriously affected the lives of many people. As a result, the country has put forward the concept of the "Year of Weight Management". Our goal is to make the sqr and fcsd enzymes produced in large quantities by special Escherichia coli into tablet or capsule forms to help with fat loss and blood sugar reduction, and we have built home and medical versions of hardware to assist in measuring the hydrogen sulfide content in patients' bodies.
nominations: Best Hardware, High School
advisors: XINYI CHEN
student leaders: HU YIYAO, MA YUXUAN, YANG SIQI
students: CAO XIAOXIAO, CHEN JIAYU, CHEN YANRUI, HUA RUIYANG, MA HERUI, WANG XIAOJIE, WU YUE, XU ZHINING, YANG ANLIN, YANG ANQI, ZHU ZIYAN

title: Whole-Cell Catalytic Synthesis Plant for Sialic Acid
abstract: Sialic acid is an important class of functional sugars. Its predominant form is N-acetylneuraminic acid (NeuAc), a key component of brain gangliosides and the monomeric unit of sialylated oligosaccharides in Human Milk Oligosaccharides (HMOs). In this project, we employ Escherichia coli to co-express the enzymes AGE (N-acetylglucosamine 2-epimerase) and NAL (N-acetylneuraminate lyase). To address issues of substrate-product flux balance and inter-enzyme mass transfer during the dual-enzyme catalytic process, we will assemble AGE and NAL into multi-enzyme complexes using either fusion protein technology or protein self-assembly technology. Leveraging the controllability (or tunability) of the self-assembly approach, we will optimize the expression ratio of the enzymes within the complexes to achieve highly efficient synthesis of sialic acid.
advisors: GU LANTANG, HU XINZI, XING SHUMING, ZOU SHANNI
students: Cai Zhizhi, CAO LANXIN, CAO XINYU, CUI MINGYU, Gao Hongrui, HOU JIAYUE, HU XIAOXIAO, JIANG YITIAN, SHENG ZIMENG, SHEN HANYU, XIAO YANZHI, XU ZHICHUN, YANG XIUJUN, Yuan Ruoxi, ZHANG CHUYI, ZHU JUNWEI

title: Nicotinamide synthase gene empowers crop iron and zinc biofortification
abstract: Iron (Fe) and zinc (Zn) are essential trace elements for human health. However, iron and zinc deficiency is widespread worldwide, affecting approximately 2 billion people, this project intends to use the key amino acid sites at the C-terminus of AtNAS1 protein predicted in published literature to affect enzyme activity, and mutate the key sites of the full-length protein. After purifying the AtNAS1 mutant protein through prokaryotic expression in Escherichia coli, the enzyme activity mechanics analysis was performed. Compared with the wild-type AtNAS1 protein, and using the truncated AtNAS1 protein reported in the literature as a positive control for increased enzyme activity, the point mutation combination with stronger activity of the AtNAS1 full-length protein was screened for Bacillus subtilis expression vector construction, and the iron and zinc content in tobacco leaves and roots was measured after tobacco soil culture.

title: JustBITE: A Bite into the Future
abstract: With limited land and resources, Singapore heavily relies on imported food for daily sustenance and disruptions to food production and transport could quickly compromise our food availability. We need a resilient food source that can be produced locally at high quantities and affordable prices. We hope to leverage the power of microbes, to design a new sustainable form of food to solve this. Inspired by the kombucha craze, we identified its cellulose pellicle, known as SCOBY, a Symbiotic Culture Of Bacteria and Yeast, as our nutritious canvas. Using synthetic biology, we want to transform SCOBY into JustBITE, a resilient food source with customizable taste and texture. Our project takes this radical step of reimagining microbes, not as hidden ingredients in fermentation but a revolutionary food source, that could redefine how Singapore, and the world eats. Envisioning a future where every household can safely create JustBITE with our simple machine.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, Undergrad+Best Part Collection, Undergrad+Best Food & Nutrition Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Poh Chueh Loo, Matthew Chang, Wen Shan
instructors: Aurelius Andrew, LINUS TAN, Lin Zhangyuan
advisors: Chai Chin Wei, Chavelle Kok, Chen Xiayu, Syarwina Ridwan
student leaders: Tan Peh Yen, Gwyneth, Zhou Xingling
students: Chen Ruoyu, Do Nguyen, Kenneth Low, Roopa, Selee, Shubhan, Xie Yutong

title: AptAbt:Aptamer-based antibiotic biosensor for ensuring food safety
abstract: Our project presents a fluorescent aptamer-based sensor for rapid, sensitive, and specific detection of antibiotics, integrating a target recognition module with a versatile signal amplification module. The recognition core utilizes a ligand-binding oligo (LBO) that undergoes a specific structural change upon antibiotic binding, releasing a short release oligo (SRO). For signal amplification, we design two distinct strategies to suit various application needs: a T7 in vitro transcription system, where the SRO triggers the production of a fluorescent RNA aptamer, and a CRISPR-Cas12a system, where the SRO activates Cas12a's trans-cleavage activity to degrade a fluorescent reporter. This dual-approach system enables highly amplified and quantifiable detection of antibiotic residues.
PIs: Ye Qiu, HONGHUI WANG, Haijun Tu, Shi Kuang
advisors: Kailin Yang, Wenrui Gao, Yuchen Liang

title: Fruit Peel Degradation Using Engineered Lactobacillus reuteri Expressing Polygalacturonase (PGXc)
abstract: Fruit peel waste is a significant component of agricultural biomass, yet its rich pectin content remains underutilized. To address this, we engineered Lactobacillus reuteri, a Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) probiotic, to secrete polygalacturonase (pgxC) for extracellular pectin degradation. Using the pTRKH3 backbone under the ermB promoter and fused with the Usp45 secretion signal, we achieved stable expression and secretion of pgxC. Transformation in E. coli and L. reuteri confirmed plasmid maintenance, while SDS-PAGE revealed a distinct 48.5 kDa pgxC band. Protein quantification indicated increased secretion in engineered strains (0.10 vs 0.04 µg/µL controls). Functional assays validated pgxC activity: engineered L. reuteri released significantly greater amounts of D-galacturonic acid from pectin, with degradation efficiencies varying across fruit sources (pear and tomato > kiwi > banana > watermelon). This work demonstrates probiotic-mediated fruit peel valorization and highlights applications in biofuels, feed, and prebiotic production through a sustainable waste-to-resource platform.
advisors: Alyssa Han, Daniel Sun, Ryan Oh, Yaejoon Jung
student leaders: Dongwan Kim, Ellen, Jihye Lee, Juhyun Kim, Lim, MJ, Yeseo
students: Aiden Lee, Jennifer Kim, Jun, Lukas Kim, Muyoung, Seohyun, Seungcheol Kang

title: Stress Protection of mRNA with Tardigrade IDPs for Vaccine Stability Applications
abstract: Tardigrades are extremophiles capable of surviving desiccation, freezing, and irradiation, owing to unique intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) that protect cells and biomolecules under stress. As mRNA vaccines become increasingly important, protecting these fragile molecules from degradation is crucial, particularly given the expense and inequity associated with cold chain storage systems. To harness tardigrade resilience, we synthetically engineered ten IDP genes from Ramazzottius varieornatus and Hypsibius exemplaris and expressed them in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells and Human Embryonic Kidney (HEK) cells. As a proof of concept, these proteins will be combined with mRNA encoding green fluorescent protein (GFP) and subjected to variations in temperature and heating. GFP mRNA integrity and translational capacity will be assessed in using gel electrophoresis. Demonstrating mRNA protection could enable tardigrade IDP-based stabilization of vaccines, reducing cold chain dependence and improving global vaccine accessibility.
nominations: Best Biomanufacturing Project, Undergrad
advisors: Marisol Mancilla Moreno, Medel, Sadhya
students: Aaliyah Sherfuddin, Amanda Le, Maria Shaikh, Namyuktha Prakash, Selina Wang

title: PHOENICS: Smart Synthetic Immune Cells for Precision Oncology
abstract: We present PHOENICS, a modular signaling platform that uses phosphorylation logic to enable programmable, ligand-specific cancer therapies. Combining synthetic GPCR and MESA receptors with kinase/phosphatase computation and tunable expression or secretion outputs, PHOENICS provides rapid, reversible, and retargetable control of therapeutic activity. Supported by the in silico optimization platform SPARC, it offers flexible adaptation to distinct tumor microenvironments and therapeutic effectors. Beyond the bench, we built an educational innovation ecosystem that equips future pioneers with the network and knowledge to navigate the challenges of translational research. Uniting innovation and education, PHOENICS drives modular precision oncology and empowers future translational innovators.
awards: Finalist+Top 10+1st Runner-up+Best Oncology Project+Best Education+Best Model+Best Part Collection
nominations: Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad

title: PHAntom Thalassic : From Salty-Water Strains to Ocean-Safe Plastics
abstract: Plastic pollution is a global crisis demanding sustainable alternatives. Our project, PHAntom Thalassic, develops a cost-effective method to produce biodegradable polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA) using deep-sea halophilic bacteria. Focusing on Halomonas strains LA4 and LA5, which thrive in high-salt, alkaline environments, we enable open, contamination-resistant fermentation and wastewater recycling. The phaCAB operon from Ralstonia eutropha (Cupriavidus necator) was introduced into Halomonas via E. coli S17-1? conjugation, and PHA yield was assessed by Nile Red staining and GC-MS. Using CRISPR/Cas9, we integrated PHA genes into the Halomonas genome. Through extensive Human Practices, we engaged professors, fishermen, policymakers, and industry experts to align our work with real-world needs. Our PHA plastics are designed to degrade safely in marine environments, providing a sustainable solution to reduce ocean pollution and protect coral reefs and mangroves.
PIs: Xiaojuan Wang, Wanjun Chen, Hanyue Zhang, Lichuan Chen, XU JUNMEI

title: Vesper: Engineering a Bioluminescent and Aromatic Yeast for Sleep and Mood Regulation
abstract: Modern society faces a pervasive sleep and mental health crisis, with conventional solutions often being inadequate or accompanied by side effects. Our project, Vesper, harnesses the power of synthetic biology to create a natural, non-habit-forming alternative. We engineered two distinct Saccharomyces cerevisiae strains: one capable of autonomous, gentle bioluminescence through an optimized fungal caffeic acid pathway, and another producing a spectrum of therapeutic terpenoid aromas like linalool and citronellol. These strains are designed to work in synergy within a personal sleep device, the Bio-Pod, delivering multi-sensory therapy. Our human-centered design, informed by extensive human practices, is complemented by a built-in dual-layer suicide switch for robust biocontainment. Vesper offers a holistic approach to wellness, reconnecting users with the restorative power of nature through engineered biology.
PIs: XU JUNMEI, Xiaojuan Wang, Lichuan Chen, Jintao Fang, Tiange Yu

title: Development of a Biosensor for Arsenic Contamination in Rice Using RNA Aptamer Technology
abstract: This project develops a cost-effective biosensor for detecting arsenic in rice using Broccoli RNA aptamer technology, addressing food safety concerns per the Healthy Babies Bright Futures report (May 2025). The WIST team designed an ArsR-regulated system where the Broccoli aptamer activates fluorescence with DFHBI-1T upon arsenic binding. Through Design-Build-Test-Learn iterations, two plasmids were optimized: WIST_SENSE_MedArsR_StrArsC_001_A, producing ArsR and ArsC under a constitutive promoter for detection, and WIST_REPORT_002_B, generating the F-30 Broccoli aptamer for fluorescence. Mathematical modeling with a 4-parameter logistic model established a Limit of Detection below the FDA's 100 ppb threshold, a 5-100 ppb dynamic range, and a 20-30 minute optimal window, validated by testing against interferents (Pb²?, Cu²?, Fe³?) and rice extracts from the HBBF report. Cell-free systems with T7 variants tuned synthesis. New parts are under iGEM Registry safety review. Despite uncompleted lyophilization and field deployment, the project offers valuable design data and protocols for future teams.
advisors: Po-Hsun Huang
students: Alfie Lee, Amber Chen, Andrew Hsu, Beckham, Eunice Tsai, Hank Lin, Jason Lin, MING-TI KING, Terry Kuo, Winfred Lin, Zack

title: IXPOSE: unlocking DNA detection potential of TIGR-Tas
abstract: Lithuania is a hotspot in Europe for tick-borne diseases, with thousands of people exposed to Lyme disease and tick-borne encephalitis annually. However, despite awareness of these common infections, a significant gap remains: we lack vital data on other pathogens circulating in wild tick populations. This missing information forces researchers, doctors, and public health officials to make educated guesses. To address this, we present a breakthrough solution using TIGR-Tas--a novel RNA-guided, DNA-targeting system. Unlike CRISPR-Cas, TIGR-Tas operates in a PAM-independent manner, expanding the range of detectable DNA sequences. By integrating TIGR-Tas with lateral flow assays and isothermal DNA amplification methods such as RPA, it becomes a powerful, field-ready diagnostic tool. With this system, we aim to uncover the hidden diversity of tick-borne pathogens, empowering healthcare, enhancing prevention, advancing research, and protecting communities throughout Lithuania and beyond.
students: Agn?, Areta, Augustas, August?, Domantas, Emilija, Emilis, Migl?, Petras, Urt? B., Urt? Pauliuk?nait?, Viktorija Ramonait?

title: Engineering Cupriavidus necator H16 for In-Situ Production of Alpha-Lactalbumin in Space
abstract: As deep-space missions lengthen, sustaining astronaut nutrition becomes critical. We present a synthetic-biology platform using the hydrogen-oxidizing bacterium Cupriavidus necator H16 for in-situ production of human ?-lactalbumin aboard spacecraft. The strain was engineered to autotrophically convert astronaut metabolic wastes (CO?, urea) into active ?-lactalbumin. Guided by genome-scale metabolic modeling, pathway optimization enabled a closed-loop production system. To improve nutritional performance, we rationally inserted optimized trypsin-cleavage sites to enhance gastrointestinal digestibility. We also designed a microgravity-adapted bioreactor that addresses gas-liquid mass-transfer limitations, facilitating efficient cultivation and product recovery. Together, these advances demonstrate the feasibility of microbial biomanufacturing for space life-support and provide a technical foundation for sustainable extraterrestrial nutrition.
advisors: Yuhan Zhou, Ziyang Zhang
student leaders: Hongyuan Zhou, Jialu Wang, Shiqi Cao
students: Chongyu Zhong, Hongjin Chen, Jielin Huang, Kainan Xue, Meng Li, Runting Li, Xia Si, Yifei Wang, Yixun Huang, Yuhan Huang, Yunru Wen, Zhe Sun, zhimu-zhang, Ziyi Chang

title: Insights into Molecular Interactions ? Predicting and Validating PFOA Binding to Human Proteins
abstract: PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances) are chemicals used in several manufactured products. They have been called "forever chemicals" for their inability to break down in our environment and have accumulated to an extent that at least 97% of Americans have traceable amounts in their blood (NHANES 2015). However, while the full spectrum of their effects is not entirely understood, they have been implicated in several cancers and liver conditions. Current detection methods like mass spectrometry and liquid or gas chromatography are expensive and inaccessible to the general public. Our project aims to develop a cost-effective protein-based detection system for PFAS. Using a reverse-screening approach across multiple protein-ligand databases, we identified candidate human proteins predicted to bind perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), a representative PFAS. Among these, we purified and characterized a key DNA repair protein that is significantly destabilized in the presence of PFOA based on results from differential scanning fluorimetry (DSF).
PIs: Scott Arico, Kalina, Michael Martin, Rob, Sabine Waigel
students: Aanya Veeranagoudar, Akhila Nalladimma, Aliete Yanes Medina, Arjun Nalladimma, Aryan Shah, Bhavya Agrawal, Christian, Christian Corrigan, Edward Kim, Gowshik Lavan Ramanathan, Hunter Earls, Japjee Kaur Dhall, Kabir Singh, Shlok Jena, Siddhant Shukla, Vijay Kannan

title: Dual-Action Oral Vaccine Platform: Engineered Probiotics Synthesizing Nanocyclobodies and Membrane-Displayed Antigens
abstract: AvianGuard is an innovative proposal based on a modular platform, designed to be effective against different viruses. In this opportunity, it was validated against the challenge of avian influenza (H5N1), a disease that threatens food security and poultry production. In Ecuador, the vaccines currently available do not fit the small-scale producer model; therefore, our solution consists of a dual-action oral probiotic vaccine, formulated in alginate-chitosan microcapsules that protect its immunological components and ensure their release in the bird's intestine. The system combines two protection mechanisms: active immunity, generated from conserved antigens expressed in Lactococcus lactis, and passive immunity, through cyclobodies produced in E. coli. Thanks to its easy administration mixed with feed, AvianGuard emerges as an accessible, effective, and low-cost alternative for controlling avian influenza in small-scale poultry production systems.
nominations: Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Therapeutics Project, Undergrad
PIs: Yadira Boada Acosta, Eduardo Alejandro Moncayo Palacio, Alejandro Vignoni, Francisco Flores

title: meduCA: Microbes Enabling Decarbonized-Urbanization via Carbonic Anhydrase
abstract: Space exploration is rapidly advancing, accelerating the need to protect explorers and equipment from harsh extraterrestrial environments. Building infrastructure in space is challenging, as transporting construction materials to other planets is both costly and environmentally unsustainable. meduCA addresses this by harnessing the power of microbially-induced calcium carbonate precipitation using carbonic anhydrase (CA) enzymes to turn atmospheric CO? into carbon-negative bricks via biocementation. Our system employs Synechococcus elongatus, engineered to surface display CA, enabling efficient CO? sequestration and calcite precipitation. Complementary efforts on Earth employ Caulobacter crescentus to biocement hazardous mine tailings, mitigating toxic dust and leaching. Together, these applications demonstrate the versatility of living building materials in both extraterrestrial and terrestrial settings. To empower future teams, we developed innovative software tools, a custom bioink-bioprinting platform, and an inclusivity framework to expand accessibility in synthetic biology in hopes of building a resilient future on Earth, and one day, on Mars.
nominations: Best Software Tool, Undergrad+Best Space Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Chaehyeon Lee, Trisha Macalintal
students: Aden Chan, Alan Wu, Alexi Manning, Alya, Andrew Li, Angela, Aoniya Colynn, Arda, Billy Wang, Bruce Chen, Carrie Xu, Catherine J., Ceres, Cindy Fu, Claudia, Connor Mora, Danielle Keith, Ethan Skjaveland, Evan, Felix Chan, Gabriella Gubantes, Hanna Khan, Izaak Y., Jaclyn Armstrong, Jessica Xin, Jessie Luo, Jewell, Kaylie Chen, Kelly, Leia, Libby, Lillian Pan, Marina, Matthew, Matthias Wong, Maximilien Filion, Min Mon, Nathan Yeung, Nethkini Liyanage, Nikita, Nissan, Pattarin Blanchard, Rachel Weng, Robben Liu, Saige, Satvika, Sean Fox, Sebastian Hyland, Syafiq Ghazali, Talha, Tiffany Feng, Tom Xie, Veronika B., Wendy Wu, Yoshier, Yuki G, Zahra Savoji, ZiQi Chen

title: iGEM Concordia Montreal: ToastBusters
abstract: The only effective treatment for celiac disease is a strict gluten-free diet. While this approach allows individuals to manage their symptoms, it does not eliminate the risk of accidental gluten exposure due to cross-contamination. Our team is developing an approach centered around engineered probiotic bacteria capable of secreting gluten-degrading enzymes directly in the gut. Delivering enzymes capable of break down the immunogenic peptides responsible for triggering the immune response in individuals with celiac disease. In parallel, we investigated peptide caps that can bind to residual gliadin fragments, masking the key epitopes and preventing the immune system from recognizing uncleaved gluten. Together, these strategies highlight complementary ways to significantly reduce the concentration of harmful gluten fragments before they can activate the immune system, offering a potential layer of protection beyond the limitations of a gluten-free diet.
advisors: Megan Greensill, Toluwase Fatoki
student leaders: Amanda Catherine Peragine, Dorothea Davidson, Isabela Morita
students: Aidan, Aisveen Jeyanandan, Amaury, Fanny Gallé, Karin Etemadi, Leah Kay, Mariame, Nicolas Sweet, Yasmine Bouzar

title: Magnolyse: Engineered Magnetotactic Bacteria for Ovarian Cancer Therapy
abstract: We have aimed to develop a targeted, bacterial-based cancer therapeutic platform to enhance treatment options for ovarian cancer patients. This system will employ Magnetospirillum magneticum AMB-1, a bacterial strain which exhibits magnetotaxis and aerotaxis. We are engineering AMB-1 to produce the cytotoxic agent Cytolysin A to serve as a tumor-eliminating therapeutic. Cytolysin A production will be regulated by a heat shock promoter which is inducible by increased temperature as a result of an external alternating magnetic field. In addition, we aim to maximize the specificity of the therapeutic system by implementing a ligand on the surface of AMB-1 to the folate receptor alpha which is highly expressed in ovarian cancer cells. Our ultimate goal is to develop an innovative and targeted therapeutic option for those suffering with ovarian cancer. Ultimately, we hope to develop a platform that is generalizable to all cancers forming solid tumors.
advisors: Amber E Haley, Kareem Aboulhosn
student leaders: Aditi Ganesan, Avi Patel, Grace Lombardo, Hania Timek, Henry Zhang, Joel Groves, Leah Jankoska, Malik Alabbas, Noah Black, Schuyler Byrn
students: Aico Miao, Allison Myers, Ana Ferreira, Andrei Vava, Andrew Meng, Anna, Anusha, Arnav Sharma, Aryan Kini, Aryan Singh, Daniel Yang, Ethan, Haniya Farooq, Harini Ram, Harshini Rubarajan, Henry Saltzman, Isabella Martinez, Katelin, Saad Alrazzi, Samirah, Temmie Yu, Won Lee, Yashwanth Bajji

title: MethaNO: Synthetic Biology-Based Biosensors for Rapid Methanol Detection in Alcoholic Beverages
abstract: Methanol contamination in alcoholic beverages is a serious global health risk, yet accessible detection methods are lacking. Team MethaNO from Macquarie University proposes two synthetic biology-based biosensors for low-cost, rapid methanol detection. The first design uses a whole-cell E. coli sensor featuring a chimeric histidine kinase combining MxaY (from Paracoccus denitrificans) with CusS (from E. coli), activating a kinase phosphorylation pathway to express a visible blue chromoprotein (AmilCP) in response to methanol. The second design employs a Ca²?-PQQ-dependent methanol dehydrogenase (MDH) from Methylorubrum extorquens, expressed and isolated from E. coli to create a cell-free system. MDH oxidizes methanol to formaldehyde, detectable via colorimetric assays. Both biosensors offer scalable, specific, and visual detection of hazardous methanol levels in beverages.
advisors: Josip Mujic
students: Blake Gibbs, Faith Marian Orbeta, Gehna Verma, Jack Ryan, Louis Taffinder, Mahia Quadrey, Sophia Yap, Yin Sim

title: Fluoro-free: A Probiotic to Capture and Remove Harmful PFAS from the GI Tract
abstract: Perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are synthetic contaminants that bioaccumulate and are associated with adverse health effects. While remediation efforts target environmental cleanup, strategies to lower PFAS levels within the human body remain limited. We propose a probiotic-based therapeutic approach using engineered Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) to sequester PFAS in the gastrointestinal tract. By capturing PFAS before absorption, EcN could reduce systemic exposure and enhance excretion. Our hypothesis is that bacterial PFAS uptake is primarily transporter-mediated. To maximize intracellular retention, we disrupted the TolC-AcrB efflux system. As a proof of concept, we inhibited AcrB using small molecule inhibitor Phenylalanine-Arginine Beta-Naphthylamide. Subsequently, we created a stable AcrB knockout via recA-mediated recombination.This work lays the foundation for probiotic therapeutics targeting PFAS exposure. Beyond the lab, we advance public outreach initiatives to educate and raise PFAS awareness and promote STEM accessibility in our community.
advisors: Annika Heng Shi, Corinne Drabenstott, Gavin Wiltshire
student leaders: Anusha Gupta, Joshua C. Lopez, Pristine Onuoha
students: Aimee, Alex, Allison, Aryan Kokkanti, Carrie, Chinmay, Cynthia Wen, Dhruv Ranganath, Dominic Kubissa, Evie, Hailey Nguyen, Harshil Savani, Inci Aydin, Ishita, Jack Titus, Julia Zhu, Lahari Pokala, Layla Gusa, Logan Amos, Madison, Melike Erim, Moiz Chomelawala, Olivia, Osvaldo Linares, Riya, Sruthi, Uditi Patil

title: ReguSAMe
abstract: The global incidence of cirrhosis is on the rise, and current therapies can only delay disease progression, often requiring lifelong medication. Existing studies have confirmed that S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) has unique value in restoring hepatocyte metabolism and function. However, its clinical application faces challenges such as low oral bioavailability and the risk of inducing the transition from cirrhosis to hepatocellular carcinoma due to sustained elevation of hepatic SAM concentrations beyond physiological levels with long-term use. To precisely regulate SAM in cirrhosis, we engineered a SAM-responsive aptazyme, ReguSAMe, by fusing a SAM riboswitch to the HDV ribozyme followed by multicycle evolution. By embedding ReguSAMe into the 3'UTR of MAT1A mRNA, we established a negative feedback circuit for SAM homeostasis in hepatocytes. it expresses MAT1A to synthesize SAM when levels are low and self-cleaves to terminate expression when levels normalize. This precise control offers a promising therapeutic strategy with reduced side effects.
nominations: Best Model, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad+Inclusivity Award, Undergrad+Best Therapeutics Project, Undergrad
advisors: Tao Yuan, Xiyang Liu
student leaders: Hang Yang, Huaizhi Wang, Jiaxin He, Murong Lei, Zheping Zhang
students: DengRong Gao, Hailey, Hao Zou, HuJingBo, JUNBO DAI, Juni Zhang, Nicole, Qingyang CHEN, Shengwen Ding, Yan Tianle, Yihan Guo, Yuqiao Shi, Zhiya Wang, Zichen He, Zihang, Ziheng, Zixian Zhao

title: A Pichia pastoris factory for efficient production of lipase
abstract: With the intensification of the energy crisis and the rising demand for environmental protection, biodiesel, as a clean energy source, has attracted much attention. Every year, our country generates hundreds of millions of tons of waste oils such as used cooking oil. If not handled properly, it may cause food safety and environmental risks. The traditional chemical method for producing biodiesel has problems such as high energy consumption and pollution; while the biological enzyme method, with advantages like environmental friendliness and mild conditions, has become a new direction, but it also has disadvantages such as low enzyme activity and high cost. This project aims to improve the reaction efficiency and stability of the biological enzyme method, converting waste oils into environmentally friendly biodiesel, contributing to the "dual carbon" goal, promoting the transformation of the energy structure and sustainable development.
advisors: HUANG SHANSHAN, YIN YIWEI
students: CHEN ZIYU, HU YULI, LUO YUTONG, TANG SIYAO, WANG XINRAN, WANG XIN RAN, XIAO YUHAN, ZHAO YUANWU

title: KINETiC: Kynurenine-depleting Immuno-reversal Network in E. coli for Therapy in Colorectal cancer
abstract: Our project is expected to provide a new idea and method for cancer treatment. In recent years, kynureninase (KYNase) has gradually attracted extensive attention in the field of cancer immunotherapy. We utilized synthetic biology methods and engineered bacteria to express KY Nase, regulating the metabolism of the KP pathway within tumor cells, consuming its downstream metabolite Kyn. This inhibits tumor immune escape, enhances the host's immune system response, and achieves tumor cell death. We utilized Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3) as the chassis cell and the hypoxic and high-lactic-acid regulatory ALPaGA subsystem as promoter, to express KYNase in the tumor microenvironment. We also made semi-rational modifications to KYNase, hoping to obtain an enzyme with better catalytic effect. We designed and built a PhiX174E lysis protein module to release KYNase extracellularly at the right time. For biosafety, we designed a suicide switch to prevent engineered strains from being released into the environment.
advisors: Ziqi Mi
student leaders: Chloe Ruxi Chen, Liyi Wang, LLLyc, Yanwen Mao, YIRAN LIU, Yunuo Luan
students: Gewei Zhang, Gexuan, Hanyu, Haoyu Huang, Higgs, Kaichen Jiang, Keqing Chen, Meiran Ge, Pan tianxiang, Ren Siying, Rushen Tao, Suri Mao, Weixuan Tang, Will Shen, Xiyuan Cao, Yang Xianfei, YAWEN ZHENG, ZhangZheHao, Ziming Li

title: BRIGHT: Bile Acid Responsive Indicator for Gut Health Tracking
abstract: Chronic diarrhea affects millions worldwide, yet its underlying causes often remain undiagnosed due to the lack of accessible diagnostic tools. One of the most overlooked conditions is Bile Acid Malabsorption (BAM), a disorder in which excess bile acids reach the colon, leading to persistent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and impaired quality of life. Current diagnostic methods for BAM are either too invasive, expensive, or impractical for routine clinical use, resulting in long diagnostic delays and misclassification as irritable bowel syndrome. To address this gap, we developed BRIGHT, a novel bioluminescent biosensor that detects bile acids in stool samples. BRIGHT provides a simple, fast, and affordable readout that can be quantified with a smartphone camera, opening the door to a home based point-of-care test. By lowering barriers for both patients and clinicians, BRIGHT aims to empower individuals, accelerate diagnosis, and pave the way toward improved treatment outcomes.
nominations: Best Wiki, Undergrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Undergrad+Best Diagnostics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Maarten Merkx, Luc Brunsveld, Tom De Greef
advisors: Lucas van Osenbruggen
students: Dorottya Váczy, Imke Robben, Janneke van de Ven, Jelmer Pieters, Joep Boelen, Kady Hoogenboom, Tessa Krol

title: VeriFied
abstract: Forensic science is a field that lacks reliable methods for determining the age of bloodstains, a key factor in reconstructing timelines for crimes. To address this issue, in our project we are developing an innovative, on-site forensic investigation tool - VeriFied - that allows crime scene investigators to quickly and reliably assess the age of bloodstains. The method is based on an enzyme fragment complementation assay that produces a bioluminescence signal. The signal intensity correlates with the levels of oxidized albumin that increase over time as bloodstains are exposed to air. Our aim is to introduce a scientifically robust, quantitative method that reduces reliance on individual interpretation and improves the accuracy of investigation done at a crime scene. This enables criminal investigators to establish more precise timelines and identify relevant bloodstains to the case, guiding the investigation with a scientific basis and solving crimes that would have previously gone unsolved.
students: Aisa, Amanda Pynnönen, Ari Heino, Julie Parente, Linnea Huuska, Milla Gerasin, Nea Åberg, Nyytti Koskinen, Pekka Olavi Hyppölä, Tytti Sandholm, Venni Tuulosniemi

title: GutFeeling: Fishing for Solutions
abstract: Chronic diseases often require lifelong medication, yet poor adherence remains a major barrier to effective treatment. This leads to increased mortality, higher healthcare costs, and reduced quality of life. In Parkinsons disease lack of adherence is caused by the symptoms of the disease, like memory loss and dyskinesia. Therefore, we propose the development of a self-sustaining drug delivery platform using engineered commensal gut bacteria. As a proof of concept, we aim to modify Pseudomonas alcaligenes to autonomously produce and secrete L-DOPA within the gut. To validate the constructs we used fluorescent reporter proteins and L-DOPA biosynthesis. To visualize P. alcaligenes colonization, protein expression and secretion we will use its host: zebrafish. To test our bacteria in a mammalian system we used a gut transwell system. We envision that our project contributes to a living microbial biofactory approach to drug delivery, reducing the need for continuous self-administration.
PIs: Frederik Verweij, Ewart Kuijk, Josephina Groenenboom
students: Alexander, Anne Hakkert, Eliza, Eva Schuiteman, Francisco Wu, Hein Hermans, Jochanan Maaijen, Merel Beurskens, Michelle Than

title: LATCH "Live Adhesion Tool for Candida Hunting"
abstract: Candida albicans, responsible for about 65% of Candida infections and 200,000 deaths annually, mainly affects immunocompromised individuals. Current treatments are often ineffective or toxic. In project LATCH, we aimed to improve antifungal therapy by engineering Bacillus subtilis, a generally non-pathogenic human commensal with natural antifungal properties, to target C. albicans. By expressing chitinase and SP1 on its membrane via a linking sequence, B. subtilis can bind to chitin on the fungal surface, increasing local antifungal concentration. Computational modeling guided adhesion dynamics, binding specificity, and expression optimization. Although only the plasmid design was verified and no binding data obtained, the project provided valuable insights and inspired local education on fungal infections and synthetic biology through outreach in Gothenburg.
students: Cecilia Rydberg, Daniel Atiyeh, Elin Esborn, Hedda Lundberg, Karl Sundström, Marike Ellerbroek, Siyuan Liu, Vidar Wolter

title: GenOMe: the genome LEGO baseplate for iGEM teams.
abstract: GenOMe is a next-generation, plasmid-free genome engineering platform that enables iGEM teams to integrate BioBrick components directly into specific E. coli chromosomal sites within just two days, achieving up to 80% efficiency. At its core, Bxb1 integrase mediates precise recombination between chromosomal attB and cassette attP sites, allowing seamless and site-specific DNA integration. The LandingPad module establishes reusable genomic slots that enable multi-round, marker-free insertions, while the GenOMe Parts Collection offers standardized attB/attP modules for scalable and modular construction. Combined with GenOMe Navigator, which predicts optimal integration sites and success rates, this system transforms genome editing into a fast, reliable, and standardized workflow--a true "genome LEGO baseplate" that empowers iGEM teams to build stable, creative, and inheritable genetic architectures, advancing synthetic biology into a new era of genome engineering.
nominations: Best Part Collection, Undergrad+Best Foundational Advance Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Wen-Liang Chen, Hsiao-Ching Lee, Huai-En Lu
advisors: Wendy Chan
students: CHANG,CHIA-WEI, ChiaPei, CHIH-AN, LIN, Chin, Po-Chun, CHUN-TING,KO, Elina Chang, HSIA, HSIN-CHIEN, NIEN PING-HUNG, PEI-WEI,WU, PIN-CHE, PAN, SHENG-YI, TUNG, Wang Cheng-hao, ZI-YU, CHEN

title: AshBloom: A rhamnolipid-derived foam offering a sustainable, non-toxic alternative to traditional firefighting solutions.
abstract: Wildfires in Canada's boreal forests are increasing in frequency and severity, creating landscapes that struggle to recover. Current wildfire suppression uses plain water or chemical foams that prioritize flame control but overlook ecological impacts. Class A foams, commonly used in wildland firefighting, are petrochemical-based, produced via non-sustainable processes, and harm soil and aquatic health. Ammonium-based retardants also disrupt seed germination and microbial communities, with potential nutrient runoff risks. AshBloom presents an eco-friendly alternative: a bio-based, biodegradable fire-suppressant foam made from microbial rhamnolipids via sustainable fermentation. This foam matches the performance of traditional products while enhancing post-fire soil function by promoting water infiltration, beneficial microbes, and seed germination. Being made from renewable feedstocks like waste cooking oil, it rapidly degrades without toxic residues. AshBloom supports both fire suppression and ecological restoration, offering a tool that helps landscapes regenerate sustainably and aids firefighters and forest managers in protecting ecosystems with nature-aligned technology.
advisors: Anthony Shin, Domenic Marano, Fabian Rondon, Nina Deschner, Preston Tran, Rachael Rieberger
student leaders: Amandeep Singh Hira, Cody McCloy, Jacquelyn Narsing, Katya Moroziuk, Nima Shariatzadeh
students: Abia Raza, Amir, Amy Singh, Amy Wang, Annie Tang, Anupam Kaur, Dani, Haneen Mohamed, Hannah, Janani Anand, Joy Cao, Juliane Phan, Macie Fenske, Mariam Elshazly, Raj Patel, Ruoyi Jia, Sajjad Syed, Sam_Walker, Stefan Marano, Yosri, Zahra

title: CamiRa - Crop Assessment via microRNA Analysis
abstract: CamiRa, Crop Assessment via microRNA Analysis, is an affordable, easy-to-use, all-in-one miRNA extraction and analysis kit which detects nutrient deficiencies before crops show visible signs for early intervention (i.e. before crop yield is affected). Due to its ease of use, CamiRa can also be used to check the crops after nutrient supplementation to check if they have recovered, to prevent overapplication resulting in eutrophication. Our extraction protocol combines an isopropanol-based chemical precipitation with a hand centrifuge, designed to make a cheap, easy-to-operate and safe extraction procedure that could be carried out by farmers, without needing extensive laboratory equipment and training. After extraction, our analysis tool involves a method of detecting miRNAs from our plant extracts. Three different detection methods have been considered: two using rolling circle amplification (RCA) as a form of isothermal signal amplification (G-quadruplex and Bioluminescence resonance energy transfer (BRET)), and one without amplification based on sandwich hybridisation.
instructors: Anqi Yu, Gabriele Cannucciari, Kavi H Shah, Weizhuo Chen
advisors: Cenyujia Wang, Honghao Su
students: Alexander Gillan, Amitan, Cassandra Lui, Darren, Joaquin Anjarwalla, Kelda Lee, Molly, Natchapol Vongtanakiat, Steven

title: Foundations for an AHL-Responsive Genetic Circuit in Eukaryotic Cells: A Biofilm-Disrupting Therapeutic
abstract: Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms drive chronic lung infections in cystic fibrosis (CF) by resisting antibiotics and immune clearance. Biofilm development is regulated by quorum sensing (QS) via acyl-homoserine lactones (AHLs), making QS an appealing therapeutic target. While AHL detection has been engineered in bacteria, its use in eukaryotic systems remains unexplored. We developed early-stage eukaryotic genetic circuits linking AHL sensing to gene expression using chimeric LasR and RhlR receptors. In silico docking (HADDOCK) guided variant selection based on ligand binding and dimerization stability. Complementary biofilm assays using AiiA lactonase, alginate lyase, and ?-amylase demonstrated measureable inhibition of P. aeruginosa PAO1 biofilms. Together, these results lay the groundwork for AHL-responsive genetic circuits in mammalian cells, supporting future synthetic biology-based therapies where engineered immune cells could detect bacterial QS signals and secrete biofilm-degrading enzymes for targeted CF treatment.
nominations: Best Therapeutics Project, Undergrad
advisors: Yat Tse
student leaders: Cameron, Kaden Kowalyshyn, Krish Mendapara, Morgan Lock, Sasha Jande, Sofia Leuchter
students: Claire Bunker, Elizabeth Sadek, Emma Wright, Grace, Jason Song, Jean-Paul Masotti, Milagros Lardiez, Nicole Wu, Noah Marino, Samantha, Shiv Parekh, Sophia Liu, Sophie, Tess, Tiffany Luong, Wesley

title: LiRA - A dual-input RNA logic system for precise detection and treatment of HBV-driven HCC.
abstract: Most cancer treatments, from chemotherapy to targeted inhibitors, act systemically, killing cancer cells but also damaging healthy ones. This is due to a central problem in oncology: few cancers have a single biomarker both unique and abundant enough to be safely used as a therapeutic trigger. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), especially when driven by hepatitis B virus (HBV), exemplifies this challenge. Markers such as GPC3, AKR1B10, and RP11 are elevated in tumors but also appear in healthy tissues, making single-signal therapies inherently risky. LiRA overcomes this through a programmable intracellular RNA logic gate inspired by Boolean computation. Built on the RADAR technology, LiRA activates only when two biomarker transcripts are detected together within the same cell, ensuring precise activation. In HEK293T, LiRA sensors achieved up to 23-fold activation and demonstrated strict AND-gate behavior. By replacing reporters with a therapeutic output, LiRA allows for targeted treatment, paving the way for next-generation therapeutics.
nominations: Best Oncology Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Drew Endy, Huijun Ring, Phillip Kyriakakis
student leaders: Bernardo Melotti, Liz Tsai, Melwin Cheng, Noor El Kereamy
students: Annabelle Shilling, Fatima Khawaja, Rhea Rastogi, Sabrina Olivares, Sophia Browder

title: ?BUFFER?Bioremediation of Unwieldy Organic Compounds Featuring Functionalized Escherichia coli Regulated by a Quorum Sensing System
abstract: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are persistent organic pollutants in the urban environment, because of their hydrophobic and lipophilic character, PAHs is an easily enriched in sludge, which is by-product of sewage treatment and widely used in cultivated land . The accumulation of PAHs can pose huge threats to the water bodies. According to Guangzhou WWTP, the concentration of several PAHs in local effluent, even after wastewater treatment, still remained approximately 10 to 15 times above China's acceptable risk levels. Due to the numerous drawbacks of the existing approaches, such as low efficiency and significant side effects, we come up with a more comprehensive solution to this problem: constructing an engineered E.coli which is integrated with plasmids containing diverse gene clusters, endowing it with higher degradation capability, enhanced environmental resistance, and safer switch control. The goal of the project is to provide a safer and more efficient mean of treating PAHs.
advisors: Daisy
students: Amy Tang, Brian Lu, Keyou Zhou, Lisa zhang, Lucas, Mandy Meng, Runyu Gui, Tianqi Yin, Xicheng Zhang

title: yeast SMART?yeast Synthetic Modulatory Adaptation for stress Resistant based on TCM?
abstract: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) employs "pulse diagnosis" to identify bodily imbalance via dynamic patterns--such as the speed, strength, and rhythm of the wrist pulse--and facilitate precise interventions. Industrial yeast cell factories also encounter intermittent, multi-source stresses analogous to physiological imbalances in human body, yet they lack a pulse-diagnosis-like technique to pinpoint stress disturbances and implement tailored regulation. Such stresses reduce product yield and compromise batch stability, becoming a major bottleneck for large-scale production. Inspired by TCM, we propose visualizing the spatiotemporal responses of yeast strains as "stress pulse patterns," and designing targeted genetic regulatory modules accordingly. Specifically, we developed a tripartite genetic oscillator that transforms stress inputs into quantifiable "fluorescent pulses" (to analyze stress sources/intensities) and paired it with a toolkit of multi-stress resistance genetic elements and a pulse regulation strategy. This low-metabolic-burden, customizable platform enables dynamic diagnosis and precise regulation in fermentation, boosting process robustness and efficiency.
advisors: FANZE MENG, HAOCHENG ZHANG
students: Haiyue Yu, LI, SIYAO, LIU HAO, SHENG,TIANQI, SHI,CHENYANG, Siyu Li, TONGYU JING, WANG, WEICHEN, WANG YUANYUAN, WU,MOYAN, XIONG,SIYU, XU QINGCHUAN, XU YIZHANG, Yang Zhongxuan, YANG ZIYI, YUEXUAN LI, YUNZHE ZHOU, YU YONGJIA, ZHANG ENPU

title: Mining of Marine PET-Degrading Enzymes
abstract: The marine metagenome harbors numerous functional genes that have yet to be discovered and engineered for utilization. Currently, most of the known wild-type PET-degrading enzymes and engineered high-activity PET-degrading enzymes such as IsPETase and ICCG are derived from terrestrial sources and are suitable for functioning in low-salt concentration conditions, thus their application scenarios are greatly restricted by salt concentration. At present, microplastic pollution in marine environments is severe, and one major source of marine microplastics is high salinity wastewater. The main objective of our project is to solve the degradation problem of PET microplastics in high-salt water bodies by mining PET-degrading enzymes from the ocean and conducting targeted modifications to enhance their activity.
PIs: Zefang Wang, Yanyan Wang, Yunjie Xiao
advisors: Kewei Chen
students: Dorkby, He Rouyue, huangyixuan, Kantro, limenglin, liqike, liuchang, Liu Cheng, lvhaonan, lvziwan, SkySquare, Stella, Tan Beiyuan, wangcong, xiaoshiyan, Xinyu Xie, yanzixuan, Yihan Wang, Yufeng Xiao, yuyue, Zhang Yutian, Zhengyang Wu, zhoutianchang, zhugexinhao, Ziyu Chen, ???

title: PENgUIN--Prime Editor and Novel prime editing guideRNAs for Understanding Intracellular Narratives--
abstract: While current biological tools can identify molecules, they cannot track the precise order of microRNA (miRNA) expression in single cells, creating a critical research bottleneck. Our technology, PENgUIN, overcomes this challenge. It uses a novel "miRNA switch Prime Editing" technique to sequentially record miRNA activity onto a "DNA Tape." This tape can then be analyzed to reconstruct a complete timeline of expression at the single-cell level. PENgUIN holds the promise of unraveling the mechanisms behind complex medical problems, such as the heterogeneous differentiation of iPS cells and the acquisition of drug resistance in cancer. As a highly adaptable gene circuit component, it is also positioned to become a foundational tool that will drive the next generation of synthetic biology.
PIs: Takashi Okada, Chikara Furusawa, Tsuneakwa Yuji
advisors: Kazuto Yoshimi, Kouya Mikamo, Masashi Takahashi, Tomoji Mashimo
students: Aritomo YAMAZAKI, Chihaya Kudo, Fumiya Kashiwai, Hibiki MATSUYAMA, Hirohashi mikihito, Ichi MORINAGA, Jin Kawabata, Jiro Kawano, Kei Hato, Kenji Miki, Kohei Motegi, Kohsei Doy, Kota Ishizuka, Maiko saito, Nono Tanaka, Norihiro Mizukami, Takumi Hamasaki, Tomoki ISHII, Yukiya OGATA, Yutaro Ikegami, Yuto NAITO

title: RareAmine Forge: Engineering ThermoFactories for Specialized Polyamines
abstract: This project establishes a thermotolerant microbial platform for the biosynthesis of specialized polyamines--long-chain and branched molecules with significant potential in medicine, agriculture, and advanced materials. The workflow began with collecting hot spring samples across a temperature gradient. Metagenomic analysis confirmed temperature as a core driver of microbial community structure and function, revealing a significant enrichment of polyamine synthesis pathways, especially spermidine synthase, which enabled the mining of key synthase genes. Subsequent multi-omics analysis of isolated thermophilic Bacillus strains under temperature stress revealed a coordinated cellular adaptation strategy involving metabolic reprogramming, protein homeostasis, and membrane regulation. Morphological analysis visually confirmed these adaptations. Crucially, polyamine biosynthesis pathways were consistently upregulated under heat stress, underscoring their integral role in thermotolerance. This project successfully validated native thermotolerant Bacillus as an ideal chassis, decoded the mechanisms of heat resistance and polyamine biosynthesis, and identified key synthetic biology elements. Future research will focus on developing synthetic biology tools for this chassis, genetically engineering the strain to optimize the production of target polyamines via modular pathway assembly and flux optimization, and expanding the portfolio of accessible bioactive polyamines by discovering novel enzymes from the established platforms.
advisors: Xuefen Fan, Yufan Yang
student leaders: Ailin Guan, Yuting Guo, Zixi He
students: Chunying Zhu, Jifan Lei, JingYuan, Linjia Tan, Lv Zhao, Pengfei Liu, Qingru Hua, Run Yang, Siqi Liu, Siyuan Nie, Tiantian Ji, Tongyu Liu, Yilong Xu, Yining Wang, Yiyang Deng

title: PetPeptide Antibacterial Dressing
abstract: In today's society, over one million people die each year from antibiotic-resistant bacteria [1], which is largely attributed to the excessive use of antibiotics over the past few decades. Moreover, globally, as people's living standards improve, keeping pets has gradually become a common lifestyle. Pets not only provide emotional companionship but also improve the quality of human life to a certain extent. However, as the number of pets continues to grow, health issues related to pets are becoming increasingly prominent, among which bacterial infections are particularly notable.
advisors: Lin Li
student leaders: Heyu Liu, Yining yang, Zeyu Yan
students: Alex Hu, chen Hongjian, Chen Lei, Chen zhu, Entong Zhu, huangchengxu, Jingwei Wu, kaile liu, Lamei LU, Liu QinHang, Mingjie Li, Oliviayan, Qing Si, Qinwen Shi, Tina tian, Wang, Weng Xiaofan, Xiaoyu Tao, Xin Wang, XunDing, Yangjiahui, Ye Chengyan, Yixuan Zhang, YouTianyi, Yu Wang, Zengjianglin, Zhangyukun, ZhangYutong, Zheng YuTong, Zhonglin Wang, ???

title: TasAnchor:A Whole-Cell Immobilization Platform
abstract: Although engineered bacteria hold great potential for wastewater remediation, their practical application is constrained by operational challenges such as easy washout, poor stability, and low cell density. To overcome these limitations, we developed TasAnchor, a whole-cell immobilization platform built on the chassis of Bacillus subtilis. By repurposing the endogenous biofilm protein TasA as a genetically engineered molecular anchor, TasAnchor dramatically enhances cellular adhesion and biofilm formation capacity of the engineered host on surfaces such as polystyrene filters.We further engineered TasAnchor into a multifunctional cadmium-management platform capable of the simultaneous monitoring, adsorption, and recovery of Cd²? ions in real-time. For biocontainment, a quorum sensing-activated suicide circuit was integrated to trigger cell death upon accidental release. Central to its design is modularity, allowing for the exchange of adhesive proteins to facilitate flexible adaptation to diverse remediation scenarios, thereby underscoring the platform's versatility and broad application potential.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, Undergrad
students: Bohan Yu, Furong Yang, Hao Yang, Hongyi Wang, Junxian Li, Junye Li, Kaiting Wei, Le Dong, Linjintao Chen, Qingying Zhao, Shanshan Yao, Tianyu Zhou, Wang Xuejue, Weizhen Li, Xianxin Wang, Xia Yizhao, Xintong Xie, Xin Xiong, Yanming Huang, Yifei Xu, Yongyuan Mi, Zhangyu You, Zhiqiao Zhao, Zhitong Lu, Zhuoying Li, Zhutian Mao

title: SALTY: A Salt-Inducible TYDV System for Efficient DENV-2 Subunit Vaccine Production in Tobacco
abstract: Biomanufacturing of therapeutic proteins and vaccines faces high costs and scalability limitations, posing challenges for dengue vaccine production in low- and middle-income countries such as Indonesia. To address this, we designed an expression system that enables spatially and temporally controlled, high-yield vaccine production by combining the replication mechanism of the Tobacco Yellow Dwarf Virus (TYDV) with the salt-inducible promoter pPdDREG1B for the controlled expression of the DENV-2 envelope protein subunit domain III (EDIII). To expand our repertoire of salt-inducible promoters, we developed NiSPOT, a software tool that classifies and identifies promoters inducible by various stressors, including salt stress. The vaccine protein was optimized using an ESM2-based mutagenesis model to enhance stability. Construct assembly was performed using Golden Gate Assembly and verified via Oxford Nanopore sequencing, followed by transient expression in Nicotiana tabacum through Agrobacterium-mediated agroinfiltration. This system enables precise, inducible control of vaccine protein production in plants.
PIs: Yekti Asih Purwestri, Saifur Rohman, Widhi Dyah Sawitri
advisors: Abdul, Adhityo Wicaksono, Afif Pranaya Jati, Aries Bagus Sasongko, Dewi Kartikawati Paramita, I Made Rhamandana Putra, Imam Bagus Nugroho, Indra Lesmana, Matin Nuhamunada, Setyowati Triastuti Utami
students: Anandita Amalia, Erwinda Dwi Chofifah, Fahmi Ihsanuddin Jauhari, Farrel Alfaza Marsetyo, Farrel Amroe Azhari, Fauzil Azhiim, Iffah, Muhammad Ridwan Adyatama, Naufal, nauvalrajwaa, Ninda Nandita, Pamastadewi Pryankha Hijrianto, Salma Rohmaniah, Shainna Nur, Sophie, Tan Rendy, Tsaqifa, Venus Angela, Yara

title: Oral Health Guardian: Engineered Lactobacillus for Real-Time Monitoring of Dental Caries and Biofilm Removal
abstract: Dental caries is the most common oral disease, with an incidence rate exceeding 70% in the population. The biofilm of dental plaque, formed by Streptococcus mutans (S.m.) and other bacteria, minerals, and food debris through co-aggregation adhesion, is the main culprit in the development of caries. It is particularly concerning that due to a lack of oral health education, the public often fails to recognize the early symptoms of caries. Early caries in hidden areas are even harder to detect, exacerbating the problem. To address these issues, our team has designed a biological system capable of locating and eliminating high-risk plaque biofilms. Specifically, we've integrated the signal reception module of the quorum sensing system, Com system, from S.m. into probiotics (Lactobacilli), creating engineered bacteria. Additionally, we've developed a unique signal amplification system. When the co-aggregated engineered bacteria within the biofilm receive virulence signals from S.m., they trigger the expression of fluorescent proteins and antimicrobial peptides, thereby enabling the localization and elimination of plaque.
PIs: TANG RONGBING, Hui Cai, Dengqi He, Jin He, Miao Yu, Yanqin Zhang, Yongfeng Wang
advisors: BinbinDu, Chenchen Li, Chenkai Luo, Ming Hu, Shenhan Yu, SHIXUN MA, Wenjie Jiang, Xiangdong Niu, Xiaoqiang Si, Xuanqiao Wang, Yan Zhang, Zunqiang Zhao
students: Boyuan Wang, Chenhe Lu, Dan Li, Duanlian Kong, Duo Chen, Evelyn Liang, Jingshu Luo, Kaiyan Liu, Kaiyue Li, Kun Guo, Kun Zhang, Long Pu, Manni Wang, Meng Zhang, qianyiwang, Rui Huang, Rui Zheng, Shuangwei Mao, Wenxuan Shao, Yifan Liu, yifan Mo, Yisong Li, Yu fang, YuqingRao, Yuxin Zeng

title: DiagSyn: Synthetic Multiepitope Proteins for the Accurate Diagnosis of Arboviral Infections
abstract: Dengue, Zika and chikungunya are serious diseases that are spreading worldwide. Although they are currently most prominent in tropical countries, outside travelers can get back home with the disease. Diagnosis is still challenging due to the genetic similarity among Zika (ZIKV), Dengue (DENV), and Chikungunya (CHKV), which cause similar symptoms (fever, muscle pain), and current serological assays are non-specific, significantly hindering proper patient treatment and effective epidemiological control. In this project, by utilizing synthetic biology, we will eliminate the non-specific interactions that cause cross-reactivity in current serological tests. The design of DiagSyn integrates bioinformatics-driven epitope selection with rational linker design, together with the use of structural biology and molecular dynamics tools, to generate diagnostic antigens that accurately reflect the circulating strains while excluding conserved cross-reactive sequences, enabling highly specific detection.
advisors: Bruno Lucena, Juliano de Moraes Rodrigues, Lucas Santiago, NATALIA GRIPP
students: Ananda Campos, ana stephanie, ANA VICTORIA DE HOLANDA NEVES, Clarissa De Souza Chacon, Clarissa Rodrigues de Souza, Ellen, Gabriel Santos, Lucas, Marcelle Pontes, Other, Guilherme

title: VERDE
abstract: Soilless agriculture has been an agricultural market on the rise, which yields up to 50% higher efficiency than soil-based cultivation. VERDE is an antifungal detector that works against fusarium, a common fungus that causes fungal root rot, which poses a significant threat to soilless agriculture. To enhance the specificity of detection and mitigate the scale constraints, VERDE engineers plasmid of E.coli detects low acidity below 4.5 and indicates the infection of Fusarium. The acid-inducible E. coli asr promoter drives co-expression of genes glutaminase (glsA), ?-1-3 glucanase (BGL2), and RsAFP2. These variants in the assembly allows the biosensor to not only detect the presence of Fusarium, but also facilitates its death by producing proteins that disrupts the diffusion of Fusarium: BGL2 and RsAFP2.
advisors: Alexa Seltzer, Angela Kim, Byunghyun Oh, Damini Rosenblatt, Jamie Lee, Kimmy, Mustafo Mustafokulov, Sid Lamaute, Sunyoung Oh
student leaders: Eileen Lee, Eunice, Hamin Park, jamie park, Jina Di, Joanne, Prisha Patel, Sahasra, Talya, Tess R
students: Alexander Khankin, Allen Sinai, Alyson L, andyliu, Ashley, Bekzod, Brandon Park, Derek, Elaina Chang, Eric T, Faiza, Glynnis, Gyuree Ane, Haneul, Irene Lee, Isadore, Jackson, Jayden Kim, Jihoon, Joseph, Julian Han, Justin Y, Kiran Soemardjo, Mia Thomasson, Parviz Abdumuminov, Seoyunp, Yuvan Kothari

title: AQus-HIM - A Quorum-Sensing Biosensor Kit For Hunting Invisible Microplastics
abstract: Identification of microplastics in complex environmental matrices remains a challenge. In this study, we engineered a whole-cell biosensor based on the quorum sensing regulatory circuit LasI-LasR in P. aeruginosa with a reporting module that expressed a LacZ gene. The results demonstrated that our engineered biosensor pSB1C3-LasR-pLasR3-LacZ was highly sensitive to the AHLs with EC50 values as low as 1.0 X 10-8M with N-3-oxo-decanoyl L-homoserine lactone (C10-HSL) and 3.2 X 10-8M with N-3-oxo-dodecanoyl L-homoserine lactone (3OC12-HSL) upon 2 h incubation. The values lie within the average range of AHL concentrations in water environments. Besides, the engineered biosensor is found to be functional in the real tap water environment and seawater without significant matrix effect. In addition, we engineered negative control biosensors by removing the sensing module to reduce background expression of ?-galactosidase activity. Moreover, we developed protocol of quantitative X-gal assay which can be used as a testing kit.
advisors: Anson Ng Wing Hang, Boris Au-Yeung, Ching Lap Fung, Chu Yik Long, Kelvin SH Cheng, Tang Yu Chit, Theodore Leung, Wong Ching Yuen David
students: Anson Au, Bryan Leung, Chan Yan Yin, Clarissa Ho, Daniel Wong, Donovan Cheung, Emmanuel Chan, Hayley Pun, Hinson Ng, Luo Yi, Ngai Tsz Ki, Sean Wong, Yeung Sum Yu, Yolanda Tse

title: TRIAGNOSTICS: Spotting Remission is our Mission
abstract: Breast cancer incidence is rising, primarily in women under 44. Despite being 10% of breast cancer cases, TNBC, a rare and aggressive form, has a higher rate of death (40% of breast cancer-related deaths) and recurrence (~40% of patients) compared to other breast cancers. The absence of progesterone, estrogen, and HER2 receptors means that traditional therapies are ineffective against TNBC. Patients have the best prognosis if the disease is diagnosed early, so to help detect TNBC recurrence, our team is creating a reusable, efficient, and accessible detector system. Our simple liquid biopsy test has a TNBC patient in remission pricks their finger and apply a droplet of blood to a tube with a simple detection device. In the presence of miRNAs 21 and 155 that are indicative of TNBC, toehold switches allow translation of a fluorescent reporter. Our device will be a significant step forward for at-home diagnostic tools.
advisors: Ashwin, PETER EVANS
students: Addie, Alisha, Anna Kyperountas, Cecelia Curtis, Dylan Paoletti, Erick, Ethan Sutherland, Jack, LC, Leopold, May T., Monse, Raquel Showalter, Sharifah Farah, Shumvobi Mitra, Ulysses Frank Matricciani, William Johnson, Wolfgang Heimer

title: CoreSpin: Modified Spidroin Proteins as Thermally Conductive Biomaterials for Heat Exchanger Enhancement
abstract: Heat exchanger biofouling drives global energy usage and greenhouse-gas emissions. Found in essential infrastructure, heat exchangers contain thermally conductive copper plates prone to biofilm formation, which reduces thermal conductivity by up to 98%, increasing energy consumption. Our solution entails coating copper plates with modified spider silk proteins, produced in E. coli, which maintain plate conductivity and repel bacterial adhesion through their nanostructure. Crystalline ?-sheets, flagged by amorphous terminal domains, confer high tensile strength and thermal conductivity to spidroins. ?-sheets were modified to maximise thermal conductivity by increasing size. Terminal domains were modified for copper adhesion through addition of cysteine residues. Protein expression was confirmed with fluorescence imaging, and tested by mass determination and sequencing via LC-MS. Copper adhesion and resulting nanostructure were tested with SEM imaging and ATR-FTIR analysis. This research demonstrates spidroin potential beyond biomedical contexts, providing a sustainable, energy-efficient coating contributing to a cleaner climate and sustainable economy.
nominations: Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Climate Crisis Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
students: Álvaro Terán Ré, Antonin Lew ?migiel, Denise Lemanczyk, Domonkos Barkovits, Efi Tseliou, Fumi Lesné-Akiyama, Jonas Hermans, Katya Mannar, Laurin, Lovro Hranilovi? Petri?i?, Misha Bagirov, Sara Maria Ionescu, Veerle Senkowski, Yu-Wen Chang

title: High-Folate Soybeans - Designing the Next Generation of Folate-fortified Crops
abstract: Folate is a vitamin that functions in DNA synthesis, amino acid metabolism, and various biosynthetic pathways. Folate deficiency is directly associated with diseases like neural tube defects, megaloblastic anemia, cleft lip and palate. Globally, folate deficiency has become a serious public health problem. Industrially synthesized folic acid has poor metabolic efficiency, and the synthesis process causes serious environmental pollution. However, plant folate has high active derivatives, good absorption efficiency, and is sustainable. Therefore, the most effective way to supplement folate is food fortification. This project proposes a scheme for creating high-folate soybeans by integrating biosynthetic elements. Four key folate synthetases were over-expressed in soybean seeds. HPLC-MS detection showed that the enzyme HDFR can double the content of 5-methyl-tetrahydrofolate, the active folate component, which is good for people with genetic defects. Our project has successfully achieved expected goals and exerted extensive impacts in scientific research and society.
advisors: Shuo Huang, Xinyao Wang
