title: SPARK: Signal inducible protein secretion in mammalian cells
abstract: Precise control of protein activity is fundamental to cell engineering and underpins the development of advanced cell-based therapies. While transcriptional and translational regulation provide powerful means of control in mammalian cells, post-translational regulation offers distinct advantages by enabling immediate and reversible responses to external stimuli. Here, we present SPARK (Signal-Programmable Activation of Regulated seCretion), which employs engineered molecular anchors to tether secretory vesicles carrying the target protein to the actin cytoskeleton and release them upon signal induction through protein dissociation or cleavage. We demonstrated that SPARK enabled efficient light- and chemically induced secretion of reporter proteins in HEK293T cells, exhibiting a markedly faster response than traditional transcriptional control systems. This platform provides rapid, tunable, and precise control of protein secretion, establishing a versatile foundation for on-demand therapeutic protein production and other applications that require fast and programmable protein release.
nominations: Best Hardware, Undergrad+Best Education, Undergrad
instructors: Chuanyang Liu, LU Min, Peng Zhang, Shaowei, Wenying Li, Wu Xiaomin
advisors: Chujun Xu, Yilin
students: Chenxi Peng, Handi Yang, Hao Long, Heyi Zhang, Jianfeng Dong, Jiaoxue, Jie Wang, JingBo Zhang, Jin Zhexu, PengYu Zheng, Xutong Zhu, Ye Deng, Yongheng Jiang, Yuening Zhu, Yuhan Song, Zeyu Zhu, Zhou Tong, Zhu Jiangyi, Zihan Zhang, ZiYue Wang

title: BioScent: Transforming Lignin Waste into Vanillin through Synthetic Biology
abstract: Our daily lives depend heavily on paper, yet its production and recycling processes inevitably lead to significant lignin waste. We aimed to harness synthetic biology to transform these wasted resources into valuable products. After extensive consultations with experts in policy, industry, and experimental technologies, we engineered Escherichia coli to convert ferulic acid--a representative lignin degradation product--into high-value compounds. We first demonstrated that E. coli could be adapted, via laboratory-accelerated adaptive evolution, to tolerate simulated lignin degradation liquor. Subsequently, by introducing two key enzymes, CtFCS and CUS, into E. coli, we successfully achieved the bioconversion of ferulic acid into vanillin. Our approach features modularity, transferability, and cost efficiency, making it not only technically feasible but also highly promising for practical application. It highlights the potential of engineered microbes as green and efficient tools for resource recovery, contributing meaningfully to the advancement of circular bioeconomy and sustainable development.
advisors: Alex Wang, Benjamin Yang, Eric Liu, HuiZhang, YeQingwen, Zichen Niu
student leaders: Joyce Huang, Joyce Zhang, Qiuyu Li, XUYIN DAI
students: Belle(Xinyue Tan), Braylon Ryan McCormack, Chijian (Yoyo), Ethan Cai, HeDongdong, Nina Zhou, PEIYISHUN, Ryan Lingrui Zhang, Xiang Ma, YouranLi, Yuanerma Zhao, Zheng XuTong, ???

title: Developing a self-protecting, peptide-presenting and self-eliminating EcN (PPSE)
abstract: The microbiome plays multiple functional roles in human health, sparking interest in utilizing probiotics for disease treatment. As microorganisms can be engineered into intelligent living drugs capable of sensing and responding to their environment, they can colonize the gastrointestinal tract, oral cavity, skin, lungs, and tumors to locally deliver therapeutic agents or transport antigens to activate immune responses. However, bacterial toxicity may limit the dosage and efficacy of engineered bacteria. Therefore, we integrated a microbial encapsulation system, an antigen (drug) delivery platform, and a suicide switch within EcN to construct an engineered EcN system capable of self-protection, peptide drug-presentation, and self-elimination (PPSE).
advisors: Azuo Zhao, Eva, Jian Mo, ZhuoLin Liu
students: Alexa, Angela Han, Angel???, Bella, Flora, Huang yuyan, LI HOULIN, LI JINXUAN, Liu Yinuo, SUN QIANYU, Sunyuxuan, Yiya Xiang, ZHANG JUNYAO, Zoe, ???

title: ExoAPT-CRISPR: A Targeted Detection Platform for Breast Cancer Exosome Biomarkers
abstract: To enable early liquid biopsy for breast cancer, this project developed ExoAPT-CRISPR, an ultra-sensitive and specific integrated detection platform targeting four exosomal proteins (HER-2, PD-L1, MMP-9, EPCAM). The modular platform integrates exosome capture with multistage signal amplification. Magnetic beads conjugated with CD63-specific aptamers achieve efficient, broad-spectrum exosome isolation. Highly active Cas14a protein is expressed and purified via a prokaryotic system, serving as the core detection enzyme. Two isothermal amplification modules, Hybridization Chain Reaction (HCR) and Rolling Circle Amplification (RCA), are designed for each target, converting protein binding events into amplified DNA products. These products function as trigger signals: HCR activates the Cas12a-crRNA complex, while RCA activates the Cas14a-sgRNA complex, enabling reporter cleavage and robust fluorescence generation. This strategy achieves precise molecular recognition and signal conversion, providing an innovative, clinically applicable solution for early breast cancer diagnosis and prognostic monitoring.
advisors: Zhenlong Wang, Zhifeng Pan
student leaders: Chandler Wang, Xinze Li, Yuxiao Zhang
students: Betty, Canyang Wang, jijing Ba, Jing Lei, Mary, Mengyao Yu, Peilin Li, Wenlan Fang, Xiaoran Ji, Yufei Huang, Yutong Liu, Yuxuan Xia, Zhiquan Zhang, Other, Shan Dong

title: Floraguard
abstract: In order to address the rising enviromental crisis of wildfires we set out to create biological flame retardants. We created complexes consisting of a biological flame retardant, a linker domain and then a cellulose binding domain from the cellulosome of Clostridium Thermocellum. These complexes were then expressed in E.coli before being purified and applied to cotton to test their relative flame retardancy.
student leaders: Jade, Jana Chan, Keerthi Atluri, Oliver Stearns, Preethi Mahendrakumar, Riyaan Gunaratne
students: Aidan Briatico, Amy Crook, Ankee, Elizabeth, Helena Morell, Jillian Ryan, Julia Pavlov, Kristina Duong, Lavanya Gupta, Pallavi, Rachel

title: ExoSPY : Exosomes Solutions for Pancreatic cancer
abstract: Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is one of the deadliest cancers, with a five-year survival rate below 10%. Its silent progression and late diagnosis make early detection extremely difficult, leaving patients with limited therapeutic options. Addressing this major clinical challenge, ExoSPY introduces a novel theranostic approach that combines diagnosis and therapy in a single system. Our project uses engineered extracellular vesicles (EVs) produced from HEK293 cells and loaded with nanoparticles that enable both MRI-based detection and X-ray-activated treatment. These vesicles are designed to specifically recognize precancerous pancreatic cells, allowing precise and less invasive targeting. By detecting pancreatic cancer at its earliest stages and providing localized therapy, ExoSPY offers a promising new avenue to improve survival rates and revolutionize PDAC management through synthetic biology and nanotechnology.
advisors: Sébastien, Yacine EL Bichara
students: Chloé Chambard, Guillaume Banon, Heloise, Justine, Lina, Matthieu, Selma Kocier, Thibaut, Yussera

title: Oral, Ultra-long-acting GLP-1-based Therapy with Enhanced Patient Compliance via Gut Probiotics
abstract: This project develops an ultra-long-acting anti-diabetic and anti-obesity therapeutic by engineering the gut probiotic Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 to produce stabilized human-derived GLP-1. Our integrated system employs an AAF sensing circuit for spatiotemporally controlled synthesis, protein engineering with (unnatural) amino acids to enhance circulation stability, an OR-gate biosafety module for programmable biocontainment, and dedicated hardware for intestinal delivery and in vitro characterization. Together, these components enable safe, efficient, and sustained GLP-1 production, offering a novel oral living therapeutic strategy with improved patient compliance.
nominations: Safety and Security Award, Undergrad

title: ARALEX - Autocatalyst Recycling via Advanced Leaching Extraction using oXalate
abstract: Platinum-group metals (PGMs) are critical resources with low recycling rates due to environmentally hazardous and costly conventional leaching processes that rely on harsh chemicals. This project presents an innovative, sustainable approach to PGM recycling using oxalate as a green leaching agent. Our interdisciplinary method combines biotechnological and chemical strategies: genetically modified Corynebacterium glutamicum is engineered to produce and export oxalate into the extracellular environment, providing a biological source of the leaching agent. The chemical process involves dissolving catalyst residues in water, adding the biologically produced oxalate to form PGM-oxalate complexes, and isolating these complexes through water evaporation. This novel biotechnological-chemical approach offers a cost-effective and environmentally friendly alternative to traditional PGM recycling methods, potentially increasing recovery rates while reducing environmental impact. The integration of synthetic biology with green chemistry principles demonstrates a promising pathway toward sustainable critical metal recovery from exhausted automotive catalysts.
nominations: Best Measurement, Overgrad
students: Amasia Schneider Rocha, Amelie Waller, Ayleen Titus, Daniel, Daniel Ringel, Janina Strauß, Johannes Meingast, Julius Stark, Lea Wührl, Manuel Baumann, Nathanael Strom, Nio, Noemi Reusing, Olivia Ronczka, Paul, Theresa, Yazan Ahmad

title: SynTropica - Biomanufacturing of Pineapple Stem Bromelain Across Three Microbial Hosts for Diverse Industries
abstract: Bromelain is a pineapple-derived enzyme mixture with powerful medical, industrial, and cosmetic applications, most notably its ability to selectively remove necrotic tissue in burn wounds through enzymatic debridement. However, extraction of the enzymes from the pineapple stems is costly, inefficient, environmentally unsustainable, and limited by agricultural dependence. SynTropica aims to solve this by producing recombinant stem Bromelain, the main proteolytic enzyme in the mixture, in engineered microbial hosts -- Escherichia coli, Pichia pastoris, and Bacillus subtilis. This production approach has the potential to drastically reduce costs, simplify purification, and enable scalable, consistent manufacturing. In the long term, the team envisions programmable microbial systems that not only secrete Bromelain on demand, but can serve as living bio-platforms for medicine, agriculture, and research.
nominations: Inclusivity Award, Overgrad
instructors: Iser Snoyman, Nova Noiman, Shanny Ackerman
students: Dekel, Elinor Mor, Leeyam, Lihi Lavidor, Matilda Kuliminsky, Noam Almog, Ofri, Ofry Nothmann, Roni Vaizer

title: The Living Pentacone
abstract: Coastal defense structures are important in protecting coastal communities from harsh sea conditions, including huge waves and erosion. However, these structures develop microcracks that progressively expand into larger cavities, compromising structural integrity and endangering coastal populations. Our team addresses this challenge through a multi-faceted approach centered on engineered Vibrio natriegens bacteria that employ biocementation to repair microcracks before they develop into structural failures. We have also designed an optimized coastal structure with enhanced hydrodynamic properties to mitigate erosion more effectively. Our pentacone structure features biosensing capabilities that detect changes in ocean pH and the presence of heavy metals, including mercury, cadmium, and arsenic, providing early warning of environmental deterioration. Coastal degradation often occurs in conjunction with plastic pollution and inadequate ecological monitoring. Our solution integrates educational initiatives to address marine plastic waste. This project integrates synthetic biology and community engagement to design systems that work in harmony with natural processes.
nominations: Best Measurement, Overgrad+Best Education, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad+Best Bioremediation Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
instructors: John Kwesi Tetteh, Rosemond Nyatefe Tawiah

title: Rebuilding Babel: Decode Chaos, Unleash Biosynthetic Treasures
abstract: In the ancient tale of Babel, a unified language shattered into chaos, mirroring DNA's evolutionary fragmentation across trillions of species. This "genetic Babel" hinders discovering Biosynthetic Gene Clusters (BGCs), vast reservoirs of untapped potential hidden in microbes. NJU-China 2025 defies this curse by rebuilding Babel through two towers: the Genetic Tower (BioSHINAR) and the Cognition Tower (Education Space). BioSHINAR leverages AI for a deeper understanding of DNA across three modules--NIMROD for BGC detection, ORACLE for functional prediction, and PENTECOSTA for cluster integration. Validated via DBTL cycles, it excels in mining terpenoid BGCs that elude traditional benchmarks, enabling the discovery of previously unrecognized secondary metabolites. We've completed a robust business plan, with positive company feedback highlighting commercial promise. Complementing this, Education Space enables designing education programs and exchanges to popularize synthetic biology. Through these innovations, we have successfully rebuilt the Tower of Babel of life, unleashing biosynthetic treasures.
nominations: Best Model, Undergrad
PIs: Zhen Zhou, Jing Shi, Yalan Liu

title: Programmable circRNA Switches for Cell?Type?Specific Gasdermin?Based Cancer Therapy
abstract: We present Cellective: a riboswitch-based therapeutic platform that selectively targets cancer cells by detecting specific microRNAs and mRNAs, subsequently translating a cellular kill system. This platform is intended to be further developed specifically for the treatment of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), a particularly aggressive and hard-to-treat form of breast cancer. The selective detection of cancer-specific marker RNAs using the engineered riboswitch RNAs enables a highly specific, minimally invasive therapy that spares healthy cells and is only activated in tumor-relevant contexts. The modular design allows for flexible adaptation to different tumor types and RNA profiles, allowing personalized medicine. We successfully engineered this therapeutic system and confirmed its functionality.
advisors: Anna Baack, Isabell Alexandra Guckes, Kathleen Susat, Kaya Lange, Liliana Sanfilippo, Michael Gröning
students: Ayomikun Dorothea Bolaji, Daliah Rodewald, Fabian Schmitfranz, Hannah Bunte, Jessica Richter, Laura Haeger, Laura Zagami, Marielle Rieks, Max Nolteklocke, Nils Turner, Tim Gerstner

title: Aechmi
abstract: Sepsis is a life-threatening condition caused by the body's extreme response to infection. Each year, it affects 49 million people worldwide and causes 11 million deaths, but early diagnosis greatly improves survival. Aechmi emphasizes patient autonomy, equitable access, and well-being. Its design was shaped through engagement with survivors, clinicians, bioethicists, and marginalized communities. Aechmi integrates a CRISPR/Cas13a-based microRNA detection mechanism with a Catalytic Hairpin Assembly (CHA) amplification circuit. In the presence of bacterial sepsis-associated microRNA biomarkers, selected through machine learning-based data analysis, Cas13a triggers CHA. This produces an electrochemical signal, making our system suitable for future integration into an electrochemical biosensor for real-time monitoring of the biomarkers. The proper functioning of the biological mechanism is verified through modeling based on thermodynamic and kinetic analyses of all the reactions involved.
advisors: Athina Latsi, KonstantinosBazinis, Nikoletta Galanakou, Thodoris Skondras
students: Andreas Katsaros, Despina Panteleon, Grigoris Tzortzakis, Irene Pierrakea, Konstantinos Anastasopoulos, Maria Ilektra Pavli, Maria-Nikolina Kerpinioti, Myrto Xydi, Nefeli Zormpa Sfaellou

title: The PFAS simple detection and degradation system based on engineered E. coli BL21(DE3)
abstract: Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), recognized as "persistent chemicals", exhibit remarkable environmental recalcitrance and widespread distribution in potable water and soil matrices. These compounds pose substantial risks to both human health and ecological equilibrium. Conventional detection methodologies rely on sophisticated instrumental platforms (e.g., liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry, LC-MS), whereas degradation protocols necessitate harsh conditions (e.g., high temperature and pressure), limiting their feasibility for low-cost implementation. Here, we constructed a synthetic biological system in E. coli BL21(DE3) chassis, comprising a PFAS-specific dehalogenation module, a fluoride ion-selective transport apparatus, and a dual-fluorescent reporting system (GFP/mCherry) for integrated real-time visual detection and degradation of PFAS. Furthermore, biosafety is ensured by an arabinose-inducible regulatory circuit controlling the ccdB toxin gene to prevent engineered bacterial dissemination. This approach presents a promising strategy for in-situ bioremediation of PFAS-contaminated wastewater, enabling simultaneous detection and detoxification of these persistent pollutants.
advisors: Ying Zhang, Yue Yu
students: Baoyue Zheng, EnZhou Yang, HYX, Jizhang Yang, Siwei Wang, Yuqian Li, Yuxin Cheng, Zhang Zitong, Zhixuan Li, Zhou Lesi, zxy

title: Harnessing Synthetic Biology for Healthier Flavors: Expression and Validation of Saltiness-Enhancing Peptides in E. coli
abstract: The SaltEnPep project leverages synthetic biology to address the global health challenge of excessive sodium consumption by developing saltiness-enhancing peptides that boost salt perception, enabling sodium reduction in food products without compromising taste. Peptides identified from literature were analyzed using molecular docking and dynamics to predict their interactions with human taste receptors. Selected peptides were cloned into a novel dual-intein chitin-binding domain (CBD) "sandwich" system within the pET-Blank(Kan) vector and expressed in E. coli. The system enabled efficient expression and purification via a thiol-mediated self-cleavage mechanism. Expression conditions were optimized using various IPTG concentrations, and peptide identity and purity were confirmed using Ultra-High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (UHPLC). Sensory evaluation with the ASTREE II electronic tongue showed distinct taste fingerprints and confirmed that peptides enhanced saltiness, especially when combined with NaCl. This work presents the first recombinant, scalable platform for producing salt-enhancing peptides, offering a sustainable solution for sodium reduction in foods.
nominations: Best Food & Nutrition Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Sriram Kumar

title: FluBlockers : Synthetic sentry at the nasal gate-variant-proof armor against Influenza
abstract: Influenza A virus (IAV), characterized by its high mutability and cross-species transmission capability, has triggered multiple global pandemics. Existing vaccines and antiviral drugs face limitations such as short-lived protection, target escape, and drug resistance. To address the critical challenges in respiratory infection prevention, this project employs synthetic biology to engineer nasal-colonizing probiotics (Lactobacillus rhamnosus LGG). By sensing the virus, triggering a cascade response, and ultimately realizing virus neutralization, a multi-module synergistic chain closed-loop defense system is constructed with these probiotics. Additionally, a dual biosafety mechanism is also incorporated, which enables rapid self-destruction triggered by environmental leakage or clinical risk while giving the population the freedom to control intervention. This innovative strategy pioneers a novel synthetic biology-driven approach for influenza control, offering significant public health implications.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Undergrad+Inclusivity Award, Undergrad+Best Infectious Diseases Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Ling Li, Chenguang Shen, Jiang Li, Min Nie, Xu Jiangping

title: GRACE: Ginsenoside-Rh1 from Red Algae to Cosmetic Essence
abstract: We developed an innovative, eco-friendly method to produce rare ginsenoside Rh1 using synthetic biology. By engineering yeast with metabolic pathways from red algae, we efficiently synthesize Rh1, avoiding the environmental harm and high costs of traditional plant extraction or chemical synthesis. This sustainable approach leverages abundant marine resources, ensuring high-quality, affordable skincare products like serums. Our breakthrough paves the way for greener cosmetics and unlocks the potential of marine bioresources.
PIs: Xiaoling Wu, Kai Chen, Wenyong Lou, Xiaofeng YANG
student leaders: Long Zhou, Xiaoyi Cao, Yanzhen Qu, Yaqin Guo, Yue Liu, Yunjian Liu
students: Chengyi Pan, Daichun Li, Hanyun Long, Haolin Wang, Liya Yi, Mingming Guo, Quan Zhong, Sihan Ouyang, Xinyao Xu, Yifei Shi, Yilin Liang, Zilin Li, Ziqi Tan

title: R-Home: mRNA Hepatic Optimized Modules for liver cancer
abstract: Hepatocellular carcinoma poses a severe global burden, with China accounting for nearly half of all cases. Current therapies face challenges in specificity, resistance, and cost. To overcome these limitations, R?Home presents an integrated mRNA platform for precise HCC treatment. Our unified mRNA system enables dual-protein regulation, restoring tumor suppressor HNF4? while degrading oncogenic TGF?? via p-PROTAC. We enhance specificity through GPC3-targeted LNPs and miR-21-responsive RNA switches (exCAG and eukaryotic toehold), ensuring tumor-selective expression. The platform also features optimized 5?UTRs and a spatial PK/PD model predicting drug behavior in tumors. We provide this complete system to the iGEM community, including a standardized Part Collection with optimized UTRs, eukaryotic RNA switches, and targeted delivery components, along with open-source computational models and hardware specifications - collectively advancing the development of accessible and precise cancer therapies,paving the way for accessible and precise cancer therapies.
PIs: Jun Yang, Jiaqi Lin, Du shubo, Lihan Zi
advisors: Jiangang Ren, JiaYangZhang, Liming Ma, Shengshuo Guo, Siheng Cheng, Xinghuan Ma, Yi Jin, Ying Li
students: Bowen Yang, Chenxu Zha, Diallo, Haolin Zhan, Jingyu Xia, Kang Dawei, KongYuting, Luyao Wang, Qingxin Hu, Ruiqi Tian, Rui Wang, Ruizhe Wu, Tao Zhu, Wenyu Yao, Xiangcheng Cui, Yang Lu, Yihan Xu, Yuhan Wang, Yuqi Jiang, Yushan Wang, Yuying Li, Zihan Zheng, Zixuan Lin

title: Antibacterial Blue Light Therapy for Gastric Cancer
abstract: To combat Helicobacter pylori antibiotic resistance and gastric cancer, we developed an engineered living therapeutic platform. It uses an attenuated H. pylori chassis with natural gastric targeting, integrating luminescence, quorum sensing, and bio-safety modules. Surface-loaded with Chlorin e6 (Ce6) and a lux operon, the bacteria are activated by near-infrared light to generate reactive oxygen species and blue-light phototoxicity, inducing tumor cell apoptosis. A quorum-sensing circuit triggers light emission at a high population density, activating endogenous porphyrins in wild-type H. pylori for a "bystander killing" effect, which also self-regulates the engineered population. For bio-safety, a hypoxia-responsive suicide switch ensures bacterial survival in the stomach but causes programmed death in oxygenated environments. Encapsulated in an oral liposomal delivery system, this platform offers a novel paradigm for overcoming antibiotic resistance and achieving precision gastric cancer therapy.
advisors: aowuawu, Charles, Hou Wanning, Huizi Chen, Jialin Yang, Jian Liang, Linzhao He, Rujian Wu, Yuanpeng Li, Yunfan Zhang, Zhang Sheng
students: candiceee, Flourish, Huang ping, Huiyu Tang, Jenson, Lanlan, Liu Wenxuan, Miao, Olivia, RiMing Liu, Xiaogan, zhaokeyinggg, zhuyuanjie111, Zongyu Sun, Zuo Miyu, ???

title: PhAgri
abstract: Bacteria are widespread, and bacterial crop diseases cause annual devastating agricultural damage. CAU-China 2025 builds PhAgri, a SMART phage-like particle (PLP) platform?it can precisely target and kill pathogenic bacteria without accidentally harming other. Meanwhile, since PhAgri has no self-replication ability, its safety is effectively guaranteed. Using E. coli MG1655, we developed a delivery system, tail fiber replacement platform, and Alphage software for flexible antibacterial spectrum reprogramming. We hope that when PhAgri moves beyond the laboratory, it can be cultivated and used independently by farmers. By providing them with eco-friendly and highly effective pesticides, PhAgri will align with multiple Sustainable Development Goals. In the future, we anticipate that PhAgri will not only safeguard food security, but also enable the synthesis of artificially designed bacteriophages through predictive modification of tail fiber proteins--ultimately solving all potential bacterial problems.
nominations: Best Agriculture Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Na Wang, Jian Jiao, Jingrui Li, Jinshui Yang

title: Enteroplastivore
abstract: With the widespread use of plastic products, a large amount of plastic waste gradually decomposes and breaks down, forming plastic fragments with a diameter of less than 5 millimeters, namely microplastics. Microplastics are difficult to decompose naturally and gradually accumulate in the human body. Microplastics can cause imbalance in the intestinal flora, trigger systemic inflammatory responses, and even potentially lead to tumors and cancers. Regarding the issue of how to remove microplastics from the human body, our team proposed to construct a symbiotic system of lactic acid bacteria and yeast, which secretes degrading enzymes to degrade the microplastic particles in the intestinal tract. In addition, this system can also regulate the balance of intestinal flora, enhance the intestinal barrier function, and reduce the oxidative stress caused by microplastics through antioxidant effects, thereby minimizing the possible damage to the body caused by microplastics.
PIs: Shi Hu, Changhai Lei, Ruixue Mao, ShanYang
advisors: Ruibing Chen, Shichong,Yu
student leaders: Qixing Xia, Xinyu Shen, Xuanrong Liu
students: Anqi Hu, Chencan Fang, Haoye Li, Jiatong Li, Meng Sun, Ruiyang Yu, Shen Zhao, Shitao Chen, Shiyu Tang, Wanxin Ren, Wenxi Liu, Xichen Fu, Yijie,Chen, Zhechuan Fang, Ziqi Wang

title: A.L.G.E.A
abstract: Heavy metal pollution poses a growing threat to both ecosystems and human health due to industrial activity. To address this challenge, our iGEM team is engineering the cyanobacterium Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 as a sustainable platform for heavy metal bioremediation. We have introduced genes encoding phytochelatin synthases (PCSs) and metallothioneins (MTs) under a urea-inducible promoter, enabling the cells to efficiently chelate and reduce metals ions such as cadmium, lead, zinc, and copper into nano particles. To reduce the harvest cost, we developed a self-aggregation system by inducing limonene production, allowing for energy-efficient and chemical-free biomass recovery. In parallel, we are expressing PCS and MT genes in the moss Physcomitrella patens to compare bioremediation performance in different chassis.
PIs: Murdoch Mackay, Jixiao Wu, Lei Yingjie
advisors: Zhongyi Lyu
student leaders: Chenghao Bian, Dingxuan He, Mingda Wang, Suyu Gou
students: AlexChen, Cao zihui, Celine Meng, Cissyxu, Haoyun Zheng, Jiang Yuhan, Jiarui Gao, Jinlei Wang, Leyi Huang, Norman Xu, Ruoduan Sun, Xiaoyu Jiang, Yiyi Yao, Yutian Cai, Yuzhong, zishan Huang, Ziyan Wang, ???

title: The development of a proof of concept for a continuous lactate monitor
abstract: Our aim is to develop a wearable biosensor that continuously monitors lactate concentration in the interstitial fluid. The current method to measure lactate levels widely used by professional athletes requires blood sampling through invasive needles and the use of disposable strips, disrupting training flow. Building on the success of continuous glucose monitors, our device will embed lactate?oxidizing enzymes (e.g., lactate dehydrogenase) within a microneedle array to catalyze lactate in dermal interstitial fluid into pyruvate and hydrogen peroxide. An integrated electrode will then oxidize the generated hydrogen peroxide, producing electrons whose current correlates directly with lactate concentration. By tracking these electrical signals in real time, athletes can optimize training and recovery on the run while reducing recurring costs and biological waste. During our project, we have expressed and immobilized the enzyme and verified them through electrochemical detection techniques to present a proof on concept.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Overgrad+Best Wiki, Overgrad
PIs: Dirk Linke, Athanasios Saragliadis, Kirsten Borse Haraldsen
students: Alan Samrend, Amanda Frøynes, Diego Salazar, Eline, Forough, Jon Einar Rydsaa, Khayal, Peder, Phelix

title: CinderLight----Enzymatic Upcycling of PET Waste and Kitchen Waste to Supramolecular Phosphorescent Materials
abstract: Facing the dual environmental challenges of plastic pollution and food waste, this project proposes an innovative green upcycling strategy. We employ highly efficient biocatalysts--TurboPETase and cyclodextrin glycosyltransferase (CGTase)--to depolymerize waste PET plastic into a terephthalic acid (TPA) derivative and convert starchy kitchen waste into ?-cyclodextrin (?-CD), respectively. Subsequently, these two products are assembled via supramolecular host-guest interactions to form a novel PPA-CD supramolecular phosphorescent material. This entire process operates under mild conditions, achieving the green and high-value valorization of two low-value waste streams into a functional material. It pioneers the simultaneous integration of plastic and food waste within a single system, offering a new pathway for sustainable material development and waste resource utilization.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, Undergrad+Best Measurement, Undergrad
PIs: Zhao David Yang, Wenchao Geng, Bian Wu
advisors: Gim, Jincheng Liu, QianZi Dong, Yating Li, Yinhao Wang, Yiqun Liu
student leaders: Sihui Wei, Yiran Xu, Zhaohui Zhang, Zibin Chu

title: Detective engineering bacteria: Let Pseudomonas aeruginosa have no place to hide in water.
abstract: Escherichia coli was genetically engineered to construct a dual-modal biosensor responsive to quorum sensing signaling molecules. The engineered bacteria carry a Pseudomonas aeruginosa-specific promoter that drives the expression of ?-galactosidase and ?-glucuronidase, which hydrolyze the substrates ONPG (o-nitrophenyl-?-D-galactopyranoside) to produce a yellow color and MUG (4-methylumbelliferyl-?-D-glucuronide) to emit fluorescence, respectively. This enables the qualitative and quantitative detection of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
PIs: Jinshui Lin, Guoliang Chen, Juanli Cheng, Shengjun Gao, Yan Li
instructors: Dandan Liu, Jiajia Qiao, Jiaxin Dong, Shengli Li, Shiyu Bai, Wanqing Ning, Wei Xiao, Xuning Liu, Zhiying Li
students: Jiajia Han, Jiaqi Ma, Jiaxuan Ma, Linrui Kang, Meiqing Zou, Shengxuan Bian, Shoukai Wang, Shuyu Zhang, Tingting Wang, Wangyang Teng, Xiaxin Zhang, Xinru Li, Xinyu Wu, Yi Wang, Yizhe Liu, Yuchuan Chen, Yufeng Hu, Yuxi Lin

title: AGEs Robber: Restoring Freedom for Diabetic Foot Ulcer Patients
abstract: Diabetes affects 589 million people globally, with 18.6 million new DFU cases yearly. DFUs cause infection, necrosis, and amputations, severely impacting life quality. Our project, AGEs Robber, integrates treatment and prevention. We created a hydrogel patch using soluble RAGE (sRAGE) to capture AGEs, reduce chronic inflammation, and promote healing while offering antibacterial and exudate-absorbing functions. For prevention, we conducted community outreach and designed a simple foot-monitoring device for early wound detection. This approach aims to reduce infection and amputation risks, healthcare costs, and improve DFU patients' quality of life.
PIs: Chun Ying Yu, Ching HUNG, Ching-Chieh Weng
advisors: Ahmed M. Amin, Chen Yan Su, Ginger Lin, WenJung Tsai
students: Brent, I-HUI WANG, JHIH-YI WU, Kun-Yuan Huang, Li Lin, passion, Ta-Hung Ke, Tina, Tyler, Yi-Hao Chen, Yu-Ching Wong, Yu-Yan Qiu

title: Temperature-controlled One-step Synthesis of Colored Bacterial Cellulose
abstract: The textile industry, as an important sector of fashion industry, is the second largest pollution source in the world. Traditional textile manufacturing processes, which separate fiber production from dyeing, are highly water-intensive and incompatible with the principles of sustainable fashion. To address these challenges, our project developed an integrated system for bacterial cellulose weaving and dyeing using E.coli. We have achieved one-step synthesis of colored bacterial cellulose through temperature regulation. This project aims to overcome the limitations of bacterial cellulose expressed in E.coli and endow it with hydrophobic properties. It provides a solution for the fashion industry that integrates functional aesthetics with environmentally friendly choices.
PIs: Jiandong Jiang, Chen Xi, Qun Zhang
instructors: Chun yan shao, Dongli Sun, Fang Huang, Jiayi Ren, Liang He, queligang, Rong Feng, Tao wan, Wang Jin, Wang Jufang, Yuanyuan Liu, Zhao Jing

students: Hejie wang, Jiangheng Wu, Jiaqi Li, Kun Zhang, Linhui Hu, Qichen Zhang, Tingting Zhang, Xiang Feng, Xiaoning Sun, Yangliu Dai, Yima Wang, Yixing Li, Yuchuan Qiu, Zhangqi Zheng

title: REACT - A Highly Sensitive Aptamer Based Biosensor for the Detection of Renal Distress
abstract: Globally, 15% of all kidney transplants face acute rejection, often before symptoms are noticeable. Contemporary detection methods are often done too late and face tradeoffs between invasiveness, accuracy, portability, and cost-effectiveness. We present REACT, a portable and highly sensitive point of care diagnostic for the early-onset detection of kidney rejection. REACT senses two known biomarkers of kidney distress, NGAL and CXCL-9, and uses Rolling Circle Amplification to boost signal output. A G4 DNAzyme functionalized on a reduced Graphene Oxide surface coupled with paper microfluidics allows for a multiplexed colorimetric detection, facilitated by our smartphone app to quantify and interpret the readout. Given the portable nature of REACT, users can use it outside of a hospital setting, allowing for early at-home detection of kidney rejection. This shortens the length of post-transplant hospital stay and decreases the risk of complications resulting from an untreated rejection.
nominations: Best Measurement, Undergrad+Best Diagnostics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
student leaders: Anh Bui, Ashley Qian, Derin Sayin, Fanxiao Liu, Hassan Hassan, Jacob Stotland, Jiawen Ren, Morgan Puusaari, Myra Godara, Navid Farkhondehpay

title: A Bio Synthesis Ode to Van Gogh's Irises
abstract: iRIS is a living ode to Van Gogh's Irises--where synthetic biology becomes a brushstroke, and engineered E.coli bloom in chromatic light. Guided by refined RGB-sensing circuits, these microscopic artists synthesize 6,6'-dibromoindigo, 4,4'-dinitroindigo and indigo, under precise red/green/blue illumination, painting not merely pigments, but a symphony of co-creation with life. Beyond its aesthetic beauty, iRIS bridges synthetic biology and aesthetic education, transforming laboratories into studios where genes and colors compose together. By lowering the threshold of art-making through living systems, we seek to reimagine bio-art as a democratic form of creativity, accessible to diverse communities. Our project thus highlights both the technical feasibility of programmable pigments and the cultural value of engaging the public in a dialogue between life sciences and the arts.
instructors: Bo Wang, Hongyu Shen, Sainan An, Yinghua Cao
advisors: Haobo Cao, Junjie Liao, Wendan Zheng, Yifei Lyu
student leaders: KE WANG, Mai Yuyi, pengxi, ZhangJin
students: Bingliang Liu, Cao xiaoning, Chen Liting, Fang Xiaohan, Huang Yifei, jiaming Zhu, Jiying Chen, LiAnna, Liu Rundong, LIUYU, Li XiaoQing, LI YOUAN, Li ziyu, LU YIMIN, Rong Xiaonan, Tian Yi, Wang Wenjie, WangXiyu, WangYanbing, Wei Siruo, Xiong Ruirong, Yu Zili, Zhou Chenxi

title: EnzyCaps
abstract: Digestive health disorders affect millions worldwide, posing a major public health challenge. While digestive enzyme supplements offer temporary relief, they are often unsustainable, unscalable, and may trigger allergenicity. To address this, we developed EnzyCaps--a biomanufacturing platform that uses bacterial microcompartments (BMCs) within recombinant E. coli to produce and encapsulate digestive enzymes. Our system integrates three key features: a tightly inducible promoter for precise gene regulation, BMC-based compartmentalization, and peptide tags for targeted enzyme encapsulation. This living micro-factory enables modular, tunable, and sustainable enzyme production, overcoming limitations of traditional plant- or animal-based sources. EnzyCaps represents a step forward in sustainable synthetic biology, combining stability, efficiency, and scalability for improved digestive wellness and energy enhancement.
student leaders: Gaurav Yadav, Jacob, Naman Kohli, Prateechi
students: Aman Kumar, Amogh, Anushree, Ayaan, Ganji Srinath, Jay Kumar, Manya Gupta, Manya Kansal, Moksha, Nivesh, Parth Rajput, Suzanne Jolly, Urvija Gulati, Vaishnavi Saxena

title: Enzymatic Control using Logic-Based Inducible Promoter System Engineering
abstract: Many biological systems are limited by regulation and functionality. Conventional inducible systems that rely on conditional control tend to be stochastic and offer little tunability. Furthermore, many wild-type enzymes display poor catalytic efficiency or stability when expressed in heterologous hosts. Here, we present ECLIPSE (Enzymatic Control using Logic-Based Inducible Promoter System Engineering), a genetic framework that integrates multi-layered regulation with synthetic enzymology. We combine inducible repressor-operator systems with CRISPRi-based dCas9-sgRNA repression to achieve both conditional ON/OFF switching and fine-tuned, graded control of gene expression respectively. We also optimised our effector enzyme through two complementary approaches - host optimization and rational mutagenesis. We then apply this framework to treat hypercholesterolemia, engineering E. coli Nissle to express ECOP170 for the in-situ breakdown of dietary cholesterol. Our probiotic platform thereby acts as a proof-of-concept that bridges precise genetic regulation with optimized enzymatic function, offering a generalizable strategy for designing programmable and robust systems.
advisors: CO, Derek Yuen
students: Bing Heng, Christine, Dominic Tan, Edison, Ian, Jun Rui Ting, Liu Peixuan, Li Yihan, Ng Yao Ting, Raj, Samuel Foo Enze, Serene Chai, Zi Jia

title: Hepzero: supressing the expression of HBV genes
abstract: 254 million people are living with chronic HBV. Every thirty seconds, HBV silently takes one life. A vaccine exists, and it works. But what about people already living with HBV? For them, there is no cure. The reason lies in a molecular structure called cccDNA, it can persist for years in the nucleus and is untouched by immune responses or existing therapies. This persistence is what makes HBV so difficult to cure. But we've engineered a system to change that. Hepzero is a dual-CRISPR design that targets cccDNA. Two engineered guide RNAs pair through a kissing loop to bring two dCas proteins to key regulatory regions. These RNA-RNA interactions greatly increase the chance of precise, simultaneous binding, enabling safer repression of viral activity. In this way, we block HBV gene expression and replication without cutting DNA, leaving the host genome unharmed, aiming for a one?time intervention rather than life?long therapy.
advisors: Gleb Skorokhodov, Sun Ruijia, Tang Yongxi
students: Cai Zejun, Egor Nikitin, FILIPPOVA ALISA, Kexin Zhao, Nikita Bondarchuk, Valeriia Iudicheva, Vasilevskaia Polina, VASILII TALACHANOV, Xiaonan Ma, Xiong Lingxuan, Zeng Xiaohan, Zhang Jiahui, Zhao Mingze

title: SynBeeGee
abstract: Bees are vital to global food production, yet their populations are collapsing at alarming rates. One of the main culprits is organophosphate pesticides, which disrupt bees' nervous systems and drive widespread colony losses. Our project, SynBeeGee, tackles this crisis by working directly with the bee gut microbiome. We focus on Snodgrassella alvi, a natural and stable gut symbiont, and engineer it using recombinant DNA methods to carry the organophosphate degradation (opd) gene. This gene encodes an enzyme that breaks down toxic pesticides into harmless byproducts, reducing their deadly impact on bees. Through Golden Gate Assembly and electroporation, we introduce this genetic circuit into S. alvi, creating a living pesticide-detoxifying partner. Unlike external treatments, this microbial ally persists inside the bee, spreads throughout the hive, and transfers engineered traits to offspring microbiomes, extending protection across generations. SynBeeGee offers a sustainable, self-sustaining defense for pollinators, agriculture, and the ecosystems we all depend on.
students: Aigerim D, Alexander, Judith M, Sam T, Shammah, Wikrama, YingLin, Other, Atishay

title: MAMORI: Modular Agricultural Monitoring for On-Site Rapid Pest Identification
abstract: Mangoes are both culturally and economically vital for Okinawa, small islands in southern Japan. However, Okinawan mango production is now under serious threat from yellow tea thrips. To address this challenge, our team developed MAMORI: Modular Agricultural Monitoring for On-site Rapid Pest Identification. MAMORI enables strain-level discrimination of thrips--essential for selecting effective pesticides--as well as early, unmanned detection, outbreak prediction, and coordinated island-wide strategy formulation. Our system combines LAMP-based molecular detection with a paper-based microfluidic device. We also designed automated hardware to trap insects, extract DNA, analyze results, transmit data, and replace test papers without human intervention. Furthermore, we built a predictive model that integrates outbreak data across Okinawa to forecast thrips population dynamics. With MAMORI, we aim to protect Okinawan mangoes, support sustainable agriculture on small islands, and provide a model for scalable, community-driven pest management.
students: Bakhytzhan, Faezeh, Hamzah, Hina, Jun, Mai, Shin, Shinnosuke, Shion Kinjo, Sora.N, Wahei, Youjung, Yuuna Hitani, Other, Edith

title: Microbial Biosynthesis of Triterpenoid Ambrein Using Engineered Escherichia coli
abstract: Ambergris, a rare fragrance fixative produced in the digestive tract of sperm whales (Physeter macrocephalus), is highly valued in perfumery but raises ethical and environmental concerns due to its scarcity and link to illegal trade. To address this, Team VIT-Vellore aims to biosynthesize ambrein, the key triterpenoid component of ambergris, using engineered Escherichia coli. By integrating squalene synthase, squalene-hopene cyclase, and tetraprenyl ?-curcumene cyclase into the MEP pathway, our system converts farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP) into ambrein through a renewable, controlled process. This bio-based approach provides an ethical, consistent, and eco-friendly alternative to whale-derived ambergris. Aligned with UN SDGs 12, 14, 4, and 17, our project fosters responsible innovation, marine conservation, education, and inclusivity. Through open-access learning and interdisciplinary collaboration, VIT-Vellore envisions a future where biotechnology unites sustainability, ethics, and creativity to transform the fragrance industry.
advisors: Dr Sajtiha, Dr Sudha, D S NISHANTH, Kannan, Sen
students: Advin, Afnan, Atharva Purohit, Kevin Paul, Kunjal Ningoo, Manas Kulkarni, Namyaa, Riya S, Shwetha, Srinidhi Kannan, Suganth GS, Suhas, Vivek

title: HepaSwitch
abstract: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the most common and lethal cancers, with limited effective therapies. Our project, HepaSwitch, aims to develop a selective mRNA-based therapeutic system that induces pyroptosis exclusively in HCC cells. The system utilizes a toehold switch--a synthetic RNA regulator--designed to recognize HCC-specific biomarkers, such as alpha-fetoprotein mRNA. Upon detection, the switch activates translation of gasdermin, a pore-forming protein that triggers pyroptotic cell death. Using computational modeling, we optimized the toehold switch structure for minimal leakiness and high dynamic range. Experimental validation in vitro demonstrated specific activation in the presence of the target RNA and no significant expression in its absence, confirming its precision and safety potential. HepaSwitch represents a novel approach to RNA-based precision oncology, offering a programmable and modular framework for targeted cancer treatment adaptable to various tumor types.
students: Andrzej Rzepko, Anna Szymik, Bartek ?uszczuk, Daniel Grygorowicz, Dominika Kraso?, Helena Ku?micz, Julia Gryszpanowicz, Julia Lewicka, Kacper Ko?luk, Micha? Stanowski, Paulina Gole?, Stanislaw Golebiewski, Stanis?aw Szleszkowski, Wiktoria Szymanek

title: FABRIC----Fabrication through Advanced Bioengineered Resources and Integrated Chromatics
abstract: The expression of style and personality through fashion colors is often shadowed by the heavy discharge of wastewater and the reliance on toxic fixatives. Our FABRIC project, however, utilizes synthetic biology to envision a cleaner, greener future. We engineered yeast strains to synthesize primary bio-dyes and developed a protein mordant that binds these dyes tightly to the fabric, effectively replacing chemical fixatives. Finally, the yeast's light-inducible system work in concert with our custom-developed hardware to empower users in realizing their ultimate fashion vision, establishing a truly sustainable dyeing solution.
nominations: Best Hardware, Undergrad+Best Fashion & Cosmetics Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: guo junqi, Jiawei Hou, Jiayi Zheng, Jinbao Yin, Jinbei Mu, Junjie Lai, Qiyue Xiang, Wenda Qian, XiangJie, Yifan Wang, Yinzhe Ma

students: Boxiong Yu, CHIKEI CHIO, Feiya Su, Hao Wang, Jingyun Wei, Junye Li, Lin Liu, Minzhi Li, Mohan Zhao, Shizhe Luo, Siyu Li, Wei Xitong, Wentao Xu, Xiaodong Li, Xingyi Chen, Yifei Wang, Yuejin Wang, Yufei Jia, Yundi Zhao, Zifu Tang

title: REDAPT: Retron-Engineered Degranulation Alleviation Platform for Therapeutics
abstract: The University of Oregon iGEM 2025 team introduces REDAPT, a novel therapeutic platform that uses retrons to synthesize therapeutic DNA aptamers in-vivo to mitigate gut inflammation in Mast Cell Activation Disorders (MCAD). The project involves three engineering goals. First, a histamine-sensing circuit regulates aptamer secretion using a characterized histamine riboswitch in a cell lysis system. Second, retrons are engineered to reverse transcribe ssDNA aptamers inside bacterial cells; a fluorescent aptamer expressed within a modular Eco-2 retron cassette serves as proof of concept. Third, a histidine permease from Pseudomonas putida is expressed to transport histamine into cells, triggering aptamer release. Together, these components allow engineered bacteria to accumulate and secrete ssDNA aptamers in response to high levels of histamine. With further refinement, REDAPT could be used to deliver therapeutic aptamers such as X35 in situ in the gastrointestinal tract.
advisors: Emily Sverdrup, Natanya Villegas, Russell McLoughlin
students: Abigail Firman, Alex, David Curtis, faris, Favour, Haley Mae Lohf, John, Landen, Preeyapat Wisetmongkolchai, Samantha Tan, Sophia Foerster

title: Metabolic Engineering of Saccharomyces cerevisiae for the Biosynthesis of Linalool (3,7-dimethylocta-1,6-dien-3-ol) and Nerolidol (3,7,11-trimethyl-1,6,10-dodecatrien-3-ol)
abstract: Adolescent anxiety has become a pressing public health concern, with Greece reporting the highest rates of anxiety in the European Union. Current pharmacological and therapeutic approaches are often limited by side effects, accessibility, or cost, highlighting the need for innovative alternatives. We aimed to engineer Saccharomyces cerevisiae to produce linalool and nerolidol, two naturally occurring terpene alcohols, known for their anxiolytic properties. We introduced overexpressed Erg20p and AcNES1 into Saccharomyces cerevisiae BY4741. Following fractional distillation between 78-131 °C the desired compounds were purified and steamed for our essential oil. This exploration provided insights into the feasibility of producing these terpenoids in yeast and highlighted considerations for further optimization. This approach offers a potential foundation for developing cost-effective and sustainable methods to support natural interventions for adolescent anxiety.
students: Cleopatra, Electra, Eleni, Mara, Matteo

title: LumaManta: a one-stop, continuous, spatiotemporal aquatic information-detecting device for ecological system.
abstract: To better PROTECT, we must first DETECT. LumaManta, developed by ZJU-China, is an all-in-one bio-intelligent underwater device for continuous spatiotemporal detection and treatment of aquatic environments. Aiming to advance environmental conservation, it integrates four biological modules--Detection, aTF Production, Treatment, and Algae-Bacteria Symbiosis--within a manta-ray-inspired body to achieve autonomous ecosystem monitoring. The Detection Module employs a cell-free biosensing system using DNA strand displacement, and PSR amplification to detect metal ions, biomolecules, and eDNA in real time. The aTF Production Module applies AI-assisted protein reprogramming to expand sensing specificity, while the Treatment Module uses protein scaffolds for pollutant absorption and molecular collection. The Symbiosis System maintains a cyanobacteria-E. coli co-culture for CO? fixation and nutrient cycling, enabling sustainable, long-term operation. LumaManta represents a new paradigm for bio-driven conservation technology--turning detection into the first step toward sustainable protection of aquatic life.
advisors: Haoyang Liu, Xuanhao Wang
student leaders: Xiangjun Hu, Yiyang Zhao, Zijin Fan, Zixin Lin
students: Boyue Zhang, Gefanyue, Haoran Gao, Jiayi Li, Mingtao Zhang, Silei Zhang, Tianci Cao, Tingting Liu, Yihui Wu, Yuhu Sheng

title: HpBusters: Engineered Probiotic Yeast Equipped with the Target-Adhere-Eradicate System
abstract: Halitosis, nausea, and bloating--these are discomforts that people with Helicobacter pylori (Hp) infection suffer from every day. As the culprit of chronic gastric diseases, Hp has infected over half of the global population. In 2025, integrating probiotic engineering with micromotor delivery, the Peking team constructed HpBusters. The sensing-and-therapy system and the adhesion system were designed and implemented in genetically modified Saccharomyces boulardii to sense the biomarker N?-methylhistamine, and while adhered to Hp, to secrete the biofilm-degrading enzyme AiiA. Micromotors, based on calcium carbonate, propel the encapsulating pH-responsive microgels through the gastric mucus barrier, releasing probiotics directly at infection sites. Models were established to comprehensively evaluate and simulate the efficiency of HpBusters across all processes. Human practices were conducted to forge connections between our project and society. We hope this antibiotic-free strategy enables targeted reaction, biofilm eradication and long-term protection, offering Hp-infected patients a comfortable yet effective therapeutic alternative.
nominations: Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad+Best Infectious Diseases Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Yimang Xu, Yiyan Liao, Yufei Zhao, Zewei Song
students: Haoping Li, Jiajun Chen, Jianzhe Li, Jiawen Tian, Jingyi Zhang, Rayray, Roger Liu, Xiaoming Wang, Yan Chen, Yihan Cheng, Yihao Chen, Yuhang Chen, Yunfei Huang, Zhilan Mu, Zi'ang Xu

title: Healing Fish Hearts with Leech Medicine
abstract: Heart disease is the number one cause of death in humans. But fish can also suffer from heart problems-especially in fish farms, where sick fish often go unnoticed. Many fish die from blood clots inside their bodies, and farmers cannot easily tell what caused it. Our team is studying a special molecule called hirudin, which comes from leeches. Hirudin stops blood from clotting and has been used to treat human heart disease for over 100 years. We want to know: can hirudin also help fish? We Identified hirudin genes from 12 types of leeches. We then converted these genes into genetic parts that can be used by all iGEM teams to do research on. Our own research shows that synthetic hirudin from these genes have the potential to help fish live longer and healthier lives in farms. We hope it will improve fish farming around the world.
advisors: Alaaeddine skouri, Alex Pu, Astrid, Mr.Kuchkarov, Shann He
students: amywang, Arther, Bernice Hung, Carson, Cecily Yang, Cindy, Fantasia, hardy, Holdwent, Jacelyn, Maggie, Nora Song, Wyman, Yoyo, Other, Sam

title: V-CHARGEs: VLP-Coupled High-efficiency ATP Re-Generating Enzyme system
abstract: ATP is essential for biosynthetic reactions but costly for large-scale applications. Polyphosphate kinase (PPK) can regenerate ATP from inexpensive polyphosphate (PolyP), yet its industrial use is limited by phosphate inhibition and poor stability. The BNU iGEM team developed V-CHARGEs (VLP-Coupled High-efficiency ATP Re-Generating Enzyme system), an innovative platform that integrates SlPPK with P22 virus-like particles (VLPs) and SpyTag/SpyCatcher coupling to achieve efficient ATP regeneration. By encapsulating SlPPK inside VLPs for protection and anchoring ATP-consuming enzymes outside, V-CHARGEs enables continuous ATP cycling with enhanced pH, portease and phosphate tolerance. This nanoconfined system provides a low-cost, stable, and modular solution for powering diverse ATP-dependent biosynthetic reactions, advancing sustainable biomanufacturing.
nominations: Best Part Collection, Undergrad+Best Education, Undergrad
instructors: Dong Yang, Junjie Zhang, Ruchun Tang
advisors: Jiayi Jiang, Ruiyao Xu, Xing Zhang
student leaders: Jintong Li, Xuan Zhang, Yuxuan Sun

title: The Elf Catcher of "Super Fungus"
abstract: To address the "super fungus" Candida auris (multidrug-resistant, highly pathogenic, high mortality), this project uses Acidovorax citrulli's unique fungus-killing T6SS--unlike most T6SS that only target Gram-negative bacteria. Its structural components are reconstructed in E. coli BL21 as anti-C. auris engineered bacteria, formulated as lyophilized powder and activated via arabinose-containing hydrogel. A pH-sensitive promoter (Pasr) enhances specificity in C. auris' acidic environment. A pBAD/pDUSK-regulated suicide switch controlling T6SS immunity proteins restricts survival to the hydrogel's dark, arabinose-rich environment (blue light induces death), ensuring self-elimination outside and allowing controlled death timing. Wet-lab models predict optimal parameters; improved effector delivery boosts targeting, offering an innovative treatment.
nominations: Best Model, Undergrad+Best Presentation, Undergrad+Best Wiki, Undergrad+Best Infectious Diseases Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Tao Dong, Chunhong Yu, Min Zhang
advisors: Hongqian Zhang, Qikun Gao, YUEN, Man Leuk

Caiyao, chaoxu, JackLiew, Jason, Lydia, Rose

title: FloraSynse: Personalized Detection of Vaginal Dysbiosis Using Whole-Cell Biosensors and Electronic Sensing
abstract: This project aims to advance women's health by developing an at-home diagnostic tool for continuous monitoring of vaginal health, with a specific focus on bacterial vaginosis (BV), a condition impacting nearly one in three women. Current diagnostic methods provide only a single-timepoint assessment, failing to capture the dynamic fluctuations of the vaginal microbiome. To address this gap, we propose a longitudinal monitoring approach that enables daily sampling and trend analysis. Our prototype integrates two key sensing modalities: a biosensor that detects putrescine, a biological amine associated with BV, and an optical pH sensor that provides complementary information about overall vaginal health. By tracking these biomarkers over time, we aim to generate a data-driven and personalized model of vaginal health, offering users deeper insight into microbiome dynamics and earlier detection of vaginal dysbiosis.
advisors: Juan Jose Robayo Yepes, Kristen Sheldon, Yazmin Camacho
students: Aryana Mahimtura, Josh Kome, Ludovica Pujia, Raven Coffer, Terry

title: Smart Biosensor for Early Detection and Control of Bacterial Wilt
abstract: Bacterial wilt, caused by Ralstonia solanacearum, devastates over 400 crops including tomatoes and peppers, with field incidence rates reaching 50-80% in southern China. To address the challenge of hidden early infection, we engineered a smart biosensor that detects the pathogen's AHL signaling molecules and produces a visible blue signal?indigo? for rapid field diagnosis. In addition, a companion strain synthesizes salicylic acid (SA), a natural plant immune signal, to enhance crop resistance. This low-cost, portable, and farmer-friendly system enables early detection and targeted intervention, providing an innovative solution for managing bacterial wilt and reducing agricultural losses.
nominations: Best Hardware, High School
advisors: Abby, ALEX, Cindy, steve, yang, Zeyu Chen
students: Boyuan Ren, CONNY LI, Cycran, Fiona Pang, George, Holly Yutong, Ivy, Jaden, Jason, Jenny, Johnnie Zhong, Jouis, Lana, Liangziqian, Nancy Guo, YugeLi, Zhangzhibo, Zhiyuan Ren

title: ReGenstitch?Triple-Engineered Bio-Sutures--Revolutionizing Wound Closure with Strength, Antimicrobial & Anti-Inflammatory Synergy via Synthetic Biology
abstract: SynSuture addresses the limitations of traditional sutures--poor biocompatibility, infection risks, and non-degradability--through a synthetic biology-driven integration of three functional modules: Bacterial Cellulose (BC) for mechanical strength and biocompatibility; Chitosan/Chitooligosaccharides (COS) derived from shrimp shell waste for antimicrobial and wound-healing effects; and microbially synthesized Curcumin for targeted anti-inflammatory regulation. Using engineered E. coli strains, we produce these components efficiently, creating a multifunctional suture that synergizes structural support, infection control, and anti-inflammatory modulation--all while enabling sustainable biom manufacturing.
advisors: Able, Echo, Ken Wang, majinyi, Minzi, Nier Wang, super-cat, YutianShen, Zhang Chengxuan
student leaders: ElaineShe, JackY, Ronghao Wang, Shinmyeon, tuyiran, XinDong, YUce-M
students: Adela, Alan, Aurora Liu, Camille Liu, ChloeLi, Fungi, GraceShi, Jeff, Jimmy, Kim, Motionn, Peggy, Rebecca, Ruolin Wang, Sandy, Sheldon, Zixuan, Zoeki

title: Strawberry Spoilage Full-Process Prevention and Real-Time Monitoring System
abstract: This project addresses the high spoilage rate of strawberries during post-harvest transportation, where current preservation methods are costly or have limited effectiveness, by proposing an integrated "prevention + real-time monitoring" solution. After harvest, strawberries are sprayed with chitinase and endo-?-1,3-glucanase to degrade fungal cell walls and inhibit infection. During transportation, a VOCs-based whole-cell biosensor constructed from Escherichia coli BL21 (BE3) detects spoilage-related volatile compounds and triggers a fluorescent warning, enabling logistics operators to adjust conditions or remove damaged fruit in time to prevent further spread. This approach leaves no chemical residues, has low production costs, can be integrated with IoT systems, and is suitable for large-scale application--significantly reducing spoilage rates and transport losses, improving freshness, and enhancing both economic returns and food safety.
advisors: anna-jqyang, feyd raccoon, Flora, ?HANHANHUI, lzsnn, Shiru Cai, ShuyaLiu, Tianyu Wang, Xinran Ma
student leaders: Albert, Livia Wen, Nicky, ReannaJin, Tiffany Feng
students: Bill, DYX, Fan yuchen, Jariel Ng, JENNIFER, Kc, Kitty, Luzihan, Lynn, Olivia, Russ, XuHaoxuan, Yona

title: Knotaut - Combating the spread of Japanese knotweed by hijacking its RNAi-pathway
abstract: Reynoutria japonica, commonly known as Japanese knotweed, is a fast growing and propagating neophyte present in most of Europe, North America and New Zealand that poses a severe risk to local ecosystems and communities. While this invasive plant species is generally susceptible to chemical-herbicidal-agents and physical control methods, both come with 3 key drawbacks. They are either unable to guarantee long term removal, damage surrounding ecosystems or are highly cost, time and/or labor intensive. Using a modified Escherichia coli strain and a specifically designed dsRNA expression system our goal was to produce dsRNA that is able to post-transcriptionally silence essential genes of R. japonica, ultimately leading to plant death. Additionally, dsRNA encapsulation into liposomes enhances its environmental stability as well as its uptake into and distribution in the plant. Our work had one clear objective: Create an environmentally friendly, species-specific herbicide formulation with dsRNA as its active ingredient - Knotaut!
instructors: Lucija Sovic, Sarah T, Zhang Xingjian
advisors: Alex, Henrik Seyfried
students: Christoph D., David, Fabian Gether, Florian Haneder, Hannah, Javier Figueroa, Julia, Karo, Lena, Leonie Exl, Lisa H., Marina Iskusnykh, Markus W., Max Schosteritsch, Rolando, Sebastian Mayer, Simon, Simone D., Sophia, Other, Helga H.

title: One-Cell Monodrama:Synchronized synthesis of cadaverine-succinate for bio-based polyamide 54 in one E. coli cell
abstract: Polyamide 54 (PA54)--synthesized from bio-based cadaverine and succinate--is an essential polymer with a wide range of market demand. Conventional biosynthesis requires two separate bacterial strains, leading to complex processes and substantial waste salt generation. To overcome this, we selected a lysine-producing strain E. coli NT1003 as a basal cell to engineer co-producing cadaverine and succinate from glucose. This enables acid-base neutralization and in situ CO? fixation, minimizing neutralizing agents and waste salt. We constructed genetic switches to regulate lysine decarboxylase (CadA) and optimized CadA for efficient lysine-to-cadaverine conversion. Cofactor engineering further enhanced succinate synthesis. By integrating these modules, we created an intelligent cell factory that simultaneously generates cadaverine and succinate from glucose. This sustainable strategy supports green production of bio-PA, promotes public familiarity with bio-based materials, and encourages greener lifestyles.
nominations: Best Biomanufacturing Project, Undergrad
PIs: Kequan Chen, Jiao Feng, Xiaomei Sun, Xin Wang, Xusheng
advisors: Tao Wang, Xinquan Zhou, Yang Gu
student leaders: Chenxi Lu, Chenxi Zhou, Chuning Zhu, Yuchen Ye
students: Chenyue Zhang, Chen Yun, Gongliang Wei, Hanjing Li, Haodong Wang, Hongbo Zhao, Hongwei Zhu, Huixin Chu, Jiaqi Zhang, Junhao Meng, Kanghui Ye, Lili Peng, Rui Zhang, Shen Jiawen, shen youtong, Wang Yanshuo, Weijia Zuo, Xiaofan Wang, Xinbei Shi, Xinyi Li, Xuning Wang, Yanni Zhu, Yinxiang Wu, Yu Gao, Zhang Rui, Zhong Jiayin, Zhongwei Zha, Ziqing Ma

title: Opio-Rx: Transforming Opioid Diagnostics Through Rapid, Non-Invasive Biosensing Technology
abstract: The global opioid epidemic kills 600+ people daily--over 500,000 American lives lost since 1999. In India, 2.3+ million people suffer from opioid addiction, with Punjab and Haryana experiencing alarming proliferation. This $500+ billion global economic disaster demands immediate action, yet current detection methods fail when seconds matter most. Existing diagnostics are too slow, expensive, and complex for real-time emergency response, addiction treatment, and law enforcement--creating a critical gap between urgent need and available solutions. Opio-Rx revolutionizes opioid detection with the world's first rapid, point-of-care platform detecting multiple synthetic opioids--fentanyl, oxycodone, methadone, tramadol, and codeine--from saliva in under 5 minutes. Our breakthrough combines computationally designed aptamers with FRET-based biosensing and AI-powered mobile integration, delivering laboratory-grade accuracy anywhere, anytime. This commercial solution healthcare workers, first responders, and treatment providers need. Opio-Rx saves lives by enabling instant, life-or-death decisions preventing overdoses, transforming addiction recovery. Molecular diagnostics starts here.
PIs: Dr. Anup A. Kale, Dr. Shilpa Chapadgaonkar
advisors: Dr. Prashant Malavadkar
students: Aarya Kunnure, Animesh, Arya Bundi, Ayushi Mishra, Gargi Mulay, Lalit Sinha, Payal, Rui Agashe, Sanskriti, Sharvari Bhosale, tushar

title: Pullomunch-An E. coli System for Combating Phenanthrene and Naphthalene Pollution
abstract: PAHs exert persistent toxic effects on both humans and animals. Taking two relatively simple PAHs--naphthalene and phenanthrene--as examples, we aim to engineer Escherichia coli with the nah, phn, and rhl gene clusters from Pseudomonas and other species to establish a more efficient pathway for their degradation.
PIs: Ye Qiu, Haijun Tu, HONGHUI WANG, Songqing Tang
advisors: Yourong Yan
students: Feng Shi, Jincheng Liang, Ran Du, Yanfeng Zheng, Yunduo Hao, Ziyu Luo

title: Designing a thermostable monellin variant: A next generation protein sweetener
abstract: Sweet proteins offer a natural route to cutting added sugar. Monellin is a protein that is 90,000 times sweeter than sucrose but has limited use due to poor heat and pH stability. Our project aims to modify MNEI, a single-chain engineered variant of monellin, to create a thermostable sweetener that is applicable in real-world situations. An in silico protein design pipeline was developed for systematic design of thermostable MNEI variants. In brief, an exhaustive Rosetta point mutation scan was performed to assess all possible single and double mutations of MNEI. The resulting ??G values were then used to rank mutations by predicting the folding free energy. Subsequently, molecular dynamics simulations were performed to assess the conformational stability of MNEI and its variants. The most stable variants were then cloned into pET-28a(+) and expressed in E. coli NiCo21(DE3) for future experimental validations.
advisors: Pslam
students: Arabella Chan, Benjamin, Brendan Lee, Chan Lai Yin, Daniella, Eason, Jacob Chen, Jaineel Patel, Kara Naomi, Katie, Kyra, Rain, Sherwin, Sumaiya, Sunny Liang, Tam Hoi Fu, Wai Cheng, Wallace Xie

title: NPM Zero
abstract: Facing unsustainable traditional hydrogen production, our project pioneers a biological alternative by engineering E. coli into a light-driven biofactory. We integrate synthetic light-harvesting complexes to capture energy, enabling the conversion of formate into clean hydrogen gas through optimized metabolic pathways. Rigorous safety measures, including kill switches, ensure biocontainment. Our integrated approach combines computational modeling with active stakeholder engagement--consulting energy experts, industries, and educators in Hong Kong--to align our solution, "NPM Zero," with urban energy needs and SDGs. By transforming renewable light into sustainable fuel, we advance green biotechnology and contribute to a decarbonized, hydrogen-based future.
instructors: Chiu San Bo, Jegadishwar Ananda Natarajan, Ng Tsz Chun, Vicera Christian Nelson Tejedor
advisors: Alika Wong, Ananya Bisht, Chun Yuen Wong, Hui Lan Scarlett Tsou, Matthew Lam, Soumik, Wong Tsun Hin
students: Arooba Ahmad, Asmin Rana Avsar, Charlene, CHENG KWAN WING, Elizabeth Sham, enyuyap, Hannah (Daeun), Harry, Issac, Patrick Cheung, Pitchayapa Cusinsup, Rosalin, Sajeena, Saleha khan, Seoyeon, Skye Chen Jiale, Veren, Yeung Ho Chiu, Yusra, zhouziqi

title: Plastipeutics - Plastics Shouldn't Come at the Cost of Health
abstract: As plastic waste increases, so does the breakdown of larger plastics into smaller pieces called microplastics. Microplastics can be small enough to be absorbed by the human body and cause harm. Microplastics enter our bodies in three ways: skin absorption, inhalation, and ingestion. The primary mode of absorption is oral ingestion. In the small intestine, microplastics transit through the lining of the intestine and enter the bloodstream to be distributed to other organs. Therefore, we have designed and tested peptides that bind to the plastic polystyrene with the goal of eventually expressing them on the surface of a microorganism which will "grab" plastic particles in the small intestine before they can cause harm.
advisors: Alana Chang, Ely Nieves
students: Aidan Marengo, Cate Kegel, Colin_Largen, Deirdre Thomson, Esteban Pinilla, Ivan Lepesii, Keyanna Jones, Malik Gay, Malik Roger, Nicole Karwowski, Priyanka Perumalraja, Rickerson Geneus, Zarrar Talukdar

title: Eco-friendly Bioremediation of Chlorimuron-ethyl Residues for Sustainable Crop Rotation
abstract: Chlorimuron-ethyl is a herbicide commonly applied in soybean fields to control weeds. However, its residues can persist in the soil, harming wheat seedlings in subsequent rotations by disrupting root growth, photosynthesis, and nutrient uptake. To address this issue, we engineered E. coli to express the PnBA enzyme, which de-esterifies chlorimuron-ethyl into a harmless benzoic acid derivative. Our product is formulated as a freeze-dried bacterial powder, designed for application after soybean harvest and before wheat planting. By reducing herbicide residues, this solution supports healthy wheat growth, protects soil ecosystems, and promotes sustainable crop rotation practices.
advisors: CQaoz808, Judy, Matthew, Olivia, Siyu Jin
students: Arno Zheng, Eleanora, Eva, Hannah, Isaac, Jaden, JiaruiLiu, Kan Z, Maxxime Liu, Melinda Chen, Nicole, QiYu, Shan Zihan, Sharon Li, Steven Yan, Sui Yuman, Sunrui, Tangzikai, Yan, ZhuYanzhen

title: PLASMOPROTECTOR
abstract: To address the severe harm of exogenous bacterial plant diseases and the issues of drug resistance and pollution associated with traditional chemical control, this project has transformed Escherichia coli (E. coli) into a "cell factory" using synthetic biology. It introduces the PtsG, FabH, and GlnA genes (regulated by T7 promoters and RBS) to construct a synthetic pathway that converts glucose to acetyl-CoA, then to erucic acid, and finally to erucamide. Meanwhile, we developed ErucaBead, which uses high-alcoholysis water-soluble polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) to encapsulate the engineered bacteria and boasts advantages such as rapid dissolution, degradability, and soil improvement.
students: Bosen du, Joy Jiang, Lucas Teng, Tyle Cheng, Xingyi Yan, Yitong Chen, Yu-Hsuan Shih, Zhang Chengxuan

title: De novo Design, Screening and Application of D-Tagatose-3-Epimerase (DTE) for D-Allulose Production
abstract: D-Allulose, a low-calorie sugar with multiple functions, is regarded as a revolutionary natural sweetener. The synthesis of D-allulose from fructose is catalyzed by D-tagatose-3-epimerase (DTE), while the low activity and poor stability of DTE have remained key bottlenecks for industrialization of D-allulose. Our study integrated artificial intelligence models such as LigandMPNN and AlphaFold3 for the de novo design of DTE. A novel RNA-mediated fluorescence system was developed for the high-throughput screening these AI-generated variants, resulting in a novel DTE enzyme with enhanced catalytic activity. The optimized DTE was subsequently applied to the production of D-allulose and other broader societal applications. This study establishes a applicable platform based on "AI Design-Efficient Screening-Application Validation" for enzyme development. It provides a breakthrough enzyme for D-allulose production, benefiting its industrialization and broad social applications in the food and pharmaceutical. It also offers a safe sugar-alternative solution to address obesity and diabetes etc.
instructors: Liu Ru, Sen Shang, Wang Juan, Youjun
advisors: Andong Zhang, Hui Ding, Mickey, Xueer Du, Yi-hao MA
student leaders: Danyang Song, Dingmao Pan, Wu Kanran, ZHOU RUI
students: Gao Han, Guanghe Zhan, Haozhe Wang, Hu Jiayi, Li Fangfei, Lin Xu, runwenzhong, Wangcheng Xing, Xie Mingsheng, Yifan Lin, Yiwei Zheng, Yufei Tan, Yuheng Xu, Yunqian Huang, Yuxiang LIN, zhangqi, Zhang shufan, Zhang_siyu, Zhanyi Chen, zhe zhang, ZhiqianXu

title: siREN: A Targeted RNAi Therapeutic Approach Against Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
abstract: siREN is a novel RNAi therapeutic approach for the treatment and management of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). By targeting overexpressed proteins (?CL2 and BTK) through siRNA-mediated gene silencing, we aim to inhibit the uncontrolled proliferation of leukemic cells and induce apoptosis. Our goal is to suppress the survival pathways driving disease progression, thereby restoring normal cell death mechanisms. This gene silencing will be achieved by delivering siRNAs into cancerous cells via lipid nanoparticles, engineered with antibodies specifically targeting CLL cells. These modified nanocarriers are designed to target ROR1, a protein highly expressed on the surface of target cells, and to release the siRNAs inside them, effectively silencing the genes responsible for CLL pathogenesis, while minimizing interaction with healthy cells.
nominations: Best Integrated Human Practices, Undergrad+Inclusivity Award, Undergrad+Best Oncology Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
instructors: Dimosthenis Tzimotoudis, Eleftheria, Konstantina Psatha, Stefania Maniatsi
students: Angeliki Iordanidou, Errika Sylai, Erriketti-Theodora Moumka, Georgios Zekas, Giorgos Maroulis Bousmalis, Kyriakos Marios Papamanolis, Margarita Papastergiou, Marianna Rafailia Palieraki, Olga Skarlatou

title: LactoLock
abstract: The project aims to develop a dual-action oral health therapy by engineering a probiotic bacterium (Limosilalactobacillus reuteri) to produce antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) that selectively inhibit Streptococcus mutans, the primary bacterium responsible for dental caries. AMP production genes will be integrated into the bacterial chromosome using plasmid vectors to express AMPs, with a quorum-sensing synthetic gene circuit regulating expression so that AMPs are only produced in the presence of S. mutans, minimizing disruption to the natural oral microbiome.
advisors: Ezgi Sen, John W. Biggs III
student leaders: Carlos Gomez, Haozhe Yao, Li Xu, Saul Charles, Sebastian Haines, Will Switzer
students: Afeefa Anwer, Anshul, Corina, David Hudgins, Ghayda, Haichuan Long, Haoqi Wang, Jahin Zashim, Jingbo Yang, Montserrat, Shumoos, Tabs, Wanqi Wang, Yingzhou Ji, Yuchong Yang, Yuyi Pu, Zhiyu Liu

title: R.E.Y.N.A. : Radiation-Resistant Engineered Yeast for Nutrition from Astronaut's waste
abstract: To enable self-sufficient long-term space exploration, regenerative life-support systems must minimize reliance on Earth resupply. While oxygen and water are recycled on the ISS, sustainable nutrient and food production remain challenges. Our project, R.E.Y.N.A, pioneers cellular agriculture for in-situ protein generation from astronaut waste streams, contributing to a closed-loop bioregenerative system. We engineered Saccharomyces cerevisiae to convert urea-rich urine into single-cell protein by deleting the nitrogen catabolite repression regulator GAT1 and overexpressing GLN1 and GDH1, enhancing nitrogen assimilation and amino acid biosynthesis. To ensure resilience under Galactic Cosmic Radiation, we introduced RAD51 and the tardigrade-derived Dsup protein to improve DNA repair and oxidative damage resistance. Additionally, a polyvinyl alcohol-melanin bioreactor lining provides passive radioprotection. Together, these innovations enable a self-sustaining microbial protein production system that promotes regenerative nitrogen recycling and strengthens mission autonomy for deep-space habitation.
student leaders: Agastya Prakash, Hemang Deepak Khandagale, Sarthak Kale
students: Aamod Wagh, Aditya Patil, Anushka Ambikar, Arjun AR, Arya, Atharva, Druv Keswani, Durva Kale, Harshwardhan Patil, Jay Patel, Mahee Kakade, Mohini, Prannav Choudhari, Prapti, Rudra R Chakraborty, Rutika Anand, Sanika, Tanaya Lele, Tirth, Vasavya Prasanna

title: KUN PENG-The Guardian of Beauty in Cold Conditions
abstract: Cold weather often poses significant challenges to beauty and fashion--from skincare products freezing solid outdoors to concealed door handles becoming stubbornly stuck. Inspired by the freeze-resistance strategies of polar organisms and traditional Chinese culture, the Tianjin team "KUNPENG - The Guardian of Beauty in Cold Conditions" has developed a novel solution. Leveraging synthetic biology and computational modeling, they designed an "Antifreeze Protein-Trehalose Synergistic Defense System." We displayed Antifreeze Protein(AFP) extracellularly via a yeast surface display system. Computational models were then employed to optimize the performance of these proteins and to design novel AFP variants. Through the screening strategy, we identified the trehalose pathway as critical for enhancing yeast frost resistance. Finally, we integrated these elements into a single system, achieving combined intracellular and extracellular frost resistance. The team's ultimate goal is to integrate this system into cosmetic formulations.
PIs: Yi Wu, Bingzhi Li, Lei Zhang
