title: Lactate-Induced Vector for Engineered Retinoid Supply & Hepatocellular Onco-Therapy
abstract: Advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with extrahepatic metastasis has a poor prognosis and limited treatment options. This study evaluated All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) combined with FOLFOX4 chemotherapy in a nationwide, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Prior to the clinical trial, AIVC (Artificial Intelligence Virtual Cell) modeling predicted that ATRA would induce differentiation of tumor-initiating cells (TICs) and reverse chemoresistance. The ATRA+FOLFOX4 cohort showed significantly improved median overall survival (16.2 vs. 10.7 months) and progression-free survival (7.1 vs. 4.2 months) compared to the placebo arm. Experimental validation confirmed that ATRA drives TIC differentiation, remodels the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment by repolarizing M2 macrophages to an M1 phenotype, and inhibits PI3K/AKT signaling. This study establishes ATRA+FOLFOX4 as a novel, effective, and safe first-line regimen for advanced HCC, with its mechanism rationally guided by initial AIVC predictions.
advisors: Chunhui sheng, Jiaying Luo
student leaders: Li Haibo, Shangyi Yang, Wenbin Chen, Xiaoling Yang, Ziru He
students: erjia zhang, JIAXUAN FU, Lirong Zhang, liuyaxuan, Liwen Huang, Sihui Wu, Tianyue Liu, Yixin Liu, Zhang Shuoyan, Zihui Peng, Zixin Shen, ???, ???, ???

title: LUCID: Lung Cancer Integrated Diagnostics
abstract: LUCID is a two-component diagnostic tool for the early detection of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), consisting of biosensor - OncoSense and AI model - Cancerna. OncoSense is a optical fiber biosensor for the detection of biomarkers AGR2 and CEA elevated in patients with NSCLC at early stages. Optical fiber base allows for the immobilization of binding ligands, as antibodies or aptamers. Cheap cost of fabrication and rapid detection time make OncoSense promising novel tool for the cancer detection. Cancerna is an AI assistant tool for the analysis of computer tomography (CT) scans. Analyzing CT scans as the 3D image via Lung-RADS implemented classification, Cancerna becomes the everyday tool for the radiologists. Additionally, to explain and justify its output Fuzzy logic is implemented. LUCID has its impact on diagnostic world not only by presenting a new way of diagnostics, but also by improving the work experience with already established ones.
nominations: Best Measurement, Undergrad+Best Entrepreneurship, Undergrad
advisors: Arman
student leaders: Abylaikhan Seraliyev, Anastassiya Tyazhelova, Diana Bekeshova, Rauan Muratuly, Temirlan Karatay

title: SyntcoLAB
abstract: Human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs) are essential bioactive components of breast milk that support infant immunity, cognitive development, and long-term health, yet current infant formulas provide only a small fraction of their natural diversity. To address this gap, we developed a synthetic biology platform using a modular bacterial consortium of Streptococcus thermophilus, a GRAS (Generally Recognized As Safe), dairy-adapted, and naturally competent chassis. By dividing the HMO biosynthetic pathway among complementary strains, implementing controlled cell aggregation, and establishing metabolic interdependence, we aim to reduce metabolic burden, enhance intermediate sharing, and maintain population balance. This approach is expected to enable the scalable production of a broader spectrum of HMOs than currently available, improving the nutritional quality of formula and establishing a flexible platform for other complex biomolecules.
students: Adrien, Amélie Tasiaux, Camille Cardarelli, Cassandre, Esteban, Nicolas Heymans, Pierre, Tanguy

title: Coliguard: the New Era of UC Treatment
abstract: Ulcerative colitis (UC) is driven in part by the IL-23 ? JAK2/STAT3 axis. Approved anti-IL-23 monoclonal antibodies work but require injections, are costly, and carry systemic immunosuppression risks. We propose localized mucosal neutralization: three de-patented anti-IL-23p19 scFv prototypes (A/B/C) designed by motif-guided CDR engineering with AlphaFold checks, plus two mAb-derived scFv (risankizumab-p19, ustekinumab-p40) as performance baselines. Validation: recombinant-protein ELISA for binding and a Caco-2 inflammation model measuring p-JAK2^Y1007/1008 and p-STAT3^Y705 inhibition. Long-term, the best prototype will be secreted by engineered '''Lactobacillus acidophilus''' to reduce cost and systemic exposure.
advisors: CAN-LING JIANG
students: Ben, Champ, CheHsu, ErinLee, Madilyn Chang, Wanyun Hsu, Yen-Po, Yi-Ni Liu, Yuhong

title: EcoCasein
abstract: In recent years, the environmental impact of greenhouse gas emissions from livestock has drawn increasing global attention, particularly methane released during cattle digestion. To address this issue, the NCHU iGEM team developed EcoCasein, a sustainable microbial milk alternative. Our project employs Kluyveromyces marxianus as a host to produce A2 ?-casein, a naturally digestible variant of milk protein, using the PGASO multi-gene assembly system. By introducing carbon-fixation pathways such as the Calvin-Benson-Bassham cycle, we hope to reduce the net carbon footprint of protein production. EcoCasein not only provides a cow-less, easily digestible source of dairy protein but also demonstrates how synthetic biology can contribute to climate-friendly food innovation. Through integrated wet-lab construction, gas analysis, and human practices outreach, our project envisions a new model for sustainable nutrition and low-carbon dairy development.
advisors: Jin-Cheng Li, Seiken
students: Adrika, HUANG, YU-HSUAN, Irene N., Po-Yao Wang, Saviour, Soura

title: Empowering MTHFR Mutation Diagnosis for Global Healthcare
abstract: Birth defects represent a significant challenge in the field of global public health. Among the contributing factors, folic acid deficiency is one of the primary preventable causes. These defects not only endanger individual health but also impose a heavy burden on healthcare systems and society. Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) is a critical enzyme in the folic acid metabolic pathway. Mutations in the MTHFR gene can impair folic acid metabolism, increasing the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes such as miscarriage and fetal malformations. As a result, MTHFR testing has become an essential component of prenatal screening. This project is dedicated to developing faster, more cost-effective, and convenient diagnostic methods for folic acid testing and formulating personalized intervention plans for different populations. Through in-depth research on folic acid metabolism and related genes, we aim to reduce the incidence of birth defects associated with folic acid deficiency and safeguard maternal and child health.
PIs: Xing, Bingzhi Li, Baoxing Shen, Dr_Sohail, Yuetong Wang
advisors: Fengli Su, NNuUUn
student leaders: Qimin Zeng, soso, Xintong Dai, Yicen Xia
students: Deyue Diao, Guo Yuejia, Jackson, Mingyu Zhang, Peikun Cai, Qianhan Zhang, Qianyu Chen, Wentao Zhao, Xiaoyi Zhang, Xinyan Ju, Yang, Yeling Zhou, Yijia Zheng, Yunhao Jiang, Yuxuan Wang, Zetong Lu, ???, ??

title: AleChemy
abstract: Beer is an important part of our culture, so we began our project by talking with brewers to understand their challenges. From these discussions, we learned that hops are essential mainly for providing bitterness. Guided by their feedback, we focused on reproducing this bitterness in yeast. Using untargeted metabolomics, we identified ?-acids as our target molecules for biosynthesis. Through iterative Design-Build-Test-Learn cycles, we introduced a construct into S. cerevisiae that enables the production of phlorisovalerophenone--the precursor of ?- and ?-acids--verified using both targeted and untargeted metabolomics. Our work was carried out in close contact with breweries, scientists, and the public to ensure responsible design and realistic applications. For the future, we plan to implement additional brewer-desired compounds such as xanthohumol and anthocyanins. Our project demonstrates how synthetic biology can merge innovation with brewing tradition by empowering yeast to produce hop-derived flavor precursors in an environmentally responsible way.
nominations: Best Measurement, Overgrad
instructors: Alexandre Bouillé, Ji?í Kohout, Josh, T?o Hebra
advisors: Pavel Zach, Valerio, Zde?ková Kamila
students: Adrian, Albert Tománek, Alexandra Gombitová, Aneta Salokyová, Aneta Schulmeisterová, Diana Gombitová, El, Filip, Jakub Misturik, Ján Plachý, Jeroným Koutný, Jonas Vlasak, Petr Kalina, Zuzana Ruszová

title: R-DetoX 2.0: Synthetic RDX-Induced Biodegradation Genetic Circuit in Escherichia coli within a Serial Bioreactor System
abstract: The island municipality of Puerto Rico, Vieques, remains contaminated from decades of military activity with the high-energy compound RDX (hexahydro-1,3,5-trinitroso-1,3, 5-triazine), posing severe risks to human health and local ecosystems. To address this issue, we engineered a genetic circuit in Escherichia coli for RDX biodegradation and biocontainment. The system integrates two modules: (1) a biodegradation module containing an RDX-inducible riboswitch that regulates xplA and xplB, encoding cytochrome P450 and its flavodoxin reductase responsible for degrading RDX into formaldehyde and nitrite, and (2) a killswitch module that detects these byproducts to trigger colicin-mediated cell lysis. The circuit will be implemented in a four-stage Serial Bioreactor System designed to promote bacterial growth, induce degradation, treat byproducts, and ensure safe environmental discharge. Our system provides a controlled and sustainable synthetic biology approach for mitigating RDX contamination and supporting environmental restoration in Vieques.
nominations: Safety and Security Award, Undergrad
advisors: Jorge D. Bocanegra Rosario, Sofía Teixeira-Cox
student leaders: Francisco, Isabel, Jennifer Pellicier-Caraballo, Keriel Villarrubia, Mónica D. Cortés Soto, Zulmarie Lissette Fernández Marrero
students: Angelica Pacheco-Jimenez, Carolina Joan Lebron Perez, Christian Santana, Gabriela S. González Abreu, Gabriela Sofía Matos Rodríguez, Genesis Jusino, Hiram Burgos, Javiely Colon Mas, José Esteban, Lisangelie Flores Arroyo, Paola Camila Barreto Pérez, Perla

title: Cas Advancement via Synthetic Protein Engineering and RNA knockdown (CASPER)
abstract: CASPER aims to build a standardized backbone for Cas13-based RNA knockdown, enabling fair comparisons across Cas13 variants. For knockdown, we cloned several Cas13b (bt1, bt3, pgu, Ran) and Cas13d (djCas13d) constructs into the xPERT backbone to test RNA cleavage efficiency using ANXA4 and BGALNT1 as the target. Guide RNAs were designed, cloned, and verified through restriction digestion, ligation, transformation, and sequencing. Confirmed plasmids will be transfected for RT-qPCR and editing assays to evaluate both knockdown and editing performance within a unified framework. On the computing side, we built a motif-guided protein generation model showing that conserved motifs reliably mark Cas13 subtypes. The first version (v1) used ESM-2 to generate realistic Cas13d variants that passed structural checks. A second version (v2) incorporated reinforcement learning for subtype precision but produced less natural sequences. v1 offers a practical baseline, while v2 points toward more controlled protein design.
students: Aaron, Boon How Low, Charmaine Fun, Favor Lim, Gavin Teh Li Wen, Hang Ying Ni, James, Quan Yao, Tang Pei Xuan, Yang Shann Wen, Yu Xiyao

title: Rational modification of HpCrtZ to construct cell factory for astaxanthin synthesis
abstract: Astaxanthin is a potent antioxidant with anti-aging properties and is widely sought after by manufacturers of cosmetics and skin care products. However, current production is low, resulting in high market prices. Our solution is to improve astaxanthin production using Escherichia coli as a cellular factory. For astaxanthin synthesis, the astaxanthin synthesis pathway including seven genes were chosen and they were expressed in E. coli using two T7 promoters of the pET-Duet-1 vector. In addition, we modified ?-carotene hydroxylase using rational design, achieving four HpCrtZ mutants with high catalytic activities.Then we induced the expression by IPTG to synthesize astaxanthin in E. coli efficiently. Finally we obtained astaxanthin powder by freeze-drying, made astaxanthin-containing oil. For applications, we designed three target products including essence, face mask and opera makeup pigments. Our technology is mature, cost-effective and environmentally sustainable. We aim to meet the market demand for high quality astaxanthin through this approach.
advisors: Chaogang Wang
students: ALAN TSZ HONG XU, Guanquan Wang, Jingyi Jia, Lida Liu, Tian Qin, Wenxuan Xu, Xiwu Wang, Yichun Wang

title: Engineered MHC Protein for Enhanced Tumor Antigen Visibility
abstract: Current cancer immunotherapies often fail when tumor cells evade detection by downregulating or modifying peptide-MHC presentation. In this project, we present a modular, quantitative engineering platform based on rationally modified HLA-A*02:01 molecules to improve tumor antigen visibility to T cells. We designed and built three heavy-chain constructs (wild type, single mutant W167A, and quadruple Tyr?Ala variant) plus a constant ?2-microglobulin part, all with biotinylation tags for tetramerization. Our approach combined in silico structural modeling (diffdock-guided residue selection) with wet-lab validation (SDS-PAGE, BCA quantification, ELISA binding assays). We demonstrated that engineered variants can meaningfully alter peptide binding affinity, confirmed through rigorous measurement pipelines. Alongside experimental work, we conducted public surveys and expert interviews to align our scientific goals with societal perceptions, developing educational modules to bridge knowledge gaps. This project integrates synthetic biology, immunology, measurement rigor, and human practices into a coherent toolkit for future MHC engineering.
PIs: Daein Yoon, Hyun Junre, Sungjun Yoon
advisors: Aiden Minseo Ha, Bisong Ko, Eunsu Lee, Ikon, Jeff, JeongkyooHAN
student leaders: Joungwon, Wooju, Yejun, Yun Su Hwang
students: Claire, Emma, Eunbin, Jay, Joan Kim, Nathan, Taehong, Taewoo Park, Woojin Ahn

title: Avisptosis
abstract: Our project aims to construct a novel defense system against avian influenza viruses that currently threaten global food security, utilizing synthetic biology as our primary approach. Rather than developing orthodox defense systems such as drugs or vaccines that inhabit viral entry into cells or viral replication, we are developing an innovative mechanism that prevents viral amplification within animal hosts by "actively inducing apoptosis in cells infected with influenza virus." Our ultimate goal is to suppress highly pathogenic avian influenza(HPAI) pandemics, thereby making significant contributions to improving food security issues and maintaining public health.
advisors: Daiya Ohara, Hideki Nakamura, Kento Kiriyama, Tomoo Shimada
students: Haruki Minamiyama, Hiroaki Yagi, Jiale Song, Kaito Igeta, Kazuma Yabuki, Lisa Koreeda, Mari Hashimoto, Masamune Okamura, Mayu Kataoka, Moe Baba, Rika Nishida, Riku Ogawa, Saya Nitta, Taichiro Oda, Taisei Sakurai, Taiyo Okayama, Taketo Ota, Tomoaki Asai, Yoshino Goto, Youta Oka, Yuki Wakita, Yusei Nishizaka

title: Epilepsy Shield?BHBio?EEGSense
abstract: Per WHO 2024 data, around 50 million people globally are suffering from epilepsy. The ketogenic diet is effective for epilepsy by prompting the body to synthesize ketone bodies, yet long-term adherence may cause side effects. To avoid these side effects, we use synthetic biology to synthesize ketone bodies for epilepsy treatment. We engineered Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 with a pathway to produce the ketone body ?-hydroxybutyrate (BHB), plus dynamic regulation and safety modules. Encapsulated in hydrogel as a drug, the engineered bacteria colonize the intestines after oral administration to synthesize BHB for therapy. We also developed an intelligent epilepsy monitoring system: a concealed behind-the-ear device (cEEGrid) collects EEG signals, which are Bluetooth-transmitted to a model. After software processing, seizure risk is visualized. Our project aims to provide insights into epilepsy prevention and treatment via synthetic biology, caring for patients.
PIs: Hong Li, Chenghong Liao, Chief, Hongjin Wu, Wulanfang, Wu Wenqiang, Yusheng zheng
advisors: Limbo Li, Xu Jiejie, yiyang
students: Bohan, Haitang Wen, Haizhou Ding, Hanqi Li, Hongyun, Hualong Yu, Huiyan Liu, Jiahong Wang, Jialiang Zhao, Jingjing Yang, LiuZiFei, Niu Dongfang, Peilin Liu, Shuhan Wang, Shulin Jiang, Tingzhang Chang, Xiaoya Qin, Xuanzong Jin, Yiran Liu, yuhan Kou, Zhende Huang, Zhengqi Li, Zhiyu Mei, Zixuan Ye

title: PROMNESIS
abstract: PROMNESIS is a synthetic biology therapeutic platform targeting multiple aspects of Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology: (i) intracellular tau pathology, addressed by Tau Tuner and (ii) extracellular tau "seeds" that spread neurofibrillary tangles, targeted by TRI-LYTAC. Our system's third component, a logic gate for the detection of cellular stress environment, is used as a safety precaution, activating downstream therapeutic expression only in disease-relevant contexts. The TauTuner consists of an optogenetically controlled phosphatase, which performs dephosphorylation of intracellular tau, preventing its aggregation and restore microtubule stability. The TRI-LYTAC is a lysosome-targeting chimera which combines antibodies with TfR-binding peptide and IGF-2(F19L) dimer. Its development was primarily driven by the need to target and degrade extracellular tau seed, as well as to achieve blood-brain barrier (BBB) transcytosis. The experiments performed and models we developed show that PROMNESIS can work as a complete, modular treatment system.

title: FoCas: A Novel Antimicrobial-Resistance Treatment and Infectivity Inhibition Platform
abstract: The escalating crisis of transmissible antimicrobial-resistant bacterial infections demands innovative therapeutic approaches that move beyond traditional antibiotics. In response, our team presented the concept of FoCas, a novel platform engineered to directly address the dual challenges of drug resistance and infectivity. FoCas leverages a two-component system: the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing system for precise genetic targeting and cleavage, and a DNA origami nanostructure as a smart delivery and targeting vehicle. The DNA origami is programmed to recruit and protect the sgRNA/Cas9 complex, selectively bind to specific pathogen (e.g. MRSA), efficiently enter the cell with subsequent CRISPR-Cas9 activation to precisely cleaves and disables the gene responsible for antibiotic resistance (e.g. mecA). By combining precise genetic disruption with targeted delivery, FoCas may possess great potential as a candidate for future antimicrobial therapy, holding immense promise for dealing with superbug infections.

title: PolyGone: A Synthetically Engineered Fish Feed Additive that Fights Microplastic
abstract: Polygone seeks to improve human health by eliminating the microplastics that have accumulated in our seafood. With synthetic biology, Polygone engineered probiotics can enzymatically degrade plastic in fish guts, helping to create a cleaner diet and a cleaner world.
advisors: Chris Erb, Kalen Clifton, Sophia Xu
student leaders: Justin Blumenthal, Katie Hong, Lucy Wu, Youying Dong
students: Andrew, Anmol, Dylan Luong, Mihir Sharma, Nicolas Poliak, Vanessa Zhang

title: A Protein Engineering Platform for Valuable Plant Metabolite Synthesis
abstract: Plant natural products are vital sources of medicines and health supplements, but plant extraction results in high costs and limited accessibility. Microbial production offers a sustainable alternative, yet poor stability and low activity of plant enzymes in heterologous hosts remain major bottlenecks. To solve this problem, we here developed REvoDesign, a rational evolutionary-guided workflow that integrates structural modeling with co-evolutionary data to optimize minimal key residues. REvoDesign synergistically enhances enzyme stability and activity with minimal experiments and mitigates negative epistasis via cross-region mutations. A user-friendly interface with customizable modules makes the tool easy to use. REvoDesign's effectiveness was validated by improving bifunctional phytoene synthase/lycopene cyclase(CarRP) and taxadiene-5?-hydroxylase(T5?H), leading to collaborations with multiple research teams and companies, including a signed strategic partnership. This data-driven, structure-guided approach provides a powerful solution for engineering enzymes to enable efficient microbial production of plant natural products.
PIs: Yongshuo Ma, Yi Shang, Xiaopeng Zhang
advisors: Wen Xiong

title: Team Imperial College London
abstract: The current model of meat production is environmentally unsustainable. Cultivated meat offers an alternative, yet remains hindered by high production costs, particularly by recombinant growth factors that constitute up to 70% of expenses. We tackle this by engineering a Komagataella phaffii chassis, Mannoless, designed to reduce exopolysaccharide secretion and improve yield through targeted modifications in Hoc1, Rho1, and PMI. We also developed BioKernel, an open-access, no-code Bayesian optimisation framework that accelerates design and strain engineering. Guided by our conversations with world-leading experts across different sectors, we explored unspoken pitfalls of scaling in yeast chassis. Our education efforts addressed skepticism toward synthetic biology, as innovation cannot scale without public trust and investor confidence. Finally, we were on a mission to make our outputs fully open-access reaffirming our belief that science cannot scale without non-proprietary technology. We aimed to remove cost and licensing barriers in biomanufacturing, accelerating a sustainable future for food.
advisors: Jason Yu, Lisa Neidhardt, Oliver Konzock, Sabyasachi Banerjee, Shan Jiang
student leaders: Jonathan Collard, Szonja Skenderovic, Yeline Idir
students: Akihito Gohdo, Anabel, Asay Alper, Frederick, Hugo, Povilas Šau?iuvienas, Tiffany Lin, Zichen He, Others, Amber Villait, Erika

title: No Grain, No Gain: Ferulic-Acid-Induced GLP-1 Secretion for Metabolic Health
abstract: To advance sustainable and programmable genetic regulation in synthetic biology, we engineered an orally deliverable microbial platform that functionally couple gene expression to dietary metabolites, embodying the principle of Medicine-Food Homology. By incorporating a ferulic acid-responsive regulatory circuit, our system achieves diet-inducible control of target gene expression under physiologically relevant conditions. A stabilized GLP-1 analogue was employed as a model payload to verify the system's responsiveness and molecular reliability. Operational safety was ensured through a dual-layer safeguard that integrates an engineered bacterial delivery system and a quorum-sensing-based self-limitation mechanism. Guided by our 5C Human Practices framework, emphasizing co-design and reflective integration, our project demonstrates a responsible and modular approach to system construction. Collectively, this work establishes a versatile and robust platform for translating dietary signals into programmable genetic responses, offering new possibilities for foundational research in metabolic regulation and precision biodesign.
student leaders: Jinchun Zhang, Muxi Han, Zhang Sihan
students: Boxu lu, FanYutong, Jiayi Lu, Jingyi Zhang, PuBo, Shangjiu Li, Wenqian Yang, Wenqing Zou, YaoJunYi, Yun Zhang, Yuran Hu, YUXUAN WANG, Ziyu Zhang, ???, ???

title: HemorrEaser: A Novel Strategy for Treating Hemorrhoids
abstract: Hemorrhoids present significant treatment challenges such as symptomatic relief, surgical pain, and high recurrence rates. Based on sociological research, we developed "HemorrEaser", a synthetic biology therapy. Using engineered E. coli Nissle 1917 in oral and topical formulations, our design features three innovations: OMV-delieverying bioPROTAC-mediated HIF-1? degradation combined with an activatable anti-VEGF nanobody to suppress pathological angiogenesis; ROS-responsive release of anti-inflammatory peptides for rapid pain relief; a dietary-component-responsive riboswitch enabling medicine-food collaboration for treatment regulation and safety control. HemorrEaser provides a precise, minimally invasive therapeutic strategy while establishing a new chronic disease management paradigm through lifestyle-integrated therapy.

title: NONERGY
abstract: Our project focuses on hay fever (allergic rhinitis) which is a major burden in our country Japan. We propose two solutions: the biosynthesis of narirutin and the engineering of a fusion peptide. Narirutin is a flavonoid compound found in Jabara, which is a citrus fruit grown mainly in Wakayama prefecture in Japan. This compound has anti-allergic properties, and is proven to be effective for hay fever. Our fusion peptide is mainly made out of three immunomodulatory peptides, connected with cleavable linkers. The fusion peptide is designed so that the linkers cleave at specific parts of the pathway of allergic rhinitis, dropping off certain peptides at certain parts of the mechanism. We also created a new, 100% recyclable nasal spray, as well as conducted many human practices and education initiatives targeting a wide range of people.
nominations: Best Presentation, High School+Best Integrated Human Practices, High School+Best Village Project, High School
advisors: LAM, Hin Kwan, Misaki Ozawa, Ryojun HAYASHIZAKI, Taku, YUEN, Man Leuk

title: ChronoKolla
abstract: We have designed a fusion peptide sequence aimed at addressing issues in the field of medical aesthetics. The fusion peptide primarily comprises several functional peptide segments. Firstly, to inhibit melanin production in the skin, we employed computer-aided methods to design a competitive peptide analog of the melanocyte-stimulating hormone receptor (?-MSH), which serves to block melanin synthesis. To delay skin aging and promote collagen synthesis, we incorporated segments that mimic growth factors into the fusion peptide sequence, which can stimulate skin cells to produce collagen. Additionally, we added a cell-penetrating peptide segment to the end of the fusion peptide to facilitate the entry of these compounds into skin cells for effective action. We utilize Escherichia coli DH5? for the production of these fusion peptides and have designed a microneedle-based delivery system to administer these compounds effectively.
students: Chang Su, Chenyang, Fang Jinhan, He Shuyu, Jiang Yuan, Kaige, NI WUYUE, Yishan Yang, Yuxin Han, Zhu Guanlin

title: Seawolves
abstract: Excessive nitrogen pollution from agricultural runoff, atmospheric deposition (which have increased because of fossil fuel), and other anthropologic activities have led to significant environmental challenges for the marine environment through eutrophication, the overflow of nutrients. Microorganisms reproduce rapidly in the presence of eutrophication to create HABs, or harmful algae blooms. These algae blooms can cover up to hundreds of kilometers, depriving the environment of oxygen and suffocating species into local extinction. Our review of existing nitrogen reduction methods suggests that they are of limited effectiveness. To address this problem, we formulated a solution to modify marine diatom Phaeodactylum tricornutumlum with a synthetic construct of pPha-T1 and NR gene, which increases the efficiency of nitrate degradation. By enhancing the ability of diatoms to process excess nitrogen, our approach seeks to reduce the nutrient load in marine environments and prevent the uncontrolled growth of harmful algal blooms.
advisors: Ryka
students: Allen, Angela Zhou, Caroline Calista, Danny, Jack, Jay Shen, Kemble, Lilly Menyhart, Millie, Pearson Wu, Runbang, Sebastian Briggs, Tabor

title: RectomeDy FotoZymogen?A Red Light-Programmed Microbial Therapeutic System for Targeted Colorectal Cancer Treatment
abstract: Colorectal cancer treatment faces challenges such as severe side effects from conventional therapies and a lack of precise, controllable localized treatment methods. To address these issues, we developed RectomeDy FotoZymogen--an engineered bacterial therapeutic system for colorectal cancer based on red light-controlled precise induction. Using the probiotic E. coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) as the chassis, we constructed four core modules: a Targeting Module (INP-HlpA) for tumor-specific anchoring; a Red Light-Induction Module (PadC-MrkH) that enables precise activation of gene expression via 660 nm irradiation; a Therapeutic Module delivering multi-mechanism anticancer molecules such as Coagulase and PD-L1 nanobodies; and a Safety Module ensuring automatic bacterial inactivation post-treatment. RectomeDy FotoZymogen is administered via a suppository with an embedded LED, achieving full-process precision control of "delivery-localization-activation-clearance." This system provides a localized, safe, and highly effective novel treatment strategy for colorectal cancer.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School
student leaders: Jenny, Peter, Pingkang Ding, Sara, Zhengda Wang
students: Albert, Cara Xin, Eva, Irene, Jamie, Jenny Binqi Qian, Ken, LVD F, Qianyu Chen, Shaoyanjia, Song Zehan, Tailai Cong, Xinyi Tang, Xunwen, Yeqiao Ma, Yifan-Tian, Yutong Li, Zelin Qiu, Zhen Liu, Zhiyan Ding

title: Low-burden Dairy Products: Reduced lactose, lowered sugar and Increased fiber
abstract: Dairy products are essential for human health. Our project utilizes enzyme engineering and synthetic biology to express two recombinant enzymes: transgalactosidase and glucose oxidase. Transgalactosidase catalyzes the conversion of lactose into galactooligosaccharides (GOS) and glucose, whereas glucose oxidase converts glucose into gluconic acid. This process not only alleviates lactose intolerance symptoms but also reduces sugar content and enriches prebiotics in dairy products. Ultimately, it achieves lower carbohydrate intake and higher dietary fiber content, providing a healthier dairy option for consumers.
advisors: LIU QINHAN, LYU RUNQING, WANCHEN HSIEH, WANG ZIMING, ZHANG YUXUAN, ZHU YUHE, ZISHUO CHEN, ZIYU WANG, ZUO ZIQING

title: Selective Proteolytic Botulinum Toxin Bioassay Based on Yeast (S.P.Y.)
abstract: Botulinum toxin type A (BoNT/A), needing high-demand detection in medical aesthetics and food safety, prompts us to develop a simplified, accurate, fast, low-cost detection method to replace the traditional mouse bioassay. We use Saccharomyces cerevisiae to build a dual-yeast system: one acts as substrate to sense BoNT activity and release ligands, the other receives signals to express pigments for visualizing BoNT concentration, with coupled GPCR pathway and GAL system for signal amplification. It applies to quality inspection of medical aesthetic products and food safety, boosting efficiency and offering public accessible safety verification. This project can be applied in the quality inspection of medical aesthetic products and food safety testing. It not only improves the quality inspection efficiency of relevant institutions but also provides the general public with an accessible means to verify the safety of daily food products.
advisors: Fengyuan Yang, Jiacan Ma, Jingyuan Gao, Xiaotian He, Xinyuan Shi, Zeyue Jia
student leaders: Jinlin Liu, Ruoxi Cao, Yanlin Chen, Zining Wang

title: Development and Functional Analysis of a Lab-on-a-Chip Model for NRAS^G12D Mutant Multiple Myeloma
abstract: Multiple myeloma progression is driven by genetic alterations; RAS-pathway mutations (e.g., NRAS^G12D) increase proliferation and motility. Conventional 2D cultures miss these behaviors, and animal models are slow, costly, and ethically constrained. We engineered NIH3T3 cells expressing control, NRAS^WT, or NRAS^G12D with an mCherry reporter for direct visualization and genotype validation. Using a PDMS lab-on-a-chip that mimics a bone-marrow-like matrix, we quantified growth (CCK-8) and migration (scratch wound healing vs on-chip Matrigel infiltration). NRAS^G12D accelerated wound closure and enhanced 3D invasion. Treatment with the MEK inhibitor U0126 produced mutation-dependent growth suppression, confirming pathway involvement. Overall, this reproducible 3D chip links genotype to pharmacologic response in a tissue-like context, offering a scalable route to reduce animal use and to speed evaluation of AI-nominated compounds and future co-cultures with stromal or endothelial cells for both mechanism and screening.
advisors: Clare Chaeeun Park, Joseph Park, June Choi, Mirae Do, Siyoon Kim, Yuri Kang
students: Aiden Chee, Andrew Suh, Eileen Byon, Elliot Nam, Eunice Kang, Eunu Baek, Minjun Hwang, Seunghu Lee, Sihyun Lee, Soo Young Pee, WooJoo Kang, Younho (Aiden) Park, Other, JUN YONG PARK

title: Glutamate-driven Ferroptosis Induction by Recombinant E.coli in tumor-specific environment
abstract: Current cancer therapies are limited by chemotherapy resistance, target mutations in precision drugs and severe side effects. As synthetic biology develops rapidly in recent decades, bacterial therapy has emerged as a promising alternative. Meanwhile, ferroptosis--a form of regulated cell death driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation--has shown significant potential based on previous studies. Our study integrates bacterial therapy with ferroptosis induction by engineering Escherichia coli to overexpress glutamate specifically in tumor microenvironments. Glutamate can disrupt cellular redox homeostasis by depleting glutathione and accumulating lipid peroxides, thus selectively triggering ferroptosis in tumor cells, with colorectal cancer involved in this study. This approach combines synthetic biology with the potency of ferroptosis, aiming to enhance therapeutic efficacy while minimizing off-target effects through microenvironment-responsive expression. We anticipate that it will provide new insights into bacterial cancer treatments, for innovative combination therapies that improve tumor targeting, reduce side effects, and achieve better clinical outcomes.
advisors: Jixiao Wu, Lei Yingjie, Mingchen
students: Cheng Xiang, Guo Qi, Jia Ru, Ma Xiaoyang, qinhaoming-cuhksz, XU Yuan, ZHAO JIARUI, Zhu Kexin

title: FeliSilence
abstract: Cat allergies affect a substantial population globally and are mainly caused by a few feline proteins (e.g., Fel d 1, Fel d 2, Fel d 4, Fel d 7). We developed FeliSilence, an RNA interference (RNAi) approach that silences allergen transcripts to reduce allergy at the source. To quickly and safely test RNAi efficiency, we created an accessible yeast shRNA reporter platform through simple fluorescence readouts--ideal for student teams. Candidate shRNAs were filtered to minimize off-target effects, and in the yeast assay, twelve of fifteen shRNAs demonstrated active knockdown, presenting candidates for further implementation. Human Practices guided our project priority of reversible RNAi over gene editing, and we assessed delivery feasibility through modeling of siRNA activity and lipid nanoparticle (LNP) targeting. To tackle the challenge uniting private sectors, our entrepreneurship plan outlines a feasible pathway, emphasizing safety, regulatory alignment, and clear advantages over symptom-based allergy treatments.
advisors: Chunman Li, Dalai Xu, Jing Zhang, Max and his skink, Zhang Huai Jun, ZHANG SHUHE, Zha Yi
students: Boxuan wang, Carina, Cindy, Dominic, Flora, Freya, Gloria Huang, GuanTing Liu, Hannah Liu, Hermione, Jenny Dong, Jessica Xu, Jingxin Zhang, Kyle Liu, Leo, Prince LU, Shell, Sky, Tom Wang, Yuyui Li

title: Protovate
abstract: Protein engineering underpins modern biotechnology, yet turning designed sequences into robustly functional biomolecules remains inefficient because datasets are small, screening is costly, and sequence-function mappings are uncertain. While the development of large protein models such as Alphafold has advanced structure prediction, consistent performance across diverse conditions is still difficult to achieve. We built a data-free active-learning generative protein-language model framework, Seed & Seek, cooperating with biological directed-evolution (using a coarse-to-fine tuning strategy), spanning both in vitro ePCR mutations and in vivo EcoRep systems. Using the SpyTag/SpyCatcher pair as a testbed, we targeted improved association rates and iteratively validated candidates with split-luciferase assays. By uniting computation with biological selection, our framework accelerates discovery of adaptable, high-performing protein variants.
students: CHENG, YU-LUN, Chia-Jou Ho, CHUN-HUNG CHENG, Erh-Wei Sheng, Hsin Chang, JO LING, JUI YU CHIU, Pin Che Huang, Pin-Hsuan Huang, Shiuan Ling Chen, Ting-Wei Lin, TING-YI CHEN, Tsaifei Yang, Yi Chia Fang, Yuan-Pei,Chang, Yu Chiao Yang

title: KERBEROS: Key Engineered Response for Binding and Elimination of Residual Orally-internalized Synthetic particles
abstract: Microplastics, plastic particles smaller than 5 mm, can bind harmful molecules and commonly cause inflammation and oxidative stress in cells. Due to their polymeric structure, they show high affinity for Carbohydrate-Binding Modules (CBMs), domains found in carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes) that normally bind polysaccharides. The effects of PET, LDPE, and PS microplastics are being studied in Drosophila melanogaster fed with microplastic-enriched food. A genetically modified Saccharomyces boulardii CNCM I-745 strain, engineered to display CBM on its surface using the Aga2p system, is added to the flies' food to test in vivo microplastic binding and excretion. Yeast viability is evaluated in a bioreactor simulating the large intestine, supporting its potential as a live therapeutic delivery system. Adsorption kinetics are modeled in an in silico intestinal environment, and molecular docking and machine learning (Pythia) are used to predict and optimize CBM-polymer interactions for future experimental validation.
advisors: Anastasia Zerva, Eneri Boniakou, Konstantinos Grigorakis
students: Eleni, Eleni Bethani, George, Kalliopi Margoni, Lydia Dionysia Lavrenti, Maria Dima, Silia, Stavroula Kyvelou, Zacharias Semertzidis

title: GreenAqura
abstract: Runoff carries nitrate, ammonium, and orthophosphate that drive eutrophication and waste fertilizer. We propose a modular biocartridge seeded with engineered E. coli encapsulated in alginate. In Capture mode, cells overexpress high-affinity transporters (NarK/P, AmtB, PstSCAB) and polymerize intracellular cyanophycin (CphA) for nitrogen and polyphosphate (PPK1/PPK2) for phosphorus. A burden-aware controller routes ATP and reducing power to storage only when external nutrients exceed setpoints sensed by PhoB/PhoR and NtrC networks. In Recover mode, orthogonal inducers activate CphB and PPX to depolymerize stores; a short elution concentrates N and P into a reusable stream for fertilizer blending. Encapsulation plus genetic biocontainment (auxotrophy + kill switch) prevents escape. Bench targets: 80% NO??-N removal and 90% PO?³?-P removal within 6-12 h HRT at 10-50 mg/L influent, ?10 reuse cycles with <5% activity loss per cycle. The system provides edge-of-field polishing with low reagents, nutrient recycling, and strong safety.
students: Aaditya Jain, Aadya Goyal, Arya Rathi, Diivij Todi, Janice, Keyan, Nitya, Prathmesh, Punya taluka, Sanchaya, Sarthak Dhole, Sidak Singh, Sparsh Ranjan, Ved Rathi

title: Living Scaffolds
abstract: Osteoporosis, which affects hundreds of millions of people, requires safer treatments. To address the serious side effects and high cost of current options, we have engineered E. coli bacteria as a localized, in situ drug factory. Our system uses surface-displayed tyrosinase to continuously produce melanin, a powerful antioxidant that reduces inflammation and promotes bone regeneration at fracture sites. To ensure complete biological containment, the bacteria are encapsulated in a alginate hydrogel and are metabolically auxotrophic, making them dependent on the carrier. A toxin-antitoxin system also prevents plasmid loss and survival outside the niche. This work establishes a foundational platform for a new class of living medicines aimed at bone regeneration. By enabling localized, sustained, and controllable drug delivery, this paves the way for intelligent and sustainable solutions to a wide array of diseases.
students: Hadjara, Luna, Manon, Miriem, Nadia Vidmar, Ruzanna, Sandra

title: Project PHoeBe - Achieving a Feasible Plastic Alternative in the Form of PHB
abstract: The growing use of non-biodegradable plastics has caused major environmental harm, as these materials persist for centuries and resist recycling. Polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) offers a biodegradable alternative, but its slow degradation and recycling limit its effectiveness. In Project PHoeBe, the Westview iGEM team investigates two newly identified enzymes, a PHB depolymerase and a dehydrogenase, found through metagenomic analysis, to improve PHB breakdown. Level 1 plasmids containing these genes were conjugated into knockout Alteromonas macleodii, and tests in a simulated ocean environment showed evidence of PHB degradation. Computational modeling also identified a potential catalytic triad in the depolymerase. Through outreach, we educated the public on plastic pollution, waste reduction, and the environmental promise of PHB. Our project represents an early step toward more effective, sustainable management of biodegradable plastics.
student leaders: Anna Ly, David He, Felix Zhang, Jaelyn, Kaden Chang, Ngoc An Tho Tran, Saya Schmitigal, Thomas Tong, Zeren
students: Aahana Jaiswal, Andrew, Anika Bose, Anya Yousuf, Ayushi, Brandon Crowell, Chakri, Citlali Martinez, Danica, Derek Lam, Elijah Anil, Emily, Hannah, James, Jay Yasuda, Juliana Stapleton, Karen, Kevin Chapman, Kevin Dao, Kimiya Shafaat, Leo Meng, Lucas, Shaari, Shravya Bharathwaj, Sophia Chu, Sophia Yao, Tina Tian, Tyler, Weronika Gil, Yuna Ha

title: SmokeOff: Engineering Enzymes to Block TSNAs Formation from Third-Hand Smoke
abstract: Globally, more than 1.3 billion people use tobacco. While the dangers of first- and second-hand smoke are widely recognized, third-hand smoke--residual pollutants that settle on clothing, furniture, walls, and dust--remains an underappreciated health threat. Among its most hazardous constituents are tobacco-specific nitrosamines (TSNAs), formed through the reaction of residual nicotine with airborne nitrite. TSNAs are strongly carcinogenic and highly resistant to degradation. To address this, we propose a dual-enzyme strategy: NicA, NicB, and NicC for the degradation of surface nicotine, and NirS, NorB, and NosZ for the removal of environmental nitrite. By preventing TSNA formation at the source, this biosafe and sustainable enzyme-based spray presents a novel synthetic biology approach to indoor environmental detoxification.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, High School
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Kexin Fei, Zhang Zhaoxia
student leaders: HANKE YANG, Sun Yuyang, Zeng Xiaoqian, Zimo Wang
students: FANG JIAER, Hanwen Wu, Han ZiZhuo, Huang YiXun, JIANGYUE CHEN, Jiang Yujun, Leyan Chen, LI XIANG, LU YUTONG, Pan Yuheng, shenbowen, Sihan Lin, Wang Yuchen, Yan Luo, YIHAN WANG, YUNUO YING, Yuyan Yao, Zhang YiNing, ZHAO YUNKE, ZHU YUTONG

title: AbsorBuddy: Cross-Species Recombinant Intrinsic Factors for Enhanced Vitamin B12 Absorption
abstract: Vitamin B12 is essential for red blood cell formation, neurological function, and DNA synthesis. However, millions of people worldwide suffer from vitamin B12 malabsorption. The most effective treatment currently available is lifelong intramuscular B12 injections, which are often painful, inconvenient, and associated with hidden costs, accessibility challenges, and environmental impact. Our iGEM project, AbsorBuddy, aims to develop a safe and effective alternative oral B12+IF supplement by identifying the most efficient and least immunogenic IF variant across five species. Results of our project reveal that bovine and human IF exhibit the highest vitamin B12 binding efficiency with rat IF showing minimal binding. Antibody interference test indicates markedly lower cross-reactivity for bovine and platypus IF compared to human IF, suggesting reduced immunogenic potential. Circular dichroism confirms native-like ?-helical folding in bovine IF. Complementary dry lab analyses, shows experimental binding trends and identify favourable geometric complementarity for bovine and human IF.
nominations: Best Therapeutics Project, Overgrad
advisors: Kristiina, Setareh
students: Cao Gong, Deborah, Elias, Jasmin Haltilahti, Julia, Karya, Li, Polina, Saadia S. Chowdhury, Wenjun

title: PATRONUM: PAThogen-Resistant Organisms engineered for NatUral root rot Management
abstract: Soybean root rot, a soil-borne disease primarily caused by Fusarium spp., poses a severe threat to China's soybean industry--with annual yield losses exceeding 50,000 tons. Conventional controls are inadequate: agricultural measures are slow-acting, chemical pesticides carry risks of residues and pathogen resistance, and biocontrol exhibits weak efficacy. To address this gap, our approach employs two engineered strains: the chitinase-expressing strain degrades existing chitin, destroying mature pathogens; the ?-amyrin-synthesizing strain blocks chitin synthesis by inhibiting chitin synthase, suppressing pathogen proliferation. Our team achieved key results: establishing an in-silico workflow to screen 2000 secretory peptides; verifying the chitin-degrading ability of chitinases; constructing and optimizing ?-amyrin-producing strains; developing a biosafety screening tool and a measurement tool based on safer antifungal indicator strains; confirming antifungal effects of chitinases and ?-amyrin. In the future, we will promote the large-scale application of this synthetic biology-driven strategy, further supporting long-term agricultural health and food security.
awards: Finalist+Top 10+1st Runner-up+Best Village Project+iGEMers Prize+Safety and Security Award
nominations: Best Measurement, High School+Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School+Best Integrated Human Practices, High School
advisors: Enze Zhang, Hua Chen, Jinling Yuan, Xu Yiling, Yan Yan, yaoruwei, Yuqi Xu
students: Abigail, Daniel, Fanya Ma, Georgia, Harold, Harry, Helen Xie, Henry Zhang, Jiayi Wu, Leran, Miya, Molly Zhao, Victor Young, Xincheng He, You Dengyuan, Yuxin, Yuxuan Li, ZhanZhang

title: BEDMAN: Bio-Engineered Design for Microbial Antipest Neutralization
abstract: The project aims to deliver a safe, effective green mosquito repellent "bio-fermented citral". It constructed the IPP/DMAPP?GPP?geraniol?citral synthetic pathway in E. coli using three enzymes for modular expression on 3 vectors, and screened mutants like GeDH-54883 to boost catalytic stability. Engineered strains showed normal growth. QPCR confirmed upregulated transcription of target genes; WB verified successful protein expression. TB medium fermentation yielded 0.89-1.36 g/L citral, with yield-improving synergy identified via multi-factor optimization. Non-spray sustained-release prototypes were designed. Surveys confirmed core demands, guiding compliance strategies. A closed-loop validation from pathway construction to product definition was completed, proving bio-fermented citral's scalability.
advisors: Enze Zhang, Hua Chen, Huiting Yang, Wu Shanshan, Xu Yiling, Yan Yan
students: Audrey, Boyan Zhang, Kevin, Leo, Ruiyang Wen, Simon Yu, Vivian Wan, Yilin Qian, Yuelin Cheng

title: ReSET: Reprogramming the Suppressive Environment of TME
abstract: Colorectal Cancer (CRC), the second leading cause of cancer deaths, lacks specific and effective treatments. Our engineered ReSET system uses the probiotic E. coli Nissle 1917 to detect lactate and hypoxia--key tumour microenvironment cues--and secrete an Anti-CD38 Nanobody-Fc fusion, reprogramming immunosuppressive Tregs into healthy cells. Simultaneously, it produces salicylate, a harmless reporter detected via our ReSense paper strip assay, indicating bacterial colonisation and active therapy. This dual-action system combines targeted immunomodulation with real-time monitoring, offering a precise and adaptive therapeutic platform for CRC treatment.
PIs: Supratim Datta, NS, Supratim Sengupta, Susmita
advisors: Aniket Sabar, Anshuman Das, Arkadip, Ayantik Kundu, Fathima Anjum E C, Mani Gupta, Sampoorn Pandey, Sharon, Smrutimayee Prusty, Swastika Dey
students: Amrik Das, Anjali Mishra, Asmi, Deepanshu, Gautam Menon, Nandita Sriram, Sagnik, Sattwik Pradhan, Shankha, Others, Liyam, Rohit

title: Engineered Streptomyces by alkB gene for Agricultural PE Mulch Degradation
abstract: Plastic mulching is widely applied to enhance crop yield, yet the accumulation of non-degradable polyethylene (PE) films has led to severe soil pollution and fertility loss. To address this challenge, our project engineered Streptomyces to express optimized alkane hydroxylase enzymes, accelerating the degradation of PE under agricultural conditions. Using AlphaFold2-based protein modeling, we predicted and refined enzyme structures to improve catalytic activity and stability. Moreover, we developed an environmental prediction model that recommends the most suitable mulch type according to local temperature and rainfall, promoting rational use of plastic films. In parallel, a field survey among farmers in Henan Province revealed that nearly half believed traditional PE films reduce yields, underscoring the urgency of biodegradable alternatives. By integrating synthetic biology, computational modeling, and social investigation, our project provides a comprehensive and sustainable solution to agricultural plastic pollution.
advisors: Ritsuki Aoyama
students: Haotian Li, Kiara, Liujiaqi, Mengjun Gao, Pengfei Wong, Yuexin Yan, Zhang Chenyuan, Zijie Xia

title: Y.E.P. - Yeast Electron Production
abstract: To reduce harmful greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energy storage is critical. Lithium-ion batteries dominate but pose environmental risks from mining, production, and disposal. Microbial fuel cells (MFCs) offer a greener alternative: microorganisms oxidize organic waste, generating electricity while cleaning wastewater, providing sustained, low-carbon energy with fewer ecological impacts. In this project, we engineer yeast MFCs with enhanced electron storage and electron transfer capacity. We achieve that goal by elevating the Saccharomyces cerevisiae intracellular NADH pool and enhancing their extracellular electron transfer. Using the CRISPR/Cas9 genetic editing tool, we deleted genes encoding the key enzymes of glycerol and ethanol biosynthesis, and external mitochondrial NADH dehydrogenase. Engineered strains were tested in custom MFC hardware. To fully leverage the increased intracellular NADH levels, we propose the heterologous expression of fungal cellobiose dehydrogenase (CDH) on the yeast cell surface to enhance the cell's ability to transfer electrons to electrodes.
nominations: Best Hardware, Undergrad+Best Climate Crisis Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
instructors: Aleksandrs Rebriks, Artemi Maljavin, Davit Rizhinashvili, Dmytro Fedorenko, Juli Mukhadze, Stepan Strelchenko
advisors: Nastassia Shtaida, Pavle, Veronika Podliesnova
students: Adiya Raimkul, Amina Aliyeva, Evgeniya, Natavan, Oleksandr Syritka, Polina Khrystynchenko, Temma Suzuki

title: PlasticSense Neo--Microplastic Detection-Degradation System
abstract: Microplastic pollution has emerged as a significant global environmental issue. Preliminary research conducted by the HP group indicates that the public is increasingly concerned about its widespread distribution, hidden forms, and potential for ingestion. In response to elevated concentrations of microplastics, such as polyethylene terephthalate (PET), in the environment, this study utilizes synthetic biology techniques to develop various biological modules for detection and degradation. To ensure biosafety, we designed a "OR" gate lysis module that facilitates the self-lysis of microorganisms. This research aims to provide systematic solutions for the precise detection and sustainable management of microplastics, thereby contributing to bioremediation strategies.
instructors: Shuang Liu, Yang Yu, Yinjun Zhang, Yuan Li
advisors: Chenghan Ye, Dongchang Sun, jialong Zhang, Jiyue Hu, Pengbo Zheng, Shan Dong, Yuan Cheng
students: Bing Shao, Biyao Ling, Han Xu, haoyang li, jiahua xu, Jiale Wang, jiaying Jiang, ling hao, qinruo cheng, shuhui zhao, sunyuxiang, Xinyue Fang, YiQing Wang, yi wang, Yuetong Lu, yuxin lu

title: Bactolyze
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a rapidly escalating global crisis that threatens the efficacy of life-saving antibiotics and undermines years of medical and agricultural progress. Beyond the direct health toll projected to reach millions of deaths annually by 2050, the consequences extend to food security, livestock production and trade, underscoring the interconnected One Health perspective in this regard. To address this challenge, our iGEM project Bactolyze develops a modular platform for the discovery, optimization, and application of bacteriophage-derived endolysins as novel enzyme-based antimicrobials. Combining cell-free production for rapid screening, computational modeling of antimicrobial peptide-membrane interactions, and fusion-based engineering, we target clinically relevant Gram-negative pathogens and biofilm-associated infections. By integrating experimental workflows with regulatory insights and stakeholder engagement, Bactolyze lays the groundwork for next-generation enzyme-based therapeutics, complementing antibiotics and widening our arsenal against AMR.
nominations: Best Education, Overgrad+Best Integrated Human Practices, Overgrad
instructors: Annika Potthoff, Cara Jaeckel, Niko Stanke
advisors: Ann-Sophie Jochmann, Pauline Gravermann, Sina Becker, Sriram Kumar
student leaders: Marie Sonntag, Michelle Hacker, Torben Buschmann
students: Florian Becker, Kasibek Zumataev, Laura Baune, Paul Mantke, Sara Ghotbi, Sueli Suarez, Tao Wang, Vincent Rhode

title: CadmiCatch
abstract: Cadmium (Cd) is a toxic heavy metal released through industrial processes that persists in soil and water, posing serious environmental and neurotoxic risks. Chronic exposure is linked to oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Conventional Cd remediation methods are costly and unsustainable, creating demand for biological alternatives. This project explores Pseudomonas putida KT2440 as a chassis for Cd bioremediation. We engineered a Cd biosensor using the CadC repressor protein, which activates gene expression upon Cd binding. Preliminary assays in E. coli (NEB 10?) confirmed CadC responsiveness, though the ON/OFF dynamic range was limited. Promoter characterization (BBa_J23100-BBa_J23119) in P. putida showed most variants functional except BBa_J23109. These results demonstrate the feasibility of developing a P. putida-based biosensing and bioremediation system for Cd, supporting the creation of sustainable, field-deployable microbial solutions for heavy metal pollution.
student leaders: Ashlyn Venoo, Ayush, Dana Moochnick, Tiffany Tan
students: Arya M, Debanshi, Deeksha, Jayce, Kristian, Lauren Montemarano, Laxmini, Prarthana Kiran Kattimani, Raj Kangriwala, Shrita Kalikiri, Victoria, Zoe Guttenberger

title: BioVitalis
abstract: Salidroside, the core component of Rhodiola, exhibits remarkable pharmacological effects in antioxidation, anti-fatigue, immune enhancement, and cardiovascular protection, holding significant market potential. However, traditional plant extraction methods face severe challenges, including resource scarcity, low yield, long growth cycles, and environmental pollution. To address these issues, our team has successfully developed an innovative synthetic biology approach by constructing a novel, sustainable, and cost-effective biosynthetic pathway in Escherichia coli. We have engineered a de novo pathway from glucose, incorporating key enzymes to efficiently convert precursors into salidroside. To further amplify the project's impact and ensure its market viability, we conducted extensive Human Practices and entrepreneurship initiatives. Through questionnaires, interviews, expert consultations, and multi-platform social media promotion, we deepened our understanding of public health needs, paving the way for the commercialization and sustainable development of salidroside products. Our work represents a significant step towards making salidroside more accessible for widespread health applications.
advisors: Alex, Yue
student leaders: Chengwei Li, Cici, Qicheng Duan, Yifan Xiang
students: Gechang Zhang, Haorui Li, Haoyun Xing, Jia Bi, Jiahe Du, Jiajia Cui, Kay Huang, Kunyan Guo, Lingqi Zhang, Mengshi Zhao, RenxuanTu, Sean Tang, Shenghan Xu, Xuanrui Shi, Yihan Liu, Yikai Huang, Zhenzhen Zhao, Zhongdi Guan, Zhongzhe Chen

title: GlutaGuard: A Probiotic Shield Against Oxidative Stress
abstract: The project proposes using the commensal gut microbiome to enhance antioxidative defense through glutathione production. Glutathione, naturally produced in most mammalian cells and some bacteria, is essential for neutralizing reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (ROS/RNS). However, chronic pollutant exposure can overwhelm this system, contributing to physical and psychological health issues. Three Lactobacillus strains (L. plantarum, L. reuteri, and L. rhamnosus) will be engineered to sense oxidative stress and produce glutathione to neutralize ROS/RNS. Transformation will use plasmids carrying an oxyR transcription factor, a trxC promoter, and a gshF gene. Modified colonies will be screened via ROS exposure assays to confirm plasmid uptake. Successfully modified strains may be delivered through probiotic foods such as yogurt or kombucha. By strengthening the gut's antioxidative capacity, this project aims to mitigate the adverse health effects of chronic air pollution exposure and improve overall resilience in both sensitive and general populations.
students: Alexis, Carmelita, Chris Morris, Kenny Gray, Leptzy, Luis Valdez, Raquel, Ren Griffeth, Sagan Wilkinson, Other, David Ariza

title: POSEIDON - Phytoprotein-Optimized System for Environmental Ion DetoxificatiON
abstract: Toxic metal contamination in drinking water disproportionately affects rural and industrial communities exposed to mercury, aluminum, iron, and hexavalent chromium. Conventional remediation methods are energy-intensive and often inaccessible. POSEIDON (Phytoprotein-Optimized System for Environmental Ion Detoxification) offers a synthetic biology solution, using metal-binding peptides for selective ion removal. Phytochelatin synthase (PCS) and engineered metallothionein (MT) are expressed in safe E. coli, purified, and immobilized onto biodegradable alginate hydrogel beads via EDC/NHS chemistry. Packed into modular cartridges, these reusable, gravity-operated units are optimized through modeling for efficient mixed-metal removal. POSEIDON promotes sustainability, local fabrication, and modularity while supporting SDGs 3, 6, 8, 9, 11, 14, 15, and 17.
advisors: Amal Chacko, Priya Rawat, Sabyasachi parija
students: Aditya, Aniket, Ankan Chakrabarty, Aseel Arsath, Belide Saketha Ram, Chris John, Diptendu, Sampurna Roy, Sanchit, Souvik Biswas, subrat, Swastik Sourav

title: CardioGuard: Dual-System Biosynthesis of Leonurine for Cardiovascular and Cerebrovascular Protection
abstract: Cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases claim over 17 million lives annually, accounting for 32% of global deaths (WHO, 2019). Leonurine, an alkaloid from Leonurus japonicus, shows preclinical protective effects by reducing oxidative stress, improving circulation, and inhibiting platelet aggregation. To enable sustainable production, we established a dual-platform biosynthesis strategy in Escherichia coli and Nicotiana tabacum hairy root systems. Both platforms heterologously express the final two pathway enzymes, LjUGT5 and LjSCPL, enabling conversion of the supplemented precursors sinapic acid (SA) and 4-guanidinobutanol into leonurine. We compare yield and cost efficiency across systems to identify an optimal, scalable route, providing a stable source of leonurine for cardiovascular protection.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Siqi Yang, Zhang Zhaoxia
advisors: Thinker Si
students: Amiee XIONG, ChenYiJie, Haocheng Wang, Junze Wang, LIN YIHENG, NI Pang Ho, Qi Miao, QIU SIHAN, Xinyuan Deng, Yanzixin, Yining Wang, Yixin Wang, Zhang Lanxi

title: Latent Tuberculosis Diagnosis - Infecheck
abstract: One disease. Two billion lives affected. Tuberculosis (TB) remains humanity's most persistent infectious killer - and its hidden form, latent TB, can strike without warning. Yet current tests are slow, costly, and often out of reach for the communities hit hardest. Infecheck addresses the problem with early detection of LTB. We are developing a cheap, paper-strip diagnostic that uses a simple finger-prick blood sample to detect upregulated miRNAs specific to LTB. We explored two promising methods for exosomal miRNA detection: Toehold Switches and CCDR. We envision our end-product to be in the form of a lateral flow test and to use microfluidics as the extraction method. The test delivers easy-to-read results without requiring lab-based equipment. Our approach prevents the progression from latent to active TB, therefore reducing patient suffering and TB spread. INFECHECK - because we can't cure what we can't find.
students: Abi, Angela, Antonia, Daniela Gago, Ethan Rodrigues, Igor Wade, Kash, Mateusz kowalski, Matt, Mina, Mohana, Sana Sahul Hameed, Scarlett, Zara A

abstract: Abstract not available
students: Blaze, Sean

title: Engineered EcN for Neoeriocitrin Production in Colorectal Cancer Therapy
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) incidence is rising globally and increasingly affects people under 40. Current therapies are invasive and often cause severe side effects. We developed a precision therapeutic strategy using engineered Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN). Neoeriocitrin, a natural flavonoid with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory activities, shows promise in CRC prevention and adjuvant therapy but faces limitations of low yield and high extraction cost. To overcome this, we reconstructed its complete biosynthetic pathway in EcN by introducing VvRHM, UGT73B2, and Cm1,2RhaT, enabling efficient and controlled production. To ensure biosafety, we designed a dual suicide system: arabinose-inducible pBAD triggers in vivo lysis, while low-temperature-inducible pCspA provides environmental containment, both cooperating with MazF. This engineered probiotic integrates high-yield biosynthesis with strict biocontainment, offering a safe, controllable, and effective adjuvant strategy for CRC therapy, particularly for young patients with early-onset disease.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, High School+Best Wiki, High School
students: Daniel, Ella, Eric Miao, Grace, Grace Chen, Haoqing Zhou, Isabella, Jamie, Johnny Zhu, Keiya, Kevin Wong, Liangziyou Kang, Luna Chen, Sophie, Xinyuan Zhang, Yuna

title: NANODEN - Nanobodies for Dengue
abstract: In 2024, Brazil recorded the world's highest number of dengue cases, with over 6 million suspected and 3 million confirmed infections. Foz do Iguaçu, in western Paraná, faced a severe outbreak, with more than 10,000 reported cases, 1,280 confirmed infections, and 22 deaths, leading to a State of Emergency. To address this situation, Nanoden proposes an innovative synthetic biology solution: to develop nanobodies capable of binding to the dengue virus envelope protein, followed by the genetic modification of the mosquito's natural bacterium, Serratia marcescens, to produce these nanobodies. This interaction prevents the virus from entering mosquito cells, interrupting its transmission and offering a sustainable, long-term strategy for vector control.
advisors: Luis Carrasco, Marco Almeida
student leaders: Aline Lima, Ana Alice Rodrigues de Oliveira, Andrea Simone Moreno Salvador, Gabriela Santana Queiroz, Leonardo, Luis, Maria Eduarda Machado Catalan, Rosie
students: Cecília de Azevedo Marques, Elvira Márquez, Emerson Danzer, Gissella Silva, Guilherme Berlim, Ingrid, Isabella Forteza, JHOSSELYN, Julia Abatti, Larissa, Luane, Maria Esther Vivanco Suazo, Rafaela, Veronica

title: A High-Yield Plectasin Yeast Cell Factory: Constructing Efficient Plectasin-Producing P. Pastoris
abstract: Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are naturally occurring defense molecules with broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity, low resistance induction, and high stability. Plectasin, a fungal AMP, effectively inhibits Gram-positive bacteria and is used in feed additives. Current production methods such as extraction and chemical synthesis remain limited by low yield and high cost. Genetically engineered microorganisms offer a promising alternative, enabling scalable, cost-effective AMP production with tailored design. The yeast Pichia pastorisis a particularly suitable host due to its safety, efficient secretion machinery, and simple cultivation. In this study, we engineer P. pastorisby integrating the plectasin NZ2114 gene and optimizing regulatory elements to generate a high-yield strain, thereby facilitating its commercial-scale production.
nominations: Best New Basic Part, High School
student leaders: JIN ZICHENG, RAO NIKE, WANG MANNI
students: CHEN SIYUAN, LI YINYUE, TANG XITONG, WANG KEXIN, WANG XIWEN, XIONG YANJUN, YANG BORUI, YANG YAN

title: SynNotch-Engineered Macrophages for Enhanced Liver Cancer Therapy (SYNERGY) - A Precision Immunotherapy
abstract: The AFMU-China 2025 team has developed SYNERGY, a synthetic Notch system (SynNotch)-based engineered macrophage therapy designed to address two critical challenges in liver cancer treatment: tumor antigen heterogeneity and the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. SYNERGY employs a team-developed anti-SLC17A2 single-chain variable fragment (scFv) as an INPUT module to specifically recognize the SLC17A2 protein on hepatocyte surfaces, enabling liver microenvironment-specific activation. Simultaneously, a P65-SIRP? shRNA bicistronic system serves as the OUTPUT module, reprogramming macrophages into an anti-tumor M1 phenotype while blocking the "don't eat me" signal, thereby synergistically enhancing therapeutic efficacy. To reduce costs, we further established an in vivo gene editing platform using lipid nanoparticles (LNP) for tumor-associated macrophage (TAM) reprogramming, offering a "single-injection" therapeutic strategy for liver cancer. This technology holds broad potential for applications in hepatitis, liver fibrosis, and other liver diseases, providing a novel avenue for precision liver cancer therapy.
PIs: Junlong Zhao, Hongyan Qin, Chunchen Gao, Fan Fan
advisors: Jin yao, Ziheng Wang
students: Bohua Wang, Hanchang, Haotian Xu, HU YING DONG, Shutong Li, Xiaolin Chen, Xikun Lu, Xinlei Liu, Yimin Yang, Yuhao Cao, Zhu Lisichen, Zhutian, Zishuo Xie, Zixuan Liu, Ziying Wang

title: Generative Design of Osteocalcin Binder Protein for Point-of-Care Based Sensor
abstract: Long-duration spaceflight causes accelerated bone loss, increasing astronauts' risk of skeletal weakening. Existing bone monitoring methods rely on invasive sampling, underscoring the need for a rapid, non-invasive diagnostic suitable for microgravity. Targeting osteocalcin, a key marker of bone turnover, our team is developing a de novo protein binder as the foundation for a biosensor. Using BindCraft, an AI-based protein design platform, we generated and refined binder candidates, ranking interactions through HADDOCK3 docking simulations. Top designs were codon-optimized, cloned into E. coli, and purified for testing. Binding kinetics and affinities will be assessed via Bio-Layer Interferometry (BLI). This project integrates computational and experimental approaches to create a modular workflow for selective protein binder development, enabling future biosensors that can monitor astronaut bone health and other biomarkers in both space and clinical settings.
student leaders: Caroline Lee, Lucy Pellenbarg, Nicholas Marotta
students: Abigail Leon, Alyssa, Anouska Seal, Ayush, Cassandra, Divya Huilgol, Jae Sarner, Mahi Balaraju, Shruti Sreekanth, Velan, Venkata, Yansheng Luo

title: Eucaplyn - Biosynthesis of 1,8-Cineole: A Sustainable Approach to Anti-Acne Skincare
abstract: Currently, the primary market applications of 1,8-cineole (Eucalyptol) are concentrated in perfumes, essential oils, and food processing. However, few have utilized 1,8-cineole for producing pharmaceuticals or skincare products. The key issue lies in the current bottleneck of purifying the component from plants (purity generally only reaches 80%-85%), coupled with the fact that the active component is highly prone to thermal decomposition, and traditional extraction processes are costly. In contrast, our production of 1,8-cineole using synthetic biology methods theoretically enables high purity, high efficiency, stable, and controllable production. This is precisely the key to addressing the pain points of traditional processes and enhancing product quality. Freed from the constraints of high cost and low purity, 1,8-cineole, leveraging its multi-target anti-acne capabilities including inhibiting Cutibacterium acnes, reducing inflammatory responses, and clearing excess sebum, holds promise as a novel anti-acne product superior to current single-mechanism options on the market.
advisors: Chaster W, Emma, sabrina Y
students: Alice Liu, Chen Tianqin, Elaine Zhu, Hazel, Huang Hanyu, Jiarui Liu, Norgel, Xinyi yuan, Yongzhuo Lyu, Yucheng, zihe

title: FLUversal
abstract: Influenza remains a major global health challenge, infecting up to 10% of the population annually and causing significant morbidity and mortality, especially among vulnerable groups. Current vaccines require yearly reformulation due to rapid viral mutation, often resulting in reduced effectiveness. Our iGEM project aims to design a universal influenza vaccine that targets the highly conserved HA2 region of the hemagglutinin protein.
students: Feifan Hong, Kaining Wan, LI.JIANGYUE, Miao Zihao, motang, Qidong, QIN,ZIMENG, Shuxuan Chen, suqingyi, Wang Xinrou, Wangxintong, Wu Yixuan, Yitao Zhao, Ziheng Zhu

title: Wukong SmartDrive: A Micro-Biohybrid Robotic System for Precision Delivery of Engineered Bacterial Vaccines in Aquaculture
abstract: China's classical novel "Journey to the West", the project transforms his "72 transformations" of adaptability and breakthrough spirit into technical design concepts, demonstrating the deep integration of traditional wisdom and modern technology. Technically, our team successfully developed a novel vaccine delivery system responsive to specific light signals using gene editing technology. This system utilizes a biomimetic vaccine robot to achieve targeted penetration of fish immune barriers and precise activation of immune responses, thereby significantly enhancing disease resistance in fish. Meanwhile, the automated immersion inoculation equipment adopts high-efficiency, non-destructive designs to ensure high precision and scalability during inoculation, making it suitable for large-scale farming scenarios. Practice has shown that this technological system effectively reduces antibiotic usage and decreases disease outbreak frequency. The project's achievements provide innovative solutions for marine ecological protection and global food security, showcasing the potential of interdisciplinary collaboration in addressing agricultural challenges.
PIs: Yue Ma, Qiyao Wang, Menghao Cai, Pengfei Li, Shuai Tan, Xiaohong Liu, Youyuan Li, Yueling Liu
student leaders: Jiayi Xie, Yangxin Zhang, Yongkang Yang
students: Caijing Wu, ChenMingyu, Chenwei Luo, Chenxi Liu, Chenyang, Edward, Heng Li, Huimin Ye, maolin zheng, Ruhao Zhao, Su, Wanchen Song, Wenbo Li, Wenqi Wu, Xiang Yifei, Xiaoting Duan, Yanye Zhang, Yixuan Xie, Yusun Fu, ??

title: GoutBuster: Intestine-Targeted Engineered Bacteria for Purine-Urate Transport & Degradation and Hyperuricemia Prevention-Treatment System
abstract: Gout, driven by hyperuricemia, now affects about 55.8 million people worldwide and is projected to reach 95.8 million by 2050. East Asia bears a disproportionate burden, with a 175.9% increase in cases and 26.4% higher age-standardized prevalence. Current drugs targeting liver/kidney function often cause severe side effects, necessitating safer alternatives. Our project GoutBuster develops an engineered probiotic that modulates intestinal purine-urate metabolism. Biosafety is ensured by deleting the smr resistance gene and assessing gene transferability. Efficacy is enhanced through integration of a high-efficiency urate transporter (UacT) and a secretory uricase, enabling purine absorption blockade, urate transport, and degradation. Support tools include a dynamic dosing model, multilingual voice assistant, public engagement platform (Suprobiotics), and inclusive science communication formats. GoutBuster aligns with WHO goals for safe, accessible non-communicable disease treatments and offers a novel, replicable model for metabolic disease management and probiotic innovation.
PIs: YingZhou, Qiyao Wang, Pengfei Li, Youyuan Li, Yueling Liu
instructors: Runsheng Chen, Yifan Zhang, Zhen-Ping Zou
student leaders: Liaosha Ke, Xiancheng Huang, Xinye Liu, Ziqi Wang
students: Jiahao Wu, Qisen Li, Qiyue Wang, Shiyu Cheng, TianyaoDeng, Wanyue Xu, Xinwen Xu, Xinyu Hou, Yanrui Zhang, Yibei Ji, Yiyang Wang, Yujing Bi, Yujing Huang, Yushan Zhou, Yusheng Cao, Yutong Chu, Zhanghang Yu, Zhuorun Li, Zichen Gong, Zidong Zhou

title: LignoDoc: Biocatalytic Conversion of Lignin-Derived Vanillic Acid to Paracetamol
abstract: The utilization of lignin in straw remains challenging. Direct incineration not only exacerbates the climate crisis but also constitutes a waste of resources. To address this issue, we have successfully converted lignin into paracetamol while preserving its benzene ring structure. This approach helps mitigate environmental problems caused by straw burning and offers a sustainable pathway for pharmaceutical production. In the future, this project is expected to pave the way for more high-value applications of lignin, enabling the green synthesis of valuable benzene-ring-containing products.
