title: Surfing TentaRobot: A Tide-Synchronized Biofilm Platform for Heavy-Metal Remediation in Mangrove Ecosystems
abstract: Mangrove ecosystems face escalating heavy metal pollution threats. We developed "Surfing TentaRobot"--a tide-adaptive bioremediation platform using engineered Bacillus subtilis. Core innovations: (1) Self-assembling adsorption: TasA-ShMT3 fusion proteins and ?sinR-tasA ?epsA chassis achieve effective heavy metal capture. (2) Biomineralization: Dsp-aCA carbonic anhydrase catalyzes MICP, precipitating CaCO?/MgCO? to permanently sequester adsorbed metals and prevent tidal re-mobilization. (3) Osmotic NOT gate enables tidal rhythm function switching: LLM-assisted workflow identified osmotic-responsive PproHJ promoter; TetR-based NOT gate design enables functional switching between adsorption and mineralization. (4) Cross-scale modeling: Six-layer framework spans molecular docking to field deployment, including competitive assembly models explaining capacity limitations, coupling kinetics quantifying mineralization interference, UTide tidal analysis determining optimal deployment parameters, and biofilm growth models guiding operational strategies. (5) Social responsibility: 215+ surveys and educational activities reaching 600+ students integrated stakeholder feedback. This work demonstrates transforming tidal salinity fluctuations from engineering constraints into regulatory signals for coastal ecosystem remediation.
PIs: Wenbin Zhang, Jikai Wen, Zhe Hu
student leaders: Chunhao Jin, Haojun Wu, Ling Chen, Ruomeng Zhang, Yanbing Zhang, Yingan Pan
students: Fangxi Chen, JIangnan Zhu, Jiyu Ma, Linfeng Chen, Shukai Guo, Tsukuyo, Wanyu gong, Yaqi Zhang, Yiweiteng, Yuhe Lu, Yuqing Cao, Yuxuan Gong, Zefeng Li, Zhou Haoreng

title: Click. Customize. Cure. Engineering a Systematic Pipeline for Site-Specific Lipid Functionalization of Enzymes
abstract: Protein therapeutics have transformed medicine but often suffer from rapid clearance. L-asparaginase, used to treat childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia, exemplifies this limitation. Conventional PEGylation extends its half-life but can trigger hypersensitivity and disrupt catalytic sites, highlighting the need for precise alternatives. Using genetically recoded E. coli and orthogonal translation systems, we incorporated nonstandard amino acids (nsAAs) enabling copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne click chemistry for site-specific fatty-acid conjugation. To identify tolerant positions, we combined sequence conservation analysis with Golden Gate-based construction of L-asparaginase variants and experimentally evaluated catalytic activity. Several nsAA incorporation sites preserved native bioactivity. These data trained a computational ensemble integrating molecular dynamics, docking, and stability metrics to predict functional outcomes of nsAA substitutions. This pipeline links experimental and computational protein engineering, reducing screening needs and improving therapeutic stability--offering a safer, longer-lasting alternative to PEGylation for more effective leukemia treatment.
students: Alp Namalan, Audrey Tsai, Ethan Powell, Judy, Lofty, Michael Sarullo, Miya Zhao, Nicole Nguyen, Reagan Labert, Yiannis Scotiniadis

title: Cleaning Up Oil Spills With the Help of Alcanivorax borkumensis
abstract: Marine oil spills pose recurring threats to ocean ecosystems. Alcanivorax borkumensis, a halophic, hydrocarbonoclastic bacterium evolved to thrive around oil-contaminated environments, is promising for bioremediation. Its concentration increases naturally after oil spills, efficiently degrading alkanes, utilizing specialized enzymes including alkane monooxygenases, cytochrome P450s, and biosurfactant-producing pathways. We explored A. borkumensis's biofilm formation and alkane oxygenation, identifying its overall better performance over champion isolates. Through a proteomic study, we identified secreted proteins in alkane degradation's first steps, testing their degradation abilities through a biochemical NPD-hydrazine assay. We deem the flavin-binding monooxygenase AlmA promising in alkane degradation. We also focused on creating a genetic toolbox for A. borkumensis, studying conjugation and broad-host range plasmid transformation. The findings indicate the enzymes responsible for the degradation's first steps, setting the foundation to create more complex genetic toolboxes. Future implementation, more efficient oil spill cleanup, has potential to save marine life and protect coastal industries.
student leaders: Anna Huang, Anushree Thirukumaran, Elaine Zuo, Subiksha Srinivasan Vidya
students: Amogh Dattatri, Ashley Liu, Asvika Gobinathan, Ayan Agrawal, Camila Mendoza, Chris Zhuang, Erin Kang, Leonard Dong, Maximilian Shi, Riya Sivva, Ruchika Yerram, Satya Kokonda, Selena Gao

title: RE-PEAt?Recycling Ethylene glycol to PolyEsters And terephthalate to p-coumaric acid
abstract: The UESTC-China team presents RE-PEAt, a platform that closes the PET loop by integrating enzymatic depolymerization with value-added biosynthesis. We synergistically hydrolyze PET into ethylene glycol (EG) and terephthalic acid (TPA) using magnetically immobilized PETase and Tfca. Through bioinformatics and synthetic biology, we engineered E. coli to consume EG as its sole carbon source, alleviating its competitive inhibition on PET hydrolases. Downstream, RE-PEAt converts EG into biodegradable polyesteramide and upgrades TPA into high-value p-coumaric acid, creating sustainable product streams. Furthermore, a colorimetric biosensor was constructed to monitor EG concentrations in real time, providing reliable guidance for both PET hydrolysis and EG conversion. By combining reusable biocatalysts with microbial upgrading, RE-PEAt offers an integrated framework for PET upcycling--from depolymerization to material and chemical regeneration.
PIs: Kejun Deng, Hao Lin, Hao Lyu, Juan Feng, Kun yang, Lixia Tang, Xin Ma
advisors: Kehan Chen, Yan Pan, Yuning Luo
student leaders: JQF, Ruming Liu, XiaoweiLiu, Zijian Rong
students: Bariona, Liu Tianqi, Minus, Tongtong Wei, Wangyixuan, Xinran Lin, Ying Wang, Yuming GU, Zhang Yujie

title: A Single-Stranded DNA Biosensor in the Form of a Capillary Tube
abstract: The standard methods for detection of viruses in samples are expensive, time-consuming, and require access to specialized equipment. To address this problem, we aimed to design a point-of-care oligonucleotide sensor in the form of a capillary tube. This article discusses a proof-of-concept for this system as well as a modular phagemid system for us, and future iGEM teams, to safely validate viral-detection systems without the need to use pathogenic viruses.
students: Anna Zeng, Hazem, Khadeeja Abbas, Manar Bairq, Omar Amer, Preye, Rudrani Mukerji, Santiago, Ved Patel

title: Dual-Function Probiotic: Protecting Astronauts' Muscle and Mental Health
abstract: Commercial spaceflight is rapidly evolving from experimental trials to large-scale operations, with companies like SpaceX, Blue Origin, and Virgin Galactic--and China's own emerging space sector--driving down launch costs and opening the door to space tourism, lunar bases, and Mars colonization. Yet long-duration missions pose serious health risks, particularly microgravity-induced muscle loss and mood disorders. We address this challenge by engineering E. coli Nissle 1917 with a de novo HMB biosynthesis pathway to combat sarcopenia and a serotonin pathway to support mental well-being, creating a dual-function probiotic to safeguard astronaut health and enable sustainable human presence in space.
nominations: Best Village Project, High School
student leaders: Jinxuan Sun, Lingyu Wang, Qige Zheng, Zhaoyang Jiang
students: Chutong Xu, Hanqing Yang, Haozhe Ye, Hongbo Sun, Huiyuan He, Jiayi Zou, Lezhi Chen, Shiqi Xu, Sijia Ni, Siyuan Liu, Stanley Tang, Xingbo Peng, Xinyi Chen, Xinyu Pan, Xinyu Tu, Xinziyi Huang, Yucheng Zhang, Yue Zhang, Yuman Zhang, Zhitong Chen, Zijie Ai

title: PROTEUS
abstract: We have successfully developed PROTEUS--a universal AI-driven protein optimization platform based on ESM-2, employing MLM (Masked Language Modeling) for function-oriented fine-tuning. Sequences were categorized into high/low-performance groups based on metrics such as enzymatic activity and thermal stability, and a DMS scoring function was designed to build an intelligent optimization engine. This model can accurately identify key functional sites, perform targeted optimization of low-performance protein sequences (e.g., antimicrobial peptides or industrial enzyme variants), and utilize AlphaFold for structural prediction to validate design rationality. Based on this project, we have developed an open-source software tool that allows users to input a target protein sequence and obtain an optimized solution with one click, providing a universal AI-driven design platform for synthetic biology.
student leaders: Mao Du, Tong Cai, Yunfan Hu
students: Chenshiwei, Feng Shengchen, GKQ, Jia Wei, Justine, LangYanan, lsn, mym, Qiwei Zheng, Strawber, tianyu, Twx, WangKejian, WangShanEr, XuWentian, Yang Xinyi, Zhangxiaoyu, ???, ???, ???????, ??

title: Turning Bacteria into Time Fighters: Sustainable NMN Production with Synthetic Biology
abstract: Current production methods face challenges such as high costs, harsh reaction conditions, complex processes, and environmental burdens. Using synthetic biology, we redesigned E. coli by introducing the genes NiaP, nadV, PnuC, and BaPRS, enabling efficient NMN production. Considering gender differences: for men, we engineered E. coli to produce GLP-1, which is combined with NMN to make capsules; for women, we engineered E. coli to produce glutathione, developed into oral solutions and antioxidant facial masks. Through this diversified design, our solution makes it easier for people to achieve healthier and more vibrant lives.
advisors: Jinyi Chen, Wang Chong, Zhang Mengjia, Zhang Zhixin
student leaders: Chenxi Wang, Jialiang Xu, Kexin Zhou, Tengsu Wang
students: Boyuan Long, Cathy yizhi Liu, Chengzhang Cai, Chenrui Gu, Chenyu Liang, Congyu Yang, Dongxing Liu, Enzi Wu, Hongsen Xu, Huihan Cao, jasoncai, Jiuhao Lan, Qi Hou, songze wang, Wei Xing, Yachao Hu, Yiheng He, Yizhen Lyu, Yuxuan Li, Zhiyu Yao

title: Probabyotics Infant Formula: Probiotic HMOs, Digestible Casein & Lactose-Free
abstract: To address critical limitations in current infant formula--specifically the absence of immunomodulatory human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs), poor digestibility of casein micelles, and prevalent lactose intolerance--our team, Probabyotics, developed "2-FLuxe" using Escherichia coli Nissle 1917?EcN? as a probiotic chassis for integrated bioengineering. We constructed three synergistic systems: (1) a de novo 2'-fucosyllactose (2'-FL) synthesis pathway (via manB-manC-gmd-fcl-futC overexpression) to produce breastmilk-mimetic HMOs at >80% reduced cost; (2) recombinant trypsinogen expression for precise casein hydrolysis, alleviating gastrointestinal burden; and (3) high-yield ?-galactosidase (lacZ) fermentation to eliminate lactose. Manufacturing involves EcN-based fermentation with low-cost substrates (glycerol/lactose), enzymatic purification, and incorporation of 2'-FL with trypsin/?-galactosidase-treated milk. The resulting formulation eliminates key drawbacks of conventional formulas by providing 2'-FL-driven pathogen inhibition and microbiota support, enhanced protein digestibility, and lactose-free tolerance--enabling accessible, breastmilk-equivalent nutrition for infants with digestive vulnerabilities or limited breastfeeding access.

title: CerviX Spy: CRISPR-Powered Home Screening for Cervical Cancer
abstract: CerviX Spy is an innovative point-of-care testing (POCT) platform integrating CRISPR-Cas13a technology and microfluidics for early cervical cancer screening. Targeting the host-derived biomarker miR-155 - a key oncogenic miRNA upregulated in precancerous lesions--the system employs a modular toehold switch probe that undergoes conformational change upon target binding, activating a T7 promoter to transcribe sgRNA. This triggers Cas13a-mediated cis-cleavage of target RNA and collateral trans-cleavage of fluorescent reporters, enabling pM-level detection under isothermal conditions (37 ?). Validated via rigorous DBTL (Design-Build-Test-Learn) cycles, the biosensor achieves single-base specificity and pM sensitivity, overcoming limitations of traditional HPV-DNA assays (e.g., inability to distinguish transient vs. oncogenic infections). Encapsulated in the user-friendly "CerviSure Scanner" - a 3D-printed, disposable microfluidic device - the system supports decentralized, non-invasive screening with rapid results (<60 min). This platform promises to reduce healthcare disparities by enabling accessible, high-accuracy screening in low-resource settings, advancing global cervical cancer elimination efforts.
student leaders: Sunyiyang, SUYUE MENG, wujunyi, YU, LEXUAN, ???
students: chengzai, Jiangziheng, Kailang, Lyu Lu, Ryan, Shang Zichen, sunruitong, TangJinglei, WEIRAN MA, Wengxiaohhu, Yang Sen Fan, YANGZERUI, yifan huang, yixuanhuang, ZHANG ZIJIN

title: SCG Detoxification: A Solution for Transforming Waste Coffee Grounds into Biofertilizers
abstract: The spent coffee ground (SCG) holds significant potential for producing organic fertilizers. Residual caffeine, however, inhibits plant growth due to its phytotoxicity, substantially limiting the application of SCG in bio-fertilizer production. Conventional decaffeination methods suffer from high costs and environmental concerns. Here, we genetically engineered Escherichia coli (E. coli) by integrating genes involved in caffeine degradation, aiming to remove the residual caffeine from SGG during fermentation while producing valuable biofertilizers. Our project provides an eco-friendly and cost-effective solution for the recycling of SCG. The safety and scalability of the engineered E. coli ensure its broad applicability in agriculture, horticulture, and environmental protection.
nominations: Best Part Collection, High School+Best Sustainable Development Impact, High School+Best Village Project, High School

title: The Salidroside Initiative: Protecting the Plateau and Every Heartbeat with Synthetic Biology
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases increasingly threaten young populations due to stress and unhealthy habits. Salidroside, a cardioprotective compound from Rhodiola rosea, shows antioxidant and anti-hypoxic effects but is difficult to source sustainably. To solve this, we engineered Escherichia coli to biosynthesize salidroside via an optimized tyrosol pathway and heterologous expression of a UDP-glucosyltransferase (UGT). In addition, we developed a whole-cell biosensor targeting 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate (4HPP), a key intermediate in the microbial biosynthetic pathway of salidroside. By employing this sensor, we enhanced salidroside production through directed evolution. Our system provides an eco-friendly, scalable alternative to plant extraction, reducing pressure on fragile plateau ecosystems while supporting youth heart health through synthetic biology innovation.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, High School

title: CatWell: Oral Peptide Contraceptive System for Humane Feral Cat Control
abstract: As urban feral cat populations continue to grow, ecological balance, public health, and animal welfare are increasingly threatened. To address this, we designed an oral contraceptive peptide based on a sequence-modified cyclized GnRH antagonist that competitively blocks reproductive hormone signaling without affecting animal health. By optimizing peptide stability through sequence modification and disulfide ring formation, and co-administering with SNAC to enhance gastrointestinal absorption, we enable effective oral delivery. For safe and precise administration, we designed CatWell, an AI-powered smart feeder that provides controlled daily dosing to individual feral cats. Together, this integrated system offers a humane, scalable, and non-surgical solution for feral cat population control.

title: Modular attenuated vaccine development for sustainable aquaculture
abstract: Our iGEM project addresses the critical challenge of Pseudomonas plecoglossicida-induced visceral white spot disease in large yellow croaker, which causes annual industry losses exceeding ¥600 million due to high mortality rates (70-80%), while traditional antibiotic therapies exacerbate drug resistance and ecological harm. We employ an integrated computational-experimental strategy to develop a novel live attenuated vaccine. Starting with the CLEF model, we screen effector proteins, then validate candidates using engineered E. coli BL21(DE3). These virulence factors serve as vaccine targets. We also use C. elegans for preliminary toxicity and protection studies. Mathematical modeling simulates immune responses and economic impact, linking predictions with practical efficacy. Our goal is to establish an efficient antigen screening system to accelerate novel aquaculture vaccine development, offering a sustainable strategy to reduce disease prevalence and enhance productivity.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Kexin Fei, Shan Su
advisors: Qiyao Wang
student leaders: LU YUTONG, SU YUETONG, Wenbo Wu

title: SOD Shield: Novel Eye Drops Prevent Oxidative Cataracts
abstract: Cataracts, a leading cause of global blindness, primarily result from oxidative damage to lens proteins. Current treatment relies on invasive surgery. Superoxide dismutase (SOD), a key antioxidant enzyme, neutralizes reactive oxygen species but suffers from instability and rapid degradation, limiting its therapeutic potential. Manganese superoxide dismutase (Mn-SOD) is an important subtype of the SOD family. This enzyme is closely related to the occurrence and development of cataracts. Our project employs computational biology and machine learning to engineer thermostable, high-activity Mn-SOD variants. These variants will be characterized in E. coli. Furthermore, a multi-scale mathematical model will be developed to simulate the spatiotemporal efficacy of Mn-SOD when delivered as an eye drop, from catalytic kinetics to reaction-diffusion within the eye. The goal is to develop engineered Mn-SOD as a core component of novel eye drops, offering a non-invasive strategy for cataract prevention and early intervention to alleviate the global disease burden.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Leyu Xu, Shan Su
advisors: Fuyuetong, kaixu chen, Lin Li, Shuaiwenjing

title: Protective effect of ginseng on bioaccessibility and oxidative stress induced by microplastics during in-vitro digestion
abstract: This study investigated how Korean ginseng affects amine-functionalized polystyrene microplastics (MPs) using a simulated digestion model and liver cell cultures. Researchers found that ginsenosides, the active compounds in ginseng, promote the aggregation of MPs through electrostatic interactions. This clumping effect significantly reduced the bioaccessibility of the microplastics, with a 1:4 (MP:ginseng) ratio lowering it to just 6.52%. Dynamic light scattering and microscopy confirmed that a 1:2 ratio induced the greatest aggregation. Hyperspectral imaging showed a strong binding between ginsenosides and MPs. Critically, when human liver (HepG2) cells were exposed to MPs, co-treatment with ginseng significantly lowered the production of harmful reactive oxygen species (ROS). The findings suggest that ginseng can mitigate the potential harm of microplastics by decreasing their absorption in the gut and protecting hepatic cells from oxidative stress.
advisors: Dongmin
students: Ian Kim, Jaeheon, Jeongseo Kim, Stella Pyeon

title: Chitinator et al.
abstract: Chitinator et al. transforms seafood waste into growth. Chitin, the tough biopolymer found in shrimp and crab shells, is often discarded despite its vast potential. Our team engineered a powerful dual-enzyme fusion combining Endochitinase and Exochitinase through a flexible linker, enabling synergistic and continuous chitin degradation into chitooligosaccharides (COS),bioactive molecules that stimulate plant growth and immunity. Expressed in E. coli and optimized for secretion in Bacillus subtilis, our construct lays the foundation for a living bioconversion platform that upcycles chitin waste into a natural bioactivator. Applied to garlic crops, this eco-friendly solution helps combat fungal pathogens like Fusarium oxysporum and Sclerotium cepivorum, promoting sustainable yield and soil regeneration. Through synthetic biology, Chitinator et al. turns what nature discards into what agriculture needs most resilience, protection, and life.
nominations: Best Bioremediation Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
advisors: Adamantia Koulouri, Alexandros Skouris, Athanasia Arampatzi, Margarita Geranopoulou, Maria Eleni Tsatsou, Sotirios Touliopoulos

title: Colors from bacteria: production of natural dyes with synthetic biology
abstract: Synthetic dyes are widely used in the textile industry but generate toxic effluents that cause serious environmental pollution. Our project seeks to provide a sustainable alternative by engineering Escherichia coli to biosynthesize several natural pigments, carotenoids (red, orange), violaceins (ranging from green to purple), and indigo (blue). We focus on optimizing tryptophan metabolism to efficiently channel precursors toward pigment biosynthesis, ensuring higher yields and consistent production. For indigo, we are also exploring novel flavin monooxygenases with enhanced catalytic activity and stability, aiming to overcome the limitations of existing enzymes. Through a combination of metabolic pathway engineering and enzyme discovery, we aim to create a robust microbial production platform capable of replacing harmful synthetic dye processes. By demonstrating the potential of microbial biosynthesis for natural dyes in E. coli, this project highlights synthetic biology's ability to address environmental challenges and proposes an eco-friendly approach for the future of textile dyeing.
nominations: Best Measurement, High School+Best Presentation, High School+Best Wiki, High School+Best Integrated Human Practices, High School

title: APOPTO-SENSE 2.0: Engineering a Dual-Cell Biosensor for Rapid, Personalized Chemotherapy Sensitivity Testing in Cancer
abstract: Cancer treatments often fail due to individual variability, with 40-60% of patients non-responsive to standard chemotherapies for leukemia, breast cancer, and non-small cell lung cancer. APOPTO-SENSE 2.0 addresses this with a synthetic biology platform for rapid ex vivo drug sensitivity testing. Our dual-cell system uses engineered HEK293T sensor cells with an Annexin V-fused synNotch receptor to detect phosphatidylserine on apoptotic target cells (e.g., HL-60). Activation releases Gal4-VP64, driving dose-dependent TagBFP expression normalized to mCherry. Iterative DBTL cycles optimized linearity (R²=0.95) and specificity (>95%) through wet lab co-cultures and dry lab ODE simulations. Human Practices integrated clinician feedback, pivoting to ethical patient-derived cell proxies. Education reached 500+ via workshops and a synthetic receptor toolkit. This proof-of-concept enables personalized oncology, reducing ineffective treatments and extending to multiplexed cell death detection, advancing SDG 3 for equitable health.
students: Alan Tian, Cecilia Lei, DonnieZhang, Esta, Flora, George Ren, Hanson Xu, Joseph wang, Raymond Tang, Rongyi Zhu, Zackzhao

title: Efficient conversion of biomass waste with biomimetic rumen microbiota to produce volatile fatty acids
abstract: Lignocellulose is a highly promising renewable resource, but its complex structure hinders degradation. The rumen of ruminants represents a naturally efficient degradation system. This study employed rumen-mimicking microbiota to ferment corn straw in a semi-continuous reactor for volatile fatty acid (VFA) production. Results showed that after 72 hours, VFA concentration reached 8.99 g/L, with hemicellulose, cellulose, and lignin degradation rates of 54.3%, 40.2%, and 8.61%, respectively. At corn straw loading rates of 2.5%, 5.0%, and 8.0%, average VFA concentrations were 8.5, 11.1, and 13.3 g/L, respectively. Metagenomic analysis indicated that low pH and VFA accumulation were the main factors affecting microbial communities, while core genera remained stable. This study provides a theoretical basis for the resource utilization of biomass waste.
students: CHEN I KAI, Chenrui Zhang, Chloe H, Elliot cheng, Hui, Lorraine, Tina, Zhihao Huang, Zou

title: MORPHE
abstract: The Morphe project proposes a new therapeutic approach for the treatment of obesity. A non-invasive gene therapy aiming to restore leptin and insulin sensitivity. By achieving conditional silencing of HDAC6, a protein, that in patients with obesity mainly disrupts insulin and leptin metabolic pathways in the hypothalamus, we manage to reverse the underlying neuroendocrine dysfunction. The HDAC6 knockdown will be facilitated by miRE, a microRNA-mimicking shRNA molecule designed to evade immune detection, while selectively silencing HDAC6 mRNA. We will introduce miRE into AgRP neurons using lentiviral vectors through intranasal administration for permanent genomic integration. This genetic circuit incorporates a three-tiered logic system. A transcriptional AND gate and a post-transcriptional failsafe using endogenous miR-7-5p to prevent activation during normal fasting states. These engineered neurons will continuously monitor metabolic signals and autonomously activate therapeutic intervention only during metabolic dysfunction, creating a living therapeutic system capable of long-term, adaptive regulation.

title: Developing a Continuous Wearable Sepsis Biosensor with Novel Electrically Active Aptamers
abstract: Early disease detection improves outcomes and reduces costs, yet current biomarker monitoring requires periodic blood draws, limiting continuous assessment. This proposal aims to develop a wearable, aptamer-based biosensor for critical care diseases like sepsis and kidney failure. A microfluidic device connected to a venous port would continuously monitor biomarkers such as procalcitonin (PCT) and creatinine, providing real-time data to guide treatment. SA 1: Using mutagenic SELEX, we will evolve aptamers with reversible binding under physiological conditions. Aptamers will be immobilized on microfluidic channels with gold electrodes; biomarker binding triggers conformational changes detected electrically and transmitted via Bluetooth. SA 2: A biocompatible port with a semipermeable membrane will exclude blood cells while allowing biomarker flow. Sterility will be maintained using antibiotic-eluting materials, minimizing infection risk during periodic microfluidic replacement. Impact: This platform enables continuous, modular biomarker monitoring, improving patient care, accelerating interventions, and advancing wearable diagnostics in critical care.
advisors: Lindsey Shimoda, Sylvestri
students: Edison, Ethan, Jake, Josef C, Junhao Liu, Khoa Cao, Mackenzie, Michael Karpov, Parker Haskett, Preston, Ryan Yao, Sebastian Franco

title: Plant waxes: a regulatory symphony of biosynthesis pathways
abstract: Our research is based on the idea of ??synthetic biology to develop a high-efficiency and high-yield wax synthesis system. Using Nicotiana Benthamiana as a carrier, we increase the wax content in tobacco plants by modifying the wax synthesis and metabolic pathways in the plant. On the one hand, we improve the plant's own stress resistance and create new high-wax germplasm resource materials. On the other hand, we provide low-cost, green and sustainable industrial raw materials.

title: ByeFilm
abstract: ByeFilm is a synthetic biology system using engineered *E. coli* to secrete Dispersin B, Proteinase K, and DNase I, degrading biofilm polysaccharides, proteins, and eDNA to enhance antibiotic action. A ?cI857 thermal lysis switch triggers enzyme release at ?37 °C, ensuring localized activity and biosafety. This approach offers a minimally invasive treatment for prosthetic joint infections and shows potential against other biofilm-related conditions such as catheter infections, chronic wounds, and dental plaque.
students: Aaron Keith, HUI-JOU, CHEN, Johan Susilo, Sheng Hao, Yang, Shu-Yen, Kuo, YU-CHIA, YU, ???, ???

title: Development of a Non-Invasive Prenatal Detection Platform for Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa (DEB)
abstract: This project combines synthetic biology with CRISPR-Cas12a technology to create a non-invasive prenatal diagnostic platform for DEB. We designed and constructed a novel plasmid vector for the expression of the Cas12a protein, which was successfully expressed and purified in E. coli through a streamlined synthetic biology workflow. The purified Cas12a enzyme was used in conjunction with Recombinase Polymerase Amplification (RPA) to detect two high-frequency mutations in the COL7A1 gene (c.520G>A and c.6745C>T), which are major causes of DEB. By extracting cell-free fetal DNA (cfDNA) from maternal blood, we were able to amplify and analyze the target mutations. Cas12a's unique trans-cleavage activity enabled the detection of mutation-specific signals, providing high sensitivity and specificity.
advisors: Tsz Ching Lam, Xuecheng Jiang, Zachary, ZHANG YUXUAN, ZIYU WANG
student leaders: TianYu QianZhang, WANGYINAN, WU BOYANG, ZHAO LENING

title: Development of Antioxidant Formulations Based on the SOD-CAT Enzyme System
abstract: With the exacerbation of environmental pollution and UV radiation, oxidative stress has become a major contributor to skin aging. The hierarchical antioxidant system comprising superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT) operates synergistically: SOD converts superoxide anions into hydrogen peroxide, which CAT then decomposes into water and oxygen. This system demonstrates superior stability and efficiency compared to single antioxidants like vitamin C or E. In this study, recombinant SOD and CAT were produced in Escherichia coli, purified, and their activities validated. Through in vitro assays including superoxide anion and ABTS? radical scavenging, the optimal synergistic ratio of SOD to CAT was determined. The effects of temperature and pH on enzyme stability were evaluated, offering a promising strategy for developing advanced anti-aging cosmetics.
advisors: CHEN SIRUI, LANXIN CUI, Michael, Thea, Zheng Xiangyi
student leaders: CHEN JIANKAI, Li Zihan, XU FANGAN, YIRU GAI
students: CHENG YUE, CHEN LINXUAN, CHEN SHEN, CHEN XIANGYIN, FU QINGCHENG, HE SIJIA, JIN LEXIN, LIU SICHENG, LI XINRUI, LUYANG CHAI, MAO YUTIAN, PIAOJUNYU, QIYAN DING, WANG HAOYUE, WU YUCHEN, YANG WENYU, YAO CHENG, YIXIAO LI, YUJIA ZHANG

title: ARGUS-2440: Ammonium Rhizospheric Generation Using Soil Bacteria
abstract: Nitrate leaching is a major environmental and human health concern. In our bioremediation-focused project, we aim to insert the nir and nrf operons expressing multiple nitrite reductase genes into Escherichia coli DH5-Alpha and Pseudomonas putida KT2440. We aim to determine the most efficient enzymes for the process via nitrite and ammonium measurement assays, under the XylS/Pm inducible promoter. Simultaneously, we will monitor the plant growth-promoting biofilm that P. putida forms to determine any relation with the aforementioned genes and enzymes. In the dry lab, we will model the ammonium production to predict wet lab results. The model will help us tailor the modified bacterium to specific crop and soil types to optimize efficiency, minimize nitrogen loss, and predict challenges like ammonium toxicity and bacterial overgrowth. We will also build a ML model to predict soil ammonium levels, and changes in ammonium content on application of the engineered bacterium.
nominations: Best Sustainable Development Impact, Undergrad
advisors: Hassan, Suvam Saswat Das
students: Abhay, Aditey, Chandana, Devansh, GT, Jashandeep, Manya Gupta, Mihir, Mukta, Vidhi

title: POVANO: Engineering Pichia pastoris as a Circular, Nutritional Microbial Protein Platform for Sustainable Pet Food
abstract: POVANO aims to develop a circular, low-impact protein production platform by engineering the methylotrophic yeast Pichia pastoris to convert CO?-derived green methanol into high-yield, nutritionally balanced protein for pet food, addressing sustainability challenges from conventional meat- and fish-based feeds. We constructed a pGAPZ-based ovalbumin expression cassette (pGAP-?MF-OVA-6×His-tAOX1), integrated and validated its expression & secretion, and implemented heterologous expression of inositol biosynthesis enzymes (ScIPS/INO1 and EcIMP) to produce myo-inositol for pet health benefits. To improve product quality and scale-up acceptability, we used CRISPR/Cas9 to knock out pyruvate decarboxylase (PpPDC1) and suppress alcoholic volatiles. POVANO demonstrates a controllable, scalable microbial route that can be tailored for amino-acid balance and reduced land, water and greenhouse gas footprints, aligning with SDGs for responsible consumption and climate action. Next steps include yield and nutritional optimization, pilot-scale fermentation, safety/nutritional testing, and life-cycle analysis to quantify environmental impact.
advisors: Eugene, Jiayi LI, woooof
student leaders: Chengjun Jiang, Elina, Xiaoman Li, Yijia Huang, Yuesi Xu
students: Amy, Benjamin Yang, Chen Chen, Felix, Francis, Hamo Wan, Haotian Lu, Haotong Li, Jianing, Jiayang, Khloe, Lezi, Siyuan Yu, Tsz Hin Felix Hai, Wenjie Zhai, XIAOHAN WANG, Xiaoyuchen Liu, Xinglin Yu, Yueyang Xia, Zimeng Yu, Zongling

title: Protein Pre-Binding State Framework Enables Mechanistic Insights and Engineering of Robust Biocatalysts for Plastic Depolymerization
abstract: Plastic pollution has emerged as a pressing global issue, with plastics accumulating in diverse environments to disrupt ecosystems. While natural enzymes that degrade common plastic PET exist, current PET hydrolases are not optimized for efficient, economical industrial use, and many bio-based polyester alternatives still degrade very slowly in the environment. Our project addressed these challenges by integrating AI-driven strategies, physics-based computational methods, and innovative polymer chemistry. It engineered high-performance PET hydrolases, such as TurboPETase, to enhance PET depolymerization, used simulations and calculations to explore enzyme catalytic mechanisms, and developed controlled-degradable, bio-based polyesters. The goal was to create a scalable enzymatic PET recycling system, design environmentally responsive plastics, and establish a closed-loop plastic cycle, bridging synthetic biology, computational chemistry, and materials science to promote sustainable plastic solutions.
advisors: Tiffany, Xiafeng Zhang
student leaders: Kele Zhang, Xiaoyu Zhang, YUFAN DONG, Zicong Chen
students: Asteria, Bohang Gan, Charles, Chenfan Wu, Chuai Rao, Eric, Howard, Iris, Jessie, Lily, Maria, Melanie, Nathan Tianhe Tong, Nayifan Luo, Sam, Sophie, Tony, Yueyang Du, Yunhong Zhang, Zimo Jiang, ZIYU ZHONG

title: VitaPop Jelly: A Probiotic Platform for GLP-1 Delivery in Glucose Regulation
abstract: According to the International Diabetes Federation, approximately 589 million adults worldwide have diabetes, with Type 2 diabetes comprising over 90% of cases. Persistent hyperglycemia can lead to serious multi-organ complications. Current treatments require frequent administration, creating practical burdens and reducing quality of life. Our project, VitaPop Jelly, addresses this through an innovative solution: using engineered E. coli Nissle 1917 to enable continuous intestinal secretion of GLP-1 for sustained glycemic control. We optimized the GLP-1 codon usage to enhance expression and implemented a dual biocontainment system using cysteine auxotrophy and a temperature-sensitive promoter to prevent transgenic leakage. We aim to provide people with diabetes with a safer, more convenient biologic treatment option that improves both health outcomes and daily life.
student leaders: Abigail, Firefly, Ruby white, Sherrie, Steve, Yanting Peng
students: AndrewDeng, Ethan, Fiona Bai, Giselle, Haochuan Ding, Hierophant, Jennifer, Jinrun Zhan, Mouzhisan, Renelle, Ruichen Sun, Sindy He, William, Xiaomeng Luo, Xinyue Ao, Yinxi Liu, Yufei Li, Yurui Yang, ZongzanGuo

title: BioComplete: AI-Powered DNA Design Assistant
abstract: AI models are transforming biology by capturing complex patterns in DNA sequences. However, realizing their full potential requires both high-quality training data and user-friendly tools for scientists. The iGEM Registry contains the largest collection of synthetic biology parts, but inconsistent annotations and limited search functionality make it difficult to use directly for AI training or for everyday part discovery. Our project addresses these challenges by adapting a DNA foundation model, Evo2, to genetic circuit design. We develop representations that capture functional similarity between parts, enabling reliable retrieval and AI-guided part suggestions. To support this process, we developed a sequence-centric data model that provides easily accessible, findable metadata, including safety status. Our sequence editor and search engine makes the model's capabilities available to users at https://biocomplete.it/. Together, these components form a cycle: cleaner data improves the model, the model creates meaningful embeddings, and these embeddings power new tools for synthetic biology.
nominations: Best Model, Overgrad+Best Presentation, Overgrad+Best Software & AI Project, Undergrad & Overgrad
PIs: Bernhard Renard, Jakub Bartoszewicz, Melania Nowicka
students: Alexander Sohn, Alexey Hramov, Arman Beykmohammadi, Belana Zwadsich, Christian Raue, Fynn Kröger, Jannis Baum, Kilian Glase

title: NanosphinX
abstract: Our project began with bioinformatic analysis and flow cytometry experiments, which revealed that breast and pancreatic cancers frequently exhibit upregulation of both CD47 and HER2 receptors. To address this challenge, we designed a bispecific fusion protein incorporating an active antibody fragment targeting HER2 and a nanobody targeting CD47. These designed fragments, along with those retrieved from existing databases, formed a library of candidate antibody fragments. The most stable fragments with the lowest binding free energy were selected for the assembly of the active bispecific antibody, NanosphinX. Two assembly strategies were tested to link the two selected active antibody fragments into the final bispecific format. Cell viability assays demonstrated that NanosphinX exhibits cytotoxic effects against wild-type breast cancer cells and maintains strong activity even in trastuzumab-resistant cells, effectively inhibiting tumor growth. It also enhanced the cytotoxicity of gemcitabine in gemcitabine-resistant cell lines, providing a rational basis for combination therapy with gemcitabine.
advisors: ZhuoLin Liu
student leaders: MA Chi Yung, TAM In Pan
students: Bohan Liu, Dianzhe Tian, Rui Cong Wu, Xingjian, Xinyao

title: Dermalogic - Dual Plasmid Biosensor + Response System to Mitigate Inflammation
abstract: Skin inflammation, like in acne, is driven by immune signals such as nitric oxide and hydrogen peroxide, which amplify irritation and tissue damage. Our therapeutic molecule, Indole-3-acetic-acid (IAA), a plant auxin, has anti-inflammatory benefits by blocking NF-?B signaling and neutralizing reactive oxygen species. Our project is focusing on designing a dual-plasmid biosensor system built as a biological AND gate to detect these cues. The system requires two concurrent inputs: NO detection (via the NorR/PnorV? promoter to produce LuxR) and H2?O2? detection (via OxyR/PoxyS? to activate 3OC6HSL). Only when both LuxR and 3OC6HSL are present will they combine to activate the Plux? promoter, driving downstream gene expression of indole-3-acetic-acid.
students: Aarya Adusumilli, Aashni Katari, Ananya, Arnav Pallapotu, Ashwin Mantravadi, Dhyan Soni, Rayna, Samridh, Sarvajh N, Suhaas

title: PRIME-Guard: A PRoactive Immune Modulation and Evasion-blocking Platform for Virus Prevention
abstract: Our project aims to develop a CRISPRa/TetON fusion system for inducible antiviral gene activation, enabling precise control over immune and endocytic pathway upregulation in mammalian cells. By combining dCas9-VP64, rtTA, and sgRNAs within a modular delivery framework, we sought to create a tunable gene expression platform that could be rapidly activated through Doxycycline induction. Preliminary results have shown minimal to no detectable protein expression across varying Doxycycline concentrations and induction times. Moreover, the system's capacity to induce downstream gene activation via independent or co-delivered sgRNAs remains uncharacterized. Despite these challenges, our work establishes an important foundation for refining inducible CRISPRa systems and contributes valuable insights toward achieving safe, controllable antiviral gene therapy.
advisors: Chenlu XUE, Ruochen Liu, Yishan ZHOU
student leaders: Fu Jiayu, Joshua Cevey, Shaun Masigman, Yuxuan cong
students: Da XU, HuRunwen, Jiacheng Hu, Luyao Yan, Wenlong Qiu, Wt, Yixiao PAN

title: LEGO: Light-induced Expression of GLP-1 and insulin for Obesity and diabetes treatment
abstract: The global epidemics of type 2 diabetes and obesity demand innovative, long-term solutions beyond traditional invasive and single-target therapies. We developed LEGO (Light-induced Expression of GLP-1 and Insulin), an optogenetic gene therapy platform that enables precise, reversible, and non-invasive control of dual-hormone secretion. Leveraging endogenous bioluminescence or a wireless light source, LEGO regulates the co-expression of insulin and bioactive GLP-1(7-37)--a clinically validated combination for managing hyperglycemia and obesity. Activation is achieved via oral administration of a luciferase substrate or through a wearable light device, eliminating the need for repeated injections. To enable personalized treatment, we created an open-source software-hardware package that converts patient data (e.g., glucose levels, weight, meal information) into programmable light stimulation for optimized hormone release. Designed with future implantable use in mind, LEGO offers a smart, patient-friendly, and sustainable therapeutic strategy for metabolic disease management.
nominations: Best New Composite Part, High School+Best Integrated Human Practices, High School+Best Village Project, High School
advisors: Jimmy Wang, Min Zhu, Xinyang Wang
students: Amanda Ji, Doris Tao, Esther Gao, Felix Sun, Jerry Li, Jerry Liu, Jessica Ji, Mae Lu, Olivia Sun, Rule Zhong, Ryan Jiang, Thomas Wang, Tom Yao, Tracy Xie

title: The Bisphenol A Analysis Detection System
abstract: Bisphenol A (BPA) is an endocrine disruptor linked to developmental, metabolic, and reproductive risks in humans and wildlife. Lab analytics can quantify BPA accurately but are costly and inaccessible to most users. We present a low-cost detection toolkit that converts BPA binding into a visible reporter using a LexA-based yeast two-hybrid (Y2H) design. The estrogen receptor-? (ER?/ESR1) ligand-binding domain is fused to the LexA DNA-binding domain (pGilda) and the B42 activation domain (pB42AD); ligand-induced ER? dimerization juxtaposes BD and AD, activating yeast reporters. To boost sensitivity to BPA's weak agonism, we engineered mutations in the ER? LBD (residues ~519-535) by splicing-by-overlap-extension PCR and cloned variants into pGILDA (bait) and pB42AD (prey). We will evaluate wild-type and mutant ESR1 by dose-response ?-galactosidase assays with positive/negative controls and selectivity tests, as a foundation for future community kits.
students: Alicia, Chong-Gu, Georgina Peng, James, Li-Hsing Yu, Meng Tse Sung, Zoey

title: Unburdened Intimacy: A Natural Shield of Antimicrobial Peptides Against Zoonotic Bacteria
abstract: As pet companionship becomes more common, zoonotic bacterial infections are an increasing health concern. Many current antibacterial products are irritating, ineffective, or may lead to bacterial resistance, making them unsuitable for daily use. Must we choose between closeness and safety? We believe not. Using synthetic biology, we engineered E. coli to efficiently produce optimized natural antimicrobial peptides. Based on this, we developed a gentle, safe, and broad-spectrum antibacterial spray for pets. Our project aims to inhibit common zoonotic pathogens while ensuring ecological safety and user convenience--helping pet families enjoy close companionship with confidence and peace of mind.
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Leyu Xu, Yaoyao Liang
advisors: Fuyuetong, kaixu chen, Shuaiwenjing, Sun jingyang
student leaders: Deng zihan, Huiyuan Yang, Xu Yusheng
students: CAI JINGXUAN, Chu herun, Jingtian Liu, Llujielin, SANG ZIHAN, Yuxuan Lou, Yu Ziyi

title: TCsensor: Integrated Tetracycline Detection and Biosafety Control
abstract: Tetracycline antibiotics (TCs), among the most globally used antibiotics, persistently accumulate in environments (e.g., water, soil), threatening ecosystems and human health. Current detection methods face limitations in sensitivity, cost, and field applicability. We developed TCsensor, a detection platform for on-site TC monitoring. An engineered Escherichia coli (E. coli) biosensor uses a tetracycline-responsive tet promoter linked to a reporter gene, enabling visual, semi-quantitative detection directly in environmental samples. To ensure biosafety, TCsensor incorporates a robust triple-induction lysis system (temperature-sensitive, L-arabinose-inducible, and lactose-inducible), enabling precise engineered cell self-destruction upon application of specific external signals post-detection, thereby preventing environmental release. This integrated "detect-and-destroy" system offers a practical, field-deployable solution for environmental TC monitoring with minimized biosafety risks.
nominations: Safety and Security Award, High School
advisors: DAIZIQIAO, Xinjiang, Zixin Rong
student leaders: Feng Yixuan, Lexuan Zou, Li Jiayin
students: LIAN?JINRUI, WANG ZONGXI, Wu Jiayan, XIONGZIXI, Zhang Jingyao, Zijin Wang

title: Lacto-Bexo: Engineering a Lactobacillus-Derived Exosomal Protein for Sustainable Obesity Management
abstract: The global obesity crisis demands solutions that balance efficacy, safety, and access. GLP-1 agonists show strong short-term effects but face high cost, side effects, and relapse after discontinuation. Lacto-Bexo uses the gut microbiome as a metabolic health platform. Through a Design-Build-Test-Learn cycle, we identified hisF, a protein secreted in Lactobacillus rhamnosus exosomes; in vitro, hisF cut adipocyte differentiation by ~50%, likely via AMPK activation. Beyond the bench, our Human Practices and Entrepreneurship work--clinician interviews, six-language surveys, and ethical review--addressed safety perception, accessibility, and body-image stigma. The resulting concept is a probiotic, food-grade therapeutic aligned with Korea's R&D priorities in microbiome and lipid metabolism. Together, we show how synthetic biology, inclusivity, and design thinking can responsibly advance evidence-based obesity management.
students: Chloe, Doyeon, Gracia, Harin, Jaehyuk, Jaehyun, Jason, Jayden Oh, Jaykeun, Jihyuk Ryu, Jiwon Han, Joanna, Liz Uhm, Minseo, Monica, Ryan, Seoyeon Park, Sienna, Sophie, Taehoon Kim, Theo Jeon, Victoria Chang, Other, Jay Hwang

title: Light The Way To Pain-Free----Far-infrared light-regulated bacterial pain-relieving hydrogel
abstract: NETMAP-PaurTx-3 project aims to develop a light-controlled, non-addictive pain management system using engineered E. coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) expressing PaurTx-3, a sodium channel blocker, specifically at pain sites. The key innovation is the first light-controlled system for targeted pain management using engineered bacteria, integrating the NETMAP system with PaurTx-3 for precise spatiotemporal control. Experimental results show Gibson Assembly achieved 65% efficiency (vs. <10% for traditional PCR cloning), but PaurTx-3 solubility was only 15% (85% formed inclusion bodies). Hydrogel encapsulation maintained >80% bacterial viability and light-responsive expression. The critical challenge is PaurTx-3 low solubility, addressed by implementing a SUMO fusion tag. The project features multiple safety mechanisms including self-destruct systems and gene blockade, complying with FDA/EMA/WHO standards. Future work includes in vivo testing to develop a non-addictive pain management solution for cancer and burn patients.
students: Howllowxiang, Jiang Haoxuan, Li Wan Chak, Matt, Wenyi Wang, Yanqianya, YaoHa, Zhang Qiaoer

title: TERRA
abstract: We want to turn red mud, a hazardous bauxite waste, into a source of rare earth elements (REEs). Using Chlamydomonas reinhardtii engineered with a high-affinity binding protein, our algae capture lanthanides from dilute solutions with low concentrations of the precious materials. The workflow is straightforward: pre-treat the red mud, let algae accumulate REEs, ash, recover. A prototype bioreactor supports easy growth and handling. The goal: pair red-mud cleanup with low-input REE recovery that plugs into classical downstream extraction. Experts told us loud and clear: turning red-mud cleanup into a win is exciting and overdue. We have been fueling that momentum, sparking awareness and enthusiasm in the next generation of students.
nominations: Best Hardware, Overgrad
students: Maide Cebi, Max Grün, Nina Bernier, Rémi Peuscet, Ricardo Heinzmann, Ruqia Ali Hassan, Sabine Palm, Tarzis, Xiang Xiang

title: MakeSense - HEK293T cell-based hydroquinone detecting biosensor
abstract: Cosmetics reflect identity, confidence, and culture, but behind their glossy image lies a growing public-health crisis. The $900 billion industry is increasingly flooded with counterfeit products containing toxic ingredients like hydroquinone, a banned skin-lightening agent in the U.S., U.K., and EU. Despite its whitening effect, hydroquinone causes oxidative stress, cytotoxicity, ochronosis, and even cancer risk. Yet in much of Asia and Africa, it remains freely sold in unregulated "brightening" creams, exploiting beauty insecurities and endangering lives. Beyond public health, counterfeit cosmetics cause massive economic losses to legitimate brands. Existing detection methods are expensive and limited to specialized labs. To address this, we developed a HEK293T cell-based biosensor using the Nrf2-ARE pathway to sense oxidative stress and activate an EGFP reporter, producing a visible signal when exposed to hydroquinone. Our biosensor offers a low-cost, portable tool for safer cosmetics to empower consumers and protect global health.
PIs: Zhanna Utebayeva, Kudrat Ergashev, Symbat Alimbek
advisors: Alua Shertayeva, Gulzay Abdulova, Vyacheslav
student leaders: Merey Nogaibayeva, Nurlytang Meirash, Roman Ligay, Zhansaya Amangeldi

title: AMPlify
abstract: This project addresses antimicrobial resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis through the in silico design of a novel therapeutic combining lytic mycobacteriophage D29 with a computationally engineered antimicrobial peptide (AMP). Using an AI-driven pipeline, over 40 candidate peptides were generated and screened via machine learning for high antimycobacterial activity and low host toxicity. Initial targets of intracellular proteins were abandoned after molecular dynamics simulations showed poor peptide stability. The focus shifted to designing membrane-active AMPs with enhanced structural robustness. Final simulations confirmed the lead AMP's stability in solution and its ability to disrupt a model bacterial membrane. This AMP was then conceptually integrated into a donor cassette for insertion into the D29 genome. The result is a synthesis-ready, computationally validated blueprint for a therapeutic phage, with a clear plan for experimental validation in Mycobacterium smegmatis* a safe surrogate host. This work lays the foundation for a novel, precision-engineered biotherapeutic against drug-resistant tuberculosis.
students: Aadit Kumar Sahoo, Abhinav, Aditya Chauhan, Aditya kumar, Divya Kumar, HANUMA NIHAR, Hima Shashidhar, KHUSHI VERMA, Kshitij, Madhumitha R S, mofa_iitr, Piyoosh, Pragyan Parashar, Pranshu, Prisha Sinha, Rishabh, Ritesh Singh, Rohit, Sameeksha, Sreesh, Suryadeep, Vansh, Vignesh, Yash Bansal, Yash Drall

title: OdorPure: An Odor-Control Cat Litter Additive Powered by Antisense RNA
abstract: Odor control is a critical feature in the cat litter market, as ammonia produced from urea degradation is the main source of unpleasant smell. Conventional deodorization methods, such as physical adsorption or fragrance masking, carry inherent risks and limitations. To overcome these issues, we designed antisense RNA targeting bacterial urease mRNA to block urease synthesis in ureolytic bacteria, thereby suppressing ammonia release at its origin. For the first time, we developed an asRNA-chitosan-montmorillonite complex as a safe, eco-friendly, and antibacterial additive for cat litter that tackles urine odor from the source while enhancing litter performance.
nominations: Best Measurement, High School+Best Village Project, High School
PIs: Ruyi Shi, Kexin Fei, Yuqi Fu, Ziying Xu
advisors: Sihan Wang
student leaders: Chen Hening, Kelly Liu, Xu Yuqin
students: Caoyuxuan, Chen Dalin, Chenyiwen, CUI ZHANCHENG, FANG MOBAI, GUAN CHEN LI, HUANG XINYI, JIALUO FEI, Ma Lele, WANG JUNDA, XU ZHONGQI, YAO YICHEN, Zhangsiyi

title: Neurobloom: Early Interventionists for Alzheimer's Disease
abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a rapidly growing global health challenge, with limited options for early intervention. We developed Neurobloom, a synthetic-biology-based probiotic system using the safe strain E. coli Nissle 1917, featuring three integrated systems: System 1 enables continuous production of sakuranetin, reducing A? deposition and neuroinflammation through antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects; System 2 produces lysophosphatidylcholine (LPC), which supports gut-brain axis regulation, improves synaptic function, and optimizes gut microbiota balance; System 3 incorporates a safety suicide circuit, ensuring the strain deactivates under abnormal conditions to minimize ecological risks. These systems work synergistically to deliver a sustainable, low-barrier, and adherence-friendly intervention, particularly suited for early-stage patients and high-risk populations. Neurobloom introduces a promising strategy for preventive and adjunctive AD care, paving the way toward more equitable and innovative cognitive health solutions worldwide.
student leaders: Andy Wang, Beverly, Shiyun Wang, Yang Li
students: BONING, Ephriam Wu, Grace yang, hank, Jerry, Jingwen Jia, Liu Pinzhuo, Lorraine, Mark, Noah Wang, Xin Guan, Yibin Zhang, Yuetong Hua

title: NeuroSplice: Low-Cost RNA Diagnostic Tool for Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) lacks a rapid and affordable molecular screening tool, with diagnosis currently dependent on MRI and invasive CSF analysis. A key genetic risk factor involves exon-6 skipping in the interleukin-7 receptor (IL7R) gene, producing a soluble isoform (sIL7R) associated with immune activation and MS susceptibility. To address this gap, we developed NeuroSplice, a cell-free toehold-switch diagnostic platform that detects the IL7R ?6 splice junction with high specificity. In the OFF state, the switch sequesters the RBS and start codon within a hairpin structure. The binding of the cognate RNA trigger unwinds the hairpin and activates GFP translation. Using an in-silico pipeline (NUPACK, RNAstructure, BLAST) alongside iterative design-build-test-learn cycles in TXTL assays, we optimized sequence context and incorporated sfGFP to reduce background expression and achieve strong ON/OFF discrimination in 12-µL reactions. Freeze-dry compatibility makes NeuroSplice portable, offering potential for triage in resource-limited settings, longitudinal monitoring, and therapeutic response tracking.
students: Aadya, Aditya, Arjun, Azhahini Krishnamoorthy, Dean, Diya, Garv B Goswami, Harkirat Kaur Batth, Khushi Kangle, Kirsten, Krrishika Saxena, Parmis, Pinaki Pramanik, Poorvi Thairani, Prithika, Radha, Richard Kim, Sanoja, Scarlett Huang, Sharika, Shravan Balaji, Sia Jain, Sindhuja, Sophia Jiang, Sriya Yenne

title: BIOMNIGEM: An AI Assistant That Truly "Understands Biology"
abstract: We introduce BiomniGEM, a large language model (LLM) specifically designed for multi-omics data understanding and biological reasoning, which integrates three omics modalities (DNA / cell profile/protein) and explicitly embeds omics information during joint training, enabling the model to directly read and reason over biological data. Our text builds upon prior ideas of transforming single-cell profiles into "cell sentences" and complements sequence-level foundation models in genomics and proteomics. The SynBioCoT dataset spans cell profiles, DNA, and protein modalities and covers five categories of omics tasks, aiming to systematically teach both omics understanding and biological reasoning. Experimental results show that BiomniGEM consistently outperforms leading commercial and open-source models in understanding raw omics data and demonstrates superior reasoning performance, achieving the best results on our benchmark tasks.
PIs: Yonggang Zhang, Fangming Gu, Bo Yang
students: Congming Li, Cyy, Fangruyue Wang, Jiachen Gu, Liuyu Yang, Wang Zhongqi, Yizhou Wang, Yutong Jiang

title: TRACER: Targeted Relapse Assessment via Cellular Effector Response
abstract: TRACER is a tunable cell-based sensor that detects CD19 and reports only when the signal is strong. Its core is a SynNotch receptor that, upon CD19 engagement, releases a transcription factor to activate a reporter. An intracellular inhibitor binds the transcription factor and blocks promoter access until its concentration surpasses a preset buffer, creating a built-in threshold that filters weak signals. Using a design-build-test-learn loop, we optimized promoter strength, DNA ratios, and inhibitor dose. Dry-lab models predicted SynNotch cleavage, inhibitor binding, and reporter output, guiding mid-range expression for stable control. Wet-lab assays in HEK293T cells confirmed contact-dependent activation and graded suppression with increasing inhibitor copy number. Fixing SynNotch:Reporter at 1:10 lowered baseline, and titrating the EF1?-driven inhibitor shifted activation predictably. TRACER enables adjustable sensitivity without redesigning the receptor, offering a compact, modular platform for robust CD19 detection adaptable to other outputs and formats.
advisors: ANUP, Aratrika, Sayan Das, Soumik Dey
students: Akshara, Ayush Munshi, Bhanvi, Jishnu Manglam, Jitendra, Krishna Kant, Shreya Mohanty

title: Sandure
abstract: Kuwait's extreme heat, scarce rainfall, and sandy soil composition contribute to rapid water loss and reduced agricultural productivity. To address this environmental challenge, this project proposes engineering Escherichia coli ATCC 25922 to enhance soil water retention through the controlled production of extracellular polymeric substances (EPS). By co-transforming the strain with plasmids pVanCC (Amp^R) and pAcu (Kan^R), the bacteria can be designed to express EPS under specific induction conditions, such as elevated temperatures. The produced EPS would act as a natural hydrogel, improving the soil's ability to retain moisture and reduce evaporation in arid environments. When applied to Kuwaiti soil, the modified bacteria are expected to create a microenvironment that binds water and stabilizes soil particles. This theoretical approach highlights the potential of synthetic biology to provide a bio-based, sustainable solution for water conservation and agricultural resilience in Kuwait's desert ecosystems.
students: Abdulrahman AlQimlas, Faeq, Fahad, Hamed, Lara, Melanie, Sara, Wafaa, Yahia AlOmari, Yousef

title: The Project Title and Abstract will be available after the team submits the Judging Form.

title: Fleur: An Oral Delivery System for GLP-1
abstract: GLP-1 receptor agonists, such as semaglutide, stimulate insulin production while blocking glucagon release and slowing down stomach emptying. Though effective at weight management, semaglutide has several adverse gastrointestinal side effects, ranging from mild nausea and diarrhea to severe damage to the kidneys and pancreas. Semaglutide's injectable synthetic form and extended systemic half-life make it difficult for patients to access and tolerate this medication. In response, Fleur was designed as an orally delivered engineered probiotic that can express and secrete wild-type GLP-1 within the human gastrointestinal tract. By using components of the body's own gut microbiome and avoiding synthetic products, we hope to reduce systemic exposure to semaglutide and lower the risk of adverse events, while making a product that more sustainably controls T2DM symptoms and provides a comfortable and affordable alternative to injectable products.
advisors: Aydin Wells, Christopher Turlo
student leaders: Gianna, Jennifer, Lorin Aknin, Oliver Wardhana, Swindar Zhou, Ziyuan (Jessica) Zhang
